narrative:
On August 20, 2021 at 9am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin and Licensing Program Manager JoAunne Griffin arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection on the home. LPA met with Theresa Nunez, Residential Director who granted access into the home. The home was toured both inside and out. Currently residing in the facility is one client. The facility is licensed to care for six male children ages 13-17 years and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. The home is located in a residential area and was set as follows: four bedrooms; two single-occupancy and two double-occupancy, all equipped with twin beds. Bedroom doors were observed to lock from the outside, however clients are able to open from the inside. There is ample closet and adequate drawer space is available. There are three bathrooms, observed in good repair and working order, living room/dining area, kitchen, and an attached garaged which has been converted into a rec room and laundry/storage area. There is an outdoor area including basketball court that is free of obstructions. The second floor of the facility is used as a staff area and includes the therapist’s office, staff bathroom, and a storage room. The home was inspected and the following was observed: Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There are no swimming pools or bodies of water on the premises. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are inaccessible to clients. Cleaning solutions are stored in hall closet and sharp knives are stored in staff office on first floor. Clients in care are supervised and protected at all times. Four cameras were observed on the exterior of the home. Cameras view is of the front right, left, center and left rear of home. Fire escape ladder is located on second floor exterior of home. Facility has ample perishable and non-perishable food. Three refrigerators and pantry were observed in garage converting into storage area. Facility provides nutritious between meal and snacks. Menu observed posted in kitchen area. Medications are locked/accessible only to employees Continued on LIC 809C

responsible for stored medications. Psychotropic medicine is tripled locked in staff office. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Child's rights, grievance process and emergency disaster plan observed posted at entry door. Mental Health certification effective March 23, 2021 - March 22, 2022. Accreditation effective through May 31, 2025. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Clients accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Clients attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Facility reports changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Facility reports client injuries requiring medical treatment. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Current and available for review. Designation/staff assignments current. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the home. Fire extinguisher was available and last serviced September 9, 2020. There were no bars on the windows at the time of the visit. All posting requirements were met. The facility has a 2016 Ford Transit – 150XL van and Hyundai passenger vehicle to transport clients. Current automobile insurance is with Riverport Insurance Co. LPA will return at a later date to complete Annual Inspection. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with Teresa Nunez and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On August 25, 2021 at 12pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection Continuation on the home. LPA then went to the main office at 6957 N. Figueroa St. Los Angeles, CA 90042 to inspect the staff and client files. LPA met with Maria Bhattachan, Chief Compliance Officer and began my inspection of the files. LPA inspected staff file for Maggie Williams, House Supervisor hired 5-16-2011. File contained all the necessary documents which include Criminal Record Clearances, Personnel Records, Employee Actions, Child Abuse Clearances, Training, Education and medical requirements. Maggie also has a Conditional Certificate for the STRTP Administrator Certification Program. LPA inspected Client file for Takato Fortune DOB 6/10/2002. The client file had all Medical/Immunization Records available. The client had a complete and current Needs and Services Plan as well as current Mental Health and medication documentation. Staff interview was conducted with Theresa Nunez, Residential Director. The interview went very well and all questions were answered completely. LPA was unable to interview a client at this time. There were no deficiencies to report at this time.

On 06/30/2021 at 10:10AM (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to OPTIMIST VAN NUYS for the purpose to conduct Annual Required facility inspection. LPA-Gray met with facility residential Counselor who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the entire physical plant both inside and out. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) clients, ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only; as well as three (3) 18-year-old non-minor dependents. S1 states that there is no weapons or guns on the premises. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are no security bars on the windows. There is an active alarm system, which notifies staff when any doors are open. The facility is a two story STRTP in a residential neighborhood. This is a two story home with three (3) bedrooms and four (4) bathrooms, living room, dining room, 1 staff office and 1 therapy office located down (downstairs) the living room has a non-operable fireplace with a secure screen attached. Bedrooms: All bedrooms are located upstairs, and furnished with enough lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean linen, blankets, and pillows, all in good repair. Bedroom#1: Is occupied by Client#1 and Client#2; (one (1) minor and one (1) (NMD) Non-Minor dependent). It has two twin beds, adequate drawer adequate lighting, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #2 (upstairs): Is occupied by two (2) minors Client#3 and Client#4. It has two twin beds, adequate drawer adequate lighting, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #3(upstairs): Is occupied by Client#5 and Client#6; two (2) (NMD) Non-Minor dependents (. It has two twin beds, adequate drawer adequate lighting, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. There is a full-size walk-in bathroom, walk-in closet, a balcony with and fire escape. [See Confidential Names (form LIC811), dated 06/30/2021 for names] (Continued on LIC-809C)

There are four (4) Bathrooms: LPA observed one (1) staff bathroom located downstairs and three (3) full-size bathrooms upstairs; All were observed to be clean and in working order. Hot water temperatures were within safe temperatures. There is adequate linen and hygiene items. Living room: LPA observed needed repairs in the living room LPA observed several broken and missing blinds in the living rooms that need to be replaced. Kitchen and Dining area: with a six (6) chair dining table There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer; electric stove/oven with (4) burners were operable. There is an ample supply of perishable and non-perishable food in the facility. The facility ensures three nutritious meals, snacks, and special diets. Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients (stored in a locked cabinet in the dining room on locked cabinet). The weekly menu is current and posted on the refrigerator. LPA observed covered trash cans in the dining are, kitchen, bathroom and staff office. Observed deficiency: LPA observed the refrigerator had pad locks on the upper freezer door. All smoke/ carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA-Gray observed three (3) fire extinguishers throughout the facility that were operable at the time of inspection. There is locked door that leads the laundry area equip with a Washer and dryer unit, all chemicals were locked in the upper cabinet. There is locked door that leads to the garage. LPA observed a full-size pool table, exercise equipment, two (2) additional refrigerators, one (1) freezer, pantry and storage cabinets with ample nonperishable food supplies. Staff office: All client’s files and medications are stored in key locked staff office, in locked cabinets and are inaccessible to clients. All posting requirements were met and posted on the wall in the staff (regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights). LPA's reviewed the Clothing Inventory Log, Food Menu, and the Weight Log for all clients. LPA observed two (2) the First aid kits that in compliance.

The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Backyard: The front yard and portions of the back yard were free and clear of debris. Clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Clients in care are always supervised and protected. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Clients can contact Community Care Licensing or Foster Care Ombudsman office in confidence without threats or punishment. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 06/30/2021, indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3, There was deficiency observed and cited (see D page). Exit Interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left with S1

On 523/23 at 2:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an announced Office Visit in order to review component II with the Licensee. During the Pre-Licensing Inspection at the above listed facility, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted a Face-to-Face, Component 2 Meeting with the applicant, Facility Administrator Marciela Romero, . The purpose of the meeting is to discuss the Our Healing Center, Short Term Residential Theraputic Program (STRTP) application, which had been submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on April 7, 2023. The proposed facility will provide care and supervision for 6 ambulatory only children, ages 12 through 17 years old, and Non Minor Dependents (NMD) ages 18-21 years old. . LPA reviewed/discussed the children/staff forms that are required and to be maintained in the facility so that they are available for inspection. LPA informed licensee that the original Plan of Operation and Program Statement were reviewed and the following revisions will be required prior to the application being approved. The following matters were discussed: Licensing forms that need to be amended and updated (LIC401A, LIC610C, and LIC9016) LPA Wilson provided a detailed overview with feedback on the application, Program Statement and Plan of Operations. LPA Wilson also discussed revisions stated below. The following revisions have been requested: Revisions provided in detail on a separate form to Licensee: Plan of Operation B. Administrative Organization C. Facility Sketch (Continued on 809C)

(Continued from 809) D. Staff Plan F. Administrative Policies and Procedures G. Admission Determination Procedures J. Removal and/or Transfer Policies and Procedures L.Handling Money, Personal Property and Valuables N.Trauma Informed Intervention and De-Escalation Techniques Q. Continuous Quality Improvement Program Statement 1. Population to be Served 2. Emergency Disaster Response Services 3. Transportation Arrangements 4. Core Services and Supports 5. Culturally Relevant Interventions, Practices, Services and Supports Other Additional Information Required: -Nursing Services LPA Wilson provided (2) Foster Youth Bill of Rights and (2) Foster Youth Rights Handbooks and (1) Foster Youth Bill of Rights Coloring Book Should this information not be received by June 22, 2023 this application will be considered withdrawn. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Applicant.

On 5/23/23, at 12:20pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above-listed facility. Licensing staff was met by Facility Administrator, Maricela Romero. The facility is one-story home which contains three (3) bedrooms, and two (2) bathrooms. The home has a fully equipped kitchen and a spacious living room, and sun room, that can be utilized as a multipurpose room. The front yard, and backyard was observed to be secure with a cinder-block fence 5.5ft in height , free of obstructions, and neat. The facility maintains one facility vehicle, 2009 Toyota Sienna LE, that seats 8 people and insurance/registration were observed to be current. All seat belts are in working order.. There is one (1) charged fire extinguisher through the facility. (2) Carbon monoxide and (4) smoke detectors were tested and fully functioning. Detergents and cleaning supplies were observed to be locked and inaccessible to minors. Medication closet was observed to be secured and inaccessible to minors. Facility files will be maintained within the staff office. LPA observed the following during inspection: Kitchen: equipped with a stove, microwave, oven, refrigerator, plenty of cabinet space, and enough plates/cups/utensils for all clients. Trash cans are covered. Dishwashing machine is not in working order and will not be used. Dining Room: there is a dining table adjacent to the kitchen with enough seating for (6) with cabinet space. Living Room: the living room is a large open space that functions as a area for relaxation, and is attached to a sun room, with plenty of seating for 10+ people, tv, a non-functional fireplace, and access to the backyard. Hallway: The hallway has a (2) linen closets and maintains enough linen and towels for all residents. There is a working smoke detector and a carbon monoxide detector in this space. Bathrooms- there are two (2) bathrooms through the facility, each with operational plumbing and running water that meets temperature requirements. (Continued on 809C)

Bedroom #1: will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is adequate closet and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm. The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #2: will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is adequate closet and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm. The bedroom serves as a passageway to the backyard of the facility through a sliding door, which is indicated on the facility plan as an emergency exit. Bedroom #3 :will be occupied by two clients and maintain two twin beds, There is adequate closet and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm., and an attached bathroom. Garage Space- the garage has been converted to a small room that is only large enough for storage. Licensee communicates that it was converted to include the adjacent staff office to a office activity space and provided LPA with a copy of the building permit. Laundry: located in the garage area and equipped with a washer and dryer in working order, and plenty of cabinet space. Laundry detergents and cleaning supplies are kept in locked cabinet adjacent to the laundry appliances and are inaccessible to clients without supervision. This area also functions to hold locked storage space for sharps, cleaning supplies, hygiene supplies and extra linen. Backyard - there is an enclosed cinder-block fence that extends around the perimeter of the facility that meets height requirements. There is no body of water on the premises. The yard appeared clean and orderly with no hazards. Medication station- medications will be stored in a locked cabinet, in a closet in the staff office. The policy for medication administration will be posted on the inside of the door and was reviewed by LPA. Medication boxes were kept locked within the locked cabinet, with a standard key lock and Licensee agrees to obtain and utilize a lock and key for meds. Staff office- this office is located near the kitchen and has computers, desks, chairs. This space will be utilized for staff to conduct administrative duties, and where client records will be stored. LPA observed that door does lock. There is no additional bathroom designated for staff. Licensee indicates that Bathroom #1 will be used by staff and clients. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed emailed to the licensee.

On June 15, 2023 at 9:20 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson, held a TEAMS meeting with Licensee, Our Healing Center for the purpose of conducting a Component III meeting. LPA Wilson virtually met with the Representative Facility Administrator (FA). LPA Wilson reviewed/discussed the children/staff's forms that are required, and to be maintained at the Facility so they are available for inspections. LPA Wilson went over the Child's Records documents, placement appraisal information LIC603, Appraisal/Needs and Service Plan LIC625, Physician Report For Community Care Facilities LIC602, Identification and Emergency Information LIC601, Admission Agreement Guide for Residential Facilities LIC604, Personal Rights Children’s Have the Rights LIC613B, Record Of Client’s/Resident’s Safeguarded Cash Resources LIC405, Client/ Residential Personal Property and Valuables LIC621, Consent For Emergency Medical Treatment Children’s Residential Facilities LIC627B, Unusual Incident Report LIC624, Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record LIC622. LPA Wilson also reviewed/discussed the Personnel records, Health Screening Report, Facility Personnel LIC503, Personnel Record LIC501, Criminal Record Statement LIC508, Employee Rights LIC 9052, Statement Acknowledging Requirement To Report Child Abuse LIC9108, Child Abuse Central Index Check For State Licensed Facilities LIC198A, Designation Of Facility Responsibility LIC308, Personnel Report LIC500, Criminal Record Exemption Transfer Request LIC9188, Criminal Background Clearance Transfer Request LIC9182, Applicant/Licensee Rights LIC9058, Appeal Procedures For Applicants/Licensee LIC9058, and provided the relevant regulatory reference as questions arose. Facility representative was informed that the license can be obtained within 90 days. Note: Should additional/revised documents be requested, a revised Program Statement will be submitted to LPA-Christine Wilson within a week of the request. Orientation/Application Process Certificate of Completion was signed by licensee, and sent a copy sent to LPA Wilson. A copy of this report was sent to the representative following today's meeting.

On 03/25/24 at 10:55 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Facility Administrator (FA) Maricela Romero Rodriguez who granted access to the facility and provided a tour. This is a three bedroom, two bathroom home is a residential location. LPA and LPM observed the following: Entry contained postings such as personal rights, facility sketch and disaster plan and closet where non-chemical supplies are stored. Hallway contains an empty linen cabinet, thermostat with temperature no more than 80 degrees, cabinet for accessible first aid and first bathroom. Bathroom #1 contains functional toilet, sink and tub/shower combo with additional storage. Bedroom #1 rooms C5 and C2. It is equipped two twin beds, two dressers and closet. Bedroom#2 is the master bedroom and rooms C1 and C4. It is equipped with one twin and one full bed, two dressers and an ensuite bathroom with functioning toilet, sink and stand alone shower. Bedroom #3 rooms C3 and C6. It is equipped with two twin beds, two dressers and closet. It has an exterior exit. Living room is equipped with a TV, two coffee tables and adequate seating for clients. There is a bookshelf with client activities. Activity Room contains two couches, bookshelf, TV and game console. Clients use this room to take private calls or play games. There is an exterior exit. Kitchen/Dining is equipped with adequate dishes for client use, functional appliances. Fridge contains perishables for up to two days, operating at temperature no greater than 40 degrees and 0 degrees in the freezer. Menu is posted with alternative options. Pantry contained non-perishables for up to a week. There are snacks available for in between meals and adequate seating for meal times. (Continue on LIC809-C)

Exterior contains three locked storage sheds, outdoor trash cans, recycling and compost bins. There are seating and gazebo for client leisure. The are two company vehicles used for transporting clients. Vehicle insurance and registration are current and vehicles are operating in safe conditions. Staff Office contains seating, secured medicine cabinet, and additional storage room. Storage room is equipped with washer and dryer, staff only fridge, locked cleaning supply cabinet with chemicals. There is a first aid kit equipped with required dressings including but not limited to bandages, tweezers, scissors, and thermometer. There is a secured hygiene cabinet, secured cabinet where sharps and batteries are kept. There are two locked storage cabinets for clients. Staff and client files are secured in a cabinet. There is a half garage storage that is accessible from the exterior that extra clothes, shoes and activities are stored. In addition, LPA observed disaster plan, monthly emergency drill log and medication log. LPA and LPM observed a non-operational camera in the front-left corner of the house. Due to time constraints LPA will return to complete file review. No deficiencies will be cited at this time An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed with facility administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 10/15/2024 at 2:00pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced inspection to Our healing Center for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the findings. LPA spoke with Facility Administrator, Maricela Romero and together, discussed the investigative finding. During the investigative process by Licensing program Analyst (LPA), Jhane Haynes,all relevant parties have been accounted for. During the investigation LPA Haynes interviewed and accounted for all relevant parties. Based on interviews conducted, Interviews reflect youth struggles with hygiene due to developmental disability that is being addressed in weekly goals. Program provides incentives when prompted to complete hygiene. Youth was observed to meet basic hygiene. LPA Haynes did not obtained statements to corroborate the above allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview was conducted, and due to technical difficulties with the printer, a copy of this report will be emailed.

narrative: Confidential interviews and documentary evidence revealed several youths at Our Healing Center engage in the use of drugs and alcohol while at the facility. Corroborating statements found the facility has had issues with youth using drugs and alcohol while in care, including marijuana, vaping and on July 7, 2024, facility reported a medical emergency as youth was reported to have overdosed on fentanyl. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence further revealed acknowledgement that a former youth resident engaged in sexual interactions with one or more youth residents while in care. Documentary evidence reveals between May 2024 and July 2024, a former resident engaged in sexual interactions with another resident. On an isolated incident, the youth was allegedly sexually assaulted by another resident while in care. Statements also revealed some residents felt uncomfortable by the former resident’s sexual advances towards them. Information obtained indicates the facility Administrator promptly addressed the situation and reported the concerns to mitigate the issues upon discovery. Based on the information obtained during the investigation, claims alleging drug activity and sexual interactions on facility premises is Substantiated. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 5, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, 87065.2 Personnel Duties. Exit interview conducted. Appeal Rights issued.
investigation_findings: 13On January 28, 2025, at 3:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at OUR HEALING CENTER Facility and met with Administrator, Maricela Romero Rodriguez, to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. On July 16, 2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging drug activity and an alleged sexual assault occurring on facility premises. It was reported that since January 1, 2024, local law enforcement has responded to Our Healing Center facility multiple times indicating that on at least four occasions, staff reported they were unable to control their clients. The reported allegations were referred to CCLD Investigations Branch assigned to Investigator, Dennis Douglas. On July 23, 2024, LPA Regina Martin conducted the initial complaint notification, met with Administrator, and obtained requested documents. The investigation further included review of client files, incident reports and review of facility file history as well as, review of Santa Barbara County Sheriff’s incident reports. In addition, confidential interviews were conducted with six youth residents, five staff members, Administrator, and contacts with the Santa Barbara Sheriff’s Department (Continued on page 9099-C)

deficiencies.description: Personnel Duties Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews and documentary evidence corroborate that youth engage in drug activity (marijuana, vaping, alcohol, and fentanyl) while at the facility and youth engaged in sexual activities including an alleged sexual assault occurring while under the care and supervision of facility staff. This poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Please submit a written plan of correction outlining specifics to ensure compliance by 1/31/2025. Please include copy of training and list of attendance. (if applicable). Please email to POC to LPA Regina Martin at regina.martin@dss.ca.gov

investigation_findings: 13On 11/7/2024 at 1:15pm, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced inspection to Our Healing Center to conclude the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the findings. LPM spoke with Facility Administrator Maricela Romero and discussed the investigative findings together. During the investigation LPA Haynes interviewed and accounted for all relevant parties. Based on the interviews conducted, the facility maintains continuous oversight of the youth under its care. The staff closely monitors the individuals to ensure their safety and well-being when leaving the facility. Additionally, due to the specific behavioral needs exhibited by some of the youth, the facility has even proposed implementing one-on-one supervision for those individuals. This approach aims to provide tailored support and address their unique challenges more effectively. LPA Haynes did not obtained statements to corroborate the above allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview was conducted, and due to technical difficulties with the printer, a copy of this report will be emailed.

narrative:
On 12/18/24, at 10:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell conducted an unannounced Annual inspection at the above-listed facility. LPA was met by Facility Administrator, Maricela Romero Rodriguez. The facility is one-story home which contains three (3) bedrooms, and two (2) bathrooms. The home has a fully equipped kitchen and a spacious living room, and sun room, that is utilized as a multipurpose room and individual therapy room. The facility maintains two facility vehicles, a 2009 Toyota Sienna LE, that seats 8 people and a 2013 Toyota Corolla that seats 5, All insurance/registration were observed to be current. There is one (1) charged fire extinguisher, (2) carbon monoxide detectors, and functional smoke detectors throughout the facility. All detectors and alarms were tested and fully functioning during the time of inspection. Detergents and cleaning supplies were observed to be locked and inaccessible to minors within the staff office. Sharps are stored within a locked cabinet within the staff office and inaccessible to minors. Medication closet was observed to be secured and inaccessible to minors. Facility files are maintained within the staff office. LPA observed the following during inspection: Kitchen: equipped with a stove, microwave, oven, refrigerator, plenty of cabinet space, and enough plates/cups/utensils for all clients. Trash cans are covered. Dishwashing machine is not in working order and will not be used. Dining Room: there is a dining table adjacent to the kitchen with enough seating for (6) with cabinet space that store non-perishables, and breakfast food. Living Room: the living room is a large open space that functions as a area for relaxation, and is attached to a sun room, with plenty of seating for 10+ people, tv, a non-functional fireplace, and access to the backyard.The living room rug showed stains a licensee reports that the rug is scheduled for replacement. Hallway: The hallway has a (2) linen closets and maintains enough linen and towels for all residents. Extra clothes and shoes are kept for client needs. There is a working smoke detector and a carbon monoxide detector in this space. Bathrooms- there are two (2) bathrooms through the facility, each with operational plumbing and running water that meets temperature requirements. LPA observed dust and debris in the bathrooms, and licensee reports that she will instruct the staff to clean the bathroom more frequently. (Continued on 809C)

Bedroom #1:occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is adequate closet and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm. The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #2: occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is adequate closet and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm. The bedroom serves as a passageway to the backyard of the facility through a sliding door, which is indicated on the facility plan as an emergency exit. Bedroom #3 :occupied by two clients and maintains two twin beds. There is adequate closet space and (2) drawers. There is a functioning smoke alarm, and an attached bathroom. Garage Space- the garage has been converted to a small room that is only large enough for storage. Laundry: located in the garage area and equipped with a washer and dryer in working order, and plenty of cabinet space. Laundry detergents and cleaning supplies are locked and inaccesible to clients. This area also holds locked cabinets that have staff and client files. There is a small refrigerator for client meds if needed. Backyard - There is no body of water on the premises. The yard presented with trash debris strewn on ground around yard, dusty lawn furniture, cardboard boxes, and an old dresser drawer that is intended for trash. The licensee communicated that trash is scheduled to be thrown out and staff will be directed to maintain cleanliness on a more frequent basis. Medication station- medications will be stored in a locked cabinet, in a closet in the staff office. Medication boxes were kept locked within the locked cabinet. During the inspection, LPA reviewed medication records for C1 and C2 and noted multiple documentation errors along with missing medications for C1 and C2. Licensee observed documentation errors and agreed that medication is being incorrectly logged. She communicated that she will work with her nurse to ensure medication logs are maintained. Staff office- this office is located near the kitchen and has computers, desks, chairs. This space will be utilized for staff to conduct administrative duties, and where client records will be stored. LPA observed that door does lock. There is no additional bathroom designated for staff. Licensee indicates that Bathroom #1 will be used by staff and clients. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, there are two deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the licensee.

On June 17, 2025 at 9:45 AM Licensing Program Analysts LPA, Kenrick Ellis made an announced visit to Our Healing Center STRTP to conduct the Psychotropic Case Management Medication Inspection. LPA conducted a Health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Kenrick Ellis met with the Administrator, Mariecela Rodriguez and conducted a brief walk through of the physical plant inside and out. LPA reviewed 3 client files and conducted 2 client interviews at the facility. One client declined to be interviewed. One client has been at the facility for less than one month. One client does not take psychotropic medications. One client is a non- minor dependent. LPA reviewed three staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA interviewed two staff members. LPA reviewed the LIC 500 to confirm the shift which starts in the evening and ends early morning and reviewed the staff Criminal Records Clearances. The Administrator provided a physical hard copy of the psychotropic medication training topics during the training for LPA’s to review. No deficiencies were cited per Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP Version 5. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 5/16/25, at 1045 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the findings. LPA spoke with Facility Adminstrator, Marcela Romero Rodriguez and together, discussed the investigative findings. During the investigative process by Licensing program Analyst (LPA), Nestor Gomez, all relevant parties have been accounted for except LPA could not get in contact with C1. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occu, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to FA.

narrative:
At 2PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Madi Fremont and AmyLe Tran met with the home above over Zoom for the purpose of conducting an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection regarding the facility's recently approved application to transition from a Group Home to a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Administrator Crystal Campbell, who helped facilitate this inspection. The home is currently licensed to care for 6 ambulatory clients aged 6-17. The current census is 5. The requested capacity is 6. LPAs toured the facility inside and out, inspecting the facility grounds and physical plant. The home is a 1 story house with 3 bedrooms - 0 single-occupancy and 3 double-occupancy. The home also has 2 full bathrooms. LPAs started the house tour in the front yard, which was observed to be in good condition and free of obstacles, with the facility van parked in front of the house. Ms. Campbell took LPAs to the front door, where COVID-19 visitor policy signs were posted. Both the front door and screen door were self-latching with a deadbolt. Inside the front door, there was a hand sanitizing station and a visitor sign-in sheet where all visitors record their temperature. Posted next to the front door were client personal rights, client grievance policies, house rules, and activity schedule. The facility License was posted prominently in the living room. There is a fire alarm that rings through the whole house next to the front door. The fireplace in the living room has a gate up in front of it. Next, LPAs toured the kitchen, which was free of dirty dishes or food debris. There was a handwashing sign posted above the kitchen sink, and sharps are kept locked away from client access. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Cleaning supplies are kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen, and all staff have a key. The facility first aid kit is also kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen, and was fully stocked with bandages, thermometer, antibacterial ointment, tweezers, gauze, and gloves. LPA Fremont inquired about the expiration dates of the ointments in the first aid kit, and all were within their expiration date. Next, LPAs inspected the freezer and refrigerator. The freezer temperature was 0°F and the refrigerator was 36°F. LPAs observed at least 2 days of perishable food and at least 7 days of nonperishable foods. Dry foods, cereals, and snacks are kept in the cabinets, and there were two large fruit bowls stocked with apples on the kitchen counter. Clients may access the refrigerator and freezer whenever they like. The weekly menu was posted on the kitchen wall, as well as the chore chart and schedule, laundry chart and schedule, emergency disaster plans, school schedules, first aid information, and floor plan with emergency exit plan. Next, LPAs toured the bedrooms and bathrooms. All three bedrooms were furnished with two beds, two dressers, two desks, a couch, and ample closet space divided in sections for each client. Locks on bedroom windows were functional. All furnishings were in good repair with no damage. The thermostat was observed on the wall in the hallway outside of bedroom 1, and the room temperature was set to 73°F. There was also a smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector in the hallway, both of which were tested and in working order. Emergency exit plans and floor plan were also posted in the hallway. Both client bathrooms were clean, well-furnished, and had plenty of drawers and cabinet space for clients to store hygiene and toileting products. LPAs were shown through a door to the screened porch, and then another door to the backyard. LPAs toured the backyard next, which was free of debris or obstacles, and was surrounded on all sides by a retaining fence. There was a sitting area set up in the corner of the backyard, and a detached unit that serves as the laundry room and staff offices. The backyard does not have any open bodies of water. Inside the laundry room were the washer, dryer, and laundry detergents. Medications are kept in a locked cabinet in the screened porch, and each client taking prescribed medications had a Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) and a Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Record for each prescription. All staff have a key to the medications cabinet. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Fire extinguishers were observed in the living room next to the fireplace and in the kitchen. Both were inspected by the Fire Marshall in September 2020, and were within their expiration dates. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were observed in the client bedrooms, the hallway, and the kitchen - all were in working order. The home does not have any security alarms or security cameras, and all window and door locks were in working order. There was a second refrigerator and freezer in the detached laundry room, and LPA Fremont advised the licensee to label all raw meat products in the freezer with expiration dates. At 3:13PM, LPA Fremont received the following water temperatures from Administrator Campbell: -Bathroom 1 shower: 108°F -Bathroom 1 faucet: 108°F -Bathroom 2 faucet and shower: 106°F -Kitchen sink: 110°F This concluded the pre-licensing inspection. LPA Fremont informed Administrator Crystal Campbell that her facility had passed the pre-licensing inspection, and that there would be communication in the next few days about licensure. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Crystal Campbell with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

At 2:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met virtually with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Regional Office-initiated office meeting with the licensee. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss possible extension of Our Safe Haven's Provisional License (expiring 10/30/2021) pending the home's Mental Health Plan Approval by the home's host county. LPA met with Licensee/Administrator Crystal Campbell, who helped facilitate this meeting. Also in attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) representative Patricia Coyle. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. During this meeting, attendees discussed barriers to the final facility survey and approval of Our Safe Haven's Mental Health Plan by Alameda County, which the county has stated is due to the unprecedented high volume of regularly scheduled and pandemic-deferred surveys that have taken precedence. Licensee Campbell has been in continual contact with the county, submitting required documentation and coordinating scheduling the final site certification visit. According to Licensee Campbell, the county has communicated that submitted documentation is under review, and the licensee should be contacted before the end of next week regarding scheduling the final walkthrough. Attendees also discussed ways to speed along this process, and discussed extending Our Safe Haven's Provisional License for an additional 6 months to allow for the approval process to be completed. Attendees requested the Licensee Campbell submit documentation of correspondence with Alameda County Mental Health to support the decision to extend the provisional license date. The facility shall submit a written request for extension of their provisional license, to include steps already taken for approval, and barriers to approval of their mental health plan. To be turned in by 5PM on Wednesday, 09/29/2021. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee Crystal Campbell, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. **See facility file for signed copy**

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced annual inspection at Our Safehaven Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility. LPA met with Crystal Campbell Administrator. The facility is licensed for 6 residents (all can be ambulatory) ages 12-18 and currently 3 clients reside in facility. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms (3 double occupancy rooms for clients) and 2 bathrooms. House is one level and cottage in the back that consists of two offices, conference room, therapeutic area for clients and a place where staff hold group meetings. No more than two clients to a room. At 12:00 PM, LPA Rollins and Administrator toured the facility inside and out. The kitchen is clean. The hot water in the bathroom and kitchen measured at 107.7 degrees F which is currently between 105 - 120 degrees. The facility has plenty of nonperishable and perishable food supply. Medication, cleaning supplies and knives are locked away. Medication logs are up to date and current. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are update and working. The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. There are no bodies of water on the property. LPA observed first aid kit to be fully stocked. The home is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted and in clear view. At 12:45 PM, LPA Rollins reviewed 3 client files with Administrator. LPA Rollins observed all three client files to be complete and found no deficiencies. The documentation in the clients file are complete and up to date.

At 2:00 PM, LPA observed all ten staff files with Administrator. LPA observed all ten staff files to be complete, all correct documentation and all staff were up to date with there 40 hours of annual training for the year. At 3:00 PM LPA Rollins conducted staff and client interviews. During inspection, LPA receive a updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on December 21, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the program has DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

On Monday 3/14/22 at 3:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver notification of a citation related to an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Facility Manager Jessica Reyes and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, mask-wearing, and hand-hygiene. During investigation, LPA learned that there was an incident in which resident R1 (See LIC 811, dated 3/14/22) became upset by something that staff S1 stated after possibly misunderstanding what S1 said. The incident escalated, and R1 threw apples at S1. During the incident, S2 was holding R1 back to avoid an escalated altercation, and S1 was heard by S2 and S3 over the phone stating S1 did not care about the job and asking S2 to let go of R1 to see if R1 would fight. Prior to this incident, there had been another incident between S1 and R1, and a supervision plan was put in place, which involved two staff being present so as to allow S1 to avoid all communication with R1 to not aggravate R1. However, during the incident, the second staff S2 was in the administrative office and the facility manager had left for a short while (approximately 20 minutes), which was long enough for an incident to occur. S2 intervened and notified Facility Manager by phone, who made their way back to the facility. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065 Personnel Requirements. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Jessica Reyes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection with Our SafeHaven and spoke with Crystal Landa, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on why incident reports not being submitted on time for 2021 and 2022. LPA Ng reviewed incident reports that have been sent in by the listed facility and found 14 IR’s submitted to CCL for 2021-2022. When reviewing documents for a complaint (complaint # 14-CR-20211230121455), LPA Ng found that 5 incident reports for 2021 have never been submitted to CCL. When LPA Ng was reviewing monthly temporary stay report for a different facility, LPA Ng recognized a few client’s names that are residing at Our Safehaven. In the report, it says that C1 (Please refer to LIC811) AWOLed nine times in February and March. Also during an attempted visit to C1’s school, LPA noticed that C2 was not at school. LPA called S1 (Please refer to LIC811) to see if C2 was at the facility. S1 said no and LPA Ng told S1 to submit an incident report within the required time frame. LPA asked the administrator why none these incidents were reported to CCL and Administrator stated she was unaware of not sending incident reports. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and sent to Crystal Landa, Administrator.

The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. There is one citation, per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072 Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Facility Manager Jessica Reyes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on the LPAs' observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Facility Manager Jessica Reyes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 3/14/22 at 2:50PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Facility Manager Jessica Reyes and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, mask-wearing, and hand hygiene. During investigation, LPAs Mariah Hawkins and Christopher Rollins inspected facility, personnel and resident records and conducted confidential interviews with administrator and all staff and residents involved in the incident at the center of the complaint. Based on interviews and record review, resident R1 (See LIC 811, dated 3/14/22) became upset by something that staff S1 stated after possibly misunderstanding what was said. The incident escalated, and R1 threw apples at S1. During the incident, S2 was holding R1 back to avoid an escalated altercation, and S1 was heard by S2 and S3 over the phone stating S1 did not care about the job and asking S2 to let go of R1 to see if R1 would fight.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights
(c)(11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from... intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review, the licensee did not ensure personal rights were accorded to resident due to staff S1 (See LIC 811) making inappropriate intimidating/threatening statements to resident R1.  This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
S1 is currently out on unpaid leave with no set return date at this time. R1 is no longer in care.
Licensee agrees to have S1 sign the infraction notices; and to have all staff attend a 2hr de-escalation training that covers verbal redirection, inappropriate language and tone, and supervision requirements (including a... ...facility manager always being present when residents present at facility, and present vs nearby supervision).  The signed forms and the training material, sign-in sheet, and post-training quizes for all staff listed on the current LIC 500 will be sent to LPA by email/fax by due date of 3/31/22.

narrative:
On 8/08/22 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Alyssa Ng and George Karkazis made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility and met with Crystal Landa, Administrator. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 5 clients. During this inspection, 4 clients and 3 staff were present in the home. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied and has three double occupancy bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured degrees 120 F. The thermostat measured 71 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. Extra linens are located in a locked closet in a bedroom. The weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. LPA's observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA Ng interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. All three clients declined. LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is inaccessible to clients.

All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was did have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR). All medications were consistent with these records. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance, with only the following exception: LPA Ng reviewed client records and saw that each client's needs and service plans and consent forms are not up to date. Administrator Crystal Landa advised that the therapist Constance Oliver has the updated needs and service plans and has the day off. Administrator told LPA Ng that she can send in the updated needs and services plan and consent form by 8/9/22 by 4:59 PM At this time, two technical violation and 0 deficiencies was cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Crystal Landa, Administrator .

13On 1/25/23 and 11:34 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Carole Blanchard, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During investigation, interviews were conducted, and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that staf verbally abused client in care. Based on LPA’s interview with staff, client, and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation, Staff verbally abused client in care is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80072(a)(1) Personal Rights. Please refer to attached 9099D. deficiencies.description:
80072 (a)(1) Personal Rights: (a)Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff..
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, staff verbally abused client in care, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC: Licensee will hold a training in regard to trauma-informed care, client engagement, and other similar topics. Licensee will send proof of training with a sign in sheet and topics that were discussed to LPA by due date.

narrative: On 2/22/23 at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management deficiencies inspection with Our SafeHaven and spoke with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. LPA Ng discussed safety plans to ensure proper supervision and making sure the facility is meeting the needs for all clients. On 1/25/23, LPA did a facility walk through when opening complaint # 14-CR-20230119093202. During the facility walk through, LPA noticed the window screen for bedroom 1 on the floor. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80088 (b) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. Please refer to attached 809D. At this time, one deficiency was cited. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager.

deficiencies.title: Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies
deficiencies.description: (b): (b)	All window screens shall be in good repair and be free of insects, dirt and other debris.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/22/23 at 1:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, interviews were conducted, and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that minors engaged in inappropriate behavior while in care and had access to alcohol. Based on LPA’s interview with staff, clients, and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation, Minors engaged in inappropriate behavior while in care and minors had access to alcohol is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. No citations were given due to facility following their emergency intervention protocol and having a safety plan set in place. At this time, no deficiencies was given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager.

narrative: On 06/23/2023 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a visit to Our Safe Haven. LPA Ng was informed that an 16 year old client of the facility has passed away. LPA met with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. Facility got the notification of the client's passing yesterday at 3:30 PM from the county social worker. county social worker and the facility is unaware of the cause of death at this moment. LPA Ng collected client social worker contact information, copies of the incident reports, the client's treatment plan, needs and service plans for client, and any other information regarding the client. LPA also discussed with Facility Manager what steps the facility is taking to help staff and youth process the incident. The facility will continue to provide grief counseling to clients and staff. Facility has also provided extra support to clients by utilizing therapeutic services, etc. Facility will schedule a time to debrief and discuss the next steps for the staff, and more resources being provided to the clients. The facility will work with the county social worker to coordinate a meeting with facility to collect their belongings. LPA conducted an exit interview with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. Facility will provide updates on what was discussed during the debriefing meeting and when the county social worker collects the client's belongings.

On 8/17/23 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection with Our SafeHaven and spoke with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. LPA Ng discussed the incident that occurred on 6/22/23. After investigating the incident, CCL found that facility staff did not follow policies and procedures in notifying the Alameda County Sheriff’s Department when C1 returned to the facility on 06/16/2023. Facility staff did not report C1's AWOL when C1 left on 06/21/2023 since law enforcement was never notified of C1’s return on 06/16/2023. Facility Manager stated that after the incident, the facility held a meeting in regards to reporting requirements. Facility will implement a plan in place to ensure that law enforcement gets notified when a client comes back from AWOL. Regardless of how long a client comes back, a call will be placed to law enforcement. Supervisor and social worker will be notified and the call will be noted in the staff shift notes. No deficiencies were cited today. A copy of this report was given to Facility Manager Jessica Reyes.

investigation_findings: 13On 9/11/23 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA Ng reviewed documents and conducted interviews with clients and staff. Based on the interviews, it was not confirmed whether or not facility staff forced youth in care to take drugs. In addition to the confidential interviews, LPA also reviewed medical records and found no evidence of staff handing that youths' medication nor the youth being on medication. Although, the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that facility staff forced youth to take drugs. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report will be emailed to Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager.

On 3/25/2024 at 10:20 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno and LPA Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted a case management visit. LPA Cardeno and LPA Singh-Sood met with Facility Manager, Jessica Reyes, and Facility Administrator, Carole Blanchard who facilitated a walk-through of the facility. During the course of the investigation, there were 3 staff and 2 clients in the facility. LPA Cardeno and LPA Singh-Sood toured the facility and observed that there was not an adequate amount of food. Additionally, the refrigerator contained expired deli meat that was dated with an expiration date of 12/2023. LPA Cardeno and LPA Singh-Sood took photo evidence of the food deficiency including the expired meat package, the food inside of the refrigerator, and a picture of the menu. LPA is issuing a citation of 80076(a)(1) under Title 22 regulations for Food Services. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was given to Facility Administrator, Carole Blanchard, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.description: In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply: All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients [..] and served in a safe and healthful manner. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During the walk-through, LPAs observed expired deli meat in the refrigerator that had an expiration date of 12/2023. In addition, LPAs observed the refrigerator to be lacking the appropriate quantity of food. LPA took photo evidence of the deficiency. This is an immediate health and safety risk.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to ensure that the facility will have adequate perishable and non-perishable food supply. In addition, the refrigerator will not contain expired food and all food is to have proper labeling. Licensee will submit photo evidence of the refrigerator to show adequate food supply to LPA by due date of 3/26/2024.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela made an unannounced case management inspection at the above agency on 06/18/2024 at 12:50 PM. LPA Valenzuela met with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager who assisted with the inspection. LPA Valenzuela conducted a walk through of the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an interview with a current youth. Youth was not home at the time. Attempted interview was conducted. Exit interview was conducted with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. A copy of the report was printed, and left with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager whose signature on this form confirms receipt. Report will also be emailed to facility email address.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela made an unannounced case management inspection at the above agency on 06/25/2024 at 11:50 AM. LPA Valenzuela met with Ashley Leite, Direct Care Staff who assisted with the inspection. LPA Valenzuela conducted a walk through of the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an interview with a current youth. Interview was conducted with youth. Exit interview was conducted with Jessica Reyes, Facility Manager. investigation_findings: 13On 08/15/2024 at 11:49 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno made an unannounced visit to Facility Our Safehaven. The purpose of this visit was to inform the facility representative of the findings for the allegations listed above. LPA met with Facility Manager, Jessica Reyes, who assisted with the inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, record review, and walkthroughs of the facility. Based on confidential interviews, record review, and observations the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. LPA concluded that the allegations, “Staff are retaliating against a minor," "Staff are not providing a minor privacy," and "Staff do not prevent a minor from being mistreated while in care," are

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(1) Personal Rights:
The licensee shall ensure that each child, [..] is accorded the personal rights [..] as applicable: To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. [..]
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and observations, LPA observed a client in care being retaliated against by staff. This poses as a potential Health, Safety, and Personal RIghts risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility Our Safehaven will submit trauma-informed care training and will gather information and provide support for the client in care being in communication with the team and county worker. Our Safehaven will provide documentation of proof of comlpletion by September 13, 2024.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(10) Personal Rights:The licensee shall ensure that each child, [..] is accorded the personal rights, [..] as applicable: To be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. 
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and observations, LPA observed a client in care having an unreasonable search of personal belongings. This poses as a potential Health, Safety, and Personal RIghts risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility Our Safehaven will have staff meetings to have a discussion and agreement regarding the procedures of searches. Our Safehaven will provide documentation and meeting notes by September 13, 2024.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(15) Personal Rights:
The licensee shall ensure that each child, [..] is accorded the personal rights, [..] as applicable: To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and observations, LPA observed staff do not prevent a minor from being mistreated while in care. This poses as a potential Health, Safety, and Personal RIghts risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility Our Safehaven will have a discussion and a team meeting with staff. The staff will come up with a plan for the client's needs and how to provide better care for the client. Documentation will be submitted to LPA by September 13, 2024.

narrative: On 12/18/24 at 12:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility and met with Carole Blanchard, Administrator. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 4 clients. During this inspection, 4 clients and 3 staff were present in the home. LPA Medina toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied and has three double occupancy bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured at 120 degrees. The thermostat measured at 73 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. Extra linens are located in a locked closet in a bedroom. The weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. LPA observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. LPA Medina reviewed both client and staff files during the inspection. It was noted that one of the client files was missing documentation of a TB test. Additionally, LPA Medina discussed with the administrator the implementation of a shared room agreement document. The inspection remains incomplete, and a follow-up visit will be scheduled. There was one deficiency cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80069(c)(1). Please refer to 809-D. One Technical Assistance was issued for California Code of Regulations (ILS) 87087(e). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Carole Blanchard - Administrator.

On 3/14/25 at 9:26 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Omar Sawyer conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct a case management regarding staff criminal record clearance. Based on a review of the Guardian system and staff roster and schedule at the facility and confidential interview conducted, it was observed by LPA's that there are four individuals who do not have criminal record clearance (see LIC811 dated 3/14/2025). This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the clients in care. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division, Six, Section 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance, as described on the following page LIC809D. A Civil Penalty is being assessed. Based on observations of the staff schedule and confidential interview, the facility does not have a facility manager on shift every time clients are present in the facility. This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care. Facility issued a Technical Violation. During the a walk through of the facility with facility manager, LPA observed the food supply and discussed the food supply with the facility manager. The facility food supply was observed to be low where snacks should be available to clients in care. During this inspection, facility manager was able to show LPA's where more food was stored and made a plan to keep the supply in the home more accessible to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights, was left with facility manager Jessica Reyes.
