narrative: On 12/19/24 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to complete the required annual inspection. LPA met with Crystal Landa - Executive Director, at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA Medina reviewed the facilities operations, disaster preparedness plan, and discussed facilities core/therapeutic services. LPA Medina also conducted 3 staff and 1 client confidential interview. In the previous visit LPA reviewed staff and client files, conducted physical plant inspection, and began reviewing the disaster preparedness plan. The needs and service plan, as well as the medication list, were not found in the disaster binder but were available in the client binder. LPA Medina requested that a copy be printed and added to the disaster binder before the end of the visit, which the Executive Director promptly completed. Additionally, the complaint box had been broken by a client and had not yet been replaced. However, the Administrator successfully created a new complaint box by the end of the visit. One Technical Assistance was issued for California Code of Regulations 1565(d). Three technical Assistances were issued for California Code of Regulations 87072.2(a), 1565(e)(2), and 1565(c). Due to a technical error, the previous 809-D did not save and was re-signed during today’s visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Crystal Landa - Executive Director.

On 5/29/2025 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Omar Sawyer, made an unannounced inspection to above facility and met with Facility Manger Jessica Reyes. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management regarding concerns observed by the department. Present during this inspection were two staff. All clients were at school during this inspection. Based on confidential interviews conducted, between 3/20/2025 and 5/20/2025, and obtained documentation from the facility, to include, staff schedules, client rosters, client needs and service plans, mental health service notes, staff shift notes, incident reports, and staff time sheets. LPA Belfield observed that on at least three days and four different shifts, there was no proven shift coverage by staff. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the clients in care. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. A civil penalty is being assessed. During a review of incident reports submitted, between 3/20/2025 and 5/6/2025, to the department, it was observed that a staff who was not criminal record cleared, continued to work at the facility. Facility was previously issued a citation on 3/14/2025. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. Facility cited for a repeat violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80019(e). A civil penalty is being assessed.

Based on a review of staff shift notes, between 3/20/2025 and 5/20/2025, it was observed by LPA’s that incidents occurred at the facility that were not reported to the department. These incidents include calls to law enforcement. This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care. Facility cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Based on a review of staff schedules, client rosters, and employee time sheets, between January 1, 2025,, 2025 and February 28, 2025, LPA observed that on at least three occasions there was only one staff on shift with at least five clients. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. Facility issued a Technical Violation Advisory for Interim Licensing Standards section 87065.5(a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. Based on a review of the needs and services plans for clients in care between January 1, 2025 and February 28, 2025, LPAs observed that all plans are missing the required signatures. The plans were also observed to be not properly updated and missing information. Facility is being issued a Technical Advisory for the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 87068.3(a)(3), 87068.3(a)(4), 87068.3(b), and 87068.3(b)(1), Modifications to The Needs and Services Plan as described on the following pages LIC809D and LIC9106TV. Three deficiencies and four Technical Advisory notes are being issued. An Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was left with Facility Manager Jessica Reyes, whose signature confirms receipt of this report.

An in person informal meeting was held on June 16, 2025, at 3:00 PM in the San Jose Children’s Residential Regional Office. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss concerns observed by the department. Present during the meeting: Licensing Program Managers, (LPM) Carolyn Flynn, LPM Joel Segura, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, LPA Omar Sawyer, LPA Brenda Rodriguez, Administrator Carole Blanchard, and Facility Manager Jessica Reyes. The following are topics were discussed based on concerns the department observed during past inspections: Reporting requirements: Based on observations of shift notes at the facility dated from December 1, 2024, to March 1, 2025, there were multiple incidents, including calls to law enforcement that were not reported to the department. Criminal Record Clearance: Facility was cited and received civil penalties for having staff work without being criminally record cleared on March 14, 2025. Facility was cited a second time and issued more civil penalties for allowing the same staff to work in the facility without being criminally record cleared on 5/29/2025. Lack of Supervision: Facility was cited for lack of supervision for not having proof of staff coverage for multiple shifts. During a review of staff schedule and time sheets, it was observed by LPA Belfield and Sawyer, that on at least four occasions staff were working 24 to 36 hours in a row. This is a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care. Facility currently as two incident reports describing a lack of supervision of clients during the overnight shift.

Needs and Service Plans: Plans do not meet the requirements outlined in the regulations. Plans are missing information that includes, client progress or decline, history, and current needs and services needed by the client. During this meeting a plan for compliance was discussed: TSP services were discussed and offered to the program. The program agrees to utilize TSP services, reaching out to LPA for more support for guardian and utilizing supportive services and resources available from the CDSS website. LPA will send information from the California Code of Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards regarding the needs and services plan to support program in becoming compliance. The meeting was concluded.

All posting requirements and Emergency Plan were met and posted on each cottage. Children will are accorded personal rights. The clients Personal Rights are posted on the wall. On June 22, 2021 at 11:30 AM (LPA) Licensing Program Analyst Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to PACIFIC LODGE CAMPUS- STRTP for the purpose to conduct Annual Required facility inspection. LPA met with the Staff#1 (S1) Administrator of the (STRTP) SHORT TERM RESIDENTIAL THERAPEUTIC PROGRAM who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. The facility is currently licensed to provide care and supervision for 35 clients ages 13-17 years Ambulatory Only. Currently there are no children residing in the STRTP cottage and no staff working in the cottage the recent Temporary closure of the STRTP May 20, 2021 “due to staffing issues and renovation”. All children have been transferred to the Eagle Rock STRTP and Penny Lane”. S1 states that there is no weapons or guns on the premises. There is a swimming pool and on the premises; located mid campus by the AC gym. The Neimeyer Cottage: Has nine (9) bedrooms and occupies two clients and two (2) twin size beds in each room. Bedrooms #1-9 Bedroom #2 Bedroom #3 Bedroom #4 Bedroom #5 Bedroom #6 Bedroom 7 #8, and Bedroom #9 Currently there are No children occupying the rooms. There are two (2) twin size beds in each room.; adequate shelf space, closet space and lighting, comfortable mattress. The beds have been stripped down to the mattress due to being unoccupied. The clean linen, blankets and pillows are stored in the linen closet located in the Hallway BATHROOMS: The staff bathroom is adjacent to the community bathroom, located outside of the bedroom’s mid hallway. The community bathroom is equipped with a four (4) showers, four (4) toilets and a four (4) sinks. There are two windows with blinds and screens that were observed to be in good condition. The Hot water is also is temporarily shut off due the renovation. LPA confirmed that the water works in the kitchen, bathrooms, sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. The laundry room is located near bedroom #3, equip with a washer and dryer unit. S1 confirmed when clients are present the laundry detergent is distributed to children individually according to the load of their laundry.

Due to the Temporary Closure, currently all posting requirements (i. e The Clients Personal Rights; Emergency Plan, weekly menu, etc.) are not posted; however, S1 displayed were they are stored and ready to be posted when the cottage is cleared to reopen. There is a private room located adjacent from the kitchen dining area that is utilized for the children to make phones calls. The Phone Call Log and the children’s records are kept in the staff office. Although the cottage is Temporarily Closed LPA observed LPA observed ample stored hygiene supplies and feminine products. 2 Sofas, a large chair and a book shelf was observed in the Living room/TV room. The cottage kitchen is not utilized to cook food and all meals are delivered to each cottage from the facility Dining Hall; snacks are also distributed from the Dining Hall to the staff office 3 times a day to the residents. Sharp knives and hazardous solutions are not accessible to residents. The smoke detectors operated on a connected system and Carbon Monoxide detectors are operational but are temporarily shut off. LPA observed five (5) fully charged Fire Extinguishers stored and ready to be placed in the cottage. The First aid kits are available, located in staff and nursing office. LPA observed them to be in compliance with all items and ready to be utilized. All trash cans are covered with lids are stored away ready to be utilized. S1 confirmed that when the youth are present an assigned staff “Youth Care Counselor “transports clients to local recreational facilities. Activities were previously restricted due to the rules of the CDC COVID-19 Guidelines. The facility will resume outside extracurricular activities and social events when the temporary closure is lifted. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3, there were no deficiencies cited at the time of this inspection. LPA-Gray concluded the Inspection and a copy of this report will left with the Administrator on 06/22/202.

LPA obtained evidence that proper supervision was implemented to care the needs of children in placement. investigation_findings: 13On April 27, 2022 at 11:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to the PACIFIC LODGE CAMPUS STRTP to conclude the investigation and to deliver the finding. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information regarding the child’s involved in the incident. Information and records obtained revealed that there were no statements or documented evidence to support that the allegations that the facility "Food service is inadequate; staff did not supervise the resident, resulting in resident sustaining a broken tooth; Staff are not providing assistance with medications; staff do not supervise the residents adequately and Medical care is not provided when needed”, occurred. The internal Investigation revealed that no evidence to support the allegations Neglect and Lack of Supervision and Personal Rights were violated. LPA obtained statements and records that the child had major difficulty adjusting to placement; did not engage in her program and was detained.

narrative: LPA obtained evidence that the facility met the regulation of staff to client ratio, records of photos and receipts replenishing basic hygiene products; the facility has implemented various structured programs while in placement and ensured that the children receive individual therapeutic services and resources to help the youth succeed when they transition out. LPA identified discrepancy in information reported by the child regarding lack of support, LPA obtained statements and records that the child was actively engaged in her program and successfully transitioned to independent living program. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has determined that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision and Personal Right are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3. An it interview was conducted in person and the report was provided to the Program Supervisor on 04/27/2021.

The investigation included review of facility file, client file history, related incident report, staff file records, related reports from the Los Angeles Department of Children and Family Services and the Los Angeles Police Department as well as confidential interviews and contacts with Y1, S1, and three staff members. The investigation revealed on 08/22/2023, Y1 accused S1 of inappropriately touching their buttocks area. Confidential statements and records reviewed indicate a lack of evidence to substantiate the alleged. Statements obtained from parties interviewed by the Los Angeles Police Department, the Department of Children and Family Services and CCLD Investigator were inconsistent as to the date, time, and location of said incident. Review of staff file history and confidential interviews found no witnesses to corroborate S1 inappropriately touching Y! or displaying any sexual misconduct. Based on the statements gathered, and records reviewed the Department has determined there is not enough evidence to support the allegation of Sexual Abuse; therefore, the finding is unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to Facility Representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 31, 2024, at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Facility Manager, to discuss the investigative outcome. On August 23, 2023, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received a complaint alleging that Staff member #1 (S1) sexually touched Youth #1 (Y1) while in care (see LIC811, dated 1/31/2024). The investigation was conducted by CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Philippe Ryan Miles. On August 28, 2023, LPA Martin met with facility representative, informed of investigation, and obtained records. On August 24, 2023, the facility filed an incident report reporting an allegation of sexual abuse by a staff member (S1) towards a youth (Y1). Staff #1 was released from their position until further investigation. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

Mr. Patrick Davis agrees to meet the outlined conditions and understands that the Provisional License with Conditions will expire on 03/31/2021. met_with: Patrick Davis- Executive Director, Mattie Marsh Adminstrator, Bowra Faiez- Clinicical Director
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a Tele Inspection visit with facility listed above to conduct a pre-licensing inspection. The facility submitted an application on February 10, 2018 to be licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The Application, Plan of Operation and Program statement is current. The facility submitted their third revisions on May 20, 2020 LPA was on the Tele Inspection with Mattie Marsh Administrator, Patrick Davis Executive Director (ED), Mandave Sandhu Board Member, Ron Dhillon Board Member and Bowra Faiez Clinical Director (CD). At 10:30 AM, LPA was given a virtual tour of the facility by Administrator. Facility consist of 1 House and garage (storage) on the back side of the house. All areas applicable were inspected. 1. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Medication logs and procedures for psychotropic medications were discussed. 5. Two First aid kit were located in facility, and were all fully stocked. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. 8. In the house, the facility has a total of 3 bedrooms, which consist of 2 double occupancy rooms. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings.

9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable will be maintained in the facility. Healthy snacks are available to the residents. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large tables and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12. Facility has 2 restrooms and both restrooms have shower and bathtubs. All restrooms is in working order. 13. Hot water measured within appropriate range 14. All smoke detectors appear to be in proper working order 15. Carbon monoxide detector observed 16. Fire extinguishers are up to date 17. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed 18. Facility current fire clearance and facility sketch was posted 19. Sharps stored in locked cabinet 20. Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 21. Facility has no bodies of water. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during inspection Administrator will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week, as verified by Mattie Marsh Administrator. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Licensee is in the process of obtaining Mental Health Certification and has been in communication with Contra Costa and DHCS regarding the time frame. Facility anticipates receiving Mental Health Certification by the 12 month window. Licensee reports that facility is working on receiving National Accreditation through CARF. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files will be maintained on site at 1820 Galindo Street Concord, California 94520 and will be available to the department for review upon request. The files will be kept in a locked cabinet in the facility.

LPA discussed the following with Administrator, ED, CD and BM; Incident reporting, including incidents related to Law Enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving Emergency Intervention. Discussed procedures for CFT (Child and Family Team) meetings. Discussed needs and services plan procedures as well as the current referral process. Discussed trauma informed care training and emergency intervention training. Discussed the overview of required Core Services and Supports. Facility is licensed for a capacity of 6 female clients ages 10-17. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. Licensee accepts child welfare and probation. Currently, the facilities STRTP Program Statement/Plan of Operation is complete. The following items are still needed for licensure: Executive Director and Administrator currently finishing up STRTP Administrator training LPA has requested the items to be complete by March 31, 2021. The facility anticipates to be recommended for licensure on a provisional basis on December 31, 2020. Exit Interview was conducted and LPA e-mail Executive Director report for signature. No Deficiencies were cited

SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Oquendo on 6/3/21 at 2:00PM. LPA spoke with administrator - Mattie Marsh, who also sent the requested file documents for review. This inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on-site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA viewed the medications, which were locked in a cabinet, located inside the locked staff office. Facility has a capacity of six, with 4 children in placement. There were two children placed at this facility that are prescribed psychotropic medications at the time of the file review, but one child recently moved out of this facility. This facility has not received an SB 484 inspection prior. LPA conducted exit interview and will send a copy of this report to the administrator.

On 12/17/21 at 9:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh, and Administrator Patrick Davis arrived at 12:30PM. LPA informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARES Inspection Tool to complete the inspection. LPA reviewed current staff and resident records and interviewed Administrator. LPA toured the facility and grounds and observed the facility to be in good condition, well-maintained, clean and sanitary, and free of hazards or obstructions. Room temperature and hot water temperature measured within permitted ranges, at 74 F and 116.1 F, respectively. The kitchen is stocked with food within date and in the quantity necessary to meet current resident needs. During the review of facility records, LPA observed that emergency disaster plan, license, personal rights, facility sketch, menu, and complaint procedures were posted in the facility. LPA observed that the disaster drills documentation was not maintained on site, and LPA advised, per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80023, that disaster drills be documented and that documentation be maintained on site. During the review of resident records, LPA observed that resident R1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 12/17/21) had a medical screening but did not have a TB test. LPA advised, per CCR, Title 22, Section 80069, that the LIC 602 Physician's Report be completed by a physician for R1. During the review of staff records, LPA observed that staff records and staff training records were located at the administrative office and needed to be brought to the facility during the visit. LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Sections 80066 and 87095.65, that originals or copies of personnel records be maintained at the facility site at all times. LPA observed that staff S2 and S3 had TB tests but no LIC 503 Health Screening. LPA advised, per CCR, Title 22, Section 80066, that the LIC 503 be completed by a physician for both staff. Training records were accidentally not brought to the facility, so LPA requested that the 2021 training records and certificates for S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, and S6 be sent to LPA by 12/21/21.

There are two citations: 1) LPA observed that staff S1, S2, and S3 did not have a clearance association to the facility and did not appear on the Guardian roster. LPA checked staff clearances during visit and observed that the three staff will require a transfer request be submitted. LPA issued a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 80019(e), and, per Section 80019(g), LPA issued an immediate civil penalty of $100 per violation (S1, S2, and S3) for a maximum of 5 days, for a total of $1500. 2) LPA observed that staff S2, S3, S4, and S5 did not have valid first aid / CPR certificates, as the ones on file were expired. LPA issued a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 87065.1(e)(8). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Patrick Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on March 16, 2022 at 10:43 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, March 16, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Michelle P. Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Mattie Mash, Facility Administrator.

On 5/24/22 at 2:50PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During an investigation at the facility, it was discovered that the facility is refusing to transport resident R1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) to an extracurricular activity in the region. There is a posting in the staff office that reads, "No one is to give [R1] a ride to color guard. We do not provide transportation for extra curricular activities." Additionally, R1's needs and services lists traveling to color guard as a goal for R1 and discusses that R1 has taken the bus, but it does not have anywhere in writing that there is an agreement that R1 is to take the bus. Further, neither R1 nor R1's county social worker signed the needs and services plan; only the clinical social worker and the administrator have signed. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87074 Transportation and an advisory of Section 87068.2 Needs and Services Plan. It was also discovered that the facility issued a consequence to resident R1 due to R1 not completing chores and being disrespectful to staff. The consequence was issued on Saturday 5/21/22, and notice of the consequence was given to youth the same day. The consequence was that R1 could not attend the outing, bowling. During today's inspection, LPA observed that the consequence was not documented in the consequence log binder or elsewhere, and Administrator admitted it was not documented. Administrator also stated that the consequence was issued without collaboration with the youth. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87072.1 Discipline Policies and Procedures. Lastly, during today's visit, it was discovered that the facility was short-staffed this morning with a ratio after 7AM of 1 staff to 4 residents. Per Administrator, the staff who was scheduled to work this morning called off last night due to a family emergency, but no additional staff was called until this morning at 7:38AM.

Administrator stated that they believed they could manage supervision of all residents on their own. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. Three citations and one advisory was issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Mattie Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Additionally, during inspection on 5/4/22, LPA observed dark spots in the corners and along the seal of the shower-tub in the hallway bathroom and small, dark spots in the shower in the en suite bathroom. During today's inspection, LPA took a glove and was able to smear the spots, indicating they are not stains and are active mold/mildew. LPA inspected the facility's store of cleaning supplies and observed three cans of bathroom cleaner targeting soap scum but no cleaners for mold/mildew or mold/mildew stains. There is no evidence that spots have been treated to ensure no active mold is present. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing two citations of California Code of Regulations (CCR), TItle 22, Section 80087 Buildings and Grounds. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Mattie Marsh, whose signature confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/24/22 at 1:08PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During complaint investigation, LPA inspected the facility and interviewed 4 residents and 2 staff. Based on observation and interview, 2 of 4 residents reported seeing bugs in the facility. Photos of 3 different bugs on different occasions inside the facility were sent to LPA, including at least two where bugs were found in a resident's bed. During one observation, LPA was called by a resident, and LPA could hear staff remove the bug as requested by the youth. Additionally, LPA was initially informed by the facility that the facility had a current contract with an exterminator service. However, upon request for the most recent invoice, LPA was provided with a new contract dated 5/6/22, after LPA's intial inspection on 5/4/22. SEE NEXT PAGE.

deficiencies.description:
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, the licensee did not ensure the facility was clean, safe, and sanitary due to mold being found in the hallway bathroom around the shower-tub.  This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to acquire cleaning agents that target mold and to have staff clean the shower-tub in the hallway bathroom.  Photos of the cleaned tub (LPA understands there may be stains) and the cleaner used will be sent to LPA by due date of 5/25/22.

deficiencies.description:
The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, the licensee did not ensure to take measures to keep the facility free of insects due to multiple bugs being found in the facility, including in resident bed, and facility not having an exterminator as stated.  This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee has obtained a contract with an exterminator.  Copy of the contract has been sent to LPA.

narrative: On 8/24/22 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management inspection at the facility regarding a recently submitted incident report. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and Facility Manager Brice Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on the incident report and confidential interviews with staff and residents, a staff member did not follow facility procedures for medication administration by allowing a resident to have direct access to their box of medications and also by not maintaining constant, direct supervision of the resident, resulting in the resident being able to pull out a bottle of psychotropic medication. The resident was later able to self-administer the medication and took enough to induce vomiting and potentially overdose. The youth was admitted to the program on 8/16/22, and this incident occurred on 8/21/22 evening around 7:30PM-8PM, and on 8/22/22 morning around 8AM, staff noticed the medication was missing. On 8/22/22, after being unable to locate the medication, staff spoke to involved resident, who admitted to taking the medication and to taking the high amount of pills missing from the bottle, which was about 26 pills. The facility immediately took the resident to the hospital. The youth was held overnight and released the following day. Based on confidential interviews, the facility has increased supervision, checks in more with the resident to provide additional supports, and has made a plan to terminate the staff member. LPA obtained staff file for further review. No deficiencies have been found at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager Brice Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/7/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the short-term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) facility. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. When LPA entered the facility, there was one resident present and one staff present. The staff present stated they are not a facility manager. When the administrator was called and LPA requested someone who is authorized to sign the visit report be at the facility, Administrator stated she would arrive. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065 Personnel Requirements. On 8/24/22, LPA Hawkins conducted a case management visit regarding an incident in which a resident obtained a psychotropic medication from the facility's medication storage and self-administered too many pills of the medication. Based on record review and confidential interviews, the staff administering the medication allowed the resident to have access to the bin of their own medication allowing the resident to grab a bottle of medication while the staff member was distracted by another resident asking a question. Additionally, based on confidential interviews, while the staff member's training record reflects that they were trained on medication administration, this was not the first time the staff had the bin of medications accessible to residents during administration. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80087 Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Mattie Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing three citations, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80076 Food Services and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Sections 87022 Plan of Operation and 87072 Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Mattie Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 9/7/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on record review, physical evidence obtained during the investigation, and confidential interviews with residents and staff, the facility has food in the quantity to meet the residents' needs but has not been following the menu, menus as served were not available for review because they were not being updated as served, and facility receipts provided from 8/18/22 to 8/23/22 reflect that five (5) visits were made in that time to fast food restaurants, and on at least two days, multiple visits were made in the same day. Based on the amount spent, not all residents were fed fast food meals on these occasions, but as stated above, no menus as served were available to review. Additionally, based on physical evidence and confidential interviews, multiple facility staff are disrespectful to residents and use abusive language toward residents.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/14/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Mattie Marsh/Patrick Davis, Administrators and Bryce Marsh, House Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to open the complaint and deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, interviews were conducted and documents were reviewed, and it was determined that the facility staff did not surrender valuables entrusted to them to a youth in care upon the youth's disharge and facility staff did not safeguard valuables to them. Based on LPA’s interview with staff and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, facility staff did not surrender valuables entrusted to them to a youth in care upon the youth's disharge and facility staff did not safeguard valuables to them is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80026(b) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables. At this time, one deficiency was given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Mattie Marsh/Patrick Davis, Administrators and Byrce Marsh, House Manager.

investigation_findings: 13On 1/9/23 and 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Palo Verde and spoke with Mattie Marsh and Patrick Davis, Administrators. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. This complaint was taken as an assignment by Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB) and assigned to Inv. Blake Williams on 09/22/2022. Complaint was upgraded to a full investigation on 11/30/2022. During investigation, confidential interviews, police reports, and physical evidence were obtained, it was determined that staff did not handle resident in a rough manner and staff did not choke a resident. Although, the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff handles resident in a rough manner and staff choked a resident. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. At this time, no deficiencies were cited. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with Mattie Marsh and Patrick Davis, Administrator

met_with: Administratos Patrick Davis and Mattie Marsh
narrative: On 1/25/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit regarding an incident at the facility where furniture caught on fire. LPA met with Administrators Patrick Davis and Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA obtained details of the incident and the residents involved. The facility provided the fire department incident number and will be sending in written reports to the Department this week. LPA also inspected the facility and observed that there was no structural damage. Staff responded promptly to the incident, and there were no injuries. Residents were relocated to a safe, nearby location and will be able to be moved to the unaffected rooms following the affected room being cleaned. An overnight facility manager was and has been designated to supervise residents. When the fire department arrived to the incident, an investigator spoke to the residents about safety. During visit, an inspector came and informed the administrators that they will need to remove the affected bed and all of the bedding in the room. The residents' clothing will need to be thoroughly cleaned, but the residents have enough unaffected clothing from the drawers, and Administrators stated if they need anything, they will go to the store with the residents. There are no deficiencies observed at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrators Patrick Davis and Mattie Marsh
narrative:
On 1/25/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to follow-up on the noncompliance conference (NCC) held on 10/13/2022, terms from which are listed below. LPA met with Administrators Patrick Davis and Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. (1) The facility will be subject to frequent visits following this NCC, at which supervision, emergency intervention procedures, trauma-informed care, and general compliance will be assessed through review of staff training records and confidential interviews with staff and residents. - This is the first quarterly inspection. At visit, LPA reviewed training records and conducted interviews to assess supervision, emergency intervention procedures, trauma-informed care, and general compliance. The facility has shifted one of the administrators out of the day to day items and and is overseeing the program tasks but checks in at the facility. The other administrator is at the facility everyday for four hours and meets with the lead facility manager (house supervisor) every week. Additionally, staff now work in teams; there is a food team, activities team, mental health team, and medication team. The facility has staff training certificates from careprovider.org and maintains a training log on which staff sign verifying attendance and the trainer signs as well. The facility is also using a past checklist from the Department to train staff on general compliance in the facility and to be able to spot and correct issues during their shifts. The facility is using MANDT training for de-escalation and trauma-informed care and is finding this very helpful. The facility is getting away from consequences and now uses education and specific language and tone to redirect residents. Supervision is maintained so that staff provide direct supervision. If residents, for instance, go in the garage, outside, etc. a staff member will follow. If a resident states they want to go for a walk, a staff will go on a mental health walk with them. Additionally, the LIC 500 reflects 40 hours of Administrator and Program Director coverage, Monday-Friday lead facility manager (house supervisor) coverage, and facility manager coverage at all times residents are present. The facility is in the process of designating one of the current staff as the head of services and therapist, has received approval from the State, and is waiting to hear back from the county on their approval. The facility has hired a psychiatric nurse who comes to...

... the facility to administer medications and who oversees the home health care needs of the residents. (2) The licensee will retrain all staff, including administrator(s) and facility manager(s), on personal rights, de-escalation procedures, and trauma-informed care. Staff will receive a minimum of 2 hours of training on each topic, for a total of 8 hours of training. For each topic, training must be from a source not affiliated with the licensee. All training will be completed within 120 days from the date of the NCC, and training certificates for each training will be maintained in staff training records and available for review. - The training is to be completed by 02/10/2023. The facility has increased the 2 hour training requirement to 8 hours on each topic. See narrative above. (3) The licensee will develop and submit to the Licensing agency by December 1, 2022 on the retraining, including job shadowing plan, for former administrator if they are to continue working at the facility. - The licensee completed the training plan and submitted on time to the Department. (4) The licensee will submit the bi-annual review of the facility's emergency intervention plan, per STRTP ILS Section 87095.22(h), by January 5, 2023. The plan will include a review of intervention methods used to de-escalate residents during altercations. - The licensee completed the biannual review and submitted on time to the Department. (5) The licensee will ensure that staff schedules reflecting facility manager and/or administrator coverage on site at all times residents are present are available for review at all visits. - LPA reviewed the LIC 500 and discussed with staff. See narrative above. (6) The licensee will notify the Licensing agency by December 1, 2022 if licensee would like to receive technical support services. - The licensee stated that the services did not meet their needs so were not utilized. No deficiencies were observed at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/27/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to follow-up on the noncompliance conference (NCC) held on 10/13/2022. LPA met with Facility Supervisor Brice Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. The terms from the NCC that require follow-up today are listed below. - The facility will be subject to frequent visits following this NCC, at which supervision, emergency intervention procedures, trauma-informed care, and general compliance will be assessed through review of staff training records and confidential interviews with staff and residents. - The licensee will ensure that staff schedules reflecting facility manager and/or administrator coverage on site at all times residents are present are available for review at all visits. During visit, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff and 1 resident. A second resident refused an interview, and the third resident was still at school. LPA reviewed the staff schedules and observed that they reflect facility manager coverage on each shift. Staff completed over many hours of training, including 5 days of training in April, covering topics of trauma-informed care, behavior interventions and treatment planning for a higher acuity of youth, STRTP mindset shift, counseling techniques for direct care staff, and cultural humility and working with LGBTQ+ youth. No deficiencies were observed during today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Supervisor Brice Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 5/19/2023 at 1:17PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct a case management for the lack of incident reporting. LPA met with Mattie Marsh,Program Manager. The facility has not provided all incident reports to Community Care Licensing (CCL) within the reporting period. LPA delivered a Type B citation for Title 22 California Code of Regulation 80061(b) Reporting Requirements (see LIC809D). LPA devised a Plan of Correction with Mattie Marsh, Program Manager. LPA conducted an exit interview and delivered appeal rights to Mattie Marsh, Program Manager at 1:40PM.

deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements -... the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency.. In addition... (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days 
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the facility has not provided written incident reports to Community Care Licensing within seven days.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee has sent the missing reports to SBIRCR@DSS.CA.GOV and LPA Hood on 5/17/2023.

narrative: During the course of the investigation, LPA Hood conducted seven confidential interviews. LPA reviewed the facility’s program statement, incident reports, C1’s Needs and Services Plan, and email correspondence. According to four confidential interviews and record review, on 4/28/2023 the facility had informed Community Care Licensing (CCL) and Butte County of a plan to temporarily close on 5/1/2023 via email. This email also documented that C1 would need to be removed from the facility on or before 5/1/2023. This temporary closure and eviction were rescinded on 4/31/2023. Based on three confidential interviews and record review, facility staff did not provide updated service plan to the authorized representative until 5/19/2023. Based on the confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that staff did not provide client's records to authorized representative and staff did not follow proper eviction procedures are substantiated. LPA delivered a Type A citation for STRTP Interim Licensing Standards 87068.4(c)(1). Facility did not provide service plan or proper communication during the eviction process which poses an immediate risk to health, safety and/or personal rights of the client in care. LPA conducted an exit interview with David Beanes, Facility Manager at 1:58PM and provided appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/12/2023 at 12:14PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. LPA met with David Beanes, Facility Manager, who informed them that they were leaving to pick up a client and nobody else was present in the home. LPA Hood attempted to call Administrator, Mattie Marsh, and Director, Patrick Davis. LPA returned to the facility at 1:45PM. LPA met with David Beanes, Facility Manager. During the course of the investigation, LPA Hood conducted seven confidential interviews. LPA reviewed the facility’s program statement, incident reports, C1’s Needs and Services Plan, and email correspondence. Continued on LIC9099C...

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review, the facility informed Community Care Licensing (CCL) and authorized representative that the facility would be temporarily closing due to youth's behavior on 4/28/2023. Facility did not provide service plan until 5/19/2023.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility did provide service plan documents to the authorized representative and CCL on 5/19/2023. The youth was discharged on 6/5/2023.

narrative: Based on confidential interviews, the facility had informed Community Care Licensing (CCL) of the inability to safely place C1. Based on the confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegation that facility did not follow eviction protocols may or may not be true. The allegation has not met the preponderance of doubt, and the allegation is therefore unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Mattie Marsh, Program Manager at 1:35PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/22/2023 at 12:11PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct interviews and deliver the finding for the above allegation. LPA met with Mattie Marsh, Program Manager. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted five confidential interviews. LPA reviewed the 14-day notice, pertinent incident reports, daily notes, C1's Needs and Services Plan, photographs of staff injuries, and email correspondence. Based on confidential interviews and incident report, C1 was placed on a 5150 hold by Pittsburg Police Department on 6/1/2023. Based on confidential interviews, on 6/2/2023 the facility gave notice to Butte County that they would not be able to accept C1 back from their hospitalization because of multiple staff injuries.

narrative: On 7/28/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to follow-up on the noncompliance conference (NCC) held on 10/13/2022. LPA met with Facility Supervisor Brice Marsh and Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. The terms from the NCC that require follow-up today are listed below. - The facility will be subject to frequent visits following this NCC, at which supervision, emergency intervention procedures, trauma-informed care, and general compliance will be assessed through review of staff training records and confidential interviews with staff and residents. - The licensee will ensure that staff schedules reflecting facility manager and/or administrator coverage on site at all times residents are present are available for review at all visits. During visit, LPA conducted confidential interviews with 2 staff and 1 resident. A second resident refused an interview, and the third resident was on an outing. LPA reviewed the staff schedules and observed that they reflect facility manager coverage on each shift. LPA requested the training records for all staff listed on the staff schedule, including Admistrators and mental health professionals for the months of May through July 2023. The records should also indicate how many hours of training have been completed by each staff since their hire date or 2023 anniversary date. Administrator agreed to submit by Friday 8/4/23. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Mattie Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 8/10/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to follow-up on the noncompliance conference (NCC) held on 10/13/2022. This visit was a continuation of the visit on 7/28/23. LPA met with Administrator Mattie Marsh and informed of the purpose of the visit. During LPA's initial visit, LPA requested training records which were not available for review during the visit. During today's visit, LPA continued the review of training and personnel records and interviewed Administrator. During visit, LPA obtained and reviewed camera footage compiled by the licensee. On 7/31/23, LPA requested the footage for the month of July 2023. Licensee was unable to supply more than the past 11 days, and the footage was not continuous, resulting in gaps in the footage. Also, based on record review, interviews, and observations, a repairman who does not have a background clearance associated to the facility has performed work resulting in frequent presence at the facility. LPA advised that the facility ensure the required conditions (outlined in advisory note) are met to ensure the individual continues to be exempt from fingerprinting. Lastly, the following deficiencies were observed. See LIC 809-Ds and LIC 811 Confidential Names. Training records were not available for review during the initial visit on 7/28/23. Staff S3, S4, S5, and S7 are designated facility managers but their training records do not reflect facility manager training. Staff S3, S5, and S6 are designated facility managers and have been filling this role, but their files do not contain the facility manager job description reflecting training on job duties and only contain the signed direct care counselor job description.

Staff S3, who was hired in July 2022, has only 16 hours of training reflected in their training record, which is less than the required 40 hours of annual training. Staff S2's training record does not reflect training on the core program model/approach Nurtured Heart Approach. Staff S2, S3, S5, and S8 have less than 24 hours of initial training reflected in their training records. Personnel files reflect signed consequence procedure acknolwedgements that are pulled from the old group home (GH) program statement, which do not align with the current, approved Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) program statement. The current STRTP program statement is not maintained on file. The old GH program statement was supplied to LPA upon request of the program statement, and the STRTP program statement could not be supplied at visit. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80066 Personnel Records and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Sections 87065 Personnel Requirements, 87065.1 Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements, 87022 Plan of Operation, and 87022.1 Program Statement. Additionally, due to a repeat violation within 12 months of Section 87022(f), LPA is assessing an immediate civil penalty of $250. See LIC 421FC. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Mattie Marsh, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.description:
87065 Personnel Requirements
(f)(2) Prior to assuming...duties...of...facility manager, the individual shall complete a minimum of one hour of training as specified in Section 87065.1(a), in addition to training required in Sections 87065.1(c) and (d).
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure facility managers were training due to staff S3, S4, S6, S7 not having documentation of facility manager training, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to ensure S3, S4, S5, and S7 complete the facility manager training as outlined in the facility plan of operation.  Evidence of completion of training will be delivered to LPA by due date.

deficiencies.description:
80066 Personnel Records
(a)(8)
Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (8) Duties of the employee.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure staff had correct duties job duties in the file due to facility managers S3, S5, S6 not having facility manager job duties in file, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to ensure S3, S5, and S6 files indicate the appropriate job duty, as reflected by the LIC 500 and staff schedules.  The signed job descriptions for S3, S5, and S6 will be delivered to LPA by due date.

deficiencies.description:
87065.1 ...Training Requirements
(e)(1)...all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training, except as specified in (2) below.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure staff received required hours of training due to staff S3 training record reflecting 16 hours of training over past 12 months, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit a training plan to have S3 receive the required 40 hours of training over the July 2023 to July 2024 period.  This plan will be submitted to LPA by due date.

deficiencies.description:
80066 Personnel Records
(c) All personnel records shall be available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit, and copy upon demand during normal business hours.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and observation, licensee did not ensure personnel records were available for review during business hours due to records not available during initial NCC visit, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee submitted training records to LPA.  Licensee agrees to submit in writing the arrangements to ensure the locked personnel file storage is accessible to management staff.  This will be submitted by due date.

deficiencies.description:
87065.1 ...Training Requirements
(d)(3)(B) Facility's program and services, including program philosophy


This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure staff had training on facility program and philosophy due to S2 not having core philosophy/approach nurtured heart training, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to ensure S2 completes the nurtured heart training series.  Evidence of completion will be delivered to LPA by due date.

deficiencies.description:
87065.1 ...Training Requirements
(d)(2) Sixteen hours of training shall be completed by new direct care staff within 90 days of hire. Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure complete initial training due to S2, S3, S5, S8 training records reflecting less than 24 hours of initial training, missing the 16hr portion, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to ensure staff receive the remainder of the initial training, per the facility's initial training plan in the plan of operation.  The signed initial training logs for the 16hr training portion for S2, S3, S5, and S8 will be delivered to LPA by due date.

deficiencies.description:
87022 Plan of Operation
(f) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and observation, licensee did not ensure the plan of operation was followed due to following and training staff on consequence procedures that differ from the approved plan of operation, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to retrain staff and have all staff sign new acknowledgements of discipline procedures based on the approved STRTP plan of operation.  This will be submitted by due date.

deficiencies.description:
87022.1 Program Statement
(a) A facility shall have and maintain on file a current, written, definitive program statement that meets the requirements of this section.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure program statement maintained on file due to the STRTP program statement not at facility site and old GH program statement supplied to LPA, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to prepare a copy of the approved STRTP program statement to have maintained at the facility site.  This will be completed by due date.

13At 02:00PM on 10/23/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karmen Balhotra made an unannounced complaint inspection to the facility listed above. The reason for the inspection is to deliver findings for the allegation listed above. LPA met Brice Marsh, Supervisor who helped facilitate the inspection. Over the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and a file review. Evidence obtained revealed that for the allegation of, Minor inappropriately touched another minor while in care, is found to be substantiated. During confidential interviews, three of four staff members interviewed stated that a former client did inappropriately touch another client in care. Confidential interviews revealed that staff were unaware of sexualized behaviors that the client may have had and that the incident took place after clients were leaving the facility together on unauthorized absences. The facility separated clients upon learning of the incident. Therefore, per evidence obtained, the preponderance of evidence has been met. Based on today’s inspection the facility is being cited under section 80072(a)(1) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Supervisor.

At this time, the Case Management will not be completed due to staff leaving for a client dentist appointment and another client’s behavioral health appointment. A Case Management continuation will be required to complete the inspection. LPA toured the facility, and no safety hazards were present. An exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager, and a copy of this report was left.

On July 24, 2023, the Department received a complaint alleging facility staff did not allow client to call social worker, staff locked client out of facility and staff reported false allegations to law enforcement. Based on confidential interviews, client was in crisis and staff tried to redirect client to base level for client to use the phone. Staff offered to dial social worker for client and was denied by client. Client continued escalated behaviors outside of facility and law enforcement was called at which time staff were told to shelter in place and lock the doors until law enforcement arrived. LPA Pavia could not obtain transcripts of the 911 call to verify staff were given the direction to lock the client outside while waiting for officers to arrive. Client was outside of the facility for no more than 15 minutes. Staff purportedly informed law enforcement that client was attempting to get a knife from the staff office, not that client tried to stab staff. Client did not have a knife in possession during this incident. Based on confidential interviews conducted, the above allegations may have happened or are valid, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff did not allow client to contact social worker, or staff made false allegations to law enforcement or staff locked client out of facility without direction from law enforcement; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated.

deficiencies.description:

This requirement was not met, as evidenced by; Based on interviews, staff stated that the facility did have rodents at the time of the complaint and continue to have them present. This poses a potential Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

Licensee will provide in writing of the pest control invoice addressing the rodent problem. Licensee will send confirmation to the department and at Carolyn.Flynn@dss.ca.gov by the due date.

Licensee will include in detail of this session with client to the department and at Carolyn.Flynn@dss.ca.gov by the due date.

narrative: On 4/15/2024 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno, Mona Lam, and LPA Shikya Belfield made an unannounced case management inspection at Palo Verde House. LPA' s met with Nick Morriano and Mandave Sandhu, who assisted with the inspection. The Department was notified via email on March 27, 2024, by Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) that the Mental Health Program Approval for Palo Verde House was being revoked. On April 10, 2024, the Department was notified that an appeal was filed, and all supporting documentation was to be submitted by close of business on April 26, 2024 to DHCS. Facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standard (ILS), Version 5, section 87089.1(b) Mental Health as described on the following page LIC 809D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and Appeal Rights were sent to Mandave Sandhu, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.description: A short-term residential therapeutic program shall have up to 12 months from the date of obtaining a provisional license to obtain mental health program approval from the California Department of Health Care Services, or from a delegated county Mental Health Plan. If the facility requires additional time to obtain mental health program approval, the licensing agency may extend the provisional license for up to an additional twelve months as specified in Section 87030. A short-term residential therapeutic program that has obtained a permanent license shall maintain the mental health program approval in good standing. This requirement was not met as evidenced by, The Department was notified via email on March 27, 2024, by Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) that the Mental Health Program Approval for Palo Verde House was being revoked. This poses a potential Health, safety, or personal rights risk to cleints in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Currenty the facility has submitted an appeal of the decision. If the appeal is denied program will follow protocol to discharge all clients within 30 days once all discharges have taken place program will infom CCL on their plans to submit closure plan or remain in operation. Notification will be submitted to the department by the plan of correction due date of 5/31/2024.

investigation_findings: 13On 03/20/2024 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno and LPA Shikya Belfield made an unannounced visit to initiate a complaint investigation at Palo Verde House to deliver the findings on the listed allegation. LPA Cardeno and LPA Belfield met with Tony Beane, Facility Manager. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cardeno and LPA Belfield toured the facility, conducted confidential interviews, and had documentation including photo evidence of the refrigerator being locked up and not being accessible for the clients in care. Based on confidential interviews and supportive documentation that include but not limited to photographs the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, the allegation, “Staff did not ensure food was accessible to minor in care” is substantiated. Food service regulation 87076(c)(1), is being cited on the attached LIC9099-D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Tony Beane, Facility Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents. Appeal rights were given to the facility.

deficiencies.description: Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days shall be maintained on the premises. This requirement was not met as evidence by, Based on confidential interviews and supportive documentation that include but not limited to photographs, the facility locks up the refrigerator. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to immediately cease using a lock on the refrigerator and will submit a plan to the department regarding how they will maintain safe  and accessible food supply for all clients in care. narrative: On 5/3/2024 at 11:14 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct a case management regarding information obtained by the department regarding the operations of the facility. LPA met with facility manager Deby Elkins and Head of Service Nick Moriana who assisted with the inspection. At the time of the visit there were three staff and three clients present in the facility. One staff took a client to the doctors appointment and another client went to the dentist during this inspection. Based on confidential interviews conducted, it was confirmed that clients do drugs in the facility and in the backyard of the facility. Although the staff spoke to clients in care regarding these situations, there was no follow up or prevention in place to keep the events from happening again. There was no information provided in the needs and service plans of the clients. The preponderance of evidence has been met; therefore, these allegations are Substantiated, therefore, the facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards Section 87068.3(a) Modifications to The Needs and Services Plan. Based on confidential interviews, it was confirmed that S1 (see LIC 811 dated 5/3/2024) worked on the evening of 4/23/2024 after the facility was cited for S1 not having criminal record clearance. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards 80019(e) Criminal record Clearance. Facility is assessed a civil penalty. Based on communication with Head of Service Nick Moriana, C1 (see LIC 811 dated 5/3/2024) was inappropriately discharged from the program and no program policies / procedures or regulations were followed. Facility cited for violation of 87068.4 Removal and/or Transfer Procedures as described on the following page 809D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was left with Head of Service Nick Moriana.

narrative: On 07/12/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a facility evaluation visit for a case management regarding an observed deficiency from a complaint investigation; control number 14-CR-20240510153331. LPA met with facility Administrator and informed on the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, confidential interviews and records review were conducted. Based on interviews, record review, and video footage the following deficiency was discovered regarding staff implementation of trauma informed care. LPA observed S1 not utilizing trauma informed practices to de-escalate the residents in care after an incident had occurred. Upon further review, LPA observed one of the residents in care to contact Law Enforcement to help de-escalate the situation since S1 was identified by the residents as a trigger for the incident that had conspired. (See LIC811 Confidential Names List). LPA is issuing a citation for violation of the Interim Licensing Standard (ILS), Version 5, Section 87072 (c)(16) Personal Rights. See attached LIC9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to facility Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
