narrative: On 09/03/2021, starting at approximately 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a Prelicensing Inspection of this facility. LPA was met by Executive Director Maritza Jefferson who gave a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. There are no bodies of water on the premises; the front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egresses were unobstructed. No potentially hazardous items or areas were observed--there is a shed in the backyard that is lockable (it currently does not contain any potentially dangerous equipment). The facility has three bedrooms: the master bedroom has an en-suite full bathroom whose two vanity faucets provided hot water with temperature readings of 110 and 116 degrees Fahrenheit; the temperature reading for the hot water that the shower provided was 109.6; the toilet in that master bathroom was in working condition. There is also a common bathroom off the bedroom hallway: the toilet flushes, the vanity faucet's hot water temperature reading was 121.4, the shower's water temperature was 105.8. The kitchen faucet's hot water temperature reading was 110.2. The house has two refrigerators: one in the kitchen and one in the garage, both are in good working condition. There is also a sizeable walk-in pantry. The house is equipped with two fire extinguishers, one was located in the threshold between the receiving area/dining room, and the other was mounted on the back wall of the kitchen. The house has an office area immediately to the right of entering the house; Ms. Jefferson stated that this room, as well as the built-in cabinet in the office, will be securable as this is where confidential client and staff files will be housed. No structural defects to the house was observed by this LPA: the windows and window screens were in good repair and there were no unfinished areas. Per Ms. Jefferson, the beds, along with all other necessary furnishings for the bedrooms, will be procured shortly; cabinets, storage spaces, and all other areas that need to be inaccessible to future residents will also be secured (locking mechanisms to be installed, for example) by the next Prelicensing inspection. Ms. Jefferson was reminded that she could call this LPA directly for guidance should she have any Regulations-related questions to ensure compliance. A subsequent Prelicensing inspection will be conducted at a future date. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Jefferson.

On 12/28/2021 at approximately 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Rivera and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez arrived at the facility to complete a post-licensing inspection. This was an attempted post-licensing inspection. LPA observed the front yard and entry to be clean and clear of clutter. LPA knocked on the door and called Maritza Jefferson, as no one answered the door and appeared to be at the facility. LPA sent Maritza Jefferson an email and text message. LPA and LPM waited in their vehicle for an hour. At 11:20 AM, Martiza Jefferson returned LPA's phone call and informed LPA that they were on vacation out of the country. They will not return until January 3, 2022. Additionally, there are no placements in the facility at this time. LPA asked if any other staff was available to assist with the inspection, Maritza Jefferson reported that no one is available, as they are on vacation as well. LPA will schedule an inspection for the first week of January to complete the post-licensing inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Maritza Jefferson via telephone at 11:30 AM. A copy of this report will be sent electronically to MJefferson@paradisehomes.org. Signature on file.

On 10/24/22 at 09:35 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made a unannounced visit at the above facility with the purpose of conducting a required Annual Inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools. During the inspection LPA and LPM met with Maritza Jefferson, Executive Director and Carol Ayers, Administrator. There are no staff and clients placed at the facility, therefore clients were not interviewed. LPA Carmona conducted a walk- through of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility consisted of 4 bedrooms, 1 bedroom is designated as a staff office and there are 2 full bathrooms. LPA Carmona observed the following required posters posted in the facility: employee posters, emergency forms, disaster plan, emergency exits, license, HIPPA, personal rights poster, and mental health poster. Prior to the inspection, LPA Carmona reviewed the facilities: annual fees, administrator certificate, accreditation, personnel roster, facility sketch, LIC 500, LIC 610C, LIC 308, waivers, and exceptions. The facility is current on their fees. LPA Carmona and LPM Rodriguez inspected the following: Physical Plant: Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions are inaccessible Currently there is no perishable food due to having no placement's. The facility has at least a weeks’ nonperishable foods. The facility has a “mock” menu posted on the refrigerator. Continue to page 2

There is a working telephone in the kitchen. There are dual Carbon Monoxide/Smoke detectors in the hallway, kitchen, and all 4 bedrooms. The First Aid Kit is fully stocked There is a common room and living room available. There is a dining area with enough seating and dining table in good repair The office has door that locks. There is a locked cabinet reserved for medications. The hot water is 115-degree F. There are 2 fully charged fire extinguishers. There are working toilets, bath and showers, all in good repair. The bedrooms have required bedding and furnishing are in good repair. The facility is free of vermin There is a shed in the backyard, it is empty and unlocked. Operation: All requirements met. No citation cited for this section of the domain. Disaster Preparedness: All requirements met. No citation cited for this section of the domain. Staffing/Client Records: The facility is vacant therefore there are no clients or staff. The facility had a “mock” file for staff and clients. LPA and LPM reviewed the “mock” files and they had appropriate examples of required documents. LPA and LPM reviewed the “mock medication binder which also had the required documents. Core/Therapeutic Services: There are no placement's at the facility. Services are not being provided at this time; however, the facility has a program, and it will be implemented. An exit interview was conducted with Maritza Jefferson, Executive Director and a copy of this report will be emailed to mjefferson@paradisehome.org.

On 9/07/23 at approximately 09:40 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced annual inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools and met with Administrator, Carol Ayers. LPA toured the interior and exterior of the facility during the inspection today. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms, which had all the furniture, linens and lighting as required. 1 bedroom is designated as a staff office. LPA observed 2 bathrooms available to clients which were appropriately equipped with toilet paper, paper towels and running warm water as required. LPA observed that the showers and toilets were in working condition as required. The kitchen had a adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the client in care. LPA observed that the facility appliances, refrigerator, and freezer to be clean and function as required. LPA observed that sharps, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored and were not accessible to clients in care. LPA observed a menu posted in the facility. LPA observed the laundry services available for the youth to complete their own laundry. LPA observed working carbon monoxide detectors and a 2 fully charged fire extinguisher. LPA observed that the facility has a functioning telephone in the facility. The 2 living rooms and dining room were free of obstruction and had furniture in good repair. The office used by clinicians and administrator has a locked cabinet for client’s files and a locked cabinet for medication. All the posting requirements were available in a visible area. First aid kit was fully stocked and available.The back yard and front yard were free of debris and in compliance. There are no bodies of water located on the property. LPA Carmona conducted 2 client interviews and 1 staff interview. Currently the facility has 2 clients in care. LPA Carmona conducted the Physical Plant domain and will return to the facility to complete the rest of the domains in the (CARE) tool. Continue to page 2

Exit interview was conducted. There was a technical violation assessed during todays visit. A copy of report was provided to the Facility Manager.

On 9/14/23 at approximately 10:55 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools. LPA Carmona met with Administrator, Carol Ayers who assisted with the inspection. LPA Carmona continued the inspection of the following domains: Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing Records, Client Records, Core Therapeutic Services and Clients With Special Health Care Needs Currently the facility has 2 clients in care. LPA reviewed 2 client files and 5 staff files. A review of the staff files indicated the staff have current CPR and First Aid training. They also have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Check clearances. The client’s file contained all required documentation. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is current with their facility fees at the time of the inspection. During the previous inspection conducted on 9/07/23 LPA Carmona discovered 2 staff members who were working at the facility and did not have their full fingerprint clearance. Based on records review and interviews conducted, and reviewing the facilities roster from Guardian, it was confirmed that on 09/07/23 during LPA Carmona’s inspection, the two staff members were not fingerprint cleared which posed an Immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. An exit interview was conducted. The facility has been cited for Criminal Record Clearance and Personnel Requirements (See LIC 809D) and a $1,000 civil penalty was assessed during today’s visit. A copy of the report and appeal rights was provided to the Administrator.

Personnel Requirements

narrative: On 11/17/23 at 10:15 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by the Department via email on 11/09/23 which was dated 10/26/23. LPA met with Carol Ayers, Administrator. STRTP/ consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 living rooms, a kitchen, and a staff office. The backyard is free of debris. The facility is in compliance at the time of the inspection. On 11/08/23 LPA Carmona received a call from Executive Director self-reporting that facility staff failed to report an incident to the Department which occurred on 10/26/23. A client was assaulted by a school peer in a transport vehicle on the way to the facility from school on 10/26/23. The client notified facility staff on 10/27/23 and the facility staff reported the incident to the client’s school and CPS. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed, and the facility has been cited for Reporting Requirements 80061 (b)(1)(E) (See LIC 809D).

(1) below, a report shall be made.. next working day..In addition, a written report containing the information..(1)Events reported shall include the following:(E)Any unusual incident..The following was not met as evidence by: LPA Carmona  recieved SIR dated on 10/26/23 on 11/09/23. Facility staff did not report the incident next business day.

narrative: On September 20, 2024 at 10:35am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Zaria Turner arrived at the Paradise Adolescent Homes INC. LPAs were met with Administrator, Carol Ayers. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPAs observed the following deficiency. Trim on the outside of the living room window is detaching, exposing the nails underneath. (See LIC 9102 TV) LPA Shulz requested work orders be placed and copies of the work orders. This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report will be left with Administrator, Carol Ayers.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above cannot be substantiated due to conflicting statements. 4 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that the client is not spoken to in an inappropriate manner. 3 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that the client is always fed, and that snacks are readily available. Since the client doesn’t trust certain staff members to make their food, they will cook for themselves most days with staff supervision. 3 out of 5 confidential interviews also state that no staff member has recorded the client or has driven the client in an unsafe manner. Lastly, LPA Shulz was unable to confirm or deny these claims after attempting to obtain further details from a fellow client that was in the home around the time of the incidents. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

deficiencies.description:
80087(a) Building and Grounds
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations conducted, the licensee did not ensure the good repair of the home by allowing the side window trim to become detached, exposing nails which poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to participants.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will provide proof of correction to LPA via email by 10/4/24 close of business.

narrative:
On 10/14/2024 at 9:50 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPAs met with Carol Ayers, Administrator and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant Room 1 is a therapy room with a couch, bean bag chair, games and a desk. Room 2 is the dining room with a couch, chairs and a dining room table. Room 3 is the living room with a couch, chairs and a TV. Room 4 is the office and file room which is inaccessible to clients, with an attached bathroom area. Room 5 is a clients bedroom with a bed, dresser and closet. Room 6 is a client bedroom with a bed, dresser and closet. Room 7 is the laundry room with a washer and dryer. There are two bathrooms, one located in the staffing area and one in the main hallway leading to the clients rooms. Each bathroom is equipped with a working toilet, and running warm water with a temperature of 105 degrees. The home has sufficient activities, including books, age-appropriate toys, arts/craft materials and all furniture is in good repair. The backyard is gated, with a cement patio, an empty shed and dog run. The backyard is clear of debris and clean. There is a garage stocked with cleaning supplies, storage space, and an extra refrigerator with overflow food. There is a 2000 GMC Safari in good working condition, properly maintained, lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts and is available to transport clients if needed. Continue to LIC 809-C

The following required documents were posted, License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions inaccessible to children in care. Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum. Menu present and posted in the kitchen area on the fridge. Working telephones are available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible to children. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguisher up to date and in working order. Toilets wash basin, bath, and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedroom required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. Facility free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today’s inspection, Physical Plant, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, Client Records. A total of 5 staff files, 2 children’s files were reviewed. LPAs also conducted 3 staff interviews and 2 client interviews during todays inspection, no concerns for follow up was noticed. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility fees and all the staff were fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. The facility has been cited for Health-Related Services and Children’s Records. A Technical Violation was also given for Client Medical Assessment. See 809-D page. An exit interview was conducted with Joanna Waters, House Manager and a copy of this report, and the Appeal Rights will be provided to the facility.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegation above cannot be substantiated due to lack of evidence. 4 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that they are unaware of how hot the home gets and that once it reaches a certain temperature the AC unit is set to turn on. Before LPA could conduct the 10-day inspection, the facility had already placed a covering over the thermostat preventing clients from altering the temperature of the home without staff consent. During initial inspection on 10/3/2024 LPA observed the temperature of the home to be between a minimum of 68 degrees F and a maximum of 85 degrees F. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

On Decemeber 16, 2024 at approximately 10:15 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Orlando Areizaga and Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced inspection to Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an initial 10-day complaint investigation on the above allegation(s). LPAs Areizaga and Shulz met with Administrator (AD), Carol Ayers who granted LPA access to the facility. Upon arrival, LPAs observe the roof of the STRTP was being worked on due to a leak in the home. The roof had left over materials that were not secured to the roof. During the physical plant inspecting of the exterior, LPAs noted to AD for staff and clients to be careful on the side of the home where the materials were not secured. AD stated they will add a sign on the door leading to the exterior of the home warning staff and clients to be careful. A sign was added to the door leading to the exterior before LPAs left.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation(s) cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements throughout the investigation process. During the investigation LPA Areizaga was informed the residents toilet was fixed. Interviews conducted confirmed that staff addressed the pest issues at the facility by conducting regular pest control services. During LPA’s inspection on 12/10/24, LPA did not notice any mold in the facility only the smell of mold. 4 out of 6 interviews conducted confirmed that staff have address the mold smell at the facility. Additionally, minor in question refuses to attend school regularly and staff encourage them to attend school but can’t force them. LPA was informed that residents help create the monthly activity plan. It was confirmed during multiple interviews that residents can participate in activities but can have their privileges revoked if they do not attend school or misbehave. Finally, records review confirmed by LPA that client in question refused their medications on a regular basis and staff denied this allegation. LPA was informed that if a resident requests any clothing, staff will purchase the clothing with-in a reasonable time but client in question refused to agree with the reasonable time frame staff provided to go shopping for clothing. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On March 4, 2025, at 10:05 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Orlando Areizaga and Sara Luman-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection to Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator,Carol Ayers and was granted entry. Prior to the meeting LPA Areizaga initiated the complaint investigation on December 10th, 2024. No deficiencies were cited during that inspection. LPA Areizaga requested the following documents: needs and services plan, incident reports, medication log, client personal property and valuables log, resident points distribution sheet, and unusual incident report. LPA’s Areizaga and Shulz conducted 7 interviews between December 2024 and February 2025 (CONT TO C PAGE)

narrative:
During the investigation LPA Areizaga received consistent statements regarding staff engaging in a physical altercation with minor in care. 8 out of 8 confidential interviews confirmed staff did physically fight minor in care inside the facility. It was also confirmed that staff have slept at the facility while not on shift. LPA was notified that staff have permission from management to stay at the facility while not working due to them living far from the facility, which is not approved under their Plan of Operation. Based on LPAs observation and interviews which were conducted and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are founded to be substantiated. California Code of Regulation Interim Licensing Standard (LIS) are being cited on the attached on LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and Appeal Rights were discussed with Administrator, Carol Ayers. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left at the facility.

During the investigation LPA obtained inconsistent statements during the investigations process about staff not treating minor with respect. 5 of 8 interviews confirmed that minor(s) in care are always treated with respect. In addition, Client 1 confirmed there is a lack of respect towards minor(s) in care, but LPA Areizaga was unable to confirm with Client 2 the above allegation due to them not being available. Lastly, Social Workers did not have any concerns with minor(s) being treated without respect while in care. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated.

narrative: On 11/2/2020 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced Comprehensive Inspection via Facetime with Carol Ayers, Administrator. LPA inspected the facility inside and outside. LPA reviewed four client files and four staff files. LPA observed the facility medication, hygiene supplies, staff and client files are kept in a locked cabinet. The chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet in the garage. The fire extinguisher has been serviced in the last 12 months. The First Aid kit is fully supplied. The facility license, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch/floor plan, foster care youth personal rights and foster care ombudsman information and COVID-19 posters are all posted and visible in public areas of the facility. Due to the State of Emergency and shelter-in-place ordinance put into place by the Governor of California as safety protection relating to the Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19), the department is limiting in-person contact. This inspection was conducted via Facetime. No deficiencies being cited at this time.

On 1/14/2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced Comprehensive Inspection for a 10-month inspection via Facetime with Carol Ayers, Administrator. LPA inspected the facility inside and outside. LPA reviewed five client files and three staff files. (See LIC858 and LIC859). LPA observed the facility medication, hygiene supplies, staff and client files are kept in a locked cabinet. The chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet in the garage. The fire extinguisher has been serviced in the last 12 months. The First Aid kit is fully supplied. The facility license, facility sketch/floor plan, foster care youth personal rights and foster care ombudsman information and COVID-19 posters are all posted and visible in public areas of the facility. The facility has at least a two day supply of perishable food and seven day supply of non-perishable food. Two clients and two staff were present. Maritza Jefferson, Executive Director (ED) stated she is working with Solano County for their Mental Health Approval and ED stated they are waiting for the site visit to be scheduled. Due to the State of Emergency and shelter-in-place ordinance put into place by the Governor of California as safety protection relating to the Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19), the department is limiting in-person contact. This inspection was conducted via Facetime. No deficiencies being cited at this time.

On 07/08/2021, at approximately 1 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon arrived at this facility to conduct a case management inspection, the purpose of which was to assess the facility’s readiness to have its license be taken off “Provisional” status. LPA was met and let in the facility by Administrator Carol Ayers through the front door which appeared to be its one central entry point. Ms. Ayers checked this LPA’s temperature and proceeded to give a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant: there is an office area where locked cabinets were located, one for confidential client and personnel records, within which the facility’s ‘sharps’ were also housed, one for medications, and one for miscellaneous personal supplies for clients. The kitchen refrigerator contained perishable food items sufficient for at least three days, and next to it was a pantry cabinet stocked with non-perishable goods. Snack items were observed to be readily accessible for clients. An additional refrigerator/freezer was located in the garage area which had locked access from the dining area—this refrigerator/freezer contained more perishable food items. Also in the garage area were more non-perishable items sufficient for at least seven days along with additional emergency supplies. The common bathroom’s toilet, sink, and bathtub/shower were in working order. The clients’ bedrooms were equipped with appropriate furnishings and sufficient storage spaces for personal possessions. The pathways and egresses were unobstructed and the facility’s front and back yards were free of clutter. There is a locked shed in the backyard that mostly housed personal belongings of previous clients—no potentially hazardous gardening or yard maintenance equipment was observed on the premises, and there were no indications that the facility has any firearms. The facility’s license was posted in an accessible area along with the Emergency Disaster Plan. The property has no bodies of water. The facility is clean, sanitary, and in good repair. Staff files were reviewed and found to contain the following: Background Check Status Results including CACI (Child Abuse Central Index) clearances. Training records included documentation showing completion of Mandated Reporter training. Also present in personnel files were signed Statements Acknowledging Requirement to Report Child Abuse, and documentation of performance evaluations. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

Client records included current Needs & Services Plans, medical records including Physician’s Reports or documentation showing attempts to obtain said report(s), Admission Agreements, medication records or logs, and JV-223’s (Orders on Applications for Psychotropic Medications) where needed. Interviews were conducted with the two current clients, both of whom indicating in their respective statements that the facility is providing adequate services and personal provisions to meet their needs, and that they feel safe in the facility. Neither client expressed any grievances against the facility. Based on these interviews, the following were also indicated: the administrator is onsite for a sufficient amount of time during the week, the staff-to-client ratio is adequate, the quality and quantity of food for the clients is acceptable, direct-care staffers utilize trauma-informed care practices including de-escalation techniques to address crisis situations, the clients receive mental health services, the clients are afforded the opportunity to participate in Child & Family Team meetings and in their own case plans, and that the clients were advised of their personal rights and of the house rules. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection; the facility is found to be in substantial compliance with the Interim Licensing Standards and/or Title 22 Regulations. The facility is therefore considered to be in good standing in regards to the following: -there are no health or safety concerns with the facility -the facility has obtained its Mental Health Approval from DHCS (Dept. of Health Care Services) -the facility has Medi-Cal Certification -the facility has a Mental Health Contract -the facility has been accredited by CARF (Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) A non-provisional license will be issued to this facility. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report is being provided to this facility.

On 7/13/21, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Carol Ayers, Administrator for the purpose of conducting an SB484 Psychotropic Medication inspection. The inspection was rescheduled due to an unexpected emergency. LPA Stidman printed the facility permanent license and left it with the Administrator.

Based on IB’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. No Interim Licensing Standards or Title 22 Regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report is provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility on 07/08/2021, at approximately 4 PM, to deliver complaint allegation findings. LPA met with Carol Ayers, Administrator, and discussed the above allegation. During the investigation of Lack of supervision resulting in a minor sexually assaulting another minor in care. LPA toured the facility with Carol Ayers, Administrator on 4/28/21. On this inspection, LPA inspected the physical plant inside and out, reviewed two client files and obtained documentation for the complaint investigation. LPA obtained the agency STRTP admission agreement, identification and emergency information, preplacement appraisal information, case notes and incident reports from 4/2/21 – 4/27/21 and hand written notes between clients. This investigation was conducted by Investigations Branch (IB) Investigator Shannan Borton. IB reviewed the Child Welfare System/Case Management System (CWS/CMS) records, interviewed four clients, eight staff, Alameda county social worker for client C2 and law enforcement reports. Client 2 (C2) was not willing to discuss details and client 4 (C4) reported it was consensual then stated C2 assaulted her (C4). Staff did not observe the incident. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 7/28/21 at 11:45AM. During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Chelsea Dailey House Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. All files and medication documents were reviewed and a medication count was conducted during the inspection. LPA reviewed two child’s records on site on 7/28/2021 at 11:45am. LPA interviewed two children currently taking psychotropic medication at 2:00pm. LPA reviewed one staff personnel file on site on 7/28/2021 at 11:45am. LPA interviewed one staff on site at 11:45am. Facility cited for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Training Requirements 87065.1(d)(3)(F) Annual Training. Staff training must include oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications for children in foster care. Staff file review is missing this documentation. Facility cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulation 80075 Health Related Services )Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription according to the physician's directions. The medication count showed the facility was not administering medication according to the physician's directions. Facility cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulation 80075 Health Related Services 80075(k)(7). The licensee shall ensure for each client, of a record of centrally stored prescription medications. The facility did not have a Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) for C2 Aripiprazole started 7/20/21 One Advisory Notes for Technical Assistance was given for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulation 80075 Health Related Services 80075(k)(4) No person other than the dispensing pharmacist shall alter a prescription label. Staff used a red marker to write the start date on the prescription bottle. LPA conducted exit interview with Chelsea Dailey House Manager at 4:30 pm. LPA provided the Summary Report to Chelsea Dailey House Manager upon completion.

On 3/28/2022 at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Rivera met with Carol Ayers,Administrator. Administrator assisted with the inspection. There were no children or any other staff present at the facility. At 10:03 AM, LPA completed a walk-through of the facility, inside and out. LPA observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. There is a working washer and dryer in the garage. There is a staff office and two living rooms. The backyard is fenced, clear, and clean. LPA inspected and reviewed the following: Physical Plant License and Personal Rights posted COVID-19 information is posted, along with a check-in area by the front door that has a sign-in log, thermometer, sanitizer, and disinfectant wipes. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible Nonperishable Foods more than one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum Menu present and posted Carbon monoxide detector and Smoke Detector fully functioning First Aid Kit fully stocked Common Room available and Dining area with enough seating, furniture in good condition Medication centrally stored and locked Staff Office is located in the home with locked staff and client files 2 fully charger Fire Extinguishers Toilets, sink, bath and shower fixtures in good repair, there is soap and paper towels Bedrooms have required linen and furnishings are in good repair Motor Vehicle properly maintained, lights and working seat belts. Facility free of vermin Continued on page LIC 809-D

Disaster Preparedness Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available Monthly Drills conducted and documented Staffing Records 5 Staff files reviewed Criminal record clearances verified First Aid Certificates are current Certified Administrators certificate valid and current, job title/qualification verified, 24 Hours required training verified. 40 Hours required annual training verified Client Records 2 Clients files reviewed 1 out of 2 Needs and Services Plans were not signed and will be corrected. Centrally Stored Medication and log reviewed Psychotropic Medication and log reviewed Cash Resources and Personal Property reviewed Core/Therapeutic Services Trauma Informed Practices are implemented as needed (including specialty mental health services and extracurricular activities and social supports). An exit interview was conducted with Carol Ayers and a copy of this report was provided via email. Appeal rights were discussed and provided.

This amended report supersedes report dated 07/15/22. Licensing Program Analyst Dawn Eunice (LPA) conducted a case management inspection to the above facility for the purpose of ensuring compliance with Interim Licensing Standards, Health and Safety Code and Title 22 regulations regarding criminal record clearances. On 7-15-22 LPA Euince discovered none of those five staff were/are properly associated. When LPA arrived on 7-15-22, to deliver reports regarding the previously identified people, there three additional staff, present and caring for children, who are not properly cleared/associated. All eight staff without clearances/associations are identified on the confidential names list; those identified 7-13-22, then the three additional staff/individuals present on 7-15-22. LPA discovered one of those eight staff have been working/present/taking care of children since August 2021. Based on documentation received it was confirmed that the staff members were associated to facility # 075600345 in San Ramon. On 7/19/22 LPA Eunice replied to the email stating the staff needed to be associated to the proper facility #487003584 subject to the citations and civil penalties. On 7/25/22 the Department received a letter stating all eight staff had been properly associated to the correct facility #487003584. In addition, it was asserted that Antinia Gregory personally called Guardian on a recorded call on 05/05/22 and received confirmation that three of the eight staff members who were recently hired were properly cleared and eligible for employment. Lastly, details were provided that proved that two staff members in question who were assured had no physical contact with clients until 06/01/22. The Department has thoroughly reviewed all the information provided to support your appeal. We reviewed emails, licensing investigative reports, and checked clearance for the eight staff members on Guardian. As of August 23, 2022 Guardian reflects all eight staff members to be properly associated to Paradise Adolescent Homes #487003584. Therefore, your appeal to overturn the citations and civil penalties was granted. Exit interview conducted with the administrator and a copy of this report was provided.

deficiencies.title: – Penalties
deficiencies.description: An immediate penalty of $100 per cited violation per day for a maximum of five (5) days shall be assessed if any individual required to be fingerprinted under Health and Safety Code Section 1522(b) has not obtained a California clearance or a criminal record exemption, requested a transfer of a criminal record clearance or requested and be approved for a transfer of an exemption.  After a review of facility records and a review of the Department’s Guardian website, 8 individuals do not have these mandated clearances and/or the proper associations.

narrative: Based on interviews conducted by LPA Carmona during the investigation process 5 out of 10 interviews conducted, all corroborated that they never had knowledge or observed youth being molested by staff while in care. LPA Carmona received screen shots of messages disclosing youth in care witnessed staff being inappropriate to youth in care, but LPA Carmona attempted and was unable to interview those clients. In addition, LPA Carmona was also not able to retrieve text messages disclosed to have been sent from staff to youth in care. This agency has investigated the complaint alleging staff molested youth while in care. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided via e-mail to the Administrator.

narrative: Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations facility staff yell at minor in care, minor is not being accorded dignity between staff at the facility and facility is not providing adequate food to client cannot be substantiated because statements given in the 14 interviews conducted from 9/20/22- 11-/30/22 did not corroborate. 4 confidential interviews conducted on 11/02/22 11/30/22,11/29/22 and 09/20/22 alleged facility did not provide adequate food to client. 10 confidential interviews disclosed the facility did provide adequate food to clients. 9 confidential interviews corroborated that staff do yell at minors and in care. The yelling or raising of the voice from the staff occurs when minors are not following facility rules or when there is non complaint behavior from the client. Confidential interviews dated 11/18/22, 11/29/22 and 11/30/22 corroborated that minors are not being accorded dignity between staff at the facility staff in the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the Administrator.

LPA Carmona met with Carol Ayers, Administrator. narrative: On 2/16/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Melissa Williams Direct Care Staff for the purpose of a Plan of Correction (POC) inspection. LPA requested documentation to clear the POC from the SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection on 7/28/21.The facility was unable to produce any documentation after Melissa Williams Direct Care Staff made several attempts to reach other staff for assistance. Facility is cited on the LIC809D page under the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (iLS) regulation 87044(a) Inspection Authority. In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80044, the following shall apply. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 04. Administrative Actions, Title 22 regulation 80044(c)(1) states The licensing agency shall have the authority to inspect, audit, and copy client or facility records upon demand during normal business hours. Records may be removed if necessary for copying. Removal of records shall be subject to the requirements specified in Sections 80066(c) and 80070(d). The licensee shall ensure that provisions are made for the examination of all records relating to the operation of the facility. A copy of this report was reviewed with Melissa Williams Direct Care Staff and emailed to the facility as LPA was unable to print due to technical difficulties.

On 02/14/23 at 11:25 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management to the above Short Term Residential Program (STRTP) regarding information obtained that the facility does not have a Head of Service on site. It was also disclosed that a staff member hit a client in care. LPA met with Chelsea Dailey (who assisted with the inspection). STRTP/ consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 living rooms, a kitchen, and a staff office. The backyard is free of debris. The facility is in compliance at the time of the inspection. LPA conducted an interview with House Manger and gathered contact information for the Head of Service. An exit interview was conducted with Chelsea Dailey, House Manager and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegation facility staff did not provide transportation is substantiated because the facility did not provide transportation to work for a client in care on 11/29/22, 1/7/23, and 1/13/23. The facility’s Program Statement states in section 3 the facility will provide clients transportation to employment. During three confidential interviews on 11/29/22 it was disclosed transportation needs of the client couldn’t be met due to the facility only having one vehicle and distance of the client’s workplace. The facilities Program Statement in section 7 also states there will be two agency authorized vehicles at the facility to ensure that adequate transportation needs are met. When LPA Carmona opened the complaint at the facility on 12/02/22 there was only one vehicle at the facility to ensure adequate transportation needs were met. In addition, two confidential interviews conducted on 12/02/22 corroborated that the facility had not had two vehicles for over a year. During 2 confidential interviews on 11/29/22 and 1 confidential interview on 12/02/22 it was disclosed the facility was not aware their Program Statement contained the terms in section 3 and 7. Although the facility was not aware of the terms in their Program Statement once LPA Carmona addressed them, they made sure to try and transport the client in care to and from work. 7 confidential interviews conducted from 11/29/22- 1/06/23 corroborated that the facility was accommodating transportation to and from work for the client in care to their best ability. Although the client was not provided transportation on 1/07/23 and 1/13/23 it was disclosed in a telephone conversation on 1/13/23 that the facility staff would not be driving in unsafe weather conditions to transport client to work. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, (ILS 87022.1), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.”) An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the House Manager.

Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process on the allegation’s facility is not providing medication to client cannot be substantiated because statements given in 3 of the 14 confidential interviews conducted on 12/02/22, 12/12/22, 1/06/23 corroborated the facility attempted to obtain medication refills for the client. In addition, case notes dated 11/20/22, daily logbook dated 11/23/22 and an email dated 11/29/22 prove that the facility staff was attempting to refill client’s medication but were not able to reach the primary care physician. The facility was able to get ahold of the public health nurse and obtained the prescription refill. MAR’s logs dated November 2022 indicate the client was not administered three medications. Upon the client’s intake on 11/10/22 the facility became aware that the client did not have enough medication for the remainder of the month. 2 confidential interviews conducted on 12/06/22 corroborated that clients are receiving their medications daily. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the House Manager.

deficiencies.description:
Program Statement: "the facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation."

This requirement was not met as evidence by: In the facility's program statement, it states that .."transportation arrangement's be accommodated for...employment. In addition, it states "the facility will have two agency authorized vehicles at each home to ensure adequate transportation needs are met."
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility to provide documentation indicating a change in intake procedures to include information regarding clients transportation needs for employment. In addition, Section 3 and 7 of the program statement is to be amended so as to reflect that the facility will forego the policy regarding transportation accommodations for clients employment and number of vehicles at the facility. Amended section should be submitted to CCL by 02/28/23

narrative:
On 3/23/23 at 8:45 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced annual inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools and met with Administrator, Carol Ayers. LPA toured the interior and exterior of the facility during the inspection today. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms, which had all the furniture, linens and lighting as required. LPA observed 2 bathrooms available to clients which were appropriately equipped with toilet paper, paper towels and running warm water as required. LPA observed that the shower and toilet were in working condition as required. The kitchen had a adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the client in care. LPA observed that the facility appliances, refrigerator, and freezer to be clean and function as required. LPA observed that sharps, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored and were not accessible to clients in care. LPA observed a menu posted in the facility. LPA observed the laundry services available for the youth to complete their own laundry which is in the garage. LPA observed working carbon monoxide detectors and a fully charged fire extinguisher. LPA observed that the facility has a functioning telephone in the facility. The 2 living rooms and dining room were free of obstruction and had furniture in good repair. The office used by clinicians and administrator has a locked cabinet for client’s files and a locked cabinet for medication. All the posting requirements were available in a visible area. First aid kit was fully stocked and available. LPA observed that the facility vehicle appeared to be in good operating condition. The back yard and front yard were free of debris and in compliance. There are no bodies of water located on the property. Currently the facility has one client in care. LPA reviewed 1 client file and 5 staff files. A review of the staff files indicated the staff have current CPR and First Aid training. They also have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse check clearances. The client’s file contained all required documentation. LPA interviewed 2 staff and will return to interview 1 client. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is current with their facility fees at the time of the inspection. Continue to page 2

Exit interview was conducted. No deficiencies were cited during the inspection today. A copy of report was provided to the Administrator.

On 3/23/23 at 8:45 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management to the above Short Term Residential Program (STRTP) regarding information obtained that the facility does not have a Head of Service on site. It was also disclosed that a staff member hit a client in care. LPA met with Carol Ayers, Administrator (who assisted with the inspection). STRTP/ consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 living rooms, a kitchen, and a staff office. The backyard is free of debris and there are no bodies of water. The facility is in compliance at the time of the inspection. LPA Carmona conducted 9 confidential interviews and obtained the following documents for review: Job offer letter dated 10/28/21 and 10/31/22, Staff schedules for the month of January, Staff training logs, Communication logs and Virtual Therapy session dated 1/17/23, Progress notes for the months of March 2022, November 2022 and December 2022. Based on interviews conducted and documents reviewed LPA Carmona was able to confirm the facility does have a Head of Service. There were conflicting statements given during the confidential interviews about the allegation staff hit client in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed. There were no citations issued.

On 9/07/23 at 1:15 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 09/05/23 dated 8/28/23. LPA met with Chelsea Dailey, Facility Manager. STRTP/ consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 living rooms, a kitchen, and a staff office. The backyard is free of debris. The facility is in compliance at the time of the inspection. The Department received an LIC 624-LE on 09/05/23 which was dated 8/28/23. The client C1 was assaulted by a school peer on a school bus on the way to the facility and was taken to the Emergency Room to be treated per client’s request. Law Enforcement was contacted by hospital staff. On 9/05/23 LPA Carmona contacted the Facility Manager, and it was confirmed the Department was not notified the following business day of the incident that took place on 8/28/23. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Facility Manager. This case management investigation is closed, and the facility has been cited for Reporting Requirements 87061 (j)(1) (See LIC 809D).

deficiencies.description: (j)The licensee shall submit reports to the Department,. regarding any incident that involves law enforcement..(1) The licensee shall make an initial report .. no later than the next business day following each incident This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on a records review and telephone conversation with facility staff it was confirmed the Department was not notified the next business day of the incident which occured on 8/28/23.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA Carmona is to receive documentation by end of business day 9/22/23 on how the facility will ensure staff remain in compliance with reporting requirements.

narrative: Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above cannot be substantiated because statements given in 9 out of 9 confidential interviews conducted corroborated that client did not have access to a dangerous object. All statements given corroborated that the staff always keeps sharps locked up in a cabinet. In addition, 8 out of 9 confidential interviews corroborated that there was an altercation that occurred between a minor (Y1) and staff. Although the altercation between staff and minor (Y1) occurred it was not initiated by the staff. The staff member intervened by stepping in front of another minor (Y2) to protect the minor (Y2) from being hit by minor (Y1). Lastly there were conflicting statements about staff hitting the minor (Y1) accidentally while trying to block minor (Y1) punches or if it was intentional. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the Facility Manager.

LPA Carmona met with Chelsea Dailey, Facility Manager. During the investigation, LPA Carmona reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history and criminal background check for staff. LPA Carmona also reviewed the client’s needs and service plans, Personal Rights Training Certificate, Pro-ACT Certificate, Case Notes, Communication Log dated 8/02/23 and LIC 624-LE dated 08/02/23. narrative: On 12/08/23 at 10:30 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management to the above Short Term Residential Program (STRTP) regarding an incident report received by the Department. LPA met with Carol Ayers,Administrator (who assisted with the inspection). STRTP/ consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 2 living rooms, a kitchen, and a staff office. The backyard is free of debris and there are no bodies of water. The facility is in compliance at the time of the inspection. On 12/01/23 the Department received an incident report regarding a client driving the facility vehicle onto the street and returning to the facility. The client was able to access the facility vehicles keys by entering the staff office and opening the desk drawer where the keys were stored. Based on interviews conducted it was confirmed there were 2 staff members present as the incident unfolded. The facility staff have put a plan in place where all keys are locked in a cabinet. In addition, the clients will not be allowed to be in the staff office moving froward even if staff are present. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Carol Ayers, Administrator. This case management investigation is closed. An advisory note was given during this visit.

Licensing Program Analyst Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on 03/07/2024 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 3 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 03/07/2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee contacts law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Carol Ayers, the facility Administrator.

On 3/14/24 at 11:58 a.m. Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jacqueline Carmona and Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced annual inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools and met with Administrator, Carol Ayers. LPAs toured the interior and exterior of the facility during the inspection today. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms. 2 client bedrooms had all the furniture, linens and lighting as required. Bedroom 3 has been converted into an office and furniture is in good repair. LPAs observed 2 bathrooms available to clients which were appropriately equipped with toilet paper, paper towels and running warm water of 110 degrees as required. LPAs observed that the shower and toilet were in working condition as required. The kitchen had a adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the client in care. LPAs observed that the facility appliances, refrigerator, and freezer to be clean and function as required. LPAs observed that sharps, disinfectants, and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored and were not accessible to clients in care. LPAs observed a menu posted in the facility. LPAs observed the laundry services available for the youth to complete their own laundry which is in the garage. LPAs observed working carbon monoxide and fire detectors and a fully charged fire extinguisher. LPAs observed that the facility has a functioning telephone in the facility. The 2 living rooms and dining room were free of obstruction and had furniture in good repair. The office used by clinicians and administrator has a locked cabinet for client’s files and a locked cabinet for medication. All the posting requirements were available in a visible area. First aid kits were fully stocked and available. LPAs observed that the facility vehicle appeared to be in good operating condition. The back yard and front yard were free of debris and in compliance. There are no bodies of water located on the property. Continue to page 2

Currently the facility has 2 clients in care. LPAs reviewed 2 client files and 5 staff files. A review of the staff files indicated the staff have current CPR and First Aid training. They also have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse check clearances. The client’s file contained all required documentation. LPA interviewed 3 staff and 2 clients. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is current with their facility fees at the time of the inspection. Exit interview was conducted. During todays visit the facility was cited 87075.1(g)(1) and 87075.1 (e) (Refer to the LIC809D). A copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to the Administrator.

Based on the evidence obtained/reviewed, in calendar notes, daily log sheets and in witness interviews, the above allegations cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements obtained throughout the investigation process. LPA obtained consistent information in witness interviews when discussing clients’ personal rights. Staff members denied the allegations and confirmed that C1 had a lot of behavior issues and constantly eloped from the facility which cause missing scheduled appointments. It was also confirmed that nobody witnessed or heard clients being threatened while in care. Also, LPA learned that proper shoes were not purchased initially but they were purchased when C1 requested them. Lastly, LPA learned that medical information was provided to the responsible party initially, but it was oversight between all the paperwork. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted and copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided during today’s visit.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez conducted a complaint inspection to the above Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) for the purpose of delivering investigation findings to the allegations indicated above. The Department obtained the following documentation/evidence: children’s face sheets, children’s needs and services plans, hospital discharge instructions, staff daily logs, Health and Dental Update forms, printed e-mail messages, Healthy Together Nutrition Class information, Sutter Medical Foundation Hospital documents, Medications List, After Visit Summaries from Sutter Health, copies of calendars documenting medical appointments, Law Enforcement Contact Report dated 11-28-2023, additional Law Enforcement Contact Reports, Unusual Incident / Injury Reports, and Superior Court of CA County of Contra Costa Status Review Report. LPA Eunice conducted 6 confidential interviews between 04/30/2024 – 05/29/2024. (Cont. on LIC 9099C)

narrative: Client subsequently contacted 911 and requested to be taken to the hospital for evaluation even though staff at the facility were making attempts to advise the client that pain in the surgical area was normal. While at the hospital, client was administered pain medication. Lastly, 4 inconsistent staff members interviews indicated that it was unclear how the staff did not meet minor’s medical needs, and why the hospital staff never contacted the facility to inquire about the medication list. As it relates to the allegation of staff not meeting minor’s dietary needs, LPA conducted a review of the discharge paperwork/postoperative instructions and learned that the client was supposed to be on a soft diet which includes no sharp foods/chips. Client was given options by staff which included soft diet foods in the form of soups, popsicles, and ice cream which were declined. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were given. A copy of this report was provided to Supervisor, Chelsea Dailey.
investigation_findings: 13On June, 24, 2024 at approximately 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Paradise Adolescent Homes and met with Supervisor, Chelsea Dailey for the purpose of delivering findings. During the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check and facility personnel report summary. LPA conducted interviews with all appropriate parties. At 10:19AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above virtually over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection. The purpose of this Case Management Inspection was to address incidents that were disclosed during Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives' interviews with facility staff and clients. LPA Fremont met with Former Administrator Maritza Jefferson, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance was LPA AmyLe Tran.. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. In an interview with C2 on 05/04/2020 at 1PM, C2 stated that staff do not often check on clients when they are in common areas of the facility, and staff also do not enforce bedroom or bathroom rules. C2 explained that the clients will often go into each other's bedrooms to hang out, and also stated that clients will often go into the bathroom to use the toilet while another client is in the bathroom showering. These statements are corroborated by interviews with C3 on 05/04/2020 at 2PM, C4 on 05/04/2020 at 2:22PM, and C5 on 07/29/2020 at 8:25AM. In her interview, C3 stated that clients are not allowed in each other's bedrooms, but they often are anyway because staff are not always around to enforce the rules or catch clients violating the rules. When asked where staff usually are during shift, C3 responded the staff are usually in the office or in the living room. C3 also stated that sometimes staff will check on clients in common areas every 30 minutes, but other times they will go 2-3 hours without checking on clients. C4 stated in her interview that when clients are in their bedrooms, staff typically check on them every hour, however if they are in common areas of the house staff do not typically check on the clients. C5 reiterated these claims, reporting that staff were usually in the facility office or in the living room watching TV, and the clients would often go into each other's bedrooms because staff only performed checks every 1-2 hours. C5 also stated that S2 was the only staff who stayed on top of checking on the clients, but even then it was every other hour. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

These statements are contradicted by interviews with S1 on 05/04/2020 at 3PM, S2 on 07/16/2020 at 1:15PM, S3 on 07/20/2020 at 10:51AM, and S4 on 07/20/2020 at 10:58AM. S1 stated that room checks were performed every 15-20 minutes, and client checks did not have a set timeline but were typically every 5, 10, or 15 minutes depending on the clients and their behaviors. S1 did acknowledge, however, that sometimes the bedroom rules were not enforced if the clients were doing each other's hair or borrowing clothing. S2 also stated that it was common to find clients sitting on each other's beds. S3 stated staff check on the clients every 15 minutes, and then later stated that checks were performed every 20-30 minutes. S3 also acknowledged that clients often broke the bedroom rules if they were doing each other's hair or makeup. S4 reiterated that clients were checked on every 15-20 minutes, however the house was small and they could often hear clients in other rooms of the house without doing checks. Finally, in follow-up interviews with C3 on 07/29/2020 at 1:59PM, and C5 on 08/03/2020, both clients reiterated that staff were not performing regular client checks. When asked if she feels safe at the home, C3 told Licensing staff she did not feel safe due to the behaviors of the other clients because staff, although present in the home, were not always in the same room as the clients to observe incidents. C5 confirmed this, relating to Licensing staff an incident that had occurred where C2 touched C5's breast and kissed C5 while watching a movie at night alone in the living room. At the time, staff were in the office and had not checked on the clients. Based on the information gathered, including interviews with staff and clients, there is a preponderance of evidence that direct dare staff at the home did not have the supervision of the clients as their main priority at the home by not performing routine client checks. A deficiency is being cited per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Article 6, Section 87065.2(b)(1) - Personnel Duties. Please refer to the attached LIC809-D for more details. At this time, one deficiency is being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Paradise Adolescent Home with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

deficiencies.title: Personnel Duties
deficiencies.description: (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

narrative:
On 05/04/2020 at approximately 1PM, Investigator Austin conducted an interview with C2. C2 stated that she and C1 had a relationship at the home. She stated C1 would try to put her hands in her pants and C2 would push her away. When asked where in the home this had happened, C2 stated that it happened in the living room, the "front room", the bathroom, and the facility office. When asked where staff was during these incidents, C2 stated that staff did not check on clients often when they were in common areas. This statement is corroborated by interviews with C3, C4, and C5, who stated that staff usually check on clients every 30 minutes when clients are in their bedrooms, and staff do not usually check on clients in common areas. All clients stated that staff are usually in the office or in the living room watching TV. In her interview, C2 also disclosed to Investigator Austin two separate incidents that had happened involving her and C1 in the front room of the home. C2 described that on the day of 12/07/2019, all clients were hanging out in the front room of the house when C3 threw something at C2. C2 refused to give the item back to C3, and C3 responded by holding a butter knife to C2's neck. C2 told staff, who did not take the allegation seriously. On the same day, C2 described that she was doing wrestling moves on C1, when C1 put her finger in C2's buttocks. Both of these incidents are corroborated by interviews with C3 on 05/04/2020 at 2PM, C4 on 05/04/2020 at 2:22PM, and C5 on 07/29/2020 at 8:25AM. In C3's interview, she stated that all clients were in the front room getting ready to leave for an outing, when she threw her phone at C2. C2 would not give the phone back, so C3 held a butter knife to C2's neck. C2 responded by doing a wrestling move on C3, and while C2 was standing over C3, C1 put her toe in C2's buttocks. C4 also stated that C3 held a butter knife to C2's neck, but only heard about C1 touching C2 inappropriately as she had left the room already. C5 also stated that she witnessed the butter knife incident, and later heard about C1 touching C2 inappropriately. This is contradicted by a statement made by C1 in an interview on 05/04/2020 at 9AM. When asked if she had ever had any incidents with C2, C1 stated "of course." C1 went on to deny ever touching C2 or any of the other clients in an inappropriate manner. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

In an interview with S1 on 05/04/2020 at 3PM, S1 stated that she did not hear about the incident between C1 and C2 until the next day. S1 was informed by other staff that C2 had been doing wrestling moves on C1, and C1 had poked C2 in her buttocks. S1 acknowledged that she did not question any of the clients about this incident, and it was not talked about again until the police were involved approximately a month later. In an interview with S2 on 07/16/2020 at 1:15PM, S2 stated that on the day of 12/07/2019, C1 and C3 had come into the kitchen to complain that C2 was doing wrestling moves on them. C2 came into the kitchen to defend herself and asked S2 to "Tell C1 not to put her finger up my ass." C1 denied this happening, and S2 goes on to describe that all the girls left the kitchen laughing, so she and other staff did not take the allegation seriously , and did not question any of the girls further on the matter. No incident report was made. A week later, the incident with the butter knife was reported and as a result, the home removed all of its butter knives with serrated edges. In the coming months, C3 would disclose to S2 the incident when C1 touched C2 inappropriately. S2 stated that after C2 filed a police report regarding the incident, other staff at the home instructed her to retroactively fill out an incident report and date it back to December of 2019. In an interview with S3 on 07/20/2020 at 10:51AM, S3 stated that she found out about the incident between C1 and C2 a few days after it happened. She was told by other staff that C1 and C2 had been playing when it turned aggressive and C1 touched C2 in her buttocks. The other staff on duty was S4, who was at the grocery store at the time of the incident. Finally, in follow-up interviews with C3 on 07/29/2020 at 1:45PM and C5 on 07/29/2020 at 8:25AM, both clients stated that C2 had also been touching clients in an inappropriate manner. C3 stated an incident happened where she was sitting on the couch in the living room with C2 and C5, when C2 reached down and put her hand on C3 and C5's breasts. Both C3 and C5 removed themselves from the situation and went to their shared bedroom. This is corroborated by statements made by C5, who said that C2 had touched her breast and had also kissed her in the living room. Both clients indicated that staff were in the facility office during these incidents and had not been performing regular client checks. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

Statements from staff, clients, and review of facility documents suggest that clients of the home were left unsupervised on multiple occasions and that inappropriate touching between clients occurred during these times. While it is unclear which client definitively touched which other clients, statements overall support that inappropriate touching between clients did occur, and C1 touched C2 on the buttocks in an unwanted and inappropriate manner. Based on the information gathered, including staff and client interviews and review of facility files, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that a lack of care and supervision resulted in a client being sexually assaulted by another client while in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. The licensee is being cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Additionally, due to the substantiated allegation above, and based on interviews with staff, clients, and review of facility files, the licensee denied its clients the personal right to live in a home free from physical or sexual abuse by repeatedly allowing clients to be unsupervised in the home, resulting in inappropriate touching between clients. The licensee is being cited per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Article 6, Section 87072(d)(11) - Personal Rights. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Two deficiencies are being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, Plan of Correction discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Paradise Adolescent Home with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.
