deficiencies.description:
80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a): The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, interviews, and review of facility records, the licensee allowed its clients to be unsupervised on multiple occasions, resulting in inappropriate touching between clients. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to submit a plan to incorporate and train staff on 15-minute client checks into the home's supervision protocol, to include the location of each client and initials of the staff performing the client check every 15 minutes. This plan will be submitted no later than 11:59PM on 10/21/2020.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights (d) [...] in addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights (11) To be free from physical, sexual, or emotional, or other abuse [...]. 

This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on interviews and review of facility records, the licensee denied its clients the personal right to live in a home free from sexual abuse by repeatedly allowing the clients to be unsupervised, resulting in inappropriate touching between minors. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to submit a plan to retrain staff on client Personal Rights, which will include the name of the instructor and topics being discussed. This plan will be turned in no later than 11:59PM on 10/21/2020.

narrative:
At 1:06PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of addressing incidents that were disclosed during Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives' interviews with facility staff and clients. The purpose of the second portion of this inspection was to conduct a Regional Office-Initiated Informal Meeting with the Licensee. LPA met with Paradise Adolescent Home (PAH) Administrator Biana Jones, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were PAH Executive Director Maritza Jefferson, PAH Clinician Susan Carol, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and LPA AmyLe Tran. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 10/29/2020) In interviews with C1 on 05/04/2020 at 1300 hours, C2 on 05/04/2020 at 1400 hours, C3 on 05/04/2020 at 1500 hours, and C4 on 07/29/2020 at 0825 hours, all clients reported to CCL representatives that on one occasion, all clients had been in the front room of the house, when C1 took something of C2's and refused to give it back. In response, C2 held a serrated-edge butter knife to C1's neck. C1 then fought back by doing a wrestling move on C2, and threw C2 on her back. C3 added that C1 had a mark on her neck from the butter knife for days following this incident, and staff did not document it. C1 stated that when she tried to report the incident to staff, staff asked her why she hadn't just called them. All clients interviewed stated that this incident occurred while the clients were unsupervised for an extended amount of time. In an interview with S1 on 07/16/2020 at 1315 hours, S1 confirmed that this incident had occurred, however she had not found out about it until weeks later when C1 reported it to her. S1 asked C2 if this was true, and C2 confirmed it had happened. As a result, the facility removed all of its butter knives with serrated edges. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Based on the information gathered, client and staff statements support that C2 held a butter knife to C1's neck while clients were unsupervised in the facility. A deficiency is being cited per Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Article 6, Section 87078(b) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. Additionally, in an interview with S1 on 07/16/2020 at 1315 hours, S1 stated that on 12/07/2019, an incident had occurred where inappropriate touching between clients was reported. When the incident was originally reported by C1 on 12/07/2019, S1 stated that because the clients were laughing and joking, they did not take the allegation seriously and did not write an incident report. S1 stated that the following month, C1 reported the incident from 12/07/2019 to police and an investigation was launched. S1 went on to explain that once more information started to come out and CCL was notified, staff had S1 document the incident to "cover themselves". S1 explained she filled out two incident reports early in January 2020, one for the butter knife incident and one for the inappropriate touching incident, as both incidents had happened on the same day (12/07/2019), and staff instructed S1 to back date the reports. Upon further investigation of these incident reports, it was found the reports were backdated to 12/16/2019 and signed off by a supervisor on 12/17/2019 as the day they were completed, although the incident occurred on 12/07/2019. S1 ended her interview by stating it was management who had instructed her to back date the reports. Based on the information gathered, staff at the home did not fill out incident reports at the time the incidents occurred, and dates were fabricated on the reports showing an earlier date than they were actually written. A deficiency is being cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(b)(1)(E) - Reporting Requirements. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. The second portion of this inspection focused on conducting a Regional Office-Initiated Informal Meeting, with the purpose of addressing obstacles the home has faced since its transition from Group Home to Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), and to create a plan for the home to come back into compliance with CCL regulations. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

CCL called this meeting due to the facility facing recent challenges with operations, as well as to address recent deficiencies that the home was cited for. Specific challenges the facility has faced since STRTP licensure are as follows: 1. Staff training (specifically on Personal Rights, Care and Supervision, Reporting Requirements, and Personnel Duties 2. Staffing and Administration, including hours spent at the home and competency of facility staff on caring for STRTP level clients 3. Supervision of staff, including how the home ensures staff are preforming all of their duties 4. Appropriate client interactions 5. Enforcing program rules Proposed Plan: 1. The Licensee will submit an updated and current LIC500 - Staff Roster, to ensure that the Administrator is present in the home for at least 20 hours per week during normal working hours (Monday-Friday, 8AM-5PM), and to ensure adequate staff coverage at all times. Please submit no later than end of business hours on 10/30/2020. 2. CCL will offer the facility assistance from their Technical Support Program (TSP), during which time the facility will not be subject to enforcement actions and will receive guidance from the Department on how to regain compliance. Timeline to be determined by Licensee, should they agree to the offered assistance. 3. The Licensee will retrain all facility staff on Personal Rights, Reporting Requirements, Care and Supervision, Personnel Duties, Prudent Parenting Standards, and Administrative Duties. The Licensee will ensure that all training is approved for STRTP level. Plan for timeline of all training will be submitted no later than end of business hours on 11/30/2020 (30 days). All trainings shall be completed and proof of completion submitted no later than 01/12/2021 (75 days). Proof of completion shall include: dates/times, names of trainers, staff sign-in sheets, topics included. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

4. The Licensee will make note of any supervision changes in case notes as necessary, and continue to fill out the log book as usual. Starting December 2020 and continuing through June 2021, the licensee will submit log book notes and case notes for the 7th day of each month, to be submitted no later than the 29th of every month. 5. Beginning December 2020 and continuing through July 2021, the Licensee will ensure that all staff are fulfilling all of their personnel duties at the home, by conducting quarterly audits that address any staffing issues and identify what staff are doing well, as well as things that could be improved on. Quarterly staff audits shall be submitted no later than end of business hours on 01/03/2021, 04/01/2021, 07/01/2021. Shall any of these days fall on a weekend or holiday, the Licensee will submit on the next business day. At this time, 2 deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Biana Jones with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

On Tuesday 4/20/21, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Executive Director Maritza Jefferson to discuss an advisory regarding medication administration records (MARs). Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a televisit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA reviewed MARs and psychotropic MARs (PMARs) for residents in care at the facility for the months of April and May 2020. LPA observed that there were some minor inconsistencies, including medications not being listed under the month in which they were prescribed. For resident R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 4/20/21) MARs, Hydroxyzine is listed as a prescribed medication administered in April and May, but it is only listed on the prescribed medication list on the April log and not the May log. Additionally, not all administered psychotropic medications were documented on PMARs. For R1's records, Prazosin, Hydroxyzine, and Rizatriptan were documented on PMARs, but Clonazepam and Levetiracetam were not. Both of the latter medications are anticonvulsants, which are categorized as psychotropic medications, and should be documented on PMARs, even if administration is on an as-needed basis. No citations were issued at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Executive Director Maritza Jefferson, who agreed to receive an emailed copy of this report and return a signed copy.

It is not clear if R1 knew at the time that the first cup was not intended for R1. R1 does have a history of ingesting substances with intent to cause harm to self, but R1 was prescribed to multiple medications at the time and reported not thinking anything of being administered two cups of medications. S1 immediately realized that the first cup was empty and that R1 had taken those as well. R1 was told to try to throw up and was taken to the ER for a possible overdose. R1 was put on an IV and then released with no issues. The youth did not overdose but did have an excessive intake of psychotropic medication. The facility reported the incident to the required parties, and S1 was written up for not following the program's policy on medication administration. The facility also held a staff training on 6/3/20 to specifically address medication storage and administration. S1 was in attendance and completed a training questionnaire afterwards. LPA reviewed documentation of the training, sign-in sheet, and S1's post-training questionnaire. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. There is one citation, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80075(b). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Executive Director Maritza Jefferson, who agreed to receive the report by email and return a signed copy to LPA.
investigation_findings: 13On Tuesday 4/20/21 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver complaint investigation findings. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a televisit. LPA met with Executive Director Maritza Jefferson and informed of the purpose of this visit. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with director and involved resident and reviewed the incident report for the incident in question, medication documentation, and training documentation. Based on interviews and record review, on 5/28/20, staff S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 4/20/21) was preparing medication for administration to two youth by placing their medications in cups. Staff called youth to come and take their medication. While S1 was waiting for the youth, S1 continued preparing the medication. Youth R1 walked up and took the cup of medication on the table that S1 had already prepared but which was for another youth. S1 did not see this and handed R1 their cup of medication, which R1 took. [CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE]

deficiencies.description:
80075 Health Related Services
(b) Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review, Licen-
-see did not ensure youth was appropriately assisted with self-administration of medication due to a short lapse in supervision resulting in youth ingesting another youth's psychotropic medication. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility held a staff training on 6/3/20 that addressed medication administration and watching youth during administration. Involved staff S1 attended and completed post-training assessment.

narrative:
At 10:48AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to Paradise Home for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Residential Counselor Sabrina Shelton, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. At the time of this visit, one client and two staff were present in the home. (Please reference LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 06/29/2021) LPA toured the facility inside and out. The home was observed to be clean and free from hazards. The home is one story, with a kitchen, living room, family room, staff office, two full bathrooms, and 3 bedrooms which each house 2 clients. One bathroom is shared by the clients, and one bathroom is located in the staff office. Each room was observed to be well lit and all light bulbs functional. Each bedroom was equipped with 2 twin beds and ample storage space for clients' belongings. All hallways and passageways were observed to be free from obstruction. LPA toured the backyard, which was free from hazards. The backyard is surrounded by a fence on 3 sides. No bodies of water on the premises. LPA observed at least 7 days of nonperishable food and at least 2 days of perishable food in the kitchen refrigerator. The facility license, weekly menu, activities calendar, and client Personal Rights were posted prominently in the home. Sharps and chemicals are kept locked and inaccessible to clients. Medications are centrally stored in the staff office. During this inspection, LPA reviewed 3 client records and 3 staff records. All client records were complete with all required elements. For S3, the LIC503: Health Screening is missing a signature from a healthcare professional. An LIC9102 - Advisory Note was issued to the home for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80065(g)(2) - Personnel Requirements. Please see the attached LIC9102 for details. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

The home's thermostat was set to 72 degrees Fahrenheit. The kitchen faucet and client bathroom faucets measured 117.2 degrees Fahrenheit. All smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are functional. LPA observed hygiene items in the bathroom for each client. Handwashing and COVID-19 safety posters were posted throughout the home. No firearms on the property. LIC610 - Emergency Disaster Plan was observed in the staff office. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. One LIC9102 - Advisory Note was issued for 80065(g)(2) - Personnel Requirements to communicate best practice for staff record keeping. At this time, Paradise Home has been approved to transition from a Provisional License to a regular STRTP License. LPA Fremont will issue a new license once the change has been processed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Residential Counselor Sabrina Shelton, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

In an interview with W1 on 02/24/2021, W1 stated that during a recent provider meeting for C1 on 02/17/2021, W8 had reported that C1 was regularly smoking marijuana as part of their coping skills when they were depressed or feeling anxious. Per W1, W8 continued by saying C1 was allowed to take daily 10 minute walks in the neighborhood to smoke marijuana outside, and didn't see a need to make C1 stop because it was the only coping skill C1 had. In interviews with C1, C2, W2, W3, W4, W5, W6, W7, W8, and W9, all interviewees stated that smoking was never allowed inside or outside of the facility, and that staff would never grant permission for a client to smoke marijuana as a coping mechanism. C2 stated they had never seen C1 smoking in the home, has never heard of it being an issue at the home, and stated the clients were not allowed to smoke as a coping skill. W2 and W3 both stated they had never heard of any complaints of inappropriate behavior or drug use at the home. W2, W7, and W8 all stated they were aware that C1 smokes marijuana, but that C1 had never done it on facility property and it would not be permitted. C1 denied this allegation, stating they never smoked inside or outside of the facility. In regard to W1's statement that W8 reported C1 was smoking in the facility as a coping skill, W8 stated this was false, that smoking was not allowed even for coping. W8 denied telling anyone they had given C1 permission to smoke, and that C1 was allowed to go on walks but not for the purpose of smoking. W7 and W4 both stated that marijuana paraphernalia had been found once during a room search of C1's room, but confirmed C1 had never smoked in the home. W5 also conducted an investigation into this incident for their own agency, and found the allegation to be unfounded based on interviews with staff and clients. During this investigation, there was insufficient evidence to substantiate that staff allowed C1 to smoke marijuana. C1 initially disclosed that facility staff allowed them to smoke in the backyard, but later declined to speak further on the matter because they stated it was untrue. Although the allegation "Staff is allowing a minor to smoke marijuana while in care" may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Sabrina Shelton, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13At 11:01AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to Paradise Home STRTP for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Complaint Investigation Inspection. LPA met with Care Coordinator Sabrina Shelton, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 3 ambulatory clients. (Please reference LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 09/10/2021) On 02/19/2021, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Paradise Home with one allegation: "Staff is allowing a minor to smoke marijuana while in care." This complaint was assigned to LPA Fremont and was investigated by Investigator Dinah Watkins of Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB). (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

13At 11:46AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to Paradise Home to conduct an unannounced Complaint Investigation Inspection and to deliver findings for a complaint received on 05/11/2021. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 11/24/2021). On 05/11/2021, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Paradise Home with two allegations: (1) "Staff mishandled a minor while in care," and (2) "Staff did not seek timely medical attention for a minor while in care." On 06/04/2021, LPA AmyLe Tran traveled to the home to notify the licensee of these allegations and to request relevant documentation. LPA Fremont returned to the home on 11/18/2021 to collect additional documentation and to conduct interviews with staff and clients. Regarding these allegations, LPA Fremont conducted interviews with 2 clients and 5 staff. LPA obtained the following information: According to all those who were interviewed, if a client expresses to staff that they are feeling sick or injured, the staff protocol is to immediately offer the client medical attention, either by making an appointment at the nearest urgent care during normal business hours or by taking the client to the closest emergency room if no appointments are available. All those interviewed stated there was no reason that staff would ever deny a client medical attention, although clients were able to refuse treatment if they wanted. Neither of the clients who were interviewed were living at the home when these allegations were reported, and could not speak to the incident in question. All staff who were interviewed stated that the client named in this complaint (C1) had a history of aggression and making false allegations about staff. All staff stated that C1 had been the aggressor for the duration of the incident on 05/07/2021, and had been making verbal threats and exhibiting physical aggression toward the staff involved. It was reported that San Ramon Police responded to this incident after C1 called 911, and both officers agreed with staff that the client had been the aggressor, and they did not feel the need to make a report for the incident. It is noted in the incident report dated 05/07/2021 and in staff shift notes for the same day that C1 had taken a video of the incident, but upon showing the video to the police, C1 was told that it only showed her being the aggressor toward staff, and that she needed to go to bed. All staff interviewed corroborated this information, but did not know where a copy of this video could be found as it was never provided to the licensee. All staff stated that the client had reported their foot was injured during the incident, but the client did not report this to the responding officers, and the client did not mention an injury or request medical attention at all in the days following the incident. The staff involved stated they would have offered the client medical attention if they had requested it, but did not because the client did not show any observable signs of injury. These statements are corroborated by an incident report dated 05/07/2021, as well as the staff shift notes for the day of the incident. LPA Fremont attempted to contact the client involved, the responding officers, and the complainant several times over the course of this investigation, but was ultimately unsuccessful in getting a response. This agency has investigated the allegations (1) "Staff mishandled a minor while in care," and (2) "Staff did not seek timely medical attention for a minor while in care," and has found that althought the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to the licensee.

A screening call was conducted with Maritza Jefferson, Licensee prior to visit. Safety precautions taken including mask-wearing and social distancing. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are three bedrooms and two bathrooms. One bathroom is for clients and one is for staff use. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are located in the garage and are not accessible to the residents. There are no firearms in the facility and all sharps are inaccessible to clients in care. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. Water temperature measured 112.9 F. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. Medications are located in the staff office and are locked. Medication that needed refrigeration was locked as well. Medication binder was inspected and LPA Ng let Care Coordinator Sabrina know that some boxes were left empty and signatures were missing. See attached LIC9102 for more details. The facility has Personal Rights and Emergency Disaster Plans are posted and in clear view. Licensee Maritza Jefferson came by to introduce herself to LPA Ng. LPA Ng introduced herself and assured Martiza to contact LPA for any questions or concerns. LPA Ng reviewed all 4 client files and were found to be complete. LPA Ng interviewed two clients.

All Staff training hours meet the minimum requirements, A review of Guardian Background Check System indicate that all facility staff have DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances (CAIC). The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the licensee did not ensure that there was enough staff supervision to prevent minors attacking minors while in care, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On 3/13/23 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Ashaki Gregory, Facility Manager and Sabrina Shelton, Care Coordinator and informed of the purpose of the visit. During this inspection, 1 client and 2 staff were present in the home. Safety precautions taken including mask-wearing and social distancing. At 1:30 PM, a client came home from school. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are three bedrooms and two bathrooms. One bathroom is for clients and one is for staff use. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are located in the garage and are not accessible to the residents. There are no firearms in the facility and all sharps are inaccessible to clients in care. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. Water temperature measured 116.6 F. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. Medications are located in the staff office and are locked. Medication that needed refrigeration was locked as well. The facility has Personal Rights and Emergency Disaster Plans are posted and in clear view. At 11:00 AM, LPA Ng observed the backyard. LPA observed it to be free from hazards. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is inaccessible to clients. LPA Ng reviewed all 4 client files and were found to be complete. LPA Ng interviewed 2 staff and 2 clients. ------------CONT. ON 809C---------------

At 12:00 PM, LPA Ng reviewed 3 staff files. All three staff files were complete except for the following: One staff member did not have a Tuberculosis test in their file. Facility was cited under California Code Of Regulations, Title 22, Chapter 6, Section 80066(a)(11) Personnel Records. Lastly, Out of the three staff files reviewed, all three staff did not have an active CPR/First Aid Certification. Facility was cited under California Code Of Regulations, Title 22, Chapter 6, Section 80075(f) Health- Related Services. All Staff training hours meet the minimum requirements, A review of Guardian Background Check System indicate that all facility staff have DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances (CAIC). At 2:45 PM, an exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Ashaki Gregory, Facility Manager.

narrative: On 12/4/2023 at 9:54AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and LPA Brenda Rodriguez conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the psychotropic medications inspection. LPA met with Ava Vallard, Shift Supervisor. Prior to the visit, LPA Hood was provided the LIC500, client roster, and list of clients currently prescribed psychotropic medications. The current census of the home is four clients, three clients were prescribed psychotropic medications. Of those three clients, two clients were eligible for psychotropic medications inspection review. LPAs reviewed two eligible client files. LPAs found that one youth had a parental consent document for psychotropic medications; however, not all psychotropic medications currently being prescribed were listed. LPAs delivered a Technical Violation for Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87070(b)(13). LPAs reviewed six staff files. LPAs observed no deficiencies in the staff files. LPAs conducted three confidential interviews at the facility. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility of the facility and observed no deficiencies. LPAs observed Ava Vallard, Shift Supervisor, conduct a medication count of four psychotropic medications. There were no issues with the medications count. LPA conducted an exit interview with Ava Vallard, Shift Supervisor, at 2:12PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

investigation_findings: 13On 1-12-24 1:19PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at Paradise Home, and met with Ashaki Gregory, Facility Manager, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that staff are not providing adequate supervision to the youths while in care. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and document research, which provided conflicting information. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove staff are not providing adequate supervision to the youths while in care. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Ashaki Gregory, Facility Manager.

narrative:
On 07/11/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam visited the facility listed above. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a case management regarding the facility and informed Shift Supervisor, Ava Ballard. During an investigation at the facility, LPA Lam noticed a bag of powdered laundry detergent was open and placed on top of dryer machine in the garage. Staff member reported that garage is always locked and inaccessible to clients. When clients enter the garage for laundry or therapy sessions, the clients are supervised. Staff member informed LPA that previous visits this was not an issue to leave powdered laundry detergent out in a locked garage. LPA Lam observed a broken chair in the garage. The leg of the chair is broken. LPA asked staff member when did it occur. Staff member informs it may have happened several months ago. LPA observed a broken bathroom sink counter inside the bathroom. Broken piece was removed, however edges of the counter is sharp and in access to clients. Staff member informs the incident happened recently and maintenance is supposedly coming to the facility 07/11/2024 to fix the broken counter. LPA observed broken door knob for one of the client's bedrooms. Staff member informs incident occurred 07/10/2024 overnight. Staff member informs LPA that door knob is supposed to fix the broken door knob as well. If maintenance does not come, staff member said another staff member will put on the door knob as of 07/11/2024 overnight. During the inspection of clients' safeguards for cash resources, LPA observed inaccurate records of accounts pertaining to cash resources. Staff member explains process of recording cash records were: client was to ask and receive a certain amount of cash (recorded under Amount Received), client was to spend the certain amount of cash (Amount Spent), hence Balance results in $0.

However, transactions were solely recorded of how much money was given and used to clients. It does not overall reflect allowance earned and saved by client. No citations were issued at this visit. An exit interview was conducted and appeals rights was discussed to Shift Supervisor Ava Ballard. A copy of the report was emailed to the facility.

narrative: On 09/18/2024 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno and LPA Celeste Aparicio conducted an unannounced visit to the facility Paradise Home. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the psychotropic medications inspection. LPAs met with Shift Supervisor, Ava Ballard and Manager, Ashaki Gregory. LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility facilitated by Shift Supervisor, Ava Ballard and Manager, Ashaki Gregory. LPAs observed the three client bedrooms, one bathroom, the kitchen and living room area, garage area, and one staff office room. LPAs observed the facility to be clean and the walkways to be free from obstructions. During the inspection, LPAs obtained an updated LIC500, client roster, and list of clients currently prescribed psychotropic medications. The current census of the home is four clients. Three clients were prescribed psychotropic medications. Of those three clients, none of the clients were eligible for psychotropic medications inspection review. LPAs reviewed three staff files and conducted two confidential staff interviews. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Shift Supervisor, Ava Ballard, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 11/22/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a case management visit to follow-up on a submitted incident report (IR). LPA met with Shift Supervisor Ava Ballard and informed of the purpose of the visit. An IR was submitted for an incident that occurred on 11/13/2024. According to the IR, it was reported that two clients, C1 and C2, got into an altercation at school. As a result, C2 made a threat to C1, instructing them not to talk about what happened. This incident is related to CSEC. The Shift Supervisor further explained that both clients were brought back in separate car rides and when they got back home they seemed fine. In the following days, an emergency CFT meeting was planned and conducted on 11/18/2024. During the meeting, the clients' behaviors were discussed, as well as their problems with CSEC. C1's mother confirmed that she had been involved with CSEC prior to arriving at the facility, and not because of the other client. Additionally, a safety plan has been created, and discussed several rules that C1 signed and has to abide by. On Monday, MeeChell Williams, a Human Trafficking Case Specialist from Community Violence Solutions, will begin providing ongoing support for C1. LPA reviewed the safety plan and conducted a confidential interview with Shift Supervisor. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Shift Supervisor, Ava Ballard, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Based on record review and confidential interviews obtained, LPA found that a staff member witnessed a physical altercation between clients that led to one of the clients being assaulted and did not attempt to prevent or de-escalate the situation prior to calling 911. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) are found to be substantiated. This is a violation of the Interim Licensing Standards, Personal Rights(c)(1). The facility is being issued a citation on the attached page LIC 9099-D. Based record review and confidential interviews obtained, LPA found that the facility did not send 26 Incident Reports to the Department between October 2023 and February 2024. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) are found to be substantiated. This is a violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Reporting Requirements 80061(b). The facility is being issued a citation on the attached page LIC 9099-D. Based on record review and confidential interviews obtained, LPA found that a client was not taken to get medical care after expressing they had injured themselves and that the client took themselves to the hospital to get care a few days later. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) are found to be substantiated. This is a violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Health Related Services 80075(a). The facility is being issued a citation on the attached page LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was left with Shift Supervisor whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights 87072(c)The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9..:(1)To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and confidential interviews, LPA found that a staff witnessed an altercation between clients that led to client being assaulted and did not attempt to prevent/deescalate the situation before calling 911.This poses an immediate health,safety,or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will submit training plan on the Emergency Intervention Plan for all staff to LPA by 11/21/24. Training will be completed by and proof of training will be sent to LPA by 12/13/24.

deficiencies.description: Health Related Services 80075(a) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services, including arrangement for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and confidential interviews obtained, LPA found that a client was not taken to get medical care after expressing they had injured themselves and took themselves days later. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will develop a plan to ensure all clients receive timely medical care. Facility will email plan to LPA by 11/21/24.

deficiencies.description: Personnel Requirements 87065(g)(3) Direct care staff shall meet the training requirements specified in 87065.1(c) and (d). This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, LPA found that not all staff have attended the required trainings and found discrepancies in training logs sent to LPAs. LPA was not provided the required initial training for new hire staff to review. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will develop a training plan for all staff to meet training requirements. All required training must be completed by 12/13/24. Facility will keep all completed training certificates in staff files for review by the Department.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements 80061(b) Upon the occurrence...of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made...(2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following occurrence of such event. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based record review and confidential interviews obtained, LPA found that the facility did not send Incident Reports to the Department. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will create an incident report log of incidents sent/unsent to CCL and responsible representatives. Facility will post a sign to remind staff to write incident reports by end of shift. Facility will email items to LPA by 12/13/24.

narrative: On June 18th 2025 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hanako Primer and Brenda Rodriguez conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPAs met with Evette Watts, Direct Care Counselor and Melissa Saidak, Head of Service. The Short-term Residential Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve six clients. Present during the inspection were two staff and three clients. LPAs reviewed three client files. LPAs conducted two client and two staff interviews. One client declined. LPAs toured the facility. LPAs observed one bedroom and one bathroom. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA tested the water temperature and found it to be 117 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 71 which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in staff office. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. LPAs observed back door screen removed from door frame and placed on the side of the facility. Staff provided work order to repair screen. Based on record review, head of Service stated that roommate compatibility agreements are done verbally, and there is no documentation. LPAs cited one Technical Violation under STRTP ILS 87087(e) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Evette Watts, Direct Care Counselor.

On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learning was embraced by about half of the clientele, with the other half preferring in-person learning.

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Marla Horne and Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced annual inspection on 7/26/21 at 10:00 AM. LPAs toured the facility inside and out and observed that the facility has three dual occupancy rooms and two bathrooms accessible to clients in care. LPAs observed the facility license and foster youth rights posted in a prominent area. Medications were locked in a box in a file drawer in the staff office. LPAs observed and tested the smoke/carbon monoxide detector. LPAs observed the refrigerators and freezers to be well stocked with perishable and non-perishable items. Fresh fruit was observed on the kitchen counter, a menu was posted on the refrigerator. LPAs observed the bedrooms to have required furniture and bedding. LPAs observed cleaning supplies and chemicals in a locked closet. The fire extinguisher was last serviced June 2021. The water in the kitchen and bathroom sinks warmed up to a required temperature. The shower and toilets functioned properly. Soap and paper towels were observed in the kitchen and hallway bathroom. The back bathroom was observed during the inspection as well but was not clean although it was cleaned prior to LPAs leaving the facility. Facility was cited for 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds as the facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair and LPAs observed that the back client bathroom was not clean during the inspection but was cleaned while LPAs were present in the facility. An exit interview was conducted with Jovan Metoyer.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and time-frames be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral inspection on 9/24/21 at 12:30 PM to the administrative office location for the agency located at 6060 Sunrise Vista Drive, Suite 2100, Citrus Heights 95610 and met with Laynee Kuhn, Chief Executive Officer for the agency. LPA made the visit to discuss the following incident reports for this facility: On 6/27/21 C1 left to the store while staff was in the kitchen. While at the store youth was asking for cigarettes and customer called law enforcement who then returned youth to the facility. LPA inquired as to whether staff were even aware of youth's absence prior to law enforcement returning youth to the facility. Ms. Kuhn states that she believed On 5/5/21 C2 threw a bowl of cereal at staff's back after one staff denied having a conversation C2 claimed to have had with C2. The incident appeared to possibly be confrontational between the C2 and staff. LPA learned that C2 has a history of being confrontation and volatile with staff and facility is working with C2 on tempers and reactiveness to situations as C2 could have responded the same if staff had not responded about the alleged conversation. Agency did not see this as confrontational or out of line for staff during this incident. On 4/23/21, C3 was playing with fire while in the facility living room. LPA asked Ms. Kuhn about contacting law enforcement following incidents of this nature and Ms. Kuhn states that they have historically contacted law enforcement but are typically told that they will not respond unless there is an active fire in progress. If staff are successful in putting out the fire, there is no need to respond. This was discussed during C3's child and family team meeting and youth is currently no longer in this placement. Facility typically will not accept youth with fire starting behaviors. LPA discussed with Ms. Kuhn the additional clarification needed on the reports to ensure all details including antecedents and follow up are captured appropriately. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection. Document provided to Ms. Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson arrived at Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) Administrative Office on 7/27/2021 at 4:30 PM. LPA Johnson spoke with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director to discuss the conclusion of this investigation initiated from incident reports and previous case management visits. LPA Johnson informed Ms. Kuhn this case was investigated by the Department’s Investigator Jami Eaton and LPA Cindy Johnson. The investigation included: on 12/19/2019, POYS provided initial notification to the Department, via email of an allegation obtained on 12/13/2019 that Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) has a “girlfriend” that is a staff person and provided three incident reports (see LIC 811 dated 7/27/2021). On 12/20/2019, POYS provided additional documentation including: an Internal Investigation (summary concluded on 12/20/2019) and one incident report concluding S1’s boundaries were inappropriate with NMD and S1 was terminated for providing inconsistent statements about an iPad (see LIC 811 dated 7/27/2021). Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson conducted a Case Management- Incident visit at POYS Administrative Office on 12/31/2019 with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director and Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director. Two staff (S2 and S3) were interviewed (see LIC 811 dated 7/27/2021). S1’s file was reviewed and copies obtained, including: LIC 501, Employee Address Change Form, Child Abuse Reporting Policy, Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Suspected Child Abuse, Allegation of Abuse and Social Media,

Training Logs, S1’s Statements dated 12/13/2019 and 12/20/2019, two photos of S1’s iPad, email dated 12/20/2019, Communication Notes dated 12/18/2019 and 12/19/2019, and S4’s Statement dated 12/18/2019 (see LIC 811 dated 7/27/2021). LPA Johnson conducted another Case Management visit on 2/12/2020 with Stephanie Fisher, Program Director and obtained copies of two incident reports of staff witnessing S1 return to two POYS facilities and transporting NMD, after being terminated, three Communication Notes dated 1/28/2020 and 2/10/2020 (see LIC 811 dated 7/27/2021). On 3/4/2020, POYS provided notification that when a former staff resigned, he alleged that NMD is having a sexual relationship with S1 and S1 is pregnant. A Suspected Child Abuse Report was made on 3/12/2020 and Investigator Jami Eaton was assigned to investigate this case on 3/16/2021. Interviews were conducted from 12/31/2020-6/2/2020 with S1, Probation Officer Winifred Temple, NMD and six current or former POYS staff (see LIC811 dated 7/27/2021). The allegation is whether S1 had a sexual relationship with NMD when NMD was a minor client of POYS. NMD was placed on 8/26/2019, turned 18 years old on 10/4/2019, and S1 was terminated on 12/20/2019. Both S1 and NMD denied there was a sexual relationship. Two staff directly heard statements from NMD admitting to having a sexual relationship with S1, however the statements did not indicate when the relationship began. So it is not possible to determine if the relationship occurred while S1 was employed by POYS (See LIC811 dated 7/27/2021). Based on the investigation, interviews conducted and records reviewed, the complaint allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. Facility signature is on hard copy. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

On 3/10/22 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Rivera made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 2/15/2022 regarding an incident report which mentions a possible violation of personal rights of a client. LPA met with Ulyous Ingram who assisted with the investigation. The STRTP was overall clean and in good repair. There were more than 7 days' of perishable and nonperishable foods. The toilets and showers were functioning. The dining table was broken due to a client engaging in property damage and a repair request has been put in with the maintenance team. There was a fire extinguisher, fully functioning smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector. Each room had bedding, beds, dressers, and sufficient storage space. No citations were issued. LPA Rivera conducted interviews with the Administrator, 2 Facility Managers, Case Manager, and 3 clients and gathered information on staff and clients.. An exit interview was conducted with Ulyous Ingram and a copy of this report was emailed to Jovan Metoyer at JMetoyer@paradiseoaks.com. Signature on file. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

One of the individuals involved in the incident provided different details than the reporting party and the other person involved in the incident only spoke with the reporting party about the incident in question. Not having consistent information or corroboration, the allegations are determined to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal process was provided.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/04/2022 at 11:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced inspection for the purpose of delivering findings with the Facility Administrator. Prior to the meeting, LPA Kinder reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports and facility personnel report summary. LPA Shelton conducted an inspection of the facility inside and out on 5/2/22 and no citations were issued. LPA Kinder conducted 5 confidential interviews between 7/25/22-7/26/22. LPA attempted to conduct an additional 3 interviews but they were either declined or calls not returned. LPA obtained and reviewed the following documents: Needs and services Plan for 1 client, Treatment Plan for 1 client, Case Notes, Placement History, Staff Training Records, and a staff/client roster. Based on 5 confidential interviews conducted, there is conflicting information provided by the reporting party who heard about the alleged concerns second hand. It is unclear as to the nature of comment as whether the comment was misheard. Regarding staff being verbally argumentative, again there is a difference of interpretation about the tone of the conversation. Continue....

narrative: On the allegation that staff failed to keep youth safe following a youth brandishing a weapon and threatening other youth, corroborating statements and documentation detail staff doing a search of the suspected youth’s room immediately after the first verbal threat by that youth was reported by another youth to staff. Additionally, a search of the youth’s person was conducted where the youth was asked to empty their pockets—no “pat-down” search is allowed in the facility. Law enforcement was also called and responded—this first search yielded no discovery of a weapon. After a second time that the threat was purportedly made again and upon this being reported to staff, another search was conducted with the involvement of law enforcement, at which time a folding knife was found on the suspected youth’s person—that youth was then detained by the responding officers. No other youths interviewed attested to seeing the suspected youth actually brandishing the weapon, nor did any of the interviewed staffers state that they saw the weapon before it was discovered. Beyond threats made by the suspected youth, no other youths were actually harmed due to this ordeal. On the allegation that there are Altercations between youths at the facility, though physical fights sometimes took place in the facility, no youths interviewed reported non-action on the part of the staff. The youths corroborated that staff do intervene when a physical fight breaks out between youths. Reviewed training records show that staff are educated on de-escalation techniques and, when needed, application of restraints. It is not a reasonable expectation that no altercations between youths happen in the facility—only that facility staff attempt to de-escalate situations or intervene when a physical fight does occur. Corroborating statements by youths indicate that staff do their part in this regard. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. No citations are being issued as a result of this investigation; a copy of this report along with a copy of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.

On 2/27/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor conducted an announced annual inspection at the above facility. LPA Lor met with the Administrator who provided a tour of the interior and exterior of the facility. There is currently no clients or staff associated to this facility. LPA conducted 1 interview with the Administrator. LPA reviewed 5 staff files. LPA toured the facility inside and out and observed that the facility has three dual occupancy rooms and two bathrooms accessible to clients in care. On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learning was embraced by about half of the clientele, with the other half preferring in-person learning.

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection 7/22/21 at 10:15 AM using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools and met with Carla Izzarelli, Administrator. LPA toured the facility inside and out during the inspection today. LPA observed three dual occupancy client bedrooms, that had all of the required furniture as required. LPA observed that there are two bathrooms available to clients and that the bathrooms were appropriately equipped with toilet paper and paper towels. LPA observed that the bathrooms had warm water as required. LPA observed that the showers and toilets functioned as required and showers had hot water as required. LPA observed that the facility had an adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the clients in care. LPA observed that there is a fire extinguisher in the facility and it was last inspected in June 2021. LPA observed that there is a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway near the client bedrooms. LPA observed that the smoke detectors functioned as required. LPA observed that the facility appliances, fridge and freezer appeared to be clean and function as required. LPA observed that sharps and disinfectants and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored where not accessible to clients in care. LPA observed a menu posted in the facility. LPA observed that the facility has laundry services available for each youth to complete their own laundry. LPA observed that the facility has a functioning telephone in the facility. LPA observed that the facility vehicles appeared to be in good operating condition. No citations were issued during the inspection today and exit interview was conducted with Ms. Izzarelli and document was provided.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral inspection on 9/24/21 at 12:30 PM to the administrative office location for the agency located at 6060 Sunrise Vista Drive, Suite 2100, Citrus Heights 95610 and met with Laynee Kuhn, Chief Executive Officer for the agency. LPA made the visit to discuss the following incident reports for this facility: C1 (see LIC811 dated 9/24/21) attempted to leave the facility on a bicycle and when youth returned, the bicycle was locked up and it was not clear if that was an attempt to deter youth from leaving or if it was staff locking up the bike because it was being used as a mode of transportation. C2 brought into the facility a bb gun that was not authorized to be with youth in the program. The facility confiscated the weapon and attempted to have law enforcement come and retrieve the weapon as it looked a real. Facility was informed that they were going to need to destroy the weapon themselves and that law enforcement would not take possession. LPA discussed with Ms. Kuhn the additional clarification needed on the reports to ensure all details including antecedents and follow up are captured appropriately. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection. Document provided to Ms. Kuhn.

three to five days to receive the results. The facility did not attempt to obtain results until August 16, 2021. Documentation obtained during the investigation indicates that youth were tested August 12, 2021, and their results were ready as of August 14, 2021. Test results were obtained verbally from the clinic. Until a subsequent visit to the facility on January 27, 2022, the facility did not have any documentation of the test results in question. Facility Administrator went to the clinic during the LPA's visit and obtained the documentation because it was not obtained previously. Amongst the results, there was one positive youth and two youth's results indicate that COVID was "Not Detected" and the narrative of the results states "re-testing should be considered" but these two youth were not re-tested. During the time from the date of the test to the date of the receipt of the COVID results these youth were not isolating in their rooms and were potentially exposing staff and other youth. The youth that was in the hospital for another reason returned to the facility on August 15, 2022, was retested but was in isolation in their room until their test results were received August 17, 2022 indicating they were negative. As a result of the information obtained, interviews conducted and documentation received, the allegation that the facility did not obtain the youths' COVID test results in a timely manner is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility was cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80070(b)(9) Client Records. Licensees are required to maintain a separate, complete, and current record in the facility for each client that also includes, but is not limited to, record of any illness or injury requiring treatment... The facility took four youth for COVID testing on August 12, 2021, but did not obtain the written documentation of the COVID testing results as necessary to meet the intent of this regulation. The written documentation was not obtained from the clinic until January 27, 2022. Facility obtained the COVID testing results via phone on August 16, 2022, but the results of the verbal contact with the clinic was not documented in client files. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Kuhn and documents provided along with appeal rights.

When LPA interviewed staff about COVID-19 protocols, it was discussed that staff were not sure what part they play in mitigating the spread of COVID outside of cleaning multiple times throughout the facility and following Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines and protocols. Staff also confirmed that they feel that COVID is so new and ever-evolving that they aren't confident that they could be trained in a thorough manner either. Confidential interviews revealed that while staff some have been trained to clean, maintain social distancing, wear masks and wash their hands often, they feel that the agency could provide additional training on how all of these measures are helpful and what other things they could do. Some staff insisted that they have not received any training related to COVID mitigation and prevention at the facility. The allegation that the facility is not following their emergency plan to protect clients and staff is related to staff feeling that Paradise Oaks administrative staff asked at least one staff to return to work once their quarantine and/or isolation period was over regardless of still being symptomatic. LPA attempted to speak to this staff person about the circumstances but staff refused to be interviewed. Other confidential interviews revealed that a staff person reported to other staff that they were cleared to return to work regardless of still being symptomatic. This situation made staff question facility's policies to mitigate the spread of COVID, further creating the potential for additional spread of COVID. Confidential interviews revealed that said staff did not return to work and forfeited their position with the agency. Other interviews revealed that staff are trained and constantly reminded and trained that they are not to return to work if they are experiencing any COVID-related symptoms. As a result of the investigation, interviews conducted, and documentation reviewed, the allegations that facility staff are not properly training on COVID protocols, facility is not following their emergency plan, and facility failed to implement mitigating factors that created additional exposure to clients and staff are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Kuhn and documents provided along with appeal rights.
