The hospital alerted the facility staff that youth had tested positive so all the remaining youth were taken to a clinic for tests on August 12, 2021. According to the administrator, the clinic's policy on testing is that the tests can

deficiencies.description: Client Records.Licensee shall ensure that a separate, complete, and current record is maintained in the facility for each client and must contain information including, but not limited to, record of any illness or injury...for which the facility provided assistance... This is not met as evidenced by The facility took four youth for COVID testing on August 12, 2021, but did not obtain the written documentation of the COVID testing results as necessary to meet the intent of this regulation. In addition, the facility allegedly obtained the COVID testing results via phone on August 16, 2022, but those results were not documented in youth files either which poses an potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Faciilty shall obtain written results whenever youth are COVID tested to ensure that all documentation is accurate and part of the records. For this incident, the records were obtained on 1/27/22. The agency shall submit a written statement showing that they understand the policy and shall ensure that this policy is provided to all administrators to prevent future citations of the same nature.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres conducted a case management inspection on May 3, 2022 at 9:02 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 5 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 5 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 3, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA David Torres observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Carla Izzarelli, Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst, Uchenna Ajaero and Jodean Hall, LPM, made an unannounced case management inspection regarding incident reports received on 1/22 and 24, 4/8, 4/24, 4/26, 5/23, 2022 involving missed medication of client #1. We met with Administrator Carla Izzarelli, staff Misha Scott, and Melissa Maturino, who assisted with this inspection. The client is currently not at the facility. LPA Ajaero, LPM Hall and Administrator conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection. LPA, Ajaero and LPM, Hall conducted interviews with staff, and reviewed medication logs for receiving the medications, documenting the medications, and records addressing the errors. LPA Ajaero and LPM Hall collected medication logs and contact information. Further investigation is required in order to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was emailed to her and she confirmed receipt.

S1 contacted S2 to inform S2 that the school was requesting that C1 be picked up due to illness. S2 contacted the school to discuss reasons for C1 needing to be picked up. During that discussion, school personnel were not able to confirm seeing or hearing C1 vomiting. S2 informed the school that because there was no physical evidence of C1 being ill, the facility would not pick up C1. C1 then contacted their probation officer to inform them that they were walking home since the facility would not pick them up. C1 then walked off the school campus and walked home. Upon arrival to the facility, C1 was taken to urgent care. While C1 had reported being ill, the facility is aware that C1 has a history of lack of attendance in school due to unauthorized absences at school or leaving the school grounds after being dropped off by facility staff. Upon the school personnel not being able to confirm C1’s illness, facility staff refused to pick up C1 as a tactic to encourage C1 to stay in school. As a result of the interviews conducted, the allegation that staff abandoned minor at school is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Carla Izzarelli, Facility Manager and documents were provided.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero conducted an unannounced complaint inspection on 6/3/22 at 12:40 PM and met with Laynee Kuhn, Chief Executive Officer to discuss the allegation as stated. LPA Ajaero informed Ms. Kuhn that the complaint investigation included a facility health and safety inspection conducted on 5/9/22. C1’s client file (see LIC 811 dated 5/9/22) was obtained on 5/9/22. Interviews were conducted with reporting party on 5/9/22, three school personnel 5/9/22, agency staff (S1, S2) on 5/9/22 and 5/19/22, client (C1) on 5/9/22. During interviews conducted with school personnel, C1 reported that they were not feeling well while in school and C1 requested that the school contact the facility to be picked up on 5/3/22. School personnel contacted the facility to request that facility staff pick up C1 as it had been reported that other youths in the classroom heard C1 tell a teacher that they had vomited and was ill.

narrative:
An unannounced case management visit was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall on 07/01/22 at 02:00 pm. LPA and LPM met with Carla Izzarelli, Administrator, to deliver the licensing report findings of a case management inspection conducted on May 25, 2022 for five special incident reports (SIR) received for medication errors. The facility was toured both inside and out with Carla Izzarelli, Manager. No clients were present during inspection. Interviews were conducted with Misha Scott, Medication Manager and Carla Izzarelli, Administrator. During the investigation three staff records were reviewed, one client record was reviewed (see LIC 811 – Confidential Names List dated 5/25/2022), medications were reviewed, two medications counted, MAR records for April and May were reviewed, training records were reviewed for S3, S4 and S5. · SIR dated May 25, 2022 –C1 was mistakenly given his p.m. prescription medication in the a.m. on May 23, 2022. · SIR dated April 26, 2022 – C1 was two tablets short for two prescription medications. C1 was one 1 tablet short for a prescription medication. Staff are unsure if the pills were dropped or the client was given an extra pill and there was no notation of the missing medication. ·SIR dated April 22, 2022 – C1 was not given a prescription medication because staff replaced the bubble pack prescription with an over the counter bottle due to the prescription not being filled and staff did not read or recognize the new packaging. SIR dated April 8, 2022 – C1 was missing one tablet of a prescription medication. Staff is unclear if he was given a double dose or if one was dropped. · SIR dated April 4, 2022 - C1 was missing one prescription medication. Staff is unsure if C1 was given an extra dose or if one fell on the ground. There was no notation of the missing medication.

The medication manager checks the medications and the MARs on Mondays and Fridays. The administrator said they thought the errors could be attributed to the rotation of on call staff, Agency wide, who are not familiar with the houses or clients and the medication distribution process. The administrator also said she was working on a plan to have only permanent staff dispense medications and a plan to improving the medication dispensing process. Facility is cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80065 (a) – Personnel Requirements. Record reviews and interviews conducted confirms multiple medication errors were made by means of lack of documentation, dispensing or not properly reading labels. Facility personnel shall be competent to provide the services necessary to meet individual client needs and shall, at all times, be employed in numbers necessary to meet such needs.

On January 27, 2023 Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Dara Campos, Regional Office Manager Margo Castaneda, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna held an Informal Conference Meeting from 1:00 PM to 2:45 PM to discuss concerns. The meeting was facilitated by LPM Campos. Attendees included (in-person) Paradise Oaks Youth Services staff, Laynee Kuhn (Executive Director), Stephanie Fischer (Administrator), Amanda Lee (administrator) and Board Member Al Werner, as well as (Via Teams Meeting), Shawn Wade Fresno County Social Worker, Julie Leong, Case Manager Mateo County Behavioral Health, Khoa Nguyen Stanislaus County Social Worker, and Tia Carter Sacramento County Social Worker. The topics discussed included: Absent without Permission Temporary Release (TR) Communication with local law enforcement Cancelling Missing Person reports Incident Report details No deficiencies were cited during today's meeting. A copy of this report was provided to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.

On 2/14/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Deanna Davis Facility Social Worker for the purpose of a Plan of Correction inspection. On 5/27/21 an SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted and the facility was cited for two clients Needs and Services Plans missing signatures of the authorized representative. LPA obtained documentation of one clients Needs and Services Plans (see attached LIC811 confidential names) signed by the authorized representative from April 2021. The facility will review their records for the other client. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility and observed the facility is a single story three bedroom home. Present was one client, one staff supervising the client and the facility social worker was in their office, During the inspection the one client and the one staff supervising the client left the facility to pickup another client.

An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Whitlow on 5/27/21 at 9:00am. During the inspection, LPA met with Carla Izzarelli, facility administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted using Zoom video technology. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA prior to the inspection. A medication count was also conducted using the Zoom platform on this date. LPA reviewed two children’s records prior to the inspection. LPA reviewed four staff and administrator personnel files prior to the inspection. LPA interviewed four staff and administrator on site during the inspection. LPA interviewed two children currently taking psychotropic medication. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87068.2(d) the licensee shall ensure and document that the child, and his/her authorized representative(s), and the child and family team were offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and services plan (NSP). Facility failed to get the authorized representatives signature for clients NSP. LPA conducted exit interview with Carla Izzarelli, Facility Manager. LPA provided the Summary Report to Carla Izzarelli, Facility Manager, upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan back with signature.

On 3.13.2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jennifer Baca arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management visit. The incident involved FY1 and FY2 having an altercation, where FY2 sprayed FY1 in the face with a cleaning solution. LPA spoke with Assistant Administrator. LPA asked if Assistant Administrator recalled the incident? Assistant Administrator stated he recalled that FY1 had sprayed FY2 with a cleaning solution in the face. LPA asked why did FY2 have the cleaning solution? Assistant Administrator stated that staff were unaware that FY2 had the cleaning solution in their room. LPA asked if staff conduct checks of the bedrooms? Assistant administrator stated that checks are conducted during each shift. LPA asked how are the checks conducted? Assistant Administrator stated that staff will open drawers and look around, however staff are not allowed to dig into the youth belongings, so the spray bottle could have been hidden under clothing, sheets or anything else where it would not have been detected. LPA asked if staff checked the amount of cleaning items that are taken during cleaning time and check again upon the completion of the cleaning? Assistant Administrator stated that the staff should do that , however they do not. LPA asked how this situation could be avoided in the future? Assistant Administrator stated that they could implement a check out and a check in system, with the cleaning supplies ,Assistant Administrator stated that this idea would need to be given to upper management to see if they are able to implement. A copy of this report was left with the Assistant Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst, Dung Mac, conducted a case management inspection on 4/25/2023 at 10:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 4 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 4/25/2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth’s monthly safety plan, and crisis intervention plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Mac observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Carla Izzarelli.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Tina Thorn on 05/04/2023 at 9:00 am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Valencia and Thorn met with Carla Izzarelli, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed two of three (2/3) child’s records and two of two (2/2) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed two (2) child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two (2) staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed two (2) of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Carla Izzarelli, Administrator No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Carla Izzarelli, Administrator.

before the altercations escalate. Interview with RP and FFY both stated FFY was not treated with respect while at the house. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted regarding the staff allowing minors to engage in physical altercations with another minor, this allegation has been found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. During the investigation LPA Baca investigated the complaint that staff did not safeguard minors personal property. Interviews with A1 and S1 both stated that when a youth comes into the facility a safeguard property list is given to list all the youths belongings. LPA observed this document for FFY. Interview with FY1 and FY2 both stated that there has not been an issue with their belongings being taken or messed with at the facility. Due to the FFY being discharged from the facility quickly and a relative putting FFY belongings in multiple bags to take, staff was unable to conduct a safeguard of property form during discharge. Interview with FFY stated that a staff had accidentally dropped a fidget spinner that belonged to the FFY. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted regarding the allegation that staff did not safeguard minors personal property, this allegation has been found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. During the investigation LPA Baca investigated the complaint that staff did not treat minor with respect. During interviews with FY1 and FY2, both stated they feel they are treated with respect by staff at the house. S1 and A1 both stated they do their best to treat all clients with respect and try to teach the clients respect as well. Interviews with FFY and RP both stated that FFY was not treated with respect while at the facility. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted regarding the allegation that staff did not treat minor with respect, this allegation has been found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. End of report.
investigation_findings: 13On 4.11..2023 at 1:45 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Roberts arrived at the agency to conduct an unannounced complaint inspection. LPA Roberts spoke with Carla Izzarelli, Administrator to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegations stated above. LPA informed agency staff this case was investigated by LPA Baca. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the agency on 3.20.2023. Documents obtained on 3.20.2023 included trainings, facility sketch, staff schedule and Incident reports pertaining to complaint allegations. and the foster youth's needs and services. Interviews were conducted with Reporting Party (RP) on 3.16.2023, Former Foster Youth (FFY) 3.16.2023, Foster Youth 1 (FY1) on 3.20.2023, Foster Youth 2 (FY2) on 3.16.2023, Staff 1 (S1) on 3.16.2023, Administrator (A1) on 3.20. 2023. LPA Baca investigated the complaint that staff allowed minors to engage in physical altercations with another minor. Interview with FY1 and FY2 stated that staff will stop any altercations that happen between the youths in the house. S1 stated that when he sees any altercation that he will separate the youths. Interview with A1 stated that staff are to break up any altercations that they see with the youths

narrative: On 6/29/23 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility for the purpose of interviewing a client. LPA met Ben Afisivalu, Assistant Administrator. LPA interviewed one client. This report was reviewed with and a copy was left with Ben Afisivalu, Assistant Administrator.

This is an annual inspection but FAS failed to pull up the annual inspection link on the LIC 809 "Type of Visit" link. This case management record is used in the place of the LIC 809 Annual Inspection/CARE Tools records. FAS does not show any annual inspection requirement for this facility. On 8/25/23, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Uchenna Ajaero and Monica Roberts made an unannounced annual inspection visit to the facility, Paradise Oaks, Hazel, a Group Home. LPAs met the facility Administrator and the inspection commenced. About 10:30 AM, LPAs toured the facility inside and outside. LPA observed the following: the house has 6-beds, 3-bedrooms and 2-bathrooms. License was hanging in a conspicuous place on the notice board and a copy in the office. Emergency notification/fire drills records. Emergency kit was not in this facility. Administrator explained they have an emergency location where they take the clients to in the case of an emergency. The facility has food, water and emergency requirements at that home in the case of an emergency. Facility sketch posted; youths rights poster; house rules were in the clients files; laundry room; locked chemical for laundry; perishable food to last more than 3-days, non-perishable food that will last for more than 5-days. Emergency food supply; fire extinguisher was last checked on 8/23/23 ; staff unlocked the garage with youths' personal items; trash cans had covers; the bathrooms were lighted; there was one linen closet; evacuation plan posted in a conspicuous area; disaster plan; hygiene closet; activity calendar and water temperature was within the allowed range. LPAs reviewed 2-staff files, 2 youth files, and 3 clients' medication containers against the MAR. LPAs interviewed 3 staff members and 2 youths at school. This concludes the annual inspection. No citation was issued. A copy of this report is issued to the Administrator.

On 8/25/23 about 1:35 PM, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Uchenna Ajaero and Monica Roberts made an unannounced case management visit for a medication error that occurred at the facility. The LPAs met the facility administrator. The LPAs reviewed the medications with the administrator. The administrator explained that the missed dose was because Omni Care pharmacy has been habitual in failing to deliver filled medication. When they call the pharmacy they were totl the medication was en-route to them for delivery but it never came. When they could not wait any longer they went and picked up the medicine by themselves and wrote the incident report. Administrator said they have resolved to bot let that happen anymore. They will endeavor to go and pick their medications before it is time to give it to the client. That way it will not be late.

On 4/3/24 LPA Ajaero received the incident report of medication error at the above facility that required a follow up visit. LPA contacted the LPA, Jodean Hall and it was determined that LPA could follow up with the facility by phone. The IR report had indicated that the facility admin will follow up with the staff involved in order to resolve this issue. 4/8/24 about 9:00 AM, LPA Ajaero contacted Amy Goock, the Agency Social Worker who informed the LPA that the error has been corrected. ASW stated that the incident with C1 was because C1 was a new client to their facility and the pharmacy made some error while filing C1's prescription. Additionally, that C1 was not a patient of their regular facility doctor. They contacted both their doctor and the pharmacy and the error has been corrected and they have not had any confusion since then. An additional report was discussed involving C2 in the same facility with same error. ASW stated they had a staff from another facility who worked the shift and she did not receive the report about the medication and so she did not give the client their medication for that shift because she did not know they had not been given at the time she showed up for work. That issue has also been resolved. End of report.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie on 04/30/2024 at 09:05 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Goldie met with Carla Izzarelli, Program Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed two child’s records. LPA reviewed three staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed two child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed two children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection the LPA observed three type B deficiencies (see attached 809D pages). LPA Goldie cited Interim Licensing Standards Needs and Services Plan 87068.2(d) and 84068.3(a) and Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Health Related Services 80075 (b)(5)(B). LPA Goldie issued one technical violation. This is not a deficiency. Plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Carla Izzarelli, Program Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
Needs and Services Plan 87068.2(d)
(d)	The licensee shall ensure that the child and his/her authorized representative(s) are offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and services plan. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, observation and records reviewed, it was observed that two of two clients Needs and Services Plans were not signed by clients and their authorized representatives which poses a potential risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will have clients sign current NSP within the week and going forward will have them sign at the end of the child family team meeting. Administrator will submit the current NSP's with signatures by POC due date.

deficiencies.description:
Modifications to Needs and Services Plan 87068.3(a) The needs and services plan*, as described* ..in specified.. in Section*s* 87068.2 *and 87068.22,*shall be updated at least every 30 days...
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, observation and records reviewed, it was observed that five of nine modified  Needs and Services Plans for C2 were not updated at least every 30 days as required which poses a potential risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will ensure that CFT meetings are scheduled every 21-28 days and if there are any changes, we will document them an place in the youths files. Administrator provided May 2024 scheduled dates/times during today's inspection.

deficiencies.description:
Health Related Services 80075(b) Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications...(B)	Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, observation and records reviewed, it was observed that C1 was not provided two medications (M5 and M6) on 04/1/2024, 04/11/2024 and 04/25/2024 which poses a potential risk to health, safety and/or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will provide additional medication training on 05/08/2024 during staff meeting. Administrator will submit agenda and signature page to the Department by POC due date to Connie.Goldie@dss.ca.gov.

narrative: On 5/14/24 abut 12:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced visit to this facility for an annual inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools and met with Hans Owhowho, the Facility Manager. LPA toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed the license was posted in an open area, three dual occupancy client bedrooms, that had all of the required furniture as required. LPA observed that there are two bathrooms available to clients and that the bathrooms were appropriately equipped with hand washing soap, toilet paper and paper towels. LPA observed that the bathrooms had warm water as required and the showers and toilets functioned as required. LPA observed that the facility had 4 refrigerators with an adequate supply of perishable food, and the pantry had nonperishable food for the clients in care. LPA observed that there is a current fire extinguisher in the facility. LPA observed that there is a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway near the client bedrooms and the smoke detectors functioned as required. LPA observed that the facility appliances, fridge and freezer appeared to be clean and function as required. LPA observed that sharps and disinfectants and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored where not accessible to clients in care. LPA observed a menu posted in the facility. LPA observed that the facility has laundry services available for each youth to complete their own laundry. LPA observed that the facility has a functioning telephone and the facility vehicles appeared to be in good operating condition. LPA requested all staff updated TB verification due by 6/30/24. No citations were issued during the inspection today and exit interview was conducted with Mr. Hans Owhowho and a copy of this document was provided.

LPA Crass investigated the above allegations. Based on video footage provided by the reporting party, LPA Crass observed staff member (S2) casually eating and on their cell phone, while clients had put a chair on a table, to climb on to an awning, to get on to the roof. While the children were on the roof, the staff member was looking down at their cell phone, and then was watching a youth on the roof, while eating. The staff member did not appear to be preventing the child from being on the roof, or verbalizing for them to get down. The staff member eventually walks back inside the house. Additionally, two youth can be seen vaping in the video, one of which vaped right in front of the staff member, with no intervention from S2 being observed. Based on record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards, Article 6, 87065.2(b)(1) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with Carla Izzarelli. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.

It was reported that sometime in 2021 or 2022, youth in care were hiding from the fire department at night, and that staff had locked the back door so the youth could not enter the facility. LPA Crass investigated the above allegation. Based upon information obtained during the investigation, LPA received conflicting statements from interviews, and was not able to observe youth being locked out of the home in video footage, therefore this allegation has been found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Carla Izzarelli. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.
investigation_findings: 13On Friday, September 20th, 2024 at 12PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass conducted an unannounced visit at the facility to deliver findings for the investigation of the complaint allegation stated above. LPA Crass met with the Facility Administrator, Carla Izzarelli, who arrived at 12:20PM, and informed them of the purpose of today’s visit. The initial 10-day complaint inspection was conducted by LPA Crass and LPA Tamara Hill, at the facility on 8/29/2024. At the facility, LPA Crass and LPA Hill conducted a health and safety tour, interviewed C1, C2, the facility administrator, and reviewed video footage and documentation. On 8/26/24, LPA Crass interviewed the reporting party. On 9/17/24, LPA Crass reviewed additional video footage. (Continued on LIC 9099-C).

deficiencies.description:
(b)Direct care staff shall perform the following duties:
(1)	Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the facility did not comply with the section cited above. LPA observed S2 casually eating and on their phone, while clients were climbing onto stacked furniture to get onto the roof. S2 also did not intervene when children were vaping.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S2 no longer works at the facility, so no further action is required. Current staff is all new, and will complete their required supervision training before being allowed to work in the facility.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne spoke with Laynee Kuhn on 11-9-20 at 10:33 a.m.to deliver the finding of the above allegation. During this investigation some copies of documents obtained from the agency include an initial needs and services plan and progress notes. The reporting party was interviewed on 5-12-20, the facility social worker was interviewed on 7-29-20 and the youth was interviewed on 8-11-20 (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 5-11-20). It was alleged that the facility staff did not follow child’s needs and services plan by not providing weekly therapy sessions with the facility social worker. According to documents between the time period of 8-5-19 to 6-5-20, the youth refused to meet with the facility social worker six times. On 3-24-20, the facility social worker attempted to contact the youth but did not get a response. On 2-25-20 it was decided that the youth would start having bi-weekly therapy sessions. According to the youth, one or two therapy sessions were held at the facility with the facility social worker. Documents indicate that some sessions took place in the community. The facility social worker was on modified duty from 8-16-19 until 9-6-19 but it is not documented if anyone else provided therapy for the youth. There is not any documentation of therapy for the month of September 2019. The initial needs and services plan dated 8-5-19 was provided to this LPA from the agency. The needs and services plan should be updated every thirty days. The agency was unable to provide an updated needs and services. Based on the information gathered during this investigation the allegation is substantiated. Facility cited for violation of Title 22, Interim Licensing Standards version 3.1 regulation 87068.3(a) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC811 were sent via email to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.

deficiencies.description:
87068.3(a) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. The needs and services plan shall be updated at least every 30 days...
this requirement was not met as evidenced by: a client was in the program from 8-7-19 until 6-5-20 and only had an initial needs and services plan dated 8-5-19. There wasn't any documentation of the client having therapy sessions during thr month of September 2019.
This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Executive Director stated that all areas of the N&S plan will be addressed on a 30 day basis. Paradise Oaks Youth Services has already put in place a facility social worker will be reassigned to provide therapy for a client if the regular facility social worker is out on leave for any reason. POYS will develop a procedure to update the N&S plan monthly and/or when services are modified. Executive Director will send procedures and amendment to their Program Statement to LPA Horne on or prior to 12-9-20.

narrative: The facility temporarily moved client 2, who was bullying, to another one of their facilities for safety measures. Staff made roommate changes to increase compatibility and safety. Staff members intervened with a restraint to keep physical distance between clients and separate a physical altercation. Based on the information gathered in the interviews with staff and clients, LPA found that bullying was occurring between clients. LPA also found that staff attempted preventions and moved clients when necessary to ensure their safety. Therefore, the allegation that staff did not prevent youth from being bullied by other youths in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED - meaning although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegations is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and the LIC811 were discussed and emailed to Carla Izzarelli.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/18/2021 at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan conducted a teleconference call and spoke Carla Izzarelli, Administrator, to deliver findings for the investigation alleging staff did not prevent youth from being bullied by other youths in care. LPA Marla Horne initiated the investigation and interviewed two clients on 2/24/21. LPA Robin Sullivan completed the investigation and interviewed three staff on 5/3/21 and one staff on 5/14/21. Documents reviewed include incident reports, needs and service plans, child and family team meeting notes, house meeting notes and planned activity schedules. The investigation revealed that bullying occurred between clients at the facility. Both clients and staff confirm that client 1 was bullied by two other clients in the facility. LPA found that staff intervened during verbal and physical incidents to protect client 1. Staff made attempts to prevent bullying by holding house meetings with the clients. Clients identified what they considered bullying and discussed solutions. Client 1 stated, “we tried to do a problem solve with client 2 but it did not work.” Client 3 stated, “staff did the best they could do. There’s not much they can do if it’s verbal.”

narrative:
CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne conducted a unannounced annual inspection at the facility on 7/29/21 at 4:06 PM. The inspection was a continuation to review client files. There were not any clients at the facility during the inspection. One client is on a home visit and two non-minor dependents were at work. The files contained all the required documentation. An exit interview was conducted with Sonia Lewis, Facility Social Worker.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Paradise Oaks Youth Services administrative office located at 6060 Sunrise Vista Drive, Citrus Heights. The inspection was a continuation of staff file reviews. LPA reviewed 5 staff files for the Hickory location and 4 staff files for the Antelope location. All required documentation was found in each file. No citations were issued during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Lisa Garceau, Human Resources Director.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Marla Horne and Jennifer Baca made an unannounced annual inspection to the facility on July 22, 2021 at 11:13 AM and met with Facility Administrator Stephanie Piring. LPAs conducted an inspection of the facility inside and outside along with Stephanie Piring. LPAs observed one bedroom which was unoccupied. The bedroom contained the appropriate furniture and bedding. The other two bedrooms were occupied by sleeping non-minor dependents who work a night shift. LPAs observed the water temperature of all bathroom and kitchen sinks to be warm. The shower and toilet functioned properly. LPAs observed and tested the carbon monoxide/smoke detector in the hallway. LPAs observed sharps and medications in the staff office in a locked container. LPAs observed the pantry, refrigerator and freezers to be well stocked with perishables and non-perishable food items. Opened food items were wrapped and labeled. LPAs observed laundry items and chemicals locked in closets. An adequate supply of linens, towels and personal hygiene were observed. LPAs observed the facility vans to have working seat belts, blinkers and first aid kit.LPAs observed the facility license posted in the living room area and the staff office. Foster youth rights were also posted in the living room area. The outdoor area was clear of debris and the bedroom screens were clean and free of bugs and dirt. LPAs noticed that there was a possible tripping hazard due to no transition strip on the floor located between the hallway and living room as well as bedroom number two. Overall, the facility appears to be safe, clean and in good repair. No citations were given during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Stephanie Piring.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled

On 1/21/22 at 11:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor met with Administrator to conduct a case management inspection concerning youth smoking illegal substances. LPA Lor spoke with Administrator about the incident report submitted on 1/2/22. Staff reported that Alcohol and Other Drug services and education have been offered to the youth, but youth is refusing services. A prevention plan is being developed for the youth and will be implemented next week. The plan include incentive offerings and alternative activities. LPA Lor also met with the youth and had a discussion with her about smoking. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted with the staff and will be emailed to the facility. This case management inspection will be closed. No further investigations needed.

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced case management inspection with the administrator on 3/3/2022 related to an incident report dated 2/28/2022. LPA inspected the facility with the administrator. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 4 clients for 8 days/4 weeks. LPA inspected the refrigerator, freezer and pantry. The administrator tested the smoke detectors which were in good repair. LPA observed 2 fire extinguishers that were fully charged. There are 2 common areas for the clients to socialize in, as well as their bedrooms. LPA observed marijuana in the second bedroom sitting on the night stand next to the bed on the right side of the room. The administrator just came on duty and the male staff that was on shift was unable to go into the second bedroom because the client, was not wearing a shirt and was only wearing her bra. The Administrator reported that Alcohol and Other Drug services have been offered to the youth, as well as anger management classes after attending court on 3/1/2022 and is now willing to participate. A PPCFT is being held on 3/8/2022 for the youth. The plan will include incentive offerings and alternative activities. A copy of the report will be provided to LPA after meeting. LPA Lor met with the youth and had a discussion with the youth about smoking. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted with the administrator a copy of the report will be emailed to the facility. This case management inspection will be closed. No further investigation is needed.

According to corroborating staff and client statements, the minor in question was first reported as unresponsive as early as around 7 PM on the evening of the incident. Per medical records, an ambulance was dispatched at about 11:09 PM, which meant that for approximately four hours the facility did not seek medical attention for what later proved to be an acute condition--an adverse reaction--that the minor was experiencing. Based on interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D, a violation of Personal Rights as set forth via the Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87072(c), and specified in the Welfare and Institutions Code, Section 16001.9(a). A copy of this report, and of the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 03/23/2022, at approximately 11 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection at this facility to deliver the findings of the complaint investigation. LPA met Carla Izzarelli, Administrator, with whom the report was discussed. Investigator Chris Krogstad of Community Care Licensing's (CCL) Investigations Branch (IB) conducted the investigation which was opened on 01/05/2022. Interviews were conducted with facility staff, administration, and clients; also done was a review of relevant documentation, including medical records. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights: "The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal right...to access and receive medical…services…with reasonable promptness..." WIC 16001.9(a)(22)(A). This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff did not seek medical attention for a minor incapacitated due to ingesting a controlled substance for four hours from when the minor was first observed as unresponsive. This poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator to formalize re-training of all direct-care staff to reinforce proper protocol regarding how to better assess a client's condition and distinguish between 'unresponsive' and 'ignoring' and when to seek medical attention. Documentation due by 4/29/2022.

narrative: On 4/6/22 at 12:11pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephanie Lor emailed the Director to inquired about an incident report received by Community Care Licensing on 3/24/22 regarding youth smoking. On the report, it did not state what the staff did to prevent the youth from smoking. Director stated that staff are constantly prompting the youth about not smoking at the facility. investigation_findings: 13On 10/28/22 at 2:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit to the above agency to deliver the complaint investigation findings. LPA Lor met with the Director. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the facility on 07/19/2022 by LPA Burgess. A walk through of the facility was conducted and copies of agency documentation obtained include current client roster, needs and services plans, staff schedules, on call tracker, staff timecards, communication notes and daily logs for time period April – June 2022. LPA Lor conducted 10 confidential interviews between 7/18/22-9/8/22. Facility staff are treating clients in a rude, hostile, and disrespectful manner. Based on the interviews conducted, there were inconsistent statements provided by 1 client. 3 out of the 4 clients reported that staff treats them with dignity and respect. Additionally, staff denied treating clients in a rude, hostile, and disrespectful manner.

narrative:
This is an amendment and supersedes the original report on 9/16/22 issued by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor who conducted a required annual inspection for the purpose of delivering the amended report. Deficiency on cash resource was overturned. On 9/16/22 at 9:24am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor, LPA Jacqueline Carmona, and LPA Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit at the agency for the purpose of completing a required Annual Inspection. During the inspection, the LPAs met with the Administrator. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. The required posters are posted: employee posters, emergency forms, disaster plan, emergency exits, licensee, hippa, foster rights poster, and mental health poster. LPAs reviewed 5 staff files, and 4 client files during the inspection. Prior to the inspection, LPA reviewed: annual fees, administrator certificate, accreditation, waivers and exceptions, and personnel roster. LPA inspected the following: Physical Plant: There is 1 living room with 3 couches, 2 sitting chairs, a shelf for books, and tv. The hallway has a linen closet, a washer and dryer, and a locked drawer for chemical. Bedroom 1, 2, and 3 have 2 twin size beds with dressers. There are 2 bathrooms in the facility (1 bathroom in the master's bedroom). The kitchen has a table, chairs, utensils, spices, pots and pans in the cabinets. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. There is a trash can with lid, 3 fire extinguishers and 1 first aid kit. The classroom space is used for staff and youth. There are 2 freezers and 1 refrigerator with food in the classroom space. There are 4 locked cabinets filled with utensils, gloves, and cleaning chemicals. The recreation room has a table, a desk computer, and storage for art materials. There is a locked storage in the front for snacks and can goods. The staff office has 2 locked cabinets for medication, sharps, folders, and cooking essentials. A type B was issued for missing window screens. (see next page)

Operation: All requirements met. No citation cited for this section of the domain. Disaster Preparedness: All requirements met. No citation cited for this section of the domain. Staffing: All requirements met. No citation cited for this section of the domain. Client records: Tv was given for the emergency list, 1 file missing ambulatory status form and missing care plan. Type B was given for 1 file immunization record. Core/Therapeutic Services: All requirements met. No citations given for this section of the domain. Clients with Special Health Care Needs: All requirements met. No citations given for this section of the domain. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. A copy of the report will be email to the facility.

LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with this inspection. LPA Stiger observed 3 of 3 client bedrooms to have all required furnishings, bed linens, and storage space for client clothing and personal items. Living room has couches, new television, and new carpet. Front Door was observed to have damage showing the wood split in several areas. LPA Stiger obtained a photo of front door. Facility was clear of hazards and observed to be clean and safe. Exterior was clean and free of debris. Case Management- The incident report received indicated client's medication was off count by one (1) pill and staff’s initials were missing from 9/7/2023. Client 1 is due to take their medication twice daily. LPA Stiger observed and obtained copies of the medication log. Client does not have a signed JV-223 due to parents having medical consent. LPA Stiger will receive the updated Needs and Services plan to be emailed from the Case Manager. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was given to the facility. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

On September 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 9/13/2023 regarding Medication Error. LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with this inspection. LPA Stiger observed 3 of 3 client bedrooms to have all required furnishings, bed linens, and storage space for client clothing and personal items. Living room has couches, new television, and new carpet. Front Door was observed to have damage showing the wood split in several areas. LPA Stiger obtained a photo of front door. Facility was clear of hazards and observed to be clean and safe. Exterior was clean and free of debris. Case Management- The incident report received indicated client's medication was off count by one (1) pill and staff’s initials were missing from 9/7/2023. Client 1 is due to take two (2) tablets by mouth before bedtime. LPA Stiger observed and obtained copies of the medication log and signed JV-223. LPA Stiger will receive the updated Needs and Services plan by email from the Case Manager. LPA Stiger conducted interviews with Administrator, Case Manager and two (2) clients. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was given to the facility. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

On September 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 9/13/2023. LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with this inspection. The facility was clean and in good repair. The incident which was disclosed on 9/13/2023 involving youth and a client from another facility engaged in sexual activity while absconding from care. Based on interviews conducted with the Administrator and Case Manager, it was confirmed that the incident took place while youth and the other client was AWOL’d at a park outside the facility. Youth and the other client absconded from care on 8/18/23 and 8/19/23. Staff attempted to intervene and redirect clients into staying at their respected facilities. After returning to the facility, youth disclosed to staff they were sexually assaulted by the other client and was overheard by staff saying they were going to report “rape” as retaliation against the other client. Staff took the youth for medical treatment on 8/18/23, 8/19/23 and 8/25/23 and each time, youth refused sexual assault assessment and kit. LPA Stiger observed youth's signed voluntary release on 8/19/23 declining sexual assault services. The facility reported the disclosed incident to Law Enforcement/ Citrus Heights Police Department, submitted SCAR reports and reported it to youth's Probation Officer. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed.

On December 18, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to conduct a follow up case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 9/13/2023 regarding Medication Error. Initial case management was conducted on 9/21/2023. LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with this visit. Case Management- The incident report received indicated client's medication was off count by one (1) pill and staff’s initials were missing from 9/7/2023. Client 1 is due to take two (2) tablets by mouth before bedtime. LPA Stiger observed and obtained copies of the medication log and signed JV-223. During the investigation it was confirmed that Client 1 did not miss their medication dosage during this incident but it was discovered that the staff who administered the medication did not initial the medication log when provided to Client 1. Administrator provided a correction memo to staff and included additional training. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was given to the facility. This case management is closed and a Technical Assistance was provided.

On December 19, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to conduct a follow up case management. LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with this visit. During the visit LPA Stiger observed damage to the front door of the facility that occurred during a client crisis. LPA Stiger provided a Plan of Correction to repair the door by January 19, 2024. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and this case management investigation is closed. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide LPA Stiger a plan to repair the door and submit a photo of completion and email to LPA Stiger at shalisa.stiger@dss.ca.gov by January 19, 2024.

On March 6, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by The Department on 2/27/24 regarding a Medication Error from 2/25/24. LPA met with the Administrator who assisted with this inspection. The incident report received indicated client's medication was off count by two (2) pills on 2/25/24. Client's prescription indicates three (3) pills to be taken in the evening and staff only distributed one (1) pill instead of three (3). LPA Stiger observed and obtained copies of the medication log. LPA Stiger was advised client was discharged from facility on 3/5/24. Administrator provided LPA Stiger the client's county social worker contact information to follow up. Staff is due back in the facility on 3/12/24 and will be provided training to review medication policies and ensure understanding. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was given to the facility. This case management needs further investigation.

On May 22, 2024 at 2:45pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Tatyana Shulz and Farhaan Sarangi made an unannounced inspection to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by the Department on 2/27/2024 regarding a medication error, client was not provided the correct dosage of over-the-counter medication on 2/25/2024. LPA met with Administrator, Carla Izzarelli who assisted with the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility and made observations. LPAs observed that the facility is clean and at a comfortable temperature with all exits free from obstruction. LPAs observed no sharps, hazardous items or toxins. In addition, all the sharps are locked and inaccessible to the clients in care. Based on interviews conducted with parties involved including, facility staff, Social Worker, and Administrator, it was confirmed that the incident took place. In addition, the facility has also been assessed Technical Violations in the past for the same type of incidents on several occasions for this year. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and given to Administrator, Carla Izzarelli during today’s inspection. This case management inspection is closed.

deficiencies.description:
80075(5)(B) Health Related Services	
If the client's physician has stated in writing that the client is unable to determine his/her own need for... medication … facility staff ...  shall be permitted to assist the client with self-administration … Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: 
It was confirmed by staff members that the medication error did take place, C1 was not provided the correct dosage of prescribed medications on 2/25/2024.This posses an immediate Health and Safety and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility has conducted disciplinary action and provided additional trainings with the staff member on how to properly dispense medication, plan of correction has been cleared during today’s inspection. Administrator will provide LPA signed disciplinairy action via email by 5/27/2024 close of business.

narrative: Consistently, interviewed youth reported that direct-care staff do a good job keeping an eye or maintaining visual of clients in care and that, if anything, the supervision might seem overbearing at times. The reporting youth only made staff aware of these unwanted advances later on in their placement. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the Licensee via email.
investigation_findings: 13On October 31, 2024 at 1:08 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program to close the complaint investigation. LPA met with Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator to whom the following report was delivered. Community Care Licensing (CCL) investigated an allegation that there were Inappropriate interactions between youth in the facility. LPA Chad Cabigon officially opened the investigation on 07/23/2024, during which time a tour of the facility grounds was conducted and multiple youth as well as staff were interviewed. Though inappropriate interactions, in the form of touching, between youth were corroborated by at least two clients. These instances never happened in the presence of facility staff, according to the youth who corroborated these occurrences. (Continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegation cannot be substantiated. 10 out of 11 confidential interviews confirmed they had never heard or witnessed the staff member discussing confidential information about clients with others in care. LPA Buchannan was informed that anyone who reported that the staff shared confidential information had done so based on what another client said, rather than from personal observation. Additionally, it was found that clients could overhear conversations in the Case Manager's office from their bathroom, creating a possibility that they may have inadvertently overheard confidential discussions about other clients in care. (See LIC 9102 TA) Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and sent to Licensee via email.
investigation_findings: 13On October 31, 2024 at 1:08 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit to deliver findings to the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program and met with Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator. narrative:
Though there were substantive corroborating statements from those interviewed describing how a particular staffer’s approach was not ideal when it came to providing care, supervision, and engagement to facility clients, there was insufficient evidence that the staff member failed to accord youth the right to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable environment. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights is being provided to the facility. *This is an amended version of the original report issued on 10/31/2024.*

Statements given by interviewed youth and staff were inconsistent as to whether there was improper and/or unsanitary preparation being done by a specific staff-person with food being served to clients. As for the purported emotional abuse, not enough evidence was found to support the claim; a video recording of a staff member’s interaction with a client was also reviewed—and though the video showed poor judgement on the staff-person’s part during a heated exchange between them and a youth, the recording does not show actions taken by that staffer that rise to the level of being abusive, emotionally or otherwise, to youth. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights is being provided Licensee via email.

met_with: MET WITH: Carla Izzarelli, Facility Administrator
narrative:
Five out of the nine interviews conducted confirmed staff did not handle client's medication properly and staff did not report incidents to appropriate parties including Community Care Licensing (CCL) in a timely manner. The incident report for the missed medications was received on April 18, 2025 however, Community Care Licensing (CCL) did not receive any 24Hr reports regarding the multiple incidents. Interviews conducted confirmed that a staff member had given a client in care medication that seemed to be "moldy". Staff informed that the medication was not moldy but was wet, altering the appearance and client did not want to consume the medication. It was also confirmed by the facility administrator that the medication became wet due to the water cup dripping into the pill cup. In addition, medication was not administered correctly and a client in care was given an additional dose of medication on April 8, 2025, April 9, 2025, April 10, 2025, and April 11, 2025. Additionally, on April 25, 2025 the client was only given a single dose of a required double dosage of medication. Based on LPA Turner's observations and interviews which were conducted and records reviewed, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

Seven out of the nine interviews conducted confirmed the allegations staff did not provide a safe environment for minor(s), staff did not safeguard minor’s personal property, and staff made inappropriate comments in the presence of minor did not occur. During the investigation LPA Turner was informed by clients in care that they feel safe in the home. Several clients expressed their appreciation of staff members and how well taken care of they are in the facility. Staff informed LPA Turner that they provide a safe environment for clients in care and a safe place for client's belongings. Clients informed that they have space to keep personal belongings and that they have never heard staff making inappropriate comments around them. Three out of four clients stated that staff are very mindful of what they say around them while in care. During the interviews, LPA Turner was notified that clients in care misplace their personal belongings and they have seen other clients in care break or mishandle their belongings to try and get staff or other clients in trouble. Clients confirmed that they have removed some belongings from their room due to incontinence issues from other clients in care. Staff interviewed denied the above allegations regarding inappropriate comments and clients stated that staff only talk about the health and safety of clients in care. Lastly, LPA Turner was notified by staff and clients in care that a client in care has made allegations in the past to try and get staff and clients in trouble. Clients advised LPA Turner that they do not get along with this client in care because they like cause arguments in the house. Staff advised LPA Turner that they are working with this client in care so they can resolve their behavioral issues. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Goodman conducted an unannounced tele-visit on August 31, 2020 at 12:35PM to follow up on a Case Management Investigation that was opened on 4/10/20. This case management was regarding a critical incident that happened resulting in the death of a client. This case management investigation was combined with complaint investigation Control # 23-CR-20200506093514. Refer to the complaint control #23-CR-20200506093514 for details regarding the investigation. Exit interview was conducted with Juan Andres, Administrator copy of 809 will be emailed with return receipt requested due to COVID-19.

The alleged allegation is that client stole facility vehicle while in care. Interviews were conducted with RP, C1, C2, C3, C4, S1, S2, S3, FSW and Gma on 03/02/2020, 03/05/2020, 3/12/2020 and 04/02/2020. LPA requested a police report from Sacramento Police Department on 3/12/2020. Interviews were consistent that the stolen vehicle belonged to S2 which was parked in front of the facility. The interviews were consistent with that the staff office was unlocked and C1 was able to steal S2’s car keys; and that C1 was left in the backyard unsupervised providing C1 the opportunity to get into the office and steal the car keys. Clients, S1 and S2 shared that both staff were inside the house watching C1 from the window. Interviews show that it was another client and not the staff that noticed C1 in the staff’s car starting the engine. The facility was aware about C1’s history of stealing cars and did not ensure to lock the office door where the facility vehicle’s and staff vehicles keys are located. When the LPA asked who is responsible to make sure the staff office is locked S2 responded that he does not know. On 03/17/2020 LPA got an email from FSW informing about court hearing for C1. The facility staff shared that C1 was charged with auto theft and had to go to the court. The charges for auto theft were dropped during this hearing. and C1 was sent back to reside in the facility. During the investigation of the allegation clients are threatening another client in care. LPA Sanders interviewed RP, C1, C2, C3, C4, S1, S2, S3, FSW and Gma. Interviews were consistent that clients in care are bullying C1. Interviews were consistent about C1 provoking the bullying by sneaking in other clients’ rooms, touching their bodies and asking them to have sex with them. Clients were clear that they do not want C1 touching their bodies or their belongings. It was disclosed that other client’s trash C1’s room, break or steal his belongings and once one of them even urinated in his bedroom. The facility staff were consistent sharing that there are meeting with residents asking them to stop. Interviews show that counseling provided to C1 is not sufficient to meet client’s needs. FSW shared that the facility gave C1 a 14-day notice to which the County denied due to the facility was aware about C1’s background when they took them in. Interviews show that despite the risk C1 was putting himself and others by his behaviors the facility did not increase the supervision. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter Number 1, Article 6 80078 (a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and 80072 and 80072(a) Personal Rights Exit interview conducted with Laynee Kuhn, a copy of this report, Lic 811 dated 3/2/20, a copy of the appeal rights were emailed to the facility with a return receipt requested.

deficiencies.description:
80078 (a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision
The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and reviewed documentations LPA observed that the facility did not ensure the safety of the client. The door to staff room where all the documents and staff belongings were located was unlock. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will change the lock on the office door so that it automatically locks when closed.

deficiencies.description:

The license shall ensure... that each child is accorded the following personal rights...To be free of physical, sexual, emotional or other abuse and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, thereat, mental abuse, or other actions..This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documents reviewed shows that Foster Youth has been mistreated by the peers verbally and physically. This is a poses a potential Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to children in care.
