On October 15, 2021 at 4:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson conducted a case management visit and met with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) regarding the STRTP, see the Confidential names list, LIC 811, dated 10/15/2021. On July 30, 2020, the Department concluded a complaint investigation for the facility; Paradise Oaks Youth Services - Linda Creek. The complaint alleged C1 died while in care. The investigation revealed that C1 had a history of sexual assault and was facing charges for a sexual assault. C1 was inadequately supervised giving him the opportunity to sexually assault other residents, including C2. C1 needed a higher level of supervision than provided at the facility and therefore the facility should have acted to provide a higher level of supervision. The allegations were substantiated, and the licensee was cited for violating California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, Regulations 87072 (d) Personal Rights and 87065.5(g) Direct Care Staff Ratio. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the Department has determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for the violation of Personal Rights ILS Section 87072 (d) of C2. The penal code section 243 defines serious bodily injury as "a serious impairment of physical condition. This section describes willful acts that constitute physical abuse. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548 (f)(1)(c), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Administrator.

Investigation shows that on the morning of 4/10/2020, the date of the incident in question, C1 (see LIC811 dated DATE) got out of bed early in the morning and went into C2's bedroom but was observed by S1. S1 asked C1 to leave C2's bedroom but when C1 refused to leave, S1 woke C2 and informed C2 that C1 was in the room and to remove themselves from the room. C2 allegedly went after C1 and a fight ensued between the youth. S1 was able to separate the youth and then went to call for assistance. While calling for assistance, C1 left the facility and was seen in front of the facility. S1 ordered C1 to return to the facility but C1 refused to come in and instead walked into traffic and was struck by a passing vehicle, and died. On 4/10/2020, the facility was within the required staffing ratio of one staff to six clients. Staff was supervising C1 at the time of the incident. Staff instructed C1 to come back into the facility, which C1 refused. Staff then called for back-up assistance. Although C1 did need additional supervision at times, due to C1's challenging behaviors, there is no documentation in C1's Child and Family Team meetings to warrant additional staff was needed at all times or at the time of C1's death; C1's behaviors were normal for C1 and non-injurious to staff or other youth in the facility. While it is unfortunate that C1 died while in the care of the facility, there was no regulatory violation noted at the time of the incident. As a result of the investigation, the allegation "Minor died while in care" is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Kuhn and report was provided via email.

narrative: The investigation revealed the following: FY1 (see LIC811 dated 11/6/2020) went into FY2's room in the early morning hours of 4/3/2020 and touched FY2 inappropriately. During this incident, it was documented that S-6 was present and attempted to redirect FY1 out of FY2's room. Law enforcement was contacted due to FY2 alleging to staff that FY1 touched him in the genital area. However, during interviews with law enforcement and Licensing, and in analysis of the incident reports, S-6 made conflicting statements. S-6 told law enforcement they saw FY1 go in and out of FY2's room "throughout the night" and when FY1 went into FY2's room in the early morning hours, they couldn't tell for sure, but it appeared that FY1 was not wearing clothes and had a pair of shorts draped around their neck. S-6 wrote an incident report stating that FY1 went into FY2's room and S-6 was behind FY1. S-6 told Licensing staff FY1 would sleep through the night and regularly wake in the early morning hours. An incident report written by S-6 states that they were behind FY1 when they entered FY2's bedroom and FY1 dropped the basketball shorts once in the room. FY2 told law enforcement that FY1 had been harassing FY2 for the past two months. FY2 said that this was the first incident where FY1 had touched FY2 on the genitals directly. Incident reports written indicate that FY1 went into FY2's room and began pulling on FY2's shorts while touching FY2 but there is nothing about touching of the genitals or even touching FY2 inappropriately. Based on investigation including observations made, interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation that staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in inappropriate behavior between clients is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of all amended documents were provided with appeal rights.

Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne, met with Laynee Kuhn on 11-9-20 at 10:40 a.m. to deliver the findings of the above allegations. During this investigation a virtual inspection of the facility was conducted on 7-27-20. Some copies of documents obtained include needs and services plan for the FY, clothing inventory dated 7-29, 11-20-19 and 11- 25-19 and an incident report dated 3-3-20. Interviews were as follows: FY was interviewed on 8-26-20; the intake social worker (ISW) on 9-10-20; facility administrator (FA) on 9-17-20 and a former employee (FE) on 10-29-20 (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 7-27-20). It was alleged that the staff did not seek medical attention in a timely manner. FY was beaten up after school on 2-25-20 and was taken to an urgent clinic that same evening by a Paradise Oaks staff (FE). FE was informed by medical personnel that the clinic did have the appropriate equipment to take an x-ray and suggested FY be taken to the hospital emergency room for an x-ray. According to FE, FY kept changing his mind about going to the emergency room. FE took FY to a fast food restaurant and it appeared that FY was eating without any difficulty. The FE called the FA and was told they could wait until the next morning to take FY to the emergency room.

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne, met with Laynee Kuhn via MS Teams on 11-9-20 at 10:40 a.m. to deliver the finding of the above allegation. During this investigation a virtual inspection of the facility was conducted on 7-27-20. Some copies of documents obtained include needs and services plan for the FY (see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 7-27-20) incident reports dated 3-3-20. Interviews were as follows: FY was interviewed on 8-26-20; the intake social worker on 9-10-20; facility administrator on 9-17-20 and a former staff on 10-29-20. It was alleged that staff engaged in a verbal altercation with FY. According to the intake social worker FY had thrown grapes at a staff because the staff would not give the phone to FY. The intake social worker observed the staff person get close to FY’s face and at first thought the two were joking around until the intake social worker saw the look on the staff person’s face. The intake social worker told the staff to step outside and take a breath. According to FY the staff did get in his face. The staff person did admit to being angry and stated he did get into FY’s face and told FY he wanted to hit him. According to documentation the incident took place on 3-3-20 and the staff person resigned on 3-4-20. Based on the information gathered during the course of this investigation the allegation is substantiated. Facility cited for violation of Tilte 22 Division Six STRTP Interim Licensing Standards version 3.1 regulation 87072(10) Personal Rights. Exit interview conducted , a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC811 were sent to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director via email on 11-9-20.

deficiencies.description:
87072(10) Personal Rights-
to be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement wa not met as evidenced by: A staff person lost his temper and got into a client's face and told the client he wanted to hit him. This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Executive Director stated that staff receive training in Pro-Act, self control and crisis intervention. The staff who lost his temper attended a two day basic workshop on Pro-Act on 2-11-20 & 2-12-20 and completed 4 hours in restraint certification on 2-13-20. The situation appears to be an isolated incident. The staff person resigned on 3-4-20.

narrative: The investigation revealed the following: It is alleged that the facility is not implementing activities. Communication Logs for May-July 2020 indicate the following outings were planned: Banister park, Denios, Hidden Trails, Folsom Lake, Hiding Falls, Bradshaw animal shelter, Boat outing, and Antelope Creek. The communication logs list the following in-house theme nights and activities: water balloon throw, connect 4 board game, ice cream outing, card games, puzzles, movies, BBQ challenge, arts and crafts, color wars, baseball with Mariposa house, and baking. The facility has no record of which client(s) participated in activities or went on outings. Records do not indicate if the planned activity or outing occurred or did not occur. There were inconsistent statements for the use of the internet in the house. Four foster youth stated the house had internet or limited internet. Two foster youth stated the house did not have internet access. According to two staff, youth have internet access for distance learning, homework, and earned free time. It is alleged that the disciplinary system restricts activities. The facility utilizes a progressive point system designed to motivate youth to advance through a behavioral modification program. According to the facility Program Statement, the program is structured to encourage and reward positive behaviors and decrease negative behaviors. Staff stated that if a client is on a level drop due to misconduct, they lose privileges for four days. If a client re-offends prior to the four-day loss of privilege, then the time starts over again. The youth are confined to the facility and typically do not participate in planned outings when they are on loss of privilege. Seven youth stated if they were off level, they could still go to the park, go to the gym, and play basketball. Five of seven youth stated they could not go on planned outings if they were off level. The five youths stated they never went anywhere because they were never on level. Staff reported the Administrators and Social Workers have the ability to modify restrictions to incentivize youth to participate in activities. Based on the evidence, the allegations that the facility is not implementing activities and that the disciplinary system restricts activities are UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director. A copy of the reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/09/2020, at 10:12 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Robin Sullivan, Michelle Goodman, and Marla Horne contacted Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director via MS Teams video, due to COVID19 precautions, to deliver findings on a complaint investigation for Paradise Oaks, Madison. Licensing Program Manager, Jodean Hall was also in attendance. LPAs Robin Sullivan, Michelle Goodman, and Marla Horne investigated the allegations listed above. Copies of documents obtained for the investigation include: Needs and Service Plan, Placement Timelines, Behavior Logs, Safety Plans, Safety Watch, Close Supervision, Client contact, CFT Notes, Placement Preservation Meeting notes, Clinical Case Presentation, Transition Determination Plan, Behavioral Intervention Plan, Licensing for clinicians, Clinical Director job description, Group Notes, Client Treatment plans, Progress Notes Reports, Staff contacts and schedules, Joint Program Planning Meeting Notes, Board Minutes, Activity Schedules, discharge documents and Incident Reports. Interviews of Staff 1 (S1), S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S8 (see confidential names LIC811 dated 8/18/20) and Foster Youth 1 (FY1), FY2, FY3, FY5, FY9, FY11, AND FY12 were conducted between 8/18/2020 – 9/14/2020. County Social Worker (CSW) interviewed on 10/2/2020.

narrative:
It is alleged that the stabilization process after behavioral episodes is not meeting the needs of the youth. Staff interviews state procedures are in place during a crisis and immediately following a behavioral episode to include de-escalating youth, calming communications, encouraging use of individual coping skills, active listening, and staying in proximity until the client is at baseline. Documentation discusses increased anxiety of FY1, placed in the program for the second time on 4/21/20, but no specific intervention or specialty mental health services were documented for anxiety. FY1 was identified with anger issues and unsafe impulsive behaviors. The objective on the Needs and Services Plan for the youth is to remain safe, refrain from substance use, aggression, AWOL, and other unsafe behaviors 100% of the time in May 2020. This goal was met 28% of the time in April and 31% of the time in May. However, the goal for June remained at 100% of the time. Although documentation identifies a need for stabilization, the facility lacks evidence that behavioral episodes result in a modification to the Needs and Services Plan (NSP) or interventions to assist youth to stabilize. It is alleged that the Needs and Services Plans and Treatment Plans are inadequate or ineffective. NSP monthly updates have unrealistic goals. Example: FY1 met Focus Area One, 31 % of the time in May. Youth’s goal for June is to meet the goal 100% of the time. Interventions listed on the NSP are not individualized and are not updated. A template of interventions are listed monthly. The NSP monthly updates do not specify a method of evaluating progress in the specific Focus Area. Example: Focus Area 2 states FY1 struggles with anger management. The objective is that youth will utilize appropriate coping skills, such as deep breathing, or taking time away, or have 1:1 with staff by the 3rd prompt, 70% of the time over the next 30 days. NSP does not specify individualized interventions to assist the youth with meeting the goals. A Treatment Plan lists a goal for FY1 to manage his feelings of anger appropriately. The objective is for the youth to manage his anger 90% of the time by a 3rd prompt from staff. The intervention plan lists the same methods and interventions for each goal in the Treatment Plan. It is alleged that the facility's services and supports are inadequate. NSP do not have attainable goals based on observed behaviors. Interventions and specialty services are not specified on documentation. Example: FY1 has a reading level many years behind his grade level and it is identified as a barrier in his treatment plan yet no documentation of this specific need in the NSP for April, May or June, nor any interventions noted. AWOL is listed on youth’s NSP as an objective for youth to refrain from 100% of the time over the next 30 day. No intervention strategy of how youth is to obtain that objective. Youth met this goal 28% of the time in April and 31% in May. The goal for June remained at 100% of the time. It is identified in progress notes that FY4 has abandonment issues yet there is no documentation addressing this specific need.

As a result of the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited for violation of Title 22 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3, regulations 87078.2 Trauma-Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices, 87068.3 Modifications to the Needs & Services Plan, and 87089.1 Mental Health. An exit interview was conducted with Laynee Kuhn. A copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility via email.

Licensing Program Manager, Jodean Hall was also in attendance. LPAs Robin Sullivan, Michelle Goodman, and Marla Horne investigated the allegations listed above. Copies of documents obtained for the investigation include: Needs and Service Plan, Placement Timelines, Behavior Logs, Safety Plans, Safety Watch, Close Supervision, Client contact, CFT Notes, Placement Preservation Meeting notes, Clinical Case Presentation, Transition Determination Plan, Behavioral Intervention Plan, Licensing for clinicians, Clinical Director job description, Group Notes, Client Treatment plans, Progress Notes Reports, Staff contacts and schedules, Joint Program Planning Meeting Notes, Board Minutes, Activity Schedules, discharge documents and Incident Reports. Interviews of Staff 1 (S1), S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S8 (see confidential names LIC811 dated 8/18/20) and Foster Youth 1 (FY1), FY2, FY3, FY5, FY9, FY11, AND FY12 were conducted between 8/18/2020 – 9/14/2020. deficiencies.description: 87078.2 Trauma-Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices(2)(B) How... behaviors will be identified and evaluated to assess the need for services,(E)How individualized strategies for healing can be implemented in...including the Needs and Services Plan and Treatment plan. This requirement was not met as evidenced by the following: Based on the NSP and treatment plans of 6 clients, the facility did not ensure individualized strategies for healing are implemented and NSP are not modified to reflect stabilization services. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Management will develop a policy and procedure to include individual strategies for healing that are identified during stabilization and CFT meetings. Modifications will be included in the NSP. The Program Statement will be amended to reflect new policy. Documents will be email to LPA by 12/9/20.

deficiencies.description: 87068.3 Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan (a) The NSP specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following: (3) The need for modification in services. This requirement was not met as evidenced by the following: Based on the review of six NSP, only the initial NSP is a comprehensive plan that meet requirements. The subsequent monthly NSP are not updates of the initial NSP but instead are focus areas extracted from the client treatment plan. The interventions on the NSP remain the same monthly and goals are not modified for success. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Management will develop a procedure to update the NSP monthly and/or when services are modified. A process on how to re-evaluate the NSP goals and objectives will be developed. Program Statement will be amended to reflect new procedure. Documents will be email to LPA by 12/9/20.

deficiencies.description: 87089.1 Mental Health (d) a STRTP program shall provide or ensure access to mental health services, including specialty mental health services and mental health supports… (1) Ensuring the Needs and Services Plan of each child…reflects any mental health needs identified in the case plan, treatment plan, or any available mental health assessment. Based on NSP, treatment plans, progress notes and intervention logs of six clients the facility did not ensure educational, behavioral, and mental health supports needs were met. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Management will develop a procedure to update the NSP on a 30-day basis. The updates will include mental health needs identified in the case plan, treatment plan, or other mental health assessments. Program Statement will be amended to reflect new procedure. Documents will be email to LPA by 12/9/20.

narrative: On 03/11/21 at 2:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Robin Sullivan, Cindy Johnson, Marla Horne, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall met with the following Paradise Oaks Youth Service (POYS) management team: Laynee Kuhn Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher Program Director, Thomas Harrer Clinical Director. The meeting was conducted on MS Teams due to Covid-19 restrictions. A Plan of Corrections (POC), submitted by POYS-Madison on 12/9/2020 and a POC, submitted on behalf of POYS-Linda Creek on 8/8/2020 were discussed. POYS will revise the POCs and resubmit to LPAs for approval. LMP reviewed the non-compliance conference summary for POYS-Linda Creek and confirmed actions are meeting the required timelines. Bi-monthly meetings (every other month) with CCL have been suspended. Quarterly meetings will be held with stakeholders to include DHCS, Sac County, CCL, and CCR. A copy of this report will be emailed to Laynee Kuhn.

On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learnin

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson arrived at Paradise Oaks Youth Services Main Office to initiate a Required Annual on 6/23/2021 at 10:00 AM with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, due to this facility not currently having any placements. Areas discussed: annual fees & outstanding fees, updated Administrator Certificate, waiver for 40 hours of annual staff training; and updated Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565). The status of other requirements was discussed, and current/updated version is being requested, for the following: · CARF International Accreditation was conducted 4/26/21-4/28/21, new certificate is pending · Mental Health Contract is renewed annually with Sacramento County · Mental Health Program approval- is currently in process of renewal and making corrections. · Emergency Intervention Log, via Board Meeting Minutes for the past 6 months, LPA Johnson followed Ms. Kuhn to the facility location and conducted the inspection. The following items were observed and evaluated by LPA Johnson: Posted items in the facility: Facility License, Emergency Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Personal Rights, Foster Youth Ombudsman posters, exit routes, COVID-19 handwashing instructions with health & safety information. Kitchen- 4 refrigerators were present and tested below 45 degrees F, one frig was missing the door handles; 2 freezers were present and tested at zero degrees. Refrigerators and freezers had various areas that needed cleaning and/or removal of old food (onion). Area to post menus is available. Hot water temperature tested within the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees (120 degrees). Knives and Sharps will be stored and locked inside the staff office.

However, none are currently present. Dishwasher is operable. There are no refrigerated medications. Trash can has a lid. Kitchen window is missing a screen. No disinfectants or cleaners are stored in the kitchen. Living Area- Furniture is clean and in good repair, except one couch to be disposed. Smoke & Carbon monoxide detectors are present and operable. Two windows were missing screens. Carpet was in good repair. Flooring in the staff office has two areas of damaged/ ripped linoleum. Bedrooms- There are 3 client bedrooms with double occupancy. All had the required furnishings, except Bedroom #2 only had one dresser. A drawer was missing exterior knobs. The facility has the required items for a bed: mattress pad, fitted sheet, top sheet, pillow and mattress in good repair, even if not on the bed; extra linen supply was present. Two windows were missing screens and window seal needed cleaning. Smoke detectors are operable. There are no staff bedrooms. Vent in hallway has dirt and rust. Bathroom- There are 2 client bathrooms (regular & master) and 1 staff bathroom. Hot water temperature tested exceeded the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees: 123, 122, and 127 respectively. The master bath: toilet was not operable & had no water; sink did not drain and needed cleaning. The shower rod in the regular bathroom is mostly rusted. Tub/showers were clean and operable. Buildings and Grounds- Fire extinguisher was serviced in 2021. Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were tested and working. Cleaning & Chemical Supplies were not accessible. Passageways are clean and free of obstructions. Facility has no bodies or water, cameras, or firearms on the premises. Outdoor fencing has a few areas that need additional support. Agency has engaged with the neighbors for repairs. Facility Telephone was not operable or present. Front door was replaced, but surrounding molding and exterior bricks is incomplete, needing repair. Detached structure (store) was inspected and does not store dangerous items. Medication- Medication is stored and locked in the filing cabinets inside the staff office, when it is present. Since no youth are currently placed, no medication or documentation were present to inspect. First aid kit was incomplete, missing adhesive tape and antiseptic solution.

Since this facility is currently not occupied with clients and staff are not assigned to this location, file reviews and interviews were not conducted. Prior to resuming operations of this facility, the following items remain needed: Updated forms: LIC 308, 500, 610C If the administrator is changed, an updated board resolution and valid certificate. Adequate food supply- 2 days of perishable, 1 week of non-perishable and snacks Monthly menus and activity schedule need to be posted. Adequate dishware and cooking utensils. Hygiene supplies. Inspection of facility vehicle Beds have all required items No deficiencies are being cited due to no clients in placement. The agency should address all items prior to resuming the operation of the facility. Exit interview conducted and reports discussed with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director; copies of documentation were provided to the facility, via email.

The details in the initial allegation, staff sexually assaulted minors in care was lacking specificity. After obtaining additional information on 10/1/2020, the allegation in this case is already being investigating in other cases. For these reasons, the other investigations needed to be completed to determine if any additional investigation would be needed. After the other cases (23-CR-20200203171258 and Case Management Investigations on 12/31/2019, 2/12/2020, and 7/27/2021) concluded, no new information was obtained, and no additional investigation was needed. The previous cases investigated these same allegations and no further investigation is needed. Based on the investigation, interviews conducted and records reviewed in this investigation and the previous cases, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time, meaning that the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. Facility signature is on hard copy. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled

On January 27, 2023 Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Dara Campos, Regional Office Manager Margo Castaneda, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna held an Informal Conference Meeting from 1:00 PM to 2:45 PM to discuss concerns. Attendees included (in-person) Paradise Oaks Youth Services staff, Laynee Kuhn (Executive Director), Stephanie Fischer (Administrator), Amanda Lee (administrator) and Board Member Al Werner, as well as (Via Teams Meeting), Shawn Wade Fresno County Social Worker, Julie Leong, Case Manager Mateo County Behavioral Health, Khoa Nguyen Stanislaus County Social Worker, and Tia Carter Sacramento County Social Worker. The topics discussed included: Absent without Permission Temporary Release (TR) Communication with local law enforcement Cancelling Missing Person reports Incident Report details No deficiencies were cited during today's meeting. A copy of this report was provided to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.

On 9/15/23, about 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero attempted to conduct an annual visit at this facility. On arrival there was no one on site. On 9/29/23, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced random annual investigation visit to this facility and met Stephanie Piring, Floating Administrator. The Administrator took the LPA on a tour of the facility. The building has a clothing closet which is a full room with clothes serving all the youths in all their other 5 facilities. At this time this facility is closed. There are no youths in the home now and there is no staff at the premises, and there is no plan in the near future to begin placement. This facility had youths at some point back in 2020. The facility has 3 bedrooms. One bedroom has a full bath and there is another full bath in the hall way. Each room has a closet. The facility has a kitchen, laundry, large living room area with boxes, and furniture, clothes storage room, and an overflow storage area. There is a van parked outside. During the tour LPA Ajaero observed: Fire extinguisher serviced 8/2/23; Working smoke alarm, carbon monoxide detector. Posted items in the facility: Facility License, Emergency Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Personal Rights, Foster Youth Ombudsman posters, exit routes, floor plan, COVID-19 handwashing instructions with health, HIPPA Compliance notice & safety information. No interview was conducted of any youth or staff because there is no one at the facility at this time. Exit interview was conducted. No citation was issued.

On 9/3/20 at 3:05PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Goodman made an unannounced Case Management visit. On November 6, 2020 at 4:05pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Goodman conducted a tele-vist with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director via Microsoft Teams to discuss findings for an open case management investigation initiated on 9/3/20. Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall was present during the televisit. The case management was regarding an incident report indicating that youth conducted an exchange with a community member and then that community member banged on the door looking for the youth in care and the door opened. The investigation revealed the following: Interviews conducted with Staff-1 (S1) on 9/3/20, Staff-2 (S2) on 9/4/20, Staff 3 (S3) on 9/4/20, Foster Youth 1 (FY1) on 9/9/20 , Foster Youth 2 (FY2) on 9/4/20, Foster Youth 3 (FY3) on 9/8/20, Foster Youth 4 (FY4) was unavailable to talk on two different days and Foster Youth 5 (FY5) was interviewed on 9/10/20. See Lic 811 confidential names list dated 11/6/20. According to the incident report the incident happened on 8/29/20 at 9:37PM. S-3 indicated that they followed FY1 outside to the front of the house observed FY1 give money and then pick up pot from a car. S-3 requested FY1 to give him the pot but FY1 refused and went in the house. A few minutes later S-3 indicated that a girl and a guy was banging on the door. S-3 stated that the door was kicked open and S-3 wasn’t sure how the door opened. FY5 stated that S-3 opened the door and then closed it but it wasn’t closed all the way and the people outside opened the door. It was also stated by S-1 that staff opened the door. S-2 and S-3 both stated the people outside were knocking/banging on the door loud and ringing the doorbell nonstop and S-2 or S-3 did not know the individuals at the door but according to the statements made by S-2 and S-3 the people wanted FY1 to give them money because FY1 used counterfeit money or return the weed. After the door was opened the second time S-2 stated they called the police. Based on LPA’s interviews and records reviewed the facility is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter Number 1. Exit interview conducted with Laynee Kuhn, a copy of this report, Lic 811, copy of the appeal rights were emailed to the facility with a return receipt requested.

deficiencies.title:
Personnel Duties
The licensee shall ensure that direct care staff shall perform the following duties
deficiencies.description: Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.

narrative: On January 6, 2021 at 1:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Goodman made an unannounced Case Management tele-visit due to Covid-19. LPA spoke to Jovan Metoyer, Administrator regarding an incident report indicating youth conducted an exchange with a community member and made comments regarding performing illegal activity. Six clients currently reside in the home. This case management requires further investigation. An exit interview was conducted with Jovan Metoyer, Administrator and a copy of this report and Lic 811 will be emailed with a return receipt requested due to Covid-19.

On February 26, 2021 at 10:38AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Goodman made an unannounced Case Management tele-visit. On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learning was embraced by about half of the clientele, with the other half preferring in-person learning.

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Hill, Marla Horne and Jennifer Baca made an unannounced annual inspection on 7/21/21 at 10:30 AM and met with Jovan Metoyer. LPAs toured the facility inside and out during the inspection today. LPAs observed four client bedrooms, two single occupancy and two dual occupancy bedrooms that had all of the required bedding and furniture as required. LPA observed that there are two bathrooms available to clients and one half bathroom available to staff and that all of the bathrooms were appropriately equipped with toilet paper and paper towels. LPA observed that the bathrooms had warm water as required. LPA observed that the showers and toilets functioned and required and showers had hot water as required. LPAs observed that the facility had an adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the clients in care. LPAs observed that there is a fire extinguisher in the facility and it was last inspected in June 2021. LPA observed that there is a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway near the client bedrooms. LPAs were not able to test the smoke detectors as they are linked to the pull system. LPA observed that the facility appliances, fridge and freezer appeared to be clean and function as required. LPA observed that sharps and disinfectants and cleaning supplies were appropriately stored where not accessible to clients in care. LPA observed a menu posted in the facility. LPA observed that the facility has laundry services available for each youth to complete their own laundry. LPA observed that the facility has a functioning telephone in the facility. LPA observed that the facility vehicles appeared to be in good operating condition. LPA observed that there is no transition strip from the living room to the kitchen area which may lead to a trip hazard and did advise that the facility to put one in place. No citations were issued during the inspection today and exit interview was conducted with Mr. Metoyer.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral inspection on 9/24/21 at 12:30 PM to the administrative office location for the agency located at 6060 Sunrise Vista Drive, Suite 2100, Citrus Heights 95610 and met with Laynee Kuhn, Chief Executive Officer for the agency. LPA made the visit to discuss the following incident reports for this facility: 4/14/21 there are five reports related to property destruction in the facility and one resulted in a restraint after causing a hole in the wall as a result of opening a door too hard. LPA questioned what was happening at the facility and why this one particular incident resulted in a restraint of C1. Ms. Kuhn states that the staff that handled this incident has been out as a result of this restraint due to an injury sustained by the staff person. Ms. Kuhn is to provide a follow up statement from staff that would provide additional detail to this incident. . C2 also reportedly had females at the facility overnight and it was reported to the agency that the overnight staff knew that the females were there and did not do anything to deter this from happening. When speaking with Ms. Kuhn, the staff was immediately terminated as a result of this incident. LPA did obtain additional documentation related to staff person (S1). C2 was observed to be playing with fire/starting fires in the living room of the facility. Facility reports that there was not any reported damage to the facility and this incident was discussed in child and family team meeting but that the child is no longer in the facility. C3 had gone out on his own and gotten a job interview and when reporting this to the facility, C3 was informed that per the child and family team meeting, C3 was not authorized to have a job. LPA asked what the protocol of this is and Ms. Kuhn states that they discuss age and behavior appropriate readiness for employment and this youth was not cleared to have outside employment.

C4 left the facility to go to the store after getting allowance and staff contacted to report youth as unauthorized to be out of the facility. LPA asked if youth was authorized community time and if law enforcement was contacted due to youth not signing out of the facility. LPA was informed that they contact law enforcement immediately if they do not have authorized community time per the discussion in the child and family team meetings. C5 left the facility to go to a store and there is mention about juvenile hall on the report. LPA inquired as to why a youth leaving to go to a store would justify contact with juvenile hall. LPA was informed that when the missing persons report was filed per the agency protocol, they were informed of an outstanding warrant record however this issue had already been cleared up in court prior to youth coming into placement. LPA discussed with Ms. Kuhn the additional clarification needed on the reports to ensure all details including antecedents and follow up are captured appropriately. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection. Document provided to Ms. Kuhn.

Quarterly Reports, Behavioral Intervention Plans, Discharge Report, and Individual Education Plan. Copies of facility documentation of S1 was also provided including Personnel Record, Child Abuse Reporting Policy, Allegations of Abuse Policy, Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Suspected Child Abuse, Training Records, Facility Communication and Meeting Notes, Performance Evaluations and Disciplinary Notice. Client interviews were conducted with C1, C2, C3, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, from 8/30/2020 to 4/29/2021. Staff interviews were conducted with S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10, S11 from 3/25/2021 to 4/29/2021. Additional interviews were conducted with Witness 1 and Witness 2 on 7/27/2020 and 4/13/2021. County Social Workers (CSW) Nina Allen and Michelle Fitzgerald-Panelle were interviewed on 9/25/20 and 4/8/2021 (see LIC811 dated 7/27/2021). On 2/12/2021, Citrus Height Police Department provided a copy of Police Report #CH20-05787. Unsuccessful interviews were attempted with C9, Witness 3 and CSW Lakisha Purham-Davis on various dates (see LIC811 dated 7/27/2021). The first allegation is whether S1 had a sexual relationship with C1 or C2. S1, C1 and C2 denied there was a sexual relationship. Ten staff were interviews and all heard rumors or conversations S1 was having a sexual relationship with C1 and/or C2 but did not witness anything. In addition, C1 reported to two staff there was not a sexual relationship with S1. However, it was reported C2 confirmed to other residents that C2 had oral sex with S1.

Based on the investigation, interviews conducted and records reviewed, the complaint allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. Facility signature is on hard copy. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the agency via email.

Quarterly Reports, Behavioral Intervention Plans, Discharge Report, and Individual Education Plan. Copies of facility documentation of S1 was also provided including Personnel Record, Child Abuse Reporting Policy, Allegations of Abuse Policy, Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Suspected Child Abuse, Training Records, Facility Communication and Meeting Notes, Performance Evaluations and Disciplinary Notice. Client interviews were conducted with C1, C2, C3, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, from 8/30/2020 to 4/29/2021. Staff interviews were conducted with S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10, S11 from 3/25/2021 to 4/29/2021. Additional interviews were conducted with Witness 1 and Witness 2 on 7/27/2020 and 4/13/2021. County Social Workers (CSW) Nina Allen and Michelle Fitzgerald-Panelle were interviewed on 9/25/20 and 4/8/2021 (see LIC811 dated 7/27/2021). On 2/12/2021, Citrus Height Police Department provided a copy of Police Report #CH20-05787. Unsuccessful interviews were attempted with C9, Witness 3 and CSW Lakisha Purham-Davis on various dates (see LIC811 dated 7/27/2021). Another allegation is whether S1 had an inappropriate relationship with C1 or C2 resulting unprofessional conduct. C1 admits to more than ten inappropriate incidents with S1. While many of the incidents were identified as occurring after S1 resigned, the investigation was unable to determine if the below incidents occurred before or after S1 resigned.

Those incidents include: C1 reported S1 provided him with marijuana 12-13 times, S1 called C1 extremely late on his cell phone multiple times, S1 took C1 to S1’s personal residence four times and spent the night twice. S1 encouraged C1 to AWOL and provided transportation. S1 rented a hotel room for C1. The most egregious incidents occurred when S1 obtained and provided C1 the address of a person that assaulted him. S1 showed C1 a “Glock” handgun and allowed C1 to hold it while at S1’s residence. Then S1 told C1 to “take care of him”. In addition, S1 told C1, her ex-fiancé was abusive and suggested C1 “shoot him up”. On 4/12/2021, an electronic search was conducted and determined a firearm is not legally registered to S1. None of the statements made by C2 were consistent. It is noted that S1 was disciplined by the licensee for incidents reported by staff. Based on the investigation, interviews conducted and records reviewed, the complaint allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. Facility signature is on hard copy. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the agency via email.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson arrived at Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) Administrative Office to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 7/27/2021 at 12:30 PM. LPA Johnson spoke with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegations stated above. LPA Johnson informed Ms. Kuhn this case was investigated by the Department’s Investigator Jaime Eaton and Lori Rodriguez. The investigation included: on 7/15/2020, POYS provided notification of an incident that a former Staff 1 (S1) person had contact with a current Client 1 (C1) and C1 spent the night at S1’s home. Photos of Snapchat conversation was also provided. Subsequently the Department received a complaint with the same allegation. On 8/6/2020, the initial 10-day complaint investigation tele-inspection was conducted with the facility. Additional details were obtained alleging S1 also had an inappropriate relationship with C2. Copies of facility documentation of C1 and C2 were provided on various days including: placement agreements, contact information, physical and medical information, intake documentation, CFT notes, Need & Service plans, JPPM notes, incident reports, progress notes, Close Supervision, Safety Watch, Placement Preservation Meeting Notes,

narrative: On 1/21/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor conducted a case management inspection and met with Administrator and Case Manager worker. The purpose of this inspection is to discuss two incident reports concerning youth using illegal substances and no refills on youth's medication. Staff reported that the youth is scheduled for a CFT and has been referred to AOD twice, but the youth is refusing services. Staff reported that they have provided education about the effects of smoking and would redirect the youth when youth engages in smoking. Incident two reported that youth ran out of medication. Staff reported that the medication arrived late and is now in stocked in the office. Medication and binder logged were shown to LPA Lor. No interviews were conducted with any of the youth due to AWOL. No citations were issued during this inspection. This case management inspection will be closed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be email to Administrator.

On 2/2/22 at 2:15pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor conducted an over the phone case management inspection to the above FFA facility. LPA Lor spoke with Case Manager. LPA Lor discussed an incident report submitted to Community Care Licensing on 9/29/21 concerning sexual behavior at the facility between two youth. A plan was developed after the incident to separate the youth. Sex education was also provided to the youth. Interviews couldn't be conducted with youth one due to being discharged from the facility. Youth two was unavailable during the time of the phone call. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility. Case management will be closed. No further investigation needed.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres conducted a case management inspection May 5, 2022 at 9:13am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 5, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA David Torres observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Javon Metoyer, Administrator.

On 6/10/22 at 11:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding an incident report received by Community Care Licensing on 5/16/22 regarding youth feeling unsafe at the facility. LPA knocked on the door and called the facility, but no one answered. LPA returned at 12:30pm, but no one was at the facility. LPA will conduct this case management at another time. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Stidman and Cecilia Warren on 6/13/22 at 10:00am. During the inspection, LPAs met with Jovan Metoyer, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed two child’s records on site at the facility at 10:00am. During the review of one child’s records, LPA Stidman observed child (C1) psychotropic medication logs for medications M1, M2, M3 for June 2022 have inaccurate information including medication counts for M1, M2 and M3, psychotropic medication administration logs month dates, prescription numbers and start dates. LPAs observed two client's Needs and Services Plans are missing the signature of the client and the client's authorized representative. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 809D under the California Code of Regulations, Interim Licensing Standards # 87068.2(d) and 87070(b)(13). LPAs reviewed two staff personnel files on site at the facility at 10:00am. LPAs interviewed two staff on site at 10:00am. LPAs interviewed one child currently taking psychotropic medication at 1:30pm. LPAs conducted exit interview with Jovan Metoyer, Administrator at 4:45pm LPA provided the Summary Report to Jovan Metoyer, Administrator upon completion. On 9/7/22 LPA met with Ranjeeta Sharma Assistant Administrator to amend this Summary Report.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted with the Director . A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights will be emailed to the agency.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/28/22 at 2:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit to the above agency to deliver the complaint investigation findings. LPA Lor met with the Director. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the facility on 07/19/2022 by LPA Burgess. A walk through of the facility was conducted and copies of agency documentation obtained include current client roster, needs and services plans, staff schedules, on call tracker, staff timecards, communication notes and daily logs for time period April – June 2022. LPA Lor conducted 6 confidential interviews and 3 attempts between 8/25/22-9/20/22. Based on the interviews conducted, 5 out of the 6 interviews reported that the facility is in ratio and a floater is available for additional support when needed. In addition, timecard revealed that there are 2 or more staff on shift based on the number of clients at the facility.

narrative: On the allegation of lack of supervision resulting in altercation between youth in the facility, based on interviews and incident reports, it was confirmed that the facility moved the youth to a different house due to an altercation with another peer. Incident reports dated 6/3/22 also confirmed that information. On the allegation lack of supervision resulting in youth in possession of marijuana, based on interviews conducted, it was reported that youth obtained substances while on awol. In addition, self-searches and room searches were conducted. It was also reported that prompts are given when youth are seen using substances. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted with the Director. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights will be emailed to the agency.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/28/22 at 2:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor made an unannounced visit to the above agency to deliver the complaint investigation findings. LPA Lor met with the Director. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the facility on 6/21/22 by LPA Kinder. LPA obtained copies of the following: Staffing schedule for January-June of 2022 and Client Roster from January-June of 2022. LPA Lor conducted 11 confidential interviews 7/26/22-9/22/22. On the allegation of lack of supervision resulting in client stealing from another resident, based on the interviewed conducted, it was reported that the facility addressed the stealing issue with the youth. It was also confirmed that lock boxes are available to youth to lock their personal belongings. Although the incident occurred, the facility addressed the issue and offered alternative solution for the youth.

narrative: On January 27, 2023 Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Dara Campos, Regional Office Manager Margo Castaneda, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna held an Informal Conference Meeting from 1:00 PM to 2:45 PM to discuss concerns. The meeting was facilitated by LPM Campos. Attendees included (in-person) Paradise Oaks Youth Services staff, Laynee Kuhn (Executive Director), Stephanie Fischer (Administrator), Amanda Lee (administrator) and Board Member Al Werner, as well as (Via Teams Meeting), Shawn Wade Fresno County Social Worker, Julie Leong, Case Manager Mateo County Behavioral Health, Khoa Nguyen Stanislaus County Social Worker, and Tia Carter Sacramento County Social Worker. The topics discussed included: Absent without Permission Temporary Release (TR) Communication with local law enforcement Cancelling Missing Person reports Incident Report details No deficiencies were cited during today's meeting. A copy of this report was provided to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.

On April 06, 2023 at 11:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephannie Verna, arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of conducting a collateral visit to gather testimony from a facility staff (S1). LPA met Jovan Metoyer, Facility Administrator, and S1. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility. LPA conducted two confidential interviews. On February 2, 2024, at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of an Annual Inspection. LPA Stiger toured the facility inside and out. LPA observed the living room to be clean and free from debris. LPA observed client bedrooms that had all of the required bedding and furniture. LPA observed client bathrooms and one half bathroom available to staff. LPA Stiger observed that the facility had an adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for the clients in care. LPA conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of report to the facility.

On February 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger conducted a case management visit following an incident report received on January 19, 2024. The incident advised the facility found bed bugs in two (2) bedrooms and two (2) youths reported bites. The facility put a Plan of Action to: -Replace both bed frames in Rm 1 and Rm 2 -mattresses included - Wash all bedding, clothing, and upholstery for all youth and common areas at a local laundry mat. - Spray down entire facility with Bed Bug spray (Rooms, couches, chairs, etc). - Toss out a love seat sofa in common area that maybe concern for re-infestation. LPA Stiger toured the facility and observed the client beds were replaced, bedding washed, rooms disinfected and common area furniture removed. LPA Stiger interviewed two (2) staff and one (1) youth advising LPA they have not seen any new occurrences since the 1/19/24 incident. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and this case management investigation is closed. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

On February 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger conducted a case management visit following an incident report received by the Department on January 19, 2024. The incident report received indicated client's medication was off count by three (3) pills and staff’s initials were missing from 1/17/24, 1/18/24 and 1/19/24. It was reported that staff forgot to give youth their medication. LPA Stiger observed and obtained a copy of the medication log showing missing initials. Administrator provided a correction memo to staff to included additional training. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was given to the facility. This case management needs further investigation.

On February 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger conducted a case management visit following an incident report received by the Department on January 19, 2024. The incident report received indicated client's medication was off count by three (3) pills and staff’s initials were missing from 1/17/24, 1/18/24 and 1/19/24. It was reported that staff forgot to give youth their medication. LPA Stiger observed and obtained a copy of the medication log showing missing initials. Administrator provided a correction memo to staff to included additional training. After conducting interviews, it was reported that the youth refused to take the medication. The Youth does not take medication and was taking the medication for an isolated incident (bug bites). An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was given to the facility. This case management is closed.

LPA was unable to interview the youth due to being in a 30-day visit pass and was not able to verify how the youth obtained the medication. Additionally, it was confirmed in the interviews that facility staff adequately supervise youths in care. When youths abscond from care, staff shadows youths, redirect and prompt self-search if needed once youths return to the facility. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the agency.
investigation_findings: 13On 3/14/24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to the above agency to deliver the complaint investigation findings. LPA Stiger conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on 11/9/2023. No deficiencies were cited at that time. LPA Stiger obtained copies of staff schedules, training certificates, Needs and Services plan, case notes and background clearance. LPA Stiger conducted six (6) confidential interviews between November 2023- February 2024. Based on interviews conducted, the above allegation cannot be substantiated because inconsistent statements were obtained during the interview process. It was confirmed that youth absconded from care and returned to the facility after taking the medication. Staff prompted youth to conduct a self- search and once staff became aware youth took the medication, staff called for Emergency Services. Cont...

narrative:
Documentation further shows that drills were done on all three shifts. The monthly drills are a protocol set forth by the facility’s Program Statement, whereas the Health and Safety Code only requires drills to be conducted at least once every three months. Based on LPA’s interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore the allegation is found to be Substantiated. No citation is being issued due to the aforementioned mitigating circumstances—a Technical Violation Advisory Note (LIC 9102-TV) is being issued. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.

—the facility in each of those unannounced on site inspections, was not found to be in disrepair; multiple outside Social Workers also reported, based on their visits to the facility, similar observations about the STRTP grounds—that the facility is maintained in good repair. investigation_findings: 13On October 29, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zaria Turner conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met Jovan Metoyer, Facility Adminstrator with whom the following report was discussed: The investigation was opened on 06/21/2024 during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant was done and facility records were requested; interviews were conducted with facility staff, youth, and county Social Workers as part of the investigation. A records review found that for the month of May, 2024, there was no documented disaster drill conducted—interviews with Program personnel corroborate that no monthly safety drill was done for that month. However, records indicate that emergency response drills were done for all other months from the start of the year up to the date of this complaint. Report conitnued on LIC9099-C

narrative: The one youth who was positively identified or described by the reporting party did not, themselves, confirm any staff violations being perpetrated on any youth in the facility. That same youth reported that staff were present during an incident that closely resembles the one in the complaint—according to this youth, facility staff intervened appropriately. That youth did not report ever having been physically abused or mistreated throughout their time in Paradise Oaks. The youth indicated that they felt safe in the facility. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.

On January 14, 2025 at approximately 9:15 AM Licensing Program Analysts LPA Zaria Turner made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Facility Administrator, Jovan Metoyer, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant LPA conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility was clean, safe, and kept free of obstruction. LPA observed the posting of a License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of four bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, a classroom, kitchen, living room, dining room, staff room, and an office. Two client rooms are quipped with one bed, bedding, a closet, and a dresser for clothing and personal belongings. Two client rooms are equipped with two beds, bedding, a closet, and two dressers for clothing and personal belongings. The three bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets and running water. The living room is equipped with two sofas, two coffee tables, an office desk and a monitor, a TV, and hockey table. The dining room is equipped with a sofa, chair, and dining table with five chairs. There are three closets with extra linens, towels, toys, and a water heater. There are two storage rooms which contain two fridges, shelves, and cabinets for snacks. The staff bathroom contains a washer and dryer. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to clients in care and locked in the staff bathroom and laundry room. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees Fahrenheit. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. Sharp objects are locked away in a cabinet in the office. There are containers to place leftover food. A working telephone is available at the facility. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. The First Aid Kit is fully stocked. The Hot Water is between 105–120 degrees Fahrenheit. The Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets, bathtubs, and shower fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a grassy area with a tether ball set. There is a concrete area with a basket ball hoop, punching bag, and a bin containing extra basketballs. There is safety netting along the top edges of the fence. There is no pool on the premises. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection, Physical Plant, Operation, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention, Staff and Client Records, and Core and Therapeutic Services. A total of five staff files and three client files were reviewed. LPA conducted three staff interviews and one client interview. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility annual fees. No deficiencies were cited during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Jovan Metoyer, Facility Administrator, and a copy of this report was provided during today's inspection.
