Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson arrived at Paradise Oaks Youth Services Main Office to initiate a Required Annual on 6/23/2021 at 10:00 AM with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, due to this facility not currently having any placements. Areas discussed: annual fees & outstanding fees, updated Administrator Certificate, waiver for 40 hours of annual staff training; and updated Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565). The status of other requirements was discussed, and current/updated version is being requested, for the following: · CARF International Accreditation was conducted 4/26/21-4/28/21, new certificate is pending · Mental Health Contract is renewed annually with Sacramento County · Mental Health Program approval- is currently in process of renewal and making corrections. · Emergency Intervention Log, via Board Meeting Minutes for the past 6 months, LPA Johnson arrived at this facility on 6/25/2021 at 9:00 AM and conducted the inspection with Amanda Lee, Administrator (another house). The following items were observed and evaluated by LPA Johnson: Posted items in the facility: Facility License, Emergency Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Personal Rights, Foster Youth Ombudsman posters, exit routes, COVID-19 hand washing instructions with health & safety information. Kitchen- There is no oven in the facility. Two refrigerators tested below 45 degrees F; two freezers tested at zero degrees. Area to post menus is available. Water furnace had been turned off and the water did not meet the regulatory range. After turning it on, it took while for the hot water temperature to reach the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees (107 degrees).

Knives and Sharps will be stored and locked inside the staff office. However, none are currently present. Dishwasher is operable. There are no refrigerated medications. Trash can has a lid. No disinfectants or cleaners are stored in the kitchen. Dining table has areas with random paint. Removal of paint or tablecloth was recommended. Additional chairs are needed for the dining table to for the capacity of 6. Living Area- Furniture is clean and in good repair. Smoke & Carbon monoxide detectors are present and operable. Carpet and flooring are in good repair. A fireplace screen is not fastened / attached to secure blockage of access of clients. Bedrooms- There are 3 client bedrooms with double occupancy. Some required furnishings were missing: Bedroom 1- dresser needs repairs, Master bedroom only had one dresser. The facility has the required items for a bed: mattress pad, fitted sheet, top sheet, pillow and mattress in good repair, even if not on the bed; extra linen supply was present. Smoke detectors are operable. There are no staff bedrooms. Bathroom- There are 2 client bathrooms (regular & master) and 1 staff bathroom. Ceiling light/vent in staff bathroom needs some cleaning. Water furnace had been turned off and the water did not meet the regulatory range. After turning it on, it took while for the hot water temperature to reach the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees (105 degrees). Toilets, sinks and tub/showers were operable; toilets need to be cleaned. Buildings and Grounds- - Fire extinguisher was serviced in 2021. Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were tested and working. Cleaning & Chemical Supplies were not accessible. Doors and passageways are clean and free of obstructions. Facility has no bodies or water, cameras, or firearms on the premises. Facility Telephone was not operable or present. Detached structure (workshop for maintenance staff) was inspected and stores many dangerous items (tools, chemical, cleaners, & tools). In addition to being locked, it has an audio alarm system. Facility was clear of hazards and observed to be clean, safe and sanitary. Medication- Medication is stored and locked in the filing cabinets inside the staff office, when it is present. Since no youth are currently placed, no medication or documentation were present to inspect. First aid kit was not available to be inspected.

Since this facility is currently not occupied with clients and staff are not assigned to this location, file reviews and interviews were not conducted. Prior to resuming operations of this facility, the following items remain needed: Updated forms: LIC 308, 500, 610C If the administrator is changed, an updated board resolution and valid certificate. Adequate food supply- 2 days of perishable, 1 week of non-perishable and snacks Monthly menus and activity schedule need to be posted. Adequate dishware and cooking utensils. Hygiene supplies. Inspection of facility vehicle Beds have all required items No deficiencies are being cited due to no clients in placement. The agency should address all items prior to resuming the operation of the facility. Exit interview conducted and reports discussed with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director; copies of documentation were provided to the facility, via email.

On October 05, 2023 at 09:45 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced annual facility inspection. LPA met with Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator (Olivine) who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA and the Licensee conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The facility is licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory clients, ages 0 to 17 years old. The census is currently zero. The facility license, Emergency Disaster plan, Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights postings, Client menu, Client Daily Activity Schedule, and a boards of resources and flyers were posted in a prominent location in the facility. The home is one story and consists of three bedrooms, three bathrooms, kitchen, dining room, living room, a staff office, garage, and a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. There are no cameras utilized in the home or exterior cameras posted. LPA observed that the living room contained two couches, coffee table, along with a television, a desk and computer, and cabinets which contained games. In the hallway LPA observed a drop box to submit grievance forms, however the agency grievance forms and the facility's policy regarding procedures was not posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. continued on 809-c

LPA observed hallway cabinets which contained extra linens, pillows, towels, and paper supplies. There is a fireplace in the living room, that not used. The garage contained storage supplies and holiday decor. LPA observed that the dining area was included in the kitchen and the table had six chairs. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the living room and the kitchen area had the stove, oven, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen cabinets and drawers were in good repair. Sharps were locked in the staff office in a locked box. The pantry was located in the kitchen. LPA observed sufficient amounts of food in the pantry, refrigerator and freezer and fresh fruits and snacks on the counter. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days were observed. LPA observed that the facility has three bedrooms with double-occupancy floor plan, and each bedroom had two beds and clean bedding provided including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows. Dressers with operational drawers for personal items, lighting and ample closet or storage space was provided. Windows and screens were in good repair. There were three bathrooms observed in the facility. One bathroom was located in a client bedroom, and the other bathrooms were located in the hallway and the staff office. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. The water temperature was measured to be at 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. LPA observed a laundry room, which contained a washer and dryer. Cleaning supplies and detergents were locked in the cabinets. Next to the laundry room is the staff office and a locked door to the breezeway and backyard. The The staff office contained a working landline phone and art supplies, and confidential client medication and records were stored in a locked filing cabinet. continued on 809-c

The backyard contained a small courtyard, a lawn, garden, and a basketball court. There were no areas of damage to the surrounding fenced area. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. LPA observed working Carbon Monoxide and smoke detectors, and they were tested and in working condition. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the hallway. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in August 2023. LPA observed the first aid kit were stored in the staff office. The first aid kit was in tact. Upon request to review past licensing reports, the Administrator stated that they do not have facility's past licensing reports for the past three years at the facility and they are stored with the Director at the Agency's Administrative Office. It was observed that while the facility has a written complaint procedures by which children or their authorized representatives are permitted to file complaints, however they were not posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. LPA Verna conducted one personnel interview, with Amanda Lee, Administrator. LPA Verna completed the following domains of the inspection: Physical Plant, Operations, and Disaster Preparedness. There were no clients in placement at the facility and client and personnel files were not required for inspection. The required annual inspection was completed on today's date. The facility is being issued two technical advisories related to STRTP ILS, section 87072.2(a)(3) and Health and Safety Code, section 1538.5(a)(3). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and technical advisories were provided to Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator.

On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learning was embraced by about half of the clientele, with the other half preferring in-person learning.

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021. A copy of this report will be emailed for signatures to Laynee Kuhn.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan conducted unannounced required annual inspection on 6/30/2021 at 8:47 AM with Amanda Lee, Administrator. The facility follows Covid-19 entrance protocol with a sign-in log and temperature check conducted at the entrance. The facility’s status of some requirements are as follows: · Accreditation review with CARF International was conducted 4/26/21-4/28/21 and new certificate is pending. · Medi-Cal Certification completed. · Mental Health Contract is annual with Sacramento County. · Mental Health Program is currently in process of renewal. The facility censes is four. Three client files were reviewed and ­­two client interviews were conducted.The following items were observed and evaluated by LPA Sullivan: Posted items in the facility: Facility License, Emergency Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Personal Rights, Foster Youth Ombudsman, exit routes, COVID-19 handwashing instructions, and health and safety information are posted. .Kitchen- Two refrigerators tested below 40 degrees F; two freezers tested at below six and below 2 degrees. Hot water temperature tested within the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees. Knives and Sharps are stored and locked inside the staff office. Adequate food supply including 2 days of perishable and 1 week of non-perishable items were observed. Dishwasher is operable. Adequate dishware and cooking utensils are present to meet capacity. There are no refrigerated medications. The trash can is covered. Living Area-. There is a sofa and over-sized chair for seating. Smoke & Carbon monoxide detectors are present and operable. Windows have screens. Carpet/flooring are in good repair.

Bedrooms- 3 of 3 client bedrooms were observed to have all had the required furnishings, including storage space. Each bed has the required mattress pad, fitted sheet, top sheet, blankets and pillow bed covering. Two rooms are currently single occupancy, with the capacity of 2, and one room is double occupancy. Additional linen supplies are stored in the hall closet. Windows have screens and coverings. Smoke detectors are operable. Buildings and Grounds- Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were tested and are working. Facility was clear of hazards and observed to be clean and safe. Telephone: Available and in operable condition. Cleaning & Chemical Supplies: Adequate, locked and stored in a hall closet. Doors and Passageways: Clean and free of obstructions. Facility has no bodies or water, cameras, or firearms on the premises. Facility vehicle has current registration and insurance. The tires observed to be new and all seat belts function. Exterior was clean and free of debris. Sunflowers were planted by a An exterior building was observed to have a large conference table with chairs to be used for trainings and meetings. Medication- Medication is stored in a locked container, inside a locked filing cabinet, inside the locked staff office. Documentation of dispensing medication was reviewed. Facility has copies court approval for dispensing medications. First aid kit (manual, tweezers, scissors, dressings, bandages, adhesive tape, thermometer, antiseptic solution) was available and had an adequate supply of items. LPA Sullivan will review employee files located at the Administrative office. An exit interview was conducted and the inspection discussed with Amanda Lee. Copies of documentation were provided to the facility. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited.

LPA Sullivan made a visit on 6/30/2021 at 2:05 PM to Paradise Oaks Administrative Office at 6060 Sunrise Vista Drive, Suite 2100, Citrus Heights, CA 95610. The licensee provided a current copy of the LIC 500. Four Staff records were reviewed after the physical inspection at the facility. See LIC 859.

Due to technical difficulties, a handwritten report was issued. This is an electronic copy of the report issued to Amanda Lee, Administrator at the time of the law enforcement contact case management inspection conducted on 6/29/21. See handwritten copy for original signatures. Licensing Program Analyst Hugo Licea conducted a case management inspection on June 29, 2021 at 10:11am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 5 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 4 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated June 29, 2021, were reviewed. 4 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 4 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Amanda Lee, Administrator.

One staff (S1) stated that she is Pro-Act trained but new employees do not get the hands-on role playing because Covid has forced the training online. Staff stated with the assaultive behaviors of their youth, there is not enough staff if there are multiple crises but staff are trained. Staff acknowledge Covid has created employee shortages and lack of in-person training. C3 stated that staff do not do enough when clients are escalated, but there is not much staff can do. C1 stated staff try to get us to disengage with each other and calm us down and go for walks or go outside. C1 stated if there were more staff, there would be more support for everybody. It is alleged that the needs of a child are not being met. CSW stated that C1 is getting TBS from the facility clinicians. Therapeutic behavioral services are an intensive, individualized, one-to-one behavioral mental health service for youth with serious emotional challenges. CSW stated the facility typically had a lot of resources but Covid has made it difficult everywhere. The facility social worker (SW) stated the number one issue is keeping C1 safe from self-harming tendencies. SW is working closely with house staff so interactions with the youth are consistent with her treatment plan. S1 stated youth participates in all her therapies but has a high need for recognition and seeks attention, so it is difficult to answer if youth is getting her needs met. C1 stated she would like more support when she is upset. C1 stated she has a treatment plan and participates in therapy sessions but she feels more one-on-one time would help. C1 used to go on drives with her social worker but that ended with the Covid restrictions. Based on the interviews conducted the allegations, that staff are not adequately trained to intervene during incidents and the treatment needs of a child are not being met, are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may or may not have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and the LIC811 were discussed and left with Amanda Lee.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/28/21 at 9:40 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan contacted Amanda Lee, Administrator, to deliver findings for the allegations that staff are not adequately trained to intervene during incidents and the treatment needs of a child are not being met. LPA interviewed three foster youth (C1, C2, C3, see confidential names on LIC811) on 3/24/21, the facility social worker (SW) on 6/14/21, one staff (S1) and the county social worker (CSW) on 6/15/21, and one staff (S2) on 4/8/21. LPA conducted a file review and obtained the following documents: Pro-Act training certificates, staff contacts, maintenance repair logs, four needs and services plans and treatment plans, behavioral plans, and a register of current clients. It is alleged that staff are not adequately trained to intervene during incidents. Staff attend Professional Assault Crisis Training (Pro-Act) for de-escalation and restraint training. The first sixteen hours of Pro-Act training is on hands-off de-escalation techniques. Staff are then trained to use hands-on restraints as a last course of action. If a restraint becomes necessary, two restraint-trained staff must be present to conduct the restraint.

narrative: C3 confirmed she smokes cigarettes but learned she may be pregnant and will stop smoking. C3 and three staff confirm that when youth leaves the facility, staff follow her. If staff loses sight they immediately call law enforcement to report a runaway. C2 confirmed she sometimes smokes marijuana when she goes on unauthorized leave but not at the facility because staff get in her face. S1 stated C2 uses substances infrequently. All clients are offered alcohol and substance use classes if they are using substances or they indicate they may be interested in attending. If clients are using substances staff discuss the dangers, coax clients to give substance to staff, have clients conduct a self-search if they show signs of intoxication or use, and encourage substance use treatment. It is alleged that a minor in care is not adequately provided with care and supervision. C1 fears that C3 is too aggressive and impulsive to live there and that regular staff are doing their best but if C3 returns to the facility she will be a threat to herself, other clients, and staff. C1 stated that C3 needs a higher level of care. According to S1, C3 will not be returning to the facility. A higher level of care is being sought for the youth. Based on information obtained from the interviews C1’s concerns were based on fear that C3 may come back to the facility. Staff follow runaway protocol and contact law enforcement if they lose sight of a youth. Substance use treatment is offered to clients and searches are conducted if contraband is suspected. The inappropriate interactions between minors in care occurred during an unauthorized absence. Staff were not present but had notified law enforcement of youth’s absence. It was determined that C3 requires a higher level of care and will not return to the facility. Although the incidents have occurred, staff followed standard procedures, therefore the allegations that inappropriate interactions between minors in care, staff did not prevent minors from smoking marijuana, minor in care not adequately provided with care and supervision, and lack of supervision resulting in minor going AWOL are UNSUBSTANTIATED. There is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/26/21 at 11:45 aM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan conducted a complaint inspection at the above facility for the purpose of delivering investigation findings. LPA met with Amanda Lee, Administrator. LPA interviewed the complainant, three clients (C1, C2 and C3, see confidential names LIC811) C1 and C2 on 4/19/21, C3 on 4/7/21, and three staff on 4/14/21, 6/14/21 and 6/15/21. LPA reviewed the facility file and obtained the following documents: three foster youth’s need and services plans, incident reports and register of facility clients. The investigation revealed that a foster youth (C1) was concerned about the imminent return of another youth (3) when released from juvenile detention. C1 is concerned for the safety of clients and staff if C3 comes back to the facility. C3 has a history of assaultive and destructive behaviors and was detained due to an assault on staff. It is alleged that there were inappropriate interactions between minors in care, staff did not prevent minors from smoking marijuana and lack of supervision resulted in minor going AWOL. C3 confirmed that while on an unauthorized leave she engaged in sexual activity with a youth from another facility.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled.

In LPA's review of the facility's Program Statement, there was no mention of confiscating clients' belongings as a consequence and storing them locked in the garage for 24 hours. The Department has not approved this method. The facility's Program Statement states the facility uses positive discipline, trauma-informed practices, and that, "staff are trained not to be punitive with the youth." The facility is not following their Program Statement, nor CCL Personal Rights regulations, by confiscating clients' clothes and other personal belongings as a consequence. This practice is also not trauma-informed. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87072(c)(11) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to FM with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

LPA learned from confidential interviews that C1 would often try to push their way into the staff office and need to be prevented from entering by way of body blocking, removing them from the door, or by shutting the door before C1 could enter. LPA reviewed four incident reports detailing incidents like that. LPA was informed in one confidential interview that when C1 had barricaded themselves in their room, S1 tried to push open the door. It became a pushing back and forth situation between them and one individual states that staff pushed the door on the client, and another individual denied it. All other non-involved individuals interviewed either stated they have never seen S1 do that to a client, or that they did not have knowledge of the incident. All staff and all but one client interviewed denied that staff have threatened a client before, other than phrasing for giving consequences. An example of this could be something to the effect of: "if you don't do X, you'll have a point taken away." One client claimed that S1 threatened violence on them. S1 denies ever threatening any client. Based on all evidence collected through interviews and incident reports, LPA has found that C1 and S1 at times have a tumultuous relationship, there are inconsistent statements from clients and staff, and it is uncertain whether or not the allegations occurred. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to FM with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with facility manager Joanna Barnhill, who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing the facility's Program Statement, Incident Reports, and by conducting confidential interviews with six staff, the Administrator, and five clients on 6/15/2022, 6/16/2022, 6/21/2022, 6/22/2022, and 6/23/2022. LPA also received a written statement from the Administrator on 4/1/2022. Based on confidential interviews, LPA learned that staff and clients do put clients' belongings in the garage due to overflow in the clients' own room. This is generally a voluntary choice by the client. However LPA also learned from four clients, the Administrator, and four staff interviewed that clients have had their belongings taken away from them as a punishment for at least 24 hours before, which staff locked inside of the garage.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights...To be free of...withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews with staff and clients, the facility violated the above section when they confiscated clients belongings for at least 24 hours, locked in the garage as a consequence. This is a potential Health, Personal Rights, or Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: By POC due date of 7/29/2022 the facility will submit to CCL a written memo, which is signed by all staff, stating the practice of removing clients' belongings and locking them away for any period of time is prohibited as it violates this personal right.

investigation_findings: 13On 8/31/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver findings for this complaint alleging “Facility is violating client's personal rights by not providing adequate clothing.” LPA met with Amanda Lee, Administrator, to review findings. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted five confidential interviews, and reviewed client files for needs and services plans, clothing inventories, journal entries, and cash resources. LPA interviews determined that each youth is provided adequate clothing. This agency has investigated the allegations of this complaint. There is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview was conducted with administrator and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On January 27, 2023 Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Dara Campos, Regional Office Manager Margo Castaneda, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna held an Informal Conference Meeting from 1:00 PM to 2:45 PM to discuss concerns. The meeting was facilitated by LPM Campos. Attendees included (in-person) Paradise Oaks Youth Services staff, Laynee Kuhn (Executive Director), Stephanie Fischer (Administrator), Amanda Lee (administrator) and Board Member Al Werner, as well as (Via Teams Meeting), Shawn Wade Fresno County Social Worker, Julie Leong, Case Manager Mateo County Behavioral Health, Khoa Nguyen Stanislaus County Social Worker, and Tia Carter Sacramento County Social Worker. The topics discussed included: Absent without Permission Temporary Release (TR) Communication with local law enforcement Cancelling Missing Person reports Incident Report details No deficiencies were cited during today's meeting. A copy of this report was provided to, Amanda Lee, Administrator.

During interviews, three out of three clients denied that staff took inappropriate pictures or videos of them, and instead stated in various ways that staff ask permission first, take a picture for them then delete it, or take a picture of the client on the client's phone. All of these instances were of appropriate pictures. During interviews with the Reporting Party, Assistant Administrator, and the Administrator LPA learned that the accused staff member has been harassed by a former partner who they believe fabricated this allegation. LPA reviewed harassing voicemails and texts by this individual towards the staff. LPA was also informed that there is a past history of this, and Law Enforcement found no merit to this allegation. No inappropriate videos or information were provided to Law Enforcement, and there was no physical evidence of this allegation occurring. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with Assistant Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with them
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Assistant Administrator Johanna Barnhill who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by conducting confidential interviews with the Reporting Party, three clients, the Assistant Administrator and the Administrator on 1/10/2023 and 1/11/2023. LPA also conducted an internet search for the accused staff and reviewed the staff's social media accounts and personal phone and tablet pictures, which were voluntarily shown to LPA by the staff. LPA did not observe any pictures or videos of any client posted by the accused staff on any of their social media accounts. There were also no inappropriate pictures or videos of clients in the staff's cellphone or tablet. There were three deleted pictures of one client which the staff took for the client and then deleted afterwards. These pictures were not inappropriate.

narrative:
Confidential interviews were conducted with nine individuals, and attempted with two individuals, during the period of 03/27/2023 to 05/17/2023. LPA’s observation, interviews conducted, and records reviewed were inconsistent that staff, S1, caused injury to a minor in care, FC1. Statements given by individuals interviewed were inconsistent, including regarding the events that occurred, and the location of the incident. Additionally, it could not be determined when the injury and bruising on FC1’s arm occurred or if it had been caused by S1. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was provided to Amanda Lee- Administrator

Confidential interviews were conducted with nine individuals, and attempted with two individuals, during the period of 03/27/2023 to 05/17/2023. LPA’s observation, interviews conducted, and records reviewed were consistent that staff, S1, used profanity and made inappropriate comments to youth in care. Statements given during interviews were consistent that there were multiple occasions where S1 used profanity and/or made inappropriate comments to youth. Staff were made aware of one instance that S1 used profanity and/or made inappropriate comments to FC5. Based on a review of personnel documentation and based on statements given, this instance was not reported to the Department and the facility stated that no disciplinary action was taken against S1. Additionally, while some allegations of S1 using profanity and/or making inappropriate comments to youth were denied by S1, S1 did admit to multiple instances of using profanity and making inappropriate comments to youth, including to FC1 and FC5, due to “losing their patience” with the youth. The facility is being issued one citation for violations to STRTP ILS section 87072(c)(10). See LIC 809-D for citation and Plan of Correction (POC) information. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Amanda Lee- Administrator
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna conducted an unannounced complaint inspection with the above facility on May 23, 2023 at 03:55 PM and met with Stephanie Piring, Floating Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint findings for the above allegations. On March 27, 2023 at 12:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephannie Verna, arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of initiating a complaint investigation related to the above allegations. LPA met with Stephanie Piring, Floating Administrator. During the course of the investigation, the following documents were gathered and reviewed: Incident Reports for multiple youth, Needs and Services Plans, Intake documentation, and client face sheet for one youth, staff personnel documentation, staff roster and client roster. continued on 812-c

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(10)
Personal Rights
(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (10) To be accorded dignity in their  personal relationships with staff and other persons.


This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on documentation review and statements made during interviews, the licensee did not comply with the section cited where it was determined S1 used profanity and made inappropriate comments to youth in care, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Amanda Lee- Administrator stated that the staff, S1,  will only be scheduled to work in facilities with male clients . Training was given to the staff regarding trauma informed care on May 17th 2023 and A self-control plan was created. In addition the staff was issued a written disciplinary action regarding the incident involving FC5. Amanda Lee- Administrator Submit a written letter outlining how the facility will ensure they remain compliant, ensuring  clients' personal rights are afforded, and regarding the regulation.

narrative:
On September 20, 2023 at 10:30 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager and Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA and the Licensee conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical. The facility is licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory clients, ages 0 to 17 years old. The census is currently three. There were one to two clients present at certain times during the time of the inspection. There were multiple staff present at the time of the inspection, three or more, and there was a facility staff meeting occurring in the external/educational building. The facility license, Emergency Disaster plan, Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights postings, Client menu, Client Daily Activity Schedule, and a boards of resources and flyers were posted in a prominent location in the facility. The home is one story and consists of three bedrooms, two bathrooms, kitchen, dining room, living room, recreation room, a garage, and a backyard with an exterior building utilized for meetings and educational purposes, and no swimming pool or pond. There are no cameras utilized in the home or exterior cameras posted. LAP observed that the living room contained two couches along with a television and a cabinet which contained games. Also, while the facility had a binder in the living room which stored facility grievance forms, the facility's policy regarding procedures was not posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. continued on 809-c

LPA observed two locked hall closets which stored art supplies, soaps and hygiene products and hair styling tool. There were cabinets also located in the hallway which contained extra linens, pillows, towels, and paper supplies, and cabinets for client's personal property. The recreation room contained a couch and a desk. There is a fireplace in the recreation room, that is covered, and not used. The garage contained storage supplies and holiday decor. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table had six six chairs. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and recreation room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had the stove, oven, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen contained a working landline phone. The kitchen cabinets and drawers were in good repair. Sharps were locked in the staff office in a locked box. The pantry was located off of the kitchen in the laundry room. LPA observed sufficient amounts of food in the pantry, refrigerator and freezer and fresh fruits and snacks on the counter. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days were observed. LPA also observed three expired food items in the facility refrigerator that youth have access to. The items that were expired included milk, grape jelly, and deli meat. The facility had extra inventory of these items in another food storage area of the facility, and removed the expired items immediately and replaced them with fresh items. LPA observed that the facility has three bedrooms with double-occupancy floor plan, each client in care had a bed and clean bedding provided including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows. Dressers with operational drawers for personal items, lighting and ample closet or storage space was provided. Windows and screens were in good repair. There were two bathrooms observed in the facility. One bathroom was located in a client bedroom, and the other bathroom was located in the hallway. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. The water temperature was measured to be at 109.5 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. LPA observed a laundry room, which contained a washer and dryer, and refrigerator and freezer with extra food storage; shelving for storage of small kitchen appliances, and locked cabinets. Cleaning supplies and detergents were locked in the cabinets. Cabinets also stored extra cleaning supplies, tools and paper products. At the rear of the laundry room is one staff Social Worker office, and the food pantry, and a locked door to the backyard. continued on 809-c

The backyard contained a small patio with a shaded cover, facility trash cans, the exterior/educational building, and a large grassy area, with a basketball court at the back of the yard. There were no areas of damage to the surrounding fenced area. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. The backyard can be accessed by the two side access points on either side of the facility. There was an area of the grass that had a one to two foot hole, filled halfway with water, LPA Verna was informed by Facility Manager that the facility was in the process of repairing the issue and the area is to be cautioned off while repairs are being made. It was observed that three indoor trash cans located in the kitchen (1) and restrooms (2) did not have tight-fitting covers kept on the trash cans. LPA observed working Carbon Monoxide and smoke detectors, and they were tested and in working condition. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and exterior/education building of the facility. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in August 2023. LPA observed the first aid kit were stored in the staff office. The first aid kit was in tact, with the exception of it not including a current edition of a first aid manual. The confidential client medication and records were stored in the staff office in a locked filing cabinet. While the facility had a binder in the living room while stored facility grievance forms, it was observed that the facilities policy regarding procedures was not posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. While the facility conducts emergency disaster drills quarterly, it was observed that the documentation of the drills conducted does not include the names of staff who participated in the drill and documentation of all drills conducted in the last year were not maintained at the facility. The Administrator provided LPA with documentation of the drill conducted in August 2023.

Upon review of past licensing reports, the Administrator stated that they do not store the facility's past licensing reports for the past three years at the facility and they are stored at another facility office, Rosa Vista. LPA conducted one client interview. LPA Verna completed the following domains of the inspection: Physical Plant, Operations, Core-Therapeutic Services, and Disaster Preparedness. The inspection was not completed on today's date and will be completed, including the following domains: Staff records, Client Records, and Emergency Interventions, on another date. The facility is being issued three citations related to deficiencies to Title 22 Regulations, sections 80076(a)(18) and 80088(f)(1); and Health and Safety Code, section 1538.5(a)(3); and four Technical Advisories related to: Title 22 Regulations, sections 80075(g)(1)(A)and 80023(d)(2); STRTP ILS Regulations section 87072.2(a)(3), and Health and Safety Code, section 1565(c). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, technical deficiencies, and LIC-809D and appeal rights was provided to Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator and Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator.

The youth was discharged to their Authorized Representative and the future custody of the youth was between Authorized Representative and a community member who works at the facility. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on 10.12.23 for the purpose of delivering complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Tasha Bradford, Facility Manager.LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. The investigation was opened at the facility on 07.20.23. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed a Facility Administrator, Clinical Director, Clinical Manager, 4 staff, and 2 youth. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. LPA reviewed relevant records from the facility including, Staff Rosters, Client Needs and Services Plan for the last 18 months, a SCAR, and Client Roster. Six out of eight confidential interviews supported that the youth’s transition plan was developed with the youth’s Authorized Representees agreement and that while the youth resided at the facility there was no disclosed inappropriate interactions between staff and youth. Cont. 9099C

narrative: On November 08, 2023 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA Verna met with Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager. During the review of an Incident Report received from the facility where a reportable incident occurred on 10/31/2023 and 11/02/2023, and involved FC1 and FC2, a case management visit was warranted to gather further information regarding the incidents. LPA Verna requested and reviewed documentation, including the facility event calendar. LPA discussed the incidents with Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager and Administrator, Amanda Lee. LPA gathered further information, including information about the youth involved and facility schedule, antecedents and outcomes of the incidents, and safety measures taken or plans created or implemented by the facility staff surrounding the incidents. LPA conducted a health and safety inspection and observed no deficiencies. LPA completed three interviews. The case management was completed on today's date. An exit interview was conducted and provided to Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager.

On September 25, 2023 at 11:45 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility to complete unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator, who assisted LPA with the inspection. During the review, the HR Director Tennies Gentry arrived with the personnel records for five staff. The personnel records are not maintained at the facility site and are maintained at an agency office located at: 6060 Sunrise Vista Dr. Suite 2100 Citrus Heights, CA 95610. LPA Verna completed the following domains of the inspection: Staff records and Emergency Interventions, and began the inspection of the Client Records domain on today's date. Upon request to inspect the monthly intervention log on 09/20/2023, the log was not present at the facility and was then made available for review on 09/25/2023, and will be maintained at the facility. Upon review of five staff files, it was observed that: Three out of five staff files (S2, S3 S4) reviewed did not include documentation of a criminal record clearance and two out of five staff (S2 and S4) did not have documentation regarding a transfer request on file, as S2 and S4 are currently not associated to the facility, and are associated to another licensed facility. In review of Guardian, all staff had a criminal record clearance on record with the Department. continued on 809-c This report (page 1) was amended, signed by and a copy was given to Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager.

It was observed that while the facility had a "New Employment Confirmation" document in the staff files pertaining to initial staff training, the document did not include the exact date of completion and length of each initial (8 hour and 16 hour) of each training/topic. It was observed that S1's and S3's staff file did not contain all annual training documentation for the past year, 2022. Completion of the annual training could not be confirmed for S1 and S3. LPA Verna was informed by the Administrator that training was completed fully online in 2022. It was observed that one out of five staff files (S5) did not contain a current and valid CPR/first aid certificate or card, and (S2) had an expired CPR/first aid card filed in their staff file (expiration date of 07/12/2023) It was observed that one out of five staff (S5) files reviewed was missing the health screening and TB test document. It was observed that one staff file (S1) had an incorrect employee rights and the Employee Rights (LIC 9052) was not signed by the employees (S1 and S4) and filed in their file. LPA conducted one staff interview. The facility is being issued three citations related to deficiencies to STRTP ILS sections, 87065.1(e)(7), 87065.1(d)(6)(A) and Title 22 Regulations, section 80066(a)(12)(B); and multiple Technical Advisories. LPA Verna completed the following domains of the inspection: Staff records, and Emergency Interventions, and will complete the domain Client Records on another date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, technical deficiencies, and LIC-809D and appeal rights was provided to Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator.

On October 05, 2023 at 12:00 P.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility to complete an unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator, who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA Verna completed the Client Records domain on today's date. Upon review of three client files, it was observed that: Two out of three (C2 and C3) medical assessments or LIC 620 forms were not present in the client records. One out of two youth records (C2) had documentation of youth's refusal to attend medical appointments. There have been no other refusals documents since 06/02/2023 to complete the medical assessment/TB test. C3 attended a physical in November 2023, however the document does not include all required information. Two out of three (C2 and C3) medical assessments or LIC 620 forms were not present in the client records and there were no records of required information, TB test results, physical restrictions, determination of child's ambulatory status and prescribed medications. One out of two youth records (C2) had documentation of youth's refusal to attend medical appointments. C3 attended a physical in November 2023, however the document does not include all required information including TB test results, physical restrictions, determination of child's ambulatory status and prescribed medications. continued on 809-c This report (page 1) was amended, signed by and a copy was given to Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager.

One out of three client initial NSP (C1) was not due yet, however was completed, and three out of three initial NSP did not contain required signatures (C1, C2, C3). C2's initial NSP (05/09/2023) was not signed by the client, and C3's initial NSP (11/17/2022) was completed within 30 days, however the NSP in the file was not signed by the client or their authorized representative. It was observed that NSP were not updated every 30 days following the initial date of placement, including for NSPs for C2 and C3. Additionally, some NSP were missing from the youth records for some months the youth was in care (C2 and C3). C2 was missing documented NSP for July-September 2023, and C3 was missing documented NSP for December 2022, February 2023, and May-September 2023. It was observed that three out of three youth had NSPs filed in their client records which were missing signatures, including the client and Authorized Representative signatures. In some cases, there was record/emails of the facility requesting signatures from the Authorized Representatives, but only once attempt was documented in each case. The facility is being issued three citations pertaining to deficiencies to STRTP ILS sections, 87070(c)(1), 87068.2(f), and 87068.3(a); and technical advisories related to Title 22 regulations, sections 80069(a) and 80069(c) LPA Verna completed the required annual inspection on today's date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, technical deficiencies, and LIC-809D and appeal rights was provided to Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator.

narrative: On December 28, 2023 at 01:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA Verna met with Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator. During the review of an Incident Report completed by a staff of the facility (S1), where a reportable incident occurred on 10/02/2023, and involving FC1 and S2, a case management inspection was warranted to inquire if the incident had been reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) as required. LPA Verna discussed the incident with Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator, and gathered further information. LPA Verna inquired with Laynee Kuhn, Director, regarding the submission of the incident report, who confirmed the incident was not reported to CCL. The facility was issued a technical advisory regarding CCR Title 22 Regulations, section 80061(b), Reporting Requirements. A signed copy of this LIC-809 report was provided to Joanna Barnhill, Facility Manager, and an exit interview was conducted.

On January 05, 2024 at 1:20 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of meeting with Administrator, Amanda Lee. LPA arrived and waited for the Administrator to arrive at the facility. LPA Verna met with Amanda Lee, Administrator, who signed the Civil Penalty Assessment Form (LIC421FC) regarding a visit made to the facility on December 28, 2023. LPA Verna provided a copy of the signed LIC421FC and this report to Amanda Lee, Administrator.

Confidential interviews were conducted with ten individuals and attempted with one individual during the period of 10/05/2023 to 12/28/2023. LPA’s interviews conducted, and records reviewed were consistent that a staff violated a youth’s personal rights. Multiple statements given during interviews were consistent that S1 had violated FC1’s personal rights, by not affording them dignity and respect, when laughing at the youth, making insensitive comments and power-struggling with the youth. Additionally, S1 did not utilize a trauma-informed approach when engaging with FC1. Documentation, including Incident Reports, revealed that there was prior known concerns of personal rights and HIPAA violations regarding S1 recording FC1 during an interaction that occurred on 10/02/2023. S1 has received coaching from their Supervisor in the months of October and November 2023, however additional development and training was identified as still being needed for S1, per S1’s employment evaluation completed and dated October 22, 2023. Based on LPA documentation reviewed, and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is being issued one citation regarding a violation of STRTP ILS section 87072(c)(10), Personal Rights. The facility is also being issued a Civil Penalty for a repeat violation of the same regulation within a 12 month period. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Amanda Lee, Administror.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(10)
Personal Rights
(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (10) To be accorded dignity in their  personal relationships with staff and other persons.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on documentation review and five statements made during interviews, the licensee did not comply with the section cited where it was determined S1 made inappropriate gestures and comments to a youth in care (FC1), which posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Administrator stated that they will assess S1's progress at this time related to training and development at their current assigned facility. Additionally, there will be a Corrective Action or Write Up completed with S1 regarding youth personal rights being violated. Along with this, there will also be assigned mandated training for S1 to complete and is to include training topics related to trauma-informed approaches, and youth personal rights. The facility will provide all completed personnel and training documentation to the Department  by the POC due date.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Tina Thorn on 08/25/2023 at 08:45AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Valencia and Thorn met with Amanda Lee, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed two of two (2 of 2) child’s records and 2 of 2 staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed two of two (2 of 2) child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two of two (2 of 2) staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed two of two (2 of 2) of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection the LPAs observed four (4) deficiencies (see attached 809Ds), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Amanda Lee, Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
Section 87068.3(a) Modifications to The Needs and Services Plan (a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days This regulation was not met as evidenced by:
Based on observation and record review, two of two (2 of 2) clients in care did not have Needs and services plans completed every 30 days, which poses potential health, safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: facility agrees to implement a documentation policy to provide proof of effort to get signatures from all parties and schedule a CFT meeting every 30 days and have meeting notes in file.

Based on observation and record review,  the needs and services plans were not signed by authorized rep, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.

narrative: On March 04, 2024 at 02:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA Verna met with Justin Le, Facility Manager. During the review of an Incident Report (IR) received from the facility on 02/21/24, it was reported that on 02/20/2024 a client in care (C1), made an allegation to Law Enforcement of a personal rights violation that had occurred while in care. LPA Verna conducted confidential interviews, discussed the incident and confirmed further information and interventions taken by parties involved, including the facility staff and Law Enforcement. Further information is to be documented in an addendum incident report, and will be submitted by the facility Administrator to the Department regarding the outcomes of the incident. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed at the facility during today's case management inspection. No citations are being issued. The case management inspection was completed on today's date. An exit interview was conducted with Justin Le, Facility Manager, and the facility was provided a copy of this report.

LPA inspected the facility inside and out with Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator. The case management will need to be completed another day.

Confidential interviews were conducted with six individuals, and attempted with one individual, during the period of 8/6/24 to 11/5/24. The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegations: Lack of staff supervision resulting in minors engaging in inappropriate activity. During the investigation, six interviews were conducted, C1 reported feeling pressured by C2 to vape and expressed dissatisfaction with staff support but admitted to being a follower and not standing up for herself. C2 denied pressuring C1, claiming that C1 initiated requests to vape, and that staff provided support for her coping skills. Staff generally reported that while C1 and C2 had a complicated dynamic, there was no clear evidence of C2 pressuring C1. Staff supervision is in ratio and if C1 has AWOL they do follow their emergency intervention. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with, and a copy of this report was provided to Amanda Lee, Administrator.

Confidential interviews were conducted with five individuals during the period of 9/5/24 to 11/27/24. The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegations: Staff made inappropriate comments towards a minor During the investigation, multiple interviews were conducted with C1, S1, S2, S3, and S4, and relevant records were reviewed. C1 alleged that S3, told them to "shut up" during a conversation about an activity. However, S2, S1, and S4, denied making the comment. They stated that C1 became upset over a misunderstanding regarding the activity and used inappropriate language, but no one recalled telling C1 to "shut up." S3, who was not present at the time of the incident, also denied hearing any staff make inappropriate comments toward C1 or any other youth. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with, and a copy of this report was provided to Aubrey Douglas, Facility Manager.

narrative: Confidential interviews were conducted with five individuals, and attempted with one individual, during the period of 9/5/24 to 11/27/24. The department has conducted a complaint investigation regarding the allegations: Staff speaks inappropriately to minors in care. Staff does not provide adequate supervision to minors in care. Facility administrator is not present during facility operations. During the investigation, S1, S2, S3, and C1 were all interviewed regarding the allegations. S1, S2, and S3 consistently denied that staff had spoken inappropriately to minors or used derogatory language, with no clear evidence to support such claims. C1 mentioned overhearing an isolated instance of inappropriate language but could not identify who said it or to whom it was directed. C2 however reported there was derogatory comments toward her by S1. Regarding supervision, all staff confirmed that minors are adequately monitored, although C1 and C2 expressed concern when only one staff member is present with multiple minors. However, staff explained they follow established procedures in such situations. Finally, while the Administrator's presence was reported to be minimal, there was no indication that it negatively impacted the care or operations of the facility. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with, and a copy of this report was provided to Naeem Brown Assistant Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Avelina Martinez arrived at this facility unannounced on June 16, 2025 at 9:10 AM to conduct a case management visit. LPA Martinez met with Naeem Brown (Assistant Administrator) and explained the purpose of the visit. The purpose of the visit today is to discuss the following deficiency: reporting requirements. During record reviews, it was learned that the facility has not reported incidents to the Department as required. The unreported incidents that occurred directly threatened the physical, emotional health, and safety of the clients in care. Documentation shows child 1 (C1) had seven incidents pertaining to aggression towards staff and youth. There were two incidents of verbal aggression towards staff and youth. Three inappropriate sexual behavior incidents towards staff. On February 07, 2025, an event occurred that was not reported to the Department. Staff 1 (S1) and child 1 (C1) were in a physical altercation. Upon the occurrence, the facility staff did not implement a safety plan that would entail de-escalation of physical aggression and the separation of S1 and C1. A February 07, 2025, facility notes, indicated this incident would not be addressed until February 13, 2025, CFT meeting. The lack of addressing the February 07, 2025, altercation in a timely manner resulted in a second physical altercation between S1 and C1 on February 09, 2025. Continued...

Based on records review there were physical aggression commonalities between the unreported incidents and the physical altercations on February 07, 2025. However, the identified behavioral patterns were not addressed after the February 07, 2025, altercation. As a result, the Agency will be cited, and the 80061(b) reporting requirement deficiency can be found on the 809-D page. LPA Martinez will also return at a later date and time to follow up on the following: Open bedroom door policy, bedtime hours, and access to bedrooms. An exit interview was conducted with Naeem Brown (Assistant Administrator). A copy of this 809 report, 809D page, and appeals rights were given to the facility at the end of this visit.

narrative: Confidential interviews were conducted with seven individuals, and attempted to interview four individuals, during the period of February 28, 2025, to June 05, 2025. LPA Martinez’s interviews conducted, and records reviewed were inconsistent that facility staff rough handled C1. There was no corroboration for the allegation “Facility staff handled youth in a rough manner,” as C1 declined to be interviewed. Additionally, two out of three children denied any mistreatment from facility staff. Two out of three facility staff reported C1 was not rough handled by them. One out three staff was informed of the altercation between S1 and C1, but they did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. Based on LPA Martinez’s interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Naeem Brown (Assistant Administrator).

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Suzanne Martinez and Licensing Program Manager Stephen Kim conducted a case management inspection on July 22, 2025, at 12:00 PM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 2 youths were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811 (July 22, 2025). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the Board of Directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were emailed and reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth files review including the Needs and Service Assessments, Safety Plan, Risk Assessment and Treatment Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Martinez observed documentation of completed training and policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Carla Izzarelli.

On 01/08/2021 at 8:54 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Robin Sullivan contacted Amanda Lee to conduct a case management pre-move-in inspection. Paradise Oaks is relocating four clients from the Olivine facility to this facility later today. The inspection was conducted virtually due to COVID19. LPA observed required documents, including personal rights, CCL and Ombudsman information, emergency disaster plan, and COVID health notification posted in multiple locations. The facility has a sign in sheet and thermometer near the front entrance. LPA observed the smoke detector and carbon monoxide to be in working order. LPA observed all required bedding to be present and on each bed. All bedrooms have closets, hangers, and dressers for personal storage space. The showers, toilets, and bath sinks were observed to be clean and functioning. LPA observed seven days of non-perishable food and three days of perishable foods along with many snack items. Client medications and med binders are stored in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office. The client binders will be transported to Rosa Vista from Olivine later in the day when the clients are moved over. LPA observed the facility to be clean and in good condition for the relocation of clients.
