On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learning wa

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan conducted unannounced required annual inspection on 6/30/2021 at 11:50 PM with Carly Brown, Case Manager. The facility’s status of some requirements are as follows: · Accreditation review with CARF International was conducted 4/26/21-4/28/21 and new certificate is pending. · Mental Health Contract is annual with Sacramento County. · Mental Health Program is currently in process of renewal. The facility census is three. No clients were present during the inspection. The following items were observed and evaluated by LPA Sullivan: Posted items in the facility: Facility License, Emergency Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Personal Rights, Foster Youth Ombudsman, exit routes, COVID-19 handwashing instructions, and health and safety information are posted. .Kitchen- One refrigerator was tested below 45 degrees F; three freezers tested at or below zero degrees. Hot water temperature tested within the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees. Sharps are stored and locked inside the staff office. Adequate food supply including 3 days of perishable and 1 week of non-perishable items were observed. Dishwasher is operable. Adequate dishware and cooking utensils are present to meet capacity. There are no refrigerated medications. The trash can is covered. Living Area-. All window screens installed and in good condition. Seating capacity in living room and dining area accommodate all clients. Smoke & Carbon monoxide detectors are present and operable. Bedrooms- 3 of 3 client bedrooms were observed to have all had the required furnishings, including storage space. Each bed has the required mattress pad, fitted sheet, top sheet, blankets and pillow bed covering. Additional linen supplies are stored in the hall closet. Windows have screens and coverings. Smoke detectors are operable.

Bathrooms- Hot water temperature tested within the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees. Toilets, sinks, and tub/showers were clean and operable. Disposable towels observed at sinks. Clients have individual personal hygiene supplies and additional hygiene items are stored in a hall closet. Buildings and Grounds- Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were tested and are working. Facility was clear of hazards and observed to be clean and safe. Telephone: Available and in operable condition. Cleaning & Chemical Supplies: Adequate, locked and stored in a hall closet. Doors and Passageways: Clean and free of obstructions. Facility has no bodies or water, cameras, or firearms on the premises. Facility vehicle has current registration and insurance. The tires observed to be new and all seat belts function. Exterior was clean and free of debris. Outdoor maintenance storage shed was locked and not available for inspection. Medication- Medication is stored in a locked container inside the locked staff office. Documentation of dispensing medication was reviewed. Facility has copies court or parent approval for dispensing medications. First aid kit (manual, tweezers, scissors, dressings, bandages, adhesive tape, thermometer, antiseptic solution) was available and had an adequate supply of items. Records- LPAs reviewed three of three client files. LPA Sullivan will review employee files located at the Administrative office. An exit interview was conducted and the inspection discussed with Carly Brown. Copies of documentation were provided to the facility. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled.

Based on the interviews conducted and the documents reviewed the allegation that staff had a hit and run accident while transporting a foster child is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. investigation_findings: 13On 11/10/2021 at 11:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan went, unannounced, to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings on the allegation that staff had a hit and run accident while transporting a foster child. LPA met with Breana Gatson, Assistant Administrator. During the investigation LPA interviewed one staff (S4) on 7/26/21, three clients (C1-C3) and one staff (S3) on 10/21/21, two staff (S1, S2) on 10/25/21 and one client (C3) on 11/2/21. The following documents were obtained and reviewed: facility vehicle maintenance log, client rosters, and staff schedules and contact information. The investigation revealed that two of three clients have no memory of being in a facility vehicle that may have backed into a parked car or hit an object. Four staff have no knowledge of either facility van being involved in an accident. LPA observed two facility vehicles to have dents, dings, and scratches on the rear bumper. The facility vehicle maintenance log has no record of vehicle body repair between 10/03/2020 – 08/03/2021.

deficiencies.description: 87076(a) Food Service the following shall apply: (80076(A)(5) states Menus shall be written at least one week in advance and copies of the menus as served shall be dated and kept on file for at least 30 days. Menus shall be made available for review by the clients or their authorized representatives and the licensing agency upon request. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA Stidman observation on 1/19/22 the facility’s menu posted was dated July 2021 and the Administrator stated this was the last one the facility received from the licensee.This pose s an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Faciltiy will ensure the menu shall be written at least one week in advance and copies of the menus as served shall be dated and kept on file for at least 30 days. LPAs observed the facility has current menus posted for the month of April 2022.

investigation_findings: 13On 10/4/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegation of “Staff are making inappropriate comments to clients.” LPA met with Stephanie Piring, Administrator, and discussed the above allegation. During the investigation of this allegation, LPA toured the facility with Administrator, Amanda Lee on 6/15/22 and 8/11/22. During these inspections, LPA inspected the physical plant inside and out, reviewed two client files, and obtained documentation for the complaint investigation including incident reports, client inventories, training, and meeting agenda. LPA conducted eleven confidential interviews during investigation. Five of the eleven interviews reported that staff comments are not trauma informed and have been interpreted to be rude or inappropriate. There is no documentation of comments being reported to staff or discussed during therapy. Continued on 9099-C

narrative: Eight of the eleven interviews reported that this policy was not being followed due to clients not being informed of the search, not being present during the search, and not being informed of items removed during the search. Documentation observed stated that clients have the right to be present for the room search and that staff are to request approval from the social worker and document this request and the outcome of the search on the incident report. Incident reports reviewed for room searches for May and June 2022 documented that clients were not present for the room searches and do not indicate if approval was requested from the social worker before the search was conducted. Based on LPAs observations, confidential interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards v4, Regulation 87072(c)(11) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were reviewed and left at the facility with Stephanie Piring, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/4/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegation of “Facility is not following policy and procedures regarding room searches.” LPA met with Stephanie Piring, Administrator, and discussed the above allegation. During the investigation of this allegation, LPA toured the facility with Administrator, Amanda Lee on 6/15/22 and 8/11/22. During these inspections, LPA inspected the physical plant inside and out, reviewed two client files, and obtained documentation for the complaint investigation including incident reports, client inventories, training, and meeting agenda. LPA conducted eleven confidential interviews during investigation. Eleven of the confidential interviews reported that it is the facility’s policy to inform the clients of room searches, provide clients the opportunity to be present for the search, and to inform them when items are confiscated. Continued on 9099-C

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child… is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition,...: To be free of... actions of a punitive nature... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, eleven interviews stated it was the facility’s policy to inform client’s before conducting a search of their belongings and eight of those interviews reported that clients are not informed of the search or of the items that were confiscated.  Incident reports documented that youth were not present for the room searches. This poses an immediate personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will provide additional training to all staff on personal rights and the facility room search policy.  A plan for training will be provided to licensing by 10/5/22 outlining how all staff will be trained by 11/5/22. The licensee will provide the written room search policy to licensing by 11/5/22.

Department of Social Services IB Investigator, Shannan Borton, Badge #238, conducted the complaint investigation for: Sexual Abuse: “Staff asking youth to post inappropriate pictures on social media,” and “Staff propositioned minor(s) in care for sex acts.” On 6/15/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger initiated the complaint investigation inspection at the facility. LPA Caplinger conducted a facility inspection inside and out. No deficiencies were cited at the time of the inspection. LPA Caplinger informed the Administrator that Investigative Branch (IB) Investigator will be contacting the facility for further investigation. Continued on 9099-C

narrative: On 10/4/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection for the purpose of conducting a case management regarding recent incidents of substance use at the facility. LPA met with Stephanie Piring, Administrator, to discuss the incidents. LPA conducted a walk through to observe the facility inside and outside. LPA conducted three confidential interviews for this case management. No deficiencies were noted during this inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Stephanie Piring, Administrator, and a final copy of this report was left at the facility.

Based on LPAs observations and confidential interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards v4, Regulation 87076(6) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were left at the facility with Amanda Lee, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/27/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegations of “Facility does not provide adequate food to clients.” LPA met with Amanda Lee, Administrator, and discussed the above allegation. During the investigation, LPA Caplinger conducted unannounced inspections on 5/18/22, 6/10/22 and 6/15/22. LPA Caplinger obtained documentation for the complaint investigation of staff communication logs, team meeting notes, house meeting notes, and activity plans as well as reviewed three client files during inspection. LPA conducted ten confidential interviews regarding the complaint. Confidential interviews and record review revealed the facility was out of compliance with providing adequate food to clients. Based on five confidential interviews and record review, it was determined that clients are not given the opportunity to grocery shop for items. Continued on 9099- C

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87076 (c) (6) As agreed upon with a licensee, a child shall have the opportunity to plan meals, grocery shop, and store and prepare food. This was not met as evidenced by:
Based on confidential interviews and record review, five interviews revealed that clients are not given the opportunity for consistent meal planning or grocery shopping and clients do not have access to all food available at the facility as items locked in the garage are not accessible to the clients for meal preparation.  Record review documented one-time clients were given the opportunity to choose items for grocery shopping.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will ensure all youth have the opportunity to plan meals, grocery shop, and store and prepare food by discussing this during the weekly house meeting.  The facility will individually check in with youth that were not present during the house meeting and have them sign on the meeting notes.  Facility will provide weekly house meeting notes to LPA by 8/26/22.

narrative: Based on LPAs observations and confidential interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards v4, Regulation 87079(e) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were left at the facility with Amanda Lee, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/27/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an unannounced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegations of “Facility does not provide activities for clients.” LPA met with Amanda Lee, Administrator, and discussed the above allegation. During the investigation, LPA Caplinger conducted unannounced inspections on 5/18/22, 6/10/22 and 6/15/22. LPA Caplinger obtained documentation for the complaint investigation of staff communication logs, team meeting notes, house meeting notes, and activity plans as well as reviewed three client files during inspection. LPA conducted ten confidential interviews regarding the complaint. Confidential interviews and record review revealed the facility was out of compliance with providing activities for clients. On 6/15/22, the facility did not have a weekly schedule of activities posted and copies of the weekly schedules were not available for review. Based on five confidential interviews and record review, it was also determined that clients are not given the opportunity to plan activities. Continued on 9099-C

deficiencies.description: 87079(e) A schedule of the planned activities shall be posted on at least a weekly basis in a central facility location readily accessible to children, relatives, and representatives of placement and referral agencies. This was not met as evidenced by: The facility was observed on 6/15/22 to not have a weekly schedule of activities posted. Based on confidential interviews and record review, scheduled activities are not being offered on a regular basis.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will re-train staff in activity planning and documentation requirements.  Facility will provide evidence of this training and a copy of the current activity plan to the LPA by 8/26/22 with a statement that the plan is posted and stored per the requirements.

narrative: Based on interviews and documentation observed, self-harming is occurring in the facility. However, there is no evidence that the staff were aware of the self-harming as it happened to prevent it. The facility provided documentation of resources provided to the youth regarding self-harming and discusses this with the youth during therapy. Self-harming is addressed in the youth’s Needs and Services plan. Confidential interviews corroborated that staff supervise the youth and maintain a safe facility free of sharp objects to prevent self-harm. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/28/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger, conducted an announced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegations of “Staff did not prevent minor from self-harming.” LPA met with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, and discussed the above allegation. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the facility on 08/11/2022 by LPA Caplinger. A walk through of the facility was conducted and LPA obtained copies of incident reports for one youth, case notes for two youth, needs and services for one youth and CFT meeting notes for one youth. Seven confidential interviews were conducted during the investigation. Continued on 9099- C

narrative: Two of the nine interviews reported that staff comments have been interpreted to be rude or inappropriate. There is no documentation of comments being reported to staff or discussed during therapy. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Amanda Lee, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/28/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Jessica Caplinger and Stephanie Lor, conducted an announced inspection to deliver findings for a complaint with allegations of “Facility staff are treating clients in a rude, hostile, and disrespectful manner.” LPAs met with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, at the agency regional office and discussed the above allegation. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted at the facility on 07/19/2022 by LPA Burgess. A walk through of the facility was conducted and copies of agency documentation obtained include current client roster, needs and services plans, staff schedules, on call tracker, staff timecards, communication notes and daily logs for time period April – June 2022. Nine confidential interviews were conducted during the investigation. Continued on 9099-C

narrative: On January 27, 2023 Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Dara Campos, Regional Office Manager Margo Castaneda, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna held an Informal Conference Meeting from 1:00 PM to 2:45 PM to discuss concerns. The meeting was facilitated by LPM Campos. Attendees included (in-person) Paradise Oaks Youth Services staff, Laynee Kuhn (Executive Director), Stephanie Fischer (Administrator), Amanda Lee (administrator) and Board Member Al Werner, as well as (Via Teams Meeting), Shawn Wade Fresno County Social Worker, Julie Leong, Case Manager Mateo County Behavioral Health, Khoa Nguyen Stanislaus County Social Worker, and Tia Carter Sacramento County Social Worker. The topics discussed included: Absent without Permission Temporary Release (TR) Communication with local law enforcement Cancelling Missing Person reports Incident Report details No deficiencies were cited during today's meeting. A copy of this report was provided to Amanda Lee, Administrator.

On March 01, 2023 at 12:05 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA Verna met with staff Hansel Owhowho. There was one staff and one client present in the facility at the time of LPA's arrival. During the review of an Incident Report received from the facility, where reportable incidents occurred on dates including 02/22/2023 and 02/24/2023, LPA Verna required additional information and a case management inspection was determined to be required. LPA Verna discussed incidents and gathered further information from staff. LPA requested, reviewed and gathered documentation pertaining to the youth involved in the incident(s). LPA completed three interviews. LPA completed a physical inspection of the facility, assisted by staff Hansel Owhowho. No citations are being issued during today's inspection. Further investigation is needed to complete the Case Management related to the Incidents and Incident Reports Received. A signed copy of this LIC-809 report was provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted with Stephanie Piring, Floating Administrator.

On March 06, 2023 at 03:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA Verna met with Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator. During the review of an Incident Report received from the facility, where reportable incidents occurred on dates including 02/22/2023 and 02/24/2023, LPA Verna required additional information and a case management inspection was determined to be required. LPA Verna discussed incidents and gathered further information from Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator. LPA gathered documentation pertaining to the youth involved in the incident(s). LPA gathered additional information pertaining to staffing, Law Enforcement Contact, youth behaviors and staff interventions. LPA completed one interview. No citations are being issued during today's inspection. Further investigation is needed to complete the Case Management related to the Incidents and Incident Reports Received. A signed copy of this LIC-809 report was provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted with Amanda Lee, Facility Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dung Mac conducted a case management inspection on April 5, 2023 at 10:30 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, April 5, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were emailed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and Daily Communication Log, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Mac observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Amanda Lee.

Page 2. The records of 4/10/23 stated that FC1 refused this appointment and stated they want a new dentist. On the issue of court appointments, S2 stated that the facility has an agreement with the county that the county will pick FC1 up for court days as the facility does not participate in scheduling the hearings and are not made aware when those appointments are scheduled. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Allegation #3. Staff are not picking up minor in a timely manner. During the interview, FC1 stated that staff does not pick them from school in a timely manner. FC1 stated they have had to wait more than 2 hours before being picked up on one occasion and 30 minutes or so on some other occasions. When staff was interviewed, S1 stated that staff was late to pick FC1 up one time that she remembers, and this incident was addressed in another complaint. When FC3 was interviewed at school, FC3 stated that they have not experienced staff picking them up late from school. When S6 was interviewed on 7/20/23, S6 stated that he picks up the child that gets off from school by 2:45 pm and that the staff that resumes work at 2:00 pm picks up the youth that gets out of school by 2:50 pm. S6 stated that there was never a conflict in picking up the kids that he remembers because FC1 rarely goes to school and when FC1 attends school, FC1 calls the facility randomly and other times in the morning hours to pick FC1 from school. S6 said when this happens, he is the one that picks FC1 up from school. During the second interview of FC1 on 5/25/23, FC1 stated that staff does not pick them up on time and because of this reason they do not attend school regularly. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Cont. 3.

Page 3. Allegation # 4. Staff are making inappropriate comments towards minors. On 4/28/23, FC1 stated that there was an incident on 4/20/23 where S5 was inciting FC2. FC2 corroborated this this and stated that on 4/20/23, S5 was inciting them to become violent by telling FC2 to “run up or shut up.” When S5 was interviewed on 5/10/23, S5 denied making the comment and stated that FC2 had shown her a tattoo gang carving on FC2’s skin. S5 expressed the belief that FC2 was trying to intimidate her by the tattoo. S5 stated that during that incident, FC2 called their grandmother to report S5 and Staff could hear the grandmother uphold FC2’s action. S5 stated she could hear grandma of FC2 telling FC2 to "show the Sacramento bitch what the 209 is all about.” Facility Manager submitted an incident report to LPA about this incident. The report revealed the youths were aggressive towards staff without provocation. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Allegation #7. Staff don't provide minors with privacy. When staff was interviewed regarding this allegation on 4/26/23 and 5/11/23, all staff stated that they provide the minors with adequate privacy, however whenever two minors that are not located together in the same room are seen together, the facility policy provides that staff should be close by to monitor and prevent them from fighting which happens very often when the clients stay close to each other. When FC2 was interviewed on 4/26/23, the youth stated that they, referring to the youths, are aware that when two youths who are not placed together in one room come together, a staff is required to be close by and this is because they fight when they come together, and staff is trying to prevent them from fighting. FC1 also stated they understand they could have gone outside to make the call, but they did not wish to take the call outside. Cont on 4.

Page 4. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Allegation #10. Facility is dirty. During the youths’ interviews on 4/26/23 both FC1 and FC2 stated that the facility was left dirty for about 2 days. During the interview of the facility manager, S1 on 4/26/23, S1 stated that the youths fought in the living room and spilled ketchup all over the floor. LPA observed the carpet has been cleaned but there was still stain on the carpet from that incident. A picture of the evidence was obtained. S1 stated that due to the amount of spill, a work order was placed for the carpet to be deep cleaned. On 4/28/23 the carpet cleaned company cleaned the carpet, but the stain could not be completely removed. On 7/13/23, LPA visited the facility, and the Facility Manager informed the LPA that a work order has been issued to change the carpet and the company had come out to take measurements. LPA observed the stain on the carpet floor, and litters all over the office floor. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeals right was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Allegation #2. Staff are not ensuring minors are taken to appointments. During the interview of FC1 on 4/26, FC1 stated that staff does not regularly provide transportation to their dental and court appointments and that staff does not inform them in a timely manner about their appointments. FC1 said because they do not get this information on time, they are not able to prepare for their appointments. When FC2 was interviewed, FC2 stated that they have not been declined transportation to their appointments, but that staff has failed to take FC1 to some of their court appointments. When FC3 was interviewed on 5/9/23, FC3 stated they have not experienced staff not taking FC3 to their appointments. During the interview with FC1’s case manager, the Case Manager stated that FC1 is the one refusing to attend their dental appointments. S2 provided CFT notes to corroborate this statement. The note showed that FC1 attended the checkup scheduled on 3/20/23 where the doctor referred them for orthodontist and fillings visit. The notes on 4/3/23 stated that FC1 refused to come out of their room or attend this appointment and it was rescheduled on 4/10/23. Cont 2.

narrative: Page 2. Allegation #1. Staff is not keeping minors’ personal information confidential. During the interview of FC1 on 4/26/23, FC1 stated that on one occasion, S1 followed them to the bus stop, and while they were trying to awol, staff told the bus driver they were from a mental hospital and not to let them on the bus because they were leaving the facility without permission. Another passenger on the bus said that FC1 should not be allowed on the bus. Staff disclosed they told the bus driver not to let FC1 on the bus because FC1 is a minor running away from the facility and the bus driver should not aid a minor to run away. FC1 was refused a ride on the bus and returned to the facility. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Sec. 80072, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. (a) Except for children’s residential facilities, each child shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to the following: (3) to be free from …humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report delivered to Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 8/4/23 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced complaint visit to the Paradise Oaks in Rosa Vista to deliver findings for this complaint. LPA met Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator and informed her of the purpose of the visit. On 4/26/23, LPA Ajaero visited the facility and interviewed the Facility Manager (S1). LPA Ajaero obtained incident reports, needs and services plan for FC1, work order currently in place for carpet cleaning, case notes, CFT meeting notes for FC1. LPA also interviewed the Agency Social Worker, (ASW), S4, FC1 and FC2. On 4/28/23, LPA interviewed FC3 at school. On 5/11/23, LPA interviewed another Facility Administrator, S3. On 5/12/23, LPA interviewed the Facility Case Manager, S2. LPA interviewed Staff S6 on 5/25/23 and FC1 again on the same day. Cont.

deficiencies.description: (a) Except for children’s residential facilities, each child shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to the following: (3) to be free from …humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse… Based on LPAs record review and multiple statements given during interviews, staff disclosed minor's confidential information which violates youths' rights to confidentiality. This is a potential risk to the health & safety of children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will review the rights to confidentiality of all youths in the facility and train their staff. Facility will email proof of training to LPA Ajaero by EOB 8/14/23.

narrative: The child who was the alleged victim did not sufficiently detail the nature of the purported bullying by a peer. When asked and pressed, the child would not or could not provide specific examples of instances that can be reasonably characterized as bullying. The context in which the report was made was immediately after a physical altercation that resulted from a disruption in the facility by the child and the peer’s response to that disruption. Both children corroborated that a direct-care staff-person was present and intervened during the incident. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/19/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this facility to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Assistant Administrator Joanna Barnhill and the following report was discussed: LPA investigated a complaint alleging that Staff are not preventing minor(s) from bullying other minor while in care. The investigation was opened on 08/02/2023 via an unannounced onsite inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) wherein a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant was done. On the same day, interviews were also conducted with two Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) staff and two youth in care. Records requested were the Needs & Services Plans (where available) for youth as well as training records for direct-care staff. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. LPA met with Facility Manager (FM) Ashley Rupp, and Terricka Jennings (staff) who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA spoke with one client about a matter unrelated to this facility. An exit interview was conducted with staff and a copy of this report was sent to Administrator Amanda Lee.

On November 20, 2023 at 10:00 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Naeem Brown, Facility Assistant Administrator who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA and the Facility Assistant Administrator conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The facility is licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory clients, ages 0 to 17 years old. The census is currently three. There were two clients present at the time of the inspection. There were four staff present at the time of the inspection. The facility license and Emergency Disaster plan were posted in a locked staff office. The client Personal Rights poster and facility grievance procedure was not posted or present at the time of the inspection. The Client menu, Facility Sketch, Client Daily Activity Schedule, and a boards of resources and flyers were posted in a prominent location in the facility. The home is one story and consists of three bedrooms, two bathrooms, kitchen, dining room, living room, recreation room, a garage/storage room, staff offices and a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. There are no cameras utilized in the home or exterior cameras posted. LPA observed that the recreation room contained two couches and a chair along with a television and a shelf which contained games, books and DVDs. The recreation room contained a chair and a desk. There is an electric fireplace in the recreation room and is not used. Also, while the facility had a binder in the recreation room which stored facility grievance forms, the facility's policy regarding procedures was not posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. LPA observed two locked hall closets which contained extra linens, towels, and cleaning supplies. Cleaning supplies and detergents were locked in the cabinets. There were shelves located in the garage which contained storage supplies and holiday decor, hygiene supplies, soaps and hygiene products and extra food storage, including a refrigerator and freezer. continued on 809-c

LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and living room and it had a table had five chairs. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and recreation room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had a stove, oven, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The light bulb in the refrigerator was missing. The kitchen contained a working landline phone. Sharps were locked in the staff office in a locked box. LPA observed some areas of the kitchen that were observed to be in need of cleaning and repair, including the kitchen drawers, kitchen flooring, baseboard and grout. The pantry was located off of the kitchen and the facility contained sufficient amounts of food in the pantry, refrigerator and freezer and fresh fruits and snacks on the counter. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days were observed. LPA observed that the facility has three bedrooms with double-occupancy floor plan, each client in care had a bed and clean bedding provided including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows. Dressers with at least two operational drawers for personal items, lighting and ample closet or storage space was provided. Some drawers were observed to have difficulty opening smoothly and may need repair. Windows were observed to be in good repair, however window tracks were observed to contain dirt and may be in need of cleaning in multiple windows. Window screens were missing in four facility windows. LPA observed writing on multiple areas of two out of three youth bedrooms, including on a window sill, two doors, and a dresser. There were two bathrooms observed in the facility. One bathroom was located in a client bedroom, and the other bathroom was located in the hallway. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. The water temperature was measured to be at 1155 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. LPA observed dirt on the light switch plate; stains, dirt, and damage on the tile floor, grout, shower door and frame, sink cabinet; and the bathrooms were observed to be in need of cleaning. One light bulb was observed to be out in one of two bathrooms, and the trash can in one of two bathrooms was observed to contain solid waste, but no trash liner or lid. LPA observed a laundry area, which contained a washer and dryer, and cabinets containing extra linens. Cabinets also stored extra cleaning supplies, tools and paper products. continued on 809-c

There is also a staff office, and Social Worker office, which are accessible through the kitchen. The offices contain confidential client files, and medication. Files and medications were observed to be locked. The backyard contained a large grassy area, with a bench and shed. There were no areas of damage to the surrounding fenced area. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. The backyard can be accessed by the two side access points on either side of the facility. LPA observed working Carbon Monoxide and smoke detectors, and they were tested and in working condition. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and exterior/education building of the facility. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in August 2023. LPA observed the first aid kit were stored in the staff office. The first aid kit was in tact, with the exception of it not including a current edition of a first aid manual and scissors. While the facility conducts emergency disaster drills quarterly, it was observed that the documentation of the drills conducted does not include the names of staff who participated in the drill and documentation of all drills conducted in the last year were not maintained at the facility. The Assistant Administrator provided LPA with documentation of the drill conducted in October 2023. LPA conducted one client interview and three staff interviews. LPA Verna completed the following domains of the inspection: Physical Plant, Operations, Core-Therapeutic Services, and Disaster Preparedness. LPA Verna began the review of the domain Client Records. The inspection was not completed on today's date and will be completed, including the following domains: Staff records, Client Records, and Emergency Interventions, on another date. The facility is being issued one citation related to deficiencies to STRTP ILS Regulations section 87072(a)(1); and Technical Advisories related to: Title 22 Regulations, sections 80075(g)(1), 80088(e)(3), 80087(a), 80023(d)(2), and ; STRTP ILS Regulations section 87009(a); and Health and Safety Code, section 1565(c). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, technical deficiencies, and LIC-809D and appeal rights was provided to Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator.

On November 21, 2023 at 12:20 P.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility's Administrative Office, located at 6060 Sunrise Vista Dr. Suite 2100 Citrus Heights, CA 95610 and continued the unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Alberto Muller, Recruiter/HR Assistant, who assisted LPA with the inspection of staff records. During the review of staff records, LPA Verna observed that: It was observed that one out of five (S1) staff files did not contain a current job description; The required education and experience requirements, documentation of transcripts or degree were not filed or located in the staff file (S1 and S3); During the review of annual training documentation, it was observed that documentation pertaining to required annual training for the date ranges of June 2021-2022 and June 2022-2023 was not filed and/or required annual training was not completed for one out of five staff files reviewed, (S2). Additionally, during the review of personnel files, it was observed that initial training documentation for initial minimum of 24 hours of training was documented on the "New Employment Confirmation" document in the staff files, the document did not include the exact date of completion of each initial (8 hour and 16 hour) training topic and the length of each training or training topic for all staff. LPA Verna completed the following domains of the inspection: Staff Records. The inspection was not completed on today's date and will be completed, including the following domains: Client Records, and Emergency Interventions, on another date. The facility is being issued Technical Advisories related to: Title 22 Regulations, sections 80066(a)(8), 80066(a)(10) and 80066(a)(11) and STRTP ILS Regulations sections 87065(g)(5), 87065.1(d)(5) and 87065.1(e)(7). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Alberto Muller, Recruiter/HR Assistant.

On April 02, 2024 at 03:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA Verna met with Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator and Amanda Lee, Administrator (Via phone). During the review of an Incident Report received from the facility on 03/19/2024, where a reportable incident occurred on 03/18/2024, the facility reported a medication issue. LPA Verna reviewed documentation, discussed the incident with the Assistant Administrator and Amanda Lee, Administrator (Via phone), and gathered further information, including processes used by the facility staff, and outcomes of the incident. LPA completed interview. An inspection of the facility was completed, and no deficiencies were observed. The case management was completed on today's date. The facility is being issued one citation for a violation of Title 22 Regulation, section 87075(c), HEALTH RELATED SERVICES. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this LIC-809 report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87075(c),
Health Related Services
(c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(..11.. *13*). 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The facility reported the medication issue/error to the department on 04/18/2024, where a facility staff (S1), had given a youth in care, C1, an incorrect dosage of their prescribed psychotropic medication on two dates (3/16/24 and 3/17/24),  which posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Assistant Administrator and Administrator stated that the staff (S1) receved coaching, and training regarding the agency's medication policy, and understands the error and medication that is prescribed to the client (C1). The Administrator will submit copies of the signed policy and procedures, and staff training documentation (completed 3/29/24) to the Department by the POC due date.

narrative: During the course of the investigation, the following documents were gathered and reviewed: Client Face Sheet, Placement Policies and Agreement(s), Incident Reports, Communication Logs, and Grievance forms for one client (FC1), and one staff file (S1); which included: background clearance documents, staff training record, employee application, staff evaluations and disciplinary notice, Communication Logs and Supervision Logs. Confidential interviews were conducted with nine individuals, and attempted with two individuals, during the period of 12/28/2023 to 04/02/2024. LPA’s interviews conducted, and records reviewed were inconsistent that a facility staff sexually touched a minor while in care. Interviews conducted were inconsistent, and while statements were made pertaining to negative rapport S1 built with youth in care, no corroborating statements were made regarding an individual witnessing the alleged inappropriate or sexual touching occur between S1 and FC1. Additionally, statements made were inconsistent regarding the period of time the alleged staff member had worked at the specified facility, transported the youth, or had been in the presence of the youth for the allegations to have occurred. The staff, S1, resigned from their employment on 02/03/2024. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was provided to Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna conducted an unannounced complaint inspection with the above facility on April 08, 2024 at 03:45 PM and met with Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint findings for the above allegation. On December 28, 2023 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stephannie Verna, arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of initiating a complaint investigation related to the above allegation. LPA met with Joanna Barnhill, Assistant Administrator. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility, and gathered documentation related to the complaint investigation. continued on 9099-c

narrative: An unannounced Missed Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kayla Green on 6/26/2024 at 10:05AM. During the inspection, LPA Green met with Naeem Brown, Assistant Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. During the review of an Incident Report (IR) received from the facility on 06/25/24, it was reported that on 06/22/24 a client in care (C1), Staff l checked the bubble pack and noticed on 6/22/24 there were only 4 bubbles popped out and signed for oil this day. Staff 1 checked the medication log and saw that there were no staff initials for 06/22/24 12pm, indicating the youth missed her 12pm medication that day. LPAs reviewed one child’s records on site at the facility at 11:55 am. During the review of one child’s records, LPA Green saw the missed initial on the medication log. The facility is receiving a Type B deficiency for the missed initial. The Administrator will provide the proof of training for the Plan of Correction by 07/26/24. LPA reviewed 2 of staff personnel files on site at the facility at 12:15PM. LPA interviewed 2 staff on site at 12:35PM. The case management inspection was completed on today's date. LPA conducted exit interview with Amanda Lee, Administrator at 12:40 PM, and provided the Summary Report.
