met_with: Amanda Lee-(Administrator) and Joanna Barhill (Assistant Administrator), and Isiah Jordan (Facility Manager)
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Avelina Martinez made an unannounced Annual Random inspection on July 09, 2025 at 9:30 AM. During the inspection LPA met with Amanda Lee-(Administrator) and Joanna Barhill (Assistant Administrator), and Isiah Jordan (Facility Manager) who assisted with the inspection. LPA Martinez conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection (two staff/ four kids present) Number of staff interviewed Two Number of clients Four LPA observed # Three bedrooms, # Two bathrooms LPA Martinez inspected and/or reviewed the following: Posting of license X Personal Rights X Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions inaccessible X Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F X Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees X Nonperishable Foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum X Menu present and posted X Working telephone X Carbon monoxide detectors X Smoke Detector X First Aid Kit fully stocked X Common Room available X Dining area (enough seating, furniture in good condition, not broke or damaged) In good repair Technical Violations due to three bedroom window screens not being in good repair. Work order for repair in progress. Continued...

Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible X Office (locked and privacy) X Hot Water between 105-120 degree F (Properly labeled if over 125 degree F 115 Fire Extinguisher (07/29/2025) Toilets wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair and no leaks. Soap and Paper towels X Laundry Facilities X Bedrooms- required linen and furnishings X Motor Vehicle properly maintained , lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts X Facility free of vermin X Locked Facilities (locked storage area/building/sheds) X Bedroom (required bedding/furniture, furniture in good repair) X Complaint Procedures For Youth Reviewed X Board Minutes Reviewed X CQI Report Reviewed X Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available X Quarterly Drills conducted and documented X Disaster preparedness supplies verified X Review of manual restraint log X Staff training Pro-Act Training received. Number of Staff files reviewed Five Criminal record clearances verified Five First Aid Certificate Five Certified Administrators certificate valid and current Expired-Admin has submitted renewal documentation certificate status is pending Job title/qualification verified X 24 Hours required training verified X 40 Hours required annual training verified X Number of Clients files reviewed Four Needs and Services Plan X Centrally Stored Medication and log reviewed X JV220 Reviewed X Psychotropic Medication and log reviewed X Cash Resources X Compatible Assessment X Trauma Informed Practices are implemented as needed (including specialty mental health services and extracurricular activities and social supports) X An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Joanna Barhill. No deficiencies were cited at this annual inspection. A technical violation was given for three broken window screens.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Suzanne Martinez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Stephen Kim conducted a case management inspection on July 22, 2025, at 8:30 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 7 direct care staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 7 direct care staff and 2 out of 4 youths were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811 (July 22, 2025). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the Board of Directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were emailed and reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth files review including the Needs and Service Assessments, Safety Plan, Risk Assessment and Treatment Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Martinez observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Amanda Lee.

On 06/18/21 at 1:30 PM, the second collaborative a quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. The first meeting was held on March 19, 2020. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 28. Two locations have closed, Linda Creek on 2/3/21 and Violets on 5/11/21. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst. · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director, Thomas Harrer, Clinical Director POYS provided a status update of the CARF evaluation stating the accreditation approval is over two months out due to backlogs from covid. An extension of approval is in effect. The Mental Health review by Dept. of Health Care Service (DHCS) was completed in April 2021 and at this time POYS is working with DHCS in providing the plan of corrections. POYS reports numerous clients recently graduated from high school. Some graduates are enrolled in community college, some are working, some are seeking transitional housing programs, and some are still figuring things out. Distance learning challenges were reported to be with band-width issues both from the schools and at the facilities. Distance learning was embraced by about half of the clientele, with the other half preferring in-person learning.

CCL reported a decrease in complaints and incident reports. POYS attribute the decline to a more deliberate intake process and screening for better compatibility with the current clients. They also reported they were revamping their level system. In addition, POYS is training house staff to participate more closely with each client and their overall treatment plan. Staff are eliciting more input from youth on what is working/not working with the program. Youth have responded with more engagement. POYS reported they are resuming a higher level of training for staff as more in-person training become available. They have contracted with Relias Learning for staff training. When asked about the status of overnight staff, POYS reported, they have two roamers that are assigned to three homes each. They also have one floater that helps out as needed or if someone calls out. This model is used both for the day shift and nighttime shift. The roamers and floaters meet regularly with staff to discuss client behaviors and needs. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. They complimented the discussed areas of change and the graduation of youth. DHCS discussed the pros/cons of the virtual Mental Health review and was appreciative for POYS’ feedback on the process. Clarification on mask wearing requirements for POYS clients and staff will be provided as the Department receives details. POYS will submit an electronic Program Statement to include recent revisions. They next meeting is scheduled for September 17, 2021.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson arrived at Paradise Oaks Youth Services Main Office to initiate a Required Annual on 6/23/2021 at 10:00 AM with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, due to this facility not currently having any placements. Areas discussed: annual fees, updated Administrator Certificate, waiver for 40 hours of annual staff training; and updated Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565). The status of other requirements was discussed, and current/updated version is being requested, for the following: · CARF International Accreditation was conducted 4/26/21-4/28/21, new certificate is pending · Mental Health Contract is renewed annually with Sacramento County · Mental Health Program approval- is currently in process of renewal and making corrections. · Emergency Intervention Log, via Board Meeting Minutes for the past 6 months, LPA Johnson followed Ms. Kuhn to POYS- Sunset and conducted the inspection. The following items were observed and evaluated by LPA Johnson: Posted items in the facility: Facility License, Emergency Mass Casualty Disaster Plan, Foster Youth Personal Rights, Foster Youth Ombudsman (other posters), exit routes, COVID-19 hand washing instructions, and health and safety information. Kitchen- a cabinet door is broken off. Five refrigerators (four downstairs) tested below 45 degrees F; one freezer tested at zero degrees. Refrigerators and freezers had various areas that needed cleaning and/or removal of old and expired food (Lactaid Milk- 2 half gallons, cream cheese, various condiments) and butter. Area to post menus is available. Hot water temperature tested within the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees (118 degrees).

Knives and Sharps will be stored and locked inside the staff office. However, none are currently present. Dishwasher is operable. There are no refrigerated medications. Trash can has a lid. No disinfectants or cleaners are stored in the kitchen. Living Areas- Furniture is clean and in good repair. Smoke & Carbon monoxide detectors are present and operable. Windows have screens, but the blinds had many missing / broken slats. Carpet/flooring are in good repair. The fireplace screen that had been securely fastened and attached, now has sharp edges that can cut. The screen/blockage needs to be safely secured. Bedrooms- There are 3 client bedrooms with double occupancy; all had the required furnishings, including storage space. The facility has the required items for a bed: mattress pad, fitted sheet, top sheet, pillow and mattress in good repair, even if not on the bed; extra linen supply was present. The window in the master bedroom is missing its screen. Window coverings were adequate. Two holes are in the walls in the master bedroom. Smoke detectors are operable. There are no staff bedrooms. Cabinets in the hallway are missing handles/knobs. Bathroom- There are 2.5 client bathrooms (regular, master & half) and 1 staff bathroom. Hot water temperature tested exceeded the regulatory range of 105-120 degrees: 129, 107, 119 and 127 respectively. All client toilets need cleaning. Tub/showers were clean and operable. Buildings and Grounds- Fire extinguisher was not present. Telephone: Available and in operable condition. Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were tested and working. Cleaning & Chemical Supplies were not accessible. Passageways are clean and free of obstructions. Facility has no bodies or water, cameras, or firearms on the premises. Outdoor fencing has a few areas that need additional support. Agency has engaged with the neighbors for repairs. Medication- Medication is stored and locked in the filing cabinets inside the staff office, when it is present. Since no youth are currently placed, no medication or documentation were present to inspect. First aid kit was not available to be inspected. Since this facility is currently not occupied with clients and staff are not assigned to this location, file reviews and interviews were not conducted.

Prior to resuming operations of this facility, the following items remain needed: Updated forms: LIC 308, 500, 610C If the administrator is changed, an updated board resolution and valid certificate. Adequate food supply- 2 days of perishable, 1 week of non-perishable and snacks Monthly menus and activity schedule need to be posted. Adequate dishware and cooking utensils. Hygiene supplies. Inspection of facility vehicle Beds have all required items No deficiencies are being cited due to no clients in placement. The agency should address all items prior to resuming the operation of the facility. Exit interview conducted and reports discussed with Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director; copies of documentation were provided to the facility, via email.

met_with: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director,
narrative:
On 09/17/21 at 1:00 PM, the third collaborative quarterly meeting with Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) was held to provide technical assistance and collaborative support to assist with and ensure POYS operates a successful program. POYS consists of nine locations: Olivine, Rosa Vista, Hazel, Hickory, Antelope, Mariposa, Old Auburn, Madison, and Sunset. The current census at all locations is 27. Three locations: Madison, Sunset and Old Auburn currently have no foster youth placed. The following were present on an MS Teams virtual meeting: · CCL: Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Robin Sullivan, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cindy Johnson, LPA, Tammy Hill, LPA · System of Care (SOC): Marjana Jackson, Stacie Kinney. · Sacramento County: Linda Abdelbaki · Department Health Care Services (DHCS): Brian Keefer · POYS: Robert Pye, CEO, Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director, Stephanie Fisher, Program Director POYS reported a staff and family moved into Sunset after their home burned down approximately 2 weeks ago. Annual inspections were completed for all their facilities in June and July, resulting in Technical Advisory/Advisory Notes and no deficiencies cited. CCL will provide the electronic program statement revisions to System of Care. Program statement revisions for the SAY population was submitted but still needs to be reviewed and approved. LPA Marla Horne will review by October 20, 2021.

Incident reports regarding smoking on grounds was discussed. Both trauma-informed practices and harm reduction protocols were discussed. Harm reduction practices have not been approved by the Department. POYS is reminded that incident reports should document interventions including staff discouraging youth from smoking. CCL pointed out youth smoking in the backyard is still smoking on grounds which may require additional case management inspections. CCL requested program statement revision to Transportation services to add details of exceptions to provide transportation to youth when extreme weather, youth not feeling well or after hours. CCL requested incident reports be typed due to the difficulty of reading the handwritten reports. At this time there are multiple POYS staff that still hand write reports. This has been an ongoing conversation between POYS and CCL. CCL requests all reports be typed by November 1, 2021. POYS declined this request. CCL requested all youths’ names be included in one incident report rather than referring to other involved youth as “peer”. CCL recommended using a legend to submit the report to CCL and redacting the names for POYS purposes. POYS declined the request due to confidentiality. The CCL request was requested and approved through upper management and noted not to be a HIPPA violation. CCL requested incident reports and timeframes be more specific. Antecedent information is specific and thorough, yet more follow up details or resolution information is needed and requested. CCL recommended POYS to Technical Support Program (TSP) for incident report writing. POYS approved the recommendation. Sacramento County had no specific areas of concern. DHCS had no specific areas of concern. Due to the upcoming impact of FFPSA on program statements, a deadline for the revisions was not determined and will be included at the time of the FFPSA changes. No further meetings are scheduled.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Alyssa Burgess and Shawndra Miles made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with a Paradise Oaks Youth Services (POYS) Administrator, Jovan Metoyer, who assisted with this inspection. After the walk-through, LPAs continued their inspection at the POYS Administration Office where we met with Stephanie Fisher, Program Director and Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director. LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection as the facility has not been in use since 2020. There are three bedrooms, three bathrooms, a staff office, living room, den, kitchen and garage. LPA inspected and/or reviewed the following: Posting of license and Children’s Personal Rights checked; Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were found to be kept in the kitchen area of the facility. The refrigerator's temperature was read at 40 degrees Fahrenheit; the freezer temperature was at 0 degrees Fahrenheit. There was not an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods as required. The only food present was purchased by the Administrator for the Administrator's personal use. There is a working landline telephone at the facility. All carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were checked with the assistance of the POYS Administrator. There was one carbon monoxide detector installed in the hallway outside of the clients’ bedrooms, which was non-functional. The smoke detectors throughout the facility were working as required. There was no first aid kit at the facility. This was previously addressed with the facility on 6/30/2021, at which time they received an advisory note. An adequately sized common room was available. The dining area had enough space to accommodate clients. LPAs observed holes in the walls of the dining area and in the hallway leading to the garage. There were no medications on-site. An expired fire extinguisher was observed in the kitchen and the meter indicated it needed to be recharged. The refrigerators and freezers were not cleaned and had expired food from 2020 to Feb 2022. This was previously addressed with the facility on 6/30/2021, at which time they received an advisory note.

Sinks, baths, and shower fixtures were all in good repair. The toilets were not cleaned and the water had evaporated due to limited use. Provisions of soap, paper towels, and other personal hygiene were observed in the master bathroom only. The laundry area was clean; required linen and furnishings were found to be present and in working order in the linen closets. There were no facility service vehicles on-site. There was no indication of the facility campus having any pest infestation. The facility was unclean and in disrepair in several parts: surfaces, doors, walls, and carpets were dirty with smears, crumbs, etc. there were holes in the wall in the bathroom near the garage/kitchen, broken moulding and no door on the hallway closet, a missing light bulb in one bathroom, garbage on counter in kitchen, dirty dishes in sink, general clutter and debris throughout whole house. Administrator's bedroom messy, piles of dirty linens/towels in the garage. Staff office had a foul odor. The facility has a Disaster and Mass Casualty plan that is up-to-date and readily available. LPAs instructed the facility to amend the plan to indicate how refrigerated medication will be stored. Currently, the facility is not conducting drills, as there are no clients. LPA's observed an POYS Administrator residing at the facility. During the course of the inspection the Administrator admitted to having a firearm with a loaded magazine and ammunition improperly stored on the premises. The firearm was in a locked box, which the Administrator unlocked for LPAs to show an unloaded firearm, with two magazines next to it, one of which was loaded. The Administrator also had two boxes of additional ammunition, which was kept unlocked, in a bag. LPA let Administrator know those cannot be stored in that manner, and how to store them properly. Administrator removed the ammunition from the magazine and took all ammunition to his car to be secured. Additionally, there was curved knife that was in the Administrator's bedroom, which he stated was confiscated from a client. The Administrator's room smelled of marijuana, showed presence of marijuana, and smoking paraphrenia, to which the Administrator admitted to owning. There were various other things missing or incorrect, which LPA detailed in the attached Technical Violation Advisory Notes, which are not citations: 80076(a)(17,19-20), 80088(e)(3), Interim Licensing Standards 87076(c)(4), Health & Safety Code 1565(a)(7)(e). On this date, the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Sections: 80087(d), 80087(g)(3), 80087(a),80087(c), 80076(a)(18), 87076(c)(1), 80075(g), 80088(c). An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was emailed to her with appeal rights and read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

On January 27, 2023 Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Dara Campos, Regional Office Manager Margo Castaneda, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna held an Informal Conference Meeting from 1:00 PM to 2:45 PM to discuss concerns. The meeting was facilitated by LPM Campos. Attendees included (in-person) Paradise Oaks Youth Services staff, Laynee Kuhn (Executive Director), Stephanie Fischer (Administrator), Amanda Lee (administrator) and Board Member Al Werner, as well as (Via Teams Meeting), Shawn Wade Fresno County Social Worker, Julie Leong, Case Manager Mateo County Behavioral Health, Khoa Nguyen Stanislaus County Social Worker, and Tia Carter Sacramento County Social Worker. The topics discussed included: Absent without Permission Temporary Release (TR) Communication with local law enforcement Cancelling Missing Person reports Incident Report details No deficiencies were cited during today's meeting. A copy of this report was provided to Laynee Kuhn, Executive Director.

An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 09/18/2020 at 11:00am. This inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA Segura sent the Administrator Steve Duran a Document Request checklist on 08/28/2020. LPA Segura received requested documents on 09/04/2020. The facility has four clients in placement at this time, two are taking psychotropic medications. On 09/10/2020 student assistant Tania Martinez reviewed Assessment Needs and Services Plan, Centrally Stored Medication logs, and medication authorization documents. On this date student assistant also reviewed the facility program statement and medication policies and procedures and input to file review checklist. LPA Segura conducted a phone interview with C1 (Client 1, see confidential names list LIC 811 dated 09/18/2020) on 09/15/2020 and interview with C2 on 09/17/2020. C3 declined to be interviewed for the purposes of this inspection. During todays inspection LPA Segura conducted two staff interviews regarding psychotropic medications. LPA requested staff Monze Duenas to do a pill count for C2 and C3 (Client 2, 3, see LIC 811 confidential name list dated 09/18/2020) at approximately 12:15pm. LPA Segura calculated the pills that should be left by reviewing the centrally stored log and medication administration log submitted. There were no irregularities found during the pill count. Note a pill count of C1 was not conducted as they were discharged and moved on 09/17/2020.

In the course of condcuting the pill count. Staff Monze mentioned that the facility had an "overflow" for medication. LPA inquired and she stated that they put medication there if for example there are more pills left over due to medication refusal by the client and a new prescription bottle is obtained. LPA further explored the "overflow" medication container with the Administrator Steve Duran who indicated they actually use that box for storing medication to be destroyed and should not be used for storage of any medication. The administrator stated he would rectify the issue and rename the other medication box for medication to be destroyed to make it clear that is the only use of the box. During the inspection there were only eye drops in the box, no other medication was observed being stored. There were not deficiencies noted at today's evaluation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to the Administrator Steve Duran. A read receipt was requested to acknowledge that the report was received.

met_with: Ernest Howard, Kelly Quackenbush, George Lopez
narrative:
Interviews with youth C2 and C3 on 12/04/21 beginning at 2pm, revealed that S1 (Staff 1, see confidential name list 811 dated 01/27/21) yelled at clients over the use of marijuana at the facility. Further interview with C1 on 12/08/2021 revealed that S1 followed C1 to their bedroom when they were attempting to evade S1. While C1 was attempting to close their bedroom door, S1 pushed the door open while C1 was attempting to close the door. C1 then attempted to evade S1 into the bathroom and S1 put their foot in the door and stopped the door from shutting. C1 stated that S1 then pushed their way into the bathroom allowing the door to shut behind them and pushed C1 back further into the bathroom to gain entry. C1 stated that S1 did yell and use profanity while accusing C1 of using marijuana at the facility and scheduling a Child Family Team meeting. Interviews conducted with S1 on 12/03/21 confirmed that S1 did raise voice at clients, but denied pushing C1. S1 admitted to entering both the bedroom and bathroom as client was attempting to evade them. S1 stated that they were trying to explain to C1 they were not getting kicked out of the program. Confidential interview conducted with a staff on 12/17/2021 at 4pm revealed that they did hear S1 yelling at C1 upstairs and using profanity. Staff indicated that they did not see or hear S1 either push C1 or push their way into bathroom or bedroom. Only 1 staff out of three present that day confirmed they heard S1 using profanity toward C1; however all staff confirmed that S1 yelled at C1, C2 and C3 over the use of marijuana at the facility. In the course of interviewing staff and other clients in the home, it is confirmed that no one else was present upstairs with S1 and C1 to witness any pushing or entering of rooms forcefully. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that S1 yelled at C1, C2 and C3. There is also a preponderance of the evidence to prove that S1 pushed C1 therefore handled client aggressively. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Executive Director and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to George for a signature, an email read receipt was requested.

The clients hide from and evade staff either outside or in the bathrooms. Clients statements indicated that the staff are supervising them. Clients further stated that they know staff can only do so much and limit the places they can search such as their person. Although clients are using marijuana at the facility, the Department could not determine that it is as a result of the lack of supervision from staff. There is not a preponderance of the evidence to proof staff are not supervising children resulting in the usage of marijuana. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with the facility staff listed above. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to Ernest Howard, Kelly Quackenbush and George Lopez.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura and LPM (Licensing Program Manager) Helga Wong conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at the STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) and met with George Lopez (president of the board), Kelly Quackenbush (Administrator) and Ernest Howard. This meeting was conducted via four way telephone call due to technical difficulties with Microsoft Teams. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. On December 02, 2020 the department received a report regarding the above allegations. On December 03, 2020 at 9:30am LPA Segura initiated the complaint investigation via a Microsoft Teams virtual inspection. On December 08, 2020 LPA Segura condcuted telephone interviews with C1, C2 and C3 (Client 1, 2, 3, see confidential name list LIC 811 dated 01/27/21). Continued on 9099c

deficiencies.description:
87072(d) The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9
WIC16001.9(a)(1)To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect. Based on interviews with staff and clients, Staff 1 yelled at clients. The licensee did not ensure the personal rights of children were respected, which poses an immediate Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC due on due date, 01/28/20. Licensee agrees develop a plan involving training to staff 1. LPA and LPM recommended training outside of the organization.

deficiencies.description:
87072(d) The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9
WIC16001.9(a)(1)To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect. Based on interviews with staff and clients, Staff 1 mishandled client 1 by pushing client.  The licensee did not ensure the personal rights of the child were respected, which poses an immediate Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC due on due date, 01/28/20. Licensee agrees develop a plan involving training to staff 1. LPA and LPM recommended training outside of the organization.

narrative:
An announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura on 07/14/2021 at 10am. During the inspection LPA Segura met with administrator Andrew Sandoval and Medical Assistant Heydy Hernandez. The facility was inspected inside and out. In placement at this time there are four youth; two of which are taking psychotropic medication LPA Segura began by reviewing the two files for the youth who are taking psychotropic medication at around 10am. During the review LPA Segura observed that neither of the two clients had Assessment Needs and Services Plans signed by the authorized representative. Note however, that one client has been in placement less than 30 days therefore the facility is not required to have that on the file yet. LPA Segura reviewed 2 children's records on site at the facility at 10am. LPA reviewed 3 personnel files on site at 12:00pm LPA Segura interviewed 3 staff on site at around 11am. LPA did not interview any client's during todays inspection. The two youth were asked to participate but refused. LPA explained the purpose of the inspection and the youth still refused to participate. Continued on 809c

At around 2pm LPA Segura and Medical Assistant Heydy Hernandez conducted a medication count for two clients. The medication count resulted in C1's (Client 1; Medication 3, see confidential names list LIC 811 dated 07/14/2021) M3 having one extra pill. A count of C2's medication also resulted in an extra pill for M4. The review of the centrally stored logs and PMARs revealed the following: The facility is not logging medication received from a prior placement (only filled by the facility) The facility is future dating medication start date (anticipated start date) not actual start date. This practice may not account for medication refusals. Staff are not indicating on the PMAR when medication is refused; only leaving space blank not noting required refusal information. Per Title 22 Regulations, deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

On 06/07/2021 LPA Segura observed that the facility has a defunct intercom system installed in the home. What appears to be the main control in the kitchen; has a faceplate that is no longer secure to the wall and falls down onto the counter. LPA Segura was able to use their state issued iphone to capture photos of the intercom. During todays inspection the facility repairman used a sensor to show that there were live wires in the wall of this intercom; although they were capped with plastic electrical caps. Further inspection of the home; LPA Segura observed there were multiple faceplates missing from electrical and phone outlets in the home. LPA was able to use their state issued iphone to capture pictures of the missing faceplates. Some of the faceplates appear to be missing in areas the facility has had to patch the walls due to residents damaging the walls and outlets. On todays date, 06/07/2021 LPA observed that the living room sliding door windows are in need of repairs. The part of the sliding doors that is are not meant to slide have been pushed away from the wall creating a half inch opening to the outside. Further one of the sliding doors has come off the rail creating a half inch opening to the outside. Both items have allowed cold air and insects to come into the home. Based on observation and photographic evidence obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility is in need of repair and deep cleaning. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Andrew Sandoval and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left Andrew Sandoval.
investigation_findings: 13The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. In the course of inspecting the home, LPA observed that the walls and baseboards throughout the home are in need of deep cleaning as they were observed to have buildup of liquid spills, dust and dirt. LPA was able to take pictures of the items in need of cleaning 06/07.

narrative: RP further indicated that this occurred due to the food meant for the meal had been consumed prior to the menu planned day. Interview with S2 revealed that the facility staff do attempt to stick to the posted menu; however, clients sometimes want something different or want the meal sooner than posted. S2 indicated that in those cases staff have to choose a different meal to provide clients. S2 stated that if they are missing ingredients or were used up, the staff calls the office to request the items be brought to the home. Interview was conducted with C1 (Client 1, see confidential names list LIC 811 dated 09/21/21) on 09/17/2021 at 12:30 pm. C1 stated denied there was insufficient food in the home. An interview was conducted with C2 on 09/14/21 at 1:20 pm. C2 indicated that they had sufficient food and had no complaints to report about food. On 09/17 LPA Segura conducted an inspection of the facility menu and confirmed that the facility had the ingredients necessary to cook meals listed on the Menu. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there was insufficient food service in the home; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. narrative: Interviews conducted with S5, S7 and S8 revealed that they had been trained and participate in annual refresher courses. Trainer S7 stated that he conducts regular training to for staff specifically for the nonviolent crisis interventions, other training's are conducted by the facility manager or self-paced online training by outside providers. The interview with S7 revealed that the runaway training is not part of the Nonviolent Crisis Intervention (NCI) and Emergency Intervention Plan training. Eric stated that the NCI training only touches on runaways when a hold is necessary not prevention. Eric indicated that due to personal rights the facility mostly tries to talk children out of running away and only ever conduct a hold on a child if they are being a danger to themselves or others such as attempting to run into traffic. Interviews conducted with staff revealed that staff felt as if they could not do anything to prevent a child from running away; however, did admit that they attempt to talk children out of running away by following them when they attempt to walk away and conduct bed checks overnight to ensure they are still in bed. Staff also report calling non-emergency number for the Monterey Sheriff’s office to report a missing child. A review of the facility Program Statement revealed that although the facility does have a Runaway Plan, there is no indication that facility staff are trained in the plan. LPA Segura reviewed at hire training list and new hire training checklists for five staff. None of the documents showed that the facility is training staff on the runaway plan. An interview conducted with S8 confirmed that although staff knows some of the steps of the runaway plan, they had not seen the plan before LPA showed them a copy on 09/17. A brief review was conducted with administrator Andrew Sandoval of the facility training documents and confirmed that the Runaway Plan is not listed on any of the checklists or training materials. Based on observation and photographic evidence obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility staff were not trained in the agency Runaway Plan. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Andrew Sandoval and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left Andrew Sandoval.
investigation_findings: 13The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Segura met with administrator Anrew Sandoval. See confidential names list LIC 811 dated 09/21/21 LPA Segura obtained staff training records at the facility on 08/25/2021 at approximately 10am. Five staff training documents were reviewed for new hire training. LPA Segura observed that all five staff had evidence that they were trained in accordance with the facilities training plan including Non violent Crisis Intervention and Emergency Intervention Plan.

deficiencies.description: (C)(3)(C) Facility's policies and procedures, including reporting requirements to the Department and as a mandated reporter; This requirement is not met as evidences by: Based on staff interviews and records review the licensee failed to train staff in the facility runaway plan. Five staff records were reviewed and none contained verfication of runaway plan training. This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care.

narrative: On September 24, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging clients engaged in sexual interactions by cuddling/spooning with each other and staff did not provide supervision to meet the needs of the clients. Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed, Peacock Acres did not provide close supervision as his Needs & Services Plan stated and C1 and C2 cuddled/spooned with each other, without staff supervision. C1 has a history of behaviors that Peacock Acres felt needed the additional staff support. Peacock Acres did not follow C1’s Needs & Services Plan as required, which led to the inappropriate client interactions. Additional staff support and staff supervision was needed. Based on confidential interviews conducted and documents reviewed, there is a preponderance of evidence that clients engaged in sexual interactions while in care and staff did not provide supervision to meet the needs of the clients. Therefore, the above allegations, are substantiated.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a complaint investigation. LPA Joel Segura initiated a complaint investigation with Executive Director, Shaniz Beza with Peacock Acres on, 9/24/21 at 9:30am. Investigations Bureau Investigator (INV) Mariana Lomeli conducted confidential interviews with clients, staff, Monterey County Sheriff’s Department, and county social workers. LPA Pavia conducted interviews with staff and reviewed client Needs & Services, client incident reports and staff training.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care & Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, C1 and C2 cuddled or spooned with each other, with no staff supervision. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights violation.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Starting immediately, facility will require staff to read and acknowledge all client Needs & Services Plans.

deficiencies.description: The licensee shall provide services identified in child's needs and services plan…as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of Needs & Services, C1 did not receive close supervision, as stated in the plan. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights violation.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Starting immediately, facility will adhere to client's Needs & Services Plans, if close supervision or 1:1 staffing is needed.

narrative: Attendees of the facility: Shaniz Beza- Interim Administrator, Andrew Sandoval- Administrator, Dr. Jill Anderson, Zeana Bey, LMFT Counties: Cynthia Elkins – Santa Clara County, Kristin Lampling, Alana Kapust, and Krista Hopper Pasillas -Marin County CCL: Nelson Martinez – Regional Manager (RM), Helga Wong – Licensing Program Manager (LPM), and Carolyn Flynn – LPM Selena Hood – Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Discussion: - Current substantiated complaint re inappropriate sexual interaction and supervision in the facility - Monterey Sheriff involvement to relocate the clients - 2 year of compliance history - Compliance plan - Staffing and Training Facility will do the following and submit them by December 31, 2021: -Written Plan on Weekly Meeting with Management and floor staff re clients' Need and Services Plans - Lic 500 current staff schedule with administrator and manager's work hours in the facility - Written Plan working with Monterey County Sheriff Department and Meetings - Written Plan working with Seneca on the Crisis Line - Training and Plan on de-escalation and intervention on client behaviors -Training information with trainer James Freeman RM and LPMs offered Technical Support Services (TSP) to facility if they want it in the future.

narrative: This LIC 809 was created in error under the wrong facility number and location. No signature for this amended report was obtained from the provider. A new LIC 809 and LIC 811 have been created for correct facility number 275200693 located in the open FAS database. Licensing Program Analyst Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on April 26, 2022 at 11:39 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 8 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, April 26, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Michelle P. Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Zeana Bey, Clinical Supervisor

As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Ana Hernandez, TAY Program Manager.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with head of Service Andrew Sandoval on June 7, 2021, regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing on February 9, 2021 . Note this report signed on 06/08/2021 due to LPA's battery dying during inspection at the facility. The SIR stated that Staff called law enforcement because there were 15 tablets missing when completing a medication count on 02/07/2021. LPA Segura conducted an interview with the facility manager on 02/10/2021 Nate Garner regarding the incident. LPA Segura obtained a copy of the police report on 05/20/2021. The police report review revealed that the officer was unable to determine who took the medication as there is multiple staff who have keys and access to the medication. Further the officer indicated that the medication boxes the facility was using at the time, allowed someone to pry the side up and stick their hand in to remove medication. The boxes used were tool utility boxes with a padlock in the middle. The facility since has installed a metal lockbox attached to the wall. The facility completed a staff training on 02/15/2021 and monitored youth for any signs they had taken medication. The interview with Nate revealed that there were room searches done after it was discovered that medication was missing. In addition LPA Segura 06/07/2021 inspected the old medication boxes and confirmed the police officers finding that it is possible to pry open the side and take out items inside. Continued on LIC 809C

The investigation consisted of interviews with staff and a review of a police report and in person inspection. Based on the interviews regarding the SIR, the facility did not ensure medication was secure; therefore, the facility is being cited. Appeal Rights were discussed and an exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was provided to Andrew Sandoval via email for a signature.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Interim Executive Director Shaniz Beza regarding an incident that occurred on 03/15/2021. The incident indicated that C1 (Client 1, see confidential names list LIC 811 dated 09/30/2021) engaged in property destruction and assault of S1 (Staff 1). LPA Segura investigated the incident and was informed C1 came out of her bedroom window into the courtyard and argued with C2. An interview was conducted with S1 on 04/07/21 at approximately 3pm. S1 stated there were no other staff in the immediate area when C1 began to hit S1. S1 indicated that he was attempting to block C1 from hitting him and eventually made it out to the living room where other staff were present and intervened. Staff S3 and S2 intervened and escorted the client to the couch. Interview with former staff S3 on 09/08/21 at 1:45 pm, revealed that C1 had sat down on the couch and appeared to have calmed down. S3 indicated that C1 stood up, still appearing to be calm and then suddenly ran into the kitchen where S1 was attempting to keep distance from C1. S3 indicated that all she witnessed was S1 attempting to deflect C1 from hitting him and pushed C1 away in a further attempt to stop the attack. S3 indicated that again her and S2 escorted the client outside to try and calm him down. Continued on 809C

S1 reported attempting to put C1 in a child hold. Interviews were conducted with S2, S3 and S4. S3 reported that S1 restrained C1 in a bear hug, S3 described S1 attempted to hold C1 from the back. Interview with S4 did not report seeing S1 hold C1 from the back. LPA reviewed Crisis Prevention Institute photographs and it appears a Child Control Position is where a child is held from behind; however, it is not a hugging action. Rather the child is held by their arms crossed in front of them. There was insufficient evidence to conclude that there was an inappropriate hold of C1. LPA Segura concluded there will be no violation per Title 22 Regulations. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was provided to the facility.

S1 stated there were no other staff in the immediate area when C1 began to hit S1. S1 indicated that he was attempting to block C1 from hitting him and eventually made it out to the living room where other staff were present and intervened. Staff S3 and S2 intervened and escorted the client to the couch. Interview with former staff S3 on 09/08/21 at 1:45 pm, revealed that C1 had sat down on the couch and appeared to have calmed down. S3 indicated that C1 stood up, still appearing to be calm and then suddenly ran into the kitchen where S1 was attempting to keep distance from C1. S3 indicated that all she witnessed was S1 attempting to deflect C1 from hitting him and pushed C1 away in a further attempt to stop the attack. S3 indicated that again her and S2 escorted the client outside to try and calm him down. S3 indicated that she did not observe any injuries on C1; but did hear C1 say "how could a grown man do that to a little boy". S3 indicated she did not know what C1 was referring to, and assumed it was S1 attempting to push client away. S3 indicated that she did not hear S1 making any inappropriate statements to C1. An interview was conducted with S2 on 08/20/21 at approximately 10:15am. The interview with S2 revealed that C1 was trying to punch and hit S1. S2 stated he did not see S1 hit, handle in a rough manner or hear S1 state anything inappropriate to C1. S2 indicated that C1 did have a negative opinion of S1. A review of the CPS report made regarding this incident did contain a statement from C1 indicated that S1 had hit C1 and had made inappropriate comments toward C1. C1 was taken into custody by juvenile hall and had run away various times since removal from the facility. A review of county welfare database indicates that as of 06/25/2021 C1 has been missing therefore no interview was conducted. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that C1 was hit, handled in a rough manner or inappropriate comments were made; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with Nate Garner. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with Nate Garner.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura conducted a follow-up complaint investigation to the STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) and met with the facility manager Nate Garner. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. On 03/18/21 the department received an anonymous complaint alleging that staff S1 had hit, handled in a rough manner and made inappropriate comments to C1 (Child 1, Staff 1, see confidential names list dated 09/14/2021). An interview was conducted with S1 on 04/07/21 at approximately 3pm. S1 indicated that C1 had a behavior incident due to being denied a late evening outing to a store. S1 denied having hit the youth, handling in a rough manner or making any inappropriate comments to C1. S1 indicated the youth was highly agitated and he had encountered the youth in the darkened hallway outside of the staff office.

narrative:
On this date LPA used their state issued iPhone to take pictures of the grounds at the facility. Pictures consisted of the linoleum near resident bedrooms in need of mopping and sweeping, stained carpets, power outlets missing face plates, missing floor board, visible patches, a small section of the homes siding appeared to have been torn off, cabinets in need of wiping from hand grease, kitchen cabinets with stuck on food particles and spills, and patches that seem to have been damaged again. During the 03/24 inspection, LPA observed that the facility had installed new windows to replace the previously broken ones. Note that although patches are not visually pleasing, they are not an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care and are fixes to damaged walls. LPA Segura interviewed staff S4 on 04/07/21 at 4:15pm, S5 on 08/25/21 at 10:15am, S6 on 08/20/21 at 10am, S7 on 09/01 at 4:15pm, S8 and S2 on 09/17 at 11:00am. See confidential names list LIC 811 dated 09/21/21. LPA Segura obtained staff training records at the facility on 08/25/2021 at approximately 10am. Five staff training documents were reviewed for new hire training. LPA Segura observed that all five staff had evidence that they were trained in accordance with the facilities training plan including Non violent Crisis Intervention and Emergency Intervention Plan. Interviews conducted with S5, S7 and S8 revealed that they had been trained and participate in annual refresher courses. Trainer S7 stated that he conducts regular training to for staff specifically for the nonviolent crisis interventions, other trainings are conducted by the facility manager or self-paced online training by outside providers. The interview with S7 revealed that the runaway training is not part of the Nonviolent Crisis Intervention (NCI) and Emergency Intervention Plan training. S7 stated that the NCI training only touches on runaways when a hold is necessary not prevention. S7 indicated that due to personal rights the facility mostly tries to talk children out of running away and only ever conduct a hold on a child if they are being a danger to themselves or others such as attempting to run into traffic. Continued on 9099C

Interviews conducted with staff revealed that staff felt as if they could not do anything to prevent a child from running away; however, did admit that they attempt to talk children out of running away by following them when they attempt to walk away and conduct bed checks overnight to ensure they are still in bed. Staff also report calling non-emergency number for the Monterey Sheriff’s office to report a missing child. A review of the facility Program Statement revealed that although the facility does have a Runaway Plan, there is no indication that facility staff are trained in the plan. LPA Segura reviewed at hire training list and new hire training checklists for five staff. None of the documents showed that the facility is training staff on the runaway plan. An interview conducted with S8 confirmed that although staff knows some of the steps of the runaway plan, they had not seen the plan before LPA showed them a copy on 09/17. A brief review was conducted with administrator Andrew Sandoval of the facility training documents and confirmed that the Runaway Plan is not listed on any of the checklists or training materials. Based on observation and photographic evidence obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility was in need of repair and deep cleaning and staff were not trained in the agency Runaway Plan. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Andrew Sandoval and deficiencies were cited. During todays inspection LPA Segura was given a tour of the facility ground and observed all windows have been repaired, floors cleaned and swept, carpets cleaned and siding of the home repaired and painted. Deficiencies were cleared as of todays inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left Andrew Sandoval

narrative: On 01/27/2022 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director, at the office space because a Covid-19 positive staff member had visited the facility itself within the last 10 days. LPA reviewed six staff files, staff schedule, and the employee manual. LPA interviewed three staff members. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director, at 4:15PM.

On 02/04/2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien and LPA Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the above licensed facility's main office. LPAs conducted the inspection in the main office because of a Covid-19 positive client in the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs met with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director, at 10:45AM. LPAs reviewed four staff files, the training log for all staff members, and the disaster plan. LPAs found two filing issues that required Technical Assistance. ILS 87065.1(c)(6)(a) was not met as evidenced by the lack of a current CPR card in one staff member's file. ILS 87065.1(d)(1) was not met as evidenced by the lack of sufficient training hours for one staff member. No further deficiencies were cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director, at 2:00PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Licensing Program Analyst Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on April 26, 2022 at 11:39 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 8 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, April 26, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Michelle P. Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Zeana Bey, Clinical Supervisor. Due to a technical error this report was created and provided via email to Shaniz Beza, Interim Executive Director (shaniz@peacockacres.org) for signature on May 2, 2022

met_with: Clarissa Joseph, Residential Manager (RM) and Steisha Monderoy, Strategic Project Director (SPD
narrative:
On 1/27/22, the County received a 14-day notice for a client residing at Peacock Acres. A County representative (CR) claimed they were told the reasoning for this is because Peacock Acres did not have enough staff to safely provide supervision for the client. CR said that the facility mentioned an altercation the youth in question had to show this. This led to the allegations that Peacock Acres does not have sufficient staff, does not provide a safe environment, and a youth was involved in an altercation with another youth while in care. RCR felt that the 14-day notice was unjustified because they felt the client in question was making progress and that they should not be given a 14-day notice because of lack of staffing. On 3/3/22 when LPA Simien asked Peacock Acres about the client’s issues and why a 14-day notice was issued. Peacock Acres explained, since placement, the client has struggled with several behavioral challenges that the program is unable to effectively address. These challenges have continued to impede Client’s ability to make progress towards his treatment goals and have continued to pose a risk to safety of staff and other residents of the program. Included in these challenges are ongoing property destruction, continuing to store and smoke marijuana in the home, verbal threats to kill and/or harm both staff and other residents, theft of Peacock Acres and other resident’s property with intention to sell, and, inciting and provoking another resident to become physically assaultive, punching another resident several times, and ongoing harassment of another resident (refusing to let that resident use the kitchen or exit his room), purposely destroying other resident's property and stalking other residents around the home while posturing and yelling threats and homophobic/transphobic slurs, throwing items at other residents resulting in property damage. The client has been unresponsive to lower level interventions instead requiring police intervention, has been unable to commit to maintaining the ongoing safety of the home and other residents, and voiced his ongoing intention to try to harm other residents. His behaviors have resulted in marked increases in the mental health symptoms of other residents, required Peacock Acres to temporarily place residents in another lower level home to ensure their safety, and have prevented clinical staff from implementing therapeutic components of the program (ex: providing group therapy) due to the need for increased staff ratios to help stabilize the client and maintain safety in the home. When LPA Simien mentioned to Peacock Acres the allegation of not having sufficient staff and that CR claimed that they said they didn’t have enough staff, they said that they are maintaining proper staff-to-client ratios based on ILS V.4 standards. They also mentioned that the client in question is much larger than the average client and that it would take more than one staff member to subdue and redirect the client in question.

They said they could not risk the whole program for one client. At the time of LPA Simien’s inspection of Peacock Acres on 2/16/22 they had the proper client-to staff ratio. Based on the review of staff schedules from 1/1/22-1/31/22 it showed that Peacock Acres did have the proper client-to-staff ratio, although there is no way LPA Simien can confirm staff worked those shifts. CR said that because Peacock Acres does not have enough staff and the altercations the client in question is having, Peacock Acres does not provide a safe environment. When LPA Simien brought up the allegation that the facility does not provide a safe environment, staff responded by saying they felt they provide a safe environment for clients. They mentioned that some of the clients (including the client in question) behaviors and actions create an unsafe environment. Based on confidential interviews LPA conducted with clients on 2/26/22 clients felt that Peacock acres provided a safe environment and only other clients make them feel unsafe. The clients LPA Simien interviewed mentioned the client in question as creating an unsafe environment. LPA Simien asked clients “Has there been any time you have felt or observed yourself, staff, or other kids being in danger at Peacock?”. They responded, only when the client in question gets upset, this individual tends to physically attack people. They also mentioned that the client in question bullies and attacks them and because of this they do not like the client in question. When LPA Simien brought up the allegation that a youth was involved in an altercation with another youth while in care, staff responded that although altercations happen between clients, they respond to them within CCL regulations. They also mention that the client in question is usually the aggressor in these altercations with other clients. Staff pointed out an incident that occurred on 2/5/22 where the client in question attacked another client in which they had to call law inforcment and the client in question was booked in juvenile hall. On 2/16/22 LPA Simien asked clients, “do you feel like there are enough staff to stop physical altercations?”. The clients’ responses were mixed. They responded, “yes, staff put a stop to bullying” and “kind of, staff attempts to stop altercations.” Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations . Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was to Clarissa Joseph, Residential Manager (RM).

met_with: Clarissa Joseph, Residential Manager (RM) and Steisha Monderoy, Strategic Project Director (SPD
narrative:
On 1/27/22, the County received a 14-day notice for a client residing at Peacock Acre and had a preservation CFT meeting with the facility. The facility explained that the reason for the 14-day notice was that they felt the client question could no longer make therapeutic progress in an environment with peers with behavioral issues and that they became a health and safety risk for clients and staff. Peacock Acres suggested that the client would benefit from being placed in an ITFC resource foster home. CFT Facilitator for the County stated that this was not an option for the client unless they could demonstrate sustained progress for 3 months or longer and that ITFC resource foster homes were in short supply and it was unlikely the County would be able to find one. Peacock Acres also suggest maybe placing the client in Texas to be closer to their Mother. The County responded that they legally could not place client in Texas. When LPA Simien talked to a County representative (CR) about the CFT meeting they claimed they were shocked by the 14-day notice and that Peacock Acres said that the client in question was doing well and progressing clinically. When LPA Simien brought this up to Peacock Acres, they acknowledge that the client did well one-on-one with clinical team but regressed with behavioral issues while with other peers with behavioral issues. On 3/3/22 when LPA Simien asked Peacock Acres about the client’s issues and why a 14-day notice was issued. Peacock Acres explained, since placement, the client has struggled with several behavioral challenges that the program is unable to effectively address. These challenges have continued to impede Client’s ability to make progress towards his treatment goals and have continued to pose a risk to safety of staff and other residents of the program. Included in these challenges are ongoing property destruction, continuing to store and smoke marijuana in the home, verbal threats to kill and/or harm both staff and other residents, theft of Peacock Acres and other resident’s property with intention to sell, and, inciting and provoking another resident to become physically assaultive, punching another resident several times, and ongoing harassment of another resident (refusing to let that resident use the kitchen or exit his room), purposely destroying other resident's property and stalking other residents around the home while posturing and yelling threats and homophobic/transphobic slurs, throwing items at other residents resulting in property damage. The client has been unresponsive to lower level interventions instead requiring police intervention, has been unable to commit to maintaining the ongoing safety of the home and other residents, and voiced his ongoing intention to try to harm other residents. His behaviors have resulted in marked increases in the mental health symptoms of other residents, required Peacock Acres to temporarily place residents in another lower level home to ensure their safety, and have prevented clinical staff from implementing therapeutic components of the program (ex: providing group therapy) due to the need for increased staff ratios to help stabilize the client and maintain safety in the home.

Peacock Acres said they would try to preserve placement if the County could take back the client while they tried to find more staff to be better equipped to handle the client’s behavior issues. The County said that was not possible. Based on conversations with Peacock Acres and CR, there was a miscommunication/misunderstanding regarding the plan of action for the client. Both said that there was an agreement that the client would stay with their mother for two weeks (starting on 2/10/22) while the County found a new placement (with County providing updates). Peacock Acres would attempt to hire more staff to accommodate the client’s behavioral issues. The misunderstanding/miscommunication stems from what would happen after the client’s stay with their mother. The County said there was an expectation that the client would go back to Peacock Acres if no placement was found. Peacock Acres says there was no agreement to accept back the client after their stay with their mother. On 2/18/22, Peacock Acres received an email from the client’s Social Worker stating no placement had been found for client, providing return date for the client and expectations for him to be picked up at the airport. On 2/20/22, Peacock Acres sent an email to the client’s Social Worker informing them of the decision not to accept the client back into the facility following return from home visit due to ongoing safety issues presented by doing so. Peacock Acres provided LPA Simien a screen shot of the email with time stamps to confirm that the email was sent to the Social Worker on 2/20/22. Peacock Acres said they didn’t get a response back from the client’s social worker On 2/22/22, Peacock Acres sent an email with the client’s discharge summary to client’s Social worker. Peacock Acres provided LPA Simien a screen shot of the email with time stamps to confirm the email was sent on 2/22/22. On 2/23/22, Client and their Social Worker flew to San Jose with the expectation that Peacock Acres were going to pick up them up. The County said that Peacock Acres refused to pick up client because of previous 14-day notice and left the client and Social Worker stranded. Once they realize that Peacock Acres was not going to pick up the client, The County tried calling various staff members of Peacock Acres, but no one answered.

This event lead to the allegations: minor was abandoned while in care, wrongful eviction, minor is being deprived of their possessions, staff are not responsive to requests for communication, and facility’s phone went unanswered. When LPA Simien mentioned to Peacock Acres the allegation minor was abandoned while in care, they mentioned the emails they sent to the client’s Social Worker (mentioned above). They said despite them informing the Social Worker they were not taking back the client and the discharge summary, The County still sent the client and Social Worker to San Jose. When LPA Simien mentioned to Peacock Acres the allegation of wrongful eviction, they said they had a consultation on 2/15 with an Alliance representative regarding the legality of not accepting client back into placement following his two week home visit. Based on this consultation it was determined that the client would not be accepted back following visitation with mother as the County had stopped paying for client's placement after his departure to home visit. The 14 Days to find placement had passed and there was no prior agreement with the County that Peacock Acres would continue placement of client after 14 days. Given client's behaviors prior to leaving on visit and additional events that had occurred in the house, client was increasingly likely to pose ongoing safety risks to the other residents of the home if they returned back. Also, increased staffing beyond required 1:3 staff to client ratio could not be secured to manage this risk. LPA Simien reviewed Peacock Acres Discharge Policy and it states, “Reasons for an unplanned discharge, removal, or transfer include but are not limited to 1. Repeated program violations, 2. Health and safety of other residents is endangered by the child’s or youth’s continued presence 3. Repeated or prolonged absences from the facility (AWOLs) 4. If it is determined the facility can no longer meet the needs of the child or youth”. Peacock Acres determined the client triggered reasons two and four for unplanned discharge, removal, or transfer. On 3/3/22 LPA mentioned the allegations facility's phones are not answered, staff are not responsive to requests for communication, and minor is being deprived of their possessions. Peacock Acres said that although they missed the County’s calls on 2/23/22 they had eventually contacted them and were working on sending the rest of the client’s belongings.

On 7/7/22 LPA Simien contacted CR regarding Peacock Acres claims regarding the allegations against them. Based on this conversation, CR stated that Riverside County had an arrangement with Peacock Acres to meet the client and Social Worker at the airport and gave no indication they were not going to take back the client. CR said that on 2/23/22 none of the various staff members they attempted to contact answered. LPA Simien encouraged CR to send him any correspondence between them and Peacock Acres. As of 7/29/22 CR has only sent LPA a copy of the client’s placement history which showed the County paying for the client’s placement at Peacock Acres until 3/1/22. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations.Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was to Clarissa Joseph, Residential Manager (RM).

narrative: On 11/22/2022 during an announced Psychotropic Medications Inspection, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Selena Hood observed that the facility does not log C1's self administration of M1, M2, and M3. LPAs reviewed Insulin Therapy Daily Log, Centrally Stored Medication binder, client file, and locked insulin storage. Based on observation and confidential discussion, the self-administration of M1, M2, and M3 had. not been documented. M2 and M3 were not documented on the centrally stored medication log. Based on this observation, LPAs cited for 80070(b)(10) Client Records (see LIC809D). LPA Belfield requested the communication log from July 2022-November 2022, facility staff agreed to provide this via email before 12/6/2022. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Ana Maria Hernandez-Lozano, Facility Manager, at 2:15PM. LPAs delivered appeal rights, citation, and plan of correction.

On 11/22/2022 at 9:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and Selena Hood conducted an announced visit to the facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Psychotropic Medications Inspection. LPA's Belfield and Hood met with staff member Daniela Flores. At the time of the inspection, there were two staff present and one client in the facility. The facility currently has two clients, both clients are prescribed psychotropic medications. LPA reviewed the both clients' files. During the time of this inspection one client was away on a home visit, therefore they could not be interviewed. The second client could not be interviewed as they were not a dependent placement. LPA's interviewed two staff members while in the facility. LPA's reviewed four staff files and the training records. A walk through of the facility was conducted with staff Flores. During the walk-through it was observed by LPA's Belfield and Hood that there were six pieces of wood with small nails sticking out of each one. LPA Hood discussed with staff Torres about removing the wood and staff Torres removed the wood and threw them away. LPA observed facility manager Anamaria Hernandez-Lozano ( who arrived at the facility at 12:50 PM to assist with the inspection) while conducting the pill count. There were no issues with the pill count. LPA reviewed the centrally stored medication binder and the Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR). There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview with Anamaria, Facility Manager, at 2:15 PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Bathroom floors were dirty and needed to be mopped. One of the bathrooms had a broken cabinet door that needed to be repaired. A light fixture in the hallway was broken. The TV stand was dirty and had a dead flower with lots of pedals on it. LPA took photos of these observations and will document them in a LIC 813. Based on these observations there is a Buildings and Grounds violation. Based on confidential interviews conducted during the initial visit on 5/20/22 the problem has to do with staffing issues. The combination of new employees, low staffing numbers, and loss of a key employee that handled a lot of the cleaning responsibilities has led to the facility not being maintained. The complaint allegations, staff do not properly maintain the facility and facility is in disrepair, are valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met As a result of this visit, there is one title 22 Regulation and General Licensing Standards 80087 Buildings and Grounds (a) violation observed. The facility will be cited (see 809-D for details). Appeal rights were discussed and provided to ED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Shaniz Beza, ED whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.
