narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on April, 6 2023 at 12pm based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, April 06, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Michelle P. Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Steisha Monderoy, Director Strategic Program

Attendees of the facility: Shaniz Beza- Executive Director, Ana Hernadez- Residential Director, Zeana Bey- Clinical Director LMFT Counties: Marni Sandoval, Eva Ortiz – Monterey County, Catherine Johnson, Linda Abdelbaki- Sacramento County, Alain Dominique- Riverside County, Noel Lossing- Santa Barbara County CCL: Helga Wong – Licensing Program Manager (LPM), and Paul Simien– Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Discussion: - Current substantiated complaint re personal rights violations - Current substantiated complaint re inappropriate sexual relations between staff member and client. - Frequency of Monterey Sheriff involvement with facility - 3 year complaint history - crisis management with Seneca/ Monterey County Sheriff Dept. - Staffing and Training, Staff supervision/care, AWOL policy Facility will do the following and submit them by 4/29/23: -Submit updated Program Statement showing changes made with the program. -Submit written plan on staff training (Prudent Parenting, Crisis Management, Law Enforcement Contact, - Boundaries, ILS V.4, and De-escalation techniques) and how the facility plans to measure staff understanding and implementation of training. -Written plan on how the facility will contact and connect with the community (MHPA & Monterey County Sheriff Dept.) LPM offered Technical Support Services (TSP) to facility if they want it in the future.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility main office to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegation. LPA met with Steisha Monderoy, Strategic Project Director (SPD) at 2:00 PM on 2/16/23. Over the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed files during this investigation. Based on confidential interviews conducted it was determined that the allegations listed above are substantiated. A witnessed viewed a client slip on water that had leaked from a water cooler. Staff was observed not cleaning up the water after the slip. Individuals stated that the facility would not provide hygiene products in a timely manner and failed to provide requested hygiene products. Clients would often have to use their own funds to resupply hygiene products. Clients' requests for alternative hygiene products were ignored and had to be purchased by clients. Facility had blanketed policy on clients being searched each time they entered and exited the facility. All clients had to take drug tests if one client was suspected of using illicit substances. Clients were not allowed confidential phone calls. Clients would be required to answer

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights (c) (8) To make,*send,*and receive confidential telephone calls *and other electronic communications,* unless prohibited by court order.

This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted by LPA. Clients had to make phone calls while in the presence of staff, thus denying clients right for confidential phone calls.

This violates clients personal rights.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility agrees to make staff policy restricting them from listening to client phone calls unless directed to do so by court order or social worker. Facility will provide a sheet signed by staff that acknowledges that they have read and understand the policy. POC due by March 18th 2023. Facility will send LPA sign in sheet via email by due date.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights (c) (9) To*have access to letter writing material and to* send and receive unopened *mail* unless prohibited by court order.

This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted by LPA. Clients had to open mail in front staff or staff opened client mail before giving it to the clients.

This violates clients personal rights.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility agrees to create a youth personal rights policy and will have staff sign a sheet acknowledging they have read and understand the policy. POC due date is March 18th, 2023. Facility will send LPA staff sign in via email sheet by POC due date.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights (c) (6) (B) to be provided with and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items...Toiletries, *grooming,* and personal hygiene products...

This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted by LPA. Staff did not provide hygiene products in a timely manner and also did not provide alternative hygiene products when requested by clients.

This violates clients personal rights.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will create a client hygiene product request sheet for clients to fill out when they need to request things. Client can turn in request sheet on Sundays so facility can fufill requests. POC due date is March 18th 2023. Facility will email LPA request sheet by the POC due date.

deficiencies.description:
80087 Buildings and Grounds (b) (1) All clients shall be protected against hazards within the facility through provision of the following: Protective devices including but not limited to nonslip material on rugs. 

This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on confidential interview by LPA. Client slipped on water leaking from water cooler. Staff failed to clean water and facility failed to protect against hazards through protective devices.

This presents a safety and health hazard for clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility agrees to provide non-slip mat to prevent clients in care from slipping on water near the water cooler. POC date is March 18th 2023. Facility will provide photo evidence of non-slip mat to LPA by POC due date.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. LPA discussed this with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director (ED) at 12:35 PM on 8/31/23. This case management was opened to discuss an incident report the department received for an incident that occurred on 8/6/23. The incident report stated, "On 8/06/23, C1 was visibly upset and threw a key chain of office keys he stole from the staff office on the floor. C1 also returned a phone, and medication (Melatonin) to staff which he stole from the staff office the previous day 8/5". C1 refers to the client involved. When discussing the incident report ED informed LPA Simien that the keys thrown were not office keys and that the client broke into the staff office by breaking into the office. ED stated that they inspected the set of keys and determined that none of the keys had access to anything related to the facility. ED informed LPA that the phone was a staff members and was locked so the client couldn't access the phone. LPA inquired about how the client was able to access the melatonin. ED responded that she was not sure and that Peacock Acres Residential Manager handled the follow up to the incident. ED agreed to send LPA Simien the follow up documents to review. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Shaniz Beza, ED whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. LPA discussed this with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director (ED) at 12:15 PM on 11/1/23. This case management was opened to discuss the on going issues with the facility's overnight staff not being able to provide adequate supervision to clients. Starting from 2021, there have been multiple incidents of clients engaging in sexual acts due to lack of supervision. LPA highlighted the importance of resolving this issue as failure to do so could lead to an NCC meeting. LPA asked ED how the facility was planning on dealing with this issue that has repeatedly occurred. ED responded by creating a plan of action (this plan of action is also a POC for a related citation). The plan of action in summary: Hiring two part-time staff for the overnight shift. This will allow the overnight shift to have two staff members from 12 AM to 6 AM. The facility will request future CSEC clients to be placed on 1-on-1 supervision ratio from the placing counties/departments. Facility will implement unannounced audits to ensure overnight staff is completing their duty. Conduct informal meetings with youth documenting their experiences and log their concerns All staff will receive refresher courses in providing attuned supervision. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Shaniz Beza.

This is a continuation of a Pre-Licensing STRTP tele inspection conducted via Google Duo that was initiated on 08/05/2020. Licensing Program Analyst Jose Gonzalez contacted and met with Executive Director (ED), Carolyn Ruffin to continue with the Pre License STRTP tele inspection. LPA reviewed both client and staff files with ED. ED provided LPA copies of the missing documents for both clients and staffs files. LPA also conducted interviews with direct care staff and facility social worker. LPA informed ED that she needs ongoing training with direct care staff and follow up with direct care staff on emergency intervention plan, location and information of the needs and services plans for the clients. LPA also informed the ED that she needs to continue with the STRTP process of being accredited and having a mental health component. LPA informed ED that Pre STRTP tele inspection has been completed and that she needs to continue to remain in compliance with the latest version of STRTP regulations. A copy of this report was given and explained to Executive Director, Carolyn Ruffin who agreed to sign and email signed reports to LPA. Signed reports will be placed in the facility file.

On January 8, 2020 at 2:05 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar conducted a case management tele-inspection with assistant administrator (AA) Rejeena Marshall in order to provide the information pertaining to the deficiencies being assessed in relation to several violations of regulation standards observed during a recent physical inspection at the facility completed on December 23, 2020. During the physical inspection of the facility on December 23, 2020, LPA Jose Gonzalez conducted a physical inspection of the facility while LPA Carmen Escobar attended and observed via FaceTime. LPAs met with Direct Care staff Mr. Robert at the start of the inspection. Since there was no facility manager on site, Mr. Rufus, facility manager, was called to come to the facility to complete the inspection with LPAs. The facility is being cited for not having a facility manager on site at time of the inspection while two clients were at the facility. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards chapter 7.5 section 87065, Personnel Requirements. LPA Gonzalez and LPA Escobar also observed that there was no carbon monoxide detector in the facility at the time of the inspection. Also, the bathroom inside bedroom #2 continues to be used by staff but remains locked for the client in that bedroom. Confidential interviews revealed that staff use client bedroom #2 as a passageway to use the bathroom located in the bedroom. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards section 87087, Buildings and Grounds. It was also observed that none of the beds in the facility had all the required linens such as a mattress pad/protector, as well as top and bottom sheets. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards section 87088, Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies. The facility does not have a phone that allows clients to make private phone calls. The only working phone at

the time of the inspection was a corded phone that is in the open office area of the living room, which does not allow for privacy of calls. Also, the window in bedroom #2 has what looked to be like nails or screws in the window track that may obstruct the window when being opened. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards section 87072, Personal Rights. The activities calendar for the facility could not be produced and was not posted. The staff stated there are usually no regular activities planned as the clients do not like to participate and get involved in anything. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards section 87079, Planned Activities. Other observations made will be cited under Title 22 Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. The first being the condition of the facility. LPA Gonzalez and LPA Escobar observed numerous holes in the walls of the facility, some patched poorly and others painted over poorly. There was a hole by the front living room where the painting was hung, another in the dining room wall, and a bigger one in the hallway. Room #1 also had small holes behind the door in the wall, and several holes were observed in the dry wall throughout the house, such as by the whiteboard. Most concerning were the broken and missing windows in rooms #1, #2, and #3. Room #1 has a missing window and curtains stapled to the wall with no board replacing the missing window. Room #2 has a 1-2 inch gap between the two window panels that allows the outside air to come in. A big piece of plywood was up against the wall, but it does not cover the window gap, nor covers the window. Room #3 has a shattered window that also is not boarded up. The glass shards are hanging off the window frame and are on the floor outside the window. A smoke detector in room #2 is hanging off the ceiling with wires exposed. Room #1 has no electrical outlet plate covers on the outlets, exposing the outlet. There is also what appears to be tagging on the wall that was painted over, but still visible. This is also the case outside in the backyard. There is tagging on the stucco wall and on the concrete patio that is still visible. Finally, the backyard has trash all over the grounds, including cigarette butts, glass pieces, and miscellaneous trash. The palm trees have not been landscaped and are overgrown with dead foliage. Lastly, there are multiple large items in the backyard that were identified as "trash" by staff, however, have not been removed. There are mattresses, old chairs, old screens, broken pieces of furniture, and drywall and plywood. Based on observations made the facility will be cited under Title 22 Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations section 80087, Buildings and Grounds. Also during the inspection, it was observed that the majority of windows do not have screens, including the

windows in all the client's rooms. The trash can in the kitchen does not have a lid or cover on it. The main restroom for the clients has six light bulb outlets but only one bulb was screwed in for light. The sink in this restroom does not drain well and was clogged. The cabinets in the bathroom were in disrepair with a broken drawer on the bottom right side. The shower curtain had stains all over the curtain of an unknown black streaky substance. The counter in the kitchen has chips and the cabinets have stains from what looks to be white paint and brown and white stains from unknown substances. Based on LPA observations, the facility will be cited under Title 22 Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations section 80088, Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. LPA Escobar and LPA Gonzalez concluded the physical inspection of the property. LPA Escobar advised facility manager, Mr. Rufus, that LPA will contact the facility to address the observations made at later date and requested some things be repaired/fixed immediately, including the missing window in room #1 and broken/missing window in room #3, cleaning of the glass shards on the window frame of room #3 and outside the window of room #3, and the missing carbon monoxide detector. LPA requested pictures of these repairs be sent to LPA by 5 PM. LPA received pictures of the boarded up windows on 12/23/20 by 6:30 PM . LPA also received pictures of the new carbon monoxide detector on 12/29/20. LPA Escobar conducted an exit interview and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Ms. Rejeena for original signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

corroborate that the facility was aware that C1 would smoke or drink, C1 was never found to have possession of marijuana or alcohol on C1’s person or in C1’s room. Staff confirm C1 would often be searched, as would C1’s room, however, nothing was ever found. Several statements corroborate C1 did smoke marijuana, however, it is unknown where C1 would get the marijuana or where C1 would smoke the marijuana as all statements corroborated that C1 was never observed to be smoking or drinking at the facility. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that C1 possessed marijuana while in care and C1 had access to alcohol while in care at the facility, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. investigation_findings: 13**This is an amended report of the original dated 01/29/21** On January 29, 2020 at 2:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar made phone contact with group home direct care staff, Ms. Watishi Turner (Ms. Nikki). Due to COVID19, a tele-inspection was conducted to issue the investigative findings for the above allegations. During the investigation, LPA requested documents from client 1 (C1’s) file including placement agreement, copy of C1’s needs and service plan, and special incident reports involving C1. LPA Escobar conducted interviews with two staff members, C1’s county social worker, as well as C1, client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), and another confidential witness. LPA Jose Gonzalez conducted an in-person inspection of the group home on 12/23/20 at 9:55 AM. It was alleged that on or around 12/17/20, C1 possessed marijuana while in care and C1 had access to alcohol while in care at the facility. Specifically, it was reported that C1 had been smoking marijuana and drinking alcohol while at the facility. Details allege a marijuana dispensary would make deliveries “around the corner” from the facility to C1. There were no details referencing where C1 would allegedly get the alcohol. It was also reported that C1 tested positive for marijuana. While several confidential statements

narrative:
**This is an amended report of the original dated 02/12/21** Witness statements corroborate this information provided, stating S1 grabbed C1 by the neck and “shoved/threw (C1)” across the living room. While another witness states C1 had S1’s handprint on C1’s neck, LPA was unable to confirm this information from pictures provided to LPA. Several witnesses confirm C1 did spit on S1, escalating the situation with S1. Several witnesses corroborate S1 grabbed C1 by C1’s neck and was pushing C1 around the house, at one point, throwing C1 into the couch in the living area. S1 denies this occurring. Several witnesses corroborate a witness recorded part of this incident on their school Ipad. Another confidential witness was not there at the time of the incident, however, confirms they viewed the recording and states there were also audio recordings where C1 was heard saying “Let me go!”, “Stop, get your hands off me!” LPA did not have access to these recordings, however, several witnesses corroborated this did occur and was recorded. S1 denies putting hands on C1 at any point during the altercation stating S1 was only using S1’s hands/arms to block the hits C1 was aiming at S1. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards section 87072(d)(10), Personal Rights. It was also alleged that on or around 12/14/20, the facility is in disrepair. It was reported that there are holes in several walls within the facility and there are several wires exposed within the facility. It was detailed that the garage door is broken and several rooms have broken windows, causing concern for client’s safety at the facility. LPA Carmen Escobar was on FaceTime while LPA Jose Gonzalez conducted a physical inspection of the facility on 12/23/20. LPA Gonzalez and LPA Escobar observed numerous holes in the walls of the facility, some patched poorly and others painted over poorly. There was a hole by the front living room where the painting was hung, another in the dining room wall, and a bigger one in the hallway. Room #1 also had small holes behind the door in the wall, and several holes were observed in the dry wall throughout the house, such as by the whiteboard. A smoke detector in room #2 was hanging off the ceiling with wires exposed. Room #1 has no electrical outlet plate covers on the outlets, exposing the outlet wires and electrical sockets. The facility is being cited under Title 22 Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations section 80087, Buildings and Grounds. Based on confidential interviews, information gathered, and LPA’s own observations, the allegations that S1 handled C1 in an inappropriate manner and the facility is in disrepair are SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for each allegation. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited under Title 22 as well as the Interim Licensing Standards cited above. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were emailed to Ms. Nikki for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

case, the facility provided LPA with a copy of the annual training log showing hours completed by staff in “Medications” training. In reference to the staff administering medication to clients without proper paperwork, the concern is that clients were receiving psychotropic medications with no current JV220 forms. While a confidential witness states the JV220 forms were expired, LPA was unable to corroborate this information. LPA requested most recent JV220 forms along with dates clients were in the home receiving the medication and LPA also reviewed the medication log. Forms were current for current client though a confidential witness states the JV220 forms were incorrect. Finally, it was alleged that the facility has a gas odor due to a leaking pilot light from the gas stove. While a confidential witness states there was a constant odor of gas in the facility, during LPA Gonzalez’s physical inspection of the home, there was no odor of gas and the pilot was in working order. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that staff at the facility are not trained, staff are administering medications without proper paperwork, and that the facility has an odor of gas, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were emailed to Ms. Nikki for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 12, 2021, at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar made phone contact with facility manager, Watishi Turner (Ms. Nikki). Due to COVID19, a tele-inspection was conducted to issue the investigative findings for the above allegations. During the investigation, LPA requested documents from client 1 (C1’s), client 2 (C2’s), and client 3 (C3’s) files including placement agreements, copy of C1’s needs and service plan, and special incident reports involving C1. LPA also obtained a copy of the group home client roster and staff roster. LPA Escobar conducted interviews with the group home Assistant Administrator, four staff members, C1’s county social worker, as well as C2 and C3, and another confidential witness. LPA Jose Gonzalez conducted an in-person inspection of the group home due to the nature of the allegations on 12/23/20 at 9:00 AM. It was alleged that on or around 12/14/20, S1 handled C1 in an inappropriate manner and the facility is in disrepair. Specifically, it was reported that C1 was asking S1 to make food and S1 refused. C1 became upset and spit on S1 and S1 grabbed C1 by C1’s shirt collar and proceeded to drag C1 around the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights: (d)The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (10) To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
Based on information obtained during  confidential interviews, S1 put hands on C1 during an altercation, grabbing C1 in an inappropriate manner.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will receive re-training on personal rights. Documentation of date completed,  topics covered, and attendance, will be provided to LPA via email. LPA is requesting specific training topics such as: de-escalation techniques, when back-up staff is needed, and when to call law enforcement.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings and Grounds: (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: LPAs observed numerous holes in the walls of the facility, some patched poorly. Hole by the front living room where painting was hung, hole in dining room wall, & one in hallway. Several holes in the dry wall throughout the house, like by whiteboard. Smoke detector in room #2 hanging off the ceiling with wires exposed. Room #1 has no electrical outlet plate covers on the outlets, exposing the wires and electrical outlet.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: All identified defects will be repaired/fixed. Proof of this will be provided to LPA by 02/12/21 (already submitted per emails, texts, videos received by LPA).

narrative:
On February 17, 2021 at 10:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar conducted a case management tele-inspection with the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility manager (FM) Watishi Turner (Ms. Nikki). The purpose of the inspection was to address issues and concerns regarding an incident that occurred on or around December 14, 2020. It was discovered through information received via confidential interviews and LPA Carmen Escobar’s and LPA Jose Gonzalez's own observations that the STRTP’s administrator is not at the facility the minimum twenty hours required per Interim Licensing Standards. Per the facility’s LIC 500 form for that week of the physical inspection, the administrator was scheduled to work at the facility on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, from 11 AM until 5 PM. When LPA Jose Gonzalez conducted a physical inspection of the facility on Wednesday, December 23, 2020, during that period of time, the administrator never arrived and was not on grounds at the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that the administrator will stop by the facility randomly on occasion for a small amount of time, however, the administrator is not at the facility on regularly scheduled days and times. Current LIC 500 states the administrator is “on call” but no specific schedule hours were provided. Additionally, all confidential interviews corroborate administrator is hardly at the facility on a weekly basis. Based on confidential interviews and document review, Community Care Licensing (CCL) is citing the facility under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87064: Administrator Qualifications and Duties. It was also discovered that staff have not received annual training as required. The facility provided LPA with copies of the annual training log showing hours completed by staff and topics covered. Training records did not show sufficient training hours as required for the year 2020. Per administration, training is occurring online due to COVID19 therefore the facility was unable to provide more specific documentation of completed training, such as a sign-in sheet for staff participation. Annual training hours for staff have not been met per the training records obtained. Several confidential witnesses state they never received the

required new hire training at hire, have not received the required annual training, and have been working for the facility for one or more years. The facility is being cited under Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87065.1: Training Requirements. LPA Escobar conducted an exit interview and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Ms. Nikki for original signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

On February 25, 2021, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith met with Lawrence Thomas, CEO of Pennacle Foundation Inc, Dr. Cynthia Powell, Administrator/Therapist, Rejeena Marshall, Assistant Administrator, Amy Guisa, acting San Bernardino County STRTP (Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program) Coordinator, Watishi Turner, facility manager, Terry Landreaux, facility manager, and Dionne Thomas, facility manager, via Microsoft Teams for a virtual office meeting due to COVID 19. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss issues and concerns regarding the facility and to bring the facility into compliance with Title 22 Regulations and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. LPM Smith summarized the facility’s deficiencies occurring since the last office meeting completed with the facility on January 23, 2020. LPM and LPA discussed concerns that have arose due to information gathered from confidential interviews and inspections with the facility. LPM and LPA reviewed issues, concerns and plan of corrections that need to be addressed in order to bring the facility into compliance with Title 22 Regulations and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. Items covered during the meeting included: -Reoccurring Building and Grounds deficiencies concerning broken windows in client rooms, trash in yard, contraband trash, holes in walls, exposed wires in client rooms, and general cleanliness of facility. Maintenance of facility was discussed. The need for the facility to be kept in clean and safe condition for clients was expressed by LPA and LPM. CEO stated a checklist for building maintenance for ongoing repairs has been implemented at the facility and a staff has been

designated as a physical plant manager to ensure the buildings and ground are maintained. -Administrator Qualifications and Duties: Administrator is not on the premises for a minimum of 20 hours per week to manage and administer the STRTP in compliance with applicable law and regulation. CEO stated that due to Administrator's "high risk" category for COVID 19 and the Administrator living with her elderly parent, the Administer is unable to be at the facility. LPA was not unaware of the Administrator’s special circumstance. CEO Thomas stated he will send LPA a letter to explain this situation and to designate an Assistant Administrator as the acting Administrator during this time of COVID 19 or until the Administrator receives a COVID 19 vaccination allowing her to be at the facility a minimum of 20 hours as required by ILS. -Training Requirements: staff have not received the required annual training. Per CEO, a majority of the staff have only been with the facility for 4-5 months. CEO will send a training calendar to show training planned for 2021 to meet the required ILS 40 hours of training as part of a plan of correction (POC) that is due on 02/26/21. CEO requested the POC be extended to 03/05/21. Also, a facility staff was required to be retrained for Personal Rights and LPA has not yet received proof of this POC which was due on 02/19/21. CEO stated he did not recall this report/POC being received. CEO requested an extension for this POC and it was agreed the POC would be submitted by 3/5/21. -Buildings & Grounds: It was discussed that no bedroom shall be used as a public or general passageway to another room, bath or toilet. Facility was cited for bedroom #2 serving as a passageway for staff to use the restroom occupied by a client. CEO states the room is now empty as there is only one client at the facility and while staff are allowed to use the restroom right now, the restroom will be locked once a client is assigned to that bedroom. CEO will send a photo of the empty room (as beds are being fixed) to LPA for previous POC that was due on 01/08/21. -Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies: Another POC not received is that client beds do not

have the required linens such as a mattress pad or protector as well as top and bottom sheets. CEO mentioned picture was sent to LPA by POC due date, will resend for POC clearance by LPA. -It was further discussed with facility representatives that the facility currently has a provisional STRTP license and the facility needs to be in compliance with Title 22 Regulations and STRTP ILS in order for the facility to be issued a permanent license. LPM mentioned that while this is a (virtual) "office meeting", the next step could be a non-compliance meeting. CEO expressed the need to find a qualified individual, who lives closer to the facility, to take over as administrator to put in the time and work the program requires, however, states Ms. Rejeena has been doing most of the management of the facility at this time. LPM and LPA summarized the issues covered during the meeting and clarified to the facility representatives that CCL's (Community Care Licensing's) purpose of the meeting is to bring the facility into ILS compliance as the regulations for an STRTP are much more detailed and demanding than the group home regulations. As long as there is communication with CCL/LPA, there are ample opportunities to bring the facility into compliance. CEO expressed his concern with the hold San Bernardino County currently has on the facility and Ms. Guisa expressed she would follow-up with CEO once the remaining POCs have been completed and cleared. LPA and LPM open the meeting up for any additional comments or questions from facility staff and nothing was asked of LPA or LPM. Meeting was concluded. A copy of this report was provided to CEO Thomas and a signed copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On September 13, 2021 at 11:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Pennacle Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with facility manager (FM) Tina Gordon. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There was one staff and zero clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection, however, the two clients currently placed in the STRTP were at school. LPA conducted the physical inspection 11:50 AM. FM Tina Gordon led the physical inspection of the facility. The facility consists of three bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility has a dining area, kitchen area, and living room/common area that also houses the make-shift staff office. The facility also has an attached garage where the washer and dryer are located. The facility does not have a clinician's office for therapeutic services, therefore, counseling and therapy is currently being provided . Staff area is located in the open common area adjacent to the main living room. All bedrooms have two individual twin beds and adequate drawer space for each client. Because there are only two clients placed in the STRTP, they each have their own room. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space for the clients. Books, board games, movies, a TV, and video game system, were observed for client’s recreation time. Carbon monoxide detector is in appropriate working order, and per staff, all facility smoke detectors are also in working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. The Grievance Procedures were not posted within the facility. The facility is being cited for Interim Licesning Standards section 87072(a)(3): Discipline Policies and Procedures. Other information, such as Personal Rights and Visitation Policy were posted.

Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked file cabinet in the staff area. The hot water in the restroom was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of the license. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a lower hallway cabinet. Sharp objects are locked and stored in the locked file cabinet in the staff area, as well as the First Aid Kits and First Aid manual. Facility has not yet obtained Mental Health Certification, however, are in process of completing the application. Facility has also not yet obtained national accreditation. There is currently a balance of $681.00 in licensing fees that were due on 08/2021. LPA began reviewing client files for the two clients currently placed in the STRTP, however, was unable to complete the reviews due to time constraints. LPA Escobar will return to complete staff file review and interviews at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager, Tina Gordon.

met_with: Facility manager, Watishi Turner & Administrator Carolyn Ruffin
narrative: On September 15, 2021 at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Pennacle Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with facility manager (FM) Watishi Turner. The purpose of the visit is to continue the annual inspection of the facility that was started on September 13, 2021. There was one staff and zero clients present at the time of the inspection continuation. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection, however, the two clients currently placed in the STRTP were at school. LPA Escobar continued to review the client and staff files but was unable to complete the inspection due to time constraints. LPA will return to complete staff file review and client and staff interviews at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility Administrator, Carolyn Ruffin, as facility manager's shift has ended.

On September 17, 2021, at 1:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar, arrived at Pennacle Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by facility manager, Watishi Turner. The purpose of the visit was to continue the annual inspection that began on Monday, September 13, 2021. There was one staff present at the time of the annual continuation. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified as the facility has two clients and both were at school during the inspection. Personnel files are kept in a locked file cabinet in the staff area of the living room. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. The facility employs one head social worker, one facility administrator, five facility managers, and one direct care staff. Seven staff files were reviewed at the time of inspection. The Administrator's file was unavailable for review by LPA. Facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 80066: Personnel Records. Four of the five staff files reviewed for facility managers (FM) do not meet the regulation qualifications to be facility managers. There was no documentation of required education and experience in file for the one direct care staff (DC1). There was no documentation of initial new hire staff training for six of eight staff files. Training records for five of seven staff files were incomplete and did not provide accurate records of annual trainings. Facility is being cited under ILS section 87065: Personnel Requirements for all aforementioned staff file deficiencies. Based on LPA's observation, review of LIC500, and confidential interviews, the facility Administrator was not at the facility a minimum of 20 hours as required. The facility is being cited under ILS section 87064: Administrator Qualifications and Duties. A civil penalty was assessed due to citation being a repeat offense. Additionally, board minutes were unavailable for LPA's review. Facility is being cited under ILS section 87063: Accountability. Staff have not been trained or have not maintained their certification to conduct restraints, though the staff state restraints are never used in the facility. Because the facility is an STRTP, it is required that staff maintain their certification for restraints. The facility is being cited under ILS section 87095:Emergency Intervention Staff Training.Lastly, one facility manager (FM5) did not have proof

of current CPR/first aid certification in staff file. Facility is being cited under Title 22 section 80075: Health Related Services. Two of two client files were reviewed during time of inspection. Client 1 (C1) did not have a copy of the current JV220 for authorization of C1's psychotropic medications in file. Neither C1 or client 2 (C2) had a visitation list showing who is or is not allowed to visit the client. Additionally, neither needs and service plan for C1 and C2 had all required signatures. The plans also did not have documentation that both client and client's authorized representative were offered the opportunity to participate in the plan development or that authorized representatives approved the needs and service plan for C1 and C2. The facility is being cited under ILS section 87070: Children's Records. C2 did not have proof of medical assessment during the first 30 days in the facility. C1 did not have proof of TB test. The facility is being cited under Title 22 section 80069: Client Medical Assessment. Neither C1 or C2 have received an allowance since arriving at the STRTP. Facility is being cited under ILS section 87072: Personal Rights. There was no record of an initial crisis management assessment in both client's files. Facility is being cited under ILS section 87068.1: Intake Procedures. Based on review of activity calendar, daily schedule, and staff and client interviews, the STRTP is not providing required core services and supports. Facility is being cited under ILS section 87078.1: Core Services and Supports. Technical violations were issued for section 80066: Personnel Records-staff missing proof of educational background in staff files, section 87095.61: Documentation and Reporting Requirements-no restrain log available for review, and section 87068.2 Needs and Service Plan-no mention of community resources in both client's plans and no mention of how much money clients are permitted to have in their possession. Technical Assistance was issued for section 87065: Personnel Requirements- employee handbook did not include disaster response procedures, and section 87079: Planned activities-no mention of activities from section (a)(1) through (a)(10) on activities calendar. During the three days of annual inspection, LPA interviewed three staff and two clients. Confidential interviews did not reveal health and safety concerns. Both clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and that they feel safe and secure in the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to FM, Tina Gordon, as other FM, Watishi Turner, has already concluded her shift.

On December 3, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar met with Pennacle Foundation Inc. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility Managers, Watishi Turner and Zachary Williams. The purpose of the case management inspection was to follow up on staff qualifications and review staff files. LPA inspected the facility on this date and there were no safety concerns. The staff files were not available for review on this date. Mr. Zachary made contact with Administrator, Carolyn Ruffin, who stated she was not available to bring the files to the facility on this date but could scan requested documents if needed. LPA Escobar needed the physical staff file to review. LPA requested for files to be brought to Riverside Community Care Licensing office on Monday, December 6, 2021 for review. LPA Escobar conducted interviews with two of two staff on this date. Based upon interviews and observation, the staff files were not available to licensing to review during normal business hours. The facility is being cited under Title 22 Regulations, section 80066(C) Personnel Records and the facility is also being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87063(a)(11) Accountability. An exit interview was conducted and a plan of correction was discussed facility manager. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Mr. Zachary Williams.

An informal conference was held with Pennacle Foundation Inc. Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to discuss current Community Care Licensing (CCL) concerns. Present at the meeting was LaCresha Cook, Regional Manager, Jennifer Smith, Licensing Program Manager, Carmen Escobar, Licensing Program Analyst, Lawrence Thomas, Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Carolyn Ruffin, Administrator, Dr. Sandra Butler, Board member, Jenell Ross, Riverside Department Public Social Services, Diana Wagner and Stacie Kinney, System of Care Branch, Karen Atkins, Riverside County Placement Liaison, David Gutierrez, Sandi Snelgrove, and Alexandria Andrews, Department of Health Care Services (DHCS), and Nisha Elliott, Riverside Behavioral Health. The following information was discussed: 1. Lack of oversight by management. 2. CCL unable to verify work hours of Administrator and hours present in the facility 3. Lack of trauma informed programming and activities for clients 4. Facility Managers unaware of Facility Manager Training 5. Lack of communication between Facility Management 6. Facility records unorganized and unavailable upon request 7. Clarification of mental health services being provided to clients. 8. Lack of Accreditation, Mental Health Contract, Medi-Cal Approval. 9. Lack of response to Department Health Care Services for denial of Mental Health Application. 10. Staff are not qualified. 11. Staff are not being adequately trained. 12. Plans of correction are incomplete and submitted late. 13. Core services, lack of trauma informed care.

who are San Bernardino County placements, are receiving mental health services in Riverside County. This could cause billing issues for the facility. Administrator stated she would obtain clarification on this. 8. CEO and Administrator confirmed the STRTP does not have accreditation, however, are working with CARF representative and have obtained the services of Maria Sarkisian to assist with the application process. CEO confirmed program does not have an approved mental health program as the application was returned by DHCS due to being incomplete. The facility has also not received Medi-Cal approval. 9. The mental health program application (MHPA) submitted by the facility to the Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) was incomplete. DHCS stated the STRTP staff did not respond to the letter that was sent advising that the MHPA was incomplete. CEO stated he was unaware any response to the letter was necessary. DHCS advised the approval process is lengthy and expressed concern that the program may run out of time as the STRTP’s second extension expires on 03/18/22. 10. CCL stated STRTP staff need to be re-valuated to confirm facility managers are qualified to be facility managers. LPA mentioned how not having a Facility Manager at the facility has been a reoccurring issue in the past, so somewhere along the line, all direct care workers were converted to Facility Managers, therefore, any staff working would also be the Facility Manager on site. LPA cited that several facility managers, upon file review, do not meet the requirements specified in the ILS either with education or experience. Almost all employees were hired after January 1, 2017, meaning they were not grandfathered into the STRTP program. Administrator states staff qualifications will be re-evaluated, however, feels this concern might only apply to one staff. Administrator stated they have been having issues with Guardian taking several months to clear a staff. Regional Manager Cook advised that if Guardian is taking a excessive amount of time the facility should reach out to LPA Escobar and LPM Smith for assistance. 11. CCL discussed a previous citation due to lack of training for staff. The annual training hours were incomplete, and upon confidential interviews with staff, many could not recall when the last training provided by administration had occurred. Concern was expressed towards facility staff's lack of understanding of trauma informed care. LPA stated upon interviewing facility staff, several employees were unable to define “trauma-informed care”. Additionally, during these confidential interviews, it was determined staff are not receiving

14. Lack of trauma informed milieu 15. CEO and Facility Managements Lack of knowledge of STRTP Requirements and Standards of Care 16. TSP Referral Information covered during the informal conference includes: 1. CEO was unaware of most STRTP requirements and has delegated all operational authority to facility Administrator. Board minutes were discussed, including the need for the Board to spend more time addressing the issues of Pennacle Foundation in Lake Elsinore, as many agendas and meeting minutes provided to LPA addressed the Pennacle facility in Fresno. While the facility has many concerning issues occurring at this time, as noted above, they are not a priority per the agendas and minutes provided to LPA. CCL/LPA expressed the need for Board of Directors to be much more involved, provide more oversight to facility, and aware of all issues occurring with the facility. CEO stated he is the direct contact with the Board of Directors, therefore, it was requested for CEO to better communicate facility issues/conditions to the Board. LPA also requested a Board meeting be conducted to address the facility issues addressed during this informal conference. CEO stated he will definitely fill the Board of Directors in on all the concerns expressed by each department in today’s meeting CCL and DHCS recommended the CEO become more familiar with the program and provide more oversight and work more closely with the Administrator and Mental Health Head of Service to ensure successful implementation of statutory and regulatory STRTP requirements. 2. STRTP submitted documentation to CCL that did not verify the work hours of Administrator nor the hours present in the facility. The documentation lacked dates, times, and hours. 3. STRTP is not providing a full program to clients, as seen on the activities calendar for clients. Activities scheduled include things such as movies and visits to park or local YMCA. LPA stated during the three consecutive days of STRTP’s annual in September, the activities listed on the calendar did not occur. CCL requested for activities provided to clients to be more trauma-informed based on the specific trauma-informed care model being followed by the program. 4. During past confidential interviews with staff, LPA was told by staff that they are unsure

if they are considered a Facility Manager. Several staff could not confirm whether or not they had been trained as a Facility Manager. Some facility managers thought they were still “direct care staff” as they were previously. CCL expressed concern with the training being provided to staff, especially since a Facility Manager is required to be on-site when clients are at the facility, per regulations. 5. CCL addressed the lack of communication between management. CEO confirmed that facility’s upper management/administration is busy trying to keep up with all the pending requirements that sometimes, they do not fill each other in quickly enough to know what may have recently occurred or developed within the program. Regional Manager Cook stated the Board of Directors, CEO, and Administrator, all need to better communicate to get everyone on same page with facility concerns. CEO agreed. 6. LPA addressed facility’s common practice of staff files to be stored “off grounds”, sometimes taking hours to be brought to the facility. CCL stated all hard copies of files need to be stored at the facility for reviewing purposes. Though Administrator generally offers to email copies of necessary documents to LPA, it was made clear by CCL all files need to be stored at the facility. LPA confirmed staff files were brought to the Regional Office for review and will be ready for pick up on Monday, December 13, 2021. Documentation of mental health service hours were also discussed. DHCS specifically addressed the need for detailed records including dates, times, and hours, etc. of services provided for each client. The program needs to create a more detailed documentation system. Per DHCS, hours, and additional details, need to be clearly recorded for audit purposes. Same issues exist for documentation of staff training hours. Administrator agreed to get files organized and completed. 7. Administrator states client 1 and client 2 are both being provided mental health services in Riverside County (Lake Elsinore), though they are both San Bernardino County placements. LPA read from facility’s program statement stating the clients in the program will receive 1-2 sessions per week of individual therapy and will have group therapy sessions once a week. DHCS pointed out that since the STRTP does not have an approved mental health care program, they cannot be providing these services to clients as of yet. Administrator confirmed clients are receiving off-site mental health care services at this time. Administrator was unsure as to which county provides Medi-Cal to clients. Riverside Behavioral Health expressed there needs to be clarification as to why the clients

the required hours of annual training. Training records submitted to LPA previously do not provide the necessary information required per Interim Licensing Standards. LPA advised facility better documentation is needed showing course title and subject matter, learning objectives and activities, number of hours per training session, qualification of trainer, and training evaluation. There should also be a way to confirm staff attendance, either attendance sheet with signature, electronic signature, time stamp records, etc. Supporting documentation of training, if available, should also be provided. Hours completed for each training should be clear for reviewing parties. 12. Plans of corrections (POCs) provided to LPA are generally incomplete and/or untimely. CCL expressed the need for more detailed documentation and records as expressed above. Additionally, CCL confirmed LPA will be following-up with the plans of correction in a timely manner to more quickly bring the facility into compliance. It was also stated that civil penalties are a possible consequence of repeat citations if they are not being properly or sufficiently cleared. LPA expressed a vital component of this occurring is simply the need for more detailed and organized documentation by the facility. Administrator agreed and stated she is always good about submitting everything on time, however, past POCs have been untimely. 13. While trauma informed care is described in the facility's program statement, System of Care Branch and Riverside Regional Office both stated that additional updates are required because the trauma informed sections are not specific and lack detail. 14. System of Care Branch advised a clear trauma informed, evidence-based, model needs to be referred to throughout the entire program statement. This is necessary because depending on the model being used, the trauma-informed practices should be specific to that model; every aspect of trauma informed should be addressed in detail and not described in a general manner. 15. CCL and DHCS recommended the CEO become more familiar with the program and provide more oversight and work more closely with the Administrator and Mental Health Head of Service to ensure successful implementation of statutory and regulatory STRTP requirements. 16. A Technical Support Program (TSP) referral will be made by CCL in order for facility to obtain assistance with the implementation of statutory and regulatory STRTP requirements. Administrator stated that she was planning on requesting help from TSP.

The facility has agreed to the following: 1. Staff will submit a Plan of Action to CCL within 30 days, due January 7, 2022. The plan should address updates to the facility's current program statement core services, staff training section including program trainer requirements, trauma informed activities that will be provided to clients and how the activities are developed or selected. 2. Update to program statement should include a clear, evidence-based trauma informed model of care and how this model will be implemented. 3. Program statement should address how trauma informed milieu will be provided to clients. This should include how clinical staff will be working with current staff, including regarding technical interventions. 4. Staff will provide anticipated hire dates for two Mental Health Specialists that are in process of being hired by facility. 5. Administrator hours will be addressed in terms of increased hours at facility, how administrator will provide additional oversight to facility and perspective dates of hire for a permanent administrator and assistant administrator will be provided. 6. Updated LIC500 will be produced reflecting exact Administrator schedule and a detailed sign-in sheet will be created, displaying date, time in, time out, staff signature, etc. CCL has requested finger-print attendance records from August 2021 through the December 9, 2021 for the Administrator. 7. Plan of action will include plan for ensuring Facility Manager is present at all times when clients are at the STRTP. 8. Plan will include how staff qualifications will be re-evaluated (specifically Facility Manager staff). 9. Perspective dates of hire for a Head of Service will be provided. 10. Facility activities schedule from October 2021 through December 9, 2021 will be provided to CCL, along with supporting documentation (such as receipts). Examples of trauma-informed activities to be completed with clients will be provided to CCL. An activity schedule for the next six months will be provided to CCL. 11. Staff training documentation will be reassessed to include all the information required per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) regulations. Training records will be updated to reflect the ILS requirements.

Upon conclusion of the meeting, Pennacle Foundation representatives were advised the goal of the informal conference is to bring the facility into compliance, especially since the STRTP's provisional license expires March 18, 2022. It was also advised that if the Plan of Action is not approved or adhered to, the next step would be conducting a non-compliance conference with the facility, which may result in administrative action. CEO, Lawrence Thomas, was advised the report (LIC809) will be provided via email for signature. Conference was concluded.

On February 17, 2022, at 1:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Pennacle Foundation Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct a Case Management inspection to determine compliance with the Plan of Action created during the informal conference that occurred with Pennacle Foundation on December 9, 2021. This Plan of Action had an original due date of January 07, 2022, however, Pennacle Foundation CEO, Lawrence Thomas, requested an extension. The extension was granted and extended with a new due date of January 21, 2022. The Plan of Action for Pennacle Foundation was received on January 25, 2022. Upon review of the Plan of Action, several items that should have been addressed and completed by the deadline of January 21, 2022, were not. The Plan of Action stated these items were being reviewed and worked on and would be submitted by February 04, 2022. As of the date of this facility inspection, February 17, 2022, the remaining Plan of Action items have not been completed and will be addressed by LPA Escobar during this case management inspection. During the physical inspection of the facility, LPA Escobar observed no health and safety concerns. During the facility inspection, LPA Escobar requested to see facility’s Activities Calendar along with accompanying receipts/logs to support scheduled activities. While staff was able to provide some receipts to LPA, activities scheduled on calendar (such as groups) do not have sign-in sheets/information of who led group, what was covered on each date for each group meeting. Additionally, there are no activities being led or conducted by community groups/resources. Confidential statements also corroborate that the facility continues to lack planned activities/outings. Administrator was unaware all clients in the facility are off from school the following day, Friday, February 18, 2022, and Monday, February 21, 2022, therefore, no special outings have been planned. Facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87078.1(a)(3) Core Services and Supports. The facility is being assessed a civil penalty due to repeating the same violation within twelve months.

LPA Escobar requested the updated Staff Training Plan with updated training hours for staff, however, Administrator states she is still working on this and was unaware a date of February 4, 2022, had been given to LPA as the expected submission date. The Staff Training Plan was discussed during the informal conference and was expected to be submitted, along with current training hours for each staff member, by January 21, 2022. Nothing has been submitted in regards to training from facility. The facility is being cited under section 87065.1(a)(7) Supervision, Evaluation, and Training Requirements as well as Title 22 section 80066(C) Personnel Records for not having personnel training records available for review. The facility is being assessed a civil penalty for each of these citations due to repeating the same violations within twelve months. Additionally, LPA requested the visitor sign-in log to verify actual dates and times that Facility Administrator, Carolyn Ruffin, has been at the facility as discussed in the Informal Conference. Administrator was able to provide both the time clock record of hours worked along with dated sign in sheets for the facility. Upon review of client files, it was observed that three of three client files did not have current, updated, signed Needs and Service Plans. LPA requested the most current plans be reviewed by clients, signed, and provided to LPA within seven days. The facility is being cited under ILS section 87070(c)(1) Children's Records. The facility is being assessed a civil penalty for each of these citations due to repeating the same violations within twelve months. LPA requested for Administrator to submit a revised LIC500, Personnel Report, to LPA with updated staff work schedules/titles/etc. by Friday, February 18, 2022. The Facility Manager scheduled for day shift for tomorrow, February 18, 2022, does not meet qualifications and does not have an approved exception from Community Care Licensing. Administrator was advised that a qualified facility manager needs to be present whenever clients are at the facility. Administrator agreed and stated will be making modifications to the staff schedule. LPA provided Administrator a copy of this report, along with accompanying LIC421FCs, a copy of the Children's Residential PIN 17-02-CCLD: AB221 Care Facilities: Civil Penalties, and also appeal rights print out. An exit interview was conducted and all documents were discussed with Facility Administrator, Carolyn Ruffin.

**This is an amended report of the original dated January 19, 2022** adequately supervise minors in care, facility staff allow C2 to smoke cigarettes while in care, and facility does not provide C1 a safe environment. Specifically, it was reported that C2 has been punching C1 in the stomach daily for two weeks and when this is brought to staff’s attention, staff don’t do anything to stop C2 from doing this. Additionally, it was reported that C2 smokes cigarettes outside the STRTP and staff are aware but do not do anything about this. It was also reported that C2 has threatened to hit C1 more if C1 tells staff that C2 is hitting C1. Per allegation details, a witness does not feel safe in the STRTP. While a witness maintains all of the allegation details are true and occurred as reported, another witness denies all allegations. FM confirmed C2 would intentionally hit C1 on occasion, however, this was not due to lack of supervision, as staff was supervising the clients when this occurred. This was C2’s behavior when arrived at the STRTP. Staff redirected C2 and separated C2 from C1 immediately in each incident. Staff confirmed C2 will look for used cigarette butts while on outings and will sneak them into the STRTP to attempt to smoke them. Staff corroborate that they confiscate the cigarette butts when this occurs as C1 knows this is against STRTP rules. Staff corroborate clients are supervised on a continuous basis due to their behaviors and conditions, however, C2 is more independent and does push STRTP boundaries regardless of staff supervision. LPA reviewed C2’s needs and service plan and observed there is nothing in the plan stating C2 requires constant supervision. Staff corroborate they have never witnessed C2 threaten C1. Additionally, staff corroborate that C1 has never mentioned the above allegations to staff to be addressed. Also, CSW states C1 has never reported allegations to CSW and CSW has never had concerns with the care being offered at the STRTP. A couple of witnesses confirm they feel safe in the STRTP despite the allegations reported. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that C1 is getting hit by C2 while in care without staff intervening, staff do not adequately supervise minors in care, facility staff allow C2 to smoke cigarettes while in care, and facility does not provide C1 a safe environment, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegation is, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to Ms. Watishi Turner for original signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative:
On February 28, 2022, at 12:25 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Carmen Escobar and Lisi Leon arrived at Pennacle Foundation Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct a Case Management inspection to address the facility's compliance with the Plan of Action created during the informal conference that occurred with Pennacle Foundation on December 9, 2021, and the plan of correction documents received by LPA Escobar on February 24, 2022. LPA Escobar conducted a physical inspection of the facility at this time and did not observe any immediate health or safety concerns. Upon review of the Plan of Correction documents, it was observed that the Training Plan and training records from February 2021 through February 2022 did not show a comprehensive total hours trained for each staff member. Staff names were used on some records while staff phone numbers were used in other training records. Five of the six staff employed by the facility for over one year, have accrued less than the required 40 hours of annual training in this past year, per the records provided. Also, the records indicated 1.5 hours of training completed by an outside entity, in this case, one training was completed by the San Bernardino County Department of Public Health. Per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), a minimum of 20 hours of annual training should be conducted by an entity other than the STRTP. The facility is being cited under ILS section 87065.1, Supervision, Evaluation, and Training Requirements. Also, the remaining Plan of Action item in reference to the Activities, deficiency 87078.1(a)(3) Core Services and Supports was not submitted to LPA Escobar by the due date of February 24, 2022. The facility is being assessed a civil penalty for failing to correct the deficiency due February 24, 2022. Additionally, because the facility has not provided sufficient evidence in this area, though it was indicated during the annual inspection that S3 is in charge of

activities, the facility is being cited under ILS section 87065 Personnel Requirements. Due to the facility's continued lack of oversight of the program as seen in the failure to correct the plans of corrections or inadequately correcting the previously cited issues and the repeated lack of communication amongst STRTP administration, the facility is being cited under ILS section 87063 Accountability. LPA provided Facility Manager, Mr. Zachary Williams, a copy of this report, along with accompanying LIC421FCs, and appeal rights print out, and an exit interview was conducted.

On April 20, 2022, LPA Escobar conducted an inspection of the facility and proceeded to advise FM of reason for inspection. Information obtained during confidential interviews revealed that around 02/28/22, Staff 1 (S1) yelled at Client 1 (C1) during a physical altercation. While a witness maintains S1 raised S1’s voice to be heard over C1, who was yelling, several confidential statements corroborate S1 yelled at C1 several times during the incident. Based on confidential interviews and information obtained, the Department has determined a preponderance of evidence that S1 yelled at C1. The facility is cited for violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), section 84072(c)(10) Personal Rights. A copy of this report, LIC 809-D, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to FM, Ayla Losoya. An exit interview was conducted and a plan of correction was discussed facility manager.

while in care. Specifically, it was reported that C1 turned up the TV because staff shift change was happening and C1 could not hear the TV. S1, allegedly, became upset and turned off the TV. C1 became angry and turned the TV back on. It was then reported that S1 got in C1’s face, telling C1 to leave the TV alone. C1 requested for S1 to “get out of (C1’s) face” and shoved S1 when S1 did not remove self from C1 personal space. There was a power struggle between C1 and S1 as C1 pushed S1 and S1 attempted to redirect C1. They were witnessed to have ended up wrestling near the couch and landed on the floor of the facility living room. Allegedly, S1 proceeded to push C1 down the hallway in an effort to put C1 in C1’s room. Several corroborating statements confirm S1 was raising S1’s voice while attempting to get C1 to go to C1’s room. Confidential witnesses state S1 attempted to restrain C1 during the altercation. Several witnesses corroborate seeing S1 put hands on C1 in an attempt to redirect and restrain C1 from potentially hitting S1. Other witnesses corroborate hearing C1 yell, several times, “Get your hands off me!” to S1. During the investigation, S1 confirmed S1 put hands on C1, stating S1 attempted to put C1 in a child pose, one-arm restraint, which S1 states S1 is trained to conduct. S1 also confirmed S1 tried to physically turn C1 around to redirect C1 to C1’s room, however, was only able to “maintain control of (C1’s) forearms”. Corroborating statements confirm that eventually S1 and C1 released their holds on each other and C1 retreated to C1’s room. Another confidential witness confirms seeing S1 restrain C1’s arms as C1 yelled, “Get your hands off me!” and both of them struggling with each other like they were going to fall on the floor during the incident. Based on confidential interviews, information gathered, and review of the facility’s program statement which states restraints are not to be used on clients, the allegation that S1 engaged in a physical altercation with C1 while in care is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegation. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87095, General Provisions. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to FM Ayla Losoya, for signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative: On July 22, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Carmen Escobar arrived unannounced and met with Facility Manager (FM), William Zachary, in regard to a Confirmation of Removal for individual (A1) identified on the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 22, 2022. FM states A1's name is unfamiliar to FM and person by A1's name has not worked at facility since FM has been working, which is since November of 2021. FM advised LPA that FM does not know this individual to have been an employee and is definitely not working or currently affiliated with the organization. FM also confirms A1 has no direct contact with any clients at the facility. LPA also confirmed A1 is not listed on the facility's most current LIC500, Personnel Report. Based on evidence obtained during today's visit, the LPA has verified the individual, A1, is not present, employed or residing at the facility. LPA has advised the licensee to disassociate the individual from their roster. LPA Escobar also conducted phsyical inspection of the facility, no health or safety concerns were observed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with FM. Verification of removal is complete.

the pills were vitamins and there was also nothing mentioned by authorized representative that the pills were vitamins.
