Specifically, it was reported that C1 has been denied access to C1’s phone book. Several witnesses corroborate this is not true and C1 has constant access to any phone numbers C1 might need, including CSW’s, county representatives, legal entities, etc. It was also detailed that S1 gets in C1’s face and yells at C1, however, no details of this were reported. It was further reported that S1 will say things such as, “If (C2) sticks (C2’s) thumb up your (C1’s) butt, you’re gay right?” While two witnesses corroborate these two allegations, all other witnesses state this has never been observed and S1 does not yell at clients or says things as indicated on report. Several other witnesses state these incidents have never been reported to them during C1’s time at the facility. It was also reported S1 refuses to make C1 food, however, all witnesses corroborate that while several staff, including S1, do not cook for the clients in the facility at times, staff will order food or pick up fast food for clients. While S1 states S1 does not cook and does not like to cook, S1 states S1 will buy clients fast food or will order food for clients, including C1. Several other witnesses corroborate this information, some even stating they would rather eat fast food than eat food cooked by staff. Again, other witnesses advise this has not been reported to them during C1’s time at the facility. It was then detailed that S1 threatened to make C1 food with a dirty plate or food that is contaminated. S1 denies this allegation stating C1 can be unhygienic and S1 will have to remind C1 to not touch C1’s private parts and then touch plates in the kitchen, or food in the kitchen, as it will contaminate items with unhygienic germs. Another witness denies this occurring. Several witnesses corroborated this incident, advising S1 was not threatening C1, but was advising of proper hygiene when eating and preparing food. This incident was also not shared with other parties and, therefore, not witnessed. It was further detailed that C1 does not have access to TV or WiFi in the facility, causing C1 to be bored. Several staff deny this allegation and advise the TV and internet are always available to C1 as long as C1 has completed chores and has not lost privileges. While a witness maintains this continues to occur, several other witnesses deny this allegation, stating the TV is always on and staff usually allow clients to use the WiFi when requested. Finally, it was also reported that C1 has not been enrolled in school, however, the facility provided documentation of the ongoing enrollment process which has taken longer than usual, but not due to lack of effort by the facility, simply issues with school district in regards to C1’s educational needs and behavioral issues. While a witness maintains this was the case initially, the facility has now been able to enroll C1 into school. S1 denies all allegations related to S1 and C1. While another witness maintains the allegations are true, several witnesses deny ever observing these allegations occur. Based on interviews conducted, the allegations that S1 denied C1 access to phone book, S1 yells at C1 while in care, S1 makes inappropriate comments towards C1, S1 refused to make food for C1 while in

care, S1 threatened C1 while in care, staff deny C1 access to activities while in care, and C1 is not enrolled into school while in care may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights, were provided to FM for original signature. Report will be put into facility file.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers & Licensing Program Analyst Veronica Whitaker conducted a case management inspection November 8, 2022, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 11/08/22). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Veronica Whitaker observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Carolyn Ruffin, Administrator.

On November 18, 2022, at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar conducted an annual inspection at Pennacle Foundation Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Facility Manager (FM) William Zachary and . The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were four staff and three clients present during the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection, through the time of the inspection. LPA conducted the physical inspection about 2:50 PM. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were four staff and three clients present during the time of the inspection. LPA inspected the facility inside and out with FM. LPA inspected the physical plant and reviewed operational requirements, core therapeutic services, and disaster preparedness. The facility consists of three bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility has a dining area, kitchen area, and living room/common area that also houses the makeshift staff office. The facility also has an attached garage where the washer and dryer are located. This garage is also used as another staff office area as well as a food storage area. The facility does not have an approved mental health program, therefore, counseling and therapy is currently being provided off site for clients. Another staff office area is also located in the open common area adjacent to the main living room. All bedrooms have two individual twin beds and adequate drawer space for each client; two clients have their own rooms and two clients share one room. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space for the clients. Books, board games, movies, a TV, and video game system, were observed for client’s recreation time, as well as a basketball hoop in backyard.

Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required postings were available at time of inspection, including Personal Rights and Grievance Policy. Facility has fire clearance, however, no copy was available for review at time of inspection. The licensee is being assessed a technical violation under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 80020(a): Fire Clearance. Additionally, the facility does not have provision of emergency power, such as a back up generator. The licensee is being cited under Health and Safety code section 1565: Task Force on Accreditation of Services for Children. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked file cabinet in the living room staff area. The hot water in the restroom was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of the license. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a lower hallway cabinet. Sharp objects are locked and stored in the locked file cabinet in the garage staff area, as well as the complete First Aid Kits and First Aid manual. Client records are stored in a locked file cabinet the makeshift staff area within the common area living room. The staff records are located in a locked cabinet within the office area in the garage. LPAs reviewed the facility personnel report summary and all staff are currently associated to facility. Facility has not yet obtained Mental Health Certification, however, are in process of completing and submitting the application. Facility has obtained national accreditation through CARF, which is valid until March 31, 2025. All facility licensing fees are current. Board minutes were unavailable for review at time of inspection, facility is being assessed a technical advisory under ILS section 87063: Accountability. LPA was unable to complete the client and staff file reviews due to time constraints and technical difficulties. LPA Escobar will return to complete staff and client file reviews and interviews at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to FM, Mr. William Zachary.

On December 20, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at the facility to continue the the Annual Inspection which was started on November 18, 2022. LPA Escobar reviewed staff files and interviewed staff and clients. Due to time constraints and technical difficulties, LPA will have to return at a later date to conclude the annual inspection. LPA conducted an exit interview with Administrator and provided them a copy of the signed report.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Medication log for months of Sept & Oct 2022 were reviewed by LPA and observed to have explanation for missed medication missing as well as staff initials missing. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide retraining for staff on how to properly record information on medication logs. Proof of retraining will be provided to LPA Escobar via email.

narrative:
On March 9, 2023, at 1:00 pm, a virtual informal conference was held with Pennacle Foundation Inc. Short-Term Residential Program (STRTP) via the Microsoft Teams platform to discuss current licensing concerns. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Lopez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith and Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook met with Facility CEO Lawrence Thomas and Administrator Carolyn Ruffin. The following individuals were additional participants in the virtually informal conference: Melissa Graham, San Bernardino Department of Behavioral Health (DBH) Program Specialist II, Angela Sellitti, Associate Governmental Program Analyst, California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Systems of Care Branch, Hong Luu, CDSS System of Care Branch, Health Program Specialist I, Alicia Bernstein, Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager, System of Care Branch, Amy Mierzwik from San Bernardino Children and Family Services (CFS), Jenell Ross, Riverside County – Administrative Analyst, Timothy Nugent, Social Worker Supervisor, Humboldt County, Karin Atkins Riverside County Children’s Out of Home Investigations/Placement, Dr. Kelsie Tatum Martinez, Senior Clinical Advisor at the CA Alliance/Catalyst Center, David Gutierrez Staff Service Manager I, Department of Health Care Services, Nancy Satterwhite, Deputy Director San Bernardino County CFS, Tracy Raymond, CFS Manager. The following information was discussed: Waiver of Time ordered by Governor Executive Order N-04-22 issued 06/14/2022. Expiration of Waiver of Time 06/30/2023 Lack of a County Mental Health (MH) Contract. Lack of Medi- Cal certification. Lack of Mental Health Program Approval through the Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) (Continued on page 2...)

Licensee’s plan to complete the Mental Health Program Approval (MHPA) process. During the meeting, LPM Smith stated the meeting was to follow up on the facility status in obtaining Mental Health Program Approval through the Department of Health Care Services. LPM Smith reminded the STRTP CEO Mr. Thomas that the STRTP provisional expiration date and expiration of Waiver of Time is June 30, 2023. RM Cook inquired about the facility’s plan in case the STRTP is not able to have a mental health contract with a county prior to the license expiration date. RM Cook inquired as to whether the facility had a plan to operate a different facility type. RM Cook stated that in addition to obtaining the mental health county contract, the facility would also have to get Medi-Cal certification, which is part of the Mental Health Program Approval process. RM Cook stated the process can take several months to complete. CEO Mr. Thomas explained that Pennacle Foundation Inc. has not yet received a Mental Health contract with Fresno or through San Bernardino County and missed the deadline to apply which was on 03/06/2023. Mr. Thomas stated that Pennacle Foundation Inc. is currently considering an option of merging with another STRTP in Riverside County. Mr. Thomas stated that there are not enough details available on specific information regarding how the merger will occur due to the different questions involved but is looking into developing a plan that can be executed within the amount of time available (prior to 6/30/2023). Mr. Thomas mentioned that it is not yet clear if Pennacle Foundation Inc. will remain a facility running under another facility or if it will cease to exist. Mr. Thomas stated that Pennacle Foundation Inc. will not be able to obtain MHPA approval within the restraints available (by 6/30/2023). Administrator Ms. Ruffin stated another option would be for Pennacle Foundation Inc. to provide vendorized services to clients through Inland Regional Center and change the facility type to a group home. Ms. Ruffin mentioned that there has not yet been any formal discussion regarding this option, but it is being considered as a possible alternative as well. RM Cook requested that Pennacle Foundation Inc. submit a closure plan by 03/20/2023 clearly indicating the next steps that will be taken to implement the facilities plan for merger or closure. Catalyst Center Clinical Advisor Tatum will connect with Pennacle Foundation Inc. via email. CEO Mr. Thomas requested Ms. Tatum’s email which is located below. (Continued on page 3...)

RM Cook informed the CEO and Facility Administrator that the Department will be in close contact with them during the remainder of the Waiver of Time. The following contact information is being provided: 1. The Catalyst Center: Kelsie Tatum Martinez kmartinez@catalyst-center.org A copy of this report was emailed to CEO Lawrence Thomas for electronical signature. The signed report will be placed in facility file.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan on March 13, 2023 at 10 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Barragan met with Watishi Turner, House Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 3 of child’s records and 2 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 3 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 0 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. There are 7 cameras inside the house, 2 cameras inside the garage, and 6 cameras on the outside. During the inspection the LPA observed two deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Watishi Turner, House Manager

On October 27, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff mishandled a minor while in care. Regarding the allegation that LFM mishandled C1 while in care, a confidential interview stated that C1 was held by LFM to prevent C1 from hurting self and others. Confidential interview continued stating that during the incident LFM embraced C1 by placing both arms around C1. Confidential interview stated that law enforcement arrived to respond to C1’s behaviors and spoke to C1 and LFM about the incident. LPA Urena obtained a 24-hour notice and a Law Enforcement Report dated 10/26/22 that states “C1 was moving so aggressively that LFM laid on C1 for approximately two minutes while trying to calm the client and de-escalate the situation”. Another confidential interview stated that clients have expressed concerns about being mishandled by staff while in care but denied that staff were intentionally mistreating clients in care and added that staff are trained on how to respond to emergency situations. It was discovered that during the process of responding to C1’s behaviors LFM did use a one-person restraint as a method of de-escalation. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that LFM mishandled C1 while in care, is supported and proven by evidence. The facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) version four Section 87072(c)(11) PERSONAL RIGHTS. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, along with LIC 809 D, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and will be emailed to Pennacle Foundation Inc. STRTP Administrator Carolyn Ruffin.

In regard to the allegation that LFM choked C1 while in care, A confidential interview denied that LFM choked C1 rather LFM was responding to C1 breaking windows at the facility resulting in no injury to C1’s neck. Another confidential interview stated that staff only place hands-on clients as a last resort and for safety purposes only. Confidential interview denied that staff maltreat clients in care. Other confidential interviews denied witnessing LFM choking C1 while in care. Another confidential interview stated that C1 did not report concerns to CSW about staff maltreatment at the facility. Confidential interview further reported that CSW did not have concerns about the placement. C1 could not be reached for comment. LPA received inconsistent information about whether or not LFM choked C1 while in care. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that LFM choked C1 while in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Administrator Carolyn Ruffin.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(11) PERSONAL RIGHTS.  

(c)The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, and a 24 hour incident report, and a Law Enforcement report both dated 10/26/22. LFM mishandled C1 while in care by using a one-person restraint and laying on C1 as a form of de-escalation method which poses an immediate Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator stated that Administrator will conduct Pro-Act retraining with staff and will provide LPA with copies of the retraining by May 19, 2023.

narrative: On November 17, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff choked a minor while in care, staff handled minor in an inappropriate manner, and that minor engaged in a physical altercation with another minor while in care. Regarding the allegations that staff choked C1 while in care and that staff mishandled C1 while in care, confidential interviews denied that staff choked and mishandled C1 while in care. Confidential interviews further stated that staff do intervene during client-on-client physical altercations but deny client mistreatment during the process. Other confidential interviews stated that C1 wanted to go back to county of origin and expressed to staff that C1 would inform school staff the C1 did not feel safe at current placement. Another confidential interview declined to provide any comments due to C1’s short stay at the facility, and C1 could not be reached for an interview. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegations. Regarding the allegation that C1 engaged in a physical altercation with another client, a confidential interview stated that there was a fight that resulted in C1 being body slammed by another client in care. Confidential interview continued stating not being sure what occurred but maintained that C1 wanted to return to county of origin and was willing to make false allegations to get relocated. Other confidential interviews denied witnessing an altercation between C1 and another client. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that staff choked C1 while in care, staff handled C1 in an inappropriate manner, and that C1 engaged in a physical altercation with another minor while in care, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, along with LIC 809 D, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and will be emailed to Pennacle Foundation Inc. STRTP Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary

On April 11, 2022, LPA Urena continued with the investigation at the STRTP and continued an interview with a Lead Facility Manager (LFM). In addition, LPA Urena conducted interviews Administrator (ADM) and four staff members (S1, S2, S3, S4). LPA attempted to interview two clients (C2, C3) however, both clients declined to be interviewed. Client #1 (C1) could not be reached for an interview due to an absence without leave (AWOL) status. Additionally, LPA interviewed a County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative: On November 29, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff did not prevent minor from physically assaulting other minor while in care, and that staff do not provide a safe environment for minor(s) in care. During investigation, confidential interviews revealed that an altercation between C1 and C2 did occur while in care and it resulted in C1 obtaining medical care for an injury. Confidential interviews denied that the altercation was a result of lack of supervision and added that C2’s behaviors against C1 were unexpected. Another confidential interview stated that C1 did not feel safe while in care and that other altercations between C1 and C2 occurred in the past. Confidential interview continued stating that C1 was not provided with medical attention for the injury sustained and that C1 was hurt often while in care. Confidential interviews stated that C1 was involved in multiple fights with other clients in care with the hopes of being removed from placement. Confidential interviews continued stating that staff respond to altercations among clients by separating clients and that staff ensure the safety of all clients in placement daily. C2, CSW and CSW’s Supervisor could not be reached for comment regarding the above allegations. LPA received inconsistent information about whether or not staff prevented C2 from physically assaulting C1 while in care or if staff were providing a safe environment for C1 while in care. There were no other known witnesses to the allegations. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that staff did not prevent C2 from physically assaulting C1 while in care, and that staff do not provide a safe environment for C1 in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary.

narrative: On November 18, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff choked minor while in care, and that staff handled minor in an inappropriate manner. During investigation, a confidential interview stated that S1 hurt C1 while in care. Confidential interview stated that on one occasion S1 used S1’s foot and placed it on C1’s head to hold C1 down. Confidential interview stated that other staff and clients were present during this incident, however confidential interview could not identify the names of staff or clients who witnessed the incident. Other confidential interviews denied that S1 choked C1 or inappropriately handled C1 while in care. Confidential interviews stated that it was difficult for C1 to communicate with peers and with staff while in care which resulted in C1’s aggressive acts towards self and others. Confidential interviews stated that C1 wanted to go back to county of origin and C1 was going to do what C1 could do to be removed from the facility. Confidential interviews maintained that C1 was not choked or mishandled while in care and added that C1 provided false statements with the purpose of being relocated. LPA received inconsistent information about whether or not C1 was choked or handled inappropriately by S1 while in care. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that S1 choked C1 while in care, and that S1 handled C1 in an inappropriate manner, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary.

narrative: On November 29, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff provided supervision to minor(s) in care while under the influence and that staff yelled at minors while in care. It was reported to CCL that S1 and S2 appeared to be under the influence and yelling at clients at a holiday event that resulted in C1 expressing feeling unsafe. During investigation, a confidential interview further stated that C1 was transported back to the facility by someone else other than S1 and S2 due to C1’s safety concerns. Other confidential interviews denied that S1 and S2 were under the influence at the event and denied that S1 and S2 were yelling at clients rather it was clients yelling at each other and using profanity while inside the facility vehicle due to a fight for a front seat spot. Another confidential interview disclosed having no knowledge regarding the allegations nor being familiar with S1 or S2. LPA received inconsistent information about whether or not S1, S2 were under the influence or yelling at minors while in care and there were no other known witnesses. A CSW and a Supervisor could not be reached for comment. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that S1, S2 provided supervision to minor(s) in care while under the influence and that S1, S2 yelled at minors while in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. narrative: It was reported that LFM threatened C1 while in care because of a situation involving C1, and neighbors that resulted in a facility vehicle being vandalized by the neighbors. Confidential interview stated that LFM made threats against the safety of C1 and C1 called law enforcement due to safety concerns. Another confidential interview denied aggressive acts towards C1 and stated that although a car was vandalized LFM did not make threats or mishandled C1 inappropriate manner. Confidential interview further stated that LFM chose not to become involved in a situation involving C1 and neighbors that resulted in C1 becoming upset and acting aggressive towards LFM. Another confidential interview denied witnessing LFM mishandling C1 while in care. Confidential interview further stated that clients have the ability to report all concerns or issues involving staff, however, nothing was reported. It was reported that C1 had a history of being untruthful and that C1 had behaviors that were difficult to manage while in care. LPA received inconsistent information about whether or not LFM handled C1 in an appropriate manner or if LFM threatened C1 while in care and there were no other known witnesses to the allegations. Additionally, a CSW could not be reached for comment. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that LFM handled C1 in an inappropriate manner, and that LFM threatened C1 in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary.
investigation_findings: 13On May 17, 2023, at 12:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena conducted an unannounced visit at Pennacle Foundation Inc., Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the finding of the above stated allegations. LPA was met by Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary. LPA Carmen Escobar conducted an inspection of the facility on December 13, 2022, at 3:10 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. LPA Urena conducted interviews with a Lead Facility Manager (LFM), Administrator (ADM), Facility Social Worker (FSW) and client #1 (C1). LPA attempted to interview two clients (C2, C3) however, both clients declined to be interviewed. Additionally, a County Social Worker (CSW) could not be reached after multiple attempts made by LPA Urena for an interview. On December 7, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff handled minor in an inappropriate manner, and that staff threatened minor in care.

narrative: Specifically, it was reported that C1 did not have access to the home and would wander the neighborhood. Regarding the allegation that staff do not ensure C1 has access into the home while in care, information gathered stated that C1 was not given access to the facility and would go around neighboring homes stating that they were locked out of the facility. Additional information detailed that C1 would have to wait for staff to return from picking up other clients in the home and would not have access to the home while waiting. Other confidential interviews denied that staff does not ensure that minors have access into the home and that staff is present to let clients into the facility. There were limited details as to what staff members did not allow C1 access into the home or when clients in care were denied access to the home while in care. Regarding the allegation that staff do not prevent minor from wandering while in care, confidential interviews confirmed that clients in care wander off without any staff supervision, specifically C1. Further details gathered from interviews stated that staff would take away or hide shoes from clients in care to prevent clients from wandering or being absent from care. Other confidential interviews denied that staff do not prevent minors from wandering while in care. Additional details gathered that some clients in care were allowed to go on walks that did not require staff supervision and would not return on time or would be absent from care. Confidential interviews detailed that some clients were chronically absent from care and would leave the facility but then come back. Staff was unable to force clients to stay in the facility to prevent being absent from care but would use other methods such as redirecting and encouraging clients to stay in the facility. Furthermore, when unable to prevent clients from being absent from care staff would contact law enforcement to report clients being absent from care. Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegations that staff do not ensure that minor has access into the home while in care and staff do not prevent minor from wandering while in care, may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and provided. A copy of this report along with, Confidential Names List, provided to Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary.
investigation_findings: 13On May 17, 2023 at 11:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena, met with Pennacle Foundation Inc., Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. LPA Carmen Escobar conducted an inspection of the facility on October 26, 2022, at approximately 11:50 am and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation included interviews with three staff (S1, S2, and S3), and three out of four clients (C1, C2, C3, C4). One of four clients declined to be interviewed. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On October 19, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging that staff do not ensure that minor has access into the home while in care and staff do not prevent minor from wandering while in care.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff do not prevent an inappropriate interaction between minors while in care, confidential interviews disclosed that staff did not prevent an inappropriate interaction between clients which resulted in an allegation of sexual abuse between clients (C1 and C2). Information gathered from confidential interviews stated that C1 indicated being inappropriately touched by another client in the home (C2). Other confidential interviews deny that there was any inappropriate interaction between clients. Information gathered from interviews stated that staff go over boundaries and respecting personal space with clients in care. Further information gathered revealed that when a client expressed that there was a possibility that they were inappropriately touched, staff sought medical attention for the client, reported the incident to law enforcement, and made proper room arrangements so that clients in care did not have to share a room with the alleged perpetrator. Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during this investigation, LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. The allegation staff do not prevent an inappropriate interaction between minors while in care, may have occurred, however it is not supported, or proven by evidence. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute these allegations; Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and provided. A copy of this report was provided to Lead Facility Manager, William Zachary.

narrative: An informal meeting was held with Pennacle Foundation Inc. Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) via the teams platform to discuss current Community Care Licensing (CCL) concerns. Present at the meeting was Lawrence Thomas - Cheif Executive Offer (CEO) of Pennacle Foundation Inc., Tracy Raymond - Manager for San Bernardino County Children and Family Services, Amy Mierzwik - San Bernardino County STRTP Coordinator, Derek Burns - County Social Worker (CSW) for Humboldt County, Michael Werder - CSW for Siskiyou County, Timothy Nugent - CSW Supervisor for Humboldt County, Nyron McLean - Cheif Financial Officer (CFO) for Plan-It Life, Sheila McLean - Director for Plan-It Life, Jennifer Smith - Licensing Program Manager and Erika Lopez - Licensing Program Analyst. The following information was discussed: Pennacle's closing date - 06/30/23. Sheila McLean will be submitting an application to CCL for Plan-It Life today to apply for an STRTP license for a facility at the address currently licensed as Pennacle. Discussion about how to transition clients and communication to Plan-It Life once the facility location is formally licensed under Plan-It Life. CEO, Lawrence Thomas, was advised the report (LIC809) will be provided via email for signature. Conference was concluded. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On January 31, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received complaints alleging that minor consumed alcohol and smoked marijuana on the premises, minor sustained injuries while in care, minor engaged in physical altercations while in care, and that staff did not intervene while minor was engaged in physical altercations. Regarding the allegations that C1 consumed alcohol and smoked marijuana on the premises, confidential interviews reported that C1 had a history of substance use prior to placement and was found in possession of drug paraphernalia on multiple occasions while in care. Confidential interviews further reported that it is unknown where C1 obtained marijuana or alcohol while in care but added that C1 left the facility without permission frequently. Confidential interviews reported that staff confiscated and discarded marijuana and other drug paraphernalia from C1 resulting in aggressive behaviors towards staff and ultimately C1’s termination from placement. LPA received reports to support that C1 was in possession of marijuana and other drug paraphernalia while in care. However, C1 could not be reached for comment regarding the allegation that C1 consumed alcohol and marijuana on the premises. Regarding the allegations that minor sustained injuries while in care, minor engaged in physical altercations while in care and that staff did not intervene while minor was engaged in physical altercations, SI Jackson received information that C1 was involved in an incident resulting in injuries. It was reported that during an outing with staff and peers C1 required medical attention due to an incident resulting in a face injury from playing with another youth in care. It was further reported that during this incident staff were present and provided C1 with the medical attention and follow-up care needed. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 engaged in multiple fights with peers where C1 was the aggressor. Confidential interviews further reported that C1 had ongoing aggressive behaviors that resulted in altercations with peers, but maintained that staff intervened during these altercations and on some occasions, resulting in law enforcement contacts. The Department received inconsistent information regarding lack of supervision by staff. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that C1 consumed alcohol and smoked marijuana on the premises, C1 sustained injuries while in care, C1 engaged in physical altercations while in care, and that staff did not intervene while C1 was engaged in physical altercations, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time.

Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was emailed to CEO Lawrence Thomas. Copies of the original signatures will be placed with the complaint file.
investigation_findings: 13On November 2, 2023, at 4:16 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena met with Pennacle Foundation Short Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Lawrence Thomas to deliver the investigative findings for the above stated allegations. This facility was closed effective July of 2023 and this visit took place virtually. On February 1, 2023, at 2:38 PM, LPA Daniel Mena initiated the investigation at the facility and collected pertinent documents from the STRTP program staff and client files. A health and safety inspection was conducted, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. LPA Mena informed the facility that Special Investigator (SI) Charlotte Jackson would be leading the investigation. Interviews were conducted with a witness, a County Social Worker (CSW), two staff members (S1, S2), and a client (C2). SI Jackson and LPA Urena made multiple attempts to interview Client #1 (C1) however no additional information could be obtained due to C1’s unknown whereabouts. Additionally, SI Jackson reviewed a police report, and other pertinent reports involving C1 to assist with the investigation process.

narrative: Specifically, it was reported that S1 did not allow C1 to step outside of the facility to say goodbye to another staff as it was their last day of working at the facility and told C1 that C1 would be reported as leaving the facility without permission if they stepped outside of the facility. C1 walked out the front door and S1 proceeded to lock C1 outside of the facility and did not allow entry from the door. Confidential interviews confirmed that C1 stepped outside of the facility and S1 told C1 that C1 could not come back into the facility unless properly searched and locked the door. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations that S1 did not provide trauma informed interventions and S1 did not allow C1 in care to return to facility are substantiated. The STRTP is being cited for violations of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), version 5, section 87072(c)(32) for Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to Lawrence Thomas, CEO.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/28/24 at 06:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo emailed Lawrence Thomas, CEO, to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations at Pennacle Foundation, Inc. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). On 06/21/2023, LPA Erika Lopez and LPA Jason Dalton inspected the facility’s physical plant, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with one staff (S1), Facility Manager (FM), two Clients (C1, C2) and County Social Worker. On June 20, 2023, Community Care Licensing received allegations stating that staff (S1) did not provide trauma informed interventions and staff (S1) did not allow youth (C1) in care to return to facility. (continued on LIC 9099c)

deficiencies.description:
(c)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights... 
(32)	To have placement that utilizes trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, the S1 was not allowing C1 to say goodbye to SX for the last time and locked C1 out of the facility which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility is closed and is no longer providing services to minors.

narrative: On September 4, 2020 at 10:20 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) JoAunne’ Griffin initiated a Case Management - Incident investigation at the facility and met with Daisy Hernandez, Residential Counselor. The purpose of this inspection was to inform Licensee of investigation currently ongoing regarding personal rights allegation concerning Child #1. This case has been referred to Community Care Licensing, Investigations Branch, assigned to Investigator, Lorraine Patterson. During this visit, LPA requested Child #1, #2, #3 and #4 Needs and Service Plan, Placement Agreement, Child and Family Team (CFT) Planning Matrix, medical documentation, client roster and Personnel Schedule (LIC 500). LPA Griffin requested that the information be emailed to JoAunne.Griffin@dss.ca.gov. Due to limited information at this time, the allegation requires further investigation in order to resolve the complaint. A copy of this report will be emailed to Luis Diaz, Supervisor at LDiaz@pennylane.org.

On September 30, 2020 @ 10:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Tele-Inspection for the above facility. The purpose of inspection was to conduct an Annual Random Inspection on the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility. LPA met with Facility Manager during the inspection. The staff and LPA toured the facility both inside and out. This is a one story home, located in a residential area. The Facility was set as follow: 4 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, Living room/family area, dining room, kitchen and dining area. One of the bedroom is used as an office space. No dogs in the home. All three client bedrooms were observed to be equipped with two twin size beds, drawer, dresser space and lighting was adequate in each bedroom. The home was inspected and the following was observed: WALK THROUGH The facility did not have any firearms/dangerous weapons. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passage ways, stairways, inclines ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants/poisons are inaccessible. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Medications are locked and accessible only to employees supervising store medications. Facility posts child’s rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more children. RECORD REVIEW Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Excluded persons are not on premises. Adults working/residing in the facility have Child Abuse Index Checks. Adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. ------->

Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. Facility records client cash resources, personal property, and valuables. Facility personnel meet staff qualification requirements. Facility personnel meet staff training requirements. Licensee has a current needs and services plan for each resident on file. Child’s records contain original needs and services plan signed by the child and their authorized rep. Child’s records contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child’s authorized rep. LPA reviewed 3-children’s records during this visit. Staff records are not on site and will be reviewed on later date. INTERVIEWS Children are allowed to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Children can contact CCL or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment. The facility has a Toyota Sienna passenger van to transport clients. Current automobile insurance is with Non Profit Insurance Alliance Group Ins. Co. Policy # 06762NPO. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 1, there were no deficiencies noted or cited during this inspection. Exit Interview was conducted with the facility representative, a copy of this report was emailed to facility.

Regarding allegation 3) Both staff and clients admit to WIFI use being disconnected during bedtime hours or for discipline. However, LPA Landry did not find WIFI control and interruptions effected the scholastic or education abilities of the clients in care. Also, it was reported if WIFI is overloaded it may have effected and slowed down signal for users. Clients are allowed to use landline if needed. At this time LPA Landry has not observed any evidence of Personal Rights abuse pertaining to WIFI usage. Regarding allegation #4) LPA Landry was not able to locate and or corroborate any witness who observed staff licking their hands and spreading their saliva to create unsanitary conditions for clients in care. The four allegations listed above are unsubstantiated. “Unsubstantiated” means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview conducted. Copy of this report and Appeal Rights were emailed to facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On April 06, 2021 @ 3:30PM LPA Kathy Landry spoke with facility representative and conducted a Tele-Inspection to deliver findings for complaint received 06/10/20. This investigation initially began on 6/16/20 and since then more information has been received. There were four clients currently residing in the home. Some staff and some former clients were interviewed for this investigation. LPA Landry was not able to locate and interview former client #2. Regarding allegation 1) Based on interviews clients are allowed to cook as it is part of their Life Skills Training. However, it was reported by some staff and some former clients cooking on the kitchen stove shuts down after dinner near 8PM and the microwave was available for use. LPA Landry was not able to corroborate that nothing was available to eat or that youths could not cook some foods in the microwave after dinner hours. Per staff, stove hours were shut down after dinner hours for better supervision and to discourage use of clients lighting illegal drugs. Regarding allegation 2) LPA Landry was not able to corroborate and locate any witness who saw or heard staff speaking inappropriately, cussing or using derogatory racial slurs towards clients. ------>

deficiencies.description: 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds:The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews & record review the facility had bedbugs on or around 06/10/20.  These bedbugs were located in at least one client's bedroom.  This was an immediate Health & Safety risk to clients.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager the bed bug problem has been corrected and cured.  However, LPA Landry is requesting a Written Plan of Correction exhibiting Facility's understanding of this regulation.  LPA Landry is also requesting receipts showing treatment for bedbugs during this and or nearby time frames.  Plan of Correction can be mailed to address listed above or faxed to (818) 596-4376.

investigation_findings: 13On Tuesday October 19, 2021 @ 3:30PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Tele-Inspection regarding complaint allegation listed above. LPA Landry spoke with Facility Representative listed above. This investigation initially began 09/07/2021, since then more information has been received. On or around May 30, 2020, child #1 was outside of the facility while two other clients (child 2 and 3) were inside of facility with staff #2. While staff #3 prepared medication in the detached garage/office area staff #2 was designated to supervise these three clients. Staff #2 was inside the facility maintaining visual supervision of clients 2 and 3 while sitting near the front door looking/ listening for child #1, who was outside in the adjacent frontyard driveway playing basketball. It is unclear how much time passed when staff #2 conducted a routine head check and child #1 was not located. Runaway Procedures were executed. A Missing Persons Report was filed and pertinent parties notified. Child #1 never returned to the facility. Based on LPA Landry's observation and interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the above allegation is found to be

deficiencies.description: 80078(a)	Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews & record review on or around May 30, 2020 child #1 was not adequately supervised and was able to leave the facility at an unknown time without being observed and deterred by staff on duty.  Child #1 was observed missing after a routine head check and was not located.  This was an immediate Health & Safety risk to clients.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry is requesting a Written Plan of Correction regarding the understanding of this regulation.  Written POC can be mailed to address listed above or faxed to LPA Landry @ (818) 596-4376.  Written POC is due on or before 10/24/21 or Civil Penalties will be assessed.
