Facility will maintain records for client cash resources, personal property, and valuables. Facility personnel meet staff qualification requirements. Facility personnel meet staff training requirements. Licensee is required to have a current needs and services plan for each resident on file. Licensee was advised Child’s records must contain original needs and services plan signed by the child and their authorized rep. Licensee advised Child’s records must contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child’s authorized representative. There were no clients residing in this facility at this time. Therefore, no client interviews and no client record reviews conducted. Staff records are not on site and will be reviewed on later date. INTERVIEWS comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Children can contact CCL or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment. The facility has a Toyota Sienna 2019 passenger van to transport clients. Current automobile insurance is with Non Profit Insurance Alliance Group Ins. Co. Policy # 06762NPO. Per Facility Representative: children are allowed to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children live in a safe, healthy, PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1, there were no deficiencies noted nor cited during this inspection. Exit Interview was conducted with the facility representative, a copy of this report was emailed to facility.

On 11/04/2020, at 10:24 am, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela and Linda Haynes ,conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection, as a result of COVID-19 related restrictions. On 01/11/2019, the facility listed above submitted an application to transition the currently licensed group home facility to a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The application, application documents, Plan of Operation and Program Statement have been reviewed by Community Care Licensing (CCL) LPA Lorena Valenzuela and Continuum of Care (CCR) Policy Analyst Patrice Coleman. The facility tele- inspection was conducted with the facility Administrator, Sterling Kirk. The home is a one-story residence with three bedrooms, one staff office, and three bathrooms. The tele- inspection included an observation of the following: 1. Yard is clean and free of debris or observable hazards. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials. 3. Chemicals stored in a locked cabinet inside the laundry room. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed inside the staff office stored in a locked closet inside a locked cabinet. 5. First aid kit complete, including manual was inside the staff office in a locked closet. 6. Adequate storage space was observed for linens and towels. 7. Individual beds in good repair, equipped with clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. (continued on page 2)

8. Facility has three client bedrooms, double occupancy. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings including closet space, drawer storage and a desk for each client. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable food items were observed. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating all clients. 12. Facility has two full client restrooms in this home and one staff restroom, all are operable. 13. Hot water measured within required range. Administrator Sterling Kirk measured the water temperature using a thermometer. 14. All smoke detectors tested and appear to be in proper working order. 15. Carbon monoxide detector was observed and tested. 16. Fire extinguishers properly charged. 17. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 18. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. 19. Sharps are stored in the staff office in a locked closet inside a container with a lock. 20. Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 21. Facility does not have any open bodies of water. 22. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed with Sterling Kirk and Denise Samano, Program Administrator, by LPA during the inspection: 1. LIC 500 reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. The facility does not utilize Peer Partners at this time. 2. Administrator Sterling Kirk will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Facility procedures for 30-day updates of Needs and Services Plans discussed. 4. Facility is to ensure all clients considered for future placement have been assessed and meet placement eligibility requirements. Facility has a process in place to contact authorized representatives to ensure assessment for clients’ continued placement. 5. Facility is to update all client admission agreements to reflect the STRTP rate. 6. Facility is to obtain Mental Health Program Approval (MHPA) within 12 months of effective date of the provisional licensure, will keep the department updated as to MHPA status, and will provide appropriate documentation to the department upon approval. (continued on page 3)

During the tele-inspection, LPA Lorena Valenzuela interviewed the facility Administrator and staff to ensure staff understanding of the STRTP program requirements. It was recommended by LPA that all line staff be trained on keeping confidentiality of a client's gender identity, expression and orientation; what the Emergency Intervention Plan is; purpose of Children and Family Team meetings; mandated reporter procedures and Reasonable Prudent Parent standards, prior to the STRTP conversion. In addition, during the tele-inspection LPA Valenzuela discussed with Administrator Sterling Kirk and Program Administrator Denise Samano the following revisions needed to the facility’s Plan of Operation (POO) and Program Statement (PS) submitted on 10/09/2020. Below the revisions requested is the facility's response to the requirement. Program Statement (PS) Section 4 - Core Services and Supports CCR Question: Does EVC have written agreements or contracts with external agencies? Such as Career Pathways. If so, please attach the agreement(s) with the final version of your PO/PS. Per ILS § 87022.1(b)(6) and ILS § 87078.1(b)(1-2) PS *The facility has some written agreements with external agencies and will submit those to CCL. and CCR. The facility will obtain written agreements for the external agencies for which they don’t have written agreements for. Section 11- Complaints and Grievances CCL Question: It is indicated if a complaint or grievance arises, there will be mediation between the involved staff and client. Will there be a neutral third party involved the mediation? (PS, page 38) *The facility will revise this section to reflect their complaint procedure which is to have client complaints or grievances reported directly to the administrator. Section 22 - Emergency Intervention Plan (Runaway Plan) CCL Review 10/19/20- Facility did not provide name and qualifications of Behavior Management Consultant who assisted in plan preparation (PS page 80, Article 10.3 ILS 87095.22, 87001(b)(1).) *The facility will revise the PS to include the name and qualifications of the above mentioned consultant. (continued on page 4)

Plan of Operation (POO) Section B - Administrative Organization 1. CCL Review 10/14/20-Missing- Staff Therapist qualifications regarding experience requirements. Facility provides the education requirements for Social work personnel per ILS, however, facility is missing the work experience requirements (POO page 11-12, ILS 87065 (c) (1) (C-F)) *The facility will review this section to ensure the work requirements for the social work personnel are included. Section E - Policies Regarding Child Abuse/Neglect Reporting CCL Review 10/14/20-Facility does not provide specific procedures and practices on how it will ensure the administrator does not impede or prohibit mandated reporting duties. (POO: page 40-41, ILS 87022 (b) (7) (A-C)) *The facility will revisit this section to ensure the administrator or other staff do not impede mandated reporting duties. -End of Revisions Requested- LPA Valenzuela advised the facility of the following steps. The facility agreed to the PS/POO revisions due date of 11/18/2020. The facility was advised to contact LPA Valenzuela or CCR Policy Analyst Coleman with any questions regarding the revisions requested. The facility was informed that failure to complete the agreed upon actions may result in denying the application to convert the facility to a STRTP. The facility was advised that the STRTP provisional licensure request will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. A copy of this report was emailed to Sterling Kirk for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

met_with: Sterking Kirk, Administrator and Denise Samano
narrative:
On 11/22/2021, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPAs) Lorena Valenzuela and Valerie Wilson arrived at Pinta Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP). LPA’s were met and granted access by Administrator Sterling Kirk. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 10:00 AM, Administrator Sterling Kirk, led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA’s Valenzuela and Wilson. Program Administrator Denise Samano was on the phone during the discussion of the report, citations and plan of corrections discussion. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s kitchen, bedrooms, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, bathroom/showers, and outdoor area. Facility outdoor grounds were not found to be clean and free of debris and observable hazards. LPA's observed debris in the outdoor area which included leaves and sticks. Based on interviews and observation, the facility dishwasher is not in good repair. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The outdoor space included a seating area with a playground area set up with a slide, swings and a monkey bar with rings. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods, a variety of snacks are available, and the menus were posted. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff office closet. Per the Administrator, Restroom #1 has a water leak in the shower/bathtub which has caused water damage to the adjacent wall which is a shared wall in Bedroom #2. In Bedroom #2, LPA’s observed a wet carpet with removed baseboards, which per Administrator were removed due to the water damage to the wall. Per Administrator the water leak in the shower had been repaired prior but the facility noticed there continued to be water leaking “2 days ago”. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility.

The facility has a dining area, kitchen area, living room, computer room, a clinician's office for therapeutic services, and a room where the washer and dryer are located. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. LPA Valenzuela reviewed the facility's Emergency Intervention monthly log and Emergency Disaster plan both of which included the necessary information and are current. LPA’s observed a living area with a computer, desk and chair, which is used by clients. LPA’s observed the chair to be worn, and with tape attached to the arm rest. LPA observed the living room area with a couch to have a torn upholstery. LPA’s also observed the fireplace harth to have two missing bricks. Chemicals and/or poisons, sharp objects/knives are locked in the staff office closet. First Aid Kit is stored in a locked closet in the staff office and contained all required supplies. LPA’s conducted interviews with Staff #1 (S1), Staff #2 (S2) and Administrator. LPA's conducted a review of board meeting minutes for 2020 and 2021. LPA’s observed that the facility does not provide children with locked containers with keys, for the purpose of storing contraceptives. Based on observations and interviews, the facility is not providing the locked containers for five of five clients. The facility is cited for violation of STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Section 87075(b) (1) (A) Health Related Services. LPA Wilson measured the hot water temperature in client Restroom #1 and the temperature measured to be over 125 degrees Fahrenheit, which is above the allowed temperature of 105 and 120 degrees F. Based on observation, the facility is cited for violation of Title 22, Section 80088 (e) (1) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies. LPA’s observed that five of five children in care share a bottle of lotion and do not have a lotion of their own. Based on interview and observations, the facility is being cited for not providing an individual lotion in order to maintain their basic personal hygiene practices. The facility is being cited for, STRTP ILS, Section 87088 (c) (3) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies.

LPA’s observed playground equipment with swings, slide, and climbing wall, however, the swings and climbing wall were not in good repair, the facility is being cited for Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Building and Grounds. In addition, LPA’s observed a monkey bar with circular bars to not be securely anchored to the ground, the facility is being cited for STRTP ILS, Section 87088.3 (a) Outdoor Activity Equipment. LPA also observed, the playground area was not cushioned with materials to absorb the fall from high areas of the outdoor equipment . The facility is cited under STRTP ILS, Section 87087.2(b) Outdoor Activity Space. LPA’s observed in Bedroom #2, there was water damage to the wall and carpet with two walls having portion of baseboards missing. The facility is cited for not ensuring a clean, safe and sanitary bedroom for clients in care, under Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. LPA’s observed in Bedroom #2 to have up to three punctures to the wall, the facility is being cited for not ensuring the walls in client bedroom are in good repair, under Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Building and Grounds. Based on observation and interview, Restroom #1 is out of order due to a water leak in the showerbath/tub, the facility is being cited for not ensuring the restroom is in good repair, under Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. LPA’s observed the couch to have ripped upholstery and not be in good repair, the facility is cited for Title 22, under Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. LPA’s observed the chimney harth to be missing two bricks and not be in good repair, the facility is cited for Title 22, under Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. LPA’s observed the facility has an outside basketball court with a cement floor area, however there was a 3 to 4 inch area hole in the cement area, the facility is cited under Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds, due to not ensuring the cement floor area is in good repair.

LPA’s observed the backyard patio awning to have two corners the two beams to have damage and not be in good repair. The facility is cited under Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. LPA’s observed the outlet in the computer room and an outlet in the backyard patio to not be in good repair, the facility is cited under Title 22, Section 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. LPA’s reviewed the board meeting minutes, and the minutes did not reflect the board’s discussion of the documents specified in the Health and Safety Code Section 1520.1 (f). The facility is cited for ILS STRTP, Section 87063 (a) (9) Accountability. The facility was given a technical assistance in regard to the facility vehicle and the outdoor area. Due to time constraints, LPA's will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 9102TA’s- Technical Assistance and appeal rights were provided to Administrator Sterling Kirk

met_with: Sterking Kirk, Administrator and Denise Samano
narrative:
On 11/23/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Lorena Valenzuela and Valerie Wilson arrived at Pinta Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on 11/22/2021. LPA’s already completed the physical inspection of the facility on the first day of the annual inspection. Program Administrator Denise Samano was on the phone during the discussion of the report, citations and plan of corrections. Licensee is in the process of obtaining their Mental Health Program Approval. The facility Program Administrator Denise Samano agrees to provide LPA Valenzuela on updates regarding their Mental Health Program Approval. Licensee is in the process of obtaining their National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF). The Accreditation is currently valid through 12/31/2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. During this annual inspection continuation, LPA’s reviewed eight personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 11/23/2021. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel files are retained at the main office located in Redlands, and will be available to the department for review upon request. LPA’s reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and work schedules to ensure appropriate staffing ratios. Administrator, Sterling Kirk is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff work schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection.

Based on staff records review, LPA’s observed staff records for five of eight staff (Staff #1 (S1), Staff #2 (S2), Staff #3 (S3), Staff #5 (S5), Staff #7 (S7)) had a job description, however, the job description was outdated and did not meet the STRTP regulation standards. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87066 (b) (1) Personnel Records. Based on staff records review, the annual training hours for seven of eight staff for 2020 were not completed including (Staff #1, Staff #2, Staff #3, Staff #4, Staff #5, Staff #6, Staff #7), the facility is being cited for violation of the STRTP ILS, Version 4.1, Section 87065.1 (d)(1) Training Requirements. LPA’s observed that the training hours for 2021, for 7 of 8 personnel files reviewed may not meet the training requirements, per STRTP (ILS) which states all direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training. Based on records review and interviews, Staff #1 and Staff #3 did not have a work performance evaluation for 2021. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87066 (b) (6) Personnel Records. Based on records review, eight of eight staff files do not have a statement signed by the employee that they are of at least 21 years of age. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87066 (c) (1) Personnel Records. Based on records review and interviews, the facility does not have an on call direct care staff that is capable of arriving to the facility within 30 minutes. The facility is being cited for violation of STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87065.5(a)(3) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. Based on records review and interviews, the facility did not have an employee training handbook maintained at the facility. The facility is being cited for violation of STRTP (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87065(l)(1) Personnel Requirements. In addition, LPA’s reviewed the employee handbook provided by the facility and the handbook did not contain the facility’s program mission, vision and values, disaster response procedures, law enforcement contact procedures, and reporting requirements as required by ILS.

Based on records review, Staff #1 did not have a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and first aid training card on file. The facility is being cited for violation of STRTP (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87065.1(c)(6)(A) Training Requirements. Based on records review and interviews, the facility did not have documentation of successful training maintained in all direct care staff personnel records reviewed. The facility is being cited for violation of STRTP (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87065.1(d)(7) Training Requirements. Based on records review and interviews, Staff #1 is the designated employee to develop, implement and evaluate the facility's activity program, however Staff #1 does not have the qualifications required to perform this duty per regulation standards. The facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4.1, Section 87066 (e) (1) Personnel Records. LPA's conducted interviews with one staff today and three staff on 11/22/2021. Staff were not able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's STRTP Program Statement, clients’ Needs and Services plan, and Trauma- Informed care. The facility was given an LIC 9102- Technical Assistance (TA) in regard to providing additional training to staff regarding the Program Statement/Plan of Operation, Needs and Services plans and Trauma Informed care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 9102-TA, LIC 809-d and appeal rights were provided to Administrator Sterling Kirk.

met_with: Sterking Kirk, Administrator and Denise Samano
narrative:
On November 30, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPAs) Lorena Valenzuela and Valerie Wilson, arrived at Pinta Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on November 22, 2021. LPAs already completed the physical inspection, staff records review of the facility on the first and second day of the annual inspection. The LPAs met with Facility Administrator, Sterling Kirk. Program Administrator Denise Samano was on the telephone for the report, citations and plan of corrections discussion. During this annual inspection continuation, LPAs reviewed five of five client files (Client 1- C1; Client 2- C2; Client 3- C3; Client 4- C4; Client 5-C5) to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Client files are maintained in the home and at the main office. There was four children present at the facility. LPAs conducted interviews with C2, C3, and C5. Client #1 (C1) refused to be interview. LPA's interviewed Head of Service Gregory B Johnson and based on interviews the facility is providing the children in care with Core Services and Supports. Based on the records review and interviews, LPAs observed they did not meet the regulation and requirements. LPA's observed for five of five clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, and C5) discipline policy is not written to reflect STRTP regulation, including the facilities Emergency Intervention Plan not matching the facilities current crisis intervention program. The facility is cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Section 87070(c)(2) Children’s Records. Based on records review, client's record for C1, C3, and C5 do not document Tuberculosis results within 72 hours of the test. The facility is being cited under Title 22, Division 6, Section 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessments.

Based on records review, client's cash record for five of five clients did not include income, disbursement, balance, and receipts maintained in chronological order. The facility is being cited under Title 22, Division 6, Section 80026(h)(1) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables. Based on interviews, allowance resources were taken in the form of fines. The facility will be cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4, Section 87026(c) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed documentation of bedroom arrangement compatibility for five of five clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, and C5) are not maintained in the child's record. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS, Version 4, Section 87087(e) Buildings and Grounds. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed the Needs and Services Plan did not include money management needs and or goals, including maximum amount of money permitted in the client's possession at any one time for five of five clients. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS, Version 4, Section 87068.2(b)(5) Needs and Services Plan. Based on the records review and interview, LPAs observed the Needs and Services Plan for five of five clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, and C5's) record did not include Needs and Services Plans updated at least every 30 days. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS, Version 4, Section 87068.3(a) Modifications to The Needs And Services Plan. Based on records review, the Medication Administration Record (MAR) for C1, indicated C1 had refused medications at least 26 times in a month period. The MAR did not include documentation regarding the reason for refusal, who was notified, and any observed results of the refusal. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS, Version 4, Section 87070(b)(12)(G)(1) Children’s Records.

Based on records review, five of five client records did not indicate the services to be provided by the facility in cooperation with community resources. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS Standards, Version 4, Section 87068.2(c)(2)(C) Needs and Services Plan. Based on records review, five of five client Needs and Services plan did not include information to include the placement agency’s case plan and services necessary to meet the child’s needs based on the case plan. The facility will be cited under STRTP ILS Standards, Version 4, Section 87068.2(c) Needs and Services Plan. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report LIC 809Ds, Appeal Rights, was provided to Administrator, Sterling Kirk.

narrative: On December 16, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela arrived at Pinta Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to conduct a Plan of Correction (POC) follow up visit to determine compliance with a plan of correction (POC) plan for the deficiency cited on 11/22/2021. Program Administrator Denise Samano was on the telephone during the review of the report. On 11/22/2021, the facility's hot water temperature in client Restroom #1 measured to be over the allowed temperature, measuring over 125 degrees Fahrenheit. On 12/16/2021, LPA Valenzuela measured the temperature in Restroom #1 and it measured to be over 130 degrees Fahrenheit. Based on observation , the POC plan where the facility was to maintain the hot water temperature to be between 105 and 120 degrees Fahrenheit was found to not be in compliance. Therefore, the facility is being cited under Title 22, Section 80088 (e) (1) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies. The facility is being fined a civil penalty due to repeating the same violation within 12 months. A copy of this report, LIC 809-d, LIC 421FC and appeal rights was provided and discussed with Administrator Sterling Kirk.

On December 16, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela arrived at Pinta Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Administrator Sterling Kirk to discuss information received during a review of an incident that occurred at the STRTP facility. Program Administrator Denise Samano was on the telephone during the review of the report. Records review and interviews, revealed the facility did not report a missed medication made on 09/26/2021 where Client #1 (C1) failed to receive C1’s morning dosage of a psychotropic medication. Based on records review an interview, the Department finds the facility did not comply with the reporting requirements. Facility is cited under Title 22, Division 6, Section 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. A signed copy of this report, the LIC 809-D, Appeal Rights, were provided to Administrator Sterling Kirk. In addition, the facility is advised in reviewing incident reports submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL), all required information is not being included in the incident reports. The facility is advised to review STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87061 Reporting Requirements.

On January 28, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Lorena Valenzuela met with Pinta Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Head of Service Gregory B. Johnson and Program Administrator Denise Samano and Executive Director Larnel Jackson on the phone. The purpose of this case management is to discuss information received during a review of facility documents and interviews conducted. LPA Valenzuela conducted a review of facility records on November and December 2021, as well as conducted interviews with witnesses. It was revealed that Administrative Staff # 1 (AS1) and Administrative Staff #2 (AS2) knowingly received fifteen First Aid and Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) cards for personnel without having the personnel complete the training required for the First Aid and CPR cards to be considered valid. In addition, AS1 and AS2 had personnel who work directly with children, continue to work at the facility without having a current and valid First Aid and CPR card on file. Based on records review and interviews, the Department has determined that the licensee did not ensure adequate oversight and accountability was provided to the STRTP program, to ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations. The facility is cited for violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Section 87063 (a)(11) Accountability. An exit interview was conducted where the citation and plan of correction was discussed with Gregory B Johnson and over telephone with Denise Samano and Larnel Jackson. A copy of this report, appeal rights were provided to Gregory B Johnson.

met_with: Larnel Jackson, Denise Samano, Gregory B Johnson, Francine Haynes, Sterling Kirk
narrative:
On February 17, 2022, an informal office tele-conference was held via Microsoft Teams video platform with representatives from East Valley CHARLEE Inc. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facilities, including representatives from Pinta Home, facility # 360906534 and Santa Maria Home, facility # 360906507. In attendance were: STRTP representatives Executive Director Larnel Jackson, Program Administrator Denise Samano, Administrator Francine Haynes, Administrator Sterling Kirk, and Head of Service Gregory B. Johnson. And from San Bernardino county Children and Family Services Amy Guisa. Also, in attendance from Community Care Licensing (CCL) were: Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager’s (LPM) Christina Barnes and Cheraki Davis and Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela and Valerie Wilson. The following was discussed with the facility: • Facility Oversight • Accountability • False information • Staff Training • Operational needs Regional Manager (RM) Cook stated the reason for the meeting were concerns regarding the Board of Directors lack of oversight and accountability. RM Cook stated, based on information received, it was found the facility issued fifteen First Aid and Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) cards for personnel without having the staff complete the entire certification process which included, video review and hands on compression training. (continued on page 2)

LPA Wilson stated that the CPR, First Aid vendor was contacted, who confirmed, that in order for the CPR First aid cards to be valid, the personnel would have to complete both an online video training and an in-person hands on training. Interviews conducted by LPA Wilson and Valenzuela revealed that 15 staff were issued cards without completing the hands-on training. LPA Valenzuela expressed concerns regarding the CPR First Aid training sign in sheets submitted to the Department and personnel who signed in as having completed the training which was later revealed that some personnel had not completed the training. RM Cook asked the facility to explain the process for training. Program Administrator (PA) Denise Samano stated the CPR training consisted of a video training, and hand on compression training with an instructor. PA Samano stated that she was responsible to ensure the CPR and First Aid training was conducted and completed. RM Cook asked who was responsible to verify the personnel who signed training sign in sheets attended the video and hands on training. PA Samano stated she was responsible for setting up the training and overseeing it was completed. PA Samano stated she did not follow up to see who had completed the compression training. PA Samano stated she oversaw who attended the video training, however it is possible that some personnel did not complete the video training in its entirety. PA stated there was at least one staff person signed in to have watched the video but left early and did not watch the video entirely. Executive Director (ED) Larnel Jackson stated there will be a plan to ensure CPR cards are kept current and that they will not let this occur again. He further stated, there is “no excuse” for not having the cards on file. PA stated that during the CPR training she was occupied with many tasks and duties. PA Samano stated that when an administrative employee had stopped working at the facility in July 2021, she took on the responsibilities of that staff person and repeatedly stated, “there was a lot going on”. San Bernardino representative Amy Guisa asked who was supporting PA Samano in her duties, as PA appeared to be overwhelmed. ED Jackson stated that PA Samano was doing her job and PA Samano kept him updated on everything regarding the facilities. ED stated that a Quality Improvement personnel left in July 2021, and after this date another personnel Ricky Chali, who is also the Child and Family Team (CFT) Facilitator and in charge of billing, is taking on the role and tasks of ensuring quality assurance/improvement. ED Jackson stated, he interviewed applicants for the quality improvement position however, he has not yet hired anyone for that role. RM Cook asked who trained Mr. Chali for the role in quality improvement? ED stated he had personally trained Mr. Chali. (continued on page 3)

RM expressed concerns for lack of accountability and lack of a plan to ensure compliance with licensing regulations. RM asked the facility how the facility will resolve these concerns. ED Jackson stated that he oversees PA Samano and stated that he thought everything was being done to ensure compliance. ED Jackson stated that during the COVID 19 pandemic he did not visit the facilities. ED Jackson stated that he trusted things were being done but “did not verify”. RM Cook stated that due to facility disseminating false documents to the Department the facility is being cited. Based on interview, document reviews, the facility is cited under STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 4, Section 87063 (a) Accountability. The Department is requesting a written Plan of Action detailing how the board of directors will ensure that oversight of program operations and internal controls are adequate and effective for the management of the short-term residential therapeutic program pertaining to: accountability, lack of oversight by Management, administrator duties, delineation of Management responsibilities, lack of staff supervision, staff training, continuous quality improvement policies, procedures, and practices, and how operational needs of the facility will be addressed on a continuous basis. The office conference also provided the opportunity for the STRTP representatives, CCL and county representative, Amy Guisa to discuss concerns regarding placement and acceptance of youth into the STRTP. RM reminded the facility that they must demonstrate the willingness and capacity to assess and determine the appropriateness of placement within the program, consistent with the population to be served on an individualized basis for each child referred by the placing agency. At the conclusion of the conference, RM Cook thanked the facility representatives. A copy of this report, LIC 809-D was emailed to Executive Director Larnel Jackson for signature. Appeal rights were provided. Original signed report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: On 6/8/2022, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that clients are not receiving their allowances. Confidential interviews reported that clients had stolen other clients’ allowances. Confidential interviews reported that a client reported a staff member stealing their allowance. In addition, confidential interviews reported that an unknown client stole the allowance from C6. Other confidential interviews reported that staff had not stolen clients’ allowances. Confidential interviews reported that staff always provide the clients with the allowances that they are required to have. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff allows inappropriate touching between clients. Confidential interviews reported that staff does not allow hitting and inappropriate touching. Some confidential interviews reported that inappropriate touching was allowed by certain staff members and that this type of behavior was not corrected in a timely manner. Other confidential interviews reported that staff always redirected inappropriate physical behavior in a timely manner. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews during this investigation, the allegations that staff are allowing inappropriate touching between clients and clients are not receiving their allowances may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time.

narrative:
On 11/07/22 at 8:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo arrived at Pinta Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP). LPA Lo was met and granted access by Direct Care Staff, Tiana Van. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 8:40, Direct Care Staff, Tiana Van, led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Lo and at 9:07am, Direct Care Staff, Selena Ponce and Administrator, Francine Haynes took over the physical inspection. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s kitchen, bedrooms, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, bathroom/showers, garage, therapy/storage room, staff office and outdoor area. Facility outdoor grounds was found to be clean and free of debris and hazards, the wired fence around the facility is in good repair. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The outdoor space included a seating area for arts and crafts. Basketball hoop, punching bag and soccer ball is available for children to play with. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods, a variety of snacks are available, and the menus were posted. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff office closet. Per the Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Continue on LIC 809C

At 9:15am, LPA observed the water temperature in Restroom #1 is not in compliance. The temperature was at 131.5-degree F. Per CCR 80088( e)(1) - (e) Faucets used by clients for personal care such as shaving and grooming shall deliver hot water. (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). Per the Administrator, Restroom #1 water temperature has been an issue since last year and the water heater was replaced. The hot water temperature flatulates throughout the day and staff monitors the temperature and documents in a log. The Administrator called the maintenance person, and the issue was fixed at 11:40am and currently reading at 112.2-degree F. At 10:04am, LPA observed Child #1 (C1) is missing medical assessment. Per CCR 80069(a) Except for licensees of ARFs, prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client, as specified in Section 80069(c), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the client. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. Per the Administrator, C1 was admitted on 09/28/22 but did not get the Medi-Cal card until 10/26/22. The staff acted diligently and called the medical office for a medical assessment; the earliest date for an exam is going to be on 11/11/22 @ 9:30am. LPA met with Administrator and completed the Operational Requirement, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing Records, Core/Therapeutic Services and Client with Special Health Care Needs and no deficiencies were noted. At 12:45pm, LPA conducted Staff interview with Staff #1 (S1) and Staff #2 (S2). At 1:50pm, LPA conducted Client interview with Client #2 (C2) and conducted Client interview with Client #1 (C1) at 2:20pm. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809D and appeal rights were provided to Administrator, Francine Haynes.

Confidential interviews reported that S1 told C1 to “shut the f up,” but that S1 did not call C1 the “b” word. Other confidential interviews reported that S1 did admit to telling C1 to “shut the f up.” Confidential interviews reported that S1 admitted to calling C1 the “b” word and telling C1 to “shut the f up.” Confidential interviews reported that C1 admitted to verbally disrespecting S1. Confidential interviews reported that S1 admitted they did not respond in a professional manner. There are corroborated statements that S1 did not communicate in a dignified way toward C1. Based on confidential interviews and S1’s own admission to the allegations, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegations that staff (S1) spoke inappropriately to a foster child (C1) and staff (S1) do not accorded dignity in their personal relationship with a foster child (C1) in care are substantiated at this time. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards Short-Term Residential Treatment Programs, Version 4, Personal Rights 87072(c)(10)(11). The facility did not ensure C1 was free from emotional abuse, humiliation, and intimidation. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the children in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Direct Care Staff LaTonya Brown. This report serves as an amendment to the LIC9099 report created on 03/21/2023.

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87072(c)(11): Personal Rights. (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of…emotional, or other abuse, and from…humiliation, intimidation, ridicule… mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature… This requirement is not met as evidenced by:
Based on confidential interviews and S1’s own admission to the allegations, the facility did not ensure that C1 was free from emotional abuse, humiliation, and intimidation. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A plan of correction that includes how Pinta Home STRTP will ensure all facility staff has ongoing training on the client’s personal rights to ensure each client is free from emotional abuse and intimidation. In addition, to include how this deficiency can be avoided in the future.

narrative: On 05/30/2023 at 12:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced case management inspection and met with Leonard Haynes, the Facility Manager (FM) of Pinta Home Short-Term Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP), to discuss the incident report dated 05/19/2023 regarding Client 1 (C1). On 05/22/2022, Community Care Licensing received an incident report from the STRTP Facility. Per the incident report, on 05/19/2023, the facility reported that staff #1 (S1) did not follow correct Pro-Act restraint guidelines according to the Facility's Emergency Intervention Plan when utilizing a restraint on C1. It was reported that S1 observed C1 with C1’s medication in their hand and that C1 was showing this medication to another client. It was reported that S1 instructed C1 to return the medication to S1, but that C1 refused and ran down the hallway, away from S1. S1 then called Staff 2 (S2) for assistance. It was reported that when S2 arrived to assist, C1 had their arms behind their back as S1 was trying to retrieve the medication. It was also reported that S1 had a hold of C1’s arm and was advised by S2 to let go of C1’s arm so that it would be easier to de-escalate C1. It was reported that Facility Manager (FM) and Administrator (AD) responded to the facility and assisted with de-escalating C1. FM advised LPA Choi that after S1 reported the incident details and admitted to grabbing and holding C1’s arm instead of waiting for S2 to assist, S1 was suspended from work for grabbing and holding C1’s arm. LPA was advised there was no video surveillance within the facility. Based on confidential interviews, a records review of facility documentation of the incident and the facility Emergency Intervention Plan, and an admission from S1 that they did utilize an improper use of a restraint on a client, the STRTP is being cited for violation of STRTP ILS, Personal Rights 87072(c)(11), To be free of physical...emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment,...infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature...This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the children in care. Exit interviews were conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given and explained to Facility Manager Leonard Haynes.

deficiencies.description: ILS 87072(c)(11) To be free of physical...emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment...infliction of pain, ...or other actions of a punitive nature...This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the children in care. Based on confidential interviews, records review of facility documentation of the incident, an admission from S1 that they used an improper restraint, and the facility Emergency Intervention Plan, the STRTP did not ensure C1 was free of physical, emotional, or other abuse while in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A plan of action that includes information on how East Valley Charlee Pinta Home STRTP will ensure all staff has ongoing training on trauma-informed based strategies for de-escalating clients and to ensure the facility staff adheres to their Emergency Intervention Plan / Pro-Act Guidelines.

narrative:
On November 19, 2020 at 1:00PM an Office Tele-Conference was held with representatives from Plan It Life Incorporated via Microsoft Teams video platform. In attendance were: Plan It Life representatives Chief Financial Officer Nyron McLean, Director Sheila McLean, Administrator Dana Taylor, and Administrator Joe Jones. Also in attendance were: Meghan Boyd, Karin Atkins, Sophia Williams, and Alain Dominique, representatives from Riverside County Department of Social Services; Rose Collins and Amy Guisa, representatives from San Bernardino County; Stephanie Hudak and Jennifer Smith, Licensing Program Managers (LPM); LaTonya Wilson, Ronnesha Fountain, and Linda Haynes, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA). The following issues were discussed: · Staffing Plan · Complaints · Personal Rights · Needs and Services Plan · Providing Documentation to the Department In regard to the staffing plan, LPM Hudak and LPA Wilson observed various staff changes within the past year. LPM Hudak inquired about proper training for new Administrator Joe Jones. Mrs. McLean explained that Administrator Jones has Administrator knowledge as he was previously employed as an Administrator at another facility. Administrator Jones has also received training provided by Mrs. McLean and Administrator Taylor. Concerns were also brought forth regarding the LIC 500 not reflecting the correct hours the Administrators are present at the facility. Mrs. McLean explained that additional issues may arise within the facilities requiring the Administrators to work outside of the schedule provided on the LIC 500, such as concerns related to COVID-19. Mrs. McLean also stated Administrator Richards is performing a dual role at the Banning facility as the Administrator and Facility Manager. The facility has also implemented Assistant

Facility Managers at each facility so that they can fulfill the facility manager role if needed. In regard to complaints and personal rights, LPM Hudak and LPM Wilson observed an increase in complaints within the past year across all four Plan It Life facilities. Multiple concerns regarding personal rights violations were discussed pertaining to staff speaking to the youth inappropriately, weekly allowance, clothing allowance, and telephone usage. Suggestions were provided such as allowing the youth to manage their own allowance money, providing more options for shopping, allowing unrestricted phone time when the youth are speaking to the Ombudsperson, Community Care Licensing (CCL), or Social Workers. Mrs. McLean mentioned that certain problematic staff are no longer employed with the corporation and additional training has been provided to staff regarding the concerns. In regard to Needs and Services Plans, it was discussed that during a recent complaint investigation, LPA Wilson observed multiple Needs and Services Plans for youth residing at the Temecula facility that had not been signed by the youth or County Social Worker. In addition, LPA observed that approximately one month prior, a separate LPA noted that multiple Needs and Services Plans were missing signatures from the youth. Mrs. McLean stated that there was some confusion regarding the various forms required from separate entities that govern the facility, however, steps have been taken to ensure all the care/treatment plans are updated and following guidelines. In regard to providing documentation to the Department, LPA Wilson voiced concerns of having to request documentation multiple times from facility staff before they are received pertaining to various complaints investigated within the past year. In addition, there are concerns that the youth’s Needs and Services Plans are not being kept at the facility site to allow CCL as well as facility staff immediate access to the files. Mrs. McLean stated that measures have been taken to include these records in the youth’s files. In regard to medication, concerns were discussed pertaining to medication documentation and records. Mrs. McLean stated the staff have received medication training and additional plan of corrections will be put in place to ensure staff are administering and documenting medication appropriately. Additionally, Administrator Jones stated the medication logs are now checked by the Administrator, Manager, and Assistant Manager weekly on separate days for the four Plan It Life facilities. There were no medication errors for the month of October 2020.

Strengths of the program discussed since the last office conference in September 2019: Plan It Life staff are meeting reporting requirements and the Corporation has taken steps to hire multiple Administrators. Mr. and Mrs. McLean have agreed to do the following in order to bring the facility into compliance and to ensure future compliance with Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards and to provide to CCL within 30 days: 1) Plan of Action detailing how the personal rights of the children will be protected. 2) Plan of Action detailing how staff will appropriately administer medication and maintain medication logs. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was provided. This report was emailed to Shelia McLean for signature. The original report will be placed in the facility file.

Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection 9/14/22 at 10am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated September 14, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Interim Administrator Sonchray Garrett,

narrative:
On 11/29/2022 at 09:08 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sarah Lo, conducted and unannounced annual inspection at Plan-It Life, Inc., Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met at the facility by Darla Alexander, Facility Manager (FM) and was granted entry into the facility for an annual inspection. FM stated the census is six and currently there are three out of six clients present. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 09:15 am and included the following checks: The facility was toured inside and out with FM. The home is a one-story residence with three bedrooms and three bathrooms. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. At 09:36 am, LPA Lo observed in Bedroom #1 with both dressers are not in good repair and a missing window screen. At 09:45 am, LPA Lo observed in Bedroom #2 with a flimsy and unsteady dresser that is not in good repair, missing a second dresser, and a missing window screen. At 09:55 am, LPA Lo observed in Bedroom #3 with a dresser not in good repair and is missing a second dresser. Per CCR 80088(b) All window screens shall be in good repair and be free of insects, dirt and other debris. Per ILS 87088(c)(4)(a) The licensee shall provide and make readily available to each child the following furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for personal care and maintenance of personal hygiene: Portable or permanent closets and drawer space in the child's bedroom to accommodate the child's clothing and personal belongings. A minimum of two drawers or eight cubic feet (.2264 cubic meters) of drawer space, whichever is greater, shall be provided for each child. The hot water in the client bathrooms are within the required temperature between 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Lo also observed all trashcans in the bedrooms and bathrooms did not have lids. Per CCR 8088(f)(1) Solid waste shall be stored, located and disposed of in a manner that will not transmit (continue on LIC 809-c)

communicable diseases or odors, create a nuisance, or provide a breeding place or food source for insects or rodents. All containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes shall have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers; shall be in good repair, shall be leakproof and rodent-proof. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Cleaning supplies and chemicals are locked and stored in a locked storage area in the hallway. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the staff office. The First Aid Kit is in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in all bedrooms were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detectors are linked with the facility smoke detectors and located in all bedrooms and throughout the facility were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by FM. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, and current menu. At 10:27 am, LPA Lo observed no covering around the fireplace located in the dining area. Per CCR 80088(c) Fireplaces and open-faced heaters shall be inaccessible to clients to ensure protection of the clients' safety. At 10:35 am, LPA Lo observed the facility outside grounds was messy with palm tree branches, bushes around the block walls of the swimming pool are not trimmed. Per CCR 80087(c) All outdoor and indoor passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, open porches, and other areas of potential hazard shall be kept free of obstruction. At 10:41 am, LPA Lo observed six holes ranging the size of a tennis ball to a size of a soccer ball along the house block walls. Per ILS 87087.2(a) Children shall have access to safe outdoor activity space. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is a swimming pool located at the rear of the facility, which is locked and inaccessible to clients. The pool is surrounded by a wrought iron fence measured over 5 feet tall with a gate that self-latches and opens outward. Due to time constraints, LPA Lo will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809c, LIC 809d along with the appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager, Darla Alexander.

On 12/06/2022 at 09:17 am, Licensing Program Analyst, Sarah Lo, arrived at Plan-It Life Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to complete an Annual Continuation. LPA Lo was greeted by Administrator Dana Taylor and was granted access to the facility. Administrator stated the current census is six and there are no firearm on facility. LPA Lo visited the facility on 11/29/2022 to complete inspection of the Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Core Therapeutic Services and Emergency Intervention Plan. At 09:31 am, LPA Lo began review of five staff files (S1-S5) assisted by Administrator Dana Taylor and Facility Manager Darla Alexander, who assisted with staff training files and assisted with this area of the inspection. At 10:39 am, LPA Lo observed through file review that S2 and S5 is missing Tuberculosis (TB) test result. Per CCR 80066(a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator, and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g) and CCR 80065(g)(1) Except as specified in (3) below, good physical health shall be verified by a health screening, including a test for tuberculosis, performed by or under the supervision of a physician not more than one year prior to or seven days after employment or licensure. At 11:08 am, LPA observed through file review that S2 and S5 is missing medical/physical clearance. Per CCR 80066(a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator, and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (10) A health screening as specified in Section 80065(g). (continue on LIC 809-c).

At 11:39 am, LPA Lo began review of five client files (C1-C5) assisted by Administrator Dana Taylor and Facility Manager Darla Alexander, who assisted with this area of the inspection. At 12:03 pm, LPA Lo observed through file review that C1 and C2 is missing the facility policies and procedures regarding the child’s removal and/or transfer is not signed by the client. Per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87070(c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. At 12:17 pm, LPA Lo observed through file review that C2 and C4 is missing the initial medical examination. Per California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 80069(a) Except for licensees of ARFs, prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client, as specified in Section 80069(c), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the client. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. At 12:35 pm, LPA observed through file review that C2 and C4 is missing the Tuberculosis (TB) test result. Per California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 80069(c) The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. At 01:26 pm, LPA Lo conducted two staff interviews (S1 and S2). At 02:32 pm, LPA Lo conducted two client interviews (C2 and C6). Deficiencies are being cited based on LPA observations and file reviews; see LIC809 D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were given to Administrator Dana Taylor.

Other confidential interviews revealed staff did not verbally abuse C1, however, it was reported staff was verbally abusive. Furthermore, confidential interviews revealed C1 was denied food and snacks and staff did not like C1. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that staff denied C1 food while in care may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager, Jermaine Manassa.

investigation_findings: 13On March 12, 2024, at 8:55 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera met with Plan It Life Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Manager Juan Denny to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations stated above. LPA Linda Hayes conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility on March 17, 2022, at 10:57 am, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with four children in placement (C1, C2, C3, and C4), and three staff (S1, S2, and S3) and a Facility Administrator were interviewed. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that minors (C1 and C2) in care are consuming marijuana and alcohol, and staff do not prevent harassment between minors (C2 and unnamed minors). Confidential interviews reported that C1 was called inappropriate names by the minors (specific names unknown), and no further information was provided. Confidential interviews reported that staff does intervene and will verbally redirect the minors who are making inappropriate comments. Confidential interviews reported that when a minor leaves the facility without permission and later returns to the facility, the minors has returned under the influence. Continued on page

narrative: Attempts were made by LPA Urena to interview C4, C5 however, clients declined to be interviewed and no additional information was obtained. On December 14, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff do not prevent the minors from having access to drugs, and that staff did not prevent a minor from fighting another minor. It was specifically reported to CCL that C1 has access to nicotine and marijuana in wax form and that C1 and other clients obtain these products out of care and use these products at the facility. It was also reported CCL that C1 was observed with a nose injury that was a result of a fight in care. During the investigation there was no corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Confidential interviews reported that C1 engages in drug use while not in care, away from the facility. Other confidential interviews stated that C1 has been in possession of drug paraphernalia in care, and that staff respond to the incidences by removing the items and following facility protocol. Other confidential interviews reported not observing C1 in possession of drugs in care but have observed C1 under the influence of a substance when returning to the facility. The statements received are inconsistent in determining if a violation of lack of supervision by facility staff is a result of C1 having access to drugs. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation and two clients refused to comment on the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent C1 from engaging in a fight with another minor in care. Confidential interviews provided inconsistent statements about whether the injury to C1’s nose was a result of a fight due to staff not intervening. Confidential interviews indicated that there was a nose injury due to a fight at the facility. Some confidential interviews reported that the injury was not due to a fight but rather due to a skin problem and was treated in care. Other confidential interviews stated that there was no injury observed on C1’s nose and that fights in care involving clients are stopped by staff in a timely manner. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegations that staff do not prevent the minors from having access to drugs, and that staff did not prevent C1 from fighting another minor, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Youth Care Counselor, Sharon Hancock.

narrative:
On 6/5/2024 at approximately 10:10 AM, LPAs Joon Choi and Maryjane Perez arrived at Plan-It Life, Inc. Corporate Office - 6235 River Crest Dr., Suite N, Riverside, CA 92507, and met with Administrator Dana Taylor (AD) and Youth Care Counselor (YC) Sharon Hancock, for the purposes of conducting an Annual Inspection for Plan-It Life STRTP (Banning) Facility #336408020. At 10:33 am, LPAs were assisted by YC for conducting four client file reviews At 11:15 am, LPAs were assisted by YC and Earl Richards Human Resources Staff (HR) for conducting five staff file reviews. Based on record reviews, one deficiency was cited during this visit and four Technical Advisories were provided: 1) Type B CCR 80066(a)(11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g). One staff file had an expired Tuberculosis test. Technical Advisories: 1) 87065.1(c) (c) The licensee shall maintain, and implement a written plan for the supervision, evaluation, and training of all direct care staff. 2) 87070(b)(12) (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: (12) Consent forms, completed by the child's authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care. 3) 87070(c)(2) (c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer, discipline, and complaints. 4) 87068.2(d) (d) The licensee shall ensure and document how the child, and their authorized representative(s), and the child and family team collaberated in the development of the needs and services plan, including in determining the date and location of the meeting.

An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeals rights was provided to Administrator Dana Taylor.

On June 6, 2024 at 08:43 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced annual inspection at PlanIt Life (Banning) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met by Administrator Dana Taylor (AD). The facility is situated in a residential neighborhood and is a 3 bedroom, 3 bathroom (2 bathrooms for clients, 1 for staff) - single story home with a living room, family room, dining room, kitchen, two car garage, and backyard with a patio and fenced swimming pool. There is a staff office and a separate therapist's office, with a staff restroom. The facility's two registered vehicles are parked in the drive way full-time and have the required current registration, valid/current insurance and first aid kits. LPAs observed the following postings located in the front entry way and common area: facility license, grievance procedures, Personal Rights, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, the contact information for the California Foster Care Ombudsman is on the Foster Youth Bill of Rights poster, visitation policies, and grievance procedures. LPAs began a physical plant inspection at 09:30 AM assisted by AD. LPA inspected the facility's kitchen, dining area, refrigerators, food storage areas, garage, living room, faimly room, staff office, therapy office, three client bedrooms (B1,B2,B3) and the backyard pool area. The client bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients are were assigned to a room, and there is one client per bed, there were individual dresser drawers and a shared closet. Each client room had the appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses are in good repair. Extra linens and client hygiene supplies are stored hallway closets . The living room had a couch with a coffee table and the family room had a functional television. The dining room had a dining table with enough chairs for all the clients and some staff. Cleaning supplies such as chemicals are kept locked in the staff office. Sharp utensils and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients and locked in the staff office. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPAs observed a minimum seven day non-perishable foods in the pantry and a two day perishable supply of food in the kitchen and garage refrigerators.

There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. Client records are kept in the staff office and their full client files are kept in the facility's corporate office. Per AD, there are no weapons or guns on facility grounds. The facility’s outside grounds (front yard, backyard and side areas) were also inspected and were found to be clean, well maintained, and free of observable hazards. The swimming pool had the required locked fencing surrounding the entire pool. The facility has an operable carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway near the staff office and additional smoke detectors are located throughout the facility including client's rooms. LPAs observed the facility had three fire extinguishers, with one located in the kitchen, one in the staff office and one in the garage. Each fire extinguisher was fully charged and inspected in October of 2023. The medications are centrally stored in the staff office, in a locked cabinet. The facility had a First Aid Kit in the staff office. The washer and dryer are located in an entry way before the garage and are accessible to clients with staff supervision. The laundry detergents are kept locked in a cabinet in the garage. The Kitchen had a fully stocked refrigerator, and the gas stove and dishwashing machine were operational. There were no cleaning supplies observed to be lying around unattended in the kitchen. The kitchen cabinets had plenty of pots, pans, plates and bowls for the clients to use. The hot water in the client bathroom measured 105.5 degrees Fahrenheit and was within the specified 105 to 120 degree range. LPA observed that each client's hygiene items such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, lotion, and deodorant were in their rooms. Facility also had an extra supply of hygiene and beauty items in case clients run out. The facility has two vehicles used to transport clients to appointments, schools and recreational activities. Each vehicle had no damage. The inside upholstery was intact for each vehicle. The brake lights and signals were operational. There was a fully stocked first aid kit in each vehicle as well as current registration and proof of insurance. At 10:36 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Operational Requirements. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 10:50 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Disaster Preparedness Requirements. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 11:10 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted.

At 11:20 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Core Therapeutic Services. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted. Based on observations and record reviews, no deficiencies were cited during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Dana Taylor.

Confidential interviews reported that the facility didn’t provide the incident to the authorized representative until this facility was approached regarding the incident. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff (S1) did not report incident involving minor (C1) in care as required may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation.
