narrative: On 7/30/2025 at approximately 1:35pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted an unannounced visit to Plan It Life Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) Riverside House. LPA met with Youth Care Counselor Yamka Mendez and explained the reason for the visit; that there might be an unauthorized staff member (S1) that has been allowed to work at this facility, prior to obtaining a full criminal background clearance. During the visit, LPA Choi obtained the facility's Guardian Employee Roster and email/forwarded it to Human Resources Administrator Earl Richards (HR). Per a brief phone interview with HR, it was concluded that S1's employment / start date at this facility was authorized in error. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03, Application Procedures: CCR 80019(e)(2): (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California Clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. A copy of this report (LIC 809), deficiencies page (LIC 809D) and appeals rigthts was provided to Yamka Mendez. This LIC 809 is an amended document to an LIC 809 created on 7/30/2025. LPA Joon Choi created this LIC 809 under the incorrect facility profile. Please refer to the correct facility Plan It Life 336407591 for this Case Management visit.

reported that it was not known when, if ever, the facility last offered internet access to the clients. Confidential interviews reported that the facility does not provide minors with wireless internet access when clients need the internet for schoolwork. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility does provide internet access for clients, but it is required per facility guidelines that the clients use the internet in the common area of the facility so that staff can properly supervise. Other confidential interviews reported that the clients want to use the facility internet in the privacy of their own room and often decline the facility’s offer for internet use in the common area of the facility. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility staff would take the clients to the library to use the internet when the clients want privacy. LPA received inconsistent information. In regard to the allegation that staff are not providing minors (C1-C6) with appropriate age activities, it was reported that C1-C6 would like outings that are age appropriate. It was further reported that the facility provided outings for the clients that are more suitable for minors. Confidential interviews reported that the facility does not provide recreational activities that are age appropriate or mature for their current clients’ age group. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility provides recreational activities that are agreed upon beforehand by the clients. Other confidential interviews reported that for the most part, the clients enjoy taking part in the outings offered by the facility, such as going to the arcade or amusement parks. Confidential interviews reported that during a health and safety inspection of the facility, the facility’s activities calendar was clearly posted. LPA received inconsistent information. Based on confidential interviews and document review, the allegations that staff are not providing the minors a form of communication while in care and staff are not providing minors with age appropriate activities may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager Sharon Hancock.

which were confiscated. Confidential witness statements further revealed that the razorblades were stolen from the staff office when staff’s back was turned. investigation_findings: 13On 11/4/2020 at 12:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Natasha Dunlap made telephone contact with Plan It Life Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Acting Facility Administrator Joe Jones to issue the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. Due to COVID 19 a tele-inspection was conducted on this date. On March 23, 2020, at 2:40 PM, LPA Nicole Roby conducted a safety inspection of the facility and observed no deficiencies. During the investigation, LPA Roby conducted interviews with Staff (S1, S2), clients (C1, C2, C3, C4) and three county social workers. LPA Roby also obtained weekly case notes, special incident reports, and needs and services plans from the STRTP and children’s files. On March 20, 2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information which alleged Facility staff do not keep hazardous items inaccessible to youths. It was reported to CCL that clients within the facility were in possession of razorblades that were obtained without permission from the staff office. Confidential interviews revealed C2 was in possession of razorblades on at least two occasions (continued on next page)

deficiencies.description:
80087(g) Buildings and Grounds. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, the C2 was able to obtain hazardous items on more than one occasion from staff office without permission which poses a health, safety and/or personal rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per FFA Administrator, a refresher training regarding buildings and grounds/keeping hazardous items inaccessible to clients in care will be conducted. Proof of training will be sent to LPA no later than 11/17/2020.

narrative:
are trained to document the medication records immediately after refusals or administering the medications to the foster youth. Staff further reported that there have been occurrences when staff did not document the medication record, and a sticky note was left to remind the staff to document the record the following day. On 9/17/20, LPA reviewed FC1’s Medication Administration Record and observed there had been no refusals documented for 9/16 or 9/17. LPA also observed that the medication logs had not been completed the morning of 9/17 for FC1, FC2, or FC3 and therefore, the medication count was off by at least one for all the youth. Additionally, a confidential witness reported to LPA that staff coordinated or attempted to coordinate hiding medication records during LPA’s visit at the facility, however, LPA was unable to verify this statement. On 9/8/20, CCL also received information that the foster youth’s allowance is being held in an allowance folder at the facility and that the allowance is being mismanaged by staff. Multiple confidential witnesses reported to LPA that the weekly allowance, ranging from $5-$7, has never been mismanaged or used by staff for any purpose. Confidential witnesses further reported that the allowance is kept in a binder for all the youth (FC1, FC2, FC3, FC4, FC5) and not given to the youth directly due to substance abuse issues. On 9/17/20, LPA counted the allowance and reviewed the allowance records. LPA did not observe any discrepancies with the amount of money the youth had. During additional record reviews, LPA observed that there were no signed confirmations from the County Social Workers allowing the facility to hold the youth’s allowance. LPA contacted the County Social Workers of two youth placed at the facility, who stated they were not aware that the allowance is being held by the facility and not given directly to the youth. Based on confidential interviews and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegations that staff failed to maintain appropriate documentation of prescribed medication and that the facility is holding the allowance for FC1, FC2, FC3, FC4, and FC5 are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Section 87070(b)(12) Children’s Records and Section 87072(d)(18) Personal Rights. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided. Note: Administrator provided authorization for staff Ebony Cherette to sign report.

CCL also received information that there are not enough towels and wash cloths for the foster youth and multiple staff tried collecting money in order to purchase additional towels for the facility. Multiple confidential witnesses reported to LPA that there are always clean towels and wash cloths available for the youth. However, other confidential witnesses reported that there are times when there are no clean towels and as a result the youth are unable to shower due to morning staff leaving the laundry for night staff. On 9/17/20, LPA observed six large towels in the closet and in the bedrooms. LPA was also informed that there were eleven large towels being dried in the dryer during LPA’s visit. On 9/30/20, LPA observed twenty large towels and twenty wash cloths. LPA was informed that staff recently purchased additional towels for the facility and discarded the older towels. Additionally, CCL received information that the food is expired at the facility and that the facility receives donated bread that is often molded. Confidential witnesses reported to LPA that there have not been any concerns about the food at the facility and that staff will check the expiration date of food items before it is distributed to the youth. Confidential witnesses also reported that staff will usually pick up donated bread and vegetables from a nearby church and will discard any expired foods. On 9/17/20, LPA observed two expired breads dated 6/28/20 and 9/13/20. Staff informed LPA that the breads are sometimes stored in the freezer and refrigerator for preservation. Lastly, CCL received information that the facility has two vehicles, Dodge Caravan and Hyundai Elantra, with bald tires, leaking fluid, and no air conditioning resulting in high temperatures inside of the vehicles around June 2020. S1 reported to LPA that both vehicles have a service alert system and the oils are changed regularly. Staff also reported that two new tires were placed on both vehicles recently and that the air conditioning was in disrepair inside of the Elantra Hyundai but was repaired immediately. Additional staff reported to LPA that bald tires were observed on the vehicles this year and were replaced right away. Staff further reported that the vehicles are inspected at the beginning of each shift and if any repairs are needed, a maintenance request should be submitted notifying facility managers of the repairs needed. On 9/17/20, LPA observed staff shift exchange logs which showed two separate notes from staff regarding tires needing to be replaced on the Hyundai Elantra in early June 2020. S1 informed LPA that there had not been any separate maintenance requests submitted to management in June or July 2020 regarding tires needing to be replaced. LPA reviewed additional documentation showing oil changes completed on both vehicles in early June 2020, air conditioning maintenance completed on the Hyundai Elantra in June 2020, and tires replaced on the Hyundai Elantra in July 2020 and on the Dodge Caravan in September 2020. Based on the documentation

provided to LPA, there was an approximate two-month period in between staff observing the bald tires and when the tires were actually replaced on the Hyundai vehicle, however, there were no vehicle maintenance requests submitted to management by staff in June or July 2020. Based on confidential interviews and records review, the allegations that foster youth smoke marijuana with S2 at the facility, youth are not provided with adequate towels and/or wash cloths, an adequate food supply is not being maintained at the facility, and facility vehicles are unsafe transporting youth, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided. Note: Administrator provided authorization for staff Ebony Cherette to sign report.
investigation_findings: 13On November 6, 2020 at 9:05AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), LaTonya Wilson, met with Plan It Life Staff, Ebony Cherette, to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. The investigation included a review of records for the facility and five of six foster youth. Interviews were conducted with two County Social Workers, eight staff, and five of six foster youth. LPA also conducted a safety inspection at the facility on 9/17/20 at 10:35AM and no immediate safety hazards were observed. On 9/8/20, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information that the medication records are not being maintained appropriately at the facility. CCL also received information that the medication count does not always align with what is written on the medication record. During confidential interviews, it was disclosed to LPA that FC1 has refused psychotropic medications for at least two months as FC1 does not like the side effects of the medication. Staff (S1) reported to LPA that the medications are administered and documented appropriately by staff. S1 also reported that FC1 had started refusing medications on 9/16/20. Additional staff reported to LPA that FC1 had been refusing medications since at least mid-August 2020 and that staff

deficiencies.description:
87070(b)(12) Children’s Records: The following information shall be maintained in the child's record: A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child showing the quantity of medication and number of refills prescribed; the date and time of each dose taken by the child.
This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records review, staff had not documented medication refusals or the administration of medication in a timely manner. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal right risk to the foster youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator stated all staff at the facility has recently completed additional medication training. Administrator will send proof of training to LPA.

deficiencies.description:
87072(d)(18) Personal Rights:

The licensee shall ensure that each child receives an allowance.

This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records review, facility staff holds the allowance for FC1, FC2, FC3, FC4, FC5 in a folder without authorization. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the foster youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator stated he will send LPA current proof of authorization to hold allowance for the youth and will release all allowance to the youth who the facility does not have authorizations for.

narrative: On September 8, 2021 at 10:57 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cindy Hamilton and Adelayci Caballero conducted an unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection. During the inspection, LPAs Hamilton and Caballero met with Katrina Vasquez, Facility Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed 1 out of 1 client psychotropic records at the facility site at 11:29 AM. During the review of client's record, LPAs observed Client #1's (C1) Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMARs) did not have the same prescription numbers as the medication labels on four out of four medications. Also, the PMAR lacked the specific time the psychotropic medications are administered to C1. LPA's also observed the facility was incorrectly documenting the PMAR when C1 refused C1's psychotropic medications. The facility did not follow the directions provided on page 1 or page 2 of the PMAR for documenting refusals. LPAs did not review staff personnel files due to files are maintained in the corporate office in RIverside, CA and will be reviewed at a later date. LPAs began one staff interviews at 11:14 AM LPAs attempted to interview C1 at 11:12 AM and C1 declined to be interviewed. LPA conducted an exit interview with Katrina Vasquez, Facility Manager at 1:56 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Katrina Vasquez, Facility Manager upon completion. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the Health & Safety Codes and two technical advisories (refer to LIC 9102 TA) during the inspection.

Continued from page 1 Staff shared with LPA that minors will come back to the facility from AWOL under the influence of substances without determining how minors gained access. LPA interviewed minors (C1 and C2) and they denied doing drugs or acquiring drugs with assistance from facility staff and did not have any information regarding how drugs are purchased. CCL received another allegation, regarding facility staff not meeting minor’s medical needs, it was specified in confidential interviews (FM, ADM, and CEO) that staff are supposed to take minors to their medical appointment and a medical appointment form is filled out even when appointments are refused. Confidential interviews indicated that appointments were made for C1, however, C1 refused to attend these appointments. C1 confirmed appointment refusals, however, the facility inconsistently documented C1’s refusals. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that the facility staff are taking minors to buy drugs and staff not meeting minor’s medical needs may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview is conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were given and explained Plan-It Life Temecula Facility Manager, Katrina Vasquez.
investigation_findings: 13On March 3, 2022 at 5:52 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, met with Plan-It Life Temecula Facility Manager, Katrina Vasquez, to deliver the finding for the above stated allegations regarding the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA conducted a health and safety inspection of the STRTP on June 28, 2021 at approximately 12:00 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Interviews were conducted with Facility Manager (FM), Administrator, Chief Executive Officer (CEO), one Youth Care Counselor (S1) and Child 1 and Child 2 (C1, C2). Additionally, Child 1 (C1) Client Record files and House Log entries were reviewed. On June 22, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that the facility staff are taking minors to buy drugs and facility staff are not meeting minor’s medical needs. Regarding facility staff taking minors to buy drugs, confidential interviews denied that minors were able to purchase drugs with the assistance of staff. Confidential interviews shared that minors are within staff visual while visiting the park and staff (S1, S2, FM, and ADM) deny observing minors purchase drugs. Continued on page

narrative: LPA Fountain was provided with video surveillance and it was disclosed that minors smoking inside the group home has been an ongoing issue. Confidential interviews reported that minors are not allowed to smoke at the facility, and staff are trained on redirecting a client who is ever observed smoking. LPA R. Fountain received a video in which it was alleged to be C1 sitting on a bed, smoking from an unknown vaping device. The video is not clear on the location as to where C1 was at the time. Confidential interviews who witnessed the video identified C1 as being in the video; however, there is no room (location) identifiers that indicate where C1 was at during the time. narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Lopez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith conducted an annual inspection. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: The facility is currently under repair and there are no clients in care. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order with the exception of Bedroom #2 which smoke detector is removed. The fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. LPAs observed the facility has all required forms Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, Facility License, Menu and Foster Care Ombudsman poster but they are currently not posted due to construction. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. Individual beds were observed with mattresses in good repair. LPA observed that there is a supply of linens for number of beds available. Due to construction, the beds are not made. Bedroom #1 has a broken dresser and Bedroom #2 has three drawers for two clients which requires additional drawer space. Outlets in the client bedrooms and tv room were missing outlet covers at time of inspection and were repaired on this date. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 127 degrees. The kitchen trash can did not have a tight fitting lid at time of inspection. The dishwasher door is dented and the dishwasher is not operating.

interviews. The facility employs 1 facility manager and 9 direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Based on record reviews, the facility was given two Type B citations: ILS 87065.1(A) Completion of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and first aid training shall be demonstrated by current and valid CPR and first aid cards issued by the American Red Cross, the American Heart Association, a training program approved by the State Emergency Medical Services Authority pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1797.191, or from an accredited college or university and ILS 80066(11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g). The facility was also provided with five Technical Advisories: 1) 87065.1(d)(1) (d) Notwithstanding California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80065(f)(1) through (6), new direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16 hour training as specified in (1) and (2) below: (1) 8-Hour Training 2) 87070(c)(2) (c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer, discipline, and complaints. 3) 87087(e) (e) In every situation where children share a bedroom, the licensee shall document that the bedroom sharing arrangement ensures the health and safety of each child and that the children are compatible. 4) 87072(c) (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable: 5) 87068.2(b)(6) (b) The needs and services plan shall be trauma informed, culturally relevant, and age and developmentally appropriate and shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: (6) Visitation, including the frequency of and any other limitations on visits to the family residence and other visits inside and outside the facility consistent with the child's personal rights as specified in Section 87072. On 10/30/2024, Community Care Licensing received a complaint alleging that facility staff did not follow needs and services plan regarding education. On 11/01/2024, LPA Joon Choi arrived at the facility, conducted a health and safety inspection, and obtained pertinent documents. No immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, LPA interviewed clients 1, 2, and 3 (C1-C3) facility staff 1, 2, and 3 (S1-S3), and County Social Worker (CSW). In regard to the allegation that facility staff did not follow needs and services plan regarding education; it was reported that C3 needed their Individualized Education Plan (IEP) updated upon starting school on 08/22/2024, however the facility did not provide an "educational rights holder" to sign the IEP until 10/18/2024 CONTINUED ON THE NEXT PAGE

narrative: On 3/19/2025, LPA Joon Choi arrived unannounced at Plan It Life Temecula House, Short Term Residential Treatment Program and met with Youth Care Counselor Bobiet Dillon. LPA visited the facility to deliver findings for a closed complaint. Upon arrival, LPA observed the facility was not in compliance with the required client to staff ratio of three clients to one staff. Upon arrival, LPA observed there were six clients and only one facility staff present. Confidential interviews reported that the second staff, that was present, prior to LPA's arrival, left to deal with a family emergency. The facility is being cited for violation of ILS 87065.5(a)(1): (a)In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows (1)During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. The above requirement was not met as evidenced by confidential interviews of facility staff and an admission of the violation by the operations manager.

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87065.5(a)(1): (a)In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows (1)During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or The above requirement was not met as evidenced by:

Through LPA observation, confidential interview of facility staff and an admission of the violation by the facility staff, it was revealed that there was only one staff on duty with six clients present on the day of the visit.  This poses a risk to the health and safety of the children.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide a safety plan that addresses the ILS violation, no later than the close of business on Thursday March 20, 2025. This safety plan will indicate how the facility will avoid the deficiency in the future by scheduling enough staff per shift.

narrative: facility, facility staff (S1-S3) did not prevent youth(s) (C1-C5) from engaging in physical altercations at the facility and facility staff (S1-S3) did not prevent youth(s) (C1-C5) from engaging in inappropriate online activity at the facility; it was reported that a video of C1 fighting and smoking vape pens with other clients in the facility; the video was posted to social media. Additionally, it was also reported to the facility that the clients were also making threats to other individuals that were not in the facility. It was further reported that Law Enforcement (LE) was notified of the video and visited the facility. Confidential interviews indicated that there was a video posted in the social medias involving three of the facility’s clients horseplaying with each other. Confidential interviews added that the clients were not engaged in physical altercations. Confidential interviews reported that it appeared the clients were smiling and laughing in the video while rough housing. Confidential interviews stated that the clients were also smoking vape pens, however, other confidential interviews disclosed that no vape pens were observed in the video. A video footage was reviewed by CCL, and it was indicated that the video in question appeared to be an older video, and the video appeared to be taken in the facility, however, other confidential interviews denied that the video took place in the facility because the facility staff conduct routine room checks every 15 minutes to prevent such incidents. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations facility staff did not prevent youth(s) from vaping in the facility, facility staff did not prevent youth(s) from engaging in physical altercations at the facility and facility staff did not prevent youth(s) from engaging in inappropriate online activity at the facility may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor Bobiet Dillon

narrative: On November 18, 2020 at 3:15 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rubio met with Plan-It Life (STRTP) Administrator Joe Jones to discuss the personal rights violations discovered during a recent review of incidents in the facility. On October 27, 2020, LPA observed all clients’ allowance money to be held by the facility in individual pouches in a locked safe in the staff office closet. Confidential interviews conducted with staff and clients also revealed that clients are not given their allowance or able to hold and manage their own allowance money. Confidential interviews revealed the reason for the facility holding client’s allowance money was due to issues in the past with clients awoling and buying contraband however none of these issues have happened recently with current clients. Additionally, it is not noted in any client needs and services plans that clients are prohibited from possessing or managing their own cash resources. The facility is being cited for Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Section 88072: Personal Rights (d) (7). Per confidential interviews and record review, the facility did not ensure clients were able to possess and manage their personal allowance money, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.

Confidential interviews revealed FM told the clients that they were going to go clothing allowance shopping and then FM said clients were not able to go because their homework and chores were not done. Other confidential interviews revealed the reason the clients were not able to go clothing shopping on a particular day was due to not enough staff on shift. C1 and C2 waited two days after that to go clothing shopping while, C3, C4 and C5 waited at least a week after. Confidential interviews of staff and clients revealed FM has told both staff and clients that clients cannot go allowance shopping as a consequence of clients’ behavior. Confidential interviews further revealed C1, C2 and C3 have not been able to go allowance shopping for the week as a consequence of not turning in their cell phones or completing chores. Confidential interviews further revealed the clients must wait until the next weekly allowance shopping to “try again” and spend their allowance. Other confidential interviews also revealed FM has also threatened to call the clients’ social workers to take their phones away if they are not compliant. Additional confidential interviews revealed FM has stated to C1 that C1 must take C1’s prescribed medication in order to live in the STRTP. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The department has determined the allegation that FM threatens minors in care is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Regulation Section 87072 Personal Rights. Per confidential interviews and record review, staff was using threats as a consequence to clients’ behaviors which poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Administrator Joe Jones.
investigation_findings: 13On November 18, 2020 at 3:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jessica Rubio made contact with Plan-It Life Administrator (AD2) Joe Jones via Google Duo video due to COVID-19, to discuss the investigative finding of the allegation listed above. On October 20, 2020, a complaint was received alleging staff threatens minors in care, specifically that FM threatens that the clients will not go clothing allowance shopping as a consequence for their behavior. (Continued on next page)

deficiencies.description:
87072 (d)(11) Personal Rights 
The licensee shall ensure that each child, ...is accorded the personal rights…To be free of... abuse...humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature...
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility failed to ensure clients were free from threats, when staff used them as a consequence of their behavior, which poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator has conducted additional training with FM and will provide proof of training by 11/23/2020.

narrative:
Confidential interviews revealed that S3, S4 and S7 have called clients names such as “b****” and staff say things like “get you’re a** to bed” and “these b****** don’t do anything”. S3, S4 and S7 denied calling any clients b****** or saying “get you’re a** to bed”. Confidential interviews revealed on one occasion S4 referred to C1 and C2 as “hoes” or whores” when speaking to C4. S4 admitted to referring to the clients as “whores” out of frustration because C1 and C2 were picking on C5 and not doing their chores. Furthermore, confidential interviews with clients revealed FM made a comment to C4 regarding C4’s choice of dress and told C4 to go change because C4 “looked like a boy”. Confidential interviews with staff revealed S5 and S4 had made comments regarding C4 “looking like a boy” as well. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The department has determined the allegation that residents were not accorded dignity in relationships with staff is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Regulation Section 87072 Personal Rights. Per confidential interviews, the facility did not ensure clients were according dignity by staff as staff referred to clients on at least one occasion using a derogatory name and making remarks to clients based on their choice of dress and appearance which poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Joe Jones.

Confidential interviews revealed that S3 and S4 have referred to the clients as “b******” when speaking to each other about the clients but not directly to the clients. Both S3 and S4 denied swearing at the clients or referring to clients as any swear words. An additional confidential interview revealed S7 called C1 a “b****” on one occasion however S7 denied using that swear word towards C1. Other confidential interviews revealed although clients cuss and call staff names, staff do not cuss or swear at the clients. Based on confidential interviews and conflicting statements, the allegation staff swore at residents may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and emailed to Administrator Joe Jones for signature.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection 8/31/22 at 9:45am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 8 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 8/31/22). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manager Natela Ward; Administrator Joe Jones was on the phone for this discussion.

On 11/21/2022, at 10:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo arrived unannounced to conduct an annual visit at Plan-It Life, Inc. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA Lo arrived at the door and was greeted by Monique Gray, Youth Care Counselor (YCC). LPA Lo stated is here for annual visit and YCC Gray gave permission to LPA Lo to enter the facility. LPA Lo asked what the census is and if there were any firearms in the house. YCC Gray stated the census is five and there are currently four clients present; there is no firearm inside the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with YCC Gray and along with the assistance of Ashley Meeks, YCC. LPA Lo covered the following Care Tool sections today: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention, Core Therapeutic Services, and Special Health Care Needs. At 10:25 AM a physical plan was conducted and the following was observed. LPA Lo observed a TV room and living room with seating space which is used for approved visitations. Kitchen table enough to seat clients in the facility for meal time and the kitchen contains utensils, dishware, pots, pans, cooking ware and operable appliances. LPA Lo observed a closet with extra clean linen in the hallway. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There are two beds in good repair with clean linen and adequate beddings. There is adequate shelf, storage and closet space for client’s belongings. Proper lighting from the window and secured on the ceiling and is operable. Age appropriate clothing were seen inside the closet and drawers. (continue on LIC 809-c)

LPA Lo observed the bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be within safety requirements; the faucet temperatures are between 105-degree F to 120-degree F, which complies with regulations. There are no common towels or wash clothes in the bathroom. The faucet, shower and toilet are in working condition for both bathrooms. Cleaning supplies and chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room in locked cabinet. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in locked closet in staff office upstairs. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA Lo observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. The facility's smoke detectors in office and hallway were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in the main hallway upstairs and downstairs were operable. The following required posted items were observed along the hallway and is accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water located on the facility premises. At 10:40 am, LPA Lo observed in Bedroom #2 is missing window screen. Per YCC Gray stated the client in the bedroom kept pushing the window screen out of place with her face. Per YCC Gray, a maintenance order is in place. Per CCR 80088(b) All window screens shall be in good repair and be free of insects, dirt and other debris. There were no deficiencies found in Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention, Core Therapeutic Services, and Special Health Care Needs. Due to time constraints, LPA Lo will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC 809-D and the appeals rights was provided to YCC Gray.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection 5/18/23 at 11:04 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811,dated 5/18/2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and master treatment plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Joe Jones.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland arrived unannounced to the facility to gather documents regarding a investigation not pertaining to this facility. Youth Care counselor was given permission to sign for the facility by Administrator Joe Jones III,

On June 22, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that due to lack of supervision minors have access to vape pens on the premises, due to lack of supervision minors engaged in inappropriate interactions while in care, due to lack of supervision minors engaged in physical altercations while in care. Regarding the allegation that due to lack of supervision minors have access to vape pens on the premises, it was revealed that clients have been in possession of vape pens while in care. Confidential interviews stated that vape pens are brought into the facility when clients are out of care, however; staff will confiscate any vape pens found by staff. Other confidential interviews denied that lack of supervision was a result of clients having access to vape pens and further maintained that staff remove drug paraphernalia from clients and involve law enforcement as needed. LPA received inconsistent information regarding whether lack of supervision was the result of clients having access to vape pens on the premises. Regarding the allegation that due to lack of supervision C2 and C6 engaged in inappropriate interactions while in care, SI Vasquez received inconsistent information to support the allegation. Although it was reported that C2 and C6 engaged in inappropriate behaviors during placement, confidential interviews denied observing inappropriate interactions between C2 and C6 in care. Other confidential interviews stated that there were ongoing behaviors between C2 and C6 that involved both clients making allegations against each other resulting in the removal of C6 from care. Records review of confidential interviews conducted by a County Social Worker Investigator revealed that there were inappropriate behaviors between C2 and C6 in care but there were also inconsistencies with the statements provided. C6 was unable to be reached for comment regarding the allegation. There were no other known witnesses to the incident. Regarding the allegation that due to lack of supervision minors engaged in physical altercations while in care, confidential interviews reported that there were multiple altercations at the facility that involved C2 and C6. Confidential interviews further stated that facility staff were responding to continuous fights among clients in care during C2’s and C6’s placement due to ongoing behaviors. Other confidential interviews reported that during altercations between clients’ staff attempted to separate clients and involved law enforcement when the situation became escalated. (**Continued on LIC 9099 C pg 3**)

Confidential interviews denied that fights were a result of lack of care and supervision by staff rather they were due to ongoing behaviors between clients in care resulting in the removal and termination of some placements. LPA received inconsistent information and there were no other known witnesses that would support staff care and supervision resulting physical altercations between C2 and C6 in care. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that due to lack of supervision minors have access to vape pens on the premises, due to lack of supervision minors engaged in inappropriate interactions while in care, due to lack of supervision minors engaged in physical altercations while in care, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Clinician, Sylvia Rodriguez Smith due to technical difficulties.

narrative: During investigation, SI Vasquez found no corroborating evidence that supported lack of supervision resulting in youth doing illegal drugs in the facility. Although confidential interviews maintained that drug use goes on with minors at the facility other confidential interviews revealed that the facility has policies and procedures in place that are implemented to ensure that clients do not engage in drug use while in care. Confidential interviews further reported that clients manage to “sneak” in illegal drugs into the facility and engage in these behaviors outside of care and in some cases returning into care under the influence. Other confidential interviews reported that when facility staff suspect minors are returning to the facility with contraband, facility staff will conduct a safety search. Facility staff also conduct room safety checks throughout the day. SI Vasquez received inconsistent information whether neglect or lack of care and supervision by staff resulted in clients doing illegal drugs in the facility. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that youth were doing illegal drugs in the facility, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Clinician, Sylvia Rodriguez Smith due to technical difficulties.

On May 15, 2024 at 08:51 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Joon Choi and Maryjane Perez conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Plan-It Life, Inc. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs were met by Administrator Jesse Jorrin (AD). The facility is situated in a residential neighborhood and is a 3 bedroom, 3 bathroom - two story home with a living room/common area, two dining rooms, kitchen, two car garage, and backyard with a patio. There is a staff office upstairs with a staff restroom. The garage has a locked therapy office that is connected. The facility's two registered vehicles are parked in the drive way full-time and has the required current registration, insurance and first aid kits. LPAs observed the following postings located in the front entry way and common area: facility license, grievance procedures, Personal Rights, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, the (contact information for the California Foster Care Ombudsman is on the Foster Youth Bill of Rights poster), visitation policies, and grievance procedures. LPAs began a physical plant inspection at 10:05 AM assisted by AD. LPAs inspected the facility's kitchen, dining area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, garage, living room/common areas, staff office, therapy office, three client bedrooms (B1,B2,B3) and one upstairs client bathroom and downstairs client bathroom. The bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients are were assigned to a room, and there is one client per bed, there were individual dresser drawers and a shared closet. Each client room had the appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses are in good repair. Each client had their own personal lockbox as well. Extra linens and client hygiene supplies are stored in two separate hallway closets . The living room had two couches and a functional television. The dining rooms each had a dining table with enough chairs for all the clients and some staff. Cleaning supplies such as chemicals are kept locked in the garage and upstairs in the staff office. Sharp utensils and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients and locked in a cabinet in the pantry closet. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPAs observed a minimum seven day non-perishable foods in the pantry and a two day perishable supply of food in the kitchen and garage refrigerators. Board games are kept in a separate closet in a downstairs closet.

There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. Client files were kept in a locked cabinet upstairs near the staff office. Per AD, there are no weapons or guns on facility grounds. The facility’s outside grounds (front yard, backyard and sides) were also inspected and were found to be clean, well maintained, and free of observable hazards. The facility has an operable carbon monoxide detector located in the upstairs hallway and smoke detectors are located throughout the facility including client's rooms. LPAs observed the facility had two fire extinguishers, with one located in the kitchen, and the other upstairs. Each fire extinguisher was fully charged and inspected in October of 2023. The medications are centrally stored in the staff office, in a locked cabinet. The facility had two First Aid Kits and were complete and kept in the staff. The washer and dryer are located in an entry way before the garage and are accessible to clients with staff supervision. The laundry detergents are kept locked in a cabinet in the garage. The Kitchen had a fully stocked refrigerator and the gas stove and dishwashing machine were operational. There were no cleaning supplies observed to be lying around unattended in the kitchen. The kitchen cabinets had plenty of pots, pans, plates and bowls for the clients to use. The hot water in the client bathroom measured degrees Fahrenheit and was within the specified 105 to 120 (107) degree range. LPAs observed that each client's hygiene items such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, lotion, and deodorant were in their rooms. Facility also had an extra supply of hygiene and beauty items in case clients ran out. The facility has two vehicles used to transport clients to appointments, schools and recreational activities. Each vehicle had no damage. The inside upholstery was intact for each vehicle. The brake lights and signals were operational. There was a fully stocked first aid kit in each vehicle as well as current registration and proof of insurance. At 11:00 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Operational Requirements. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 11:30 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Disaster Preparedness Requirements. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 11:40 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted.

At 11:50 AM with the assistance of AD, we then reviewed the facility's Core Therapeutic Services. All of the documentation pertaining to these areas of the inspection were provided, and no deficiencies were noted. Based on observations and record reviews, no deficiencies were cited during this visit. Due to time constraints, LPAs will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Jesse Jorrin.

(A) Completion of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and first aid training shall be demonstrated by current and valid CPR and first aid cards issued by the American Red Cross, the American Heart Association, a training program approved by the State Emergency Medical Services Authority pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1797.191, or from an accredited college or university. and 2)Technical Assistance ILS 87068.2(g) (g) The licensee shall obtain written approval from the child, if age and developmentally appropriate, and the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeals rights was provided to Administrator Dana Taylor.

narrative: On May 28, 2024, at 12:45 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Monique Gray, Facility Manager. Community Care Licensing received information that S1 was at an outing with three clients (C1, C2, C3) and received a phone call about a personal matter. S1 drove to their personal residence and left the clients in the vehicle for approximately five minutes while they attended to a personal matter. Confidential interviews indicated that while the clients were left unsupervised, C1 was able to obtain a bottle of alcohol, which they hid under the seat in the vehicle. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 was made aware that C1 had the bottle of alcohol hidden under the seat and S1 found the bottle and disposed of the bottle. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with and provided to Monique Gray. A signed copy of this report will be kept in the Facility file.

deficiencies.description:
Personnel Duties:  
84065.2(b)(1) Child care staff shall perform the following duties…Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews which indicated that S1 parked the vehicle outside of their personal residence and attended to a personal matter away from the sight of the vehicle which allowed C1 to obtain a bottle of alcohol and hide it under the seat of the vehicle, which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager, a text message will be sent to all the staff reminding staff are not allowed to take clients to their personal residence or leave them unattended in the vehicles.  S1 was terminated and later rehired and retrained on supervising the clients.  A screenshot of the text message and copy of S1's training form will be sent to LPA via email by end of day on 05/29/2024.

Other confidential interviews reported that S2 would have only conducted a visual search of C1’s room after hearing a description of the alleged incident. narrative: On 07/17/2024 at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi, arrived unannounced at Plan-It Life, Inc. Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Youth Care Counselor Angela Pinkney. LPA explained the reason for the visit, which was to conduct a case management regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR), which was submitted to the department in an untimely manner. Based on document review, the facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87061(j)(1) Reporting Requirements: (j) The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE...regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child in the facility. (1) The licensee shall make an initial report to the Department no later than the next business day following each incident. This requirement was not met, as evidence by the incident documented on the SIR occurred on 7/2/2024 and the facility submitted the SIR to the department on 7/15/2024. A copy of this report, along with the LIC 809D page, and appeal rights was provided to Youth Care Counselor Angela Pinkney.

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87061 Reporting Requirements
(j) The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE...regarding any incident that involves
law enforcement contact with a child in the facility. (1) The licensee shall make an initial report to the Department no later than the next business day following each incident...

This requirement was not met, as evidenced by: After records review, the facility had an incident involving an client and law enforcement on 7/2/2024, and this incident was not reported to the Department until 7/15/2024, which poses a risk to the health and safety of clients.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide a refresher training to all facility staff and provide proof (sign-in sheet or other proof of staff's attendance) of training to LPA before the agreed upon due date.

narrative: instructed to wash the clients' bedding, clothes and stuffed animals. Confidential interviews reported that even after washing the clients' bedding and belongings; the clients were still complaining of being bitten by bed bugs. Confidential interviews reported that it was unknown if pest control services were rescheduled to return to the facility. Based on the confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that staff are not addressing pests in the facility, is substantiated. The facility is being cited for Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Section 80087(a)(1) Buildings and Grounds: (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. (1) The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: confidential interviews, photos of clients injuries and health and safety inspection of the facility, showed there were bed bugs in the clients' rooms within the facility. A copy of this report, LIC 809D, and appeals rights was provided to Youth Care Counselor Jennifer Ruiz.

narrative: At approximately 8:30 PM, LE returned C1 back to the facility and added that the facility staff didn’t know that C1 was missing. During investigation, confidential interviews reported that C1 AWOL’d from the facility without facility staff knowing. Other confidential interviews reported that facility staff (S1, S2) were supervising C1 as they were having a behavior episode and monitoring C1. These confidential interviews reported that as soon as C1 decided to AWOL, S5 shadowed C1. Confidential interviews reported that when facility staff lost sight of C1, they immediately called LE at approximately 6:46 PM. LPA received a conflicting information. In regards to the allegations that facility staff (S1-S6) did not ensure a comfortable temperature was maintained in the facility and facility (S1-S6) refused to provide drinking water to youth (C1-C5); it was reported that it was extremely hot in the facility and staff will not turn on the air conditioning or give clients water when they ask for water. Confidential interviews reported that the facility’s air conditioner only works downstairs and that it doesn’t do a good job of “cooling the upstairs.” Other confidential interviews reported that the air conditioning does work upstairs but that it’s “not as strong as the downstairs.” Confidential interviews reported that the facility submitted a work order to facility maintenance staff to address the facility’s air conditioner unit. Confidential interviews reported that the facility has a 5 gallon water jug dispenser and that when the 5 gallon jugs are empty, the clients don’t have any drinking water. Other confidential interviews reported that when the 5 gallon water jugs are empty, then facility staff are sent to refill one until the delivery of the other 5 gallon jugs arrive from the supplier. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility also has bottled water on hand to provide for clients. LPA received inconsistent information. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations facility staff did not properly supervise C1, facility staff did not ensure a comfortable temperature was maintained in the facility and facility refused to provide drinking water to C1, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor Asja Meredith.

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights: (c)The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights…. 
(1) to live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and a review of video footage, clearly showed S1 engaging in an inappropriate physical interaction with C1, in which S1 physically pushed C1 and then stood in front of them in an aggressive posture. This poses an immediate health and safety or personal rights risks for the client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility has already terminated S1’s employment. The facility will also provide a refresher training with all facility staff, reviewing Pro-Act and/or CPI de-escalation techniques. The facility will provide a plan for how and when this training will take place no later than the close of the next business day.

narrative:
considered a privilege. Additional staff reported that FC1 was not denied attending the class altogether and was allowed to attend a make-up class after completing the requirements of FC1’s shared living agreement with the facility. FC1 disclosed to LPA that FC1 was not able to attend the make-up class due to school obligations. LPA reviewed the needs and services plan for FC1 as well as the shared living agreement between FC1 and the facility. LPA did not observe any noted pre-conditions in order for FC1 to attend independent living classes. CCL also received information that FC1 was denied the right to call FC1’s social worker and that a facility staff was heard instructing FC1 to end a telephone call with a representative from the Office of the Foster Care Ombudsperson. Confidential witnesses reported to LPA that the youth are allowed adequate use of the telephone during certain hours of the day. Other confidential witnesses reported that the youth’s telephone calls are often restricted and at times denied. Confidential interviews revealed that staff (S1) instructed FC1 to end FC1’s telephone conversation with a representative from the Office of the Foster Care Ombudsperson. S1 reported to LPA that the youth are limited to ten minutes on the telephone per the company’s policy and that S1 has in fact prompted youth to end their telephone calls after ten minutes no matter who the youth are speaking to. LPA reviewed the facility’s telephone policy which states the youth are allowed to contact CCL, the Child Abuse Hotline, and the Ombudsperson at any time. The policy also states the youth are allowed to use the phone during specified times throughout the week and are allowed a minimum of ten minutes for each telephone call. The policy further states that the youth may use the telephone outside of the specified times for special or emergency situations. Based on confidential interviews and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegations that staff failed to ensure FC1 attended a scheduled independent living class and that staff denied FC1 from telephone calls are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Section 87072(d)(8)(C) and Section 87072 (d)(11) Personal Rights. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided. This report was emailed to Dana Taylor for signature. The signed reports will be placed in the facility file.

Confidential interviews further revealed that staff confiscated a pair of shorts from FC1’s bedroom due to their provocative nature. Other confidential witnesses disclosed that the shorts were confiscated while FC1 was away from the facility with staff and that the youth are not always aware when and why a room search was conducted. CCL also received information that a facility staff (S2) yells at the youth all the time. Confidential witnesses reported to LPA that S2 consistently yells at the youth. However, S2 denied yelling at any of the youth. Additionally, multiple confidential witnesses reported that none of the staff yells at the youth. Confidential witnesses further reported that foster youth (FC1) has complained of S2 yelling when S2 was only trying to redirect FC1 and did not yell. Other confidential witnesses disclosed that a separate staff (S1) was observed yelling at the youth and not S2. Based on confidential interviews and conflicting statements, the allegations that FC1 was not afforded privacy while in care and that S2 yelled at FC1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided. This report was emailed to Dana Taylor for signature. The original report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On November 5, 2020 at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), LaTonya Wilson, conducted a tele-inspection with Plan It Life Administrator, Dana Taylor, due to COVID-19. The purpose of this tele-inspection was to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. The investigation included a review of records for the facility and one foster youth. Interviews were conducted with two County Social Workers, five staff, and six of seven foster youth. LPA also conducted a safety inspection at the facility on 8/14/20 at 10:55AM via tele-inspection and no immediate safety hazards were observed. On 8/12/20, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information that foster youth (FC1) was denied attending a scheduled independent living class because FC1 did not wake up on time. Confidential witnesses reported to LPA that some youth at the facility were enrolled in weekly online independent living classes. Confidential witnesses further disclosed that FC1 was denied attending at least one scheduled independent living class as FC1 had not enrolled in any college courses or submitted job applications prior to the start of the scheduled independent living class. Staff reported to LPA that if the youth are not following the program at the facility then they may not be allowed to attend the independent living class since the class is

deficiencies.description:
87072(d)(11) Personal Rights:
To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature…

This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, FC1 was denied attending a scheduled online independent living class due to failing to complete other tasks at the facility. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal right risk to the foster youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator stated facility staff will receive additonal training on personal rights. Administrator will send proof of training to LPA.

deficiencies.description:
87072(d)(8)(C) Personal Rights: To make/receive confidential telephone calls, unless prohibited by court order. Calls permitted to be restricted shall not include calls to the child's social workers, attorneys, probation officers, Community Care Licensing or the State Foster Care Ombudsperson. 
This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, S1 instructed FC1 to end FC1’s telephone conversation with a rep from the Office of the Foster Care Ombudsperson. Youth are limited to ten-minute telephone calls no matter the recipient. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the foster youth in care.

Administrator stated facility staff will receive additonal training on personal rights. Administrator will send proof of training to LPA.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts, Veronica Whitaker and Margaret Lentner conducted a case management inspection October 26, 2021 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 3 of 9 Direct Care Staff and 5 of 5 Youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated October 26, 2021, were reviewed. 3 of 9 Direct Care Staff and 3 of 5 Youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to the Dana Taylor, Administrator and Chiante Leonard, Facility Manager. *This is an amended version of the original report created on 10/26/21. This report was emailed to Administrator Dana Taylor at DTaylor@planitlife.org. for signature.

More specifically, FC1 was upset over not receiving “Tums” because it was not an authorized medication. Therefore, FC1 walked out of the room and unexpectantly took a decorative couch pillow to the stove and lit it on fire. FC1 stood and watched the pillow catch fire and stated, “I told you guys,” insinuating that FC1 was going to set the home on fire. Confidential interviews revealed that the incident happened on April 5, 2021, and there was no supervision issue; the facility had six minors to two staff at that time. There was no 1:1 assigned to FC1; because FC1 was recently placed with no history. The assessment notes provided by the STRTP therapist did not reflect any violent history. A removal request was made by the STRTP the same day of the fire incident. Other confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that FC1 had previously threatened to burn down the facility, and that no previous threats were made by FC1. Review of documents did not include a safety plan for FC1 after the alleged threats were noted. Confidential interviews reported, that no one was hurt by the hazardous fire fumes. There were only two clients in the facility at the time of the fire and the other client was in the shower at the time of the incident. Other confidential interviews revealed that FC1 was holding the pillow while it was burning emanating fumes. There were no witnesses to discern if FC1 inhaled any smoke. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations stating that staff did not properly supervise FC1 while in care and FC1 had access to a hazardous item while in care may have occurred; however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Chiante Leonard.

On June 08, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lisi Leon & Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith, made an unannounced case management inspection regarding the facility safety inspection conducted on May 05, 2022. On May 05, 2022, LPA Leon observed the flooring in the hallway and kitchen is separating and lifting and there are multiple gaps in the flooring which is a potential safety hazard for clients and staff. LPA spoke with Facility Manager, Chiante Leonard, who advised LPA facility is in the process of getting floors repaired. LPA Leon recommended facility to cover the floor with rugs as a temporary remedy until the floor is repaired. On June 08, 2022, LPA Leon and LPM Smith observed the rugs are placed in the hallway,however, are not covering all of the gaps in the flooring. It was also observed the flooring is separating in the kitchen. LPA Leon spoke with Facility Administrator, Dana Taylor, who advised the floors are expected to be repaired on July 6, 2022. LPA requested documentation of service request and installation date. Based on observations, the facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 80087(a) Buildings and Ground. Facility neglected to repair flooring. This poses a potential health and safety risk of harm to children placed in care. See page 2 for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeals rights discussed. A copy of this report was provided to Facility Representative.

permission. Confidential interviews also revealed the facility provided Nair to the clients to shave and did not have any razors in the facility. Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection on 8/3/22 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 3, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Manger Chiante Leanord.
