narrative: On October 26, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Lisi Leon and Eduardo Barragan met with the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Shift Manager La Sonjia Walton to issue a case management deficiency and serve an immediate exclusion order, Government Code 11522 for employee #1 (S1). See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 10/26/2022, for the individual involved. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information regarding an incident that occurred on or about January 17, 2022. A video surveillance from a camera located at the facility captured a physical altercation between S1 and Client 1 (C1). In the video, C1 was observed to throw an empty shampoo bottle at S1 and verbal remarks were exchanged (the video surveillance had no audio). S1 leaned toward C1 and both individuals punched each other and pulled each other’s hair. It was confirmed in the police report and confidential interviews that C1’s hair was pulled out of the scalp. The incident in the video was observed by LPA Leon and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith on 06/08/2022. LPA advised Shift Manager, La Sonjia Walton, of the immediate exclusion order for S1 from any continued or future contact with clients or presence in the facility which constitutes a threat to the health and safety of the clients in care. LPA provided the Director with an immediate exclusion order and instructed the facility to adhere to the order immediately. Based on video surveillance and confidential interviews, the facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) version four, Personal Rights violation section 87072 (c)(11) which poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC809D, exclusion order and appeal rights were provided to Shift Manager La Sonjia Walton.

On November 10, 2022 at 9:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Plan It Life Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met at by Facility Manager Chiante Leonard. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 9:30 AM assisted by the Facility Manager. The physical plant inspection included the following checks: The facilities kitchen, dining area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, garage, living room, family room, staff office, therapy office, art room, recreation room, one client bathroom and three client bedrooms (B1,B2,B3). Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. Each client room has the appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses are in good repair. Extra linens are stored in the hall closet. Additionally, there is adequate drawer space for each client’s belongings. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in the front hall closet and in the garage. The cooking knives are locked inside of the staff office. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPA observed a minimum seven days non-perishable and a two day perishable supply of food. Additionally, LPA observed the following postings: facility license, grievance procedures, personal rights, Ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Age appropriate toys, games and books were observed for client’s recreation time. The facility’s outside grounds (front yard, backyard) were also inspected and were found to be clean, well maintained, and free of observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. Per Facility Manager there are no guns or weapons on facility grounds. The facility has an operable smoke and carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway and dinning area Fire extinguishers are properly charged, serviced, and located in the kitchen and hallway. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

The medications are stored in the staff office inside of a locked cabinet. The First Aid Kit is complete and also kept in the staff office. The washer and dryer are in the locked garage only accessible to clients with staff assistance. Per Facility Manager statement clients are supervised while they do their own laundry and detergents are kept locked in the hall cabinet and a locked cabinet in the garage. The facility has a total of two vehicles that are used to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. Both vehicles were operable and in good repair . At 9:30 Am LPA observed the licensee was not in compliance with California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80088(e)(1). The regulation is stated as follows: … (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). The water temperature in the client bathroom measured 123.5 degrees Fahrenheit. At 10:12 AM LPA observed the licensee was not in compliance with CCR 80087(a). The regulation is stated as follows: (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. While inspecting the client bedrooms LPA observed B3 had five holes in the wall and damage to the wall outside of the closet. Per Facility Manager statement the holes were made by a client, no longer at the facility, and there is a work order for repair. At 10:45 AM LPA began the review Disaster Preparedness, Operational Requirements, Emergency Interventions and Core Therapeutic Services assisted by Administrator Joe Jones, Therapist Latoya Jackson, and the Facility Manager. All the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to Facility Manager Chiante Leonard.

deficiencies.description:
Health Related Services: 
80075 (1) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services, including arrangement for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, C1 had an X-ray/Imaging Referral form for their right wrist/hand/thumb, dated 04/14/2022, and an appointment was not scheduled which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

A Screenshot of the text message to staff will be submitted to LPA C. Linley via email by 5:00pm on 05/23/2023.

narrative: On September 26, 2023, at 3:40pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Plan-It-Life, Inc. Therapist, LaToya Jackson, to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL), an incident occurring on or about September 18, 2023 involving Child #1 (C1) which led to subsequent incidents involving Law Enforcement were not reported to CCL. Record review could not provide evidence of the incident involving C1 occurring on or about 9/18/2023 having been reported to CCL. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 80061(b)(1)(E) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS: (b)(1)(E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Therapist, LaToya Jackson.

investigation_findings: 13On November 1, 2023, at 09:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegation. LPA met with LaSonjia Walton. LPA Lisi Leon conducted an inspection of the facility on January 04, 2022, at 1:45 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Four of four children (C1, C2, C3, C4), four staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that staff did not properly supervise minors resulting in C1 being threatened by C2. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 threatened C2. Confidential interviews reported that C2 borrowed C1’s clothing, without permission on several occasions. Confidential staff interviews reported that when staff became aware of the aggression between C1 and C2, staff immediately intervened and ensured that C1 and C2 were separated from each other while at the facility. Some confidential interviews disclosed that this incident did not occur and C1 was the one who threatened C2. Other confidential interviews stated that the allegation was true. Continued on page

narrative: evidence of the school’s responsibility to transport C1 from the facility to the school. Confidential interviews provided conflicting statements as to how staff verified that the vehicle picking up C1 was a school vehicle. Confidential interviews revealed staff observed the vehicle to have similar markings of the school vehicle and therefore was not concerned. However, confidential interviews also reported that on the date of the alleged incident the driver of the vehicle did not pull into the facility driveway nor did the driver roll down the window to wave at staff, as was done typically. Additional confidential interviews reported when C1 entered the vehicle C1 sat in the front seat, and this was not typical behavior for school transport. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute staff observed C1 getting into the vehicle or noticing where C1 sat. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegation alleging due to lack of supervision minor (C1) engaged in sexual relationship with an adult may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Plan It Life Therapist, Latoya Jackson.
investigation_findings: 13On February 22, 2024 at 12:36 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland met with Plan It Life Therapist, Latoya Jackson, to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. A Health and safety inspection of the facility was conducted on September 26, 2023, and no immediate hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with three of five foster youth (Child #1 [C1], Child #3 [C3], and Child #4 [C4]), five staff members (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #2 [S2], Staff #3 [S3], Staff #4 [S4], and Staff #5 [S5]), and one San Bernardino County Social Worker. In addition, county records, police records and facility records were reviewed. On September 21, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging due to lack of supervision minor C1 engaged in sexual relationship with an adult. Specifically, it was reported on or about September 19, 2023, C1 was picked up by a representative of C1’s school for school transport, however the facility was later notified that C1 did not arrive at school. Confidential interviews and record review provided ***CONTINUED NO NEXT PAGE***

narrative: Additionally, it was reported that when C1 requested a napkin, S3 said "do you want me to pull out my underwear for you to use?" During the investigation, confidential interviews reported that S3 never physically pushed C1 or any other client at any time, into a car or anywhere else. Other confidential interviews stated that S3 did not speak to C1 or any other client in the facility in an inappropriate manner. Confidential interviews reported that the only staff that used inappropriate language was no longer working at the facility. Regarding the allegation that staff (S3) does not provide water or silverware to minor (C1) in care. Confidential reports indicated that S3 told C1 that C1 must buy their own water and plastic forks. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility provides silverware that is washed in a dishwasher by either clients or staff and that if clients do not wish to use this washed silverware, then they can request plastic utensils. Other confidential interviews reported that facility staff does not charge clients for plastic utensils. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility provides bottled water for clients to drink and that clients are not charged for water as well. Confidential interviews reported that during a health and safety inspection of the facility, there was a plentiful supply of silverware, plastic utensils and bottled water. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff (S3) handled minor (C1) in an inappropriate manner, staff (S3) speak to minor (C1) in an inappropriate manner, and staff (S3) does not provide water or silverware to minor (C1) in care, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor Jada Bunnell.

narrative: On June 23, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that facility staff made an inappropriate comment in the presence of youths in care. Specifically, it was reported that three clients (C3, C6, and an unspecified Client were having a conversation about "strap gun" and a staff member S3, joined them in the conversation and made the comment that S3 has their sexual release with somebody who has a strap-on. Further confidential interviews stated that the inappropriate comment was not made. Other information stated the allegation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, along with Appeals Rights were explained and provided to the Facility.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights:   87072(c)(8)(B) 
To be provided with and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items….toiletries, and grooming, and personal hygiene products as age and developmentally appropriate
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, C1 had a dental order to use an electric toothbrush and water pick and the facility did not purchase an electric toothbrush or water flosser, which posed a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Facility Manager, a training with all staff will occur on June 5, 2024.  All staff will be reminded to communicate with the Facility Manager and Administrator of doctor and dental notes and records that require items to be purchased.  A copy of the training outline and signature page will be sent via email to LPA by end of day on June 10, 2024.

reported that C1’s school called for S7 to drop off C1’s medication and the school received confirmation that S7 was in route. Other confidential interviews reported that although S1 is strict as it applies to facility rules, S1 has been learning to get along better with the clients of the facility. narrative:
Confidential interviews reported that initially, the facility was going to make minor repairs on the floors, but that the contracted workers recommended that the facility needed other major repairs and renovations such as new paint and new floors in the kitchen and throughout the facility. Confidential interviews reported that the facility approved major renovations. Confidential interviews reported that the facility management did not advise Community Care Licensing prior to renovations beginning, as is required by regulations. Based on the confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that facility is in disrepair is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation for Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Section 80086(a) Alteration to Existing Building or New Facilities: (a) Prior to construction or alterations, all licensees shall notify the licensing agency of the proposed change. (See LIC 9099D). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 809D page, and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor Jada Bunnell.

C1-C4 are made to stay in their rooms because of the renovations but leave the facility during outings. During investigation, confidential interviews reported that C1-C4 were instructed to stay in their rooms for their safety, when there was paint fumes or when the floors were being worked on. Other confidential interviews reported that C1-C4 were not forced to be in their rooms but could leave their rooms to use the restrooms or eat. Confidential interviews reported that C1-C4 were only told to be careful when they were out of their rooms. Confidential interviews reported that the facility provided all-day outings and when the facility was not deemed safe, the facility arranged for clients and staff to stay at hotels. Confidential interviews reported that the facility did not have a plan for outings until after the first day when renovations began. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility had a plan in place, prior to the start of renovations. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation facility staff are forcing minors to remain in their rooms, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor Jada Bunnell.

deficiencies.description:
Title 22, General Licensing Requirements, Article 7. Physical Environment.  80086 (a) Alteration to Existing Building or New Facilities: (a) Prior to construction or alterations, all licensees shall notify the licensing agency of the proposed change. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and health and safety inspection of the facility, the facility was undergoing construction and alterations, prior to notifying Community Care Licensing and submit a plan to operate while the facility was undergoing repairs. This poses a risk to the health and safety of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction: The facility will provide training to all of its four STRTP staff including Administrators, regarding timely reporting requirements that a specific facility will undergo construction, alterations and/or renovations. Facility will provide LPA Joon Choi with the planned date for the proposed training prior to or on 8/21/2024.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on 09/18/24 at 10:50 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 4 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 09/18/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, runaway action plan, crisis intervention plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Dana Taylor.

the children are fed food that has gone bad and/or moldy. Confidential interviews reported that when facility staff are upset with a client or clients, then they will feed the clients food that is close to expiring or appears expired. Confidential interviews reported that they could see the facility staff doing this, but that it has never happened to them. Other confidential interviews reported that staff do not feed clients expired food for any reason and that any food that is expired or close to expiring, is disposed of by facility staff. Other confidential interviews reported that if a client was fed expired food, it was probably by accident because maybe the staff didn’t know it was expired. During the facility inspection, LPA Joon Choi observed that the refrigerator and pantry appeared to have fresh and unexpired foods. LPA received conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff served expired food to minors while in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor Jada Bunnell.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that C2 and C3 were engaging in bullying behaviors towards C1. On 03/13/2025, Community Care Licensing received allegations that staff are not preventing minors from bullying other minor in care and staff do not ensure that minor is accorded privacy while in care. On 03/17/2025, LPA Joon Choi arrived at the facility, conducted a health and safety inspection, and obtained pertinent documents. No immediate health and safety hazards were observed. On 3/26/2025, LPA Choi conducted a follow-up visit to the facility. In addition, LPA interviewed clients 1, 2 and 3 (C1-C3) and staff 1, 2 and 3 (S1-S3). In regard to the allegation that staff (names not provided) are not preventing minors (C2, C3) from bullying other minor in care (C1); it was reported that C1 was being “bullied” by C2 and C3 in the facility. It was further reported that C2 and C3 were “verbally mean” to C1 and spread false rumors about C1 at their common public school. CONTINUED ON THE NEXT PAGE

narrative:
Confidential interviews further reported that S1 instructed C2 to leave the kitchen area and when C2 didn’t follow instructions, S1 then physically picked up C2 and moved C2 out of the kitchen. Confidential interviews reported that it was unknown if S1 did this in a playful manner or if S1 was genuinely upset with C2. Confidential interviews reported that there was no further escalation or incident. In regard to the allegation that staff (names not provided) did not safeguard minor's (C1) personal belongings; it was reported that C1 believed their allowance was missing and/or stolen. It was further reported that C1 had $99 dollars in February 2025 and it was $0 at the time of this received complaint. It was further reported that C1 asked for receipts to see how their money was distributed, but the facility did not provide them. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was unsure how their cash resources had decreased from $99 in February of 2025 to $0 in March of 2025. LPA obtained a copy of C1’s official facility allowance log. Document review showed that there was no indication of a “beginning balance” and/or and “ending balance” as it pertained to C1’s cash balance. Document review showed that an allowance was distributed every week but there was no indication on whether the client accepted the cash allowance and/or took a portion of the allowance and deposited a portion of the allowance to remain in their safeguarded cash resources. Document review indicated the facility was deficient in their record keeping process. Based on the confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documentation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegations that staff handled minor inappropriately and staff did not safeguard minor's personal belongings are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation for ILS 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights and ILS 87026(b) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables (See LIC 9099D). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report LIC 9099, the LIC 9099D and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor, Tanicki Wallace.

Confidential interviews reported that C1 was in the process of running away from the facility and that in response, S1 physically sat on C1 to prevent them from doing so. Confidential interviews reported there was no mention of any injuries to C1. Other confidential interviews reported that neither S1 nor any other facility staff have ever physically prevented a client from running away from the facility, nor did they hear about or personally witness the described incident. LPA received inconsistent information. In regard to the allegation that staff (names not provided) made inappropriate comments towards resident (names not provided); it was reported that facility staff make statements like “they need a whooping”, directed at clients (no details were provided). Confidential interviews reported that when facility staff observe clients are about to run away, they get frustrated and say, “they need a whooping.” Other confidential interviews reported that when staff observe clients are about to run away, they follow facility protocol and attempt to de-escalate the client in a trauma informed manner. LPA received inconsistent information. In regard to the allegations that staff are not providing adequate food service to minors and staff did not ensure the facility had food; it was reported that the facility does not have food in the home. It was further reported that the facility serves the same meal all week. For example, if they have chicken one day, the chicken will be the meal for the entire week. Confidential interviews reported that the facility had no food in the refrigerators or pantry. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility had fully stocked refrigerators in the kitchen and garage and plenty of dry goods and snacks in the pantry. Confidential interviews reported that the facility staff prepared the same meals all in the same week. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility staff adhere to the posted menu and that staff try their best to prepare diversified meals. During inspection, LPA observed the facility’s refrigerators are stocked with different foods and the facility pantry is well stocked with dry goods and snacks. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that staff engaged in physical altercations with minor resulting in injuries, staff made inappropriate comments towards resident, staff are not providing adequate food service to minors and staff did not ensure the facility had food may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Youth Care Counselor, Tanicki Wallace

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights: (c)The licensee shall ensure that each child…is accorded the personal rights…. 
(1) to live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of pertinent documentation, consistent and reliable confidential interviews reiterated that S1 physically picked up C2 and moved them from one room to another which posed a potential risk to the health, safety and well-being of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility has agreed to provide a refresher training on: "Establishing appropriate boundaries with clients and avoiding unnecessary physical contact when possible."

Facility has agreed to provide proof of this completed refresher training with all facility staff, no later than the close of business day - July 25, 2025; to LPA Choi.

deficiencies.description:
ILS 87026(b) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables: (b) The licensee shall have written policies and procedures outlining how the licensee will safeguard case resources…. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of pertinent documentation, the facility’s copy of a client’s allowance log, clearly showed there was no documentation of a beginning balance and/or an ending balance as it pertained to the client’s cash allowances dispersed on a weekly basis. The facility’s record keeping as it pertained to client allowances and cash resources was not in compliance with ILS regulations. This poses a potential risk to the health, safety and well-being of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility has agreed to revise their current allowance logs for all clients to reflect/notate a "beginning balance" and "ending balance" for each weekly allowance dispersal to clients.

Facility has agreed to provide a copy of their update allowance log to LPA Choi, no later than the close of business day on 7/25/2025.

On 7/31/2025 at approximately 10:54 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi conducted a follow-up visit to Plan It Life Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) Riverside House and met again with Youth Care Counselor Yamka Medez. LPA Choi explained the reason for the visit was to amend the LIC 809 and LIC 809D documents from yesterday's visit. Yesterday, LPA Choi conducted a case management regarding an unauthorized staff member (S1) that has been allowed to work at this facility, prior to obtaining a full criminal background clearance. (Please note: LPA Choi visited this facility yesterday, 07/30/2025, but recorded the visit under a different facility profile). During the visit on 07/30/2025, LPA Choi obtained the facility's Guardian Employee Roster and email/forwarded it to Human Resources Administrator Earl Richards (HR). Per a brief phone interview with HR, it was concluded that S1's employment / start date at this facility was authorized in error. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03, Application Procedures: CCR 80019(e)(2): (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California Clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. A copy of this report (LIC 809), deficiencies page (LIC 809D) and appeals rights was provided to Youth Care Counselor Yamka Mendez.

During investigation, confidential interviews reported that S1 stated that they would “run over” clients if they attempted to run away from the facility. Confidential interviews reported that the clients knew S1 was joking as they made this statement while laughing and smiling. Other confidential interviews reported that S1 did not make any such threats to any clients in the facility. In regard to the allegation that staff (S1-S4) left minor (C1) outside for an extended period of time; it was reported that C1 returned to the facility after running away and was not allowed to enter the facility and had to wait outside for law enforcement to arrive. It was also reported that C1 was locked out of the facility, “multiple times.” Confidential interviews reported that prior to C1 running away from the facility for that most recent incident; C1 and C1’s County Authorized Representatives were informed that C1’s bed space (placement) would be revoked if C1 ran away again. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was returned/escorted to the facility by law enforcement (LE) after running away. Confidential interviews reported that the facility staff advised LE that C1 was no longer assigned to the facility but that LE left before the facility allowed C1 to re-enter the facility. Confidential interviews reported that the facility staff was advised by their supervisors to allow C1 to “spend the night” in the facility. Confidential interviews reported that C1’s authorized representatives picked up C1 the following morning. In regard to the allegation that staff (S1-S4) do not ensure minors are provided with hygiene products; it was reported that C1 asked staff (S1-S4) for face wash but was they could not be provided with hygiene products if C1 continued to run away from the facility. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was told by facility staff that hygiene products would be withheld, if C1 kept running away. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility staff did not use the withholding of hygiene products as a punishment or incentive for clients as a way to prevent them from running away. LPA received inconsistent information in this regard. In regard to the allegation that staff (S1-S4) do not prevent minors (C1, C2) from engaging in physical altercations with other minors; it was reported that facility staff did not intervene when C1 and C2 engaged in a physical altercation. Confidential interviews reported that C3 initiated multiple physical altercations with different clients, and staff did not intervene. Other confidential interviews reported that C1 and C3 engaged in a physical fight in the presence of facility staff, and that the facility staff assisted with separating C1 and C3. Confidential interviews reported that a Special Incident Report, documenting a fight between C1 and C2, was submitted in a timely manner to licensing.

Other confidential interviews reported that C3 was not involved in any other physical altercations with other clients. LPA received inconsistent information in this regard. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews, the allegations that staff threatens minors (C1-C3), staff left C1 outside for an extended period of time, staff do not ensure minors are provided with hygiene products and staff do not prevent minor from engaging in physical altercations with other minors may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Jada Bunnell, Youth Care Counselor.

narrative: An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 9/22/20 at 11:00am. During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Ian Longue, Program Manager at the Chestnut House. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. LPA discussed an Incident Report (IR) dated 9/10/20 for a client's (C1) 39-minute restraint. The IR was missing the time(s) the supervisor checked the client’s breathing and circulation and approved the restraint to continue. The facility will ensure this information is in restraint IR's as required in Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) version 3.1 # 87095.22(f). LPA provided this report to Ian Longue, Program Manager upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date.

On 10/30/20 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman spoke to Ian Longue, Program Manager, regarding three Incident Reports (IR's) dated 09/29/2020 for client C1, 10/01/2020 for client C2 and 10/18/2020 for client C3 (see LIC811 confidential names list). LPA stated the IR for C1 has a question on page one "was this and extended restraint (Over 15 min) but the same question on the IR for C2 states "was this a normal restraint (less 15 min). LPA stated it appears the facility has two different IR forms one for each facility. LPA provided technical assistance and recommended the facility have one standard IR form that can be used by both facility's. LPA stated that restraints that last longer than 15 minutes are reviewed more in depth to determine why the restraint lasted longer than 15 minutes. LPA stated the facility number listed on the IR for C3 on page is for the Chesnut location but then on page two states the facility number for the Grove location. LPA asked Ian Longue to please have the IR corrected stating the correct facility and to resubmit it. LPA provided technical assistance suggesting the facility have one IR form that lists both locations with a checkbox next to each location for staff to check the correct facility. LPA provided this report to Ian Longue, Program Manager upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date

On 11/24/20 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced tele inspection of the facility with Ian Longue Program Manager. The facility was inspected inside and outside. LPA observed the facility has at least a seven day supply of non-perishable food and a two day supply of perishable foods. The facility has posted the menu and COVID-19 posters. The medications are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. The facility has hygiene supplies for each client and handwashing supplies were located at each sink. LPA observed the backyard has two sheds that are used for storage. LPA was not able to review any files due to limited staff so this inspection will be continued at a later date. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. LPA provided this report to Ian Longue, Program Manager upon completion by email with a request to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date

On 12/1/20 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced tele inspection of the facility with Ian Longue Program Manager via Microsoft Teams to continue the Post Licensing Inspection from 11/24/20. LPA reviewed four staff files and six client files(see LIC859 and LIC858). Record review confirm staff files for S1 and S2 are missing documentation of medical assessment within one year prior to or seven days after employment. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80065(g)(1) Personnel Requirements. (g) All personnel, including the licensee, administrator and volunteers, shall be in good health, and shall be physically, mentally, and occupationally capable of performing assigned tasks. (1) Except as specified in (3) below, good physical health shall be verified by a health screening, including a test for tuberculosis, performed by or under the supervision of a physician not more than one year prior to or seven days after employment or licensure. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80069(a) prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client. The medical assessment shall include the results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. Record review confirm client files for C1, C3, C4, C5, C6 are missing documentation of communicable tuberculosis. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessment. The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. See LIC809D for citations.

On 1/11/21 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Stidman and Robert Sandles along with Public Health Nurse Veronica Nazareth (PHN) and Ian Longue Program Manager (PM) conducted a Tele Inspection of the facility via Microsoft Teams due to the facility had clients and staff with positive COVID-19. LPA's and PHN observed that COVID-19 posters were posted in the front entrance hallway, above the kitchen sink and on the door between the staff office and kitchen, six clients were present along with four staff. LPA's and PHN observed that the game room, living room couches and dining room benches do promote clients social distancing. The furniture is placed next to each other which promotes clients and/or staff sitting next to each other. LPA's and PHN observed that the client bathroom in the hallway did not have hand soap available. The hand soap was locked in the hall closet next to the bathroom. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80072(a)(2) Personal Rights. Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: to be accorded safe, healthful and comfortable accommodations, furnishings and equipment to meet his/her needs. LPA's and PHN observed the bathroom in the game room and the staff bathroom have hand soap accessible. The laundry room has a hand sanitizer station available. PM stated the facility sanitizes frequently touched surfaces after every meal and the outdoor swings and slide is disinfected only when there is a positive COVID-19 case. The following recommendations were made: The facility place a screening and hand sanitizing station outside the facility entrance. Staff should maintain social distancing with clients. Furniture should be arranged to encourage social distancing. Meals should be served to encourage social distancing or should be staggered with staff/clients eating meals at different times or locations. Outdoor swings and slide should be disinfected either prior to or after use by clients. Staff temperatures should be screened prior to entering or

leaving the facility. Staff temperature screenings should be logged. The facility should monitor the room temperature in the laundry room to ensure it does not get too hot due to medications are stored there. See LIC809D for citation. Due to the State of Emergency and shelter-in-place ordinance put into place by the Governor of California as safety protection relating to the Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19), the department is limiting in-person contact. This inspection was conducted electronically. LPA provided the Summary Report to Ian Longue, Program Manager upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date.

On 3/9/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez and Regional Manager (RM) Margo Castaneda met with Wendi Counta, Executive Director (ED), Dianna Wade Administrative Assistant and Barbara Sommer Board Member for a follow up to the Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) dated 12/16/20. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this meeting was conducted via Microsoft Teams. It was discussed that as of 3/8/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman had not received the Executive Director's signature on the LIC9111 Non-Compliance Conference forms dated 12/16/20. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80052(b) Deficiencies in compliance. The facility failed to acknowledge receipt of the notice of deficiency. LPA Stidman requested the signature from the executive director on five separate dates between 12/23/20-3/5/21.

On 3/18/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez met with Wendi Counta, Executive Director (ED), Dianna Wade Administrative Assistant and Ian Longue Program Manger (PM) to discuss the Plan of Correction (POC) due for both facility's post licensing inspections. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this meeting was conducted via Microsoft Teams. It was discussed that the facility's form used for the client's medical assessment does not include all the information as required by regulations. ED stated that the facility will ensure that all current and/or new client's medical assessments have all the required information. LPM stated she will get clarification whether or not the SOC154 form is required for private placements. LPA & LPM discussed that all clients files need to have all the required documentation regardless of the type of placement. LPA stated she received an email from PM on 3/18/21 with several pages attached. LPA stated she will review and either clear the POC's or email ED of what is still needed. LPA provided technical assistance for documentation organization. ED stated the facility will hire a consultant to help review and/or organize their files. ED stated the facility will be doing quarterly reviews of their files. ED stated the facility plans to hire a full time office manager and head of service (HOS). LPA asked for documentation of the HOS qualifications. ED stated the facility is currently not accredited as their accreditation expired in 2020. ED stated they are working on the new CARF application and plan to submit it soon. LPA requested a copy of the application and documentation when it has been submitted. ED stated the facility plans to hire a consultant to assist the facility in meeting the requirements for CARF. LPA provided this report to Wendi Counta, Executive Director, upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date.

On 8/5/2021 at 10:45am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) N. Sanders and Chad Gabigon arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducing annual/required inspection. LPAs met with Mikey Martin, Administrative Assistant. The facility is clean and free of clutter. The facility license, children's personal rights, facility disaster plan and complaint hot line are posted in the hallway. The facility has three bedrooms, a living room, a kitchen and a dining room and staff office where clients files are locked. Clients beds are clean and in good repair, equipped with firm mattresses. All food is safe and of the quality and in quantity necessary to meet clients needs. Snacks are available for the clients. Menu is posted. Kitchen and food preparation space is clean, free of litter and rubbish. Facility is equipped with cooking supplies, dishes, glasses and utensils. Poisons and cleaning supplies are in a locked storage room. Medications are in locked cabinets in locked storage room. Knives and sharp objects are locked as well. There are two bathrooms in this facility. One is used by clients and one is used by staff. Clients bathroom is clean. Each clients is provided with grooming supplies. Fire extinguishers are up to date. Smoke alarms tested and are in working condition. The outdoor is clean and free of clutter. There are swings in the backyard. The ground is covered with wood chips. There are two sheds filled with garden supplies and donated items for the house and clients.

Facility is licensed for six clients and is operating in full capacity. LPA reviewed six clients files. The facility is cited for Facility cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations: ILS 87070(b)(10) Consent Forms, ILS 87070(c)(4) Original Needs and Services Plans and 87068.3(a) quarterly Updates for Needs and Services Plans. Technical Violation was given for California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulation, 80069(a) Medical Assessment. A copy of this report and appeal rights were left at the facility.

narrative: special treatment twice. The facility did not provide documentation that C1 received any special dental treatments. On 7/12/21 LPA obtained from Helen E. Cowell Children’s Center the Progress Ranch Medical Tracking Forms for C1 dental appointments dated 7/16/19-3/17/21. LPA reviewed Incident Reports (IRs) for C1 dated 10/5/18-5/13/21. LPA reviewed IRs submitted since the facility was licensed as an STRTP from 8/24/20 -7/19/21. As an STRTP both locations submitted 220 restraint IRs to the Department but only received 68 included the 24Hr and Full report. LPA conducted interviews on 7/1/21 with staff S1 and PD; on 7/8/21 with the Reporting Party; on 7/12/21 with client C1 and on 7/20/21 with C1’s County Social Worker (CSW). CSW stated they requested C1 IRs documentation several times via email since February 2021 and it took a long time for CSW to receive the documentation. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division 6 Chapter One) regulation 80070(d) Client Records. All client records shall be available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit, and copy upon demand during normal business hours. The facility was unable to provide all client records for C1. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division 6 Chapter One) regulation 80075(a) Health Related Services. The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services, including arrangement for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services. The facility did not ensure client C1 received necessary dental services. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Department of Social Services Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards regulation 87095.61(a) Documentation and Reporting Requirements. Each use of manual restraints must be reported to the Department and the child's authorized representative by telephone no later than the next working day following the incident. A written incident report must be submitted to the Department within seven (7) days, as required by California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80061. The facility failed to report manual restraints to the Department or the child’s authorized representative by the next working day following the incident and/or a written incident report to the Department within seven (7) days. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were left at the facility with Gonzalo Arriaga, House Supervisor.

deficiencies.description:
84065 Direct Care Staff / Child Ratio
(a) 	In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children,...direct care staff as follows:(1) 	During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one staff for every three children..., present, at a minimum.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by Based on interviews and record review Program Administrator did not ensure that Direct Staff/ Child Ratio's were met which poses an immediate Health, Safety, Personal Rights risk to youth in care.. narrative: Executive Director, and Administrator. LPA Diaz also reviewed staff file, and association page. Based on the interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation "Staff member does not have fingerprint clearance." is substantiated. LPA Diaz found that the staff member has not been cleared and background check was not filed in their file. LPA Diaz notified Administrator and Executive Director that this staff member may not be on the floor until background check has been cleared. Executive Director immediately removed staff from schedule. Based on LPA's observation and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation(s) " Staff member does not have fingerprint clearance." is found to be Substantiated. California Code of Regulations (CCR); Title 22; Division 6 Chapter 1 80019 (e) (1) are being cited on the LIC9099D. .An immediate civil penalty was assessed in the amount of $500 for up to 5 days max for one staff not being finger print cleared. narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 9/8/23 at 8:15am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Ian Longue, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed one child’s records and six staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed one child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed six staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed one ___child currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. Facility cited Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP Articles 1-10, Regulation 87070(b)(13) Children’s Records and 87065.1(d)(3)(M) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. LPA observed one child's Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) is missing staff initials and three staff files are missing documentation of training on psychotropic medications. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were left at the facility with Ian Longue, Administrator.

deficiencies.description: 87070(b)(13) Children’s Records. The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record:  A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: … Staff initials for each time a psychotropic medication is taken by a child, as an indication that they supervised the child self-administering their psychotropic medication. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During record review LPA observed client C1's Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) is missing staff initals for medication #3 on 9/7/23 at 7pm. This poses a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of training for staff on the Medication Administration Records documentation by 10/8/23.

deficiencies.description: 87065.1(d)(3)(M) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. Notwithstanding California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80065(f)(1) through (6), …new direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8- and 16-hour training as specified in (1) and (2) below: Training shall include, at a minimum, all of the following topics… oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications for children in foster care…. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During record review LPA observed three staff files for S2, S5 and S6 are missing documentation of training on psychotropic medications.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of staff S2, S5 and S6 are trained on psychotropic medications by 10/8/23.

narrative: On 11/29/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Interim Regional Manager Kourtney Hamilton and House Manager Danaye Hall. A tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant was done; LPA interviewed a floor staffer; LPA also discussed the following with Ms. Hamilton and Ms. Hall: -screens on bedroom windows -trash bin covers -cleanliness of client bedrooms -incident reporting During the course of a previous inspection conducted jointly by this LPA and LPA Jacqueline Carmona, Buildings & Grounds issues were observed. Based on these direct observations, General Licensing Requirements Section 80087 is being cited. As a result of a records review and interviews with Progress Ranch personnel, it has been determined that the facility has not been submitting special incident reports to the Department for a period of about two to three weeks; therefore, also being cited in regard to the failure to submit special incident reports is General Licensing Requirements Section 80061(a). Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description: Buildings & Grounds. "The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, a trash bin did not have proper covering, the bedrooms were in disarray, window screens that were supposed to be installed, per facility personnel, were missing. These pose a potential Health, Safety/Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A subsequent visit will be required to clear these deficiencies--the corrective actions will be due by 12/08/2023.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements. "Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department..."
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on a records review and multiple statements from Progress Ranch staff, incident reports have not been submitted for a substantial period in November, 2023. This poses a potential Health, Safety/Personal Rights risk to clients/children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A digital copy of the new Incident Reporting Process (to be implemented on 12/01/2023) as well as signed acknowledgements from direct-care staff of training they have done on this new process will be furnished to this LPA by 12/15/2023.

met_with: Alyssum Maguire, Matt Lemcke, Angie Branham, Kourtney Hamilton
narrative:
On 12/13/2023 Community Care Licensing, Children's Residential Program, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona, Farhaan Sarangi, and Chad Cabigon met with Progress Ranch Executive Director Alyssum Maguire, Director of Operations Matt Lemcke, Clinical Director Dr. Angie Branham, and Regional Manager Kourtney Hamilton for an Informal Meeting/Conference to discuss the following: - Sharp increase in number of complaints between both Progress Ranch locations: per Progress Ranch, part of the reason for this might have been an influx of new employees starting at around June/July of this year (2023) that was, in turn, a consequence of staffing for new facilities and to also bolster the current workforce. · Incident reports (full and 24-hr. notifications alike) not being submitted to CCL: directive for AM & Co. to look into whether or not there were actual reportable incidents that were not even documented at all (which are distinct from IRs being done but just not being submitted ultimately to CCL. · Required records availability: Ask from CCL was to have Progress Ranch implement a protocol wherein required records that Licensing may need are kept in a physical binder that would be readily and easily accessible on request. · Reports of staff not being supported and/or not properly equipped to meet the needs youth · Training: new emergency intervention plan component/element, Ukeru, is being reviewed by the State and, if approved, will be implemented as appliances that are part of the Ukeru system have come in--CC to look into when that program statement section can be sent back, approved, to Progress Ranch. · Key facility positions not filled: AM stated that only the board resolution for each facility administrator is needed to complete the "CCL packet" to re-designate roles to Samuel Ancheta for Chestnut, Danaye Hall for Grove; Mr. Ancheta will be designated both Head of Service (DHCS designation) and Administrator which prevents him from holding any other position. Per AM: Jalisa Chambers will be MHRS for Chestnut, and Sarah Mascardo will be MHRS and HOS for Grove. Plan, for now, is to outsource the Clinical Director position once Dr. Barnham vacates on December 29, 2023. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

·Mental health services not being rendered: per AM, no individual therapy was provided to clients between November 16 - November 26. Per AM, the newly appointed clinician, Joan Bruno, left Progress Ranch on 12/12/2023. · Allowances: it was made clear to Progress Ranch that allowances are due to youth regardless of whether or not they partake in or complete any chores they were assigned, the frequency of the disbursements are to be at least once a month. · Clients’ personal property inventory and safeguarding: according to Progress Ranch, all of the current clients' personal property inventory have been done. · Youth being left unsupervised due to school drop-off that was not coordinated: presently being addressed by a complaint investigation. · General upkeep of physical plant: multiple specific items of concern were discussed and have been addressed/resolved via the complaint investigation and/or case management inspection process. · Co-mingling of youth between the two locations: hospital/emergency packet for each client will be kept at both facilities. · Communication issue(s): intra-organization flow of information: FS suggested that leadership remind floor staff of an open door policy in regard to being approached with concerns/issues. · Groceries – facilities regularly run low on perishables/non-perishables: suggestion is to keep inventory and up the frequency of grocery shopping to at least 2x/week to get a better idea who/how it's being used. · Availability of Progress Ranch personnel for Licensing and/or other agency visits: suggestion from FS--installation and utilization of Ring (or similar) doorbell. Pending exception approval regarding bunk bed set up in Chestnut will be requested for by AM. No citations are being issues as of this time; a copy of this report is being provided to Progress Ranch.
