deficiencies.description:
80022 Plan of Operation	 (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.
This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on records review and interviews conducted LPA Carmona was not able to obtain completed clothing assesment log for all clients in care as stated in the facilities approved Program Statment.Which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA Carmona to receive documentation via email by COB 1/25/24 on how the facility  will ensure to remain in compliance by completing  a clothing assessment on a quarterly basis for all clients in care.

deficiencies.description:
80087(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.

This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on interviews conducted and observations at the time of inspection by LPA Carmona the facility was not sanitary causing there to be odor in the facility.Which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA Carmona to receive documentation via email by COB 1/25/24 on how the facility will ensure to provide all clients in care a clean safe and sanitary facility at all times.

narrative: In one of the confidential interviews conducted on 10/25/23, the youth could not remember what led to the incident and there was no other youth or staff to corroborate the allegations. Records reviewed showed the staff identified in the complaint were not working on the day stated. None of the other staff could corroborate the incident and both staff identified could not recollect the incident. Attempts to contact the Social Worker was not successful. Lastly, records reviewed showed that the alleged staff members were not on shift the day of the incident. Although the allegations that staff hit youth while in care; and that staff inappropriately handled youth while in care may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the House Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/12/23 about 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced complaint investigation visit to deliver finding for these allegations. LPA Ajaero met with Dnaye Hall, the House Manager, and informed her of the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, LPA Ajaero conducted the initial visit at Progress Ranch on 10/17/23 and met with the House Manager. LPA requested incident reports, placement documentation, face sheet, placement dates, case notes, daily log, staff training records, Needs & Services plan, Medical reports, IPP, and CFT notes. LPA Ajaero also request the school address and contact information for all clients in the home. Confidential interviews were conducted between 10/20/23 - 11/07/23.

narrative: On February 8, 2024 at approximately 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi and Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch Treatment Services for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Mental Health Worker, Patricia Button. Prospective Administrator, Danaye Hall arrived 15 minutes later. During the Case Management-Other inspection, LPA observed that the outside screen was taken off and placed on the floor. LPA educated the staff member regarding the importance of having ALL window screens on windows and the importance of ensuring that the Physical Plant of the facility meets Title 22 regulations (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation) No deficiencies were cited during today's Case Management- Other Inspection. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Prospective Administrator, Danaye Hall.

Based on LPAs observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the allegations above cannot be substantiated because inconsistent statements were obtained during the interviews from staff and youth in care. Also, attempts to contact the Social Worker were not successful. In addition, documents requested by LPA were not provided or reviewed during the investigation process. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted with Danaye Hall, House Manager. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights were provided during today’s visit.
investigation_findings: 13On 2.12.24 about 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero conducted an unannounced complaint investigation visit to deliver finding. LPA Ajaero met with Danaye Hall, House Manager and informed her of the purpose of the visit. On 10.16.2023, LPA Monica Roberts visited Progress Ranch Treatment Center and met with Allyson Stogner, Mental Health Worker. LPA Roberts requested a copy of all allowance records from 7.2023 - 9.2023, Therapy notes from all youth from August and September 2023, receipts for incontinence supplies for the past 3 months, staff time punches from September 2023 to October 10, 2023, and procedure for reporting concerns/chain of command. None of these documents were available on-site during the visit. Confidential interviews were conducted between 10.16.23 and 12.13.23.

narrative: On February 26, 2024 at approximately 01:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi, Tatyana Shultz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Rosa Rodriguez arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch Treatment Services for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Deficiencies inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Facility Manager, Danaye Hall and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Deficiencies inspection, LPAs and LPM observed that their was a exposed extension cord running from the top of the awning to the ground (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). Staff unhooked it and stored it during the inspection. In addition, during the tour, LPA observed that their was an exposed electrical outlet in bedroom #3 and the back porch was observed to be dirty and debris was left on the floor (See LIC 809D). An exit interview was conducted at Progress Ranch Treatment Services with Facility Manager, Danae Hall and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Facility Manager. This case management is closed, and the facility has been cited for Buildings and Grounds (See LIC 809D). Appeal Rights have been provided to the Facility Manager.

deficiencies.description:
80087 Buildings and Grounds		  

(a)	The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:

Based on observation, LPAs and LPM observed that their was an exposed electrical outlet in bedroom #3 and the back porch was observed to be dirty and debris was left on the floor.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction: Shall include Licensee filling out an LIC 9098. In addition, Licensee shall conduct staff training to ensure that the facility has electrical fixtures secured and submit the picture to the LPA once repaired. Furthermore, Licensee shall fill out a statement on how future compliance will be met. Plan of Correction due on February 28, 2024.

met_with: Therapeutic Care Worker, Kailah Bickle Facility Manager, Danaye Hall
narrative: On March 5, 2024 at approximately 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch Treatment Services for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Therapeutic Care Worker, Kailah Bickle and was granted access into the facility. Facility Manager, Danaye Hall arrived 15 minutes later. During the Case Management-Other inspection, LPA conducted a tour of the facility with the Facility Manager, LPA and Facility Manager both observed that bedroom #3 has an electrical cover on the socket, but not the correct one, and the wires are still accessible. Furthermore, during this tour, LPA pulled back the living room couch and observed that the electrical cover was not secure which can be a safety risk to the clients in care. Facility Manager requested to also send the pictures to the work phone. LPA sent the pictures to the Facility Manager work phone. LPA provided Technical Assistance (See LIC 9102-Technical Assistance) regarding Regulation 80087(a). Facility Manager understood the regulation and the Technical Assistance provided during today's inspection. LPA granted an extension of a citation that was originally issued on February 26, 2024. Progress Ranch Treatment Services has an extension until March 8, 2024 to correct the deficiency. If this deficiency is not corrected by March 8, 2024, Civil Penalties will be assessed. No deficiencies were cited during today's Case Management- Other Inspection. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Facility Manager, Danaye Hall.

On March 5, 2024 at approximately 01:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch Treatment Services for the purpose of conducting a POC inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Mental Health Worker, Logan Hungrige and was granted access into the facility. During the POC inspection, LPA toured the facility and found the previously cited deficiencies to be completed and addressed. Accordingly, this Plan of Correction (POC) has been completed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Mental Health Worker, Logan Hungrige.

Though specific recollected details were inconsistently described, four interviewees corroborated that a child in care was, in some way, dragged into the youth’s bedroom by a direct-care staff-person during an incident in which the child was escalated, trying to abscond, and assaultive to staff and/or to themselves. Regarding the insect/pest control matter, Progress Ranch has provided documentation of a pest control service being maintained to try to address corroborating reports of pests on facility premises; however, the issue persists in the interior living spaces of the facility--and while some interventions have been used, more measures can be taken to deter, in particular, cockroaches from entering the house. Based on LPA’s interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegations are found to be Substantiated. California Department of Social Services Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87095.01(b) and General Licensing Requirements Section 80087(a)(1) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099-D. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/12/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Grove House Manager Danaye Hall and Interim Regional Manager Kourtney Hamilton to whom the following report was discussed: LPA opened the investigation on 09/07/2023, during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant was done; on the same day LPA interviewed children and staff; records requested were the following: all iterations of the Needs & Services Plans of all youth in placement at the time, pest control service receipts, and contact information for direct-care staff and other personnel who have had interactions with youth. Additional interviews and subsequent onsite inspections were conducted in the ensuing time. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
Emergency Interventions Prohibition.
"[A]ny emergency intervention technique not approved for use as part of the licensee's emergency intervention plan must not be used at any time." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on corroborating statements, a direct-care staff-person physically dragged, in some way, a child in care during an escalated situation. This poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personnel decisions will be made regarding the involved staff-person. At minimum, re-training and some form of remediation will be done. Documentation of the decided-upon course of action will be provided to CCL by 01/01/2024.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings and Grounds.
"The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects."
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on corroborating statements, cockroaches and "water bugs" have been observed in the facility's interior areas and have been reported to come through plumbing like the kitchen sink drain. This poses a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plans and/or service receipts are to be submitted on the chemical treatment of the interior of the facility (for pests/insects), on plumbing checks/work (for potential leakeage/entryways for cockroaches), and/or other measures to address the presence of unwanted insects in the facility.

narrative:
Interviews conducted confirmed that on 11/17/2023, on an “early-out” school day, two facility youths were dropped off at the facility by their school bus driver without the driver confirming whether or not there was staff on the premises. Including the two children referenced in the complaint, all parties with knowledge of the incident in question corroborated that the children were left unsupervised at the facility for a time period of approximately two hours—from the drop-off time to when a Progress Ranch staffer finally arrived at the facility. Based on LPAs interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be Substantiated. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06 (Continuing Requirements) Section 80078(a) (Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099-D. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.

As for the allegation that the facility did not have an administrator, though the recognized administrator’s role within the organization had changed, that individual’s credentials were maintained and, according to obtained statements, responsibilities were shared between that listed administrator and the incoming one through that transition period. However, there were inconsistencies in the statements regarding whether operational tasks were actually carried out in practice. Regarding mental health services personnel, based on interviews, statements from staff and youth were inconsistent on how mental health treatment as a core service was provided. Finally, though obtained statements were consistent regarding the MHRS’ (Mental Health Rehabilitation Specialist) workload becoming more difficult to manage because of a shortage of personnel who held that position, the conducted interviews yielded inconsistent information about how or if the care for the children was negatively affected by this. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/02/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Radiance Clinton, Administrator, and the following report was discussed: LPA Jacqueline Carmona opened the investigation on 11/20/2023 during which time interviews were conducted with the children referenced in the complaint and staff. The interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant were toured. Relevant facility records were requested. Additional interviews were conducted by LPA Cabigon. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision.
"The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on corroborating statements, two children were left unsupervised after school transportation dropped off the clients at the facility with no Progress Ranch staff on premises. This poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Policy changes have already been implemented to ensure staffing is present at the facility at all times regardless of whether clients are on the premises. Facility to provide written documentation that officializes the policy change (program statement update, memo, etc.) Due on 4/5.

narrative:
Statements obtained via conducted interviews corroborated that a disclosure was made to facility staff alleging inappropriate interaction had occurred between children. A file search by this LPA of submitted reports from the facility yielded no submissions from Progress Ranch about this particular disclosure. LPA requested that the facility conduct a search of their records for the report—Progress Ranch indicated that no such report was found in their files. Based on LPA’s interviews and a review of records, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be Substantiated. No citation is necessary as incident reporting deficiencies were already cited on a case management inspection conducted on 11/30/2023. A copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.

No interview was possible with the alleged perpetrator in the reported incident; there were no other identified potential witnesses to the incident, and as such no one interviewed corroborated the accusation as described. As for whether the facility did enough to mitigate the likelihood of such an interaction from taking place, corroborating statements from current and former staffers indicate that enough was known at the time to have informed facility management that either closer supervision was necessary or a better bedroom-sharing arrangement should have been in place. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/02/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Radiance Clinton, Administrator, and the following report was discussed: The investigation was opened on 11/29/2023 at the facility, during which time a walk-through of the interior and exterior areas of the physical plant was done. Interviews were conducted with staff and one child in care. Records reviewed as part of the investigation were the following: children’s Needs & Services Plans and the facility’s Program Statement. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: During unannounced inspections on 11/29/2023 and 01/12/2024, LPA did not observe any sharp objects to be accessible—the sharps were secured in a locked cabinet in an intermediate space between the kitchen and the adjacent multi-purpose room, the door to which was also locked from the inside of the facility. Statements obtained during the investigation were inconsistent as to whether there was an actual knife involved; according to the direct-care staff on the premises at the time of the incident, a knife was never in possession of either of the clients, and the only thing that a youth got a hold of was a piece of plastic that broke off of a TV encasement that was damaged as an outcome of that client’s aggression—this was corroborated by the perpetrating youth. By all accounts, neither of the children were physically harmed; both youth stated that the intervening staff was able to keep the clients away from each other. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/19/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Clinical Data Manager Ian Longue and the following report was discussed: The complaint investigation was opened on 11/29/2023 at the facility, during which time interviews were conducted with staff and a youth in care. A physical plant inspection was also conducted on the same day which resulted in no observed deficiencies; another unannounced Buildings & Grounds onsite inspection was conducted on 01/12/2024. Subsequent interviews were conducted with another youth and additional Progress Ranch staffers. Needs & Services Plans and incident reports were reviewed as part of the investigation. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: Furthermore, the Local Law Enforcement jurisdiction investigating the case determined there was not enough evidence to support further investigation at this time. LPA conducted additional interviews with additional clients in care and staff members in question. During the interviews, LPA learned that no concerns were disclosed by the parties involved and there were no witness. As a result, the allegation above cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements made throughout the course of the investigation process. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to House Supervisor, Radiance Clinton.
investigation_findings: 13On May, 22 2024 at approximately 01:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Farhaan Sarangi and Tatyana Shultz arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch Treatment Services for the purposes of delivering complaint findings. LPA met with House Supervisor, Radiance Clinton, and was granted access into the facility. During the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check and facility personnel report summary. Department of Social Services-Community Care Licensing Division-Investigations Branch, Investigator Barajas interviewed the alleged victim client and bio mother during the Assignment. Based on a confidential interview conducted by Investigator Barajas, it was determined that an upgrade to a full investigation will not be conducted due to lack of sexual abuse disclosure. (Report continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: Furthermore, the Local Law Enforcement jurisdiction investigating the case decided to suspend the investigation due to lack of sexual abuse disclosure. LPA conducted additional interviews with additional clients in care, a staff member and other party involved. During the interviews, LPA learned that no concerns were disclosed by the parties involved and nobody witnessed the incident of any inappropriate behavior occurring at the facility. As a result, the allegation above cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements made throughout the course of the investigation process. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to House Supervisor, Radiance Clinton.
investigation_findings: 13On May, 22 2024 at approximately 01:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Farhaan Sarangi and Tatyana Shultz arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch Treatment Services for the purposes of delivering complaint findings. LPA met with House Supervisor, Radiance Clinton, and was granted access into the facility. During the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check and facility personnel report summary. Department of Social Services-Community Care Licensing Division-Investigations Branch, Investigator Barajas interviewed the alleged victim client and bio mother, CSW and a Police Officer during the Assignment. Based on a confidential interview conducted by Investigator Barajas, it was determined that an upgrade to a full investigation will not be conducted due to alleged victim recanting the allegation and making the complaint out of anger. (Report continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: On June 28, 2024, at approximately 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived at Progress Ranch Treatment Services announced for a voluntary facility closure, and met with the Administrator, Ian Longue. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received notification via email requesting a closure of the facility and stated that there were no clients in care. The Administrator notified Community Care Licensing of intent to close this facility on June 3, 2024 via email. Closure plans were forwarded to CCL for review. Administrator notified CCL that the facility will be closing on June 27, 2024. The licensee initiated this facility closure. LPA Sarangi inspected all rooms and the exterior of the building and found no evidence that would suggest that clients are residing on the premises. In addition, LPA observed that the facility is being remodeled. LPA observed moving boxes around the facility. All clothing and personal items belonging to clients have been removed. Clients that were living in the home have been relocated. LPA obtained the license for the facility. Facility closed effective June 27, 2024. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator, Ian Longue.

One out of the two interviews conducted confirmed that staff hit minor in care, staff kicked minor in care, and staff handled minor in care in a rough manner but there were no additional witnesses or clients to confirm the allegation took place. During the investigation LPA Turner was informed by the client in care that all staff members participated in burning the client on their stomach. The client informed LPA Turner that they were repeatedly kicked in the face and stomach. The client informed that staff members spat on them. C1 was unable to provide staff information during the investigation process. LPA Turner was informed by the administrator that permitted restraint was used by staff following the Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) plan. The permitted restraint consisted of holding the arms and seating clients in care. LPA Turner was informed that if the restraint was not working with two staff members, then a third staff member was called in to assist. It was confirmed by the administrator that staff never placed objects in a client's mouth. LPA Turner was informed that the client in care dealt with suicidal thoughts and harmed themselves on occasion. The client in care caused self-inflicted trauma to their head and staff used their hands to prevent injury. The client in care kicked and hit staff when they became upset, and staff intervened by using restraints. Lastly, LPA Turner was notified by the administrator that staff were often afraid to restrain the client in care due to accusations made by the client. The client frequently lied to get staff in trouble. LPA Turner was informed that the client went AWOL often and would advise the neighbors of alleged abuse taking place within the facility. The neighbors contacted Law Enforcement but no signs of abuse, such as marks or bruising, were documented during their investigation. LPA Turner was unable to contact former employees during the investigation process due to the above facility being closed. LPA Turner was unable to attain additional information from the reporting party after multiple attempts. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and will be provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2025 at approximately 9:57 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit to TSCF Progress Ranch Welcome Center to deliver findings to the above facility and met with Case Manager, Jake Caballero. Prior to the meeting LPA Turner initiated the complaint investigation on October 22, 2024. LPA Turner requested the following documents: Staff Schedule, Staff Roster, Client Roster, Needs and Services plan, and IBSP for one client in care. LPA Turner conducted two interviews between October 22, 2024 and December 10, 2024. Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation(s) cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements throughout the investigation process. Report continued on LIC 9099-C

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 9/22/20 at 9:00am. During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Ian longue, Program Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA Stidman prior to the inspection. A medication count was also conducted by Microsoft Teams on this date. LPA reviewed three child’s records prior to this inspection on 9/14/20 and 9/15/20. LPA reviewed three staff personnel files prior to this inspection on 9/14/20, 9/15/20 and 9/21/20. LPA interviewed three staff on site at 9:00am. LPA interviewed three children currently taking psychotropic medications at 9:00am. No deficiencies being cited at this time. One Advisory Notes for a Technical Violation were given. LPA conducted exit interview with Ian Longue, Program Manager at 11:00am. LPA provided the Summary Report to Ian Longue, Program Manager upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date.

On 1/22/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced tele inspection of the facility with Ian Longue Program Manager via Microsoft Teams to conduct the Post Licensing Inspection. LPA reviewed four staff files and six client files(see LIC859 and LIC858). Staff record reviews confirm files for S3 and S4 are missing documentation of medical assessment and tuberculosis test within one year prior to or seven days after employment. S2 and S4 staff files are missing documentation of a current CPR and First Aid certificates. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80065(g)(1) Personnel Requirements. All personnel, including the licensee, administrator and volunteers, shall be in good health, and shall be physically, mentally, and occupationally capable of performing assigned tasks. (1) Except as specified in 80065(g)(3) , good physical health shall be verified by a health screening, including a test for tuberculosis, performed by or under the supervision of a physician not more than one year prior to or seven days after employment or licensure. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80075(f) Health Related Services. Staff responsible for providing direct care and supervision shall receive training in first aid from persons qualified by agencies including but not limited to the American Red Cross. Record review confirm client file for C6 is missing documentation of the results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis . Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessment. The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80069(a) prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client. The medical assessment shall include the results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases.

Record review confirm client files for C2 and C4 are missing Identification and Emergency information. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80070(b)(5) Client Records Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: Names, addresses, and telephone numbers of the authorized representative. Record review confirm client files for C1, C2 and C4 are missing a signed admission agreement. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80070(b)(6)Client Records Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: A signed copy of the admission agreement specified in Section 80068. See LIC809D for citations. Due to the State of Emergency and shelter-in-place ordinance put into place by the Governor of California as safety protection relating to the Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19), the department is limiting in-person contact. This inspection was conducted electonicall. LPA provided the Summary Report to Ian Longue Program Manager upon completion by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA with their signature on this date.

On 7/29/2021 at 9:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) N. Sanders and Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducing annual/required inspection. LPAs met with Ian Longe, Program Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. The facility is licensed for six clients. At this point there are five clients in care. The facility license, personal rights, facility sketch and an emergency disaster plan are posted at the entrance of the facility. There are three bedrooms, three bathrooms, two living rooms,a kitchen and a dining room in this facility. Each bedroom has tow beds, dressers and a closet space. Mattresses are clean and in good repair. Living rooms are filled with toys, board games,and other age appropriate activities. LPAs observed that TV was broken and requested to take a broken TV off the wall. LPAs observed that carpets were dirty and requested a deep cleaning. there are extra towels and linens for the clients. Kitchen is filled with utensils plates, cups and cooking pots and pants. there are two days of perishable and seven days of non perishable food. LPAs observed a lot of expired food and requested the facility to go though their food supplies and throw away expired food. LPAs observed that perishables were open and were not saved properly. LPAs requested for perishable food to be saved in containers or zip lock bags and have labels on them of the date they were opened. Cleaning supplies and poisons are locked in a cabinet in the staff room. The backyard s clean and free of clutter. There is a play set, storage bins for the toys and a shed filled with garden tools and broken items. The shed remains locked at all times. LPAs reviewed five clients files.

LPAs observed the clients files were unorganized and missing required documentation. facility was cited for: ILS 87069.1(a) Medications: one client's file was missing immunization form CCR 8026(h) Safeguards for Cash Resources , Personal Property, and Valuables. It was observed that three out of five children's files were missing documentation about their valuables and personal properties. ILS 87072(d) Personal Rights : one client was missing signed personal rights ILS 87068.3(a) Modifications to Needs and Services Plan: five out of five clients are missing quarterly updates for their Needs and Services plans. Four out of five clients are missing original Needs and Services Plans. Technical Violations (TV) were issued for: CCR 80069(a) -Client Assessment: 30 day medical assessment were done several months after their placement. narrative: On 8/2/2021 at 9:00am Licensing Program Analyst N. Sanders arrived at Progress Ranch Main office located at 1949 5th St. Davis, CA 95616 to conduct annual/continuation inspection for Chestnut House, license number 577005990. LPA met with Mikey Martin, Administrative Assistant and explained the reason for the inspection. The facility has an Administrator, six full time staff and one full time Social Worker. LPA reviewed six staff, social worker's and administrator's files. Staff files have Personal Records, Clearance Records, Child Abuse Index, Job Application Records, Health Screening and TB tests, Criminal Record Statements and Employee Rights. Five employees have expired First Aid Certificates. Facility is cited for ILS 87065.1 (8) Training Requirements. LPA observed that Executive Director's files are not well organized. Technical Violation (TV) was issued for Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, 80066(a): Personal Records. TV is not a citation but may result if the facility does not follow given directions. A copy of this file and appeal rights were left with Mikey Martin, Administrative Assistant.

On 12/10/21 at 9:30 AM, an announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Stefanie Whitlow and Hillary Hall, at STRTP (provisional) Progress Ranch Facility. LPA’s first met Director, Alyssum McGuire, at administration office located at 1949 5th Street Suite 103. Davis, Ca 95616. LPA’s interviewed one administrator. LPA’s reviewed five children’s records. LPA’s reviewed three staff’s records. LPA observed court documentation and signatures on NSP’s of client and authorized representatives missing from NSP’s. See the two Advisory Notes- Technical Violation. LPA’s then conducted inspection of the STRTP home located at address above at 2:00 PM. The facility was inspected inside and out. There were no deficiencies noted. LPA’s interviewed seven children. LPA’s interviewed two staff. LPA’s will complete continuation inspection on 12/13/21. LPA’s conducted exit interview with Gonzall Arriaga, supervisor, who signed the LIC 809. Appeal rights were not explained, as no citations were given. LPA provided the Summary Report, upon completion, by email.

On 12/13/21 at 10:00 AM, an announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Stefanie Whitlow and Hillary Hall, at STRTP (provisional) Progress Ranch Treatment Services Facility located at address above. LPA’s conducted medication count and PMAR comparison. In addition, LPA’s met Director, Alyssum Maguire, at administration office located at 1949 5th Suite 103. Davis, Ca 95616, at 1:30 PM. LPA’s interviewed one administrator. LPA’s reviewed two children’s records. Since initial inspection, on 12/10/21, children’s records had been updated. LPA’s will, therefore, be conducting a follow-up review of them when inspection is continued. There are no citations being given at this time. LPA’s conducted exit interview with Alyssum Maquire. LPA provided the Summary Report, upon completion, by email, to be signed and returned.

On 12/15/21 at 10:30 AM, an announced continuation SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Stefanie Whitlow and Hillary Hall, at STRTP (provisional) Progress Ranch Treatment Services Facility administration office located at 1949 5th Suite 103. Davis, CA 95616 at 10:30 AM. LPA’s reviewed four clients’ records. LPA’s reviewed three staff records. Since initial inspection, on 12/10/21, children’s and staff records had been updated. LPA’s, therefore, conducted a follow-up review of them on this date: Two clients records out of four reviewed had no client signature or authorized representative signature on the Needs and Service Plans. Two clients’ records reviewed out of four had no indication the client participated in developing the Needs and Services Plan. One client did not have a Needs and Services Plan completed until more than 90 days after placement. One client record reviewed out of four had no record of receiving mental health services. One client record out of four had a non-psychotropic medication listed on a PMAR. One client out of four was lacking two separate PMAR’s for different dosages of the medication, Aripiprazole. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87068.2(a)(d) Social work staff shall...develop an individual needs and services plan, within 30 days of placement, for the child that meets the requirements. (d)The licensee shall ensure and document that the child, and his/her authorized representative(s), and the child and family team were offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and services plan (NSP). There is no indication the client participated in created the NSP. Continued on 809C

Continued from 809 ...The facility failed to get the authorized representative's signature for client's NSP. Facility Citation violation of CCR Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 80070(a)(13): ... The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: Documentation of all mental health services received by a child, to include the services received, the name of the mental health entity, and the date services were provided. Facility citation violation of CCR Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) ILS Section 87070(b)(12)(G)(1): The licensee shall ensure a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: The name of the medication. The date of the prescription. The quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed.... The required dosage and directions for use as specified in writing by the physician prescribing the medication, including any changes directed by the physician. The date and time of each dose taken by the child. LPA’s conducted exit interview with Ian Longue, Administrator, who signed the LIC 809. A plan of correction was developed and appeal rights were explained. LPA’s provided the Summary Report and appeal rights upon completion, by email.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 9/21/22 at 9:30am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Stidman met with Ian Longue, Program Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed three child’s records and four staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed three child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed four staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed three children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. Facility cited violation of California Interim Licensing Standards 87070(b)(12) Children’s Records. Based upon records reviewed one child’s records is missing current JV 223 forms authorizing the use of psychotropic medications and another client is receiving a higher dosage of a psychotropic medication than allowed. Facility cited violation of California STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87070(b)(13)(C) Children’s Records. Based upon records reviewed one child’s records the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) is missing the quantity of medication initially prescribed for both medications. Facility cited violation of California STRTP ILS 87090(h)(1)(F) Initial Certification Training Program Vendor and Program Approval Requirements. Based upon file review for one staff is missing documentation of the Administrator Certification training topics for psychotropic medications. Facility cited violation of California STRTP ILS 87068.3(a) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan (NSP). Based upon file review for three clients the NSP have not been updated within 30 days. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Ian Longue, Program Manager.

Whether it would be a small bruise or scratches. Client stated that most marks are not visible. However, clients agreed that staff does not intentionally hurt them, and they understood that at times a restraint is not perfect because they are trying to get out of it. Some clients stated they have tried to fight their way out of a restraint. All clients did state they feel safe in the home. Although, staff has denied the allegation, LPA Diaz did physically see scratches on one of the client’s arms. LPA Diaz took pictures of their arms on the state issued Iphone. Furthermore, LPA Diaz read through facility’s program statement regarding their Emergency Intervention Plan. On page 346 it states, “The restraints must not cause injury to the child.” LPA Diaz was able to identify five nail marks on client’s right forearm. Nail marks had been scabbed over by the time LPA Diaz saw them, but where still visible. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANCIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Article 10.1 are being cited on the attached LIC9099D. An exit interview was conducted with Ian Longue, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed.

deficiencies.description:
87095.01(a)(11) Emergency Interventions Prohibition (a)11 Techniques that can reasonably be expected to cause serious injuries to the child that require medical treatment provided by a health practitioner, licensed under Division 2 of the Business and Professions Code.  A health practitioner would include a physician, surgeon, osteopath, dentist, licensed nurse, optometrist, etc. This requirment is not met as evidenced by:
Based on observation and interview,the
licensee did not ensure staff to use a safe technique when restraining C1 due to visible marks on C1's arms which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risks to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Administrator had staff members ensure to have nails kept at a safe length. 
Administrator stated that correction was done with staff and will email LPA Diaz along with CPI training materials. A detailed written plan of correction will be submitted indicating how the facility will prevent this type of incident from reoccurring. Administrator to email LPA Diaz on 12/01/2022

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dawn Eunice (LPA) conducted a case management visit for the purpose of ensuring compliance with Health and Safety Codes and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) related to an incident involving a restraint. LPA toured the facility; it is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair; the incident report was well written and clear. Additionally, LPA interviewed the administrator and the staff involved in the incident. LPA interviewed the child. The incident (on 4-8-2023) involved a child who was unable to attend an outing for safety reasons. The child escalated. The child was banging their head onto the wall, punching themselves, then threatening self harm. The arm hold began at 2:27pm and ended at 2:30 p.m. The child's behavior became more unsafe, so, staff placed the child into a team hold from 2:31pm to 2:48pm. Intermediate check-in occurred with management staff. Staff offered the child with self soothing techniques, space, and when the child asked for food, food was given. Staff interviewed state that no such intervention has been required since the date of the incident. Based on LPA's interviews, review of incident reports and facility inspection, no ILS nor Health and Safety Code violations were found. (See LIC 812's for confidential interviews)

met_with: Alyssum Maguire, Executive Director, Ian Longue, Administrator, and Andrea Guthrie, Clinical Director
narrative:

Children’s Control Position d. Team Control Position 4. Administrator spoke about CPI training 5. LPM and LPA went over Progress Ranch Program Statement Section: Emergency Intervention Plan. Report continues on LIC 809-C

6. Administrator went over small child hold and LPM stated that there must be two people doing holds at all time. Per their CPI training the holds are based on the children’s sizes and at times the small child hold requires one staff. This is a therapeutic hold. 7. LPM, and LPA will attend a CPI training sometime in the beginning of 2023 to understand and have more knowledge of what CPI training is. 8. LPM, and LPA will set up a follow-up meeting with Progress Ranch end of January or beginning of February 2023.

The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following: LPA observed one out of three client files reviewed was missing the updated Needs and Services Plans. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During record review for client C1 LPA observed the Needs and Services Plan (NSP) for March and April 2023 were dated 2/15/23.

narrative: On 11/30/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met, initially, with House Supervisor Samuel Ancheta, then with Interim Regional Manager Kourtney Hamilton. A tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant was done; LPA interviewed staff; LPA also discussed the following with Ms. Hamilton: -screens on bedroom windows -window covers/curtains -unsanitary conditions of bathrooms, fixture(s) being in disrepair -bunk bed in a client room -incident reporting During the course of a previous inspection conducted jointly by this LPA and LPA Jacqueline Carmona, Buildings & Grounds issues were observed. Based on these direct observations, General Licensing Requirements Section 80087 is being cited. Also as a result of a records review and interviews with Progress Ranch personnel, it has been determined that the facility has not been submitting special incident reports to the Department for a period of about two to three weeks; therefore, also being cited in regard to the failure to submit special incident reports is General Licensing Requirements Section 80061(a). Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description: Buildings & Grounds. "The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, window screens supposed to be installed, per facility personnel, were missing, a bathroom was in need of repair/cleaning, and a trash bin did not have a lid. These pose a potential Health, Safety/Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A subsequent visit will be required to clear these deficiencies--the corrective actions will be due by 12/08/2023.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements. "Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department..."
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on a records review and multiple statements from Progress Ranch staff, incident reports have not been submitted for a substantial period in November, 2023. This poses a potential Health, Safety/Personal Rights risk to clients/children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A digital copy of the new Incident Reporting Process (to be implemented on 12/01/2023) as well as signed acknowledgements from direct-care staff of training they have done on this new process will be furnished to this LPA by 12/15/2023.

met_with: Alyssum Maguire, Matt Lemcke, Angie Barnham, Kourtney Hamilton
narrative:
On 12/13/2023 Community Care Licensing, Children's Residential Program, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona, Farhaan Sarangi, and Chad Cabigon met with Progress Ranch Executive Director Alyssum Maguire, Director of Operations Matt Lemcke, Clinical Director Dr. Angie Branham, and Regional Manager Kourtney Hamilton for an Informal Meeting/Conference to discuss the following: - Sharp increase in number of complaints between both Progress Ranch locations: per Progress Ranch, part of the reason for this might have been an influx of new employees starting at around June/July of this year (2023) that was, in turn, a consequence of staffing for new facilities and to also bolster the current workforce. · Incident reports (full and 24-hr. notifications alike) not being submitted to CCL: directive for AM & Co. to look into whether or not there were actual reportable incidents that were not even documented at all (which are distinct from IRs being done but just not being submitted ultimately to CCL. · Required records availability: Ask from CCL was to have Progress Ranch implement a protocol wherein required records that Licensing may need are kept in a physical binder that would be readily and easily accessible on request. · Reports of staff not being supported and/or not properly equipped to meet the needs youth · Training: new emergency intervention plan component/element, Ukeru, is being reviewed by the State and, if approved, will be implemented as appliances that are part of the Ukeru system have come in--CC to look into when that program statement section can be sent back, approved, to Progress Ranch. · Key facility positions not filled: AM stated that only the board resolution for each facility administrator is needed to complete the "CCL packet" to re-designate roles to Samuel Ancheta for Chestnut, Danaye Hall for Grove; Mr. Ancheta will be designated both Head of Service (DHCS designation) and Administrator which prevents him from holding any other position. Per AM: Jalisa Chambers will be MHRS for Chestnut, and Sarah Mascardo will be MHRS and HOS for Grove. Plan, for now, is to outsource the Clinical Director position once Dr. Barnham vacates on December 29, 2023. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

·Mental health services not being rendered: per AM, no individual therapy was provided to clients between November 16 - November 26. Per AM, the newly appointed clinician, Joan Bruno, left Progress Ranch on 12/12/2023. · Allowances: it was made clear to Progress Ranch that allowances are due to youth regardless of whether or not they partake in or complete any chores they were assigned, the frequency of the disbursements are to be at least once a month. · Clients’ personal property inventory and safeguarding: according to Progress Ranch, all of the current clients' personal property inventory have been done. · Youth being left unsupervised due to school drop-off that was not coordinated: presently being addressed by a complaint investigation. · General upkeep of physical plant: multiple specific items of concern were discussed and have been addressed/resolved via the complaint investigation and/or case management inspection process. · Co-mingling of youth between the two locations: hospital/emergency packet for each client will be kept at both facilities. · Communication issue(s): intra-organization flow of information: FS suggested that leadership remind floor staff of an open door policy in regard to being approached with concerns/issues. · Groceries – facilities regularly run low on perishables/non-perishables: suggestion is to keep inventory and up the frequency of grocery shopping to at least 2x/week to get a better idea who/how it's being used. · Availability of Progress Ranch personnel for Licensing and/or other agency visits: suggestion from FS--installation and utilization of Ring (or similar) doorbell. Pending exception approval regarding bunk bed set up in Chestnut will be requested for by AM. No citations are being issues as of this time; a copy of this report is being provided to Progress Ranch.

met_with: Therapeutic Care Worker, Patricia Button Mental Health Worker, Patricia Tinajera
narrative: On December 21, 2023 at approximately 02:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident Inspection. LPA was met at the door by Therapeutic Care Worker, Patricia Button, and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Incident Inspection, LPA received an incident report on December 17, 2023 indicating that a client was given an additional dose of medication on December 7, 2023. Clients physician was contacted and instructions were given to staff (See LIC 809D). Deficiencies cited from the California Code of Regulations. Appeal rights were given. Failure to correct the deficiency and/or repeated deficiencies within a 12-month period may result in civil penalties. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Mental Health Worker, Patricia Tinajera.

deficiencies.description:
87075(c) Health Related Services:

(c)	Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(13). This requirement was not met as evidenced by:

Based on review of an incident report dated for December 17, 2023, client was given an additional dose of medication on December 7, 2023. Clients physician was contacted and instructions were given to staff.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction: Shall include Licensee filling out an LIC 9098. In addition, Licensee shall conduct staff training to ensure that clients are getting proper medication administered. Furthermore, Licensee shall fill out a statement on how future compliance will be met. Plan of Correction due on: December 26, 2023.
