investigation_findings: 13On January 22, 2024 at approximately 01:00 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Farhaan Sarangi and Sara Luman-Gonzalez conducted a complaint investigation inspection at Progress Ranch: Chestnut and met with Regional Manager, Kourtney Hamilton for the purpose of delivering findings. During the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports and facility personnel report summary. LPA also reviewed client files. LPA Sarangi conducted interviews with staff and children in placement. Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process, LPA received inconsistent statements and could not corroborate the allegation. Furthermore, LPA interviewed the child in question and learned that during the incident, the child went to smell the food and accidentally sustained a small burn to the lip. LPA interviewed the staff member that was on duty that day and learned that the statements made by the child were consistent with the statement made by the staff member. (Report continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative:
Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation is being substantiated because 8 out of 13 confidential interviews corroborated staff did not ensure minors have adequate clothing. On 11/17/23 LPA Carmona observed there was no adequate amount of clothing in the client’s bedroom. In addition, LPA Carmona was not able to obtain completed quarterly clothing assessments for all clients in care based on the approved Program Statement Section 21 by the Department. Based on interviews conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) are being cited on the attached LIC9099D. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to House Supervisor.

Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements given during the confidential interviews. 12 confidential interviews conducted corroborated that there was an adequate supply of perishable foods in the facility. During a visit to the facility on 11/17/23 LPA Carmona observed more than 2 days of perishable food. In addition, an image provided to the department of the perishable food in a refrigerator was only one of the 2 refrigerators located in the facility. 12 confidential interviews also corroborated the facility staff are meeting minor's incontinence needs. In addition, LPA Carmona observed incontinence needs supplies in the facility during the inspection visit on 11/17/23. 8 confidential interviews corroborated the facility is free of odors. Lastly, LPA Carmona did not witness any odor during the inspection visit on 11/17/23. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the House Supervisor.
investigation_findings: 13On 1/18/24 at approximately 12:30 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona conducted an unannounced visit to the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver findings for the allegations noted above. LPA Carmona met with Radiance Clinton, House Supervisor. During the investigation, LPA Carmona reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history and criminal background check for staff. LPA Carmona also reviewed the client’s needs and service plans, LIC9020, LIC500, emails dated 10/02/23-10/12/23, staff schedule, clothing assessment, program statement sec 21, and grocery list receipt record for October 2023. LPA Carmona conducted 13 confidential interviews and LPA Cabigon conducted 3 confidential interviews between 11/01/23-12/14/23. Continue to page

deficiencies.description:
80022 Plan of Operation  (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.
This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on records review and interviews conducted LPA Carmona was not able to obtain completed clothing assessment log for all clients in care as stated in the facilities approved Program Statement.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA Carmona to receive documentation via email by COB 1/25/24 on how the facility  will ensure to remain in compliance by completing  a clothing assessment on a quarterly basis for all clients in care.

narrative: On February 9, 2024 at approximately 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other Inspection. LPAs met with House Manager, Radiance Clinton and was granted access into the facility. Upon entry into the facility, LPAs observed that a facility window was shattered (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). LPA educated the staff member regarding the importance of having ALL window screens on windows and the importance of ensuring that the Physical Plant of the facility meets Title 22 regulations. No deficiencies were cited during today's Case Management-Other inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the House Manager, Radiance Clinton.

"AMENDED" This is an amended version of the original report created on February 8, 2024-SEE BELOW. On February 8, 2024 at approximately 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Deficiencies Inspection. LPAs met with House Manager, Radiance Clinton and was granted access into the facility. During the Case Management-Deficiencies Inspection LPA received an incident report on February 7, 2024 reporting that a client was given one less dose of medication on February 6, 2024. Clients physician was contacted and instructions were given to staff (See LIC 809D). LPAs requested the following documents: -Medication Count Sheet(s) -Medication Administration Record (MAR) for said date Deficiencies cited from the California Code of Regulations. Civil Penalty in the amount of $250.00 was assessed. Civil Penalty Appeal rights and Appeal Rights were given. Failure to correct the deficiency and/or repeated deficiencies within a 12-month period may result in additional Civil Penalties. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was signed and given to the House Manager, Radiance Clinton.

deficiencies.description:
87075(c) Health Related Services:

(c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(13). This requirement was not met as evidenced by:

Based on review of an incident report dated for February 7, 2024, LPA received an incident report on February 7, 2024 indicating that a client was given one less dose of medication on February 6, 2024. Clients physician was contacted and instructions were given to staff.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction: Shall include Licensee filling out an LIC 9098. In addition, Licensee shall conduct staff training to ensure that clients are getting proper medication administered. Furthermore, Licensee shall fill out a statement on how future compliance will be met. Plan of Correction due on: February 12, 2024.

deficiencies.description:
87092(b)  Penalties: 	  

(b) 	Unless otherwise ordered by the Department, all penalties are due and payable upon receipt of notice of payment, and shall be paid only by money order or cashier's check made payable to the Department. (c) 	The Department shall have authority to file a claim in a court of competent jurisdiction or to take other appropriate action for failure to pay penalties as specified in (b) above.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction: The Department will submit an invoice to the Agency to advise where payment should be sent.

met_with: Therapeutic Care Worker, Patricia Button House Supervisor, Radiance Clinton Clinical Data Manager, Ian Longue
narrative: On February 21, 2024 at approximately 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident Inspection. LPA was met at the door by Therapeutic Care Worker, Patricia Button, and was granted access into the facility. Management staff arrived 40 minutes later. During the Case Management-Incident inspection, LPA interviewed a client in care and a staff member. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility and observed the facility to be clean with all exits free from obstruction. LPA observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable foods. Food menu was also observed on the refrigerator. LPA requested the following document: -Incident Report dated for February 12, 2024 LPA reviewed the Incident Report dated for February 12, 2024 (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation) which reflected the incident in question. During the review of the incident report, LPA noted that the child did express fear of being alone in the dark in the bedroom. However, the former staff member closed the door. This incident was observed by another staff member who reported it to management. Incident report noted that there were no night lights. Former staff member was terminated. LPA requested termination documents to be sent via email. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was signed and given to the Administrator. This Case Management Investigation is now closed, and the facility has been cited for Personal Rights (See LIC 809D). Appeals Rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights:
(c)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable:

(16) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:

Based on a review of the incident report, the child expressed fear of being alone in the dark room to the former staff member. However, the Former Staff Member still ended up closing the door on the client. This incident was witnessed by another staff member. This violation presents an immediate Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction: Shall include Licensee filling out an LIC 9098. In addition, Licensee shall conduct staff training to ensure that clients are being afforded Personal Rights. Furthermore, Licensee shall fill out a statement on how future compliance will be met. Plan of Correction due on: February 28, 2024.

narrative: Though there have been corroborating reports of pests (cockroaches, in particular) found on the facility premises, Progress Ranch has provided documentation that shows that a pest control service has been maintained to continually try to address the issue. None interviewed described the matter as an "infestation." Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 03/07/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon and LPA Tatyana Shulz conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with House Manager Radiance Clinton to whom the following report was delivered: On 11/01/2024 LPA opened the complaint investigation in person and was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant as part of the onsite inspection. Interviews were conducted with Progress Ranch clients and staff; maintenance records were also reviewed as part of this inquiry. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: Based on information obtained from interviews conducted, there were inconsistent statements made during the investigation process. During an interview with the client in question, they could not articulate or provide details on when, where and how the burn was sustained. Collateral interview(s) revealed that the client has self injurious behaviors and has a history of making allegations against facility staff members from current and prior placement's. Witness interviews could not corroborate the allegation, and staff members denied physically harming the client. Furthermore, medical staff reported that client repeatedly turned the heat up during a 5-day 5150 hold at the Hospital and screamed for help and yelled “you guys are burning me”. In addition, no additional follow up will be conducted by Davis PD on this allegation. Although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did, nor did not occur, therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided to the House Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On March 11, 2024 at approximately 02:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Farhaan Sarangi conducted a complaint inspection to the above facility for the purpose of delivering investigation findings. LPA was greeted at the door by House Manager, Radiance Clinton, and was granted access into the facility. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Farhaan Sarangi conducted the 10-day complaint inspection on 12/11/2023 and obtained the following documents: client’s roster, children’s face sheets, children’s needs and services plans, treatment services plan and an Individual Education Plan (IEP). This complaint was investigated by the Department’s Investigation Branch and was assigned to Investigator Sergio Guerra as a full investigation. Investigator Guerra reviewed relevant facility history, and interviewed the alleged child victim, the Reporting Party, additional clients in placement, staff members, County Social Worker, and additional witnesses. (Report continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: No definitive evidence was found to prove that confidential information was shared by the facility with unauthorized individuals. The party to whom the information was purportedly given denied receiving any such privileged information. Relatedly, though there was contact between a child and the referenced party that was supposedly prohibited, obtained statements were inconsistent on what the understanding was: no documented correspondence was produced to show a clear directive from the child’s authorized representative about prohibited vs. allowed contacts. As for the allegation that staff are not following (the) treatment plan for (a) child, according to corroborating statements, the specialized therapist who was supposed to come to the facility had stopped rendering services to the child and attempts by the facility and the County to have the services resume were unsuccessful as the aforementioned provider did not maintain communication. Regarding possible staffing inadequacies, obtained information showed that it was not the case that a child was put up at a hotel because the facility was not able to meet staffing requirements—the children were put up overnight at a hotel due to some issue with the facility grounds that was being addressed. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/02/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Radiance Clinton, Administrator, and the following report was discussed. The investigation was opened on 11/30/2023 at the facility, during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the program’s physical plant was given and interviews were conducted with staff and clients; additional interviews were conducted throughout the course of the investigation. Records reviewed as part of this investigation were a child’s Needs & Services Plans and facility correspondences. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: According to Progress Ranch, though the listed administrator for this facility left before the next appointment was made official, the administrator role was being shared in practice by at least one credentialed individual and another whose credentials were in the process of being vetted. However, there were inconsistencies in the statements regarding whether operational tasks were actually carried out. Regarding mental health services personnel, based on interviews conducted by CCL, statements from staff and youth were inconsistent on how mental health treatment as a core service was provided. Finally, though obtained statements were consistent regarding the MHRS’ (Mental Health Rehabilitation Specialist) workload becoming more difficult to manage because of a shortage of personnel who held that position, conducted interviews yielded inconsistent information about how, or if, the care for the children was negatively affected by this. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/02/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator Radiance Clinton and the following report was discussed: LPA Jacqueline Carmona opened the investigation on 11/20/2023 during which time interviews were conducted with the children referenced in the complaint and staff. The interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant were toured. Relevant facility records were requested. Additional interviews were conducted by LPA Cabigon. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: Statements obtained from LPA’s conducted in-person interviews were inconsistent and did not sufficiently corroborate the purported improper application of manual restraints. The client, themselves, did not acknowledge the allegation; but facility youths did indicate that restraints were being applied regularly, with one youth expressing that none of the children deserve to be place on holds. As for a child’s unexplained injury, that client also did not report that the injury was caused by staff doing something intentionally to hurt said child. Out of multiple interviewees, none indicated having been witness to the child sustaining the injury. And regarding the reporting requirement deficiency, though the regulatory language requires reporting of unusual incidents to authorized representatives, there is no explicit provision for incident reporting concerning the specific incident at hand: the seeking of medical treatment by the facility on behalf of the youth; however, multiple Progress Ranch staff indicated that, for the particular incident in question, facility protocol dictates notifying that authorized representative. No supporting documentation was provided by either the facility or the responsible party that showed a clear agreement or expectation to report. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the appeal rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/19/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) and met with Clinical Data Manager Ian Longue. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings of, and close, this complaint investigation. The following report was discussed: LPA opened the investigation on 12/11/2023 in the facility. A tour of the interior and exterior facility grounds was done which resulted in no observed deficiencies related to Buildings & Grounds. Interviews were also conducted with clients and staff. Records reviewed as part of the investigation were Needs & Services Plans and incident reports. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process, the above allegations cannot be substantiated because inconsistent statements were obtained during the investigation process. The allegation that Staff handle minors in a rough manner was not sufficiently corroborated by any of the interviewed clients; the child referenced in the complaint does get placed in manual restraints but obtained statements were not consistent in describing these holds as unjustified or improperly applied. As for the Program’s physical plant, through unannounced onsite inspections conducted on 11/30/2023 and on 04/02/2024, LPA did not observe any areas that were in disrepair; no weapons (or any items that could potentially be used as weapons) were found on facility grounds. Regarding staff speaking to youth inappropriately, no interviewed client confirmed the details of that allegation, though one client stated that staff occasionally yell and/or intentionally try to embarrass them by reprimanding a child in front of others in the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/19/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this STRTP (Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Clinical Data Manager Ian Longue and the following report was discussed: The investigation was opened on 11/30/2023, during which time interviews with multiple children and staff were conducted onsite. A tour of the facility grounds was also done on the same day. Additional interviews were conducted throughout the investigation. Records reviewed were children’s Needs & Services Plans, incident reports, and staff training records. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: On December 18, 2023 at approximately 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Farhaan Sarangi and Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Deficiencies Inspection. deficiencies.description:
87070(c)(1) Children’s Records:   

(c)  If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child’s needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child’s record:
(1)  A copy of the child’s original needs and services plan; verification, signed by the child and their authorized representative(s), that they were offered the opportunity to participate in plan development; and verification that the authorized representative(s) have approved the plan. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: 

LPAs reviewed a sample of client records and found that three clients did not have a signed Needs and Services Plan as outlined in Title 22 regulations.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Plan of Correction shall include the Licensee/Administrator to ensure that ALL Needs and Services Plan for ALL clients in care are signed and dated. In addition, Licensee/Administrator shall submit an LIC 9098 self-certification which entails understanding of this regulation. Licensee/Administrator shall conduct staff training on client records and the importance of having records up to date with ALL documents signed.

POC due date: December 26, 2023.

narrative: On June 24, 2024 at approximately 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home announced for a voluntary facility Closure, and met with the Administrator, Ian Longue. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received notification via email requesting a closure of the facility and stated that there were no clients in care. The Administrator notified Community Care Licensing of intent to close this facility on June 3, 2024 via email. Closure plans were forwarded to CCL for review. Administrator notified CCL that the facility will be closing on June 27, 2024. The licensee initiated this facility closure. LPA Sarangi inspected all rooms and the exterior of the building and found no evidence that would suggest that clients are residing on the premises. In addition, LPA observed that the facility is being remodeled. All clothing and personal items belonging to clients have been removed. Clients that were living in the home have been relocated. LPA obtained the license for the facility. Facility will be closed effective June 27, 2024. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator, Ian Longue.

LPA interviewed 3 out of 5 clients in placement including the client in question, but two clients did not want to give a statement. During an interview with the client in question, the client was observed to be free from bruises and marks. Furthermore, client was distracted and was not able to provide specific times or dates when this incident occurred. During an interview with the County Social Worker, the client disclosed different scenarios of the actual incident in question. Lastly, LPA attempted to interview the former staff member in question during the investigation process but was unsuccessful. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were given. A copy of this report was provided to Administrator, Ian Longue.
investigation_findings: 13On June 24, 2024, at approximately 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at Progress Ranch: Chestnut Home for the purposes of delivering complaint findings. LPA was greeted at the door by Administrator, Ian Longue and was granted access into the facility. During the investigation, LPA Sarangi reviewed the complaint history, criminal background check, incident report(s) and facility personnel report summary. LPA Sarangi conducted interviews with the Administrator, children in placement and a witness. Based on interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegations cannot be substantiated because LPA received inconsistent statements and could not corroborate the allegations. On May 24, 2024, LPA conducted a collateral interview with the Reporting Party, and learned that the reported incident was unclear of when the incident took place and/or who was involved in the incident. (Report conintued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: On August 15, 2023, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia, Cynthia Galindo and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Juanita Arroyo met with Chastity Day and Rita Stevenson for Component two of the application process. This meeting was to discuss the application, resolve any questions and determine whether the agency has the knowledge, ability, and resources to operate in compliance with licensing laws and regulations. The following items were discussed: responsibilities of the Board of Directors, keeping up with the Title 22 regulations and Interim licensing standards, cell phone policy, staff responsibilities/duties, incident reporting procedures, including law enforcement contact, clients personal rights, staff records requirements, prudent parenting standards, core therapeutic services, emergency intervention plan, and guardian background checks. Types of Licensing Visits: ~Pre Licensing ~Post Licensing ~Annual unannounced ~Complaint unannounced ~Plan of Correction unannounced ~Case Management unannounced It was determined that at this time CCL and SOC will review the fourth (4th) revision of the Plan of Operation and Program Statement for Project 14:14. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this LIC 809 was given to Chastity Day.

On September 22, 2023, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Cynthia Galindo travelled to Project 14:14, located at 7328 N. Fruit Ave Fresno CA 93711, to conduct a Pre-licensing inspection. LPA’s were met at the facility by Licensee Chastity Day and Rita Stevenson. 1. Facility Grounds were clear from debris 2. Outdoor space observed. Sliding screen door is ripped and in disrepair. One bedroom window had no screen and front of house screen was observed to be ripped. 3. Chemicals were locked upon inspection. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications were discussed. There is currently a locked space for medications. 5. First aid kit is in need of a thermometer. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair with enough storage. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Minimal nonperishable foods were observed at this time. 10. Weekly mock menu observed. 11. Dining room observed. Table and chairs for the facility were observed during inspection. 12. Facility has two full restrooms, both are operable. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. 13. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility. Including insurance and registration. 14. Licensee already has a guardian account and two staff are currently associated. Fire clearance was completed on January 19, 2023.

On April 12, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Angelica Borja travelled to Project 14:14, located at 7328 N. Fruit Ave Fresno CA 93711, to conduct a Second Pre-licensing inspection. LPA’s were met at the facility by Licensee Chastity Day and Rita Stevenson. 1. Facility Grounds were clear from debris 2. Outdoor space observed. 3. Chemicals were locked upon inspection. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications were observed. There is currently a locked space for medications. 5. First aid kit was observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair with enough storage. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Minimal nonperishable foods were observed at this time. 10. Weekly mock menu observed. 11. Dining room observed. Table and chairs for the facility were observed during inspection. 12. Facility has two full restrooms, both are operable. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. It is currently reading 103.1F. 13. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility. Including insurance and registration. 14. Licensee already has a guardian account and two staff are currently associated. 15. Licensee states they will be building a wall for confidential interviews/sessions. Fire clearance was completed on January 19, 2023.

On August 12 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelica Borja and Briana Placencia conducted a post-licensing inspection at Project 14:14 Inc and met with Rita Stevenson, Administrator. A inspection of the facility was conducted. The STRTP currently has one client in care. The STRTP currently employs 1 Administrator/Facility Manager, five Direct Care staff and one Social Worker. LPA reviewed 4 staff files and one client file. Unable to interview as client AWOL'd during the inspection. The STRTP currently has no firearms and no swimming pool. A review of the Licensing Information System on August 12, 2024, indicates that all facility staff are associated to the STRTP and have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. At this time the STRTP is in the process of accreditation. One Technical Advisory was cited during todays inspection. The STRTP will also submit an updated LIC 500 to LPA Borja within the next two weeks. A copy of this report and appeal rights will was left at the facility at the conclusion of this inspection.

On May 12, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Project 14:14 Inc, and met with Rita Stevenson. The purpose of this inspection was to discuss concerns with an incident report that was received by the Department on 05/05/2025, the incident in question happened on 05/04/2025. LPA conducted an interview. Administrator stated that it was an isolated incident. Client #1 (C1) and Client #2 (C2) did have a disagreement but were okay with each other shortly after. Staff was present and attempted to de-escalate the whole time. (See 811 and 812). Trauma informed language was discussed with Administrator. It was determined this was an isolated incident and there was no citation warranted. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

On June 3, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Angelica Borja conducted a Case Management inspection at Project 14:14 STRTP and met with Camia Scherer and Rita Stevenson via phone. The purpose of this visit was to discuss incident reports not received by Community Care Licensing (CCL). During a previous investigation it was discovered that incidents occurred with Client One (C1- See 811 for confidential names) on March 6, 2025 and March 8, 2025. Both these incident reports were not received by CCL. The Department determined this to be a risk to the health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC809D. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights was provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: 13On June 3, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Angelica Borja conducted a complaint inspection at Project 14:14 STRTP, LPAs met with Camia Scherer. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients which revealed that in fact facility staff were searching rooms. Based on LPA's observations, and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS
(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable...
(10) To be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings.

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interviews, licensee did not ensure that clients were free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings, which poses an immediate health safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee states that they will immediately stop doing searches on clients. Licensee will submit their plan to LPA Placencia via email by 6/4/2025.

narrative: On April 16, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Melissa Renovato conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at Project 14:14, located in Fresno CA. LPAs met with Administrator Rita Stevenson. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 72 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on April 15, 2024. The licensee has submitted their required documentation to obtain their Mental Health Approval, at this time it is pending. The facility is working on being accredited through CARF. Project 14:14 is currently on a provisional license that expired on 4/15/2025. Project 14:14 will have their provisional license extended for another 6 months. Per Administrator there are no weapons/firearms in the facility. There are no bodies of water. LPAs reviewed 3 client files, and 5 staff files. LPAs interviewed 1 staff and 2 clients. The facility is being cited on the attached LIC 809 D's. A copy of this report and appeal rights was left with Administrator Rita Stevenson at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

narrative: On July 23, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Project 14:14 INC, and met with Brianna Sullivan and Rita Stevenson via phone. The purpose of this inspection was to discuss concerns with an incident report that was sent into the Department on July 17, 2025, the incident in question happened on 07/11/2025. LPA conducted interviews. Administrator stated that C1 (see 811) was on 15 minute or more checks. Due to the medical, mental health needs and failure to comply with program C1 was moved on 7/14/25, per the request of her Social worker. It was determined this was an isolated incident and there was no citation warranted. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

It was informed to LPA that Staff follow facility’s runaway procedure by trying to encourage clients to stay, following the clients, submitting a Special Incident Report as well as their internal incident report and call the appropriate parties such as the client’s authorized representative, Law Enforcement and Administrator. In addition, the administrator follows the Parent Prudent Standards by having Prudent Parenting Community Day Pass Agreement in attempts to decrease AWOLs. Interviews revealed that facility does report awols but there was a time where were complications with itrack (the system to submit incident reports); however, administrator communicated with DCFS and the issue was resolved. It was reported that clients smoke weed in the home, confidential interviews revealed that the rule is to not smoke in the home; however, there were inconsistent statements on whether or not there was smoking in the home or not. Additionally, it was indicated in interviews that staff would redirect clients if clients are not following the rules. LPA confirmed that facility’s first intake was on 06/01/2020. It was reported that S1 and S2 background check was uncleared. LPA confirmed that S1 did not have an association to the facility; however, due to current unforeseen times, on May 1, 2020 PIN 20-09-CRP was issued for the following: Background Check Temporary Waiver Licensed children’s residential facilities, may comply with the following background check requirements to enable new staff to start working immediately if: 1) the licensee is experiencing a staff shortage, and 2) when Live Scan services are limited as a result of COVID-19. In addition to complying with the requirements below, licensees should give preference to hiring individuals with verified existing background clearance from a school district, state, or local government agency or other agency that conditions employment or participation on a background clearance. 1. Transferring a Current CDSS Record Clearance or Exemption: Newly hired staff may start working or caregiving immediately upon submission of a request to transfer a current CDSS criminal record clearance or exemption and Child Abuse Central Index (CACI) clearance. The request to transfer shall be sent to the local Children’s Residential Licensing office. S1 had an existing background clearance with the state and the facility was in need of staff. S1 start date with the facility was on 07/20/2020 and was sent termination notice on 08/05/2020. Additionally, S2 was cleared with the state; date association began on 05/14/2020. Continue on 9099-C

Furthermore, it was reported that clients are being transported by staff that have invalid license and insurance. While reviewing staff file records, LPA verified that S1 had a Driver’s License that had to be submitted prior to employment. Additionally, staff files were reviewed, and LPA confirmed that staff had their Driver’s License and insurance as well. Additionally, Facility has its own van to transport the clients. Lastly, it was reported that medications are accessible to the clients in the home not locked away and staff leave their keys around which makes it accessible to clients. LPA obtained pictured of the medication cabinet. Interview statements revealed the following: Clients do not have access to the medication cabinet, Cabinet is always locked, and medications are also locked in a locked box inside the locked cabinet; Staff carry their keys at all times. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews and review of documentation, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On December 18th, 2020 at 9:51am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection with Project Destiny of Hope STRTP and spoke with Administrator Deborah Manns. During the course of investigating the following allegations: Clients are using drugs in the home; Uncleared staff in home; Medication accessible to children in home; Staff allows clients to AWOL; and Clients are not being properly transported, LPA reviewed Special Incident Reports, Medication Cabinet Photos, Staff files, AWOL logs, Email Correspondences about itrack, First Client intake, facility’s internal Incident Report; home pass form, Client Roster, and conducted interviews with related parties. It was reported that staff give permission for the residents to AWOL. Confidential interviews revealed that Staff and Clients denied the allegation of Staff allowing the clients to AWOL. Continue on 9099-C

narrative: Staff denied that Staff #2 was talking inappropriately about Resident #1 to other Residents in the house. investigation_findings: 13On February 17, 2021 at 11:25 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Mercy Gago concluded the investigation on Project Destiny Home of Hope. During the course of investigating the allegation Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Mercy Gago interviewed the Complainant, Staff, and Residents. Resident #3 denied knowing about the incident. Resident #4 reported that she has seen Staff # 2 talk to Resident #5 about Resident#1 "business." Resident #4 reported that she had seen Staff #2 tell Resident #5 that Resident #1 "thinks you stole her money." Resident #5 reported that Resident #1 bullies and threatens her and she doubts that Staff was talking about her to other Residents. Resident #5 denied Staff #2 talking to her about Resident #1. Resident #6 denied knowing anything about the incident between Staff #2 and Resident #1.

On 10/28/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips, arrived at the above-said facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection of Project Destiny Home of Hope. LPA met with Darryl Sewell, who granted access into the facility, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and outside. The home is one story structure with 3 bedrooms, 2 full bathrooms and detached garage. LPA observed the following:: · The medications stored in locked kitchen cabinet next to refrigerator, with first aid kit. · The living room was observed to have 2 large sofas enough seating for 6 people.. · Hot water temperature was measured to be within a safe temperature range (at 120 degrees Fahrenheit). · There is glass sliding door, located in the Dining Room and is currently functional. · The stove 6 burners were observed to be self-igniting. · The door, accessible from the backyard, which gains access to the basement crawl space is locked, painted, and reinforced. · LPA observed the storage area located in the detached garage area has a sofa, chairs and one desk, file cabinet, shelves for storage of extra household supplies. · The Therapy Office, located within the detached garage area, was observed to have enough filing cabinets to store staff and client files. Dining Room: equipped with a dining table with 6 chairs, a desk for direct care staff to use, and a functional wall heater. This room has access to the side of the house.

Kitchen: equipped with a refrigerator, microwave, fire extinguisher, plenty of cabinet space, some are locks to store the knives, other sharps. There is a separate locked metal storage cabinet to store pots and pans and other necessary items. Detached Garage Area: This area has three (3) doors which gains access to two (2) storage areas, and one (1) therapy office. Chemicals and cleaning solutions will be kept in storage area. The 2 storage areas are not accessible to children; the small storage area is locked with a dead bolt lock, and the other larger storage area is accessible only by the garage opener. Therapy Office: is equipped with a file cabinet, a desk with a chair, a couch, a ceiling fan, and a dresser for storage. Laundry area: accessible only from the backyard, is equipped with a washer and dryer; within this room another locked door gains access to a storage area. Bathrooms: There is a total of 2 bathrooms, that are clean, safe, and in good repair. Hallways: one hallway is equipped with a fully charged fire extinguisher, and gains access to the 3/4 bathroom, and 2 bedrooms; the other hallway gains access to the bedroom with the attached full bathroom. Both hallways have locked cabinets where extra linens, and client hygiene products will be stored.

3 bedrooms: The three double occupancy bedrooms were observed to have sufficient lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. All bedrooms have security bars on the windows with quick-releases that were tested and fully functional for each of the bedrooms. · Bedroom # 1– located at the front of the house, is equipped with 2 twin beds. · Bedroom # 2 – located in between Bedroom#1 and Bedroom #2, equipped with 2 twin beds. · Bedroom # 3 – located at the rear of the facility, is equipped with 2 twin beds, and an attached full bath. LPA advised will return the next day to review residents files. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report is discussed and left with Darryl Sewell/Mental Health Liasion

Also, confidential interviews with Child 1, Child 2, Child 3, Child 4, Child 5 revealed they are getting medications and refused to sign when they decline medications. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence obtained the information did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. Due to inconsistent statements LPA Phillips was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be Unsubstantiated meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged incidents occurred. No deficiencies cited at the time of this investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and copy of this report was left with facility administrator.

deficiencies.description: 87065.5 Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios(a) a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows(2) During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: There was a lack of supervision as evidence by staff sleep on duty which poses an immediate Health, Safety, Direct Care Staff risk to the children in care .
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide by 11/30/2022 report showing  how facility will prevent staff from sleeping during shift. Licensee reports facility manger conducting random pop up checks on staff. Will provide chat submitted by facility manager. Licensee stated will conduct additional training for staff responsibility/duties.

narrative:
On 05/22/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips, arrived at the facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA Phillips met with Amanda Tovar/Executive Manager, who granted access into the facility, and provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and outside. The facility is licensed to care for 6 children ages 12 to 17 and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. This facility also provides services to non- minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 165.1 (C)(1). At the time of today’s inspection, the census was 6. The facility is a one story structure with three (3) bedrooms two (2) full bathrooms with a detached garage located in residential community. There are no firearms in the facility. LPA obtained the LIC 500 to verify Staff to Client ratio. LPA reviewed the Facility Profile and Personnel Report and confirmed that personnel have required criminal record clearance: DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse; which meet qualifications This facility LPA observed all posting requirements for the STRTP are publicly posted for all clients and authorized representatives to see. The clients' personal rights, weekly sample menu, and the monthly activity schedule. were observed on the wall. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Grievance Procedures is posted. The STRTP License was posted in a visible location. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. There are two(2) fire extinguishers located in the facility and LPA observed fully charged. First Aid kits checked and found to be complete. Hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). Living Room: LPA observed two (2) large sofas with adequate seating for six (6), large coffee table, small desk, wall mounted television, entertainment cabinet with extra storage shelves bookcase. cont on 809c

Dining Room: equipped with a large dining table with 6 chairs, a desk and chair for direct care staff to use, and a functional wall heater. This room has access to the side of the house with functional sliding glass door leading to driveway for parked cars. Kitchen: LPA observed a five (5) burner stove self igniting at time of inspection. LPA observed a refrigerator, microwave, fire extinguisher, plenty of upper and lower cabinet space, some of which have locks to store the knives, other sharps. LPA observed the upper cabinets with spices, can goods, dry goods, bows, plates and cups. LPA observed two (2) First Aid kits checked and found to be complete. A weekly menu is posted in the kitchen. LPA observed enough food to meet Title 22 requirements. All knives, household cleaners and medications are stored in accordance with Title 22 regulations. . There is an additional refrigerator and standing freezer in the detached garage with adequate food in accordance to Title 22 regulations. Therapy Office: is equipped with a file cabinets, 4 desk with 4 chairs, a ceiling fan. Laundry area: accessible only from the backyard, is equipped with a washer and dryer; within this room another locked door gains access to a storage area. LPA observed extra laundry soap, cleaning supplies and additional dishes and cups. Bathrooms: There is a total of 2 bathrooms, that are clean, safe, and in good repair. Bedrooms: The three (3) double occupancy bedrooms were observed to have sufficient lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Hallways: one hallway is equipped with a fully charged fire extinguisher, and gains access to the full bathroom, and 2 bedrooms; the other hallway gains access to the bedroom with the attached full bathroom. Both hallways have locked cabinets where extra linens, and client hygiene products. cont on 809 c

The Exterior consists of the following: Front yard is maintained and free of any obstruction or debris. The backyard has patio table with attached shade umbrella, six (6) chairs, outdoor bench and two lounge chairs. There is a covered barbecue grill. The back yard is maintained and free of any debris. LPA inspected facility van and observed current registration and insurance. Van equipped with First Aid kit. LPA confirmed all lights were in good working condition. During today's inspection LPA conducted four confidential interviews. LPA conducted review of medication logs. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. LPA will return on another day to review staff and client files. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report will be emailed to Deborah Manns Administrator

investigation_findings: 13On 07/24/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made follow up visit to PROJECT DESTINY HOME OF HOPE for the purpose of delivering findings on complaint allegation. LPA Phillips was met by Deborah Manns/Licensee who provided the census. Licensee is not ensuring that minors in care are free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. During the investigation confidential interviews were conducted, facility file review, picture taken of sign posted in facility. During the investigation confidential interviews were conducted, facility file review, picture taken of sign posted in facility. It was reported to LPA Phillips sign posted in facility wall stated: All residents bags must be checked by staff upon entry. It was reported to LPA Phillips searched were conducted of bags upon return to facility. Staff interviews reveal searches were conducted on bags when residents return from authorize absence, community pass and if resident left without a bag and returned with a bag. Based on information obtained from interviews and documentary facts, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The Department has determined a personal rights violation. cont 9099c

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee stated will conduct additional training for staff responsibility and search policy. Licensee will provide to department copy of traning sign in sheet by 08/14/2024.

On May 28, 2021 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an announced visit via FaceTime to Project Destiny Home of Hope 2 for the purpose of conducting a STRTP Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Executive Director, Deborah Mans and together toured the interior and exterior of the facility. This facility will be licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 12-17 years old, ambulatory only and non-minor dependents. On this day, the census is zero (0). The home is set-up as follows and the following was observed: This is a single-story home located in a residential neighborhood. Den/Tv room: Has a gated patio that leads to the back yard and this room is equipped with a large sectional couch. Detached garage (Therapy room): Is equipped with a sofa and was not completely furnished at the time of the inspection. Bedroom #2: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, new mattresses, two (2) new dressers, and has a walk-in closet with adequate space, an exit window, sufficient lighting, and a smoke detector. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Bedroom #3: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, new mattresses, two (2) new dressers, and has a walk-in closet with adequate space, an exit window, sufficient lighting, and a smoke detector. Bathroom #1: Is located at the front of the hallway. It has a bathtub, stand-alone shower, sink, a non-operational electric heater, and toilet. Bathroom #2: Is located along the hallway between bedroom #1 and bedroom #3. It has a tub/shower combination, a sink, and a toilet. Both bathrooms were observed to be in working order. Hallways: Has two (2) locked closets. LPA observed one cabinet to have extra towels and individual plastic containers which will store client hygiene products. The second closet stores disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisonous items made inaccessible to clients. LPA observed the home to have two (2) up to date regulation fire extinguishers, six (6) smoke detectors, and one (1) smoke/carbon monoxide combination detector. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarm were working properly. The facility will utilize a Chrysler Pacifica to transport clients. LPA observed the vehicle to have current registration and insurance. There are no security bars on the bedroom windows. Passageways and porch were clean and in good repair. The front and back yard were free of debris and hazardous material. There were no bodies of water on the premises. No firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. The following was discussed with the facility Administrator: Children will be supervised & protected at all times. Licensee will provide and ensure three nutritious meals, snacks, and special diets. Children will be accorded personal rights. Children will be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children will be able to contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children will be accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children will not be restricted in telephone use except by court order. Licensee will ensure to have written authorization to obtain medical and dental care. Licensee will ensure to have personal rights forms in children’s files as well as the Needs and Services plan. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Staff working in the facility will have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances, and Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility will operate within license conditions & limitations including capacity limit. Facility meets posting requirements, including COVID-19 best practices signage and emergency telephone numbers are in prominent locations. There were no deficiencies cited at this time of the visit. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Executive Director.

narrative: On 04/05/2023 @ 12:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Investigation follow up.. investigation_findings: 13On April 14, 2025, at 11:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong and LPM Enrique Hernandez made an unannounce visit at the above said facility, and met with the Executive Assistant Manager Amanda Tobar, who granted access into the facility. The purpose of the inspection is to conclude the complaint investigation on the allegation and to deliver the findings. LPA and Executive Assistant Manager and together discussed the investigation details. During the investigation process, LPA Armstrong conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and gathered information on the allegation above. After reviewing all the statements and information obtained, the above allegation is substantiated because the confidential interviews and evidence confirmed the fight between C1 and C2. During the altercation between the two youths (C1 and C2), only S3 was in the middle, attempting to stop the fight. Additionally, after reviewing the evidence obtained LPA confirmed the fight between C1 and C2 lasted for more than 30 seconds. C1 and C2 were physically assaulting one another by hitting each other in the head. Even though there was other staff present the staff did not follow the policy and procedures. (Continue on LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
87065.2(b)(1) PERSONNEL DUTIES - Direct care staff shall perform duties including, but not limit to, supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups… 
This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on Confidential interviews with staff and clients confirmed that no staff adhered to the facility's policies and procedures during the altercation between C1 and C2. This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A written plan of correction shall be submitted to LPA Armstrong via email at Justine.Armstrong@dss.ca.gov no later than April 28, 2025. The POC shall include steps that the licensee will take from now on to ensure that staff follow the facility policies and procedures during a physical fight.

investigation_findings: 13On March 14, 2025 at 11:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong and License Program Manager Enrique Hernandez conducted an unannounced visit to Project Destiny Home of Hope 2 to conclude the investigation of the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA met with Amanda Tobar the Assistant Executive Manager who granted access to the facility and together, they discussed the investigation details. During the investigation process, all relevant parties have been accounted for. It was reported that Staff did not take minor to the doctor for medical care, Staff locked minor out of the home, and Staff did not accompany minor to the hospital or transport minor back to the facility. After conducting confidential interviews and documents reviewed, there was insufficient evidence or testimony to substantiate the allegations.Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

narrative: On April 29, 2025, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst Justine Armstrong (LPA) and Enrique Hernandez Licensing Program Manager (LPM) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management other – To investigate concerns regarding compliance with the STRTP investigation. LPA met with Program Administrator and a health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The Community Care Licensing Department has received concerns regarding the facility's failure to provide mental health services to clients in care, staff members driving clients in personal vehicles, and changes in the staffing department with the Head of Service. During the investigation, the LPA interviewed the Administrator, Staff 1 and Staff 2. The Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) has requested the following documents: CFT notes, Needs and Service plan, vehicle insurance, vehicle registration, the policy on vehicle safety and transportation for the specified vehicle LIC 500, and the client roster. The LPA also informed the Administrator about the importance of promptly submitting Unusual Incident Reports in compliance with regulations and addressing the staffing changes. At this time, there is insufficient information to support that the above allegations occurred. This Case Managment needs further investigation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to facility staff.

Additionally, evidence showed that although staff were present, staff failed to follow the necessary policies and procedures to prevent the incident in which another client's belongings were damaged. Based on the LPA interviews, record reviews, and the evidence obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A citation in accordance with the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 5 the Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation ILS 87065.2(b)(1) PERSONNEL DUTIES - Direct care staff shall perform duties including, but not limit to, supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups... A copy of this report was sent by certified mail to the administrator office on file for the licensee's signature. (Please see LIC 809D for deficiency page)

narrative: The investigation revealed, on 4/27/2020, immediately upon knowledge of claims made by C2 that Cleint #3 (C3) punched C2, tried to drown C2 in a pool and attempted to put a squirt gun “up C2’s birth canal,” the facility filed an incident report alerting required parties and immediately conducted an internal investigation. Staffs and client were queried. The results from the inquiry determined unsubstantiated findings as there were no witnesses who either observed or witnessed interactions between C2 and C3 that would suggest inappropriate or sexual behavior. A review of facility records indicates at the time of the alleged incident, the facility was operating within approved staff to client ratios. It was further revealed at the time of the reported incident, Client #2 (alleged victim) was assigned a 1 to 1 staff for supervision for client’s safety a week and a half prior since returning from a hospitalization. C2 was not without continuous supervision. Confidential interviews produced no witnesses or additional alleged victims to the abuse. Due to the need for a higher level of care, Client #2 (C2) was replaced to another facility out of state. Attempts to interview C2 was not successful during the investigation process due to C2’s reluctance to speak to investigator concerning the matter. The investigation has determined that while the allegation may be valid, gathered information failed to produce corroborating evidence to support claims of sexual abuse, personal rights or neglect to C2. The finding is therefore determined unsubstantiated at this time. There were no deficiencies cited during the investigation. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report is emailed to Ms. Bradley for signature.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/02/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin spoke with Facility Administrator, Elin Bradley for the purpose of delivering findings and discussing investigative outcome concerning the above-mentioned allegation. On 05/04/2020, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received claims alleging in part, a youth resident at the facility had physically assaulted other residents. It was further alleged that the youth had also sexually assaulted Client #2 (see Confidential Names form, dated 9/2/2020). The claims were referred to and investigated by Investigations Bureau and LPA Martin. The investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties including, but not limited to, Client #1 (C1), parent of Client #2 (C2), relative of C2, Facility Director and the Los Angeles Police Department responding Officer in addition to review of corresponding incident reports, facility internal investigation, client records and complaint history, produced a lack of evidence to support reported claims.

narrative: On November, 19, 2021 at 8am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong Project Six Group Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection. LPA Karnsrithong met with Administrator, Elin Bradley. The current census of the facility is sixteen (16). This is a two-story facility that provides care and supervision to children ages 11 to 17 years of age and ambulatory only. There are no pool or bodies of water in the premises of the facility. The facility is located in a gated commercial area. During the inspection LPA Karnsrithong observed an outside common area with sectional patio seating and tables. The outside common area is fenced in and located in front of the facility main door. This area is used by clients and staff as needed. There is also a conference room located in the school facility. This room has a large desk, eight (8) chairs, shelves and drawers to be used for storage. This room is mainly used for staff or private meetings. This is a two-story facility and the group home is located upstairs. The facility is fenced in and there is a school adjacent to the facility. There is also an office reception area located next to the conference room. LPA Karnsrithong reviewed staff training records (Emergency Intervention, Trauma Informed Care, First Aid and CPR). LPA Karnsrithong will come back on a later date to complete the inspection. A copy of this report will be emailed to the facility on a later date.

On 12/10/2021, LPA Karnsrithong arrived at the facility at 9:30am to conduct an inspection regarding capacity decrease application. LPA met with administrator, Elin Bradley who provided the tour of the facility. The facility is located inside a gated compound that has four (4) separate buildings. The main gate is gated and secured. The first building is the school lobby, administrative offices and a gym that is used by the facility. The gym is currently not being used due to a erupted hydrant accident that occurred this week. No clients have accessed to the gym at this time while it undergoes repairs. The second building is the high school and middle school campus. The third building is the elementary campus and the outpatient clinic and wraparound and Family Preservation Services. The fourth building has the school, the facility office, and the client’s residential unit. The facility has a private gate that lets you inside the two-story building. The facility is located upstairs on the 2nd floor. The 1st floor is used as an outpatient services office and clients have no accessed to the 1st floor. CARF accreditation has been issued on July 3, 2019 and is valid until 2022. Current capacity for licensing is at twenty-four (24) and licensee is requesting for capacity to be decreased to sixteen (16). Administrator Certification is valid until December 7, 2022. The facility currently has sixteen (16) clients under their care. There are sixteen (16) bedrooms. Each bedroom is equipped with one (1) twin-sized bed, closet space, adequate lightning and two (2) dressers. Each bedroom has the emergency disaster plan and facility sketch plan posted. Each bedroom has its own smoke alarm. Each bedroom also has one (1) window with blinds. Clients have accessed to five (5) bathrooms that have showers, sinks, toilet that are in good working condition. Only one (1) client at a time is permitted to use the bathrooms. Staff uses separate bathrooms that is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. There are four (4) common area spaces inside the facility that is utilized by clients for studying, tutorials, games, video games, music and arts. There are seven (7) office spaces that are being used by both mental health, direct care, and administrative staff. One (1) office space is currently being renovated during the time of the inspection. There is one (1) common space area located outside across the facility door entrance. (Page 1 of 2)

The kitchen area is spacious and is equipped with stoves, refrigerators, dishwasher, and sinks. Sharp items are stored away and locked in a drawer and is inaccessible to clients. All kitchen items and utensils are well organized and labeled. A kitchen island is located in the center and is used for preparing food. Small kitchen appliances (coffee maker, two (2) microwaves, air fryer, pressure cooker) is also available to use. There is a separate pantry across the kitchen which stores extra perishable and non-perishable food items. This room is kept locked at all times. Kitchen is clean and well maintained. The dining area is located next to the kitchen and meals are served buffet style. Menu is posted in the dining area. There are two (2) laundry rooms that is being used by clients and has sufficient laundry supplies. The facility has a medication room that is maintained by the facility nurse. This room is used to store medication, COVID-19 tests, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), medication logs, vitamin supplements, and other medical supplies. All client medications are labeled and documented when provided to clients. Utility shut off valves are located outside the facility and is locked. Facility vehicles are in good working conditioned and parked in the facility parking area. Facility maintenance logs are kept in the vehicles for review. There are two (2) locked closet rooms that are used to store disinfectant and cleaning supplies for the facility. During this visit, LPA Karnsrithong has interviewed two (2) clients and three (3) staff. LPA also reviewed staff and client records which are stored appropriately. Staff records are kept offsite but can be accessed during inspection. The facility provides in-house mental-health services to all clients and updates their needs and services plan quarterly. Child Family Meetings are conducted regularly and documented in the client’s files as well. Facility logs are all stored in the administrative office. Staff are provided emergency intervention and trauma informed training as needed and are documented in the personnel files. All licensing postings, facility policies, and children's rights are posted in the hallway. There are eight (8) fire extinguishers and two (2) air purifiers throughout the facility. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility. (Page 2 of 2)

Additionally, LPA was informed during confidential interviews that that Child 1 becomes aggressive towards staff unprovoked. Due to statements from all relevant parties and facility records review, the above allegation is concluded as Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Supporting evidence include the following: Staff interviews and NSP. Exit interview conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Jerry Majewsky/ STRTP Program Director.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/16/2021 @ 1:10 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips conducted a subsequent investigation visit and spoke with Jerry Majewsky , STRTP Program Director for the purpose of delivering findings and discussing investigative outcome concerning the above-mentioned allegation. Initial investigation was conducted on 07/25/2021. During the course of this investigation LPA Phillips conducted confidential interviews with relevant parties. Staff admitted after Child 1 graduated and started vocational school behavior changed to aggression toward staff and others.

Licensing Program Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection May 16, 2023 at 11:00AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, May 16, 2023.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Joanna Solorio.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c) Personal Rights. Personal rights include the right to:
(12)	To make, send, and receive confidential telephone calls and other electronic communications, unless prohibited by court order.
