An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Arlene Vargas, Administrator. LPA provided the Administrator the entrance checklist and requested the necessary documents. An inspection of the physical plant was conducted. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked closet in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced January 2025. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. The facility is CARF Accredited through 01/31/2027, and Mental Health Program Approval through 04/09/2025. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 69 degrees. Hot water temperature measures 110 degrees. Facility has cameras in the common areas. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan, sampled medication and reviewed facility logs. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 1 administrator, 1 house manager, 1 clinician, 9 direct care staff, and 1 mental health rehabilitation specialist. An inspection of 4 client files was conducted as well as the centrally stored record and medications. An interview of C1 and C4 (see LIC811 dated 03/24/2025) was conducted. An interview of S2 and S3 (see LIC811 dated 03/24/2024) was conducted. An inspection of 5 staff records were inspected and met all regulatory requirements. A review of the Licensing Information System on March 18, 2025, indicates that all facility staff are associated to the STRTP had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. The exit interview was conducted a copy of this report given to the Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
80088(a)	Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. A comfortable temperature for clients shall be maintained at all areas.
(1)	The licensee shall maintain the temperature in rooms that clients occupy  between a minimum of 68 degrees F (20 degrees C) and a maximum of 85 degrees F (30 degrees C). This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted and a physical plant inspection, the temperature in the facility is not kept between 68 and 85 degrees F which presents an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Thermostats have been changed and one of the heating systems is being replaced on 12/07/2022. In addition, the temperature for the bedrooms and common areas is within regulatory guidelines. Deficiency cleared on this date.

(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 26, 2022. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo and LPA Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Mary Krahn

On the above date, Licensing Provid Risk assessment conducted prior to inspection. Met at the facility by Administrator Tamara Black and House Manager Tammy Lashley. The facility listed above is accredited through CARF and has current Mental Health Program Approval through Fresno County DBH . Arrived at the facility at 9:30 am. At the start of the inspection, LPA discussed procedures for psychotropic medication, current census and other administrative questions. The following were observed upon inspection of the physical plant inspection conducted at 10:30 am : 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, one single occupancy. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11.Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12.Facility has two full restrooms in the house for client use. one is located in a client bedroom only for the use of the clients who share that room.. 13.Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 14.No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. 15. Holes put in the wall during a recent incident were observed in bedroom 2, discussed plan for repair.

The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during Inspection 1. LIC 500 Reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. 2. Administrator Tamara Black is present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Personnel files were not reviewed on this date. Personnel files to be reviewed at a later time. 4. Client files reviewed on this date (6) from 11:00-12:30 pm. No deficiencies noted in areas observed. No clients were present during inspection. 2 staff interviews conducted. No deficiencies noted in areas observed.

narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Hope Sailors, House Manager. LPA provided the House Manager the entrance checklist and requested the necessary documents. An inspection of the physical plant was conducted. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked closet in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced December 2024. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. The facility is CARF Accredited through 01/31/2027, and Mental Health Program Approval through 04/09/2025. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 71 degrees. Hot water temperature measures 106 degrees. Facility has cameras in the common areas. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility does have a pool and meets all required regulations. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan, sampled medication and reviewed facility logs. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 1 administrator, 1 house manager, 1 clinician, and 9 child care workers. An inspection of 5 client files was conducted as well as the centrally stored record and medications. No client interviews were conducted as all clients were at school. An interview of S1 and S2 (see LIC811 dated 03/27/2025) was conducted. An inspection of 5 staff records were inspected and met all regulatory requirements. A review of the Licensing Information System on March 18, 2025, indicates that all facility staff are associated to the STRTP had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. The exit interview was conducted a copy of this report given to the House Manager.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez on April 16, 2025 at 11:30 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code 1538.9(a)(2). LPA reviewed 0 child psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 2 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 0 child currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of the licensing report to Jeimy Manzanares, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Jeimy Manzanares, Administrator.

An unannounced annual continuation inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Jeimy Manzanares, Administrator. met_with: Director of Residential Programs Arlene Vargas and Administrator Lisa Tamez
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Britanee Windom conducted a case management inspection on 07/06/22 at 9:30 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 3 out of 5 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 5 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 3 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, July 6, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, monthly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Lisa Tamez.

facility_name: PROMISE TRANSITIONAL HOMES DBA PROMISE STRTP
narrative: On February 11, 2025, at 10 AM, a Component II Office Visit was held to discuss the application received for Promise Transitional Homes DBA Promise STRTP located at 1858 W. 69th Street Los Angeles, CA 90047. Attending Component II were the following individuals:Tracia Ekollo, Applicant, and Agahnee Ekollo, Erika Butler, Licensing Program Analyst, and JoAunne Griffin, Licensing Program Manager. The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: Program Statement Sections A-Q Program Statement Sections 1 -20 Revisions have been completed and are currently being reviewed. Pre-Licensing Inspection scheduled for March 4, 2025, at 10 AM. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant, Tracia Ekollo.

facility_name: PROMISE TRANSITIONAL HOMES DBA PROMISE STRTP
narrative:
On March 4, 2025, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne’ Griffin arrived at Promise Transitional Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Applicant Tracia Ekollo who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. The home is set up as follows: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry space, and backyard area, Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, two chairs, two love seats, coffee table, and covered fireplace. Dining room: is equipped with a table with three chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and microwave. Sharp knives will be kept inaccessible in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA observed a covered trash can. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Exit signs are located at the front door and kitchen door. 809 continued on page 1 of 3

Bedroom #1: client's bedroom is equipped with two twin size bed with drawers underneath, dresser, adequate closet space, television, adequate lighting, and windows. Bedroom #2: client's bedroom equipped with two twin beds with drawers underneath, adequate closet space, adequate lighting, and windows. Exit door leads outside and will be locked. Bedroom #3: client's bedroom equipped with two twin beds with drawers underneath, adequate closet space, lighting, and windows. Exit door leads outside and will be locked. Bathroom: Bathroom #1 is located in hallway, and bathroom #2 is located in bedroom #2. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working condition. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a 2016 Chrysler Van will be used to transport clients. Insurance is valid from December 03, 2024 - December 3, 2025. The vehicle was observed to be in good condition. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed two fully charged fire extinguishers which are located in the kitchen, and dining room. Extra linens will be stored in the cabinet in the kitchen. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete with required items. The Applicant has a locked refrigerator for refrigerated medication that will be kept in the refrigerator. The applicant has locked boxes for the clients to store there belongings. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA reminded Applicant to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3)

LPA and LPM observed Ring camera at the front door and camera in the living room. Door sensors were observed at the front door, Bedroom #2 and Bedroom #3. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Applicant informed that the following corrections will need to be made. Purchase a mobile phone for clients use. Window lever needs to be replaced in Bedroom #3. Tools need to be removed from cabinet in the living room. Shower handle needs to be fixed in Bathroom #1. Remove personal hygiene items that will not be used by clients from Bathroom #2. Purchase plates, cups, bowls, utensils, pots, and pans. Place bedding on the beds in Bedroom #2. Remove tire, wood, weights, and items that will not be utilized by clients. Applicant will purchase six chairs for the dining room table. Applicant will place the drawer in the refrigerator. The Applicant will add the use of cameras in the facility to the Program Statement by March 20, 2025. Applicant will remove the glass off the floor in Bedroom #2. Applicant will remove the chandelier from Bathroom #2. Hall closet will be cleared of items not be used by clients. LPA and LPM will obtain approval for shed to be used as office space. LPA informed Applicant that a Component III meeting will be held March 20, 2025, at 10 AM. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant Tracia Ekollo.

facility_name: PROMISE TRANSITIONAL HOMES DBA PROMISE STRTP
narrative: On March 20, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin conducted a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Component III office meeting with Applicant, Tracia Ekollo. LPA Butler and LPM Griffin met with Applicant to discuss forms required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections. We discussed child and personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. We also discussed specific requirements, concerns and issues operating a STRTP, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge policies, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Licensing of facility is pending final approval due to fire clearance, association to Guardian, and corrections to facility plant. Second Pre-Licensing inspection is scheduled for April 1, 2025 @ 10. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant, Tracia Ekollo.

facility_name: PROMISE TRANSITIONAL HOMES DBA PROMISE STRTP
met_with: President of the Board (PB) Agahnee Ekollo
narrative:
On 06/27/25 at 9:40 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen & Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a Post-Licensing Inspection. Upon arrival LPA and LPM met with home owner Tracy, who granted access to the home. PB Agahnee Ekollo was contacted and made her way over. Tracy informed LPA & LPM that she is living in the home while no clients are present to protect the home. There are currently no clients or staff in the facility. Health and safety risk assessment and a facility walk through was conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA & LPM observed the posted facility License. LPA and LPM observed the foster youth bill of rights posted in the dinning room, but it is too small and illegible. LPA & LPM explained that the poster needs to be bigger for clients to be able to read. LPA & LPM observed the complaint procedures posted, LPA & LPM explained that there needs to be forms and writing tools present for clients to fill out on their own time anonymously. The home is set up as follows: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry space, and backyard area, Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, two chairs, two sofas, coffee table, and covered fireplace. There are fire place tools that will be removed. There is a camera pointed at the door. Cameras record video only, no sound. The video footage is stored by the security company for three days. Only Tracia and Agahnee have access to the footage. Dining room: is equipped with a table with six chairs and and extra chair. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. The license, personal rights poster, complaint procedures, menu, and activity poster will be posted. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and microwave. Sharp knives will be kept inaccessible in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA observed a covered trash can. The Applicant will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Currently there is no supply of perishable or non perishable food. Licensee will ensure that there is an adequate supply of non perishable food, snacks, extra cups, utensils, bowls, plates, and napkins. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher in the kitchen. Breakfast nook: is equipped with adequate bench seating and a small table. Laundry Area: is equiped Exit signs are located at the front door and kitchen door.

Bedroom #2: client's bedroom equipped with two twin beds with drawers underneath, adequate closet space, adequate lighting, and windows. Sliding exit door leads outside. Facility must ensure that there is a clear and accessible emergency exit, which can be either the sliding door or a window. Bedroom #3: client's bedroom equipped with two twin beds with drawers underneath, two closets, lighting, and windows. Exit door leads outside and will be locked. Facility will ensure that the closet is empty of the tv box and paint tray and rollers, and filled with hangers for clients clothes. There is a wall socket that must be repaired. Bathroom #2 is only accessible from Bedroom #3. Bathroom #1: Bathroom #1 is located in hallway. There is a sink, shower, and toilet. The water temperature was measured to be 115 degrees F. The toilet was observed to be operable. Bathroom #2 is located in bedroom #3. There is a sink, shower, tub, and toilet. The water temperature was measured to be 115 degrees F. There is a storage unit available for extra linens and towels. The door is a barn door that facility will add a lock to, to be able to lock for client privacy. Storage Closet: There is a storage closet in the hallway that will be made inaccessible to clients. Clients medications and medication logs will be stored in the closet. There is a mini fridge that will be able to store temperature controlled medications. There is an First Aid kit in the closet. Each First Aid kit is complete with Band-Aids, gauze, anti-septic solutions, scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and a first aid manual. The applicant has locked boxes for the clients to store there belongings. Backyard: There is adequate seating around a fire pit in the backyard. There are two walkways along either side of the house. Facility must ensure that there is no debris or other harmful items including propane tanks, ladders, animal poop, bottles, trash, pipes, weights, buckets, brooms, etc. accessible to clients. There is a shed in the back yard which is designated for the therapist, will be used to store all facility records including staff and client files, etc. The files will be locked in a cabinet inaccessible to clients. There is another shed that is storing the property owners personal belongings. This shed must be locked and made inaccessible to clients.

On Tuesday, February 23, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco followed-up on a call by Tara Flores, the Compliance Director from New Passages. LPA Tinoco conducted a Case Management for the purpose of documenting an incident that occurred at the Purvis House. Tara Flores informed LPA Tinoco that a staff had been fired due to not providing adequate supervision to the youth in care which lead the a youth and her baby going on AWOL status. The agency speculates that the youth is currently residing with the fired staff. According to Tara the agency has been in communication with the County Social Worker of the youth. Tara also provided LPA Tinoco with the incident reports relating to this incident, which will be documented on an attached LIC812. Tara Flores will provide LPA Tinoco with updates as they become available. No deficiencies were cited on this visit. Due to COVID-19 signatures are being requested Via email and documented on an LIC812.

LPA obtained client and staff records and interviewed children and staff as listed on the Confidential Names List Form (LIC 811). A copy of the LIC 809 was provided to facility Administrator.

reported that C6 never heard S1 say anything inappropriate. Confidential interviews reported that S1 showed inappropriate pictures on S1’s cell phone to C1. Confidential interviews reported that S1 showed a picture wearing lingerie. The description of color and design of the lingerie was inconsistent when clients (C1, C2, & C5) were asked about it. Confidential interviews reported that S1 was never seen showing inappropriate pictures to C1. Confidential interviews reported that S1 took a picture of C1 injured hand and forward the picture to another staff member. narrative: On 04/19/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lorena Valenzuela met with PHILOS Treatment Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) former Administrator Thomas Ybarra Sr. The purpose of this case management is to discuss information received during a review of an report received regarding an incident that occurred at the facility. The incident involved Client #1 (C1) and Staff #1 (S1). LPA conducted interviews with six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, & C6) and one Staff #1 (S1). See Confidential Names List form (LIC 811) dated 04/19/2022. On 06/15/2021, LPA Valenzuela conducted an inspection of the facility and a review of facility records. Interviews revealed that around April 2021, Staff #1 (S1) made inappropriate sexual comments to Client #1 (C1). Confidential witness statements reported that S1 made comments to C1 regarding S1’s personal sexual relationships. Additional interviews revealed that S1 stated to C1 and other clients in care, that S1 would be willing to engage in sexual relationships with clients once the clients left the facility and/or turned 18 years of age. Based on interviews and records review, the Department has determined a preponderance of evidence that Staff #1 (S1) made inappropriate comments to Client #1 (C1). The facility is cited for violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 3.1, Section 84072(d)(11) Personal Rights. A copy of this report, LIC 809-D, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to Thomas Ybarra Sr. An exit interview was conducted with Thomas Ybarra Sr.

On July 7, 2021, at 1:00 PM, an informal office conference was held with representatives from PHILOS Adolescent Treatment Centers Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facilities #336408176 and #360911251 . In attendance were: STRTP representatives Administrator Thomas Ybarra Sr., STRTP Consultant Randy Cima. Also in attendance from Community Care Licensing (CCL) were: LaCresha Cook Regional Manager (RM), Christina Barnes, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) and Lorena Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA). The following representatives were also in attendance from probation, county, and mental health, including Dianne Wolkenhauer, Anjelica Matus, Nathan Sacrano, Raul Manriquez, Juan Bretado, Rose Collins, Christopher Hernandez, Michelle Brown, Allison Brown, Jenell Ross, Rachel Rivas, Timothy Hougen, Kimberly Epps, and CARF (Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) representative Shar Whitmore. The following was discussed with the facility: 1. Accreditation requirements 2. Mental Health county contract status 3. Mental Health county approval (DHCS) 4. Medi-Cal certification status 5. Administrator Role During this meeting, LPA Barnes and RM Cook inquired about the facility’s STRTP accreditation. Per Mr. Ybarra the facility did not obtain an STRTP accreditation and plans to submit the application for accreditation this month- July 2021. Regional Manager Cook inquired if the facility had a Mental Health Program approval, Mr. Ybarra stated they have an approval as of March 2021. Regional Manager Cook inquired about the facility’s Medi-Cal certification; Mr. Ybarra stated the facility continues to have Medi-Cal certification as of now. Regional Manager Cook inquired about the facility’s county mental health contract, Mr. Ybarra stated the contract expired July 1, 2021 and the facility is seeking a mental health contract with other counties. Regional Manager Cook inquired about the Administrator role and hours spent at each facility, Mr. Ybarra stated he works at least 20 hours at each facility and more hours as needed.

The Department request that the facility formulate a plan of action on how they intent to proceed with their program and submit to CCL by August 4, 2021. The Department also request the facility is to provide the Personnel Report (LIC 500) from January 2020 to July 2021. The facility was advised that the Department will meet with the legal department for further instructions regarding the items that were discussed. LPA Valenzuela read and explained the report to Administrator Thomas Ybarra Sr., and gave a copy of the report to Administrator, Thomas Ybarra Sr.

On this date, November 10, 2021 at 08:15 AM, an unannounced required annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Wayne Aoki. LPA met with facility Administrator Maggie Mendez. LPA inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications and sharps are maintained in the staff office in a locked file cabinet. LPA inspected the medications for the minors in care. LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 999, LIC 610C There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of the inspection.

narrative: On December 1, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Quality Belmont STRTP located in Fresno CA. LPAs met with Administrator Maggie Mendez and Laura Romero. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 71 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on August 24, 2012. The facility is accredited through CARF with accreditation through May 31, 2025, and they are approved through Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health through May 26, 2023. No firearms or weapons are observed in the facility. There is no pool at the facility. LPAs reviewed 5 client files, and 5 staff files. LPAs interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. LPAs discussed the medication log, all required forms, intake process, needs and services plan, disaster preparedness plan and emergency intervention plan. LPAs requested the following updated documents by January 1, 2023. LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 999, LIC 610C. No deficiencies are being cited on today’s visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a complaint inspection at Quality Corporate office and met with Laura Romero. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff which revealed that the agency did not ensure that minor had fair and equal access to placement. Based on LPA's observations, interviews which were conducted and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87022(f). Plan of Operation. (f)The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so.   

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on record review and interviews, licensee is not following the facility’s current Plan of Operation and Program Statement by not providing fair and equal access to placement, which poses a potential health safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee stated they will complete a retraining, with Administration, Facility Managers, HOS, Clinicians and Placement officer, upon completion Licensee will email LPA Placencia verification that the training has been completed by end of business day on March 20, 2023.

investigation_findings: 13On March 19, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a complaint inspection at Quality STRTP Cambridge and met with Santiago Quinonez. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff, clients and reviewed supporting documentation which revealed that in fact the staff failed to supervise the youths which resulted in inappropriate behaviors. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. This facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1 Article 6 Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: 
(a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation the licensee did not comply with the section cited above in that the staff failed to supervise the youths which resulted in inappropriate behaviors, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

investigation_findings: 13On 05/03/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a follow up complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Clinton and spoke with Laura Romero. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, the complaint investigation was conducted by telephone. The purpose of the investigation is to deliver the findings for the above allegation. Interviews were conducted with staff and the clients in care. Based upon the content of the interviews and witness statements, it was determined that the staff knew that the clients in care have a history of acting out sexually and making poor choices. The staff still failed to provide the needed supervision to prevent this type of incident from occurring. Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to conclude that the allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. This report along with appeals rights are being emailed to the facility for signature and a scan back to CCL on this date.

deficiencies.description:
87078(b) RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROVIDING CARE AND SUPERVISION - The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's or nonminor dependent’s
needs and services plan, or Transitional Independent Living Plan, as necessary to meet the
child's or nonminor dependent’s needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff failed to provide the needed supervision of the clients in care as documented in their Needs and Services Plan, specifically when the child has a history of boundary issues with peers, sexual deviant distortions/arousal/interest and making impulsive actions manifested by poor judgement which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility shall provide additional  training to staff on implementing and following the client's Needs and Services Plan. Also provide training for providing proper supervision of clients in all areas of the facility at all times. All training and proof of completion shall be provided to Community Care Licensing by the POC date of 5/5/2021.

narrative: On 05/24/2021, an unannounced SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian at 2:00PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Laura Romero, Human Resource Manager and Juan Quevedo, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via FaceTime. All file and medication documents were sent to this LPA on the dates prior to inspection. In addition, a medication count was conducted. LPA reviewed three children's records and reviewed two staff personnel records for the facility. LPA interviewed two staff via telephone at 2:30PM. LPA did not interview any children in the home as all dependents refused an interview. No deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Laura Romero, Human Resource Manager at 3:00PM. A copy of this report was provided upon completion by email with a request for signature and a scan back to this LPA on this date.

investigation_findings: 13On May 17. 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a complaint inspection at this group home for the purpose of informing the facility of the results of the investigation. LPA met with facility representative, Laura Romero. A tele-inspection was conducted (ROM 20-11-CCLD) due to the pandemic. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA conducted interviews with staff and minors in care at the facility. The minor in care that allegedly was assaulted by staff indicated that the staff hit the minor while in the staff restroom. LPA reviewed video of two staff attempting to restrain the minor while in the staff office. The video evidence was inconclusive with regards to staff assaulting/hitting the minor. The minor involved stated that the staff did not hit him in the office but rather in the staff bathroom where there are no cameras. Other minors and staff that were interviewed either denied that the minor was hit or did not witness the alleged assault. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the above allegation occurred, therefore the above allegation is unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report along with appeals rights were emailed to the facility with a request for the signed document be provided to Community Care Licensing.

narrative: On June 18, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to discuss an incident that occurred on 02/20/2021. LPA was met by facility representative Laura Romero. On 2/20/2021 a client in care was acting out in the facility office. The client became aggressive and two staff attempted to restrain the client. The LPA determined that when the two staff went to take down the client, the failed to use proper restraint protocol. Based on the above, the facility is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. This report along with appeals rights are being provided to the facility.

On this date, October 13, 2021 at 08:20 AM, an unannounced required annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Wayne Aoki. LPA met with facility representative Juan Quevedo. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one week supply of nonperishable and a two day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 77 degrees. Hot water temperature measured 112 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. There are no bodies of water at the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and there are no pets. There was 1 Staff, 3 Minors and the present during the inspection. Both staff and minor's files reviewed. LPA interviewed 1 staff and 3 minors during the inspection. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan, sampled medication and reviewed facility logs. LPAs requested the following updated documents by October 22, 2021. LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 999, LIC 610C There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of the inspection.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a complaint inspection at Quality Corporate office and met with Laura Romero. investigation_findings: 13On 12/11/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Millbrook to conclude the investigation with regards to the above-mentioned allegations. Due to Covid-19 requirements, the closing of the allegation was conducted via telephone with a scan of this LIC9099 to facility representative, Laura Romero for a signature and a scan back to Community Care Licensing. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA interviewed the Complainant and the Facility Manager. Both interviews produced statements that were contrary to the allegations made. LPA made attempts to interview child in care. The child has been reunified with the biological parent. The child did not wish to speak with the LPA. Therefore, the parent did not give authorization for an interview of the child. LPA obtained copies from the facility of receipts and expenditures for the child. Based on the above, the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was provided by scan to the FFA Administrator.

narrative: On this date, October 20, 2021 at 08:30 AM, an unannounced required annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Wayne Aoki. LPA met with facility representative Sinsear Radford and Laura Romero LPA inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications and sharps are maintained in the staff office in a locked closet. LPA inspected the medications for the minors in care. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced May 6, 2021. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one week supply of nonperishable and a two day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. Hot water temperature measured 113 degrees. Facility has cameras or weapons are allowed in the facility and there are no pets. There was 1 Staff and 2 Minors present during the inspection. Both staff and minor's files reviewed. LPA interviewed 1 staff and 2 minors during the inspection. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan, sampled medication and reviewed facility logs. LPAs requested the following updated documents by October 29, 2021. LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 999, LIC 610C There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of the inspection.

investigation_findings: 13On October 6, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) was met by Administrator, Laura Romero for the purpose of concluding the investigation with regards to the above-mentioned allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted interviews with the minors in care and staff from the facility along with obtaining a copy of the Sheriff's report. When the LPA interviewed the youth that reported being hit by staff, his statement was not consistent with both the Sheriff's report and staff's accounting of the incident. All other minors in care did not have any knowledge of any staff hitting any minor in the facility. When staff and other minors were interviewed regarding the amount of food in the facility, all but one minor stated that there is no shortage of food in the facility. It is noted that during the intial 10 day inspection of the home, LPA observed the food supply in the facility which on that date met and exceeded the minimum requirement for food. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the above allegations occurred, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report along with appeals rights were left with Ms. Romero.

There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

The plan of correction was due on November 1, 2022 and was not met which prompted this plan of correction visit. On November 3, 2022, LPA received the updated Needs and Services plans from Human Resource Manager Laura Romero via email at 5:30pm. Licensee stated that the case manager did take on another caseload at another facility, and was a bit overwhelmed at the time. LPA advised that next time an extension can be requested. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility and there are no pets. There was 1 Staff, 2 Minors and the Administrator present during the inspection. Both staff and minor's files reviewed. investigation_findings: 13On 12/15/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Rialto at the Quality Family Services office to conclude the investigation with regards to the above-mentioned allegation. LPA was met by facility representative Laura Romero. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA interviewed staff and minors in care. LPA determined that although the minor in question did engaged in a physical altercation with a staff member, the staff member was in a defensive position and was hit/kicked and choked by the minor. The allegation may or may not have happened, or is or is not valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is deemed unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was provided to Ms. Romero.

13On 12/8/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Rialto to conclude the investigation with regards to the above-mentioned allegation. LPA was met by facility representative Laura Romero. During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA interviewed staff and minors in care. LPA determined that although the minors engaged in inappropriate sexual interactions with each other, staff did conduct bed checks on the minors approximately every 15-30 minutes. The minors disclosed that they would engage in the activity between the times that staff would conduct bed checks. Staff and Minors both confirmed that the facility policy is to conduct bed checks every 15-30 minutes when the minors are in their rooms. The allegation may or may not have happened, or is or is not valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are deemed unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was provided to Ms. Romero.

narrative: On December 15, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Quality Rialto STRTP located in Fresno CA. LPAs met with Administrator Sinsear Radford and Laura Romero. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 69 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers is properly charged and serviced in March 2022. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on December 1, 2018. The facility is accredited through CARF with accreditation through May 31, 2025, and they are approved through Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health through May 27, 2023. No firearms or weapons are reported in the facility. There is no pool and no pets at the facility. LPAs reviewed 5 client files, and 5 staff files. LPAs interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. LPAs discussed the medication log, all required forms, intake process, needs and services plan, disaster preparedness plan and emergency intervention plan. LPAs requested the following updated documents by January 16, 2023. LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 999, LIC 610C. Deficiencies are being cited on today’s visit include two type B violations. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

On April 4, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Quality STRTP Rialto and met with Sinesar Radford. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss a recent Neighborhood Complaint. LPA discussed the incident with the Neighborhood complaint, the census is currently at 3 due to the issues with the neighbor. The facility believes that the incident could have occurred back in November 2022. At this time the STRTP has had no further issues with the neighboring home and the youth in question and has since left the facility on February 2, 2023. LPA determined this to not be an immediate risk to health and safety at this time because the problem has been addressed and corrected, therefore no deficiency will be issued at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided to the facility.

LPA reviewed 1 of 3 child’s records and 2 of 2 staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 1 of 3 child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 2 of 2 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed no children currently on psychotropic medication, as they were in school at this time. investigation_findings: 13On July 12, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a follow up complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Sample and met with facility representative, Laura Romero. The purpose of the investigation is to deliver the findings for the above allegations. LPA conducted Interviews with staff, clients in care and witnesses. Based upon the content of the interviews and documents reviewed, it was determined that staff yelled and screamed at the youth in care, did not provide emergency personnel facility contact information and did not allow the youth in care to make a phone call during an incident at the facility. Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to conclude that the allegations are substantiated. The facility is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Corrections were reviewed and developed with Ms. Romero. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with the facility. Ms. Romero's whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents.

deficiencies.description: 87072(d)(10) Personal Rights - To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. deficiencies.description: 80075(h) Health Related Services - There shall be at least one person capable of and responsible for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility at all times.The following information shall be readily available:(1)The name, address and telephone number of each client's physician and dentist, and other medical and mental health providers, if any.(2)	The name, address and telephone number of each emergency agency, including but not limited to the fire department, crisis center or paramedical unit.  There shall be at least one medical resource available to be called at all times.(3)The name and telephone number of an ambulance service. deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(6)(C) Personal Rights - To be provided with and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items, 
consistent with Welfare & Institutions Code section 16001.9(a)(233), which 
includes their own: Personal belongings, including items that were a gift to the child unless 
prohibited by a discipline program.This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff confiscated minor's Identification card and social security card which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility has already addressed this issue with all staff that when they confiscate items that they are not to confiscate any personal items such as identification or Social Security cards. Facility addressed this issue shortly after CCL opened complaint as they knew this had occurred.
Deficiency Cleared during this inspection..

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(11) Personal Rights-The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, 
is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, 
as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the 
following personal rights:To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or 
unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, 
ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature 
including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, 
sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical 
functioning.This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Facility staff denied minor from showering after work which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility has already addressed this issue with all staff that they are to allow minor to shower after work even if it is after bed time. Faciltiy addressed this issue shortly after CCL opened complaint as they knew this occured after the fact.
Deficiency Cleared. Deficiency Cleared during the inspection..

deficiencies.description:
87074(c)(3) Transportation - Unless other arrangements are specified in the Needs and Services Plan or the Transitional 
Independent Living Plan for a child or nonminor dependent, a licensee shall ensure 
transportation is provided to the following: Extracurricular, *personal*enrichment, *cultural, racial, ethnic,* and social activities,
*in accordance with the reasonable and prudent parent standard specified in Section 
87067. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff did not transport minor to his/her employment in a timely manner causing the minor to be late which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: This has been addressed and staff shall transport all minors to their destination. If there is an issue that needs to be resolved with the minor, the facility will transport the minor and conclude the issue afterwards. Deficiency cleared during the inspection.

narrative: On August 29, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Quality STRTP Sample and met with Yvonne Carlos. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns with and incident report sent to Community Care Licensing (CCL) with the incident date of August 20, 2023, regarding a foster child #1 (811- Ref #1) absconding from the facility (According to staff, youth was followed until out of line of sight). It was also noted that foster child #2 (811-Ref #2) made allegations that #1 inappropriately touching youth without consent. (See 811 for confidential names). There is an ongoing police investigation for this matter. #1 has a history of absconding from the facility. #2 and #1 were in a verbal altercation prior to the allegations being made. Any further incidents will be reported to CCL in the form of incident reports. LPA determined this to not be an immediate risk to health and safety at this time because the problem has been addressed and corrected, therefore no deficiency will be issued at this time.

On September 6, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Quality STRTP Sample and met with Yvonne Carlos. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns with and incident report sent to Community Care Licensing (CCL) with the incident date of September 3, 2023, regarding a foster child #1 (811- Ref #1) got into a physical altercation with other youths in the home. Fresno Police Department was called by the neighbors as the youths were all fighting in the front of the home as staff was attempting to de-escalate and separate all the youth. #1 was taken to Fresno Community for medical clearance and the charges are "In-sighting a fight usual racial slurs" being placed on #1. #1 returned back to the facility on 9/3/23 at 730pm, after not meeting the criteria for a 5150. #1 absconded again at 805pm, that is when #1 began hitting the van, yelling throughout the streets and making allegations of "rape" "sample staff rape kids" as she walked throughout the neighborhood. A CFT was held on 9/5/2023, and it was determined that a 14 day notice would be placed on #1 as the team agreed that #1 needs a placement that is not in the city and or out of county due to her absconding and being very familiar with the Fresno Area. 14-day notice is set to expire on September 19, 2023. LPA determined this to not be an immediate risk to health and safety at this time because the problem has been addressed and corrected, therefore no deficiency will be issued at this time.

investigation_findings: 13On 06/18/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki conducted a follow up complaint inspection for Quality Family Services - Warner. LPA and Special Investigator conducted Interviews with staff and the clients in care. narrative: On March 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Wayne Aoki conducted an unannounced random inspection at Quality Yale STRTP located in Fresno CA. LPAs met with Facility Manager Sherry Blout and Laura Romero. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 70 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced on March 17, 2023. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on December 1, 2018. The facility is accredited through CARF with accreditation through May 31, 2025, and they are approved through Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health through May 27, 2023. No firearms or weapons are observed in the facility. There is a pool at the facility. LPAs reviewed 4 client files, and 5 staff files. LPAs interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. LPAs discussed the medication log, all required forms, intake process, needs and services plan, disaster preparedness plan and emergency intervention plan. LPAs requested the following updated documents by May 1, 2023. LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 999, LIC 610C. Deficiencies are being cited on today’s visit, that include two type A violations and one type B violation, and and one technical advisory. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

narrative: On August 30, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Quality STRTP Yale and met with Michelle Dodd. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns with and incident report sent to Community Care Licensing (CCL) with the incident date of August 14, 2023, regarding a foster child #1 (811- Ref #1) taking and unknown amount of sleeping pills and being admitted to the hospital. Staff #2 (811- Ref #2) reported that #3 (811-Ref #3) informed #2 that there was pills in the house. #2 conducted a facility safety check of the home and three rooms, no pills were found. After the incident it was disclosed by #1 that the youth stole the pills on a community outing. Thus staff was unaware that the pills were in the home. #2 and #4 were suspended for two days due to not following the communication protocol for this incident. Any further incidents will be reported to CCL in the form of incident reports. LPA determined this to not be an immediate risk to health and safety at this time because the problem has been addressed and corrected, therefore no deficiency will be issued at this time.

deficiencies.description:
87072 PERSONAL RIGHTS
(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9…….
(1) To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the licensee cussed at youth in care, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee states that the plan of correction is that a training will be completed with staff on professionalism and personal rights. Licensee will submit this in writing to LPA Placencia via email by 7/3/24 and the training will be completed by 7/16/24.

deficiencies.description:
80087	Buildings and Grounds	
(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and interviews, the licensee had visible mold in the common bath area, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will have their maintenance person re-grout the shower and the tub. Licensee will submit photo verification to LPA Placencia via email by 7/16/24.

narrative: On March 20, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted an unannounced annual random inspection at this facility. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator Maggie Mendez. An inspection of the facility was conducted and the following was observed: No clients were residing in the home; therefore, no client files were reviewed. LPA reviewed the administrator file. The facility was inspected indoors and outdoors. Hot water temperature was at a comfortable temperature of 108.6 degrees in the hall restroom. Home temperature was 59 degrees, due to no clients present. Fire Extinguishers were last serviced on February 24, 2025. LPA observed that there were no supply of perishables and non-perishables, LPA observed adequate supply of linen and storage space for clients. All furnishings were in place for 6 clients. Cleaning chemicals were inaccessible to clients. The facility is accredited by CARF through May 31, 2025. The facility is approved by the Department of Behavioral health through May 27, 2025. There are no weapons observed at the facility. There is a pool at the facility. LPA left a copy of this inspection at the facility.

met_with: Judy Dubeau, Alfredo Ceja, Randy Romero
narrative: On January 29, 2021, staff from Community Care Licensing (CCL) and Continuum of Care Reform (CCR) met with staff from the RAFT. Present in the meeting were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Juanita Arroyo, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo, CCR Policy Manager Alicia Bernstein, Policy Analyst (PA) Christopher Meyer, The RAFT Administrators Judy Dubeau and Alfredo Ceja and Director of Operations Randy Romero. The meeting was conducted via Microsoft teams. The purpose of the meeting was to provide technical assistance on the revisions for the Plan of Operation and Program Statement. During the meeting, the Raft staff asked questions on revisions requested by CCL and CCR. LPA and PA answered all questions asked during the meeting. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. Due to Covid-19 requirements, this report is being emailed to the facility for a signature and a scan back to CCL on this date.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAS) Lisa Slusher travelled to the facility listed above to conduct a prelicensing inspection. The facility listed above submitted an application for a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on 5/15/20. The application, Plan of Operation and Program statement have been reviewed and approved by both Community Care Licensing and the Systems of Care/ Continuum of Care Reform Bureau. Facility Inspection conducted. 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. Chemicals removed from under the sink in Bathroom #2 during inspection. 4. Procedures for Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Discussed medication logs and procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit observed. Lacks tweezers, scissors, Thermometer, first manual and antiseptic solution. 6. Additional Individual storage space required in client bedrooms- 2 drawers (8 cu ft) of space is required for each youth. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. Beds lack box springs. Facility will also send verification of sixth bed. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Adequate supply of food to be in place prior to accepting youth for placement. 10. Weekly menu to be posted. 11.Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12.Facility has two full restrooms in the house for client use, both are operable. A third restroom is available in the staff office for staff use.

13. Forms posted- personal rights form with licensing phone number to be posted. 14. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during Inspection 1. LIC 500 Reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. Direct care staff to be hired. The facility does not utilize Peer Partners at this time. 2. Administrator Alfredo Ceja will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Personnel Files are retained at the office and will be available to the department for review upon request at the Family Builders office at 3300 S.Fairway #104 Visalia, 93277. Facility has a guardian account set up with Administrative access. 4. Facility procedures for 30-day updates of Needs and Services plans and process for Crisis Management Assessments discussed. 5. Facility is to ensure all clients considered for placement have been assessed as meeting placement eligibility requirements. 6. Discussed implementation of Core Services and Supports. 7. Facility to obtain Mental Health Program approval within 12 months of effective date of licensure and will provide appropriate documentation to the department upon approval. Agency will also provide regular updates to the department regarding progress toward MHPA. 8. Facility is to contact the Foster Care Rates and Audits Division to inquire about rate and about whether this new facility meets accreditation requirements effective 10/1/21 as a part of FFPSA (Family First Prevention Services Act) Component III Orientation provided to licensee which included information regarding incident reporting procedures, facility, client and staff record requirements, application of prudent parent standards and client personal rights. On this date, this facility is recommended for licensure on a provisional basis upon receipt of verification of additions to first aid kit, box springs and individual drawer space. License will expire one year from effective date. Facility will licensed for a capacity of 6 Male clients ages 12-NMD, licensee will maintain age and behavioral compatibility. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. Licensee prefers Wards and Dependents.

narrative: Staff interviewed confirmed that the clients propensity to run was well known so they paid close attention to her moods and behavior. When staff was aware the client was going to AWOL, she was offered alternatives and interventions but inevitably would chose to leave the facility anyway and would do so in such a way that she was able to elude the staff that would follow and encourage her return. The second allegation is in reference to the client not being adequately fed. Both staff and clients contend that food was available for the client when she was in the facility and that she would eat meals and snacks along with the other clients. However, When she was AWOL there was no ensuring that she ate. Client in question was not available to confirm or deny and three clients would not provide a statement. Based on the interviews, inspection and documents reviewed, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time. A copy of this report will be provided to the Facility Representative for signature and return. Appeal Rights were also provided.
investigation_findings: 13On February 17, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an unannounced inspection via telephone in compliance with COVID 19 restrictions. LPA spoke with Krystal Ramos, Facility Supervisor in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations. On January 5, 2021 the above allegations were referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. The investigation included review of documentation supplied by the STRP, interviews with clients in care and staff members who worked with the client in question. The complaint alleged there was a lack of supervision allowing the client to AWOL and that the staff did not ensure the same client was adequately fed. One of the clients stated that the staff spend all their time in the office and provide no supervision while the other interviewed stated that the staff did indeed supervise the clients and in this case were very present for the client and always offered alternatives to running including taking a walk or going for a drive. Client in question was not available to confirm or deny and three clients would not provide a statement.

narrative: Staff interviewed confirmed that the clients propensity to run was well known so they paid close attention to her moods and behavior. When staff was aware the client was going to AWOL, she was offered alternatives and interventions but inevitably would chose to leave the facility anyway and would do so in such a way that she was able to elude the staff that would follow and encourage her return. The second allegation is in reference to the client not being picked up from school timely. Staff contend that efforts were made to pick the client up but there was occasion when the staff had to return to school because she was in the office waiting while staff was looking around the campus and another time when school personnel had to return the child to the STRTP because she would not accept a ride home from staff despite their efforts to take her home. One client stated that staff would forget to pick her up while another client did not know or remember anything about the client's transportation to school. Client in question was not available to confirm or deny and three clients would not provide a statement. Based on the interviews, inspection and documents reviewed, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations occurred. Therefore, the allegations that the foster child was not prevented from AWOLing and was not provided adequate transportation from school are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time. A copy of this report will be provided to the Facility Representative for signature and return. Appeal Rights were also provided.

On July 7, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Rachel Bruce and Priscilla Zamudio met with Angela Martinez at the Joerg STRTP. The purpose of the visit was to inspect the fence that had been taken down due to a fire at the property adjacent to the STRTP on the south side. narrative: On October 1, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an unannounced Case Management- Informal Conference for the purpose of discussing the number and severity of complaints against the facility. Specifically, on July 13, 2021 a complaint was opened regarding a client (FC1) accessing unlocked medication and overdosing. This complaint was found to be substantiated. Findings revealed that while staff was involved with another client who was causing substantial property damage, FC1 absconded out of her bedroom window unnoticed. She proceeded to climb through the unlocked bathroom window to the office. Once inside she accessed the unlocked medicine storage unit and overdosed on her own medication. Staff admitted that while the office was locked the medicine cabinet and the bathroom window were both unlocked and ultimately accessible to the client. A citation was issued for not securing medicine. For purposes of this meeting CCL is focusing on JOERG. CCL acknowledges and will honor the STRTP closure plan effective 10/4/21. As such, there will be no citations issued at this time. Acknowledging the planned closure does not negate legal action in the future or CCL's ability to consult with their legal division

narrative: On January 15, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted a case management inspection. The purpose of the visit is to address issues of staff compliance on reporting. In compliance with Covid-19 restrictions, this case management inspection was conducted over the telephone. LPA was interviewing a staff member regarding a client who felt she was bullied/harassed by staff regarding her weight. In the course of the interview the staff member stated he had been told by the client that she was hurt and felt bad about the exchanges with other staff members but this particular staff member did not elevate the issue or raise any concerns with management because he did not want to betray the trust of the client. When interviewing the client who felt 'bullied', she stated that as a result of her feeling bad, she would 'cut' as a coping mechanism. The client showed LPA Bruce the recent cutting and when asked, the client admitted that she had shared with a another staff member that she had been cutting. Her perception was that nothing was done about it because no one ever checked on her. Discussion was had between LPA Bruce and Administrator Jason Enger on the importance of staff elevating concerns voiced by the clients regardless of keeping a confidence and regardless of whether they believe the client or not. In this case, staff ignoring the client's concerns did nothing to stop the bad behavior by staff and the inappropriate behavior of the client cutting as a coping mechanism. Administrator will see these concerns addressed immediately with all staff. No deficiencies cited during this case management inspection.

Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegation is substantiated. Deficiencies were cited and a copy of this report and appeal rights will be provided to Angela Martinez for signature.

narrative: Further the client stated that the staff member sent text messages to her phone which were intended for the other client. This foster child is willing to have her phone forensically searched to retrieve the photos and texts. A staff member stated she had witnessed the male staff in question, slap the female foster child on the buttock and reported the inappropriate interaction to her manager. The manager relayed to LPA that he informed the Administrator who allegedly conducted an investigation and determined that it did not happen so no action was taken. When LPA asked the manager if he felt that the staff who reported the incident would have lied to him, he stated he had no reason to believe she would. In October 2020, LPA Bruce located and interviewed the foster child directly involved. She relayed to LPA Bruce that she was fearful she would be getting in trouble but wanted to tell the truth. She stated that she and the staff member had exchanged naked pictures and inappropriate text messages. This client no longer had the phone and stated she had borrowed the phone of her former roommate at the STRTP. She has blocked the staff member from her current phone and has had no contact with him since May. She refused to answer when asked if she had been coerced or threatened by the staff member. Based on the subsequent investigation that included review of records, ongoing facility inspections, and interviews of staff and clients, LPA Bruce has determined he preponderance of the evidence now shows the allegations are SUBSTANTIATED. The staff member exchanged inappropriate pictures with the client as well as touched the client in an inappropriate fashion. A citation and Appeal Rights were issued.

investigation_findings: 13On February 26 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an announced complaint inspection via telephone in accordance with COVID-19 restrictions. LPA spoke with House Supervisor, Dely Azarate. The purpose of the phone call was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. LPA conducted an investigation that included review of staff and client records, ongoing facility inspections, as well as interviews of staff and clients. Two clients interviewed stated staff would speak negatively and inappropriately however staff and other clients interviewed stated they did not. Again, regarding the allegation of clients being treated unfairly, two clients felt that another client got special treatment while another client felt that was not true.
