Treatment and behavior towards clients by staff is in accordance with their individual plans, not discretionary treatment.

narrative: The Program Statement for the group home indicates that a child's request for medical attention after returning from AWOL shall be accommodated. The second allegation is that staff monitor phone calls. The house phone which the clients use to make calls is located in the kitchen (a common area of the house). Because there are staff and/or clients in the common area when clients are allowed to use the phone, clients calls are not private and easily monitored by staff who are present. Unless a client has a personal cell phone, calls made to their social worker, ombudsman, CCL are made in a public area with no privacy. The third allegation is that staff lock clients out of the facility. This was in reference to children returning from AWOL. Clients must be searched for contraband and other potentially unsafe material upon returning from an unauthorized outing. If the client refuses to be searched they must wait outside the facility for everyone's safety until Law Enforcement arrives to conduct the search. However, client's personal rights are violated when they are denied access to the home and are made to wait outside. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews and records review which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegations are found to be substantiated. Deficiencies will be cited at todays visit. A copy of this report, along with appeal rights, will be provided to the Director for signature and return.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an unannounced visit to the Foster Family Agency Rainbow Valley in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations. On September 16, 2020 the above allegations were referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. The investigation included interviews with the Reporting Party, foster children, and staff as well as review of facility and foster children's records. The first allegation is that staff refused medical care for a minor who returned late in the evening from an unauthorized absence. Upon her return to the facility the client indicated that she would like to seek medical care for a leg injury which occurred during her absence. Staff did not take the client that evening instead they took her later in the week. (continue)

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights:  To receive medical, dental, vision and mental health services. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Client requested medical care upon her return from AWOL but was not taken to the doctor until later in the week.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will be instructed to accommodate medical care requests immediately and elevate any denials to ensure the safety and health of the client is addressed- necessary program statement changes will be submitted by April 9, 2021.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights:  To make and receive confidential telephone calls unless prohibited by court order.  

This requirement was not met as evidenced by : There is only one house phone for clients to use and it is located in the kitchen (common area) not allowing any privacy.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Administrator will make a cordless phone available immediately to all clients to ensure privacy.

deficiencies.description:
Discipline Policies and Procedures: Any form of discipline which violates a child's personal rights as specified in Section 87072 shall be prohibited.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff will lock out clients returning from AWOL if they refuse to be searched.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Clients who AWOL and refuse to be searched will be handled in the facility and not made to wait outside.  Standards of when to involve LE will be established to mitigate the number of calls to LE Necessary program statement changes will be submitted to CCL by April 9, 2021

narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce travelled to the facility listed above to conduct an announced annual required inspection. A general overview of their program and tour of the facility inside and out was provided on this date. The agency's current LIC500 accurately reflects current staffing. The STRTP is licensed to serve 6 ambulatory identifying female clients ages 12-17 years old. Current capacity is 6. LPA observed the following: 1. Facility Grounds have a few issues to be addressed. See Deficiency page attached. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. Facility is in compliance. 5. First aid kit complete and accessible 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed with clean linens 8. The house has 3 bedrooms for clients, double occupancy, all located on the upstairs level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Monthly menu and monthly activity schedule is posted and accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12. Facility has one and a half restrooms in the house for client use, both are operable. 13. Client's rights and other appropriate and required are forms posted in view of clients. 14. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. 15. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. CONTINUED

Inspection of the client's files reflect appropriate and timely documentation. All JV220's were checked as well as Needs and Services and found to be in compliance with the regulations. Inspection of a sample of the staff files was completed. All were appropriately associated to the facility and received fingerprinting and child abuse index check clearances. Training is up to date and filed/documented and in compliance. Deficiencies cited during this inspection relate to Buildings and Grounds. See attached. A copy of this report along with appeal rights will be left with the facility.

On September 24, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the Rainbow Valley STRTP- Cavalaire Court. LPA Bruce conducted a case management inspection with Angela Martinez for the purpose of discussing the following concerns: 1. The requirement and necessity to report any unusual incident relating to the safety and well being of clients in care. On September 16, 2021, the foster children in the home accessed paint and did considerable damage to the property by painting obscenities on the wall and spreading paint across the walls. This incident was not reported timely or through the appropriate channels. A citation for missing this requirement will be issued at today's visit. 2. Access to dangerous items. On September 16, 2021, a foster child in the home accessed paint that was not securely stored. As a result there was considerable damage to the property. The paint was accessible because the children were in the middle of an art project when one of the children chose to vandalize the property. Although staff were available the foster child did not respond to direction or de-escalation. No citation will be issued at this time.

On October 4, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce conducted an announced visit to the facility to have the facility licence relinquished and signed over to CCL. LPA conducted a tour of the home and noted that there are no residents and no personal belongings or medication. Staff was on site cleaning and boxing up supplies. Angela Martinez signed the back of the license indicating that the facility would be closed effective today.

The above-mentioned allegation was investigated by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Douglas Real. On September 4, 2020, CCLD received a complaint referral alleging facility staff sexually abused minor while in care and staff provided alcohol to minor while in care. Information obtained during the investigation including interviews and review of related reports from Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) did not provide enough evidence to support allegations. Child #1 indicated that he engaged in sexual activity with Staff #1 in a supply room at the facility and a couple of weeks later he engaged in sexual intercourse with Staff #1 in her room. There were no witnesses to either sexual encounter. Child #1 denied that facility staff provided alcohol to him while he was in care. It has been determined that the allegations are

facility_name: RANCHO SAN ANTONIO BOYS HOME, INC
narrative: On August 19, 2021, at 1pm Licensing Program Analyst, LPA Donald Martin made an inspection visit to Rancho San Antonio for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Investigation. LPA met with Judy Brevaire, Clinical Director (CD). The department received several SIR's regarding clients overdosing while in care of the facility. As a result some of the clients were detained and some remain at the facility. The clients that have returned from the Emergency Room back to the facility have been put on Relapse Prevention Plans that include a written safety plan, individual therapy, drug treatment therapist, and a child family Specialist for skill building. The facility has created supervision planning and training to increase staff awareness with the clients, documentation, and the location of the Naloxone in case of an emergency. They have increased room searches, CFT's were conducted immediately for all youth on campus regarding Fentanyl and CFT's are conducted every 30 days to get ahead of an issue with the client. A drug prevention committee was formed that includes CD, the residential director and several therapists to discuss daily the progress with the new program and the clients. According to CD the idea is to become more proactive than reactive. No clients were interviewed during this visit due to them being in school. Nothing further to report at this time.

facility_name: RANCHO SAN ANTONIO BOYS HOME, INC
narrative: On May 5, 2022 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation. LPA met with Program Director, Judy Brevaire and discussed the incident. Client stated that he was injured (whiplash) in an accident on 3/16/2022, while out in the facility vehicle. LPA conducted interviews. Special Incident Report dated 4/29/2022 indicated C1 reported whiplash over 30 days after being involved in a car accident in the facility vehicle. There was no evidence to support claim and no evidence to support facility staff did not provide medical attention. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility. Nothing further to report at this time.

facility_name: RANCHO SAN ANTONIO - BROTHER JOHN'S HOUSE
narrative:
On O3/14/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of concluding a Case Management – Incident Inspection. LPA and LPM spoke with Residential Director, Troy McNair. A health and safety assessment were conducted. On 02/11/2024, the department received an Incident Report, dated 02/10/2024, indicating that Child 1 (C1) was told by Staff 1 (S1) that they were off privileges due to negative behaviors. Staff 1 was instructed to disengage and sat in the lobby. C1 walked towards S1, called him an inappropriate name, and spat in S1 face. S1 got up off the sofa, grabbed C1, and the two stumbled out the lobby door, and wrestled C1 onto the ground outside the unit. During the investigation process, LPA obtained the S1 termination letter, conducted interviews, and reviewed video recording of incident. On video recording S1 is observed inappropriately tackling C1 by placing both hands on C1, leading C1 through lobby door, and engaging in altercation with C1 after C1 spat on S1. Due to the evidence obtained during the investigation the following deficiency is cited per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) – 87072 Personal Rights. Staff 1 restrained C1 and engaged in an altercation. Cont 809-C

An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Troy McNair, Residential Director.

deficiencies.description:
87072 (16) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishmen, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: 
On video recording S1 is observed inappropriately tackling C1 by placing both hands on C1, leading C1 through lobby door, and engaging in altercation with C1 after C1 spat on S1.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction was discussed. S1 was terminated on 02/16/2024, due to incident. Video recording of incident, S1 training records, and Pro-Act certificates recieved during employment are due to LPA Donald Martin by 03/21/2024.

facility_name: RANCHO SAN ANTONIO - BROTHER JOHN'S HOUSE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of concluding a Case Management – Incident Inspection. LPA spoke with Contracts and Compliance Director, Zeena Burse. A health and safety assessment were conducted. On 7/8/2024, the department received an Incident Report, dated 7/7/2024, indicating that Child 1 (C1) after having water thrown on him by Child #2 (C2), punched two holes in the wall. Incident Report further indicates that C1 will be charged for property damage. LPA spoke with Zeena Burse, S2 and S3 and discussed adding the properties of the Program Statement which indicates that restitution can be imposed on a child or non-minor dependent in a manner that is consistent with trauma-informed practices. RSA shall impose fines for acts of vandalism, damage of property and to replace stolen property only after review with Probation, DCFS, and/or a Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting. C1 was unavailable for comment. There was no evidence that restitution has been imposed without further review with placing agency. On 6/14/2024 LPA advised Administrator, Troy McNair to amend Program Statement and outline written policies ensuring that cash resources are not taken from children in care in the form of fines/restitution. Revisions should be submitted by 06/28/2024, for review. LPA has advised S2 to ensure that verbiage on future incident reports are consistent with the above revisions. Based on the information obtained, no further investigation is needed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Contracts and Compliance Director, Zeena Burse. There were no deficiencies cited at time.

facility_name: RANCHO SAN ANTONIO - SAINT ANTHONY'S HOUSE
narrative:
On March 17, 2023 at 9am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin and Deputy Director (DD) Kevin Gaines arrived at the above facility. The purpose of this visit is to complete a Post-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Troy McNair, Residential Director who escorted us through the inspection. Saint Anthony's Youth Support annex: This unit has the capacity of no more than 16 clients ambulatory Minor and Non-Minor dependents ages 12-17yrs old. St Anthony: The cottage has 8 individual bedrooms all equip with two beds, two stand up closets that contain a clothes hanging area, two dresser drawers and two large desks. There are two large windows in front of each bed that have large pull down window covers. Each room has its own bathroom that contains a sink, toilet and shower all in good working condition. The day room is equip with couches and a dining table with enough seating to accommodate staff and clients. Adjacent to the day room is a kitchen area with a refrigerator, stove, toaster oven and a microwave. The kitchen is only used for snacks or heating up meals. Clients eat their meals in the dining hall located on the campus. There was perishable fruit accessible to clients and there were other snacks available on request. The TV room has a large mounted TV attached to the wall and a computer area that houses 3 computers for the clients use. There are two large bookshelves containing books for the clients use. The office is at the front of the hallway. Clients files, sharps, snacks and other items are kept in there. Clients on medication has it administered by nurses. The medication is kept in the infirmary. Note: The Pool is in a large locked building on the campus away from the dorm Cont 809-C

The Laundry Room contains 2 washers and 2 dryers in good working condition. Inside the laundry room is a cabinet that has a lock on it where cleaning supplies are kept. The laundry room has a lock on the door. Clients must be allowed access to enter the laundry room. LPA advised Residential Director, Troy McNair the following things: Keep the cleaning supply cabinet locked at all times. Discard can goods (not expired, but no plans of use) that were kept stored in the kitchen cabinet. Place the word "Grievance" on the Suggestion box and check it daily. An Administrator or Facility Manager should be the only ones checking the box. Staff and clients interviewed. Staff and client files inspected. No deficiencies cited at the time of the inspection.

REPORT AMENDED ON 06/14/2024 TO CHANGE LANGUAGE On 06/14/2024, at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of concluding a Case Management – Incident Inspection. LPA spoke with Residential Director, Troy McNair. A health and safety assessment were conducted. On 02/03/2024, the department received an Incident Report, dated 02/02/2024, indicating that Child 1 (C1) was told by Staff 1 (S1) that he was unable to use the telephone to call a nonapproved telephone number. C1 escalated, walked out the office, and caused damage to cork board due to punching with right hand. Incident Report further indicates that C1 will be charged for property damage. LPA spoke with Troy McNair and obtained copy of Program Statement. Program Statement indicates that restitution shall be imposed on a child or non-minor dependent in a manner that is consistent with trauma-informed practices. RSA shall impose fines for acts of vandalism, damage of property and to replace stolen property only after review with Probation, DCFS, and/or a Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting. There was no evidence that restitution has been imposed without further review with placing agency. There was no evidence that C1 was not allowed to make a phone call. Evidence indicated that C1 was not allowed to make a call to a non-approved telephone number indicated in his intake documents. Children in care can make phone calls unless prohibited by information gathered in the initial CFT meeting. Facility representative was advised to amend Program Statement and outline written policies ensuring that cash resources are not taken from children in care in the form of fines/restitution. Revisions should be submitted by 06/28/2024, for review. Based on the information obtained, no further investigation is needed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Troy McNair, Residential Director.There were no deficiencies cited at time.

facility_name: REACH TO WIN YOUTH HOME & FAMILIY SERVICES INC
narrative:
On January 26, 2023 at 1:45pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with Licensee/applicant, Alicia Culbertson. This Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program is a one story house located in a residential area. The facility consists of 3 client bedrooms, living and dining areas, kitchen and laundry area. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is a hot tub on the facility premises, and meets safety standards. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway, outside of the client bedrooms. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 108 degrees Fahrenheit.

Staff and client files will be kept in a locked filing cabinet. Medications will be centrally stored and locked in the pantry. Disinfectants and other toxic materials will be locked in a cabinet, in the garage. Extra bedding and towels are kept in the hallway closet. Knives and sharps will be kept locked in the pantry. Head of Services (HOS) for this location will be hired. Personal Rights and client grievance forms will be posted in a community area. LPA Pavia will notify licensee, once POO/PS is approved and facility is licensed. Component II: LPA Pavia discussed with the following, with Licensee: - Administrator on site required hours - facility core services and support - facility emergency intervention plan

facility_name: REACH TO WIN YOUTH HOME FACILITY 1
narrative: On 2/23/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and Health Program Specialist (HPS) Shamika Payne conducted a required annual inspection. LPA and HPS met with Administrator Alicia Culbertson and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the inspection, the CARE Inspection Tool was used. A tour of the inside and outside of the facility as well as a review of facility records were conducted. LPA and HPS discussed facility procedures and provided feedback on program implementation. The facility was observed to be in safe condition, with clean double-occupancy bedrooms ready for residents' use, sanitary kitchen and bathrooms, and clean activity spaces. There is ample storage for residents' personal belongings as well as locked storage for medications, chemicals, and dangerous household items, such as kitchen knives. Administrator agreed to obtain and post the foster care ombudspersons office personal rights poster. Additionally, Administrator agrees to submit a written waiver request for the cameras around the facility. Some areas in which technical support will be beneficial were documented on the LIC 9102s provided with this report. No deficiency citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Alicia Culbertson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

facility_name: REACH TO WIN YOUTH HOME FACILITY 1
narrative:
On 03/11/2025 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti and LPA Simran Nayyar conducted a required annual inspection. LPAs met with Facility Manager, Tyisha Jefferson and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPAs used the CARE Inspection Tool and conducted a tour of the facility site, review of 5 personnel records and 2 resident records, and confidential interviews with 1 staff member and 0 residents. Residents declined an interview. LPAs observed the facility to be in good condition, clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The facility currently has 2 residents and each resident has their own bedroom with individual beds and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. Cameras are posted in public spaces, and the licensee recently submitted program statement revisions with surveillance camera procedures, as requested. LPAs observed personnel and resident records to be complete and had all necessary documents. Staff have full background clearances, valid intervention and first aid training certifications, and have completed their annual training hours. Residents' records contain current emergency contact information, complete care plans, and accurate medication and cash records. Based on interviews, LPAs observed staff to be knowledgeable of facility policies, mandated reporting, and intervention procedures. LPAs observed residents to each be provided 1:1 supervision, to be dressed in well-fitting, appropriate, and clean clothes, and to appear comfortable in care, showing no hesitation around staff or in responding to staff guidance.Continue on LIC809-C

No deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Administrator, Alicia Culbertson whose signature confirms receipt.

narrative: LPA is issuing citations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87074 (e) Transportation, 87022 (f) Plan of Operation, and 87072 (c)(16) Personal Rights. investigation_findings: 13On 7/23/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Tyisha Jefferson, Facility Manager and informed them of the purpose of the visit. LPA spoke with Administrator, Alicia Culbertson over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. On the allegations of Facility did not ensure safe transportation, Staff did not utilize proper deescalation tactics, and Staff did not ensure the health and safety of clients in care: LPA reviewed documentation and conducted confidential interviews. Based on LPA’s review of documentation and interviews, LPA found that on 6/11/25 as staff were transporting the clients in care back to the facility from a hospital, a client became escalated. Based on interviews it was found that the involved staff member had not utilized proper de-escalation tactics which caused for unsafe transportation while putting the clients and staff safety at risk. (See LIC9099-C).

deficiencies.description:
87074 Transportation 
(e): The licensee shall ensure that the transportation provided safeguards the health and safety of a child and shall not violate the personal rights of a child … and to not be subjected to discrimination based on actual or perceived… mental or physical disability…
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and document research, licensee did not ensure the transportation provided safeguarded the health and safety of clients due staff swerving on the highway which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to hold training on providing safe transportation while a client is escalating. Licensee will provide training plan, materials, and schedule to LPA email by 7/24/25 at 5pm

deficiencies.description:
87022 Plan of Operation
(f) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation…
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and document research, licensee did not ensure staff followed the facility plan of operation due to staff not implementing the Crisis Intervention and De-escalation Plan in accordance with terms specified in the Plan of Operation which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to hold training on the de-escalation tactics and treating clients with respect while a client is escalated. Licensee will provide training plan, materials, and schedule to LPA email by 7/24/25 at 5pm

deficiencies.description:
c) The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights…: (16) To be free of… emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment,…, humiliation,…  or other actions of a punitive nature…
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and document research, licensee did not ensure a clients’ personal rights were accorded due to staffs ridicule and humiliation towards a client in care which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to hold training on the de-escalation tactics and treating clients with respect while a client is escalated. Licensee will provide training plan, materials, and schedule to LPA email by 7/24/25 at 5pm

facility_name: REDWOOD COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC - SEQUOIA HOUSE
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection on 10/23/23 at 12:00 PM at the above location, as required for the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) licensure. LPA met with Lorraine Montano, Administrator. During the pre-licensing visit, LPA conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. LPA observed the facility was clean inside and safe. The outside of the facility is fenced in the backyard, and spacious, clean and well maintained for outdoor activities. LPA observed that there are two floors to the facility. LPA observed three client bedrooms, equipped with appropriate furniture, bedding, and supplies for clients. Sufficient storage space for client’s personal belongings was observed in each room. The facility is requesting to be licensed for 3 clients. (10 staff are hired but staff will work according to ratio, and additional staff will be on-call). LPA observed a medication cabinet in the medication room with a medication fridge which was empty, but locked, and accessible only to designated staff. The kitchen area was equipped with an adequate number of utensils, dining supplies, and cups for clients. No food was observed as there are no clients, and no pending placement at this time. Facility will verify required food on hand at time of client placement. LPA observed a staff office space that is locked and inaccessible to clients, where client records will be locked in file cabinets in a lock closet. Facility has a garage used for maintenance supplies and is locked and made inaccessible for clients. The laundry room does not have a door, but all cleaning supplies are locked up high in cabinets. The smoke detectors were tested and found to be functional during the inspection and there were functioning carbon monoxide detectors on each floor of the facility. Four fire extinguishers were present with a recent inspection date of 9/30/23. A fully equipped first aid kit was in the kitchen area. Pre-licensing report continued on 809c

The Foster Youth Bill of Rights was posted in a conspicuous location. There are two bathrooms in the facility that are accessible to client use. The water temperature was tested and found to be 115 DEGREES. The facility is ready for licensure as a STRTP and LPA recommends that the facility be licensed. A signed copy of this report was provided to Lorraine Montano, Administrator. End of report.

facility_name: REDWOOD COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC - SEQUOIA HOUSE
narrative:
On 12/11/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Amanda Shelton - Clinical Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required, Two year Annual Inspection of the facility. This is the facility's first inspection. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with five client bedrooms, two which are used as offices, one is a recreation room and the other two are client bedrooms. There is a large open kitchen with an attached dining area, and living room with a fire place made inaccessible to clients in care. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. There is no backyard, but does have a fenced side yard with a punching bag and grass area for a badminton set which is not out all the time. A variety of games can be found in a locked closet inside the facility for use. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility has one client bathroom and two staff bathroom. All were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the office refrigerator. The garage is used for storage of needed supplies and equipment. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office back room. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has 2 clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 2. Staff to client ratio is 3 staff to two clients. LPA reviewed 3 staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA interviewed 3 staff on site. continued on 809-C page

LPA reviewed 2 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans and updated Needs and Service plans every 30 days. The facility had evidence of attempting to obtain signatures from placing agencies. Needs and Service Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. 1 of 2 clients were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current JV-220’s on file. A signed copy of this LIC-809 an additional documents of the report was provided to Amanda Shelton Clinical Program manager. An exit interview was conducted.

facility_name: REDWOOD COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC - SEQUOIA HOUSE
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a Case Management following the review of Serious Incident Reports submitted by the facility to the Department. LPA met with Program Manager, Amanda Shelton. On March 4, 2025, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall conducted a review of the Serious Incident Reports (IRs) which were submitted to the Department between December 2024 and February 2025. LPM determined eleven (11), 24-hour IR’s were submitted late, and 15 full IR’s were submitted late. Three of the full IR’s submitted late, were not preceded by a 24-hour report. Four of the 24-hour IR’s did not have a corresponding full report submitted to the Department at the time of the review. Five IR’s involving law enforcement did not have a corresponding LIC 612 Law Enforcement contact form as required. The requirement of the facility is that 24-hour IR’s are submitted to the Department within 24 hours of the incident. Full reports are to be submitted within 7 days. Facility is issued a citation per Title 22, Division 6, Section 80061(b): Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. A signed copy of this LIC 809 and 809D were provided to the facility along with appeal rights. Exit interview conducted.

deficiencies.description:

This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
Records Review for December 2024 to February 2025 indicated 26 IR’s were submitted late and 4 full reports were not completed.

facility_name: REDWOOD COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC - SEQUOIA HOUSE
narrative: Interviews conducted by LPAs were inconsistent that facility staff are not providing minor with adequate transportation to school. Facility Staff interviewed reported that they did everything they could to provide transportation to and from school for one minor, but on multiple occasions, the minor had behaviors which made it unsafe to transport the minor. LPA reviewed multiple SIRs that documented the minor became aggressive during the 2-hour transport from the minor’s school of origin. It was documented that the minor was throwing items and attacking staff during transportation. On one occasion, the minor became so aggressive, they broke the car windows and door, and tore out the center console. For a period of possibly 5 days, or up to 2 weeks, based on interviews, the facility did not transport the minor, while researching and trying out other transportation options. There were some days, the minor refused being transported. The transportation concerns were discussed, and a behavioral plan was created at a CFT meeting. The youth is currently complying with transportation without unsafe behaviors. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted a Pre-licensing inspection for an STRTP change of location and met with the Program Manager Paulita Peredia and STRTP Coordinator Rebecca Diaz The entire home was toured, inside and out. The location change will correspond with a change of capacity to 3 and Program change to Complex Care serving youth age 7 to 17. The property consists of one building: a single story house used as the client residence and staff office. There is back yard that is enclosed by a fence, with a storage shed that is attached to the home by a breezeway. There is an attached garage that will be used for storage and will be inaccessible to clients. The home has 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms (1 staff, 1 shared between 3 rooms). All bedrooms will have one client and have adequate dresser and closet space. There is a living room, an office, and a kitchen/dining room. There is a locked cabinet in the office where prescription medications are stored. A laundry room is present and chemicals are stored there in locked cabinets. There are carbon monoxide and smoke detectors throughout the facility. Fire extinguishers are current. There is one complete first-aid kit located in the office. Applicant understands that the hot water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105 – 120 degrees and was measured at 120F. The knives will be stored in a locked cabinet in the laundry area designated for sharp objects. Facility uses public water. The staff files will be kept at the Ukiah Administration office. Clients files will be stored in the staff office and will be double locked in a file cabinet in a locked closet and inaccessible to clients. There are no bodies of water located on the property. The fire clearance is for three ambulatory clients. Facility will have night awake staff. All required postings are clearly displayed in the hallway. LPA Bertoli has confirmed that the location meets Title 22 requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Program Manager Peredia.

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Program Manager Paulita Peredia regarding a complaint investigation at the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli inspected the facility, attempted to interview youth, interviewed staff and Authorized Representatives, and reviewed documentation. While youth in the home stated to others that the staff had verbally and physically abused them, the youth declined to be interviewed, and both staff and authorized representatives indicated they had no knowledge of any such occurrences, and they all stated that the youth has a history of making unfounded accusations. Based on interviews conducted, LPA was unable to determine if foster youth was physically assaulted or if staff spoke inappropriately to the youth. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that foster youth was either physically assaulted or suffered verbal abuse; therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

narrative: On 08/13/2025 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno made an unannounced visit to the facility listed above. The facility has one client that meets the criteria for the SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection. LPA reviewed 1 of child’s records on site at the facility and 5 of staff personnel files were reviewed at the administrative office located on 631 S Orchard Avenue, Ukiah, CA 95482. LPA reviewed 1 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. It was reported by one youth that another youth had blankets pulled off by staff and was awakened in the middle of the night. The youth involved indicated that blankets had come off and staff put them back in place, but that woke her up. All of the youth indicated they did not like to be awakened with a flashlight during bed checks. None of the youth indicated they were injured by staff when confiscating phones. LPA Bertoli was unable to determine if there was an incident of staff speaking inappropriately or not treating minors with dignity and also could not determine if there was any inappropriate discipline. There is a lack of clear evidence to make a determination as to whether a regulatory violation did occur. This department has investigated the allegations, and although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the staff speak inappropriately to youth or do not treat them with dignity, or engage in inappropriate discipline; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. The Program Manager has agreed to sign and return the LIC9099 forms. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed, and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Program Manager Paulita Peredia and STRTP Coordinator Rebecca Diaz regarding a complaint investigation at the facility. The purpose of the conversation was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli inspected the STRTP facility (virtually), interviewed clients, staff, social workers, and reviewed documentation. LPA also listened to recordings the clients had made at the facility. LPA confirmed through interviews with clients and listening to recordings that staff had engaged in yelling with clients, although they did not use any foul language or derogatory remarks. Five of six clients said that staff yelled at the clients. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff yelled at minors in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. The Program director has agreed to sign the LIC9099. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility and LPA will issue an Advisory Note. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.

On 11/5/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted a Case Management visit to review an incident. Due to COVID-19 protocols the visit was conducted by phone and the appropriate signatures will be acquired subsequently. It should be noted that the facility number was different at the time of the incident due to a location change that occurred in the interim. Per Incident Report and other records, on 6/14/2020, client C1 (see LIC811 dated 11/10/2020) was allowed to accompany staff to the adjacent facility, contrary to program rules, whereupon C1 was allowed to interact with client C2 from the other facility and C1 attempted to kiss and grope her. The Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, regulation 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights. To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse . Based on records reviewed, lack of supervision resulted in C1's sexual abuse of C2. An exit interview was conducted and the Program Manager has agreed to sign and return the report. Appeal rights were discussed and sent to the facility with the report.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Whitlow, conducted complaint investigation for the allegation stating, “Client received inappropriate discipline from staff.” LPA, Kellie McKinley, conducted initial complaint opening inspection. LPA McKinely conducted interviews with the facility program manager and one staff member. LPA, Stefanie Whitlow conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews. The victim moved placements two days after the incident and LPA was unable to interview them, after three attempts. Three out of three staff stated restriction or removal of privileges are used for discipline and that staff do not put hands on clients. Three out of three staff stated the day of the incident, food was not refused to the victim; they did not receive ice cream due to the ice cream being a reward to other clients for good behavior. Two out of two clients interviewed stated staff do not put their hands on clients and that restriction is used as discipline. Continued on LIC 9099-C...

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Misty Valencia and Hillary Hall on 12/8/22 at 10AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Chris Magera, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. The facility currently has 2 clients prescribed psychotropic medication. LPAs reviewed 2 client’s files and 3 staff personnel files at the Administrative main office at 3191 Churn Creek Rd., Redding, 96002. LPAs reviewed 2 client’s psychotropic medications and medication records at the facility. LPAs interviewed 3 staff to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed 2 clients currently prescribed psychotropic medication at the facility. During the inspection, LPAs observed the facility did not have a proper authorization for the administration of psychotropic medication (JV-220/223) for one client on file (see attached 809D). The Administrator called the placing agency and the JV-223 was emailed immediately. The JV-223 which was emailed, was one month out of date. Per the placing agency worker's verbal report to LPA's, the court date to renew the JV-223 was continued until January 2023. The plan of correction was met with the JV-223 being produced. However, the citation is still issued as the court order was not on file and not been requested prior to the inspection. Citation issued per Interim Licensing Standards Section 87070(b)(!2) Childrens Records: (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: (12) A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child’s parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication.. LPAs provided a copy of this LIC-809 and the LIC-809D report to the Administrator. Appeal rights provided and exit interview was conducted.

On 10/06/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Chris Magera, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required, Two year Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 10/06/2021. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with three (3) client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and one locked staff office. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. The backyard was free from hazards, safely fenced, with a variety of sports equipment accessible to clients. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility has three client bathrooms and one staff bathroom. All were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the recreational room. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked file cabinet in the locked staff office. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has five (5) clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of six (6). Staff to client ratio is two (2) to five (5). LPA reviewed five (5) staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA interviewed two (2) staff on site. continued on 809-C

LPA reviewed five (5) client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans, but not signed by clients. Clients had updated Needs and Service plans every 30 days that were signed. Needs and Service Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. four (4) of five (5) clients were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current JV-220’s on file. LPA interviewed two (2) clients. Facility is issued a citation per childrens records 87070(c)(1) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (1) A copy of the child's original needs and services plan; verification, signed by the child and their authorized representative(s), that they were offered the opportunity to participate in plan development; and verification that the authorized representative(s) have approved the plan. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC 809D, report was provided to Administrator. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Chris Magera, Administrator of Remi Vista facilities. The purpose of the contact was to initiate a Case Management Inspection following up on three (3) Special Incident Reports (SIR) LPA received from the facility between 9/20/2023, 9/25/2023 and 10/08/2023 relating to client in care medication errors. LPA requested the following documents from the facility: · Procedures on medication administration and description of training · Retraining on Medication procedures. On 09/21/2023- Client 1 (C1) C1’s medication Clonidine 0.1mg was prescribed to give two (2) tabs by mouth at bedtime and was not provided on 09/19/2023. On 09/25/2023-Client 2 (C2) C2’s medication Divalproex SOD DR 500mg was prescribed to give one (1) tab by mouth daily with dinner and two (2) tabs every night at bedtime. C2 was given two (2) tablets at dinner instead of one (1). Staff contacted the pharmacy, who ordered staff to give C2 only one (1) tablet at bedtime instead of two (2) and continue as normal the next day. On 10/08/2023-Client 3 (C3) C3s medication Ziprasidone 40 mg was proscribed to give one (1) tab at bedtime. Due to the pharmacy not delivering the medication it was not being available and the pharmacy was closed on the weekend. In the future there will more diligence in attempting to obtain medications last minute on the weekend. A copy of this report has been provided to the facility. No citations issued at this time Administrator already conducted medication retraining to the staff and provided LPA with the copy.

On October 26, 2021, at 9:05 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias and Carmen Escobar arrived at Richmond, Short Term Residential Program (STRTP). LPAs met with Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 9:30 AM, Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun, led the physical inspection of the facility. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- Was furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. Bedroom #2- Was furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. Bedroom #3- Was furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. Bedroom #4- Was furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. Bedroom #5- Was furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. Bedroom #6- Was furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. Bedrooms are arranged so that only one child is placed per room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Bedroom #2 was observed to be missing a screen on the window, and therefore is being given a technical violation of Section: Physical Plant 80088(b). A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s kitchen area, four refrigerators/freezers, food storage areas, client rooms, two bathroom/showers, and community gathering area and dining area. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/musical instruments were observed for client's recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. At the time of inspection the facility license was observed to be posted by the front door.

All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be 107.6 degrees Fahrenheit for bathroom #1 and bathroom #2 was 106.8 degrees Fahrenheit. Per the Residential Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPAs inspected the facility vehicle to be in good repair. LPAs conducted a client record review of six of six client files. Client #1 did not have a TB test on file and therefore is being cited for violation of Section: Client Medical Assessment 80069(c)(1). Licensee has Mental Health Program Approval that is valid through 12/13/2021. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation that is valid through 10/31/2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809D, LIC9102, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun.
