This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Covarrubias met with Courtney Brandon, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 2 of child’s records and 2 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 2 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 1 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections were discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Courtney Brandon, Administrator.

On July 28th, 2023, at 11:37 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, met with Patricia Mendoza, Youth Specialist to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Child #1 (C1)’s personal rights were violated when Staff #1 (S1) (see confidential names list LIC811, dated 07/31/23) encouraged a fight between C1 and Client #2 (C2). On 07/11/2023, C1 and C2 engaged in a verbal and physical altercation that resulted in bruising on C1’s arms and torso. S1 supervised the altercation and did not attempt to immediately de-escalate the situation between the clients. Information received disclosed S1 and C2 began shoving each other while exchanging inappropriate comments. S1 did not report the incident to any other facility staff and did not offer medical help to C1. Furthermore, S1 failed to act in a manner that was trauma informed which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility suspended and terminated S1 from employment at the facility. Based on information obtained, the facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Personal Rights section 87072(c)(11). Exit interview conducted, appeal rights provided, and discussed; A copy of the report along with LIC811 and LIC809D page was provided to Patricia Mendoza, Youth Specialist.

deficiencies.description: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily functions of eating,sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This standard was not met as evidenced by: Based on information received, S1 spoke inappropriately to C1, shoving C1 and encouraging a physical altercation between C1 and C2 on 07/14/2023 which posed an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide proof of S1 termination to LPA E. Preciado by POC date.

narrative:
On November 8, 2023 at 8:30 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Emina Preciado and Darlene Almaraz Oseguera, conducted an unannounced visit at Richmond, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of a required annual. LPA's met with Residential Manager, Erika Oliva. While at the facility, LPA's reviewed client and facility records, conducted staff interviews, and conducted a physical plant inspection. LPA's conducted a physical plant inspection of the facility at 10:30 am that included the facility’s kitchen area, four refrigerators/freezers, food storage areas, client rooms, two bathroom/showers, and community gathering area and dining area. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There are six bedrooms at the facility and each client at the facility has their own room. Bedrooms #1-4 are currently occupied by a client and are set up as follows: Bedroom #1, 3, 4, and 6 are furnished with one twin bed and sleep one client. Bedroom #2 and 5 are open beds and do not have clients but are furnished with one twin bed and sleeps one client. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Water temperature was observed to be at 113 degrees Fahrenheit. Per the Residential Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. At the time of inspection, all required forms are posted and the facility license was observed to be posted by the front door. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside the staff office. *Continued on next page, LIC 809-C*

Due to time constraints, LPA's were unable to review staff records and conduct client interviews. LPA’s will be returning at a later date. LPA's conducted a records review of four of four client files. Client #2 did not have a medical assessment on file please refer to the LIC 811 (confidential names list) dated November 8, 2023. Based on observation and record review, the facility is cited for Continuum of Care Reform (CCR) section 80069(a) Client Medical Assessments. This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and a copy of this report along with LIC 809-D, LIC 809-C, and LIC 811 were provided to Residential Manager, Erika Oliva.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias on March 1, 2024 at 10:25 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Covarrubias met with Regional Director, Kelly Duguay and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed zero of child’s records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed zero of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. No clients were eligible for inspection review. LPA interviewed two of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed zero of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. No clients were eligible for inspection review. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Regional DIrector, Kelly Duguay. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Regional Director, Kelly Duguay.

It was specifically reported to CCL that S1, who is not assigned a role over client care and supervision at the facility is providing clients with drug paraphernalia in care. During the investigation there was no corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Although the department received information that S1 was providing drugs to clients in care the information received is inconsistent. Confidential interviews reported that clients obtain drugs from school and deny that S1 provides drugs to clients in care. Other confidential interviews stated that clients have been observed under the influence of substances and in possession of nicotine, and marijuana, however it is not known where clients obtain the drugs. A confidential interview revealed an incident in which smoke was observed as S1 was exiting an area of the facility where clients were congregating. It was further revealed that S1(non-childcare staff) was socializing with clients in care when S1 was directed not to socialize with clients. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation or to the incident involving S1 and clients in care. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that staff provides drugs to youths while in care, may have happened or is valid but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Administrator, Stacey Rougely
investigation_findings: 13On March 14, 2024, at 11:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena met with Richmond Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator, Stacey Rougely to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. On November 8, 2023, at 2:00 PM, LPA Cynthia Urena initiated the investigation at the STRTP and collected pertinent documents from the STRTP staff and client files. A health and safety inspection was conducted with a Residential Manager, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. LPA advised the Residential Manager that Charlotte Jackson with the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Branch (IB) would be leading the investigation. Interviews were completed with four staff members (S1, S2, S3, S4,), four clients (C1, C2, C3, C4), a Probation Officer and a witness. On November 8, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff provides drugs to youths while in care. (**Continued on LIC 9099 C**)

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that S1 never made any inappropriate comments to C1 or any clients. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 dislikes S1 and C1 would make false allegation towards to S1 in hopes to get S1 fired. Confidential interview revealed that there are no concerns with S1 violating C1’s personal rights. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that S1 made inappropriate comments to C1 in care may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Olive Crest - Richmond Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Mwape Nchima Chongwe, Residential Coordinator.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/09/24 at 09:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo met with Mwape Nchima Chongwe, Residential Coordinator, to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation at Olive Crest – Richmond Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). On 08/11/23, LPA Emina Preciado inspected the facility’s physical plant, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with one staff (S1), Residential Manager (RM), and two clients (C1 and C3). Clients’ Needs and Services Plans and case notes were reviewed. On August 01, 2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff (S1) made inappropriate comments to a client (C1) in care. Specifically, it was reported that S1 made an inappropriate comment to C1 on an outing. The investigation resulted in conflicting statements: Confidential interview revealed that S1 made a sexual innuendo regarding a toy to C1. (Continued on LIC 9099c)

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that C1 received pictures of C2 on their (C1) personal cell phone and showed the pictures to staff and clients. Confidential interviews reported that the STRTP does not monitor personal cell phones due to personal rights. Confidential interviews reported that C1 showed pictures of C2 to staff and that they (C1) were directed to delete the photos immediately. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was not told to delete the photos immediately but two or three days after staff was made aware. LPA received inconsistent information on the timeline from when staff was made aware of the photos and when staff directed C1 to delete the photos. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that due to a lack of supervision, the minor (C1) engaged in inappropriate interactions is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Stacy Rougely, Adminstrator.
investigation_findings: 13On October 15, 2024, at 9:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an unannounced visit to Richmond- Olive Crest STRTP to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 06/24/2024, LPA Robinson conducted a health and safety inspection at the STRTP. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA interviewed Clients (C1, C4, and C5), and Staff (S1, S3, S4, and S5). LPA attempted to interview C2 but was unsuccessful because C2 was apprehended. LPA attempted to interview C3 and C6 but was unsuccessful because both clients refused to be interviewed. LPA made several attempts to interview S2 and the Probation Officer (PO) but was unsuccessful. On 06/19/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that, due to a lack of supervision, a minor (C1) engaged in inappropriate interactions. It was alleged that C1 was sharing inappropriate pictures of C2.

narrative: On December 23, 2024, at 9:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson met with Olive Crest- Richmond Administrator Stacy Rougely to deliver a case management deficiencies report. On 12/17/2024, during the health and safety inspection, LPA Cynthia Robinson observed at the facility in bedroom #2 a hole in the wall approximately 1 foot in length and 1 foot in width, exposing the wall that is shared with bedroom #1. Based on LPA’s observations from 12/17/2024, the facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 07 Physical Environment, 80087 Buildings and Grounds (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees, and visitors. A type B citation is being issued. The STRTP facility did not ensure the health, safety, and well-being of Client 1 and Client 2, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. A copy of the report, along with LIC 809-D, appeal rights, and LIC 811, was discussed and provided to Richmond Administrator Stacy Rougely.

Confidential interviews revealed that the staff position of House Supervisor oversees notifying the mental health team of the prescription refills, but S1 did not notify the mental health team in a timely manner. Additional confidential interviews reported that the House Supervisor does not oversee medication and that the staff position, the Residential Coordinator, oversees medication refills. LPA obtained pertinent documentation of job descriptions and confirmed that the Residential Coordinator job description states this position is responsible for ensuring there is a sufficient supply of prescribed and over-the-counter medication on hand. As a result of the STRTP staff blaming each other, the STRTP did not meet the needs of C1, causing C1 not to receive their (C1) medication according to the physician's order. In addition, LPA observed that C1 was missing medication, and there was no more medication for C1 to take due to a missed refill in a timely manner. Based on consistent confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegation that staff did not refill minors (C1) prescriptions is substantiated.The facility is cited with a violation of the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Section 87075(c) Health Related Services (c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication…. The STRTP did not meet the needs of C1, causing C1 not to receive their (C1) medication according to the physician's order. LPA observed the missing medication, and confidential interviews revealed that C1 did not receive their medication due to a missed refill. This posed an immediate risk to the Health, Safety, and Personal Rights of children in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Stacey Rougely, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On January 7, 2025, at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an unannounced visit to Richmond- Olive Crest Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. On 10/24/2024, LPA Robinson conducted a health and safety inspection at the STRTP, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA interviewed Clients (C1 and C2), and Staff (S1, S2, S3, and S4). LPA attempted to interview Clients (C3, C4, C5, and C6) but was unsuccessful because clients refused to be interviewed. On 10/23/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff did not refill minors (C1) prescriptions. It was alleged that C1 did not get a refill promptly, resulting in missed medication for C1. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 did not receive their medication due to not having a filled prescription. (Continued on LIC 9099C...)

deficiencies.description:
87075 Health Related Services (c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on consistent confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the STRTP did not meet the needs of C1, causing C1 not to receive their (C1) medication according to the physician's order. This posed an immediate risk to the Health, Safety, and Personal Rights of children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The STRP will retrain the staff to follow the physician’s orders and job descriptions regarding the designated person to administer medication, including ways to avoid this deficiency in the future.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that S1 hit C1 with a closed-hand fist to the back of the head three times because C1 had stopped S1 from trying to touch them (C1). Other confidential interviews denied hitting C1 in the back of C1’s head. Additional confidential interviews reported that S1 had pointed to C1’s new nose ring and this caused C1 to think S1 was trying to take it out and raised their (C1) hands to “block” S1’s hand. Confidential interviews reported that S1 then raised their (S1) hands to “block C1’s hands” with an open palm. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was under the influence during the incident causing C1 to become defensive. Confidential interviews denied hitting C1 with closed fists or any physical abuse toward C1. Regarding the allegation that staff (S1) inappropriately spoke to youth (C1) in care, confidential interviews reported that S1 called C1 inappropriate words after the alleged incident between C1 and S1. In addition, confidential interviews reported that S1 did not say any inappropriate words toward C1. LPA was unable to determine if the allegations occurred or did not occur. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff (S1) hit youth (C1) in care and staff (S1) inappropriately spoke to youth (C1) in care are unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Stacy Rougely, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On February 7, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an unannounced visit to Richmond- Olive Crest STRTP to deliver the investigative findings for the above-stated allegations. On 12/17/2024, LPA Robinson conducted a health and safety inspection at the STRTP. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA interviewed Client (C1), and Staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, and S5). LPA attempted to interview clients (C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6) but was unsuccessful because clients refused to be interviewed. On 12/16/2024, Community Care Licensing received allegations that staff (S1) hit youth (C1) in care and staff (S1) inappropriately spoke to youth (C1) in care. Confidential interviews reported that S1 had reached their hand out to point out C1’s new nose ring and tried to reach out to pull it out. Confidential interviews reported that C1 raised their hands to stop S1 from touching them (C1). (Continued on LIC 9099C...)

narrative: On August 14, 2025, at 10:20 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Julian Lucas, arrived unannounced at Richmond Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at 20025A Vista Del Lago, Perris, CA 92570. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Administrator, Stacy Rougely. During the inspection, LPA reviewed 3 client files, facility records, three staff files, and conducted two staff interviews. Based on the annual required inspection on this date, there were no deficiencies found. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator, Stacy Roughley and a copy of this report was given to the administrator.

On December 20, 2023 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Jacqueline Garcia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection and completed Component III. LPAs met with Facility Administrator, Dana Butler. The facility is a three client bedroom one client bathroom single-family, single-story home. The applicant is applying for a Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) with the capacity of six ambulatory clients aged between 9-17 years old. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Clients will use a cordless telephone to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The water temperature in bathroom #1 located in the hallway measured to be 106 Degrees Fahrenheit. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. Medication will be locked in the locked cabinet in the attached garage used as a staff office. The staff and client files will be maintained on a digital database. LPA's advised Facility Administrator, that staff and client files to be accessible to Community Care Licensing (CCL) at any time. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and Disaster plans were posted. The facility is set up as follows There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space.The entry hallway has an attached garage that is designated as a staff office. It has locked cabinets for facility logs, client files and medications. The hallway leads to an open living room that flows into the dining area and attached kitchen. There are three client bedrooms with two clients per room with twin sized beds dresser and closet space for each client. Bedroom #1 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. . Bedroom #2 is: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. Bedroom #3 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers and closet space. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. Next to the client bedrooms is a room that is used as a clinical office and for therapy sessions. The Backyard is set up as follows: The facility dining room has a sliding glass door that leads into the backyard. The backyard has seating area for visits and large yard that is free of debris. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

Facility Vehicles: The facility has two vehicles for client needs, a facility van and a sedan. LPA Garcia observed vehicle logs that were not updated. Vehicles had current with valid registration and proof of insurance. Vehicles contained emergency backpack with required items. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant/CEO on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. LPAs observed the following areas that need to be corrected: Vehicle logs for monthly inspections. Blinds are missing slider stick to open the blinds Disaster Logs that need to be updated monthly. Monthly Manual Restraint log is needed. Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility will make the corrections and once completed submit proof of correction to LPA

On 03/11/24 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz met with Brittnie Peluso, ffor the purpose of conducting a post licensing inspection of the facility. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s building and grounds, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers and facility vehicles used to transport clients. The facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment, toys, books, games, computers were observed for children’s schooling and recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menu was posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 103 and 116 degrees. Per designee, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in the hallway closet. The LPA reviewed LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan, completed disaster training for staff and clients and completed emergency drills. LPA interviewed 2 clients and 2 staff during visit. Staff files are located at corporate office and therefore inspection will need to be continued at a later date. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Brittnie Peluso, facility representative.

On 3/15/24 LPA Munoz arrived at ROP ATCS Corporate office to complete post license inspection. LPA completed 5 staff file reviews and 5 client file reviews. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Dana Centanni, facility representative.

On April 19, 2024, at 1:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Brittnie Peluso, Program Director, to assess a deficiency citation and Civil Penalty. LPA conducted confidential interviews and a record review which indicted that there is one staff (S1) who does not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility. CCL reviewed Guardian to ensure that staff had a criminal record clearance, review indicated that S1 clearances were pending. LPA requested copies of the staff roster. Staff roster indicated and confirmed that S1 had been working at the facility. On March 15, 2024 the facility was notified via email that S1 is not cleared and should not be at any of the facilities. LPA is administering civil penalties during this visit. The facility is being cited for the violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. Record review confirms S1 has worked in the facility without a criminal record clearance. An immediate civil penalty is being issued for $1,000.00 An exit interview was conducted with Program Director. A copy of this report, LIC 811 dated 4/19/24 and appeal rights were provided to Program Director. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.description: 80019 Criminal Record Clearance(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: Based on confidential interviews and record review, LPA observed that S1 did not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility. The staff have been working at the facility without fingerprint clearances, which poses an immediate Health, Safety risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator asked the staff to leave the facility and told them they could not return until their criminal record clearance is in place. Within 24 hours Administrator will email CCL an updated staff schedule that does not include S1 and an updated LIC 500.

narrative: On 7/10/2024, at approximately 11:11 am, LPA Joon Choi arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Therapist Diana Guzman. LPA explained the reason for the visit was to interview a Client (C1) regarding a complaint (#19-CR-20240614124712) from a different facility (#33090238). During the visit, LPA interviewed C1 and provided a copy of this report.

On January 23, 2025 at 10:05 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarah Lo and Gilbert Marquez conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at ROP ATCS Baker House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs were greeted by the Senior Coach Counselor, Erika Merales and was allowed entry into the facility; and later was joined by Facility Manager, Brittnie Peluso. At 10:15 AM, LPAs toured the facility and inspected inside and out with the Senior Coach Counselor, Erika Merales. The facility is a one-story home with (3) bedrooms, (1) client bathroom, living room and kitchen. There is a mental health office and a garage used as the staff office and one staff restroom. The Administrator stated current census is five. The facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages between 12-17 years old and non-minor dependents. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The beds and dressers in all the bedrooms are in good repair, and all window screens are attached. LPAs observed age-appropriate clothing in the closet of the clients. The bathroom is clean and in good repair. The temperature in rooms that clients occupy are registered at 70 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 113.2 degrees F in the client bathroom. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office area. Cleaning supplies and chemicals are locked and stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office area. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in a locked cabinet in the staff office and a locked kitchen cabinet and contains all required items. The facility's smoke detectors located in each bedroom and common areas were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway was operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator at this time. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. (continued on LIC 809c)

LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Refrigerators in the kitchen and garage are maintained in a good temperature. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Facility has obtained Mental Health Certification which expires on March 23, 2025, and has been accredited by CARF which is valid through February 28, 2025. The facility annual licensing fees are paid to current. LPA Lo discussed the following with the Administrator: Core Services, Specialty Mental Health Service, Trauma Informed Care, Client Personal Rights, and Administrative Duties. LPA Marquez conducted two staff interviews and attempted to conduct interviews with the two clients that were present during the inspection and the two clients refused to be interviewed. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to the Administrator, Brittnie Peluso.

Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements. Some interviews indicated that it was requested for staff to stay with C1 while at the Hospital while other interviews indicated the Hospital contacted the facility and told the facility they did not need to stay at the Hospital with C1. Therefore, confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation with a preponderance of evidence. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed the allegation that staff left C1 unaccompanied while receiving medical attention, which may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights explained. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Erika Merales. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On March 6, 2025, at 1:20 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Erika Merales, Senior Coach, and Facility Administrator, Brittnie Peluso, was on the telephone, to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on December 16, 2024, at 10:25 am and no deficiencies were observed. LPA Linley interviewed one of five Clients (C1), and five Staff (S1-5), LPA was unable to interview one Adult (A1) and one County Social Worker (CSW), despite multiple attempts to contact them. LPA reviewed facility documents during the investigation. On December 20, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff left a minor unaccompanied while receiving medical attention. It was reported that C1 was transported to the Hospital via ambulance and staff did not accompany C1 to the Hospital, which resulted in A1 responding to the Hospital to stay with C1. It was reported that the Hospital attempted to contact the facility and could not reach anyone. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

met_with: Brittnie Peluso on phone and Erika Merales
narrative: staff bathroom located inside of the staff office. narrative:
On December 20, 2023 at 11 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Jacqueline Garcia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection and completed Component III. LPAs met with Facility Administrator, Dana Butler. The facility is a three client bedroom one client bathroom single-family, two-story home. The applicant is applying for a Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) with the capacity of six ambulatory clients aged between 9-17 years old. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Clients will use a cordless telephone to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The water temperature in bathroom #1 located in the hallway measured to be 107 Degrees Fahrenheit. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. Medication will be locked in the locked cabinet in the attached garage that is used as a staff office. The staff files and client files will be kept on a digital database. LPA's advised Facility Administrator, Dana Butler, that staff and client files to be accessible to Community Care Licensing (CCL) at any time. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and Disaster plans were posted. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The downstairs area is set up as follows Open living room that flows into the dining area and attached kitchen. There are three client bedrooms with two clients per room with twin sized beds dresser and closet space for each client. Bedroom #1 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. . Bedroom #2 is: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. Bedroom #3 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers and closet space. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. . The downstairs also includes an attached garage that is designated as a staff office. It has locked cabinets for facility logs, client medications. The upstairs area set up as follows: Clinician office, staff office and staff bathroom. Clients use clinical office for therapy sessions. The Backyard is set up as follows: Large open area that is free of debris. There is a detached storage shed for overflow items and large containers for client storage items. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

Facility Vehicles: The facility has two vehicles for client needs, a facility van and a sedan. The sedan is currently being repaired for broken windshield. Vehicle logs were current with valid registration and proof of insurance. Vehicles contained emergency backpack with required items. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. LPAs observed the following areas that need to be corrected: Bedroom #2 had dresser with missing drawers that need to be repaired. Blinds in dining room need to be repaired. Disaster Logs that need to be updated monthly. Monthly Manual Restraint log is needed. Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility will make the corrections and once completed submit proof of correction to LPA.

On 03/14/24 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz met with Brittnie Peluso, ffor the purpose of conducting a post licensing inspection of the facility. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s building and grounds, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers and facility vehicles used to transport clients. The facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment, toys, books, games, computers were observed for children’s schooling and recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menu was posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 103 and 116 degrees. Per designee, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in the hallway closet. The LPA reviewed LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan, completed disaster training for staff and clients and completed emergency drills. LPA interviewed 1 client and 1 client declined and 2 staff during visit. Staff files are located at corporate office and therefore inspection will need to be continued at a later date. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Brittnie Peluso, facility representative.

On 3/15/24 LPA Munoz arrived at ROP ATCS Corporate office to complete post license inspection. LPA completed 5 staff file reviews and 5 client file reviews. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Dana Centanni, facility representative.

On April 11, 2024, at 12:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management inspection of the facility. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Incident Report (IR) follow up visit. LPA Munoz met with Brittnie Peluso, Program Director. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received two incident reports on 4/9/24, dated 3/26/24 that included the use of manual restraint interventions used on two different residents. LPA interviewed two clients and three staff during this visit. No deficiencies were noted at this time however facility was provided with a Technical Assistance (TA) note. An exit interview was conducted with . A copy of this report was provided to the Facility Administrator. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On May 24, 2024 at 1:15 LPA Salem made an unannounced visit at above facility. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a collateral interview for an open investigation regarding a previous placement. LPA conducted one confidential interview with client. An exit interview was conducted with Brittnie Peluso, facility administrator. Due to printer malfunction a copy of this report will be emailed to administrator for signature.

Interviews revealed that C1 had reported this behavior to staff at facility and that as an intervention C4 would be under “heightened supervision”. Interviews further revealed that “heightened supervision” was not maintained due to the number of staff scheduled to work during a shift and other residents who also needed increased supervision due to behavioral challenges. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that a minor inappropriately touched another minor in care due to lack of supervision is substantiated. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Version 5, Article 06. Regulation 87065.5(g) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed with XXX. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to the Administrator.

LPA Interviewed three staff (S1-3), three clients (C1-3) and attempted to interview one client (C4). LPA obtained and reviewed the following documents: Needs and Service Plan, Staff Schedule, Client Roster and Incident Reports. On 03/8/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that a minor (C4) inappropriately touched another minor (C1) in care due to lack of supervision. Specifically, it was reported that C1 was touched on the thigh by a peer at the facility. Confidential interviews confirmed that C4 made sexually inappropriate comments and touched peers inappropriately during their time in placement at the facility.

deficiencies.description:
87065.5  Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios
(g) If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty direct care staff shall be increased.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews the facility did not have enough staff to follow C4’s safety plan placing C1 on “heightened supervision” which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Progrqam Director will provide LPA with protocol on increasing staffing when there are clients that need additional support because of behaviors challenges. PD will send this information by close of business day on 09/26/24.

deficiencies.description:
87072(C)(1) Personal Rights 
The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded … To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect…but not limited to, family, social, and political ties. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: 
Based on confidential interviews revealed that S1 would reply to C1 likewise when C1 was calling S1 names which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S1 was retrained by STRTP on Personal RIghts of clients at the time of allegation. In addition STRTP will retrain all staff on Personal RIghts of clients and provide verification to CCL no later than close of business day on 12/02/24.

that youth were expected to ask for food when needed during this period of time. Interviews further confirmed that the clients had to request snacks and the staff could not readily provide the clients with the snack due to attending to other clients. LPA observed the kitchen refrigerator to only contain half a gallon of milk, half a loaf of bread, several slices of cheese and a couple of condiments. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an additional allegation that staff are emotionally abusive to minor in care. Specifically, it was reported that S1 is agonistic towards youth and calls C1 names like "bitch". Confidential interviews revealed that C1 had submitted a grievance regarding S1’s behavior towards C1 to Program Director (PD). Interviews further revealed that other facility staff witnessed S1 speaking inappropriately to minors in care and that staff also reported this behavior to facility management. Interviews confirmed that S1 was addressed for this behavior by PD and supervisor. Interviews further confirmed that PD facilitated a meeting between S1 and C1 to address this concern and S1 underwent retraining. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations that staff do not ensure that minor has access to food while in care, and staff (S1) are emotionally abusive to minor (C1) in care are substantiated. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of the Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06, Continuing Requirements regulation 80076(a)(4) Food Services, and Interim Licensing Standards Version 5, Article 06, Continuing Requirements regulation 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights. deficiencies.description:
80076(a)(4) Food Services 
In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply: Between meal nourishment or snacks shall be available for all clients unless limited by dietary restrictions prescribed by a physician. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  
Based on LPA observation and confidential interviews the food was safeguarded in the garage and staff was unable to readily provide the food to clients upon request which posed a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Program Director will provide signed statement of protocol regarding plan to ensure clients have access to food while in care at all times. STRTP will provide written plan to CCL no later than 12/02/24 by 5pm.

deficiencies.description:
87072 (c)(1) Personal Rights 
The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights…To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  
Based on confidential interviews S1 was emotionally abusive to C1by calling C1 derogatory names which posed a immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S1 was retrained by STRTP on Personal RIghts of clients at the time of allegation. In addition STRTP will retrain all staff on Personal RIghts of clients and provide verification to CCL no later than close of business day on 12/02/24.

narrative:
Specifically, it was reported that on 3/27/24 C1 had been dysregulated for most of the day and that the mental health assessment team was not contacted for several hours in which time C1 bit their tongue, banged their head against the wall and that C1 had cuts to their lips and had some red marks around their head. It was also reported that other “residents came in and started to taunt” C1. Confidential interviews confirmed that C1 was in mental health distress for several hours of the day starting around lunch time and ending around 7:30 pm at which time C1 was transported via ambulance to the local hospital. Interviews further revealed that throughout the day C1 asked to be taken to the hospital on multiple occasions because C1 reported that they did not feel safe and repeatedly banged their head against the wall and floor and bit their lip which caused blood to spill onto the floor of the living room. Interviews also revealed that other residents began to taunt and trigger one another which led to multiple physical altercations which included clients climbing out of windows and running out the doors to attack C1. Law enforcement arrived to assist facility with ensuring safety of clients. Furthermore, interviews also confirmed that C1 was pushed by S2 into the wall when C1 was running towards S2 during the crisis. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations that facility did not prevent minor from self-harming, that facility did not provide a safe environment for a minor in care, that staff did not seek medical attention in a timely manner for a minor in care and that staff pushed a minor while in care are substantiated. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Version 5, Article 06, Continuing Requirements regulation 87072(C)(16) Personal Rights and Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1 Article 06 Health Related Services 80075 (a). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed with Brittnie Peluso. . A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to the Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(16)      Personal Rights To be free…from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule…interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:

deficiencies.description:
Health Related Services 80075 (a) 
 (a)The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services, including arrangement for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: 
Based on, confidential interviews C1 was in mental health distress for several hours before medical services were contacted even after C1 had requested to be taken to the hospital which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, facility will review their protocol for contacting emergency services and update their Program Statement and provide to CCL by 01/17/2025.

narrative: Confidential interviews confirmed that C1 was in mental health crisis and was displaying aggression towards facility staff. Interviews further revealed that C1 was physically restrained due to their aggressive behavior and once released from a five-minute containment, C1 ran towards S1 and flicked a cup of water from S1’s hand. S1 responded by pushing C1 to the ground and grabbing C1’s leg when they were attempting to get up and holding C1’s leg to drag them to their bedroom. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that facility staff handled youth in a rough manner is substantiated. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Version 5, Article 06, Continuing Requirements regulation 87072(C)(16) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed with Brittnie Peluso. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to the Administrator.
