narrative:
On January 22, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz and Gilbert Marquez met with Ashley Wilson, Administrator for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 10-17 years-old and Non Minor dependents. The current census is six children. Facility has obtained Mental Health Certification which expires on March 23, 2025, and has been accredited by CARF which is valid through February 28, 2025. The Facility is a two story dwelling that consists of three bedrooms, kitchen, living room, dinning room and one client bathroom and one staff bathroom on the first floor The upstairs consists of a therapist room, a staff office and a staff bathroom. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s building and grounds, and vehicle inspection. Client bedrooms consisted of three double occupancy rooms which housed a two twin beds with a closet and dresser. All beds had required linens. The kitchen was observed to be clean with sufficient cooking/eating supplies, the refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas contained two days of perishable foods and seven days of non-perishable items. Bathroom was clean, toilet and shower were in working order and the water temperature was measured to be 112.1F degrees which is within the regulated temperature. Extra towels were observed to be stored in the hall closet. The dinning room lies in between the living room and the kitchen which is adjacent to the hallway connecting the bedrooms. The areas were clean and free of debris and free of observable hazards. Books, games, computers, and movies were observed for children’s schooling and recreation time. Outdoors were also clean and free of debris and was observed to have a table and chairs for clients to use. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space.

***CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1**** The Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are are located in each bedroom, one in the hallway, one in the dinning room, and another in the garage, and were all in working order. Cleaning supplies are maintained in a lock cabinet and also in a locked cabinet in the garage which is also utilized as a staff office. Medications were locked in the garage in a separate locked cabinet. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. The LPA reviewed LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan. Two staff interviews and two client interviews were conducted at time of inspection. However, due to facility files being housed at the Corporate Office the inspection will be continued. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Ashley Wilson, Senior Coach and designee.

On August 13,2025, at 12:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management visit of the facility. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility, and no physical plant deficiencies were observed. LPA Munoz met with Child Care Worker (CCW),Porscha Townsend and was informed that Facility Administrator (FA) was not on site and could be contacted by telephone. LPA contacted FA by cellphone and notified them of the purpose of the visit. LPA informed facility that an investigation will be conducted regarding an incident that was reported on 08/11/25. On 08/11/25, Community Care Licensing (CCL) was notified of an incident that occurred on 08/07/25 that involved the facility being searched by probation officers. The search resulted in discovering marijuana vapes, nitrous oxide tanks, tagging on dressers, a small envelope that contained seven pills of C1's night time medication and an additional unknown pill hidden in the vent. LPA interviewed two staff during the visit and two clients. LPA requested and obtained documents necessary to the investigation. LPA conducted medication file review. Further information and interviews are required to resolve the concern therefore this investigation is being extended. The outcome of the investigation will be provided to the Facility Administrator. The facility is reminded not to discuss the ongoing investigation with any interested parties. An exit interview was conducted with Senior Coach, Lemasani Vaafuti and copy of this report and LIC 811 dated 08/13/25 was provided to the designee.

On August 21, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management follow-up inspection that was conducted on 8/13/25. LPA met with David Owens, Program Administrator LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on information reported to Community Care Licensing on August 11, 2025. On 08/11/25, Community Care Licensing (CCL) was notified of an incident regarding safety and supervision of clients at the facility. On 8/13/25 LPA observed that the facility did not have a Facility Manager (Senior Coach) onsite when children were present during the shift. LPA interviewed two staff (S1,S2) during the visit and two clients (C1, C2), one client (C3) refused to be interviewed. LPA obtained and reviewed documents needed for the investigation. LPA observed that the Facility did not have a facility manager present at the time of the inspection. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and records reviewed, Community Care Licensing (CCL) has determined that the licensee does not have a designated facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present as per Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted with David Owens and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to administrator. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On December 20, 2023 at 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Jacqueline Garcia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection and completed Component III. LPAs met with Administrator, Dana Centanni, Compliance Manager Sylvia Arballo,, Facility Administrator, Dana Butler, Cynthia Nandino, QA Manager for Behavioral Health and Head of Service, Brittany Kelly. The facility is a four client bedroom one client bathroom single-family, single-story home. The applicant is applying for a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) with the capacity of six ambulatory clients aged between 10-20 years old. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Clients will use a cordless telephone to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The water temperature in bathroom #1 located in rose room measured to be 107 Degrees Fahrenheit. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a first aid kit that needs a thermometer and first aid manual. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. Medication will be locked in the locked cabinet in the attached garage used as a staff office. . ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

The staff and client files will be maintained on a digital database. LPA's advised Administrator that staff and client files need to be accessible to Community Care Licensing (CCL) at anytime The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and Disaster plans were posted. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space The facility is set up as follows The entry hallway has an attached garage that is designated as a staff office. It has locked cabinets for facility logs, client files and medications. The hallway leads to an open living room that flows into the dining area and attached kitchen. There are four client bedrooms with two single rooms that maybe used for non-minor dependents and two bedrooms for two clients per room with twin sized beds dresser and closet space for each client. Bedroom #1 is designated for one client, one twin bed, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. . Bedroom #2 is: designated for one clients, one twin bed, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. Bedroom #3 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers and closet space. Bedroom #4 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers and closet space. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. and a medication office. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

LPAs observed the following areas that need to be corrected: Kitchen sink has broken dishwasher faucet. Adequate amount of Emergency disaster supply of food and water First Aid Kit needs thermometer Kitchen seating has two tears that need to be repaired Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility will make the corrections and once completed submit proof of correction to LPA. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility.

On 04/08/24 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz met with Dana Centanni Program Director (PD), for the purpose of conducting a post licensing inspection of the facility. Currently there are no residents in the home. LPA advised PD to communicate with CCL and report when residents begin to move into STRTP. Facility is pending Mental Health Certification and will provide CCL with copy once certified. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s building and grounds, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers and facility vehicles used to transport clients. The facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment, toys, books, games, computers were observed for children’s schooling and recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications will be locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. The LPA reviewed LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility will ensure that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 103 and 116 degrees. Per designee, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons will be locked in the hallway closet. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Dana Centanni, Program Director.

On January 8, 2025, at 11:00 aM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Mishaun Marshall, Administrator, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 10-17 years-old. The current census is six children. Facility has obtained Mental Health Certification which expires on March 23, 2025, and has been accredited by CARF which is valid through February 28, 2025. The Facility is a single story dwelling that consists of four bedrooms, two bathrooms (one staff, one client), kitchen, living room, dinning room, a study nook, and a therapist room adjacent to the living room. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s building and grounds, and vehicle inspection. Client bedrooms consisted of two single occupancy rooms which housed a single twin bed with a closet and dresser, two other bedrooms had a double occupancy which had two twin beds, two closets and two dressers. All beds had required linins. The kitchen was observed to be clean with sufficient cooking/eating supplies, the refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas contained two days of perishable foods and seven days of non-perishable items. Bathroom was clean, toilet and shower were in working order and the water temperature was measured to be 114.3 degrees which is within the regulated temperature. Extra towels were observed to be stored in the hall closet. The dinning room lies in between the living room and the kitchen and the study nook is adjacent to the dinning room, which is adjacent to the hallway connecting the bedrooms. The areas were clean and free of debris and free of observable hazards. Books, games, computers, and movies were observed for children’s schooling and recreation time. Outdoors were also clean and free of debris and was observed to have a table and chairs for clients to use. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. ****CONTINUED ON PAGE 2***

***CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1**** The Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are are located in each bedroom, one in the hallway, one in the dinning room, and another in the garage, and were all in working order. Cleaning supplies are maintained in a lock cabinet in the laundry area, and also in a locked cabinet in the garage which is also utilized as a staff office. Medications were locked in the garage in a separate locked cabinet. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. The LPA reviewed LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan. Two staff interviews and two client interviews were conducted at time of inspection. However, due to facility files being housed at the Corporate Office the inspection will be continued. An exit interview and a copy of this report was provided to Mishaun Marshall.

On March 7,2025, at 10:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management visit of the facility. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed.. LPA Munoz met with Facility Administrator, Mishaun Marshall. LPA informed facility that an investigation will be conducted regarding an incident that was reported on 03/03/25. On 03/03/25, Community Care Licensing (CCL) was notified of two concerns regarding clients at the facility. Concern #1 reported that C1 missed a mandatory court ordered meeting because staff were unable to transport them. Concern #2 reported that C2 ingested unknown substances and was transported to the hospital due to an overdose. LPA interviewed two staff during the visit. LPA obtained and reviewed documents and completed medication review. Further information and interviews are required to resolve the concern therefore this investigation is being extended. The outcome of the investigation will be provided to the Facility Administrator. The facility is reminded not to discuss the ongoing investigation with any interested parties. An exit interview was conducted with Residential Manger and copy of this report and LIC 811 dated 03/07/25 was provided to the designee.

On March 28, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management follow up visit to the inspection that was conducted on 3/7/2025. LPA met with Purshay Harris, Senior Coach, and with Mishaun Marshall, Facility Administrator via telephone. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on information reported to Community Care Licensing on March 3, 2025. On March 3, 2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information that the facility did not transport C1 to a mandatory court ordered substance use treatment appointment. LPA interviewed one staff (S1) and reviewed client’s (C1) Needs and Services Plan. Confidential interviews and records reviewed confirmed that C1 missed a court ordered health related services appointment. The STRTP is being cited for ILS v5 Article 06. Continuing Requirements Section 87074 (c)(1) Transportation. An exit interview was conducted with Mishaun Marshall via phone and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to administrator. Per administrator request, LPA will email report for to administrator for signature required. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.description:
87074 Transportation
(c)	Unless other arrangements are specified in the needs and services plan or the Transitional Independent Living Plan for a child or nonminor dependent, a licensee shall ensure transportation is provided to the following:
(1)	Health-related services. This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  
Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed C1 missed their court ordered health related appointment because facility did not provide transportation which posed a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator the STRTP will provide training on Activitiy Planning . The licensee will provide proof of training by 4/25/25 to the Department and the documentation shall include the date and time the training took place. In addition, what steps have been taken to ensure this deficiency can be avoided in the future.

narrative: On August 13,2025, at 9:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management visit of the facility. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility, and no physical plant deficiencies were observed. LPA Munoz met with Child Care Worker (CCW), Emily Torres and was informed that Facility Administrator (FA) was not on site and could be contacted by telephone. LPA contacted FA by cellphone and notified them of the purpose of the visit. LPA informed facility that an investigation will be conducted regarding an incident that was reported on 08/04/25. On 08/04/25, Community Care Licensing (CCL) was notified of an incident regarding safety and supervision of clients at the facility. The incident reported that clients were drinking alcohol and smoking marijuana at the facility during the overnight shift. LPA interviewed two staff during the visit and two client. LPA requested and obtained documents needed for the investigation. Further information and interviews are required to resolve the concern therefore this investigation is being extended. The outcome of the investigation will be provided to the Facility Administrator. The facility is reminded not to discuss the ongoing investigation with any interested parties. An exit interview was conducted with CCW Torres and FA gave verbal consent for CCW to sign this report. A copy of this report and LIC 811 dated 08/13/25 was provided to the designee.

On August 21, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management follow-up inspection that was conducted on 8/13/25. LPA spoke with Mishaun Marshall, Facility Administrator via telephone. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on information reported to Community Care Licensing on August 4, 2025. On 08/04/25, Community Care Licensing (CCL) was notified of an incident regarding safety and supervision of clients at the facility. On 8/13/25 LPA observed that the facility did not have a Facility Manager (Senior Coach) onsite when children were present during the shift. LPA interviewed two staff (S1, S2) during the visit and two clients (C1, C2). LPA obtained and reviewed documents needed for the investigation. LPA observed that the Facility did not have a facility manager present at the time of the inspection. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, Community Care Licensing (CCL) has determined that the licensee does not have a designated facility manager present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present as per Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. The Short-Term Residential Program (STRTP) facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 General Licensing Requirements Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted with Mishaun Marshall via phone and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the Senior Coach, Frisco Taoete that arrived for evening shift. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted a Case Management tele-Inspection with the above facility on 9/22/2020 at 3:00 PM and met with Program Director, Christina Gwin to review documentation and inspected the facility. Today, 09/24/20, at 10:00 AM, LPA continued and completed the Case Management tele-inspection with Program Director, Christine Gwin. The facility's provisional license was effective 09/24/2019 and is due to expire on 09/24/2020. The STRTP currently has two dorms currently occupied, Sierra and Yosemite that houses about 50 student athletes. Currently in placement are 34 student athletes. Each student athletes are afforded it's own private bedroom, equipped with adequate linen and furniture that are in good repair. The passageways, including pathways to egresses, were unobstructed and free of clutter. LPA observed bathrooms and showers to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility has a cafeteria on the grounds. Potential toxic or harmful cleaning detergents and other chemicals are handled by a facility staff. Medications are stored within a cabinet located in a lockable and dedicated medication room. LPA conducted a file review jointly with Program Director. Student Athletics files were inspected; where applicable, documentation of signed informed consents, authorizations, as well as physician and court orders were present including completed JV-220 forms as needed. MARS (Medication Administration Records) for the student residents were also found to be in compliance, including separate MARS for psychotropic drug administration. LPA inspected personnel staff files. All staff files contained documentation of criminal record clearances (DOJ, FBI, and CACI). Documentation also included an updated training log, First Aid/CPR and emergency intervention training for all direct care staff. Refer to next page, LIC 809-C .

The facility is accredited by CARF (Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) on August 29, 2019 which extends through August 31, 2022. The Accreditation applies to the facility's foster care and residential program which provides trauma informed treatment to its client's population. The STRTP is in good standing. There are no health or safety concerns with this STRTP. The license will be changed from Provisional to Licensed STRTP. No citation were issued during this inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Program Director. Emailed the LIC 809 and LIC 809D for Program Director's signature.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: On 09/11/2020 LPA Alarcon conducted additional interviews of residents R4 through R8 and S3 and S4. Based on interviews conducted of the residents and staff who work in the dormitory where the allegation allegedly happened, there is not enough evidence to substantiate the allegation listed above. Five of eight of the residents interviewed stated the use of racial slurs did not occur. Five of the staff were interviewed and there was no staff who witnessed this incident. Based on LPAs' interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. No title 22 Regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/22/20 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alarcon contacted the facility and spoke to Christine Gwin for the purpose of delivering final findings for the allegation of staff using racial slurs. On 07/06/20 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Alarcon and Xiong initiated a complaint investigation via Zoom. LPAs conducted interviews with AD and R1. On 07/14/ LPAs Alarcon and Xiong continued the complaint investigation by conducting an in person inspection to the facility. On this date LPAs completed a full inspection of the facility and conducted interviews with residents R2, R3, R4 and with staff S2 and S3. The investigation needed further investigation by requiring additional interviews. Continuie to 9099-C

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted a Case Management tele-Inspection via Facetime with the above facility on 11/05/2020 at 1:20 PM and met with Program Director, Christina Gwin to discuss the incident report. Community Care Licensing received an incident report dated 10/22/20 regarding a C1 going into the restroom and acting suspicious as he walked into the restroom, he was observed looking over his shoulder and looking around the restroom. Later, staff noticed the positioning of C1 feet were in an awkward position under the stall door. Staff immediately called C1 names multiple times to make sure C1 was OK. However, C1 did not respond. At this time Staff went over to stall that C1 was in and began to shake the door with increasing concern for his safety of C1. Staff again called out his name and again no response. Staff punched the door open and noticed that C1 was slumped over. The door did not open completely; however, Staff was able to see C1 slumped over the left side of the toilet, pinned up against the wall. Staff observed that C1’s right hand was in the toilet next to a white and black can of “Dust Off”, which is cleaning product for computers. Staff moved C1 shoulder and say his name multiple times. C1 began to blink and make eye contact with Staff. Staff assisted C1 to the medical department for further evaluation. C1 was immediately taken to the Emergency Department as a precaution. C1 was seen at the Emergency and released to the facility. Refer to LIC 809C, next page

After returning from the emergency room, C1 was placed on sick bed as a precaution and on level 3 watch list to be fully monitored. C1 will be participating in the stabilization program and will be required to write a treatment paper on appropriate coping skills and the detriments of substance abuse. The Director immediately put a safety plan in place. Emailing all teachers and staff to be sure that all aerosol, compressed air, or any cleaners/etc., be stored in a locked area and not be accessible by any student and the products to be accounted for. No deficiencies or citations were given at this time. Exit interview was conducted at this time.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
On 2-17-2021, Licensing Program Analyst Dawn Eunice (LPA) conducted a case management inspection for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the Interim Licensing Standards regarding providing care and supervision to children. LPA became aware that there was a lack of supervision discovered by a child’s authorized representative. Specifically, there was a 10-minute window of time children were unsupervised during shower time on August 25, 2020. Video footage suggested there was little to no supervision of youth in the “B” hallway between 6:35 p.m. and 6:45:38 p.m. During that time, a child entered another child’s room as follows: 6:38:25 C1 enters a C2’s room and leaves at 6:38:45. C1 was observed carrying clothing items and soap. 6:41:04 C1 enters C2’s room and leaves at 6:41:21 6:43:17 C1 gives “Daps” to staff 1, the two appear to converse; C1 walks away at 6:43:25 6:43:58 C1 enters C2’s room 6:45:37 Staff 2 arrives at C2’s doorway 6:45:38 C1 exits C2’s room with his shirt off and walks out, putting his shirt back on. C1 was in C2’s room approximately 3 minutes and 36 seconds.

Rites of Passage, Sierra Ridge Treatment Center provided a Plan of Correction to the citing agency on October 30, 2020. That plan included remedial training of all direct care staff to address and clarify Community Care Licensing expectations of appropriate line of sight supervision. LPA reviewed 24 acknowledgement of training documents. Twenty-four staff provided signatures acknowledging: - If there is more than one youth in the shower room, there needs to be staff to supervise. - If there is more than one youth in the bathroom, there needs to be a staff to supervise. - If students are outside at any time, there needs to be a staff visual on that youth. If there is more than one youth outside, there needs to be a staff physically outside with those youth. - All youth in my supervision always need to be accounted for. Due to the plan of correction provided, there are no Interim Licensing Standards cited.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
met_with: Justin Gaddy, Director of Group Living
narrative: LPA interviewed C3, C4, C5 and staff on 1-26-2021. LPA interviewed former staff on 2-2-2021. LPA interviewed yet a different staff person on 2-9-2021. All staff interviews contain consistent information in that children are not verbally or physically abused and that children are held accountable for bad behavior. Staff stated a child(ren) may have made a false allegation(s) out of anger, or, due to a false belief that an allegation would result in getting to go home. Staff interviews reveal children are not restrained unless someone is in danger of becoming hurt or hurting someone else. Staff indicated they feel supported by their peers. As stated above, C1’s and C2’s whereabouts are unknown; as such, LPA did not interview those children. Based on information obtained in interviews of C4 and C5, staff do not verbally or physically abuse children and they feel safe. C5 stated a motive for making a complaint is that child(ren) believe they could get a pass home. C3 indicated he saw a child get slammed against a wall. Information in reports of interviews of C1 and C2 denote physical abuse (hitting, punching, instigating peer on peer fighting), verbal abuse and retaliation for making a complaint. It is unclear whether children were abused or if false claims were made from anger, or from a false belief that allegations would result in a child(ren) going home due to COVID-19 health and safety precautions. The evidence is inconsistent. Although the allegation may be true, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to substantiate. The allegation is therefore UNSUBSTANTIATED. Additionally, this finding is in line with two separate and independent investigations conducted by San Bernardino County government officials. LPA conducted exit interview, provided appeal rights and confidential names list.
investigation_findings: 13On 02-10-2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Eunice conducted a tele-visit and met with Justin Gaddy, Director of Group Living, to discuss the complaint findings regarding the above allegation. This inspection was completed virtually because of health and safety restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic. LPA reviewed the Emergency Response Referral Information received from San Bernardino County Child Protective Services. On 10-13-2020, LPA opened the investigation and obtained staff applications, staff evaluations, staff training, staff roster, C1, C2, and C3’s children's face sheets, these children’s needs and services plans and the facility’s child roster. On 12-3-2020 and 01-19-2021 LPA interviewed a San Bernardino County CPS social worker and two San Bernardino County probation officers. Based on information obtained from interviews, C1 and C2’s whereabout are unknown and two independent investigation findings were found to be

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: During one interview with a client (1), the client (1) stated a staff fought another client (2). LPA interviewed that other client (2), who denied that happened to him. During an interview with a former staff, he admitted to verbally intimidating a client by going into his room and essentially telling him to fight him, not the other clients. The former staff also admitted to charging at a client who was being self-injurious, and the client cowering on the ground. The staff admitted to rough-housing with clients for fun and, "brotherly love," but denied that he had ever physically abused anyone. This is one of the staff that was accused of going into clients' rooms and fighting them. All staff denied all claims that they have physically abused clients. Staff denied that he pushed a client down the stairs. Staff denied that they went into clients' rooms to fight them. And all staff denied having any knowledge of any staff physically abusing any client. Staff involved in the previously mentioned restraint denied holding the client inappropriately and using excessive force. 23 clients denied witnessing or experiencing physical abuse at the hands of any staff. Additionally, one staff told LPA that a previous client was directed by a staff to put other clients in check, and to fight them to keep them in line. During interviews, a client informed LPA that he was instructed by that same staff to do the same thing. The accused staff denied this happened. Based on all conflicting and contradictory information from interviews, LPA has found the allegation that staff are physically abusing clients at the facility to be UNSUBSTANTIATED, meaning that while the allegation may be valid or true, there was not enough evidence to prove that it did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to let them know that she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA met with Administrator Christine Gwin over the phone. LPA investigated this complaint by conducting interviews with the Reporting Party, 30 clients, 9 staff, and 1 Administrator on 2/24/2021, 2/25/2021, 2/26/2021, 3/3/2021, 3/4/2021, 3/24/2021, 3/25/2021, and 3/26/2021. During interviews, four clients stated they heard about staff going into clients' rooms to fight them, but did not witness it. Two clients stated a staff pushed a client down the stairs. Another client stated the staff did not push that client down the stairs. One staff and three clients felt that a restraint conducted on one client rose to the level of physical abuse, but only by the screams the client was making and not by observing it. The client involved did not feel it was physical abuse because he was resisting. One client stated they witnessed a staff going into a client's room to fight him. LPA interviewed that client, who stated a staff did go into his room to fight him, however it ended with a hug, and they are ,"cool." The client did not name that staff and did not feel it was physical abuse.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez met with Administrator Gregory Brewer, Head of Service, over Microsoft Teams, a video conferencing application, for this Plan of Correction inspection. HOS could not assist LPA and LPM further and the meeting ended. At 5:00 PM Administrator Christine Gwin called LPA and LPA conducted the POC inspection with her. On 3/30/2021, the facility was cited for violations of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1, sections 87072(a)(6)(A), 87095.00(c)(1), and 87072(d)(11). Plans of correction for these deficiencies were due to CCL by 3/31/2021. 1. 87072(a)(6)(A): POC - Starting immediately no clothing nor shoes will be taken from clients. By POC due date of 3/31/2021, Administrator will submit her plan for preventing AWOL's in a different way. 2. 87095.00(c)(1): POC - Administrator will re-train staff on appropriate physical interventions. Administrator will tell LPA the date this training will occur on by POC due date of 3/31/2021. Administrator will submit the sign in sheet to LPA by second POC due date of 4/13/2021. 3. 87072(d)(11): POC - Administrator will meet with all staff discussed in this report and document the outcome. Administrator will also re-train all staff on personal rights. Admin will tell LPA the date for the meetings and training by POC due date 3/31/2021. By POC due date of 4/13/2021 Administrator will submit the documentation of the meetings and training sign-in sheet to LPA.

LPA did not receive POCs from the facility for any of these deficiencies by the POC due date. On this date, LPA was informed of the training dates for 87095.00(c)(1) and 87072(d)(11), and received the AWOL plan for 87072(a)(6)(A). Due to misinformation given to Administrator from the Department, Administrator did not submit POCs as required. LPA will not be issuing any civil penalties on this date. Administrator was reminded that the second half of the POC for 87095.00(c)(1) and 87072(d)(11) are due tomorrow 4/13/2021, and failure to submit those will result in civil penalties. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced Case Management visit to the facility on 4/23/21 beginning at 11:00 AM. LPA explained the purpose of the Case Management is to discuss an incident report that was emailed to the Department. This incident, which took place on 4/18/21 involved a resident that assaulted their step-parent during a visitation and also assaulted a staff member. On today’s date, LPA interviewed the administrator regarding the incident and watched the security camera footage of the incident. LPA was unable to interview the two staff members involved in this incident as they were not on shift at the time of the visit. LPA was unable to speak to the resident as they were currently AWOLed. Administrator provided LPA with contact phone numbers for the two staff members. No deficiencies were cited on today’s date. Depending on interviews with staff, further investigation may be required. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator, Christine Gwin.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Based on interviews with the Tracker, Administrator, Head of Service, five clients and staff, none reported that these allegations occurred. However, LPA was not able to interview the reporting party, therefore, the above allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED, meaning that while the allegation may be valid or true, there was not enough evidence to prove that it did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with Head of Service. A copy of this report was emailed to Head of Service for signature, and he will email the signed document to LPA by email.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto contacted the above STRIP to inform them about complaint investigation findings for the above allegations. LPA delivered the finding via Microsoft Teams video conferencing due to the current COVID-19 Pandemic. On 05/27/2021 at 1:15 PM. LPA connected with Head of Service, Gregory Brewer via Microsoft Teams and discussed the findings. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that Staff are hitting and kicking youth in care, Staff intimidate children in care, Facility has an inappropriate AWOL procedure, and Staff smoke on the facility grounds. On 03/08/21, LPA interviewed Administrator regarding the allegations and requested a copy of the AWOL procedures to be emailed to LPA. During the investigation process, LPA interviewed Administrator, Head of Service, Tracker, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, S1, S3, S4, and S5. LPA left numerous messages for Reporting party and was not successful in contacting the reporting party. Tracker stated he is called when a youth AWOLS from the facility. Tracker stated the woods are dangerous with mountain lions, bears and rattle snacks. The tracker stated, I do not carry a high-powered rifle, nor do I shoot at vehicle tires. I will follow the client and use a laser to point the way back to the facility or to assist the sheriff in finding the clients in the woods. The Tracker stated, I never get near the clients or put hands on the clients. Staff were interviewed and stated, they do not hit or punch the clients out of the sight of the cameras. Staff stated we are professional, and we don’t know of anyone hitting, punching the clients. Administrator stated, she has not heard any of the clients being kicked or punched. If a staff were to hit or punch the clients, the staff would be dismissed from working at the facility. Administrator stated the staff are not allowed to smoke or drink alcohol at the facility grounds or come to work intoxicated. Head of Service stated we constantly ask the client if they feel safe at our facility. If a client doesn’t feel safe, then we will continue to work the client to make sure the clients feel safe and we investigate the reasons that don't feel safe at our facility. Head of Service confirmed that there is no smoking or drinking alcohol on the premises. Refer to LIC 9099 C

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
LPA learned that the clients are left with one, or sometimes two, sets of clothing and have to ask for new clothes daily. The clothes clients are left with are a t-shirt, shorts, undergarments, socks, and slippers/house shoes. Two clients claimed they have had to reuse dirty clothes, however the rest of the clients either stated they did not know if clients who have AWOL'd had to reuse clothes, or that they have not had to. One staff stated sometimes it has happened that a client has had to reuse clothes. All staff interviewed confirmed that clients who have AWOL'd have their extra clothing and shoes taken away. Staff stated the reason these are taken away are so the clients will not AWOL again. One client stated staff take their clothes because they are told it is, "a conspiracy to AWOL." Based on interviews, it appears the clothing is taken away for an average of two to three days and a Shift Supervisor, Unit Manager, or Program Director has to approve giving them back. In the facility's Program Statement there is no mention of this practice, and it is not approved by the Department. The facility's Positive Discipline Policies and Procedures section in the Program Statement claims that, "there is no corporal punishment or violation of personal rights," however this practice is a violation of the clients' personal right to possess and use personal items, including clothing. Additionally, in the facility's Program Statement, section House Rules for Children/Nonminor Dependents, it states, "...any limitations for clothing will be court ordered and/or approved by the CFT," however this is not occurring for clients who get their clothing limited when they AWOL. Therefore, LPA has found the allegation that staff inappropriately discipline minors to be SUBSTANTIATED, or true. During interviews with clients, LPA learned that 21 clients have not witnessed or experienced an inappropriate restraint at the facility. Two clients were unable to be interviewed for this allegation. One client stated he has been restrained before where it has hurt his arms, but the restraint was done for an appropriate reason. One client stated he has seen clients passing out during restraints, but did not give LPA specific details about it. Based on interviews and Incident Report reviews, on 12/14/2020, a client was restrained by three staff. The client had returned from an AWOL and staff was taking his extra clothing so he would not AWOL again. The client became agitated, and other the staff were called

in to assist with the client. The staff involved wrote that the client became aggressive with verbal statements and balling his fits up, clenching his teeth. Then they state they either called for assistance first then initiated the restraint, or went straight to the restraint. At no point in the incident report does it discuss methods of de-escalation, nor evading techniques being used before the restraint was initiated. During interviews with the staff involved. One staff stated that the client had pushed another staff and that is why the restraint was initiated. This was not reflected in his write-up of the details in the Incident Report. The other two staff described the client only posturing/getting angry as the reason for restraining the client. Two staff stated that evasion was either not thought of, or not an option. When LPA asked staff if they thought to take a break, one staff stated they gave the client five minutes to get his clothes together. LPA found that methods to de-escalate the client were not used before the restraint, the staffs' actions were escalating the client, and the restraint itself further escalated the client. The restraint was not justified at the point it was initiated. The staff did not pivot or parry, two forms of evasion in the Safety Crisis Management program. The client did not want to give up the pants on his body, which is what staff were asking for when the client became escalated. The client claimed the staff took his pants off of him, however staff stated the client eventually took them off himself, and denied removing them from the client. Other clients interviewed stated they heard the client crying and screaming for the staff to stop. One client stated he saw the staff take the client's pants off of him and another client stated he saw the staff attempting to take the pants off of the client. LPA has found based on all interviews, incident reports, and Safety Crisis Management program guide that this was an inappropriate restraint as staff did not properly evade, nor de-escalate the client before restraining and their actions escalated the client, causing the restraint. Therefore LPA has found the allegation that staff inappropriately restrain minors to be SUBSTANTIATED, or true. On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Version 3.1, Sections 87072(d)(6)(A), and 87095.00(c)(1). An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to let them know that she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA met with Administrator Christine Gwin over the phone. LPA investigated this complaint by conducting interviews with the Reporting Party, 30 clients, and 7 staff on 2/24/2021, 2/25/2021, 2/26/2021, 3/3/2021, 3/4/2021, 3/24/2021, 3/25/2021, and 3/26/2021. LPA also reviewed the facility's Discipline and Runaway policy/procedures, Incident Reports, staff training records, and emergency intervention training materials. During interviews, all clients, except for three stated that as a consequence of AWOL'ing, clients' shoes and extra clothing are taken from them upon return from AWOL. Two of those three clients who did not state this, just did not know what happens upon return from AWOL. LPA learned that clients who have AWOL'd have their jackets, sweat pants, extra clothes, and shoes taken from them, including personal clothes. In general, clients have a uniform they wear to school and during free time and are allowed to wear personal clothing after nightly showers, and on weekends.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. Each child...is accorded the personal rights...including the personal right to be provided with and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items...which includes...clothing items. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews with staff and clients, staff are taking away clients' clothing and shoes as a consequence for AWOL'ing. This is a Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Starting immediately no clothing nor shoes will be taken from clients. By POC due date of 3/31/2021, Administrator will submit her plan for preventing AWOL's in a different way.

deficiencies.description: General Provisions. STRTP staff may be justified in using restraints as an emergency intervention if...the restraint is reasonably applied to prevent a child exhibiting assaultive behavior from exposure to injury or danger to self or others. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: interviews, IR review, Restraint Program review. Staff failed to take pre-restraint steps to de-escalated and evade. The restraint was not justifiable at the point it was initiated. This is an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will re-train staff on appropriate physical interventions. Administrator will tell LPA the date this training will occur on by POC due date of 3/31/2021. Administrator will submit the sign in sheet to LPA by second POC due date of 4/13/2021.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
During interviews with staff, some staff denied that staff cuss at the facility. Some staff stated that staff occasionally cuss, but not at the clients; that it might be a slip-up or accident. However, seven staff have heard other staff say--and two staff and one former staff have admitted to saying--the following: "stay your a** in your room," "don't be a b****," "stop being a b****," "quit acting like a b****," "what the f*** are you doing," "get the f*** in your room," "please go to your f***ing room," "f*** you" (in both a playful and serious way), "shut the f*** up," "stay the f*** in your room," "back the f*** up," calling a client a, "b****," yelling at clients, telling each other, "the clients are being b****es today," and "f*** your dead homies." A staff told LPA that they have heard one staff addressing clients as, "n***a." Other clients and staff told LPA that one staff (S2 - see confidential names list dated 3/30/2021) does say racially offensive comments like, "why do only black kids put their hands in their shorts," "it's not my fault black people don't make it nowhere," and called a client a, " "f***ing n****r." When LPA interviewed that staff, he did not deny using racial slurs, but asked instead what racial slur LPA was asking him if he used. That staff stated that he may have unintentionally said a racial slur, but he does not believe in them. The staff did deny saying, "f***ing n****r, however. One former staff admitted to making fun of a client who had his hands constantly in his shorts as, "gay," to make him feel bad. Another staff in particular (S1) was pointed out by four clients, and one staff for saying things to clients including, "f*** your dead homies," "f*** your family," "f*** your hood," "f*** your kids," and calling clients, "b****." When LPA interviewed that staff he denied saying those words. The clients interviewed echoed what staff admitted to hearing from other staff, or what they have said themselves, as described above. In addition to that, one client stated a staff told him, "it won’t matter, you’re still not going to be nothing, and get locked up,'" when he wanted to get a "green," week (good level). That staff denied saying that to any client, when interviewed. Based on interviews with staff and clients, with the corroborative statements and admissions made, LPA has found that the allegation that staff verbally abuse minors to be SUBSTANTIATED, or true.

On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Version 3.1, Sections 87072(d)(11), and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80078(a). At 5:48 PM an exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to let them know that she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA was not able to meet over a video conferencing app due to staff's available technology. LPA spoke with Alicia Bristol Buisiness Manager. BM was unable to complete this inspection with LPA. LPA met with Administrator Christine Gwin over the phone. LPA investigated this complaint by conducting interviews with the Reporting Party, 30 clients, 14 staff, and 1 Administrator on 2/24/2021, 2/25/2021, 2/26/2021, 3/3/2021, 3/4/2021, 3/24/2021, 3/25/2021, 3/26/2021, and 3/29/2021. LPA has found the allegation that there was a lack of supervision resulting in a resident AWOL'ing from the facility to be SUBSTANTIATED, or true.

Personal Rights. Each child...is accorded personal rights...including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse.

This requirement was not as evidenced by: Based on staff and client interviews. Staff violated this right by being verbally abusive to clients. This is an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

deficiencies.description:
The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and records review, a staff failed to provide adequate supervision when he was sleeping on shift, allowing a client to AWOL from the facility. This is an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Throughout the course of the investigation, LPA also conducted interviews with the following individuals: County Social Worker (CSW) on 5/26/21, Sacramento County Emergency Response Social Worker (ER) on 5/28/21 and 7/20/21, Residents R2-R5, R7, and R9-R12, Staff members S1-S9. Interviews were conducted on 5/26/21, 5/28/21, 6/7/21, 6/30/21, 7/19/21, and 7/26/21. LPA attempted to interview Residents R1, R6, and R8 but they declined the interview. LPA attempted to interview Staff S10 but they did not respond to LPA’s attempts at contact. During interviews with CSW and ER, they stated that Resident R1 informed them that staff had handled him roughly during a restraint. CSW and ER made consistent statements that R1 stated that staff held him down, pressing his face to the ground, were choking him out, and took his shoes off. LPA was unable to interview R1 as they declined to speak with LPA. During confidential interviews with nine residents, consistent statements were made that staff do not restrain residents roughly and do not take away their shoes during a restraint. During confidential interviews with 10 staff members, there were consistent statements indicating that staff do not restrain residents roughly or inappropriately. Three staff members made consistent statements that R1 had been combative and resisting the restraint, causing R1 to fall down on their own, but at no point did staff throw and hold R1 to the ground. Two staff members stated that by the time they reached the area where R1 had ran off to, R1’s shoes were already off and they do not know how or when it occurred. All ten staff members made consistent statements that shoes are not taken away from residents during restraints. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report along with Appeal Rights was given to Christopher Essary, Program Director.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 9/2/21 beginning at 12:15 PM. LPA met with Christopher Essary, Program Director , and explained the purpose of the visit was to conduct a Case Management regarding concerns that were discovered during an investigation. During the course of complaint investigations, LPA met and interviewed facility residents and staff members. During this investigation process, it was revealed during interviews with both residents and staff that the facility requires residents to remove their tennis shoes from their bedrooms and have it secured in a designated area in the lounge room. Consistent statements were made from interviewed staff members that this is done in order to prevent residents from going AWOL and for resident’s safety. Consistent statements were also made that the shoes were then taken and locked into the closet. The facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Version 3.1, Sections 87072(d)(6)(A) Personal Rights: … the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: To be provided with and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items…which includes: Clothing items… The facility is also being assessed an Immediate Civil Penalty Fee of $250 on today’s date for a repeat violation. Failure to correct the violation will also result in a continuing civil penalty fee of $100 per day for each day that the violation is not corrected. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was given to Christopher Essary, Program Director.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
Throughout the course of the investigation, IB interviewed former and current residents (R1, R2, R3, R4, R13, and R14), former and current staff members (S1, S2, S4, S5, S9, S10, and S11), and the Reporting Party (RP). Interviews were conducted on the following dates: 05/10/21, 06/07/21, 06/08/21, 06/09/21, 06/10/21, 07/15/21, and 07/19/21. During confidential interviews, there were consistent statements made by residents that an assault did occur at the facility which lasted around 10-20 minutes before staff intervened. This altercation, which occurred in 2018, resulted in a resident suffering from a fractured cheek bone. Confidential interviews with staff revealed that one staff who was on shift the day of the incident had walked away but was not gone for more than ten minutes. Upon their return to the hallway, this staff heard noises coming from a bedroom and when they went to open the door, they observed one resident being assaulted. During staff interviews, there was also statements that during this period, the facility was understaffed and they were times that one staff would be left alone with 15 residents. Based on IB’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited on the attached LIC9099D under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 1, section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were left at the facility with Christopher Essary, Program Director.

LPA Xiong investigated the allegation that “Staff are inappropriately restraining minors” while the allegation that “Staff are providing minors with drugs” was investigated by the Department’s Investigation Branch and assigned to Investigator Sergio Guerra (IB). During the course of the investigation, IB interviewed the Reporting Party (RP), former and current Residents R1, R13, and R14 along with Current and Former Staff S9, S10, and S11. IB and LPA conducted joint interviews with Residents R2-R4, and Staff S1, S2, S4, and S5. LPA interviewed Residents R5, R7, R9-R12, Staff S3, and S6-S8. LPA attempted to interview Residents R6, R8, and R15 but they declined the interview. LPA attempted to interview Staff S12 but they did not respond back. Interviews were conducted on the following dates: 05/10/21, 06/07/21, 06/08/21, 06/09/21, 06/10/21, 6/30/21, 07/15/21, 07/19/21, and 7/26/21. During confidential interviews with former and current residents regarding the allegation that “staff are inappropriately restraining minors,” two residents made consistent statements that staff used inappropriate restraints while nine other residents made consistent statements that staff do no inappropriately restrain residents and staff do not mistreat residents. In confidential interviews with staff members, one staff stated that some staff are more aggressive with residents so that residents will listen. However, consistent statements were made from nine other staff members that residents are not inappropriately restrained nor are handcuffs used as part of the restraint. During the investigation for the allegation that “Staff are providing minors with drugs”, six residents (former and current) were interviewed. One resident stated that a male staff sold Marijuana to residents, a second resident stated they heard rumors of staff selling drugs but did not believe it, and a third resident stated that they did not witness staff selling drugs to residents but stated that staff “sometimes” sold drugs to residents. One resident stated that sometimes staff smoked with residents. Three other residents made consistent statements that they have not witnessed nor heard of staff selling drugs to residents. In confidential interviews with both former and current staff members, all staff made consistent statements denying any knowledge of staff selling drugs to residents. Based on IB and LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations that Staff are inappropriately restraining minors and Staff are providing minors with drugs are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report along with Appeal Rights was left with Christopher Essary, Program Director.
investigation_findings: 13* This documented is being amended on 9/02/21 at 11:15 AM to reflect an appeal that was granted on 8/30/21. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 08/12/21 beginning at 2:30PM. LPA met with Christopher Essary, Program Director, and explained the purpose of the inspection was to deliver complaint investigation findings for the allegation that “Staff did not prevent minors from engaging in physical altercations resulting in severe injuries.” This allegation was investigated by the Department’s Investigation Branch and assigned to Investigator Sergio Guerra (IB). LPA had initiated the investigation at the facility on 4/26/21. On this date, LPA conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility, inside and outside. LPA reviewed and obtained the following documents for Residents R1 and R2: Admission/Discharge Documents, Needs and Service Plans, Incident Reports, and Medical Reports. LPA also obtained student roster and staff roster for the time period of R1 and R2’s placement at the facility. No deficiencies had been cited on this date. CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C

deficiencies.description:
80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews conducted, staff did not provide adequate supervision as two residents were in an altercation which lasted between 10-20 minutes before staff intervened. This resulted in one resident receiving an injury.  Interviews also revealed that one staff on shift had walked away but was not gone for more than ten minutes, and that at times, the facility was understaffed, resulting in one staff being left alone with 15 residents.  This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will submit a training plan discussing supervision and ratios.  This plan will detail how and when the trainings will be implemented and by whom.  The training plan will be submited to LPA via email by the POC due date.  Facility will then conduct the training and submit proof to LPA via email by 8/20/21.  Proof will include sign-in roster and training materials utilized.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong, LPA Rob Sandles, LPA Shawndra Miles, and LPA Maignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived to the facility on 9/16/21 beginning at 10:45 AM. LPAs met with Chris Essary, Program Director, and explained the purpose of today's visit was to conduct a REQUIRED Annual inspection. On today's date, a health and safety inspection of the facility grounds were conducted. The STRTP currently has two dorms currently occupied, Sierra and Yosemite that houses about 50 clients. Currently in placement are 25 clients. Each client is afforded their own private bedroom, equipped with beds and adequate linen and furniture that are in good repair. The passageways, including pathways to egresses, were unobstructed and free of clutter. LPA observed bathrooms and showers to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility has a cafeteria on the grounds. The cafeteria was observed to have the required two days' worth of perishable food supply and seven days' worth of non-perishable food supplies. Potential toxic or harmful cleaning detergents and other chemicals are handled by a facility staff. Medications are stored within a cabinet located in a locked and dedicated medication room. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors was observed throughout the facility and was in working condition. Water temperature was checked throughout the facility and within the required range. LPAs reviewed ten client files and ten staff files but were not able to complete the review process. LPA(s) will return on a different date and time to complete the inspection. Exit interview conducted with Program Director, Chris Essary. LPAs informed facility that they will return on a different date and time to complete the annual inspection. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: A staffer stated it was their opinion that the way the facility was staffed throughout their tenure at ROP was inadequate, in general—whether it was in the number of coach counselors working, or in which staff were assigned to the dorms, citing specific examples of when they didn’t get help at times. Although this LPA was not able to review the video footage culled from the security camera system because of the system’s protocol that deletes messages older than a certain period, the San Bernardino County Probation Departments Investigation Report was taken into account for this CCL investigation. Within this report, the Officer articulates having observed in the video footage, over a period of time, that there was a lack of supervision by staff—this assessment was corroborated by the same staffer that the report references. Furthermore, one youth stated, though there have been no instances of staff who were present on campus not providing supervision, the facility as a whole could use more staff, in general, because of the various situations that could take place that sometimes do leave an insufficient number of staff or allow for a less-than-ideal staffing situation (female staff to monitor the youths taking showers and/or going in and out of the bedrooms, for example). Based on LPA’s interviews and a review of the records, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1. The facility has provided documentation of the completed staff training prescribed by the San Bernardino County Probation’s Investigation Report. No further corrective action is being required as of this time. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/01/2021, at approximately 2 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon delivered the findings for this complaint investigation. LPA was met by Program Director Chris Essary and the report was discussed. LPA investigated the allegation that there was an overall Lack of Supervision of youths. On 06/25/20201 and 08/20/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted unannounced onsite inspections of this facility, interviewing staff and youth residents on both occasions. Records obtained and reviewed were the following: Needs & Services Plans for the referenced youths, the facility’s placement log or history of minor clients and a roster of facility staffers who worked for the time period of interest, a San Bernardino County Juvenile Probation Department STRTP Investigation Report dated 10/21/2020, and personnel files including documentation of the remedial training agreed upon as part of the corrective plan of action articulated in the aforementioned report. Interviews were conducted with the following individuals: three current student youth clients, a current ROP staffer, a former ROP employee, two involved Probation Officers (one from San Bernardino County, and one from Kern), and a biological mother to a former youth resident.

deficiencies.description:
80065(a) Personnel Requirements.
"Facility personnel shall be competent to provide the services necessary to meet individual client needs and shall, at all times, be employed in numbers necessary to meet such needs." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and a County Probation Report of reviewed video footage from security cameras, certain staff left youths unsupervised in a potentially precarious area and time of day. This posed a potential Health & Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility has submitted documentation of training provided to the entire direct-care staffing roster at the time, as prescribed by the San Bernardino County report. No additional remediation is required as of this time.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 12/17/21 at 9;15am. During the inspection, LPA Jean Stidman met with Christopher Essary Program Director and inspected the facility inside and out. All files, medication documents and a medication count was also conducted on this date. LPA reviewed ten of child’s records on site at the facility at 9:15am. LPA reviewed four staff personnel files on site at the facility at 9:15am. LPA interviewed four staff on site at 9;15am. LPA interviewed eight children currently taking psychotropic medications. facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection to the facility on 5/20/22 to discuss a serious incident that took place in the facility 5/18/2022. LPA met with Paige Woodard, Deputy Program Director to discuss the incident. LPA Hill and Ms. Woodard discussed the incident that happened at the facility on 5/18/2022 that included C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/20/2022) being beat up by a group of youth while C1 was in their room. LPA Hill, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Ms. Woodard, Galey Betzler, ROP Compliance Director, and representatives from San Bernardino County Probation all met on 5/19/2022 to discuss the incident via video technology. During this video conference, Ms. Woodard was able to share the video of the incident where it was observed that S1 left the dorm to make a phone call, leaving that wing of the dorm unsupervised for a period of approximately four minutes. In that time, two youth were observed to enter C1's bedroom and be in C1's bedroom for a few seconds, then the youth and C1 came out of the room. It appears that while the youth are in the hallway, words were exchanged amongst all the youth. C1 eventually returned to their bedroom and a few seconds later, three youth went into C1's room while one youth stayed in the doorway watching the door that staff had exited out of. LPA Hill conducted an interview with C1 via video technology on 5/19/2022. LPA Hill interviewed S1 on 5/20/2022 while at the facility. LPA also obtained additional documentation for staff and clients while at the facility. C1's account of events revealed that they were punched, hit and kicked repeatedly by the youth during both incidents. C1 allegedly called out for staff to assist but none responded to help C1. It was also noted that C1 reported not feeling well following the incident and that C1 had a headache but refused being taken for medical assessment. C1 was not seen or assessed until 5/19/2022.

LPA Hill informed Ms. Woodard that the findings of the investigation reveal that the facility was not in ratio at the time of the incident in that there were 14 youth in the dorm and only three staff. There was another staff on the facility grounds supervising four additional youth in the dining area but that still left the facility out of ratio. At the time of the incident, there were 18 youth total living in the facility and this meant that the facility was required to have five staff present but there were only four. In this hallway, it was observed via video surveillance that there was only one staff for this hallway. During the interview with S1, S1 acknowledged that they were aware that six youth were assigned this area, in that hallway and that one additional youth had come from the youth lounge that was not assigned this area. As a result of the investigation of this incident, the facility is cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Version 4, 87065.5(b)(1)(C): Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios and 87072(c): Personal Rights. Staff interviews, video surveillance review, and client interview demonstrate that staff did leave the dorm unattended for approximately four minutes allowing two fights to take place in the dorm. In addition, the evidence supports that the facility was out of compliance on this night by having only three staff in the dorm with 14 youth. In addition, the personal rights of youth were violated in that youth has a right to have a safe environment in which to live. By staff leaving their area of supervision without ensuring that additional staff was there to cover, youth was not accorded these personal rights. Facility was assessed civil penalties for a violation of the same subsection within the previous 12 months. Exit interview with Ms. Woodard and documentation provided on 5/20/2022.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 including (10) dignity in their personal relationships with staff, (11) to be free of physical...emotional, or other abuse and from corporal or unusual punishment..., and (17) to receive medical...and mental health services. This is not met as evidenced by Confidential interviewed and records reviewed revealed that S1 used a restraint that was inappropriate. The inappropriate restraint resulted in an injury and/or pain to C1 of which C1 complained about for days after which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The immediate health and safety risk was resolved when the facility removed S1 and terminated S3's employment at the facility. 

To prevent future citations of the same nature, the facility shall ensure that additional training on ROP's Staff Code of Ethics and shall provide proof of training to LPA Stidman by June 3/2022.

deficiencies.description: Medical Examination. The administrator or the social work staff shall be responsible for obtaining a physical examination during or after an incidence of emergency intervention when it is determined that: 1) There is physical injury to a child, or 2) There is a suspected injury to a child, or 3) Upon the child’s request. This is not met as evidenced by Following an incident where an emergency intervention was used, the administrator and/or social work staff failed to obtain a physical examination for C1 at C1's request, even though C1 repeatedly complained of pain in their back and neck which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The immediate health and safety risk was resolved when the facility removed S1 and terminated S3's employment at the facility. 

To prevent future citations of the same nature, the facility shall ensure that training is provided to include immediate medical assessment of all youth involved in emergency interventions by ROP staff and follow up within 24 hours by ROP medical staff. Proof of training shall be provided to LPA Stidman by POC date of 6/3/2022.
