deficiencies.description: Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. In a facility with a licensed capacity of seven or more children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows: During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm: When there are five or more children present at the facility, there shall be at least one awake and on duty direct care for every four children, or fraction thereof, present at the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interviews, the facility staff failed to provide a safe environment on 2/6/22 and 2/7/22 due to an inadequate number of staff.  The facility had 19 clients present and only two to four staff clocked in between the house of 7am-10pm. This poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to clients in care. This is a repeat deficiency and will be assessed a civil penalty due to the facility being cited for Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios on 5/20/22 when determined that during an incident on 5/18/22 the facility had 4 staff in ratio with 18 children.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will create a new schedule with staff increasing hours and other facility staff are transferring to ratio staff.  Facility will also train staff to notify office immidiately when out of ratio to get assistance.  Facility will provide licensing a copy of the schedule and signed training by 7/8/22.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection to the facility on 7/21/22 at 11 AM and met with Paige Woodard, Administrator to discuss an incident. LPA Hill learned that a youth was assaulted (C1) by another youth (C2) (see LIC811 dated 7/21/22) on 6/24/22, after the youth returned to the dorm following breakfast, at approximately 7:15 AM. LPA reviewed camera footage and observed that C2 went into C1's room and a fight ensued. LPA observed that there are two staff present in the hallway - positioned at either end of the hallway. One staff was by the exit door (S2) and the other staff (S1) was near the restrooms with another youth, not involved in the incident. Review of the camera shows that S2 was standing in the hallway watching and observed C2 go into C1's room but did not react to this. S1 was seen to come down the hallway and stop in front of C1's room and observed an altercation taking place in the room between the youth. It is observed that the fight actually starts to spill into the hallways twice within seconds of one another but S2 who was standing in the hallway did not intervene. It is unclear if anything was said by S2 to stop the youth from fighting. It then appears that S1 motioned for a youth (C3) to go into the room to stop the youth fighting. C3 then emerges from the room following C2. S1 never entered the room to stop C1 and C2 from engaging or stopping the situation already in progress. Ms. Woodard states that C3, S2 and S1 were interviewed by her and it was reported that S1 did tell C3 to go in and stop the fight. As a result of review of this incident with Ms. Woodard, LPA Hill did cite the facility for 80065(j) Personnel Requirements as clients shall not be used as substitutes for required staff. During this incident, the cameras indicated that S1 told or motioned to C3 to go into C1's room to stop the fight happening in C1's bedroom. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided with appeal rights.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 8/18/22 at 11:30 AM and met with Paige Woodard, Deputy Program Director to discuss an incident that occurred on 4/11/22. The incident is related to a S1 (see LIC811 dated 8/18/22) supervising youth in the facility dorm and while supervising, did leave his post in the dormitory leaving all youth in his direct care and supervision unsupervised for an undisclosed amount of time, while reportedly short in duration. In the time that the youth were unsupervised, C2 was able to enter C1's room and assault C1. This incident was also reviewed by the Ms. Woodard, LPA Hill and other staff from the agency via camera review. In review of the final incident report submitted to Licensing, S1 stated that the incident was observed by S1 but investigation and camera review shows that this was not possible as S1 left the youth unsupervised in the hallway for a short time. In light of this information, LPA did request that the agency update the reports and provide them to Licensing as this information documented is not accurate. LPA advised the agency that all incident reports need to be complete and accurate before submitting them to Licensing and placing agencies. LPA Hill also discussed ratios of staff to clients during this case management inspection as well. With the varied incident investigations and complaint investigations happening in recent months, it has come to the attention of Licensing that facility staff are not adhering to the ratios required by Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), specifically one staff to every four clients. LPA Hill was leaving the facility on 5/20/22 and observed that one staff left the dormitory with six clients, in violation of this regulation. LPA did advise Ms. Woodard of this observed violation via email on 5/20/22.

In addition, while reviewing camera footage related to the various incidents in recent months, there were several occasions where staff were observed to be out of the required ratio. LPA did inform Ms. Woodard and Galey Betzler, Compliance Director during the camera reviews of the observed violations. Based on the review of footage provided and shown to LPA and information obtained during investigations related to complaints and incident reports, the facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards Section 87065.5(b)(1)(C) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios as it was observed that during the incident on 4/11/22, S1 did leave youth unsupervised; on 5/20/22 LPA Hill observed one staff leave the dormitory at approximately 6:45 PM with six youth; and there were observations noted during camera reviews with ROP staff that direct care staff were entering or exiting the dorm with five or six youth and only one staff. While S1 was provided a disciplinary report for leaving their post on 4/11/22, this and the other noted violations are violations of the same Interim Licensing Standards regulation as noted and the standards that the facility is required to adhere to ensure the health, safety and personal rights of the youth at all times while in the facility. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Woodard and documents were provided to the facility via email.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 8/18/22 at 2:15 PM and met with Paige Woodard, Deputy Program Director to finalize incidents related to a case management inspection that occurred on 4/29/22. LPA Hill advised Ms. Woodard that this investigation involved a grievance form that was received alleging that S1 "choked out" C1 during a restraint. LPA Hill informed Ms. Woodard that C1 was interviewed and C1 did state that they felt that they were unfairly treated by S1 during an incident where S1 restrained C1. C1 did not feel that S1 choked C1 on purpose but C1 did feel that during the one person restraint S1's arm moved to their neck area, choking C1. When LPA Hill interviewed S1, they stated that during the incident S1 didn't touch C1 any where near the neck and thereby could not have choked C1 as alleged. LPA Hill informed Ms. Woodard that the investigation is complete as there is no evidence that C1 was choked. This report concludes the investigation for this incident. There are no citations issued and the investigation is closed. LPA Hill also interviewed C2 related to another incident investigation initiated on 4/29/22 where C2 was taken to the emergency room due to a broken nose. LPA Hill reviewed incident reports previously obtained and after interviewing C2, is closing the investigation without citation as C2 indicates that this injury took place while playing basketball and denied being assaulted by another youth in care. C2 also indicated that they feel safe in the facility at this time. LPA Hill did discuss telephone use with the facility during this inspection and did remind Ms. Woodard that youth cannot be restricted from phone use nor can phone use be restricted to specific dates and/or times. LPA Hill does understand the complexity in trying to find appropriate times to meet this need given the volume of youth in care but did advise the facility to discuss and document appropriate phone times and days during Child and Family Team meetings and in the Needs and Services to ensure that no violation of personal rights occur. Exit interview conducted and document was provided via email.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: youth in their assigned hallway with no other staff present and staff subsequently left their post leaving youth unsupervised for an undisclosed amount of time. While there is no corroborating evidence that S1 set up the fight between C1 and C2, S1 did leave his post for an unknown reason, leaving the youth unsupervised in this hallway. As a result of not having supervision in the immediate vicinity, C2 was able to go into C1's room and did engage C1 in a fight. This lack of supervision is addressed on a separate Case Management Inspection Report dated 8/18/22 as it is not related to the cited complaint allegation. As a result of the information obtained, documentation received, and interviews conducted there is no corroborating evidence to show that S1 set up a fight between C1 and C2. As a result, the allegation that staff violated personal rights of youth by setting up a fight between two youth is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Woodard and documents and appeal rights were provided via email to the facility.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: During this video conference, Ms. Woodard was able to share the video of the incident where it was observed that S1 left the dorm to make a phone call, leaving that wing of the dorm unsupervised for a period of approximately four minutes. In that time, it was observed that youth entered C1's room twice and subsequently reported that they had been assaulted by youth both times they entered C1's bedroom. This incident was investigated during a case management inspection conducted by LPA Hill on 5/20/2022. The allegation that facility staff did not supervise youth as required allowing minors to engage in physical fights in the facility is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited during the case management inspection for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards Version 4, 87065.5(b)(1)(C): Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios and 87072(c): Personal Rights. Staff interviews, video surveillance review and client interview demonstrate that staff did leave the dorm unattended for approximately four minutes allowing two fights to take place in the dorm. In addition, the evidence supports that the facility was out of compliance on this night by having only three staff in the dorm with 14 youth. As a result of the case management inspection citations, the facility was not cited again on this complaint. Facility was assessed civil penalties for a violation of the same subsection within the previous 12 months. Exit interview with Ms. Woodard and documentation provided on 5/20/2022.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill was at the facility on 5/20/2022 at 4:40 PM when the complaint for this incident came in. LPA met with Paige Woodard, Deputy Program Director to discuss the allegation and findings for this allegation as this incident was already investigated during the case management inspecton on 5/20/2022. LPA Hill obtained documentation related to this incident and youth involved while at the facility on 5/20/2022. LPA conducted an interview with C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/20/2022) on 5/19/2022 and interviewed staff on 5/20/2022 while at the facility. LPA Hill and Ms. Woodard discussed the incident that happened at the facility on 5/18/2022 which included C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/20/2022) being beat up while in their room. LPA Hill, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Ms. Woodard, Galey Betzler, ROP Compliance, and representatives from San Bernardino County Probation all met on 5/19/2022 to discuss the incident via video technology.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word made an unannounced case management inspection on 10/14/22 at 11:45 AM and met with Paige Woodard, Deputy Program Director to discuss an incident that occurred on 10/12/22.The incident is related to FC1 (see LIC811 dated 10/14/22) telling the staff he was in a relationship with his probation officer (PO) and made comments of sexual acts they perform together. LPA Word conducted an interview with FC1 and staff. FC1 stated that he did not make that statement. FC1 stated that he is never alone with his PO. FC1 stated that nothing inappropriate has happen between himself and his PO. The Program Director stated that the POs are generally not alone when on our campus meeting the youths. The Case Manager is present in most cases. Due to statements in interview the case management requires no future investigation. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

facility_name: ROP ATCS SIERRA RIDGE TREATMENT CENTER
investigation_findings: 13On 5/4/2023 at 12:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word arrived unannounced at the facility to deliver complaint findings. LPA spoke with Paige Woodard, Deputy Director, to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegations stated above.During the course of the investigation, LPA Word inspected the facility and reviewed records. Facility records provided to LPA included: Client register, Staff Roster, staff applications, staff training records, staff schedules and timecards for November and December 2022 and staff contact Information. Confidential interviews were conducted with three facility staff, two clients, Deputy Director, and Executive Director. LPA was informed by the Executive Director that if a staff calls out and is unable to work their assigned shift, the facility will utilize their on-call procedure. If that fails, the facility will then pull a staff member that is trained in childcare to cover the shift. Based on inconsistent statements in interviews, observation, and record review, the LPA was unable to determine if the above allegations occurred. As a result of the investigation, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the 9099 and appeal rights was provided to Paige Woodard, Deputy Program Director.

narrative:
To Amend the LPA arrival date On July 21, 2021 at 12:30pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation. LPA met with Raven Morrow, Facility Manager. Brief Summary: On 07/08/ 2021, the Department received a Special Incident Report stating that on 07/06/2021 a Staff member left two 15 years old male clients and one 16 years old male client alone in facility van with keys while he used the restroom at a local park. Upon returning, the facility van and clients were gone. Staff searched perimeter of park, but van nor clients were found. Staff contacted Torrance Police Department to file police report. Additional staff also canvassed the neighborhood in search of van and clients. All clients returned to facility approximately three hours later. Upon arrival, clients stated no injuries were sustained while away from the facility. 16 years old male client was arrested due to becoming combative with Torrance Police Department officer. An Addendum pending for safe return of all residents and vehicle located. No further information provided. During the investigation process, LPA reviewed Special Incident Report #763271 and interviewed Facility Manager (FM) and Child #1. Statements were consistent that on July 6, 2021 at 2:45pm Staff #2 left 3 clients in a running van while he went to use the bathroom. Staff #2 came back to where the van was and noticed it was gone. After interviewing Child #1 he stated that the client who drove the van was Child #2The van was located downtown Los Angeles after the client driving crashed into another vehicle. No one was injured in the crash. Staff #2 was suspended that day and eventually terminated on July 19, 2021. A review of facility's personnel summary on July 21, 2021 indicates that all staff required to have a criminal record clearance have obtained the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response.

Facility is being Cited for 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

Report Amended to change the facility Name On July 26, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst, LPA Donald Martin made an inspection visit to ROP Emancipation Home for the purpose of concluding a Case Management Investigation. LPA met with Raven Morrow, Facility Manager. The Department received notification from the Department of Children and Family Services requesting a follow up on a CAP put in place for the ROP facilities. Referral Number: 1355-1304-5004-1047667 which was investigated by LPA Regina Martin. The "Second Floor Interactive Supervision Policy" was put in place by ROP to be in compliance with ILS regulation 87088 (e)(2) which states: The following facilities shall maintain a signal system which meets the requirements specified in (e) and (f) below. Such system shall be used by children to summon staff during an emergency: (2) All facilities having separate floors and not providing full-time staff on each floor whenever children are present. During the investigation process, LPA reviewed ROP's Second Floor Interactive Supervision Policy and also walked around the facility. The Policy and home are in compliance at the time of this LPA's visit. No further incident has been reported. A staff re-training on interactive supervision was completed by staff and submitted to the department.

narrative:
On November 19, 2021 at 10:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA was met by Administrator, Raven Morrow, and allowed into the facility. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to six (6) children, ages 12 through 17, ambulatory only. This facility also provides services to Non-minor Dependents pursuant to W&I code 16501.1(C)(1).There are no bodies of water on the premises. LPA will conduct the facility inspection inside and out and review 3 client files on this visit. The home is set up as follows: This is a two story house with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room, staff office, kitchen/laundry area, dining area, and outdoor space. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition there is a sofa with a center table and a covered fire place. Next to the living room is a desk set up for clients to use with a computer. Dining Area: One table with five (5) chairs. Kitchen: There is a stove/oven with four (4) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. There is a fire extinguisher mounted onto the wall. Trash can has a tight lid on. All cleaning supplies are kept locked in laundry area cabinet. The knives and medications are locked in the closet that is located under the staircase and made accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Client files are also kept locked inside a file drawer in the kitchen. Laundry Area: Is located towards the back of the kitchen. There is a washer/dryer available. Staff Office: Is located upstairs. There are two desks with a desk chairs. The staff office is kept locked at all times. Bedroom #1: Is located downstairs. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #2: Is located downstairs. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #3: Is located upstairs. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Cont. 809-C

Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. One (1) bathroom is downstairs and the other bathroom is located upstairs. The bathroom located downstairs is only used by the clients in care and the upstairs bathroom is used by both facility staff and clients. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions. The faucets that are used by the children were tested and delivered hot water at a safe temperature range. There are no security bars on the windows. Outdoor Space: The entrance area and backyard to be free of debris and hazardous materials. There is an outdoor shed that is used for storage and the garage is used for clients therapeutic services and two freezers are kept inside to store extra food. The home was inspected and the following was observed: The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care. No more than two (2) children share a bedroom. Children have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. Outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. The facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives are stored in a locked cabinet inside a locked box and inaccessible to children. Staff conduct a sharps count to ensure all sharp objects are returned and locked in the lock box. Adequate supervision is provided for children in care. Staff ensure three nutritious meals and snacks. Food supply is ample in the home. Children are accorded personal rights. All posting requirements were met. Children in care are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. The home operates within capacity and limitations of license. Facility Van: Dodge Caravan, registration and insurance all current and up to date. The Van appears to be clean and in good working condition. The facility is in the process of being slightly renovated. The carpet was pulled up in the living room, two bedrooms have been painted and the third is scheduled to be painted on Monday. Note: Administrator was advised to send LPA notification when extensive work is being performed at the facility in the future. Review of Staff files and interviews will be conducted on the next visit. No deficiencies were found at the time of the visit. A copy of this report will be left with Raven Morrow, Administrator.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection on 5/3/23 at 11:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 24 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 24 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 5/3/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Raven Morrow.

On June 25, 2024, at 12pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin initiated a Case Management Incident inspection in response to self-reported incident involving Client #1 (C1) death. LPA spoke with Administrator, Faaputu Vaafuti (S1). The self-reported incident report was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on June 24, 2024. The incident, occurred on June 22, 2024. C1 and C2 left the facility on June 22, 2024, at 12:15 PM on an unauthorized absence. Facility staff filed a missing person report for C1 and C2 with the Torrance Police Department. Facility staff received information on June 23, 2024, that C1 and C2 attended a pop-up carnival in Culver City, California and C1 was stabbed to death. Facility staff spoke with LAPD Pacific Division Officer Ramirez #36911 and confirmed C1 death. C2 returned to the facility on June 24, 2024, at 11:03 AM. During inspection LPA spoke with S1. LPA was informed S1 last spoke to C1 on June 22, 2024. S1 was notified of the incident from S2. S2 , while working the overnight shift was approached by C3 who was distraught. C3 stated he just received a phone call from C2 stating that C1 was just stabbed. Additionally, LPA was informed that S3 got information from C1's girlfriend who stated C1's last location was in the Palms area. This information was possibly disclosed by C3. Staff has notified all pertinent parties regarding both C1 and C2 and Incident is being investigated by LAPD Pacific Division Homicide Detectives. LPA requested the following information from Client #1's files: Placement Agreement, Intake Paperwork, Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP), Case Management Notes, a copy of the police report, and a copy of Client #1's death certificate once the document is made available. This incident requires further investigation. A copy of this report was provided to Administrator, Faaputu Vaafuti. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.

narrative:
Confidential interviews, statements confirmed that S1 became intimately involved with C1 (former client) resulting in the birth of their child. Confidential statement revealed S1 and C1’s relationship began after C1 left the ROP Emancipation Home. Statements further revealed S1’s acknowledgement of violating ROP Emancipation Home policy and procedure (Anti-Fraternization Policy) as S1 was terminated in January 2024, for admitting to having a relationship with a former resident that resulted in the birth of a child. Based on confidential interviews and documentary evidence the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is Substantiated. The facility is cited per Health and Safety Code 1558 Persons prohibited from employment; dismissal or removal.

The investigation including review of facility file/records, and confidential interviews of C1, S1, Program Manager, and contact with Department of Children and Family Services-Out of Home Care, revealed C1 resided at the facility from October 2021 to July 2022. S1 began employment with ROP Emancipation Home in March 2022 through January 2024. Information obtained from confidential interviews, revealed denial of sexual abuse by S1 towards C1. While statements disclosed confirmation of a sexual relationship between S1 and C1, statements maintain denial of C1 being underage or engaging in a sexual relationship or intimately involved while C1 resided in the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 and C1 became intimately involved after C1 was discharged from the facility. Statements further contend that the intimate relationship between S1 and C1 was consensual. The Department’s investigation determined, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the allegation is not supported or proven by the evidence gathered. Therefore, the allegation that S1 sexually abused C1 while at ROP Emancipation facility, is determined unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Facility Representative, Facility Senior Manager.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection on 9/10/24 at 12:10pm based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 29 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 29 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 9/10/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and progress notes, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Faaputu Vaafuti.

investigation_findings: 13On February 12, 2021 at 3:45pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection and spoke to Dana Centanni, Program Director. narrative: review of medical records, facility internal investigation and review of related reports from the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) did not provide enough evidence to support allegation. Information provided by Client #1 to LAPD, Investigator Hector and facility staff show a pattern of inconsistency. Moreover, staff members working on the alleged date of the incident confirm no incidents occurred. Residents corroborate denial of witnessing alleged incident and agree that staff provide continual supervision and monitoring in the facility. Client #2 denied the allegation. There were no witnesses or documentary evidence to support or prove that the allegation occurred. As to claims of Client #3 being AWOL since August 2020, a review of records indicates on 08/21/2020, Client #3 left the facility without permission. At that time, staff followed procedures and AWOL Protocols were completed including, but not limited to, notifying required parties. Due to a lack of evidence, alleged lack of supervision leading to sexual abuse, and client AWOL cannot be substantiated. Therefore, it has been determined that the allegation is Unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited during the investigation. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to Facility Administrator.

Report Amended to change the facility Name On July 26, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst, LPA Donald Martin made an inspection visit to ROP Harbor City Home for the purpose of concluding a Case Management Investigation. LPA met with Raven Morrow, Facility Manager. The Department received notification from the Department of Children and Family Services requesting a follow up on a CAP put in place for the ROP facilities. Referral Number: 1355-1304-5004-1047667 which was investigated by LPA Regina Martin. The "Second Floor Interactive Supervision Policy" was put in place by ROP to be in compliance with ILS regulation 87088 (e)(2) which states: The following facilities shall maintain a signal system which meets the requirements specified in (e) and (f) below. Such system shall be used by children to summon staff during an emergency: (2) All facilities having separate floors and not providing full-time staff on each floor whenever children are present. During the investigation process, LPA reviewed ROP's Second Floor Interactive Supervision Policy and also walked around the facility. The Policy and home are in compliance at the time of this LPA's visit. No further incident has been reported. A staff re-training on interactive supervision was completed by staff and submitted to the department.

narrative: On September 3, 2021 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at ROP Harbor City Home for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Investigation. On December 6, 2021 at 10:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin made an unannounced visit to ROP Harbor City Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to six (6) clients ages 12 through 17. Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents. The home is set up as follows: This is a two story house with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, front patio, living room, staff office, family room/laundry area, dining area, kitchen, and outdoor space. Front Patio: There is ample seating space, one table with six (6) chairs and extra chairs. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition there are two sofas with a center table and a covered fire place. Dining Area: One table with eight (8) chairs. Kitchen: There is a stove/oven with four (4) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer and a locked storage freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. There is a fire extinguisher located to the left side of the door entering the family room. Trash can has a tight lid on. All cleaning supplies are kept locked in a storage room off of the living room. The knives and medications are locked in the closet that is located to the right once entering the office and made accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Client files are also kept inside the closet locked. Office/ Laundry Area: There is a washer/dryer located inside a closet in the office. Laundry detergent is kept in the locked closet off of the living room. There is a staff bathroom entrance also located in the staff office and a door that leads to the back yard. Bedroom #: Is located upstairs. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, individual closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #2: Is located upstairs. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #3: Is located upstairs. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C.

Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms available for client use. One (1) bathroom is downstairs and has a shared entrance to the staff bathroom. The other bathroom is located upstairs in the hallway and is shared by all clients. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions. The faucets that are used by the children were tested and delivered hot water at a safe temperature range. There are no security bars on the windows. The hallway window upstairs will be used as an emergency exit with an emergency escape ladder available. Outdoor Space: LPA observed the entrance area and backyard to be free of debris and hazardous materials. The home was inspected and the following was observed: The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care. No more than two (2) children share a bedroom. Children have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. Outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. Facility has one or more functioning carbon monoxide detectors that meet statutory requirements. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives are stored in a locked cabinet inside a locked box and inaccessible to children. Staff conduct a sharps count to ensure all sharp objects are returned and locked in the lock box. Adequate supervision is provided for children in care. There is a desk upstairs in the hallway available for staff to supervise the children when they are upstairs. Staff ensure three nutritious meals and snacks. Food supply is ample in the home. Children are accorded personal rights. Children in care are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care can contact the licensing agency or Group Home Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. All posting requirements were met. Children in care are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. The home will operate within capacity and limitations of license. LPA observed age appropriate First Aid supplies. Fire extinguishers were fully charged. There was no deficiencies cited at this time of the visit. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On 4/16/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen made an unannounced visit to Rite of Passage (ROP) Harbor City Home for the purpose of a Case Management for Special Incident Report #1285935. During this visit, confidential interviews were conducted with staff and clients. Facility Manager stated that on 4/9/25, one (1) staff and one (1) client had been involved in an automobile accident in the facility car (2018 Dodge, Grand),where the facility car was hit by another car. LPA went out and observed the car which was lightly hit on the passenger side front bumper. Facility Manager stated staff and client were uninjured in the automobile accident. Facility Manager stated that neither staff nor client was in need of medical attention as a result of the automobile accident. Client and Staff interviewed also shared that they were not in need of medical attention. LPA observed and received a copy of both an up to date staff drivers license and insurance for the facility vehicle. While the car accident did happen and a staff and a client were involved, interview evidence and records review show that all staff followed the appropriate protocol and procedure during the entire incident and after. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the facility manager.

On June 16, 2025 at 10:15 AM Licensing Program Analysts LPA, Kenrick Ellis made an announced visit to ROP Harbor City Home STRTP to conduct the Psychotropic Case Medication Inspection. LPA conducted a Health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Kenrick Ellis met with the Administrator, Faaputu Vaafuti and conducted a brief walk through of the physical plant inside and out. LPA reviewed 3 client files and conducted 1 client interview at the facility. One client declined to be interviewed. One client has been at the facility for less than one month. One client does not take psychotropic medications. One client was at school during case management inspection. LPA reviewed four staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA interviewed two staff members. LPA reviewed the LIC500 to confirm the shift which starts in the evening and ends early morning and reviewed the staff Criminal Records Clearances. The Administrator provided a physical hard copy of the psychotropic medication training topics during the training for LPA’s to review. No deficiencies were cited per Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP Version 5. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 4/28/25 at 11:49 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the ROP Harbor City Home and conducted an unannounced complaint inspection. LPA met with with Direct Care Staff (DCS) Faizon Morrow and deliverd the findings of the investigation for the above allegation. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered documentation, and reviewed records. Interviews from clients and staff record that the event in question was a misunderstanding and all parties have apologized with no further hurt feelings. Records review shows that staff are up to date on training in de-escscalation and other practices to help with these situations. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegation of “Staff do not treat minor(s) with respect.” is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was given.

narrative: Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the allegation of “Staff do not treat minor(s) with respect” is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was given.
investigation_findings: 13On at 1:12 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the ROP Harbor City Home and conducted an unannounced complaint inspection. LPA met Facility Manager Lupe Castro and delivered the findings of the investigation for the above allegation. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered documentation, and reviewed records. Interviews from clients and staff involved in the event record that the event in question that lead to the allegation that "Staff do not treat minor(s) with respect" was a misunderstanding between staff and a client. All parties have apologized and there have been no further incidents. LPA originally delivered findings, but then conducted more interviews for the investigations. These new interviews with other involved staff and clients concur with the original findings and testimonies. Records review shows that staff are up to date on training in de-escalation and other practices to help with these situations.

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheraki Davis on 08/17/2021 at 3:30 PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Lisa Ramirez, House Parent and Leo Trammell, Senior Coach and inspected the facility. LPA reviewed four children’s psychotropic records on site at the facility at 4:10 PM. During the review of children’s records, LPA Davis observed four children Needs and Services Plan were not signed by C1, C2, C3, and C4 and were not signed by the child’s Social Worker. LPA reviewed three staff personnel files at 5:50 PM. LPA began three staff interviews at 4:30 PM. LPA interviewed three children currently taking psychotropic medication at 3:40 PM. One child was out in the community. LPA conducted exit interview with Leo Trammell, Senior Coach at 6:20 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report, LIC 809D, Appeal Rights, to Leo Trammell, Senior Coach upon completion. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the Interim Licensing Standards during the inspection.

On April 05, 2021, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that foster children are not treated with respect by S3, and staff (S2 and S3) ignore C1, S2 and S3 made inappropriate comments towards C1, and S2 and S3 encouraged other foster children to ignore C1. Confidential interviews revealed staff always treat foster children in care with respect. However, confidential interviews revealed staff can get agitated at foster children and they don’t treat them respectfully. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Confidential interviews revealed staff do not ignore foster children, however there may be times where a foster child is argumentative and verbal redirection does not work. Staff will then listen to the foster child but will not engage in further dialogue to avoid further conflict. Confidential interviews revealed staff did not make inappropriate comments towards C1, however confidential interviews revealed that a staff member did make an inappropriate comment towards C1. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation. Confidential interviews revealed that staff at times do tell other foster children to ignore C1 when C1 is argumentative with staff. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 tends to try to create a hostile environment by bringing in other foster children into C1 arguments with staff. In order to deescalate an argument, staff discourage other foster children from partaking in C1’s arguments with staff. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that foster children are not treated with respect by S3, and staff (S2 and S3) ignore C1, S2 and S3 made inappropriate comments towards C1, and staff (S2 and S3) encouraged other foster children to ignore C1 may have occurred; however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Dana Centanni.

narrative:
On September 20, 2021, at 1:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on August 24, 2018. LPA was met at the facility by Senior Coach, Kammy Delp. There are currently six residents in placement. LPA toured the facility inside and out at 1:45 PM. The facility consists of a common area, kitchen, pantry, laundry room, three client bedrooms, one client bathroom, one staff bathroom, and one staff office. The client bedrooms are set up so there are two clients to a bedroom and one client per bed. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client’s belongings. A client’s mattress and box spring in bedroom #2 did not have good springs and was in disrepair. The bathroom was clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested in client bathroom #1 at 3:12 PM and registered at 109.4 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Cleaning solutions and hazardous items were observed to be stored in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. Sharp knives were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked closet. Medications are stored in a locked filing cabinet inside the entry closet. The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are electrically hard wired and observed to be operable. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Senior Coach, Kammy Delp. LPA observed facility posted items in the living room that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There is one camera at the facility located on the wall in the hallway. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction.

LPA interviewed two clients in care. Due to the need to complete staff/client interviews, staff/client file reviews, and complete the inspection, this annual will continue on a later date. A copy of this report was provided to House Parent Lisa Ramirez.

On September 21, 2021, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Jesus Cervantes continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on September 20, 2021. LPA met with Senior Coach, Kamy Delp. Licensee obtained their Mental Health (MH) Certification on March 14, 2021 and it expires on March 24, 2022. Licensee obtained National Accreditation through CARF and the accreditation is valid through August 31, 2022. Licensee has received a Medi-Cal approval through March 24, 2022. Licensing fee payments are current. LPA discussed the following with Senior Coach, Kamy Delp: operational requirements, disaster preparedness, and core/therapeutic services. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. At 10:45 AM, LPA began to review a sample of six clients files during the time of inspection. Due to the need to conduct client/staff interviews, and continue client/staff file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Senior Coach, Kamy Delp.

On September 22, 2021, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Jesus Cervantes continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on September 20, 2021. LPA met with Senior Coach, Kamy Delp. At 9:35 AM, LPA began to review a sample of six clients files during the time of inspection. All files contained the required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Three facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. Personnel files are located at ROP Corporate Office located at 400 N. Tustin Ave. Suit #120. Santa Ana, CA 92705. At 2:00 PM, LPA met with Director, Dana Centanni. LPA reviewed sample of ten of ten staff files. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging the child abuse reporting requirements. Due to the need to conduct additional client/staff interviews, and continue staff training file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Director, Dana Centanni.

On September 23, 2021, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Jesus Cervantes continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on September 20, 2021. LPA met with Compliance Manager, Crystal Maxwell. Personnel and training files are located at ROP Corporate Office located at 400 N. Tustin Ave. Suit #120. Santa Ana, CA 92705. At 9:00 PM, LPA reviewed sample of ten of ten staff training files. All files contained the required documentation and training per Title 22 Regulations. At 2:30 PM, LPA returned to the facility and met with Child Care Worker, Yesennia Villa. LPA completed three staff interviews. Four clients refused to be interviewed. Based on the facility inspection completed and files reviewed, the facility is not in compliance. The facility is cited for Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5, Version 3.1, Section 87088(c)(1), Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, Supplies. (c) The licensee shall provide and make readily available to each child the following furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for personal care and maintenance of personal hygiene: (1) An individual bed maintained in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillow(s) which are clean and in good repair. Based on the observation, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above in one out of six beds which posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and LIC 809D was provided to Senior Coach, Leo Trammell

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Veronica Whitaker conducted a case management inspection May 24, 2022, at 11:09 AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During the inspection, 9 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated May 24, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Veronica Whitaker observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Sylvia Arballo,Compliance Manager, Dana Centanni, Program Director, Rabah Mahmoud..

Confidential interviews reported that C1 might have been drinking alcohol the night before. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was taken to the hospital from school. Confidential interviews reported that C1’s toxicology screening showed an alcohol level of 0.001. Confidential interviews reported that C1 has a history of running away from their facility. Confidential interviews reported that sometimes it was suspected that C1 was under the influence of alcohol upon return from AWOL. Confidential interviews reported that C1 did not obtain alcohol at the facility, nor was their alcohol available at the facility or provided by staff. Confidential interviews reported that C1 may have received alcohol while AWOL from the facility but could not prove it. Confidential interviews reported that alcoholic beverages or alcoholic containers were not found in C1’s room or the facility premises. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that medication is accessible to a minor (C1). Confidential interviews reported that a minor in care (C1) admitted to taking Percocet before attending school on 04/19/2022. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was not prescribed Percocet while at the facility. Confidential interviews reported that facility staff locked and secured all psychotropic medication within the facility. During the health and safety inspection, LPA observed that the psychotropic medication was locked and inaccessible to clients. Confidential interviews reported that it was unknown where C1 obtained the Percocet. Confidential interviews reported that C1 may have received Percocet while C1 was absent without permission from the facility. Confidential interviews reported that facility staff did not find any Percocet in C1’s or any other client’s bedroom. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that the minor (C1) has access to alcohol and medication accessible to minor (C1), may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and provided to Senior Coach Counselor Angelica Littlefield.

deficiencies.description:
Health Related Services: Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, C1 was given an extra dose of their prescribed medication on 01/01/2024 and 01/02/2024.  This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, an email will be sent to the staff reminding them to ensure the medication label is correctly recorded on the Medication Administration Record (MAR) and staff follow the medication label, as prescribed.  A copy of the email will be sent to the LPA by 5:00 pm on 07/19/2024.

narrative:
reviewed indicated C1 was not given medication #1 on November 29, 2023, medication #2 was not given to C1 from December 23-27, 30-31 in 2023, medication #3 was not given to C1 on December 23-26, 28-31 in 2023, and medication #4 was not given to C1 on December 23-24 (in the evening) and December 27 (in the morning) in 2023. On September 30, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jesus Cervantes, conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. LPA met with ROP Paragon Administrator, Alvin Brown, to obtain information regarding an incident reported to Community Care Licensing that occurred on 9/26/20. The incident involved client behavioral incidents that required the response of the Placentia Police Department on three separate occasions within a three-hour time span, that resulted in the arrest of three clients. One client was arrested for false imprisonment and two clients were arrested for vandalism. During the inspection, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed files. Information related to the incident was obtained. Additional Information is being gathered to determine if there is a violation of the Title 22 Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards. Therefore, this case management is being extended. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to the Administrator.

On September 30, 2020, at 3:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jesus Cervantes, conducted an unannounced case management visit at the facility and met with Program Manager, Alvin Brown. The purpose of this visit was to follow up on a letter from the Department of Social Services Caregiver Background Check Bureau dated September 30, 2020, regarding Danielle Allen. Alvin Brown was not familiar with that employee working at the facility and contacted Program Director, Dana Centani. Dana Centani advised LPA that Danielle Allen was hired on 09/29/2020 as a Rehab Specialist. Danielle Allen has yet to actually work in a facility as she is currently conducting new employee orientation at facility corporate office. In response to the Caregiver Background Check Bureau letter dated September 30, 2020, Dana Centanni informed Danielle Allen that she must be removed from all facilities until an exemption is processed and approved. A CBCB-3.1 form certifying that individual has been removed from the facility/home as of September 30, 2020 was completed and submitted. Based on evidence obtained during today’s visit, the LPA has verified the individual is not present or residing at the facility. LPA was advised by the licensee intends to request an exemption as soon as all required documents are gathered. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Program Director, Dana Centani. Due to COVID-19, a signed copy of this report will be in the facility file. Verification of removal is complete.

Confidential interviews revealed that no one falsifies signatures or documents. The facility has an internal compliance manager which conducts random audits to ensure proper documentation of facility documents. However, confidential interviews and documents obtained revealed discrepancies in past documents as a result of procedural errors, not falsification of signatures. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding S5 sleeping on shifts. It is rumored S5 has been found sleeping on shifts, but it has not been witnessed by staff. Confidential interviews revealed S7 did not secure a cleaning spray in a chemical closet, however confidential interviews revealed S7 secured the cleaning spray in a locked staff office away from clients in care. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that staff would often falsify signatures on documents in an effort to cover mistakes resulting in inadequate record keeping, S5 is sleeping on shifts, and S7 is leaving harmful chemicals unattended and within reach of minors in care may have occurred; however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Alvin Brown.

Three facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. One client was interviewed during the inspection. Personnel files are located at ROP Corporate Office located at 400 N. Tustin Ave. Suit #120. Santa Ana, CA 92705. At 1:15 PM, LPA met with Director, Dana Centanni. LPA reviewed sample of five of ten staff files. The five staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulations requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. On September 09, 2021, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Jesus Cervantes continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on September 07, 2021. LPA met with Facility Director, Dana Centanni at the ROP Corporate Office located at 400 N. Tustin Ave. Suit #120. Santa Ana, CA 92705 . Licensee obtained their Mental Health (MH) Certification on May 17, 2021 and it expires on May 17, 2022. Licensee obtained National Accreditation through CARF and the accreditation is valid through August 31, 2022. Licensee has received a Medi-Cal approval through March 24, 2022. Licensing fee payments are current. At 9:15 AM, LPA reviewed sample of the five of ten remaining staff files. All files did not contain the necessary documents per Title 22 Regulations and ILS. Technical Advisory notes were issued for the following: One of ten staff did not have a health screening as specified in Section 80065(g) as per California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80066(a)(10). Three of ten staff file did not contain the following information: (11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g) as per CCR 80066(a)(11). Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging the child abuse reporting requirements. At 3:00 PM, LPA returned to the facility to complete client interviews. LPA interviewed two additional clients. Overall, three of six clients were interviewed during the annual inspection. Technical Advisory notes were issued and no citations at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and LIC 9102 AT were reviewed and given to House Manager Diana Bustamante.

On September 7, 2021, at 10:15 AM, an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Jesus Cervantes. LPA met with House Manager, Diana Bustamante and Program Director Dana Centanni. LPA inspected the facility inside and out. There are currently six residents in placement. One resident is on AWOL status. Two clients were present at the facility, three clients were at school. Two staff members were present at the facility. A physical plant inspection was conducted at 10:25 AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Games were observed for children’s recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order and fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. The exterior of facility was also inspected and observed to be clean and the landscape well maintained. There is no swimming pool or other body of water located on the facility grounds. Cleaning solutions and hazardous items were observed to be stored in a locked cabinet inside of the garage and in a locked cabinet inside of the laundry room. Sharp knives were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet inside of the staff's office. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet inside of the staff's office. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by House Manager, Diana Bustamante. There are three bedrooms and one bathroom for the residents. The bedrooms are set up so that there are two residents to a bedroom and one resident per bed. There is adequate drawer space for the resident's belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 11:14 AM, the hot water in the resident’s bathroom was registered to be 114.4 degrees

Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. During time of inspection, LPA interviewed two of two staff. Due to the need to conduct staff/client interviews, and continue staff/client file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Director, Dana Centanni.

Confidential interviews revealed that whenever the staff are made aware that a client may be in possession of drugs or under the influence of drugs the staff performs a room search, and the incident is reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL). Confidential interviews revealed that there was a wax pen given to staff that was reported to belong to C1. Staff completed a search of C1’s room and did not find any other drug paraphernalia. Additional confidential interviews stated that C2 advised C1 how to sneak drug paraphernalia into the facility. It is unclear how the drug paraphernalia was brought to the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that Minor in possession of drug paraphernalia may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and Appeals Rights were provided and explained to Sylvia Arballo, Compliance Manager.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres conducted a case management inspection July 26, 2022 at 9:09 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 11 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 26, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA David Torres observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Rabah Mahmoud, Administrator.

out the UIR and the report was not sent to the Probation Officer and CCL within the allotted time frame. investigation_findings: 13On April 18, 2023, at 2:30 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Reyna Salas of ROP/Paragon to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA reviewed the following documents: Special Incident Reports, Placentia Police Department Incident Reports/CAD calls, and Special Incident Reports sent to C1’s Probation Officer. On 01/20/2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the Facility did not report Unusual Incident Reports (URI). Confidential interviews and record review indicated that the facility did not report reportable incidents on 01/05/2023, 01/10/2023, and 01/11/2023 involving C1. Regarding the incident on 01/05/2023, confidential interviews revealed there was a miscommunication regarding who was to send ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

deficiencies.description:
80061(b)(E) Upon the occurrence…of any of the events specified...below…any unusual incident or client absence….a report shall be made…within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours...a written report…shall be submitted...within seven days...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility did not report reportable incidents on 01/05/2023, 01/10/2023, and 01/11/2023 within the agency’s next working day within its normal business hours and an Unusual Incident Report was not sent to the Department within seven days for the incident on 01/05/2023, which posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per the Administrator, an email notification of reportable incidents will be sent to cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov by the next business day within business hours.
