Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced collateral tele visit on 2/8/21 at 3:00 PM with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. This tele visit was conducted with Tracy at the administrative site located at 2560 Business Parkway, Minden Ca. LPA made this announced collateral tele visit to discuss an incident report dated 1/30/21 involving C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 2/8/21) and S1, S2, S3 and S4 (see LIC811 dated 2/8/21). The incident report details an assault by a client on a staff in the facility on 1/30/21. The incident report details that C1 and C2 assaulted S1 in an attempt to get contraband back from staff. LPA discussed with Ms. Edwards that when submitting the 24 hour reports, those need to be more detailed and give the LPA reviewing the report a good idea of what transpired in the facility. The report submitted was very vague and only stated that law enforcement was contacted due to the physical nature of the incident. The full report detailed the scope of the incident to be about a staff assault. LPA also discussed with Ms. Edwards that the incident reports are to be provided to the Department in one report per incident. The reports sent regarding this incident were multiple in that there were individual staff reports, a report written by the Case Manager and a law enforcement contact incident report. LPA advised that this is too many reports and that the final report to Licensing should only be one report covering what happened and not the individual staff perspective. In addition, LPA advised that when law enforcement is involved, one report on the LIC624-LE is required to be submitted to the Department. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that should additional room be needed to add the necessary detail to the report, the facility may attach additional pages to the report but that additional reports are not necessary. LPA did advise Ms. Edwards that further investigation is needed regarding this incident and that while Licensing is investigating, there should not be additional internal investigation for this incident. Exit interview conducted and document provided via email for signature and return. End of document.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection visit with Peter Woods, Assistant Administrator on 3/5/21 at 11:00 AM to discuss the findings of the investigation related to an incident that took place on 1/30/21 at the facility involving law enforcement. This incident was self reported by the facility. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that this inspection will conclude the investigation initiated 2/8/21 which included interviews with staff S1, S2, S3, S4 and S5 (see LIC811 dated 2/22/21) and youth C1, C2, C3, C4 and C5 from 2/8/21 through 2/17/21. The incident being investigated happened on 1/30/21 where evidence supports that S1 conducted an unreasonable search of C1's personal belongings resulting in an assault of S1 by C1. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns that need to be addressed as they affect the health and safety or personal rights of the youth in the facility. Some of the concerns discussed during the inspection are: Ratio - the facility did not have the required staff to client ratios required. Searches - investigation shows that the search of C1's personal property was an unwarranted search. Check-ins - Per the discussion with the administrator, staff should be checking in with staff present when arriving for shifts. Investigation shows that this did not happen when S5 arrived to the facility for S5's shift on 1/30/21. Follow up - following serious incidents, the facility should conduct reviews and debrief of incidents with the staff present to ensure that everyone acted appropriately or to see if the facility could do something different or better to mitigate incidents in the future.

Video Footage - LPA reviewed video footage of the incident during the investigation which supports the concerns related to ratios, searches, staff check-ins, follow up of incidents when they occur. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the facility is being cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards 87065.5(a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. Review of the video camera footage, statements from the staff and youth present at the facility, S1 was alone with the youth for approximately 30 minutes which is a direct violation of the standards. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the facility is being cited for Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards 87072(d) Personal Rights as Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9(a) which provides youth with the right to be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. Investigation shows that the search conducted of C1's property was an unreasonable search. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80065(a) Personnel Requirements. Facility personnel shall be competent to provide the services necessary to meet individual client needs. Based on review of video footage and interviews conducted, S5 did not check in with S1 upon arrival to the facility and thus was not aware of the crisis happening in the facility. S1 and S2 did request that S5 contact for additional support and law enforcement more than three times. The response from S5 was "You don't have to yell at me!" rather than calling for support as needed. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documents were provided via email for signature and return. End of report.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection to the administrative offices for Rite of Passage on 8/17/21 at 1:30 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss incident reports received for this facility. The first incident discussed with Ms. Edwards is related to a report dated 7/2/21 involving C1 and S1 (see LIC811 dated 8/17/21). The incident took place at a swimming outing at Carson Valley Swim Center where S1 left their cell phone and facility vehicle keys unattended where C1 had access. C1 stole the facility vehicle and S1's phone and left the swim center. C1 was stopped by law enforcement and taken to juvenile hall. When questioned about staff discipline as a result of leaving items accessible to youth, Ms. Edwards states that there was a conversation with staff but that nothing was documented in S1's file. Ms. Edwards states that she is conducting a training with all staff regarding vehicles and will add this into the training already scheduled for 8/18/21 and shall provide proof to Licensing upon completion. The other two incidents, 7/2/21 and 7/3/21, were provided to Ms. Edwards as more informational in that additional informed was needed to be complete incidents. LPA explained that the incident reports should have a clear picture of the events leading up to, what happened during, and the resolution of/or the consequence(s) given to the youth/staff as a result of the incident(s). LPA also instructed Ms. Edwards that the incident reports should have all youth involved in the incident named in the report so as to have a clear picture of the events. No citations issued and exit interview conducted.

As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the complaint is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80087(a): Buildings and Grounds. Interview conducted demonstrated that staff knew about the trash but did not clean it up for approximately two hours. Exit interview was conducted and documents provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection at the facility on 8/17/21 at 10:30 AM but nobody was home. LPA then went to the administrative/nonpublic school location in Minden, Nevada and met with the administrator, Tracy Edwards. Interview with S1 (see LIC811 dated 8/17/21) on 8/17/21 demonstrates that S2 was aware of a bear leaving the property about 6:30 AM after having accessed the trash bins and caused the trash to be strung out in front of the facility and across the street. S1 states they received a text from S2 stating C1 (who is no longer residing in the facility) had taken out the trash the night prior as part of their chore and had not secured the trash bin as required to prevent wildlife from accessing the trash bin. S2 told S1 that C1 needed to clean up the trash themselves as they were at fault for it being left accessible to the bear. S2, being the newer staff, did not clean up the mess left behind by the bear until C1 woke up and was taken outside to clean up the mess, two hours later. Administrator arrived to the facility at approximately 9:30 AM to find S1 and C1 outside cleaning up the mess left by the bear, including the trash that was taken across the street.

deficiencies.description: Buildings and Grounds. The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This was not met as evidenced by Staff did not ensure that outdoor trash container was securely locked resulting in a bear gaining access on 8/8/21. The bear left trash strewn about the front of the facility and across the street. Staff waited approximately two hours before cleaning up the mess which poses a potential risk to the health, safety or personal rights to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility administrator states the corrective action plan shall be to have day and night staff check the trash bin to ensure that it is properly secured to prevent wildlife from accessing the bin. Written proof of correction, to include training on a new procedure and log, shall be sent to Licensing by the POC indicated.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 11/30/21 at 11:40 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Manager, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Hill conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection due to school. LPA observed three, dual occupancy client bedrooms, two bathrooms, and one staff room during the inspection. LPA Hill inspected and/or reviewed the following: Postings of facility license, Personal Rights Poster Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible Refrigerator Temperature was at or below 45 degrees F and Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees Nonperishable Foods for one week and fresh perishable for foods two days minimum were present Menu was present and posted Working telephone was present Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were functioning First Aid Kit was present and had all required components Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room for relaxing Dining area with enough seating was present and in good condition Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible LPA observed a locked staff office/sleeping area. All documentation and equipment in the staff room is locked as is the staff room. Hot Water was between 105 -120 degree F Fire Extinguisher was observed to be last inspected on 2/15/21 Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures appeared to be in good repair, no leaks and delivering hot water. LPA observed there to be soap and paper towels available in the bathrooms.

Laundry Facilities were available and LPA observed posted assigned washing days for clients. Bedrooms appeared to be clean and organized with required linen and furnishings Motor Vehicle was observed to have working seat belts, lights and adequate tires. Facility appeared to be free of vermin LPA observed no citations during the physical plant inspection. LPA arrived to the Minden, Nevada school site location to conduct interviews with staff and clients. LPA was not able to complete the staff and client file reviews during the inspection but will return on another date to complete the file reviews as required. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided to Ms. Edwards.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 5/16/22 at 11:00 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill made this visit to the Administrative office location in Minden, Nevada as the youth were already on site at this location in attendance at school. LPA Hill made the visit today to discuss the following incidents and obtain documentation related: * 1/3/22 C1 disclosed that they had some medical concerns that C1 wanted to be tested for and when further pressed, C1 disclosed an incident that had occurred between C1 and a youth from another facility. C1 disclosed that the youth from the other facility was able to gain entry into this facility undetected on 12/22/21 and youth was able to leave the facility undetected as well. C1 further disclosed that the youth returned again to this facility on 12/23/21 and was able to gain undetected entry into the facility. The other youth overheard a staff from their facility discussing youth's absence with staff from this facility and left the facility undetected but went to the front door to be let in due to the snow and cold temperatures. Law enforcement was contacted. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that further investigation is needed regarding the staff actions on these two days. * 4/26/22 C1 was found to have allowed another youth from the other facility into the facility in the early morning of 4/26/22. The other youth was found in the bed with C1 at 4:00 AM. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that further investigation is needed regarding the staff actions on this date. Exit interview conducted and document was provided via email.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 9/1/22 at 1:30 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill made this visit to the Administrative office location in Minden, Nevada as the youth were already on site at this location in attendance at school. LPA Hill made the visit today to conclude an investigation related to an incident that took place on 4/26/22 in the facility in which a male youth from another facility was able to enter the facility undetected. The male youth was in the facility for a couple of hours without staff knowledge. The initial inspection for this incident was conducted on 5/16/22. This report concludes the incident investigation. On 4/26/22 C1 was found to have allowed another youth from another facility into this facility in the early morning of 4/26/22. The other youth was found in the same bed with C1 at 4:00 AM. Upon further investigation of the incident at this location and the other facility, investigation shows that staff were not performing the bed checks per the company policy in that they were to observe bed checks every 15 minutes and seeing skin. Staff present at the facility on the evening of 4/25/22 to 4/26/22 did not observe that two of the youth in this facility were not in their respective beds or rooms nor did staff investigate further when noticing that there was a "bulge" in the bed covers that later turned out to be a male youth in the bed with C1. The male youth then went out the bedroom window and left this facility and returned to their own facility. Based on the investigation, interviews conducted and incident reports reviewed, staff did not supervise the youth as necessary. As a result of this, the facility was cited for Title 22, California Code of Regulations, General Regulations, 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision as staff failed to supervise youth appropriately on 4/26/22 leading to a male youth being able to enter and be at the facility for approximately four hours. Exit interview was conducted and documents and appeal rights were provided to Ms. Edwards via email.

The allegation that staff did not prohibit youth from smoking on the grounds is related to an incident that took place on June 15, 2022, where an Alpine County Sheriff responded to the facility due to a youth in care running away from the facility. Upon arrival, Sheriff located S1 who informed Sheriff that the other youth from the facility were in the rear of the facility smoking. While S1 was present and supervising youth, Sheriff indicated that S1 made no attempts to direct the youth to stop smoking or extinguish their cigarettes. Sheriff indicated that they told youth to stop smoking and youth complied, but that S1 never told the youth that smoking was prohibited on the grounds of the facility nor did S1 indicate to youth the dangers of smoking for the youth's health or the dangers of fires to the community. LPA Hill made three attempts to contact the overnight awake staff on duty, (S1), on the date of the incident and was unable to interview S1 due to S1's work/sleep hours. LPA Hill interviewed other staff that are familiar with S1 and learned that S1 is not assertive with the youth in care and is not confrontational with youth. Staff stated that S1 would rather take daily points from youth for these types of behaviors/choices rather than confront the youth and counsel them to make better choices. LPA Hill also interviewed youth present and smoking and youth denied S1 telling them that they could not smoke or to put the cigarettes out. Youth further stated that S1 never told them about the dangers in the community, including wildfires. Youth stated that they knew that they were not to smoke but that information came from other staff and not S1. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff did not prohibit youth from smoking on the grounds is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the The “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited for 87087(c) Buildings and Grounds as the licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility. Exit interview was conducted with Mr. Edwards and documents were provided via email.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 10/7/22 at 10:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator for the purposes of delivering findings for the allegation as stated. deficiencies.description: Buildings and Grounds as the licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility. This standard was not met as evidenced by S1 did not make any attempts to direct the youth to stop smoking. S1 further did not tell youth that smoking was prohibited on the grounds nor indicate the dangers of smoking for the youth's health or dangers of fires to the community. deficiencies.plan_of_correction:

Proof of training shall be provided to Licensing by the POC date indicated, 10/28/22.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 11/22/22 at 11:30 AM. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 7/25/23 at 9:45 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Manager. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss an incident that took placed at the facility on 7/10/23, in which C1 (see LIC811 dated 7/25/23) was removed from the facility by local law enforcement and taken to juvenile hall. The report received by the agency details that there were three staff present when an altercation ensued with C1 being found to be in possession of a weapon and threatening other youth in the house with this weapon. Law enforcement was called and when C1 failed to respond to law enforcement's instruction to put the weapon down, C1 was arrested and taken to juvenile hall. LPA Hill also learned that during this incident, S1 restrained C2 during the original incident with C1 as C2 was instigating the incident with C1 and S1 was attempting to remove C2 from the area where C1 was at. LPA Hill obtained all staffs' written accounts of the incident during the inspection. LPA Hill observed that S1's description of their part in the incident and S1's account of their own behavior is not in align with the policies and procedures of the facility nor an appropriate intervention supported or taught by the agency as S1 detailed that they "pulled [C2] from [their] shirt" so C2 took off their shirt. S1 then "tried to pull [them] from [their] bra" and C2 then took off one side of their bra. S1 then grabbed C2 by the waist to pull them from the room without being able to get C2 out of the room. S1 then "pushed [C2] with all [S1's] force" to get C2 out of the room. S1 resigned their position with the agency. When interviewed, Ms. Edwards states that S1 had already given a resignation notice when this incident took place, but did work for two additional shifts. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that as a result of the investigation into this incident, the facility was cited for 87095.61(a) Documentation and Reporting Requirements because regulations require that each use of manual restraints must be reported to the Department and the child's authorized representative by telephone no later than the next working day following the incident. There is no evidence that a report was submitted for the restraint, regardless of the restraint not being an agency approved restraint.

deficiencies.description: Documentation and Reporting Requirements. Each use of manual restraints must be reported to the Department and the child's authorized representative by telephone no later than the next working day following the incident. A written incident report must be submitted to the Department within seven (7) days which was not met as evidenced by There is no evidence that a report was submitted for the restraint, regardless of the restraint not being an agency approved restraint 3 which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
S1 is no longer working for the agency. 

The facility shall immediately submit the 7/10/23 incident report for C2 detailing the restraint used by S1 and submit this report to Licensing and C2's authorized representative by 7/27/23. The administrator shall provide additional training to the staff regarding incident reporting about the importance of incident reports and requirement to ensure that they are completed appropriately. Plan of correction shall be submitted to Licensing by 8/11/23.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 12/20/23 at 10:30 AM and Monica Guzman, Coach Counselor assisted with the physical plant inspection at the facility. LPA Hill toured the inside of the facility and noted that there are three, dual occupancy client rooms, and one staff room in the facility. All of the client bedrooms have the required furniture and equipment as required. LPA Hill observed that the facility had the required supply of perishable and nonperishable food as required by regulation and that the house was clean and tidy. LPA Hill observed that there is one bathroom accessible to clients in the facility and one staff bathroom. LPA Hill observed that the toilets flushed, showers worked and had hot water, and that the sinks were working and had hot water. LPA Hill observed that the facility had a washer and dryer for laundering of clothing, a dishwasher to sanitize and clean dishes, and that the facility has a den off of the kitchen area for client relaxation and separation for quiet and phone calls. LPA Hill requested that the facility provide the following documents to be updated in the facility file: LIC308, LIC500, LIC610. LPA Hill also reminded the facility that the program statement update is due 2/2/16/24. LPA Hill cited the facility as follows: 87070(c)(2) Children's Records: LPA Hill observed during the review of the records that there are no Removal or Transfer Policy or Discipline Policy signed by the placing agency. 87068.2(f) Needs and Services Plan: LPA Hill observed that the facility is not obtaining the signature of the placing agency on the Needs and Services document or the modifications when this document is updated, changed, or modified. LPA Hill concluded the inspection at the facility and resumed the inspection at the business office located in Minden for review of files and interviews of staff and clients. End of report.

coerced to take medications, even if prescribed by the doctor or psychiatrist. As a result of the confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that youth were pressured to take medications prescribed or authorized is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation regarding a lack of supervision is related to an incident during an outing which lead to a youth being harassed by other youth. During confidential interviews with staff and youth, seven out of eight youth stated that they were "rough-housing" with all of the youth during the outing and staff denied any youth indicating that they felt scared or threatened during the outing or after the outing. LPA Hill attempted contact with two youth identified as being possible witnesses but one is absent from care and their whereabouts are unknown and the other has not responded to requests for interview. During interviews with staff, all staff indicated that there were never reports made and they were not informed that any of the youth felt threatened or were harmed during this outing. As a result of the confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that a lack of supervision lead to youth feeling threatened during an outing is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that staff did not provide a safe environment is related to the staff not being able to provide for youth's safety due to being new or inexperienced. During confidential interviews, youth confirmed that the majority of staff are new and/or lack experience in this field and may be immature. Youth confirmed however they trust the supervision that staff provide and fairness they demonstrate to youth. Confidential interviews indicated youth felt that staff are not perfect but are doing a good job protecting youth during incidents that happen in the facility, redirecting youth prior to physical incidents, supporting youths' mental health goals, trying to get to know youth, and supporting youth's transition goals. Confidential interviews indicated that staff did not always know when youth were going to "go off" thus leading to them not always being prepared. Staff indicated that there have been times when physical interventions have not been utilized when they should have been due to prior staff injuries which has lead to escalated behaviors with youth. As a result of the confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that staff did not provide a safe environment is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred Exit interview was conducted and documents, along with appeal rights were provided.

Seven out of eight youth and six out of six staff interviewed denied being forced, bullied, or

narrative: During confidential interviews, LPA Hill learned that there was "tension in the house" between C1 and C2. Staff in the facility decided to take youth on an outing to give the youth space due to this tension. C2 was on outing restriction due to behaviors but C1 chose not to go on the outing so the on-call staff made the decision to allow C2 to attend to create space for the day. When youth returned from the outing, C2 attacked C1 while C1 was in the den speaking with C3. C4 was present when the fighting started and, knowing that S1 could not intervene, C4 stepped in to assist in separating the youth and protect C1. C2 has a history of assaulting staff and youth since being placed with the agency. The agency's policy on restraints requires two staff to engage in physical restraints. Knowing that S1 could not engage in physical restraints as necessary and knowing C2's assaultive history, the agency did not provide an additional staff on 12/9/23, knowing that there was tension between the youth in the facility. As a result of the investigation and confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in C1 being assaulted by other youth at the facility is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of Title 22 Regulation 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision as the facility has a responsibility to provide care and supervision to meet the clients' needs and the facility did not protect C1's safety while at the facility, despite knowing of the tension between the youth and knowing that staff was unable to engage as necessary in their emergency intervention plan to protect C1 as required. Exit interview conducted and documentation, along with appeal rights were provided.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 2/29/24 at 12:45 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Director to discuss an incident report received by the Department. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the incident report was not clear in the explanation as to why C1 (see LIC811 dated 2/29/24) needed to go to the hospital for medications or due to the lack of medications if medications were refilled at the facility just eight days prior. When LPA Hill inquired about this, LPA Hill was informed that due to the type of medication C1 was taking, insulin, C1 requires this medication to be refilled on a weekly basis. Staff working at the facility failed to inform the administrator that C1 was out of or running low on the necessary medications the week prior to the emergency room visit. The agency now has C1's medications set up in such a manner that the medications are on reorder weekly and should C1 run low on these essential medications, the agency now has access to reorder the medication without having to contact the doctor, causing potential delays. LPA Hill also inquired about a Health Care Plan or other additional medical support and/or documentation necessary per Interim Licensing Standards, 87075.1 Emergency Medical Assistance, Injections, and Self-Administration of Medications for this youth as, given the medical condition of this youth, there is monitoring that is required and specific dietary needs and limitations that the facility inherently agrees to by accepting the youth into their program. LPA Hill also cautioned about the staff training that needs to be documented in the staff training plan and individual staff files per Health and Safety Section 1507.25. LPA Hill obtained a copy of C1's Needs and Services Plan and any other documentation related to C1's health condition and monitoring that is required. No citation were issued and documentation was provided during the inspection.

youth in care are left vulnerable to physical attacks by youth and the agency not proactively addressing these issues for the safety of the other youth in care and staff working at the facility. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the investigation and confidential interviews show that when youth are accepted and have a history of violence, whether against adults or other youth, the facility is not staffing to the need of the youth by having additional staff in the facility until they are better familiar with the youth or ensuring that staff that are properly trained and/or without restrictions or limitations on mobility are present to work with the newly admitted youth. This was evidenced by one incident on 12/9/23 where a youth was attacked in the facility by another youth and one of the two staff present was unable to engage in physical restraints due to a medical restriction. Another incident happened on 11/5/23 where a youth attacked two staff present at the facility, resulting in at least one staff being hurt. There were two additional incidents where the same youth allegedly attacked staff at the nonpublic school site, 12/7/23 and 12/12/23. Confidential interviews revealed that while staff was within ratio at the time of the incident(s), most staff expressed not feeling appropriately trained or comfortable in the emergency intervention training, confronting youth, or preventing incidents from happening. Review of the documentation received related to C1 in particular (see LIC811 dated 2/29/24) indicates that the agency knew or should have known that youth was a risk to the health and safety of the other youth in care and staff as the youth had a history of verbal aggression and physical aggression resulting in violence. In addition, following the initial attack at the facility on 11/5/23, the licensee did not increase staffing at the facility when the agency suspected that situations were escalated, as seen in the 12/9/23 incident. As a result of the information obtained, documentation received, confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that staff do not prevent the minors from engaging in physical altercations is SUBSTANTIATED as the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited under Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards, Personnel Requirements, Section 87065(g) as the licensee shall employ the number of direct care staff necessary to meet the needs of children and provide adequate care and supervision, including staff needing to be able to administer discipline and setting of limits for behavior, consistent with trauma-informed standards. Documentation was provided to NAME and exit interview conducted.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 3/13/24 at 10:20 AM and met with Tracy Edwards and Jim Amaral, Program Directors to discuss client phone calls as a result of recent inquiries and citations related to this issue. LPA Hill advised Ms. Edwards and Mr. Amaral that the privacy and access to calls is an essential part of the personal rights of the youth in care and that any interference in clients' access to the phone is strictly prohibited unless there is a court order indicating that there is a need for this. In addition, any restriction related to access to the phone or issues relating to privacy must be discussed with the placement agency and documented in the Needs and Services Plan. LPA Hill did advise that the agency can use Prudent Parent Standard as it relates to phone calls if youth are exhibiting behaviors that necessitate this need, i.e., a client in care used the phone to contact an individual to come to the facility and pick them up. If the client should then leave on an unauthorized absence, when the client returns to the facility, a natural consequence for inappropriate use of the phone might be to monitor who the client is calling for a set period of time (keeping track of phone numbers dialed), with the placing agency's agreement/approval. The Prudent Parent Standard is not a blanket restriction for the time that the client remains in care of the facility but for a set amount of time, i.e., a week. The discipline for this could be progressive and discussions should be held with the placing agency each time clients break rules or violate policies set by the facility to ensure that the team is in agreement of the consequences established. In addition, the practice of not answering the phone at the facility unless a staff member is alerted or expecting a prearranged call to the facility shall cease. The placing agency, family, and other individuals involved in clients' care have the right to contact the facility to speak to youth in care as needed and this should not have to be prearranged or scheduled. No citations were issued during the inspection today. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Edwards and Mr. Amaral.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 3/25/24 at 3:15 PM and met with Alina Scott, Head of Service to discuss a recent incident report provided to the Department on 3/23/24. The incident reported includes a possible inappropriate sexual interaction between two clients in care. LPA Hill interviewed one youth while at the facility's administrative offices since the clients were in attendance for school. LPA Hill also interviewed Head of Service regarding the incident. Other concerns raised was that one youth admitted to spitting in another youth's food while preparing meals for youth in care. LPA Hill informed Ms. Scott that further investigation is needed at this time and that LPA Hill would return at a later date to complete interviews and investigation. Exit interview conducted and document provided.

C1 was accepted in July 2023, during the time the agency was in the process of changing psychiatrists. The facility did not have a psychiatrist for the months of September 2023 and October 2023. Prior to this transition, C1 did see the psychiatrist 8/3/23 and 8/17/23. While the agency was unable to provide monthly consultation records from a psychiatrist as required for the months of September and October 2023, they were able to provide the Department with proof of active efforts in getting the selected doctor approved from July 2023 through October 2023. The new psychiatrist started in November 2023. C1 was receiving all other mental health services offered by the agency, including individual, family, and group therapy, as well as other mental health services despite not seeing a psychiatrist during the months of September and October. Investigation also showed that C2 was accepted despite knowing C2 had a history of violence. During the six weeks C2 was in placement, from October 2023 to December 2023, there were five incidents of violence, including attacks on staff and other clients in care. Subsequent to each of these incidents, Child and Family Team meetings were called to discuss the issues and how to resolve them. The facility continued to work with the placing agency on C2’s placement until December 2023 when C2 was removed from this agency. Confidential interviews conducted with the HOS and Administrator revealed that when youth are referred for placement, most of them have some kind of violence in their history and as a result, it is not an automatic denial. Administrator states that youth with violent pasts are accepted if they agree to the program and are willing to abide by the program’s expectations and rules. While the facility was within ratio of one staff to three clients during these episodes, staff knew, or should have known, there was a potential for violence and the agency should have augmented staffing in the facility, but this did not happen. During one specific incident on 12/9/23, staff knew that tensions were high between youth in care but one of the staff working was on light duty and unable to restrain or assist in a manual restraint as needed. When an incident did happen between youth in care, staff was unable to physically assist to break the youth up, resulting in another youth in care getting involved and assisting staff to break up the assault. (The facility was cited for this incident and lack of appropriate supervision on 1/26/24). As a result of the investigation, interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation that the facility did not follow their preplacement procedures when assessing youth for placement is SUBSTANTIATED meaning that the “preponderance of evidence” standard has been met. The licensee has a responsibility to augment staffing levels in the facility based on identified needs, behaviors or other factors but this did not happen. The facility was cited per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87065.5(g) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios as the facility shall increase the number of on-duty direct care staff if a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation provided including appeal rights.

Confidential interviews conducted demonstrated that the agency was given a 60-day notice in June 2023 that their current psychiatrist was terminating their contracted psychiatry services as of August 2023. In July 2023, the agency found and began the process of on-boarding a new psychiatrist, but the process was lengthy, and the agency did not have the new psychiatrist on board until November 2023, meaning the youth did not have the required monthly psychiatry appointments for the months of September 2023 and October 2023. The agency was able to provide documentation including emails and correspondence between the agency's HOS, Placer County, the new contracted provider, Health Link Now, and the psychiatrist from July 2023 through November 2023, indicating that the agency was actively trying to get the new psychiatrist through the contract and on-boarding process to provide services to youth in care. In addition, in anticipation of not having the psychiatrist in time, HOS did reach out to Barton Psychiatry in South Lake Tahoe on 8/5/23 but were informed that the wait time would be until January 2024, and Washoe County (Nevada) Behavioral Health but were informed they could not provide services to the agency's youth. HOS presumed it due to the youth being California youth and not from Nevada. The new psychiatrist was providing psychiatry services to youth in care as of November 14, 2023. LPA Hill learned that during the time without psychiatry services, the agency had prepared in advanced and did have prescription refills for all youths' medications and no youth went without medications or had lapses in medications during the months of September or October. As a result of the investigation, interviews conducted, and documentation received, the allegation that the facility did not provide clients in care with consultation from a psychiatrist as required for the months of September and October 2023, is UNSUBSTANTIATED as facility did employ active efforts in locating and on-boarding a replacement psychiatrist during the months of September and October 2023. This means that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that the facility did not ensure client's medical and/or mental health needs were met is related to the same allegation as stated regarding the youth having the required psychiatry consultations prescribed in regulation. When interviewing C1's social worker, it was indicated that all medical and mental health services were provided except for the psychiatry consultations as described. Social worker states that the facility did ensure that youth had consultations with doctor, dentist, and optometry as needed while at the facility and that the agency did ensure that therapy, and other mental health services were being provided during this time. As a result of this information, the allegation that the facility did not ensure medical and/or mental health needs were met is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time as the facility did employ active efforts in locating and on-boarding the new psychiatrist. This means that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation was provided along with appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 3/13/24 at 10:20 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Director to discuss the complaint findings as stated. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection to the agency on 10/27/23 where LPA Hill interviewed Head of Services (HOS) and Administrator and obtained documentation related to the allegations and LPA Hill obtained the agency's approved mental health program plan as approved by the Department of Health Services. Subsequent inspections were conducted on 11/17/23, 12/7/23, 12/20/23, 12/21/23, 1/10/24, and 2/15/24 to interview youth and staff related to the allegations. LPA Hill also interviewed a social workers and public health nurse related to the allegations. The allegation that the facility is not following their preplacement procedures when assessing youth to be accepted is related to the agency's process of assessing youths' compatibility for the facility. The original allegation is related to the accepting of youth knowing that the facility cannot meet the needs of the youths’ mental health needs and specifically the psychiatry needs when admitted.

deficiencies.description: Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios.  If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty direct care staff shall be increased. This is not met as evidenced by While licensee maintained the required ratio in the facility, licensee did not increase staffing to meet the identified behaviors for C2, knowing C2 was a risk to the health and safety of the staff and other youth in care which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Immediate health and safety concerns were alleviated with C2 being removed 12/13/23. 

The facility shall submit a written policy indicating a change in the reporting of the house behaviors and how things are going on a daily basis. This written policy shall explain how it directly correlates to the development of the staffing plan in the facility to meet the needs of the youth in care. 

The written policy shall be provided to Licensing by 4/5/24.

narrative:
Plan or treatment plan to C1’s placing agency, but they were unable to provide proof that this happened. LPA Hill then questioned the agency about implementation of the Needs and Services Plan as the regulations require that a signature be obtained as evidence that the placement agency agrees prior to implementation and the administrator and Head of Service both indicated that the needs of C1 and treatment for C1 was discussed on multiple occasions as C1 had high needs. The facility/agency did acknowledge that C1’s soothing plan was provided to the placing agency. As a result of the interviews conducted and documentation obtained and reviewed, the allegation that staff did not follow youth’s treatment plan is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Section 87068.2(g) Needs and Services Plan as the licensee shall obtain written approval from the child...and the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan. The allegation that staff speak inappropriately to youth in care is related to staff not using Trauma-Informed language when speaking with youth in the facility. Confidential interviews with staff and clients indicated that some staff would say things in a demanding tone, were rude, and argued with clients or would tell youth that they were staff, they could get away with speaking to youth in this manner or in other ways penalize youth in care for speaking up for themselves. As a result of the investigation and confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that staff speak inappropriately to youth in care is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Section 80072(c)(1) Personal Rights as the licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 including the right to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. Continued on LIC9099C.

The allegation that youth are unable to make private phone calls is related to the youth not being able to make calls to whomever they choose, staff listening to calls, and youth overall not having privacy during calls. During confidential interviews with youth and staff in care, it was noted that youth are not allowed to have confidential calls in that all calls must be done in the facility den, with the door open, and some staff sit at the doorway and listen to the calls, regardless of who youth is speaking to on the phone. At the conclusion of the interviews with staff and clients on 11/17/23, LPA Hill informed the agency that this practice shall cease immediately and informed the staff and agency that youth have the right to call who they want unless there is a court order restricting their calls. In addition, LPA Hill advised the agency that staff cannot monitor the calls, listen to the calls, be in the room with youth while making calls, log their phone calls, write down the phone numbers of calls made or in any way question youth about who they were calling during the designated call time allotted to youth. LPA Hill did confirm during follow up inspections and interviews that the staff are no longer monitoring youths’ calls and that the phone policy is changed so that youth are afforded privacy during calls. While the alleged violation has been remedied, it was true at the time that the initial complaint investigation was filed. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, the allegation that youth are unable to make private phone calls is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Section 80072(c)(1) Personal Rights as the licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 including the right to To make, send, and receive confidential telephone calls...unless prohibited by court order. While this allegation was remedied immediately, it still was a violation at the time the complaint was filed. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation including appeal rights were provided.

narrative: facility where C1 was restrained following an assault on two staff. The agency initially reported a different length of time for the restraint than what was reported on the final incident report. The discrepancy created some confusion regarding the agency policy and restraints provided but was later clarified. Another incident that took place on 12/7/23 between C1 and S1 was reported as an unnecessary restraint in that C1 was restrained for coloring on a wall. During interviews conducted, it was reported that C1 had put their hands on S1 during a confrontation about coloring on the wall and in return, S1 put C1 in a restraint of C1’s hands until another staff walked in. S1 denies placing C1 in a full restraint. LPA Hill attempted to interview C1 about this incident but C1 refused an interview twice. As a result of the confidential interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation that staff conduct inappropriate restraints is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that youth is being sexually harassed is related to reports that C2 thought that new youths newly admitted were automatically dating them. C1 reported feeling uneasy about C2 coming into their room even for benign reasons, and C2 told other youth in the facility that they were dating C1. Youth in the facility reported that youth were uncomfortable around C1 to the point that the facility eventually put C2 in a room by themselves to help with this situation. While staff and clients knew about C2 tendency to approach all newly admitted youth and attempts to be romantically involved, there was no evidence that any youth in the home felt sexually harassed. As a result of the information obtained and confidential interviews conducted, the allegation that youth are being sexually harassed is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Scott and documentation, including appeal rights were provided.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced case management inspection to the administrative offices for Rite of Passage in Minden, NV to meet with Tracy Edwards, Program Director to discuss the following issues: LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the inspection is related to the follow up on an incident involving C1 (see LIC811 dated 4/10/24) spitting in other youths' food while at the facility and/or putting chemicals used in the cleaning of the facility in the youths' foods. During confidential interviews, it was revealed that during the evening program in the house with the youth, staff usually are busy trying to get chores completed, complete paperwork necessary for the shift, supervising youth, allowing phone calls, etc. and that in doing all of these things, are not constantly supervising youth in the kitchen. It was reported that it is normal to have two staff on the PM shift and that in having these two staff, one is usually doing paperwork while seated at the computer desk in the living room and the other is either upstairs supervising youth, in the den, assisting with chores, or other tasks that leave the youth frequently unsupervised in the kitchen while preparing dinner for the youth in the house. In addition, staff and youth interviews concluded that chemicals used in the cleaning of the facility are usually taken out and left accessible to youth in care until the end of the PM shift or until all chores are completed making them accessible to put in youths' food. As a result of the investigation, interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, it is the conclusion of CCL that the facility has demonstrated a lack of supervision that allowed these incident(s) to happen. The facility was cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, General Licensing Standards, Section 80087(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision as the licensee shall provide care and supervision that meets the needs of the clients in care. Due to a repeat violation within 12 months, an immediate civil penalty is assessed in the amount of $250 and $100 per day until the violation is corrected. See LIC421 FC.

In addition, during the investigation of these incident(s), it has come to Licensing's attention that staff were aware of some inappropriate activities happening in the facility including some of the youth exposing their buttocks while in the facility and outside of the facility during walks, youth inappropriately hitting other youth on the buttocks, in the chest area, etc. While some of these incidents were reported to Licensing, LPA Hill did find incidents regarding C3 and C4 that were not reported to Licensing as required. As a result of these incident(s) not being reported as required, the facility was cited for not reporting per per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, General Licensing Standards, Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation provided, along with appeal rights.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This was not met as evidenced by Investigation demonstrated that staff were not supervising youth during food preparation in the facility leading to a youth spitting in and/or putting chemicals in youths' food without staff knowledge which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility shall provide a memo to all staff about the expectations of the PM program to include moving as a group, meaning that each activity on the PM program requires that all youth to supervised at all times and in all activities including meal preparation, showers, chores, and other elements of the PM program. These expectations shall be communicated to the youth in the program and written policy posted in the facility. 

This memo shall be provided to Licensing by COB 4/11/24.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence...of any of the events specified...a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This was not met as evidenced by It was reported that youth were exposing their buttocks in public and to other youth in care and the faciltiy did not report these incident(s) to Licensing as required which poses an potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The facility just completed Reporting Requirements for all staff on 4/3/24. Administrator shall provide the training to CCL and proof of staff attendance at that training by the POC date indicated. 

In addition the facility shall provide the incident reports not sent which include the dates of 2/24/24 and 3/6/24 and/or 3/8/24.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 5/1/24 at 10:00 AM at the agency's administrative site and met with MacKenzie DeBoer, Case Manger to discuss an incident report dated 4/27/24. LPA Hill explained that the inspection was to discuss C1's (see LIC811 dated 5/1/24) unauthorized absence from the program, property destruction, and subsequent return on 4/27/24. LPA Hill observed that the incident report indicates that C1 was able to return "undetected" and was in their room, without staff knowledge, when law enforcement arrived on site to conduct a visual of the damages caused by C1. LPA Hill attempted to interview C1 but they are not currently at the facility as C1 attends an all day off-site educational/vocational schooling Tuesday through Saturday. LPA Hill informed Ms. DeBoer that an interview may be scheduled for later this same day, when C1 returns from the program. S1 was also not available for interview today as S1's shift does not start until 1:00 PM today. Jim Amaral, Program Director was not available for interview today due to another youth's CFT being conducted off site. LPA Hill did obtain an additional description of S1's details of the incident and LPA Hill requested that the camera footage showing C1's return to be provided to LPA Hill today. Exit interview conducted and document was provided to Ms. DeBoer.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 11/25/24 at 10:50 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator, to discuss an incident report. LPA Hill met Ms. Edwards to discuss the incident dated 9/25/24 which details inappropriate contact between C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 10/25/24). Discussed during the inspection was that the agency conducted an internal investigation regarding the inappropriate contact. The Program Statement/Plan of Operation approved by the Department details that the agency investigates alleged inappropriate sexual contact following the PREA, Prison Rape Elimination Act, guidelines which is a zero tolerance policy for sexual abuse, sexual harassment, or unauthorized relationship between clients served by the facility. The agency initiated their internal investigation on 9/26/24 and concluded the investigation on 10/1/24, per their written guidelines. The investigation resulted in one youth moving facilities and the other being placed on a behavior contract due to the unauthorized/unwelcome contact. The agency followed their guidelines and did take appropriate action upon this incident being reported. As a result of the agency doing their due diligence, no citations were issued and no further investigation is needed at this time. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 12/10/24 at 10:10 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Administrator, to conduct the physical plant inspection of the facility as part of the annual inspection. LPA Hill observed that the facility has three dual occupancy bedrooms upstairs for clients in care but each of the youth currently are not sharing bedrooms with other youth. LPA Hill observed that the facility was clean, safe and sanitary during the annual inspection. LPA Hill observed that the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were functioning as required. Fire extinguishers were last inspected 1/23/24. LPA Hill observed one client restroom upstairs that had running hot water, paper towels, flushing toilets, and a shower that delivered hot water. The other restroom is downstairs and is for staff. LPA Hill observed that the client bedrooms were supplied with proper bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheets, blankets, pillows, closet space, and storage for belongings. LPA Hill observed that the facility had two days perishable food supply and seven days nonperishable food supply appropriate for the youth in care and had appropriate cook ware and dining supplies. LPA Hill observed that the facility was safe for youth, inside and out. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the client interviews were going to be conducted at the agency administrative offices as well as file reviews. LPA Hill conducted two interviews of youth during the annual inspection at the administrative site. One client refused to be interviewed. Document was provided to Ms. Edwards and exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced inspection to the agency on 12/20/24 and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill made the inspection on this date to discuss with the agency changes in the intake procedures for the better assessment of youth being admitted into the facility and how the agency is looking to lower the incidents of calling on law enforcement partners. LPA Hill discussed that calls for law enforcement services has risen in comparison to previous years and requested that the agency provide a written assessment and training plan to address this rise in calls. LPA Hill is requesting that the agency assess how they can work with staff and agency management to mitigate the need for these calls. LPA Hill advised that it is imperative that the agency try to work with staff and local partners to reduce these calls for service. LPA Hill requested that the agency provide updated written intake procedures, update of the Neighborhood Complaint Procedures, and any/all procedures on how staff and management can mitigate the calls for service to Law Enforcement partners in the community. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 1/7/25 at 10:45 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the purpose of the inspection was to discuss a serious law enforcement contact incident report that occurred on 12/30/24. The initial incident report was provided to the Department on 12/30/24. This incident resulted in the removal of two clients in care, C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 1/7/25). LPA Hill interviewed S2 who arrived after the incident had begun and after law enforcement was already on site at the facility. LPA Hill did obtain documentation for both youth while at the agency, including youths' Needs and Services Plans, Intake Assessments, and any risk assessments conducted upon placement for both youth. Placement was terminated for both youth at the time of their removal on 12/30/24. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that this incident report needs further investigation at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation was provided.

August 2024, not all youth were immediately assigned to the new therapist, S2. When it was finally decided to assign all youth to S2 and begin their transition, S2 noted that there were three to four weeks' of missing or undone therapy documentation to facilitate this change in therapists. S2 noted that in discussing this with the agency's management, S2 was directed to "start new" with all of the youth being added to S2's caseload, which was about half of all the youth they had in care at that time. S2 indicates that this meant going back and completing documents for all youth as if they were brand new, even if they had been in care for some time, as there were incomplete and/or undone documented therapy notes. Subsequent interviews with other agency personnel indicates that the agency will not be returning S1 to their employment position within the agency. As a result of interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation that staff did not ensure that youth are provided mental health services is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility cited for Interim Licensing Standards for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Programs, regulation 87072(d): Personal Rights. Youth have the right to access and receive medical...mental health, and substance use disorder services...with reasonable promptness that meets the needs of the child...Confidential interviews conducted with staff and youth in care indicate that youth were without mental health services, specifically therapy sessions, for three to four weeks. Further interviews indicate when therapy sessions did resume for youth in care, there were therapy session notes not documented as required by the previous therapist for a reported period of up to four weeks. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Edwards.
