During the course of the investigation, LPA Hill also interviewed youths' social workers. The allegation that staff did not ensure that youth are provided mental health services is related to the youth in care not being provided therapy as dictated in the agency's program statement. While the documentation provided indicates that some youth were seeing the previous therapist, S1, who went out on leave in

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. Youth have the right to access and receive medical...mental health, and substance use disorder services...with reasonable promptness that meets the needs of the child...This is not met as evidenced by: Based on investigation conducted, youth did not have mental health services, specifically therapy sessions, for three to four weeks due to a therapist being out on leave. When therapy sessions did resume for youth in care, there were therapy session notes not documented as required by the previous therapist which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The agency is recruiting to hire an additional therapist and will ensure that no youth will have a break in therapy. In addition, the agency has a designated Quality Insurance staff person that ensures that weekly reports are run to ensure that the timeframes related to documentation are met as required. Administrator shall provide an email confirmation of this as proof to ensure that future violations of the same nature do not happen.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 2/5/25 at 1:30 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator, to discuss the following issues: Cell phone policy. Cell phone policy includes discussions with youth during their Child & Family Team Meetings ensuring the policy is individualized for each youth in the program. When granted, youth must agree to usage policy including not having the phone until schooling, groups, and chores are done. Calling on law enforcement. The agency says they wait 30 minutes after losing sight of youth prior to calling law enforcement to assist, but there are exceptions such as when youth are seen getting into a vehicle or if youth are assessed to be at risk then they call immediately. Educating community partners for youth. LPA discussed how the agency is working and educating community partners about youth in their facilities. Ms. Edwards states they have not had an open of communication to bridge this gap, but is open to productive dialogue in hopes of forming working partnerships for the betterment of the youth served. Ms. Edwards states the agency is open to building a foundation of support within the community to ensure the safety and acceptance of the youth served. Discharge of youth following serious incidents. Ms. Edwards states that if a child has left the facility via law enforcement, they immediately contact the placing county to alert of what has transpired. If a client is deemed unable to return due to Health and Safety concerns with other youth, this is communicated to the placing county. Ms. Edwards reiterated that according to the regulations, they are able to make that determination if they feel it is unsafe for a youth to return to the facility and they make every effort to ensure the placing county is aware of the determination. Reimbursement for Services. LPA Hill spoke to Ms. Edwards about the communication related to unpaid or outstanding services for expenditures by the home county. Ms. Edwards states they have not received any communication from the county about any outstanding expenditures. Ms. Edwards indicated if they do get notification for any outstanding or unpaid expenses, they forward communications to the placing county where those expenditures are taken care of.

Night Staffing Solutions. Ms. Edwards states that they are working on solution(s) to ensure situations involving youth during the hours of 10:00 PM to 6:00 AM are handled internally. Ms. Edwards hopes to provide viable solutions in the weeks to come. Agency wants to ensure they are following regulations set by statute but also understands the resource limitation. Youth Refuse to Return. Ms. Edwards asked about what happens if youth are walking away from the facility and are refusing to return to the facility despite staff following. Ms. Edwards states they continue to follow and provide support to youth but do not call law enforcement for assistance if they are with the youth or have the youth in sight. They continue to walk with youth and give them time to de-escalate. Should law enforcement happen on scene, they try to get youth to return with staff. Ms. Edwards states staff try to talk to youth while walking, giving support, and ask youth what they need in the moment. Ms. Edwards states they just sometimes need to walk until they are ready to return. There have been situations where youth request to go to juvenile hall refusing to return so some agencies oblige youth as many are in violation of their probation by leaving without authorization. Interventions. Ms. Edwards states they are constantly speaking with youth in an attempt to get them to stay and not leave the facility. Facility staff engage with youth, remind them of the program and goals, follow them so the facility does not have to report them in violation to their placement agencies. Ms. Edwards states a training is planned that would include Managing Runaway Behavior where staff are trained on immediate interventions to de-escalate situations in an attempt to get youth to stay. Collaboration Meeting. Ms. Edwards states the agency is open to working on communication and collaboration with the local law enforcement and Probation Department to provide information about youth served and how better to collaborate and work together on a community solution to issues and solutions that would serve the community while assisting the agency in serving the youth in care. Ms. Edwards states they would greatly appreciate CCL's assistance and attendance to initiate this process with the local law enforcement. Ms. Edwards states the agency is open to bridging gaps in the community and finding viable solutions including bridging gaps in communication and collaboration in all of these identified areas. LPA Hill did request that the agency supply a cell phone policy discussed during this inspection. No citations were issued during this inspection and this document was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 2/18/25 at 10:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill conducted the inspection to provide findings related to an incident that took place at the facility on 12/30/24 in which C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 2/18/25) assaulted S1, were involved in property destruction and theft of staff's personal belongings resulting in S1 being unable to contact law enforcement or other staff for assistance in managing criminal behaviors of youth in care. The end result of this incident being C1 and C2 were arrested and charged with multiple crimes. Confidential interviews with staff about the state of the house included staff understood youth were hyper, but neither S1 or S2 thought things in the house would escalate as they did the evening of 12/29/24 into the early morning hours of 12/30/24. In discussing the incident with staff, information provided that youth were escalated, but were starting to calm down prior to S2 leaving the evening of 12/29/24. Shortly after S2 left, S1 and S2 were texting about youths' behaviors for over an hour, but S1 did not respond to S2's final text message. S2 did not notify anyone of S1's silence and learned of the reason for S1's lack of response in the morning hours of 12/30/24. As a result of C1 and C2's destruction in the facility, assault and threat to S1's safety and life, C1 and C2 were arrested and immediately removed from the agency and prohibited from returning to the facility. As a result of this incident, the staff stated they are hyper vigilant now with the youth and have a deeper understanding of their role and dangers in working with the vulnerable youth. The agency is acutely aware of the need of the youth and are staffing the facility according to the heightened need, including having additional staff in the house as needed, having additional on-call staff, and having a roaming supervisor to assist in either facility as needed on each shift.

While the agency was staffed below the required ratio as they only had three youth in the facility during the overnight shift, they did underestimate this situation and vulnerability of the staff. Further review of incidents and interviews with staff indicated that S1 had been struggling with supervision of C1 and C2 in the facility since at least early December 2024 but did not request additional support nor did the agency recognize the need for additional staffing until after this serious incident. LPA Hill discussed with Ms. Edwards possibly implementing a plan of evaluation of direct care staff (coach counselors) by senior coach counselors to ensure staff are meeting expectations and additional training and/or counseling can be provided prior to encountering a serious incident such as this again. Administrator states they have provided all soothing plans to be in hard copy form and in the houses for all staff to review. This would help the staff who are not familiar with new youth or even existing youth and changes to their soothing plans. The plan includes student triggers and coping skills as identified by the youth in care and worked out by their therapist. LPA Hill issued a Technical Advisory (LIC9102 AN). Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation was provided.

A meeting was held via Microsoft Teams on 2/19/25 at 1:00 PM with representatives of Community Care Licensing, including Angela Carmack, Assistant Program Administrator, Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, and Tamara Hill, Licensing Program Analyst, and representatives of Rite of Passage (ROP) Qualifying Houses, Lawrence Howell, Executive Director, Rebekah Graham, Regional Director, Jerry Crandall, National Compliance Director, and Tracy Edwards, Administrator. This meeting is being held to collaborate solutions for ongoing community grievances regarding ROP's operation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Facilities in Alpine County. During this meeting, the following items were discussed: Alpine County District Attorney Public Nuisance - Community Care Licensing did advise the agency of Alpine County's intent to file public nuisance charges against ROP due to the number of calls for services in the county and the limited resources available to assist ROP with these calls. Management and Operations of ROP - The county's concerns for the types of children being accepted at the facility and officers walking into the facilities without knowing what they may encounter. The county was educated on the acuity of youth placed in the facilities and discussed with ROP is what the agency can do to provide collaboration with the county to mitigate some of the calls even follow up after calls. Overnight Staffing and Alternative Plans of Supervision - ROP discussed plans including floater staff between houses, additional overnight staff staying in a facility when youth exhibit escalated behaviors. Law Enforcement Meetings with ROP - The agency is open to collaborative meetings and additional collaboration and follow-up discussions following law enforcement contacts. Ambulance Billing - If CCL gathers information related to any unresolved fiscal responsibilities as indicated by Alpine County, this information will be passed along to ROP for resolution. Next steps will be for CCL to communicate with Alpine County to garner dates to be distributed for a meeting between CCL, Alpine County and ROP. End of meeting.

S1 was placed on administrative leave on 3/4/25 and terminated 3/7/25, following an internal investigation. S1 did not provide a written response on the Disciplinary Action and termination documents provided at the time of their dismissal. LPA Hill attempted to interview S1 during the course of this investigation but S1 did not respond to the LPA's requests for interview. LPA Hill did observe that the facility did not report this incident to the placing county, local Child Protective Services, or Community Care Licensing. Based on review of the documentation obtained, the allegation that staff provided marijuana and/or vaping devices to youth in care and that staff's behavior poses a risk to minors is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the "preponderance of the evidence standard" has been met. The facility was cited for violation of Health and Safety 1558(a) Conduct Inimical as S1 engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of the clients living in, or receiving services from, the facility by providing a vaping device to youth in care. In addition, LPA Hill cited the agency for failure to report the incident per Title 22 Regulations Section 80061(b)(1)(E) as the agency did not provide the 24 hour report or the seven day written report as required by this regulation. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided to Ms. Edwards along with appeal rights. End of documentation.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced complaint inspection on 7/23/25 at 9:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill conducted an initial complaint investigation on 6/26/25 and a subsequent inspection was conducted on 7/17/25 to interview staff and 7/21/25 and 7/23/25 to interview youth. The allegations that staff are providing access to marijuana and vaping devices to youth in care and staff behavior poses a risk to minors is related to a disclosure made by a youth in care that S1 (see LIC811 dated 7/23/25) provided marijuana and/or vaping device to minors. LPA Hill obtained documentation related to S1's termination of employment that details S1 was terminated due to providing vaping devices to youth in care. The incident details that S1 was in a room alone with a youth. S2 entered the room, and observed a youth exhale smoke from their mouth when asked a question.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence...a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours and...a written report...shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days...This was not met as evidenced by Based on records reviewed and interviews conducted, the licensee did not submit a 24-hour report or a 7-day written report required by regulation for the incident that occurred involving S1 in the facility.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The agency shall provide training to all staff on requirements for mandated reporting and on the reporting requirements related to incident reports.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection to the administrative offices for Rite of Passage on 8/17/21 at 2:30 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss incident reports received for this facility. The first incident report discussed was an incident report dated 8/3/21 where C1 (see LIC811 dated 8/17/21) was on the phone and was asked to end their call but refused. As a result of the refusal, S1 unplugged the phone terminating C1's phone conversation. C1 in turn was escalated and caused damage to S1's vehicle. Law enforcement was called and C1 was arrested and removed from the program. LPA spoke with Ms. Edwards about the staff being trauma-informed and trained to de-escalate youth as this intervention was not trauma-informed. Ms. Edwards agreed to provide a reminder to all staff about being trauma-informed and how to de-escalate. This shall be sent to Licensing upon completion. The other two incidents, 7/2/21 and 7/3/21, were provided to Ms. Edwards as more informational in that additional informed was needed to be complete incidents. LPA explained that the incident reports should have a clear picture of the events leading up to, what happened during, and the resolution of/or the consequence(s) given to the youth/staff as a result of the incident(s). LPA also instructed Ms. Edwards that the incident reports should have all youth involved in the incident named in the report so as to have a clear picture of the events. No citations were issued and exit interview conducted with Ms. Edwards.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 10/20/21 at 11:30 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss an incident report. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the incident report in question is dated 10/16/21 in which C1 (see LIC811 dated 10/20/21) was involved in a single person restraint with staff, S1. During the restraint, S1 lost their footing and fell to the floor while still in the restraint with C1. LPA asked Ms. Edwards for the staff training manual for the Emergency Interventions and did review an section of the manual during the visit. Ms. Edwards states that she is going to look further in the manual for information about what staff are to do when they lose control of a situation. LPA did advise the facility that when the staff engage in restraints with the youth in care, that the restraint should cease the moment that the staff "lose control" of the restraint so as to prevent injury to youth and staff involved in restraints. Ms. Edwards shall also follow up with S1 regarding the incident and the reporting and inform S1 that the incident itself needs additional information and clarity as the preliminary report provided during the visit today is missing relevant information. The final report is not yet due to Licensing as the final date is 10/23/21. As a result of this, there are no citations at this time. In addition, Ms. Edwards shall provide additional clarification on the Emergency Intervention Training Plan on what it states about how staff are to respond when they are no longer in control of the emergency intervention with the youth. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided at the conclusion of the visit.

The allegation that staff gave a foster child non-prescribed medication for illicit use is related to C1 obtaining pills from S1. While S1 denied giving the medication to C1, S1 did tell law enforcement that C1 might have "helped themselves to S1's medications". Without information from S1, there is no plausible explanation for C1 to have knowledge of S1 taking any medication, of C1 knowing that S1 had medication in the facility or knowing what medication(s) S1 was taking. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, the allegations that staff sexually abused a foster child and that staff gave a foster child non-prescribed medication for illicit use are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility was cited for Interim Licensing Standards 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights. The facility has a responsibility to accord personal rights to all children in care including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse... investigation showed that S1 sexually abuse C1 in the facility. Facility was cited for Interim Licensing Standards 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties. The facility did not employ staff to appropriately supervise, protect, and care for children living in the facility at all times in that S1 provided non-prescribed medication(s) for illicit use to C1 while at the facility. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documents provided at the conclusion of the inspection.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 10/20/21 at 9:30 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss the findings for the complaint allegations as stated. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the investigation included an initial complaint inspection on 7/8/21 by Investigator Juan Barajas. All interviews with staff, clients, law enforcement, social workers, reporting party and other personnel was conducted by the Investigations Branch for the Department from 7/8/21 to 9/30/21. The allegation that staff sexually abused a foster child is related to a disclosure made on 6/30/21, by C1 (see LIC811 dated DATE) that C1 had engaged in sexual intercourse with S1 in the staff room at the facility. When interviewed by law enforcement, S1 admitted to investigating officers on 6/26/21, that this allegation was true.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable, Including the right to be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse... This is not met as evidenced by Based on investigation, S1 admitted to law enforcement officers on 6/30/21 that S1 engaged in sexual intercourse with C1 in the staff room at the facility on 6/26/21 which poses an immediate health, safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Immediate Health and Safety Risk was accomplished by the removal of S1 from further contact with clients on 6/30/21. The initial incident happened on 6/26/21. Staff were informed 6/27/21, while S1 was not working. Law enforcement requested that the facility allow S1 to report to work in order to conduct an interview of S1. Once law enforcement concluded their investigation and informed the agency of their findings, S1 was terminated. In order to prevent future violations, facility shall provide additional training to staff that shall include personal relationships and fraternizing with clients in care. Proof of the training shall be provided to Licensing by 11/8/21.

deficiencies.description: Personnel Duties. Direct care staff shall perform the following duties including supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups. This is not met as evidenced by Based on investigation, C1 was in possession of pills that were prescribed to S1. When questioned by law enforcement, S1 said that C1 "helped themselves" to S1's medications following engaging in sexual contact with C1 in the staff room which poses an immediate health, safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Immediate Health and Safety Risk was accomplished by the removal of S1 from further contact with clients on 6/30/21. The initial incident happened on 6/26/21. Staff were informed 6/27/21, while S1 was not working. Law enforcement requested that the facility allow S1 to report to work in order to conduct an interview of S1. Once law enforcement concluded their investigation and informed the agency of their findings, S1 was terminated. In order to prevent future violations, facility shall provide additional training to staff that shall include personal relationships and fraternizing with clients in care. Proof of the training shall be provided to Licensing by 11/8/21.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 11/30/21 at 12:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Manager, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Hill conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present during the inspection due to school. LPA observed two, dual occupancy client bedrooms, two single occupancy bedrooms, two bathrooms accessible to clients, and one staff room and staff bathroom during the inspection. LPA Hill inspected and/or reviewed the following: Postings of facility license, Personal Rights Poster Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible Refrigerator Temperature was at or below 45 degrees F and Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees Nonperishable Foods for one week and fresh perishable for foods two days minimum were present Menu was present and posted Working telephone was present Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were functioning First Aid Kit was present and had all required components Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room for relaxing Dining area with enough seating was present and in good condition Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible LPA observed a locked staff office/sleeping area. All documentation and equipment in the staff room is locked as is the staff room. Hot Water was between 105 -120 degree F Fire Extinguishers were observed to be last inspected on 2/8/21 and 4/1/21 (there were three present) Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures appeared to be in good repair, no leaks and delivering hot water. LPA observed there to be soap and paper towels available in the bathrooms.

Laundry Facilities were available and LPA observed posted assigned washing days for clients. Bedrooms appeared to be clean and organized with required linen and furnishings Motor Vehicle was observed to have working seat belts, lights and adequate tires. Facility appeared to be free of vermin LPA observed no citations during the physical plant inspection. LPA arrived to the Minden, Nevada school site location to conduct interviews with staff and clients. LPA was not able to complete the staff and client file reviews during the inspection but will return on another date to complete the file reviews as required. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided to Ms. Edwards.

Confidential interviews revealed that S1 told numerous youth that upon completion of their program, they could return to Nevada to live with S1. Interviews revealed that there was no discussion of anything sexual but that they didn't know S1's intentions, making them feel uncomfortable at the mention of this. When staff were interviewed, they informed LPA that there was a company policy prohibiting contact with youth following their exit from the program without notification and written approval by management. Interviews revealed that S1 has not disclosed this offer to management nor had there been any written permission allowing S1 to discuss this with youth in the program. Another incident of youth not feeling comfortable was when one youth was taken into the staff room to do a hair cut and being one on one with S1 in the staff room. While youth reported that nothing happened in the staff room, company policy states the staff room as an "off limits" area for youth. Youth know this which made the youth feel uncomfortable since the other hair cuts being done in the home were done in the dining area. The next allegation is about S1 "spatting water" in youth's face during a walrus impression joke. This incident had no direct witnesses and S1 failed to provide a statement related to this incident. The final allegation that S1 threatened youth, is related to S1 telling youth that if they misbehaved or didn't do as S1 asked, S1 would get their friends in law enforcement in the area to come over and taze them. Youth also reported that S1 asked them to help S1 get information on other staff to get them fired. S1 allegedly told youth that they planted contraband in youth's possessions and took photos to provide to management to sabotage youths' program. There is no evidence any of this happened and S1 failed to provide a statement. During the course of the investigation, a youth alleged that S1 hit them with a belt one evening while in their own room and out of sight of cameras at the facility. The youth claimed to have not disclosed this happening because S1 told youth that they would not be believed. Youth also stated they were not a snitch and could handle it themselves. During interviews, another youth in the home disclosed hearing the belt strike the youth and heard the youth get upset and scream at S1 for striking them with the belt immediately after it happened. A staff also alleged that S1 bragged about striking another youth in the stomach. While there is not a significant amount of evidence in all of these allegations, the totality of the allegations and the number of recounts of the same or like information that came out as a result of the investigation demonstrates the overall character of S1. In addition to S1 not making themselves available to provide input despite the multiple attempts by LPA Hill, give preponderance to the allegations against S1.

As a result of the information disclosed and the lack of response from S1, the allegations that S1 violated youth's rights, spat in a youth's face, and threatened or intimidated youth are SUBSTANTIATED meaning that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited for Personal Rights 87072(a)(11) as children have the right to be free physical abuse, intimidation, threat, ridicule, and coercion. On at least one occasion, S1 struck a youth in care with a belt. S1 also disclosed to a staff that they had punched a youth in the stomach. S1 intimidated and threatened youth in care to have friends in law enforcement come to the facility to taze youth to get youth to comply and behave. S1 also intimidated and threatened youth to plant contraband in their possessions to get them into trouble or to fail their program. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyat (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint visit to 2560 Business Park Drive, Minden, NV on 3/2/22 at 12:00 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss the findings. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the initial investigation of the allegations occurred on 11/23/21. LPA interviewed children and staff at the school site on 11/23/21. LPA interviewed additional staff via phone on 2/10/22 and attempted to contact S1 eight times from 2/11/22 to 2/23/22, using email, text messages and phone messages. LPA did speak with S1 on 2/18/22 and S1 stated that they were sick with COVID since 2/11/22. LPA asked staff to please contact LPA on 2/22/22 to discuss a time and date to conduct an interview to allow S1 to give input about the allegations. LPA then contacted S1 via text message and phone message on 2/23/22, but S1 did not respond to the multiple requests for interview. The first allegation is related to S1 violating personal rights of youth in care. Youth reported feeling uncomfortable around S1 due to some of the following issues.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the personal rights specific in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9...Children have the right to be free physical abuse, intimidation, threat, ridicule, and coercion. This is not met as evidenced by On at least one occasion, S1 struck a youth in care with a belt and told a staff they had punched a youth in the stomach. S1 intimidated and threatened youth in care to have friends in law enforcement come to the facility to taze youth in order to gain compliance and good behavior from youth. S1 also threatened youth to plant contraband in their possessions to get them into trouble or fail their program which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Immediately upon learning of the complaint allegations and other incidents not disclosed, S1 was removed from the facility and staff was placed on administrative leave as ot 11/10/21. Subsequently S1 was terminated on 12/9/21. The facility shall provide an updated training of Personal Rights of youth in care with all staff. Administrator shall also review the mandated reporting training with all staff to ensure that all staff are aware of their responsibilities related to disclosures. This shall be completed by 4/30/22.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 5/16/22 at 11:00 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill made this visit to the Administrative office location in Minden, Nevada as the youth were already on site at this location in attendance at school. LPA made the case management inspection visit today to discuss the following incidents: * 1/19/22 C1 drank cleaning product in an act of self harm. C1 was hospitalized for three days as a result. C1 had asked for the cleaning product at a time when the youth were completing chores and there was no indication that C1 was going to drink the product. LPA found that staff acted appropriately and that all reports were made as required. The facility was not cited and there is no follow up for this incident. * 12/22/21 C2 left the facility undetected and went to another facility. C2 was able to gain entry to the other facility, be in the other facility for an undisclosed amount of time, and return to this facility, without staff knowing that C2 was even gone. C2 left the facility again on 12/23/21 undetected and went to the other facility where C2 was inside the facility. C2 then heard staff discussing the situation of C2 being gone from this facility. C2 left the other facility through the other client's bedroom window and went to the front of the facility and knocked asking to be let in due to the snow and cold conditions. According to Administrator, S1 was given a progressive discipline for not conducting bed checks according to the facility policy. LPA requested a copy of the discipline for S1. LPA also discussed drug testing with the agency as there was a 24 hour incident report was received about drug testing youth. LPA advised Ms. Edwards that the 24 hour reports need to give enough detail which would include their cause for and consent received in order to conduct the drug testing on youth in the program. LPA advised Ms. Edwards that without a court order for weekly/random drug testing, they cannot perform drug testing without probable cause and without the consent of the placing agency and that this information needs to be in the 24 hour reports sent to Licensing. Exit interview conducted and document provided to the facility.

C1 was observed to be red in the face and have a swollen or bloody lip following the incident. It was also alleged that this incident was not reported to Licensing as required. LPA obtained a copy of a draft incident while at the agency on 5/16/2022. This report was not sent to Licensing. When staff reviewed the cameras at the facility, it was disclosed that there were no staff supervising the youth in the living area at the time of the incident which allowed the youth the opportunity to step outside, outside of view of any cameras at the facility, and engage in the altercation. As a result of the interviews conducted and review of the cameras, the allegations that there was a lack of supervision allowing the youth to engage in a physical altercation and that the facility failed to report the incident to Licensing as required are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. The allegation that a lack of supervision resulted in a youth to leave the facility undetected is related to an incident that happened on 4/26/22 in which C2 was able to leave the facility and be gone for multiple hours without staff knowing. When interviewed, C2 admits to leaving the facility around midnight on 4/26/22 but S1 failed to notice that C2 was gone until 2 AM. When the administrator reviewed the cameras for the evening of 4/25/22 to the early morning of 4/26/22, S1 failed to conduct the nightly checks according to the agency policy which requires youth to be checked on every 15 minutes and for staff to verify that they see skin when checking on youth. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted, the allegation that a lack of supervision resulted in a youth leaving the facility undetected and being gone for hours is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the "preponderance of the evidence" standard has been met. As a result of the allegations substantiated, the facility was cited for Title 22, California Code of Regulations, General Regulations, 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision as staff failed to supervise youth appropriately to prevent an altercation that took place on 5/5/2022 between C1 and C2, out of camera view and with no staff present. In addition, staff failed to appropriately supervise youth on 4/26/22 leading to C2 being able to leave the facility undetected and being gone for approximately two hours prior to staff knowing. The facility was also cited for Title 22, California Code of Regulations, General Regulations, 80061(a) Reporting Requirements as the agency failed to report the altercation between C1 and C2 that happened on 5/5/2022. The incident was not provided to Licensing until LPA Hill obtained a copy while initiating the complaint investigation on 5/16/2022. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards and documents were provided via email along with appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 9/1/22 at 11:00 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss the findings of the allegations. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection at the facility on 5/16/2022 and collateral inspection at the administrative offices in Minden, NV, to interview staff and clients involved in the incidents. LPA interviewed C1, C2, and C3 (see LIC811 dated 9/1/22) and staff while at the administrative offices and obtained documentation related to the clients and incidents under investigation. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the allegation regarding lack of supervision resulting in a serious altercation between clients happened on 5/5/2022 while at the facility in which two clients stepped out on the back patio of the facility and engaged in a physical altercation without staff detection. When interviewed, the clients refused to disclose that anything had happened but there was evidence that something had happened as

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This was not met as evidenced by Based on interviews conducted, staff failed to supervise youth appropriately to prevent an altercation that took place on 5/5/2022 between C1 and C2 as no staff were present in the room. In addition, staff failed to appropriately supervise youth on 4/26/22 leading to C2 being able to leave the facility undetected and be gone for approximately two hours without staff knowledge which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S1 was verbally counseled about the lack of supervision and subsequently left the agency. The administrator did discuss the incident and verbally counseled other staff in the second issue about supervision at all times. Administrator will retrain night staff on the supervision policy at night and all staff will be trained on providing supervision at all times during the day shift as well. This training shall include 15 minute bed checks and the observation of seeing skin on the youth at night and being present during day.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This was not met as evidenced by The facility did not report an altercation or alleged incident between C1 and C2 that happened on 5/5/2022. The incident was not provided to Licensing until the complaint investigation was initiated on 5/16/2022 which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will ensure that when they are absent there will be a staff person to cover them for the incident reporting so as to not have a lag in reporting or a report that is neglected to be reported. Email acknowledgement will be sent to LPA by close of business 9/1/22.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 11/22/22 at 11:30 AM at the school site for the youth in Minden, NV. LPA initially attempted an inspection at the facility but there were no clients or staff present at 10:45 AM. During the annual inspection on 11/22/22, LPA interviewed clients as part of the annual and reviewed some client files. LPA informed the agency that an additional inspection date will be necessary at a later date. Exit interview conducted and documents were provided at the conclusion of the inspection today.

neighbors, with the youth present, telling the neighbor to "take [their] racist ass back home" as they thought the youth walking were being racially targeted by the neighbors. Staff admitted to making the inappropriate comment out of anger toward the neighbors due to the perceived racial targeting. During confidential interviews, it was confirmed that S1 did make the inappropriate statements to the neighbors instead of attempting to intervene in an appropriate manner or attempting redirect the youth back to the facility without a confrontation. As a result of the confidential interviews and information received, the allegation that staff shouted racial epithets at the neighbors, is SUBSTANTIATED meaning that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility was cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87072(c)(10) Personal Rights as youth are to be accorded the right to dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. This did not happen as the youth were subjected to an inappropriate interaction between the staff and the neighbors. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to the facility.

The allegation about the staff not supervising the youth is related to whether or not staff were supervising youth while they were walking on the street and playing ball in front of the facility. Confidential interviews were not consistent about where staff were at to supervise the youth while the youth were on the street walking and playing ball. Some of the interviews stated that the staff were not present but other interviews stated that the staff were supervising the youth from the facility driveway as they walked approximately 300 yards down the street as part of their exercise program and played ball in front of the facility. The allegation that the facility is not adhering to the good neighbor policy relates to two separate issues wherein the community members feel that the youth and staff working in the facility are not being friendly to the neighbors, not respecting the right to privacy, and being respectful of local ordinances where the facility is located. While the good neighbor policy is not addressed in Title 22 Regulations and thereby not a violation of the regulations that govern the facility, these incidents could have been addressed within the facility's Neighborhood Complaint Policy, the community members could have contacted a facility representative when these issues surfaced. Community members have expressed concern that they have brought issues to the attention of staff at the facility but the information reportedly is not being provided to the administrative staff. The facility shall provide Neighborhood Complaint Policy to neighbors/community members for future reference. As a result of the investigation conducted, confidential interviews, and other documentation received, the allegations that youth were wandering unaccompanied by staff and that the facility was not adhering to a good neighbor policy are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 6/27/23 at 2:00 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Director/Administrator to discuss the findings of the allegation as stated. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the investigation included an initial inspection on 4/26/23, where three youth and three staff persons were interviewed. LPA Hill requested a copy of the police report from Alpine County Sheriff's Office on 4/26/23, for an incident that occurred on 4/11/23. The police report was received 4/27/23. A subsequent inspection was conducted on 6/6/23, where personnel records were reviewed. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the allegation that staff shouted racial epithets at the neighbors is related to an incident that took place in front of the facility on 4/11/23, where the youth were stopped by the neighbors while walking on the street. S1 (see LIC811 dated 6/27/23) subsequently confronted the

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, including to be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons. This was not met as evidenced by Youth were subjected to an inappropriate interaction between the staff and the neighbors which included the staff shouting racial epithets at the neighbors, which is a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Staff was disciplined and counseled immediately after reporting the incident to the administrator.

This training shall be provided to Licensing for review.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection 9/8/23 and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection today was to review the temporary repairs made to the deck. LPA Hill observed that the deck railing has been secured and that the deck appears to be stable enough for the house to repopulate at this time. LPA Hill asked Ms. Edwards if the facility is still moving forward with the replacement of the deck and Ms. Edwards states that the three bids have to be submitted to the finance committee to be approved prior to commencing the work. Ms. Edwards estimates that the deck will be completed by the end of October 2023. LPA Hill requested that Ms. Edwards touch bases with LPA Hill when the work begins and again when the work is completed. End of interview.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia on 09/14/2023 at 8:15am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Valencia met with Alina Scott, Therapist and inspected the facility inside and out. Facility is under remodeling and not sure when it will be completed to start admitting children again. LPA reviewed zero child’s records and two of seven (2 of 7) staff personnel files on site at the facility. There are currently no children in the home. LPA interviewed two of seven (2 of 7) staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Alina Scott, Therapist No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Alina Scott, Therapist

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 12/20/23 at 11:00 AM and Monica Guzman, Coach Counselor assisted with the physical plant inspection at the facility. LPA Hill toured the inside of the facility and noted that there are three, dual occupancy client rooms, one office room, and one staff room in the facility. All of the client bedrooms have the required furniture and equipment as required. LPA Hill noted that while the client beds have sheets and blankets, there are no mattress pads on any of the client beds during the inspection. LPA Hill informed Ms. Guzman that this is required and the facility will be cited for not have these as required. LPA Hill observed that the facility had the required supply of perishable and nonperishable food as required by regulation and that the house was clean and tidy. LPA Hill observed that there are two bathrooms accessible to clients in the facility and that the toilets flushed, showers worked and had hot water, and that the sinks were working and had hot water. LPA Hill did observe loofahs in the shower area and did provide an advisory to the facility about labeling them so as to ensure that all clients know what loofahs are theirs so that there is no cross contamination or cross use. LPA Hill toured the inside and outside of this facility and LPA Hill did observe that further progress is being made for the deck on the backside of the facility. LPA Hill noted that while perimeter of the facility was inspected on 12/7/23 by this analyst, the deck was and is still under construction today and there continues to be several potentially dangerous or harmful items scattered throughout the back yard related to the construction of the deck. While the back yard was deemed "off limits" to clients in care since the construction began, the potential for harm continues to be present and these issues continue to present a danger to clients in care. LPA Hill noted that many of the same items are still scattered throughout the back yard and not secured as previously discussed with Ms. Edwards during the 12/7/23 inspection. LPA Hill did cite for this during the annual inspection today.

After the tour of the physical plant of the facility, LPA Hill ceased the physical plant inspection and resumed the inspection at the business office in Minden. At this location, LPA Hill conducted staff and client interviews and reviewed staff and client files. LPA Hill requested that the facility provide the following documents to be updated in the facility file: LIC308, LIC500, LIC610. LPA Hill also reminded the facility that the program statement update is due 2/2/16/24. LPA Hill did cite the facility on this date for the following: 87087.2(a) Outdoor Activity Space: The outdoor space behind the house is not safe as it was noted that there were multiple unsafe objects laying out and accessible to youth in care who have a propensity for harm to others and self. These items were left by a contractor working on the back deck of the facility. 87088(c)(2) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies: LPA Hill observed that all six of the beds were lacking the mattress pads as required by this regulation. 87070(c)(2) Children's Records: LPA Hill observed during the review of the records that there are no Removal or Transfer Policy or Discipline Policy signed by the placing agency. 87068.2(f) Needs and Services Plan: LPA Hill observed that the facility is not obtaining the signature of the placing agency on the Needs and Services document or the modifications when this document is updated, changed, or modified. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided to Ms. Edwards.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced case management annual continuation review at the business offices of Rites of Passage located in Minden, Nevada, on 12/21/23 at 9:30 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator who assisted in records review. LPA Hill reviewed staff and client records, reviewed restraint records, and requested board meeting minutes, and conducted interviews. LPA Hill requested the Emergency and Disaster Plan but the needed requirements were not available for review (Technical Violation was provided). LPA Hill conducted the exit interview with Ms. Edwards and documents were provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection to the administrative offices for Rite of Passage and met with Jim Amaral, Program Director. LPA Hill interviewed staff and one youth related to an incident that took place that the facility 1/7/24, and was reported to Licensing. LPA Hill attempted to interview C1 (see LIC811 dated 1/12/24) but C1 declined an interview. LPA Hill interviewed C2 and S1 related to this incident. Additional interviews are necessary. LPA Hill is requesting the agency provide video footage for 1/7/24 from 9 PM to 4 AM 1/8/24 by Tuesday, 1/16/24. LPA Hill requested a copy of the individual incident reports depicting staffs' accounts of the events of the night of 1/7/24, from 3:30 PM through the incident referenced herein. LPA Hill was informed that Alpine County law enforcement was notified of the incident and have been in contact with youth involved. LPA Hill informed Mr. Amaral that further investigation is needed at this time as LPA Hill still needs to collect additional information and conduct further interviews. Exit interview conducted and document was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 1/26/24 at 1:20 PM and met with Alina Scott, Head of Service. LPA Hill informed Ms. Scott that this inspection is a conclusion of the case management inspection conducted originally conducted on 1/12/24, related to the 1/7/24 incident between C1 and C2. LPA Hill informed Ms. Scott that the investigation included collaboration with Riverside County Probation. Investigation included interviews with three staff and C2 (see LIC811 dated 1/26/24). LPA Hill attempted to interview C1 but C1 refused to discuss the incident. LPA Hill and Riverside County Probation officer reviewed camera footage of the incident while at the administrative offices for Rite of Passage on 1/17/24 and conducted interviews of staff. LPA Hill informed Ms. Scott that the investigation showed that S2 took youth on an outing where S2 admittedly did not supervise youth appropriately, causing C2 to steal an alcohol product bringing it into the facility and C1 and C2 consuming the alcohol throughout the evening. When cameras were reviewed, it showed that S1 failed to perform their duties of supervision in the facility in that S1 did not perform the 15 minute bed checks as outlined in the facility's plan of operation even though this was reported via incident report as having been done. In addition, S1 failed to provide adequate supervision of C1 and C2, knowing the youth were awake and engaging in suspicious activities. As a result of the investigation, interviews conducted, and information obtained, it is clear that the facility failed to provide the supervision necessary to meet the needs of the youth in care and the facility was cited for Title 22 General Licensing Regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. S2 did not supervise youth while on an outing, allowing youth time to abscond alcohol from a local store, and S1 did not ensure that youth were adequately supervised to prevent an inappropriate interaction between youth.

In addition, the incident report that was submitted about this incident included details that were not seen and do not appear to be accurate, including checking on youth every 15 minutes as articulated in the facility's program statement. In review of the program statement and policies of the facility, night staff are expected to conduct bed checks of the youth every 15 minutes and this was not done as required and outlined in the program statement. As a result, LPA Hill cited the facility for 87022.1(b)(2)(A) Program Statement as the facility is required to have and maintain a program statement that describes how the facility will serve the specified population, including interventions used to tailer their services to this specific population, i.e. the 15 minute bed checks necessary in monitoring youth while sleeping. The facility failed to follow this part of their program statement as necessary. LPA Hill also informed Ms. Scott that the licensee is required to provide staff ratios of one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children at a minimum daily until 10:00 PM. During the interviews with staff about this incident, it was disclosed that night staff regularly arrives at 9:00 PM and that the two day staff regularly leave the facility at 9:00 PM and 9:30 PM, leaving the night staff alone with the youth in care for a period of 30 minutes when there is a requirement to have staff ratio of one staff to three clients. There were four clients in care at the time of this incident, thereby meaning that there needed to be two staff awake and on duty until 10:00 PM. When interviewed, staff stated it was regular to leave before 10:00 PM. The facility was also cited for 87065.5(a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios as the facility is required to have one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum and this was not being done. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to the facility along with appeal rights.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This was not met as evidenced by S2 did not supervise youth while on an outing, allowing C2 time and opportunity to abscond alcohol from a local store, and S1 did not ensure that youth were adequately supervised to prevent an inappropriate interaction between youth which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall provide a written plan of correction to the Department by the POC date indicated of 1/29/24. The written plan of correction will be reviewed by the Department and confirmation of approval of the plan of correction shall be provided.

deficiencies.description: Program Statement. Facility shall have and maintain on file a current, written, definitive program statement...details for any specific models or interventions that will be used to tailor their services to their specific population...This was not met as evidenced by LPA Hill observed during the video footage review that 15 minute bed checks necessary in monitoring youth while they sleep were not done as articulated in the program statement for the facility which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall provide a written plan of correction to the Department by the POC date indicated of 1/29/24. The written plan of correction will be reviewed by the Department and confirmation of approval of the plan of correction shall be provided.

deficiencies.description: Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. In a facility... there shall be coverage...during the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This was not met as evidenced by Interviews with staff indicate that the night staff arrives at the facility at 9:00 PM and that the day staff leave at 9:00 PM and 9:30 PM when the requirement in the regulation is that there are to be two awake and on duty staff until 10:00 PM when there are more than three youth in care. On this night, there were four youth in the facility. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall provide a written plan of correction to the Department by the POC date indicated of 1/29/24. The written plan of correction will be reviewed by the Department and confirmation of approval of the plan of correction shall be provided.

narrative: current psychiatrist was terminating their contracted psychiatry services as of August 2023. In July 2023, the agency found and began the process of on-boarding a new psychiatrist, but the process was lengthy, and the agency did not have the new psychiatrist on board until November 2023, meaning the youth did not have the required monthly psychiatry consultations for the months of September 2023 and October 2023 but the agency continued to accept youth, specifically, C1 (see LIC811 dated 3/25/24) was admitted 10/23/23. The agency was able to provide documentation including emails and correspondence between the agency's HOS, Placer County, the new contracted provider, Health Link Now, and the psychiatrist from July 2023 through November 2023, indicating that the agency was actively trying to get the new psychiatrist through the contract and on boarding process to provide services to youth in care. In addition, in anticipation of not having the psychiatrist on board in time, Head of Service (HOS) did reach out to Barton Psychiatry in South Lake Tahoe on 8/5/23 but were informed that the wait time would be until January 2024, and Washoe County (Nevada) Behavioral Health informed the agency that they could not provide services to the agency's youth. HOS presumed this was due to the youth being California youth and not from Nevada. The new psychiatrist was providing psychiatry services to youth in care as of November 14, 2023. LPA Hill was informed that during the time with no psychiatry services, the agency had prepared in advanced and did have prescription refills for all youths' medications and no youth went without medications or had lapses in medications during the months of September 2023 or October 2023. The allegation that the facility did not ensure client's medical and/or mental health needs were met is related to the same allegation as stated regarding youth having the required psychiatry consultations prescribed in regulation. When reviewing C2 and C3's paperwork, it was indicated that all medical and mental health services were provided except for the psychiatry consultations as described. C1 was admitted in the facility and did have the required psychiatry appointments as required as they were part of C1’s negotiated services with the placement agency. Interviews indicate that the facility did ensure all youth had consultations with doctor, dentist, and optometry as needed while at the facility and that the agency did ensure that therapy, and other mental health services were being provided during youths’ time at the facility. As a result of the investigation, documentation received, interviews conducted, the allegations that the facility did not provide clients in care with consultation from a psychiatrist as required and that the facility did not ensure medical and/or mental health needs were met is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time as the facility did employ active efforts in locating and on boarding the new psychiatrist and were providing other mental health services to youth in care. Unsubstantiated means that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Scott and documentation provided, including appeal rights.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 9/20/24 at 10:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Manager. LPA Hill met with Ms. Edwards to discuss an incident report regarding two incidents that happened on 9/16/2024. The first incident happened at the facility between C1 and S1 (see LIC811 dated 9/20/24) and a second incident that took place at the facility with C2. The first incident took place on 9/16/24, at about 8:00 AM, in front of the facility where there was a confrontation between a client and staff over transportation. The second incident was regarding another client inside the facility and had been ongoing with the client and staff most of the morning. LPA Hill conducted interviews about the incidents during the inspection on this date, obtained documents related to C2, their placement and needs. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that further investigation is needed at this time. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 11/26/24 at 10:15 AM and initially met with Case Manager Angeline Sunday. Tracy Edwards arrived at the agency and met with this LPA to conclude the inspection. The inspection on this date was made for the purposes of discussing two incident reports regarding youths C1, C2, and C3. The details of the incidents are as follows: 11/12/24 - C1 and C2 collaborated in the taking of an educational staff's phone. C2 was arrested and charged with theft after review of the classroom cameras showed C2 taking the phone. C2 was returned to the program and remains in program at this time. LPA Hill interviewed one staff and one youth related to this incident. One youth was not available to interview due to absconding from the facility and not returning. No further investigation was needed at this time. 11/17/24 - C2 absconded from the facility and it was alleged by another youth in care that S1 assisted youth in absconding. LPA Hill conducted interviews with staff and did inform the agency that further investigation is needed at this time. 11/25/24 - LPA Hill learned of youth absconding from the facility on 11/25/24 and spoke to youth about this incident. At this time, no citations were issued and no further investigation is needed based on the information shared by youth interviewed. LPA Hill did not have a full report for this incident and spoke to youth solely based on their willingness to share what happened. At the time of the inspection, there were citations issued and LPA Hill did conduct an exit interview with Ms. Edwards.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 12/10/24 at 10:45 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Administrator, to conduct the physical plant inspection of the facility as part of the annual inspection. LPA Hill observed that the facility has three dual occupancy bedrooms for clients in care but each of the youth currently are not sharing bedrooms with other youth. LPA Hill observed that the facility was clean, safe and sanitary during the annual inspection. LPA Hill observed that the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were functioning as required. Fire extinguishers were last inspected 1/23/24. LPA Hill observed two client restrooms that had running hot water, paper towels, flushing toilets, and showers that delivered hot water. LPA Hill observed that the client bedrooms were supplied with proper bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheets, blankets, pillows, closet space, and storage for belongings. LPA Hill observed that the facility had two days perishable food supply and seven days nonperishable food supply appropriate for the youth in care. LPA Hill observed the facility was safe inside and out for youth in care. The deck is new and was very stable and no concerns were noted on the perimeter of the facility. LPA Hill interviewed one youth while at the house as that youth was home sick and not attending school on this date. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the client interviews were going to be conducted at the agency administrative offices as well as file reviews. LPA Hill interviewed two youth at the administrative office. Document was provided to Ms. Edwards and exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced inspection to the agency on 12/20/24 and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill spoke with Ms. Edwards regarding an incident that occurred on 12/9/24 in which C1 (see LIC811 dated 12/20/24) disclosed an inappropriate sexual contact with C2 at the facility, the evening of 12/8/24. Ms. Edwards states that an internal investigation was conducted and it was discovered that staff on duty, S1, did not conduct the evening bed checks as required. (Internal investigation was obtained) LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the agency is cited for 87078(b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision as the licensee shall provide those services identified in each child’s...needs and services plan...including the need for bed checks of every 15 minutes as described in the Licensee's Program Plan. This was not done which left youth unsupervised and not monitored, leading to the inappropriate interaction between C1 and C2. LPA Hill also discussed with the agency changes in the intake procedures for the better assessment of youth being admitted into the facility and how the agency is looking to lower the incidents of calling on law enforcement partners. LPA Hill discussed that calls for law enforcement services has risen in comparison to previous years and requested that the agency provide a written assessment and training plan to address this rise in calls. LPA Hill is requesting that the agency assess how they can work with staff and agency management to mitigate the need for these calls. LPA Hill advised that it is imperative that the agency try to work with staff and local partners to reduce these calls for service. LPA Hill requested that the agency provide updated written intake procedures, update of the Neighborhood Complaint Procedures, and any/all procedures on how staff and management can mitigate the calls for service to Law Enforcement partners in the community. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided.

August 2024, not all youth were immediately assigned to the new therapist, S2. When it was finally decided to assign all youth to S2 and begin their transition, S2 noted that there were three to four weeks' of missing or undone therapy documentation to facilitate this change in therapists. S2 noted that in discussing this with the agency's management, S2 was directed to "start new" with all of the youth being added to S2's caseload, which was about half of all the youth they had in care at that time. S2 indicates that this meant going back and completing documents for all youth as if they were brand new, even if they had been in care for some time, as there were incomplete and/or undone documented therapy notes. Subsequent interviews with other agency personnel indicates that the agency will not be returning S1 to their employment position within the agency. As a result of interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, the allegation that staff did not ensure that youth are provided mental health services is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility cited for Interim Licensing Standards for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Programs, regulation 87072(d): Personal Rights. Youth have the right to access and receive medical...mental health, and substance use disorder services...with reasonable promptness that meets the needs of the child...Confidential interviews conducted with staff and youth in care indicate that youth were without mental health services, specifically therapy sessions, for three to four weeks. Further interviews indicate when therapy sessions did resume for youth in care, there were therapy session notes not documented as required by the previous therapist for a reported period of up to four weeks. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Edwards.
