During the course of the investigation, LPA Hill also interviewed youths' social workers. The allegation that staff did not ensure that youth are provided mental health services is related to the youth in care not being provided therapy as dictated in the agency's program statement. While the documentation provided indicates that some youth were seeing the previous therapist, S1, who went out on leave in

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. Youth have the right to access and receive medical...mental health, and substance use disorder services...with reasonable promptness that meets the needs of the child...This is not met as evidenced by: Based on investigation conducted, youth did not have mental health services, specifically therapy sessions, for three to four weeks due to a therapist being out on leave. When therapy sessions did resume for youth in care, there were therapy session notes not documented as required by the previous therapist which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The agency is recruiting to hire an additional therapist and will ensure that no youth will have a break in therapy. In addition, the agency has a designated Quality Insurance staff person that ensures that weekly reports are run to ensure that the timeframes related to documentation are met as required. Administrator shall provide an email confirmation of this as proof to ensure that future violations of the same nature do not happen.

narrative: Facility staff acknowledge that they knew about C1's desire to exit the program as soon as possible but had not communicated directly with a responsible party to arrange for exit or transportation. C1 had a visitation scheduled at the school site with another family member on 8/31/24, where C1 was going to ask that family member for a ride back to the family's home. The agency made tentative alternate plans to provide the transportation for the youth to the family's home on 9/3/24, if the family member did not agree to provide that transportation. During the investigation, it was discovered that staff did not communicate discharge plans, including the family member transporting C1 from the program, with C1's parent/guardian to ensure that C1 had a place to stay upon arrival. Further confidential interviews indicate that the relationship between C1 and their parent/guardian was "difficult", and staff did not verify that this was an appropriate plan for C1 at the time of their discharge. As a result of the lack of an appropriate discharge plan, C1 left the facility on an unauthorized absence and when law enforcement was called and subsequently arrived, they provided transportation to C1 to a public location where C1 was left. As a result of the investigation and documentation provided, the allegation that staff did not assist C1 with their transportation needs while in care is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility was cited for Interim Licensing Standards, regulation 87068.4(c) Removal and/or Transfer Procedures as the short-term residential therapeutic program shall provide trauma-informed support and transition services including the alignment and coordination of transportation and other foster youth services as required. The facility identified that C1 was going to exit the program but did not arrange the transportation services needed for that transition. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Edwards and documentation was provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 1/7/25 at 10:45 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator, to discuss the findings of this complaint investigation. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection of the facility on 9/5/24, with subsequent collateral inspections to the administrative offices on 10/25/24, and 11/26/24, where interviews were conducted with administrator and therapist, and documents were obtained. During the course of the investigation, LPA Hill attempted contact with C1 (see LIC811 dated 1/7/25) and C1's parent but they did not respond to LPA Hill's calls. The allegation that staff did not adequately assist C1 in their transportation needs while in care is related to the facility not arranging for C1 to exit the program despite knowing that C1 had expressed their desire and intent to leave the program once they became of age to make that decision.

deficiencies.description: Removal and/or Transfer Procedures as the short-term residential therapeutic program shall provide trauma-informed support and transition services including the alignment and coordination of transportation and other foster youth services as required. This was not met as evidenced by: The facility identified that C1 was going to exit the program but did not arrange the transportation services needed for that transition which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility shall ensure that all transporation services and any other services needed by youth in care are coordinated with the responsible party, i.e., parent/guardian, social worker, and/or probation officer to ensure that arrangements are communicated and clear to all parties involved in youth's care prior to youth's planned discharge from the facility. 

Administrator shall email this POC to the Department by the POC date indicated.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 2/5/25 at 1:30 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator, to discuss the following issues: Cell phone policy. Cell phone policy includes discussions with youth during their Child & Family Team Meetings ensuring the policy is individualized for each youth in the program. When granted, youth must agree to usage policy including not having the phone until schooling, groups, and chores are done. Calling on law enforcement. The agency says they wait 30 minutes after losing sight of youth prior to calling law enforcement to assist, but there are exceptions such as when youth are seen getting into a vehicle or if youth are assessed to be at risk then they call immediately. Educating community partners for youth. LPA discussed how the agency is working and educating community partners about youth in their facilities. Ms. Edwards states they have not had an open of communication to bridge this gap, but is open to productive dialogue in hopes of forming working partnerships for the betterment of the youth served. Ms. Edwards states the agency is open to building a foundation of support within the community to ensure the safety and acceptance of the youth served. Discharge of youth following serious incidents. Ms. Edwards states that if a child has left the facility via law enforcement, they immediately contact the placing county to alert of what has transpired. If a client is deemed unable to return due to Health and Safety concerns with other youth, this is communicated to the placing county. Ms. Edwards reiterated that according to the regulations, they are able to make that determination if they feel it is unsafe for a youth to return to the facility and they make every effort to ensure the placing county is aware of the determination. Reimbursement for Services. LPA Hill spoke to Ms. Edwards about the communication related to unpaid or outstanding services for expenditures by the home county. Ms. Edwards states they have not received any communication from the county about any outstanding expenditures. Ms. Edwards indicated if they do get notification for any outstanding or unpaid expenses, they forward communications to the placing county where those expenditures are taken care of.

Night Staffing Solutions. Ms. Edwards states that they are working on solution(s) to ensure situations involving youth during the hours of 10:00 PM to 6:00 AM are handled internally. Ms. Edwards hopes to provide viable solutions in the weeks to come. Agency wants to ensure they are following regulations set by statute but also understands the resource limitation. Youth Refuse to Return. Ms. Edwards asked about what happens if youth are walking away from the facility and are refusing to return to the facility despite staff following. Ms. Edwards states they continue to follow and provide support to youth but do not call law enforcement for assistance if they are with the youth or have the youth in sight. They continue to walk with youth and give them time to de-escalate. Should law enforcement happen on scene, they try to get youth to return with staff. Ms. Edwards states staff try to talk to youth while walking, giving support, and ask youth what they need in the moment. Ms. Edwards states they just sometimes need to walk until they are ready to return. There have been situations where youth request to go to juvenile hall refusing to return so some agencies oblige youth as many are in violation of their probation by leaving without authorization. Interventions. Ms. Edwards states they are constantly speaking with youth in an attempt to get them to stay and not leave the facility. Facility staff engage with youth, remind them of the program and goals, follow them so the facility does not have to report them in violation to their placement agencies. Ms. Edwards states a training is planned that would include Managing Runaway Behavior where staff are trained on immediate interventions to de-escalate situations in an attempt to get youth to stay. Collaboration Meeting. Ms. Edwards states the agency is open to working on communication and collaboration with the local law enforcement and Probation Department to provide information about youth served and how better to collaborate and work together on a community solution to issues and solutions that would serve the community while assisting the agency in serving the youth in care. Ms. Edwards states they would greatly appreciate CCL's assistance and attendance to initiate this process with the local law enforcement. Ms. Edwards states the agency is open to bridging gaps in the community and finding viable solutions including bridging gaps in communication and collaboration in all of these identified areas. LPA Hill did request that the agency supply a cell phone policy discussed during this inspection. No citations were issued during this inspection and this document was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 2/18/25 at 10:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill conducted the inspection to provide findings related to an incident that took place on 11/17/24 in which it was alleged that S1 (see LIC811 dated 2/18/25) provided C1 a ride away from the facility as S1 was leaving the facility at the end of their shift. Investigation showed that S1 was the overnight staff working at the facility and was set to leave at 8:00 AM. S1 and the youth in care were awake and getting ready to begin the morning chores when C1 left the facility through their bedroom window and was able to access S1's running and unlocked vehicle. S1's vehicle was on and warming while S1 was inside, not supervising the unlocked vehicle. During this time, C1 was able to get into S1's vehicle and leave the facility with C1 in their vehicle. During an interview with S1, S1 denied planning to leave their vehicle on and unattended to allow C1 to get into their vehicle and take them away from the facility. S1 did admit they did not check their vehicle prior to leaving the facility property, even though they were aware of C1's unauthorized absence. S1 admitted they drove into the nearby town to get an energy drink. S1 noted when returning to their vehicle, items in the back of their vehicle were disturbed. S1 confirmed they suspected C1 was in their vehicle due to the disturbed items, but failed to notify the facility staff or the police of their suspicions until they were contacted by the sheriff's office. An interview with C2 indicates they were present during the conversation between C1 and S1 about C1 leaving the facility and S1 providing the transportation into town as it occurred. In discussion with the administrator, the agency does have a training specifically about not leaving any vehicles unattended and LPA obtained a copy of this training module while at the agency. While there is a training indicating this, S1 failed to follow the training. LPA Hill did provide an advisory to the agency to have this policy included in the agency's Vehicle Safety Policy (see attached Technical Advisory, LIC9102 AN). This concludes the investigation of this matter at this time. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Edwards.

A meeting was held via Microsoft Teams on 2/19/25 at 1:00 PM with representatives of Community Care Licensing, including Angela Carmack, Assistant Program Administrator, Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager, Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, and Tamara Hill, Licensing Program Analyst, and representatives of Rite of Passage (ROP) Qualifying Houses, Lawrence Howell, Executive Director, Rebekah Graham, Regional Director, Jerry Crandall, National Compliance Director, and Tracy Edwards, Administrator. This meeting is being held to collaborate solutions for ongoing community grievances regarding ROP's operation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Facilities in Alpine County. During this meeting, the following items were discussed: Alpine County District Attorney Public Nuisance - Community Care Licensing did advise the agency of Alpine County's intent to file public nuisance charges against ROP due to the number of calls for services in the county and the limited resources available to assist ROP with these calls. Management and Operations of ROP - The county's concerns for the types of children being accepted at the facility and officers walking into the facilities without knowing what they may encounter. The county was educated on the acuity of youth placed in the facilities and discussed with ROP is what the agency can do to provide collaboration with the county to mitigate some of the calls even follow up after calls. Overnight Staffing and Alternative Plans of Supervision - ROP discussed plans including floater staff between houses, additional overnight staff staying in a facility when youth exhibit escalated behaviors. Law Enforcement Meetings with ROP - The agency is open to collaborative meetings and additional collaboration and follow-up discussions following law enforcement contacts. Ambulance Billing - If CCL gathers information related to any unresolved fiscal responsibilities as indicated by Alpine County, this information will be passed along to ROP for resolution. Next steps will be for CCL to communicate with Alpine County to garner dates to be distributed for a meeting between CCL, Alpine County and ROP. End of meeting.

occurred as a result of trying to get youth out of the house to go to school in the morning. Staff reported that while C1 was challenging to get up and motivated, C1 was in the restroom with another youth getting ready with the door closed and locked. S1 knocked on the door of the restroom to request that the door be opened as the youth are prohibited to have more than one in the restroom at a time. When youth failed to open the door, S1 allegedly continued to knock and bang on the door to get youth out of the restroom. C1 opened the door swinging and struck S1 in the face. It was alleged that S1 hit C1 back and attempted to restrain C1 during this interaction. Immediately following the interaction, S1 called law enforcement and reported they had been assaulted in the facility. Confidential interviews of staff and youth in care revealed that while C1 was frequently a challenge both physically and verbally towards staff and other youth in care, C1 seemed to "bump heads" more with S1 than other staff in the facility. Staff indicated that S1 was typically sweet but S1 was unable to maintain their own composure at times making things harder in the facility with the youth. Staff indicated that when they observed that S1 was struggling with C1, they would step in to assist in diffusing situation(s). Staff admitted that while this didn't happen all the time, it was frequent enough that staff knew to watch for this during their shifts with S1 in the facility, and particularly when S1 worked with C1. Staff reported they did not feel that S1 was abusive but did feel that S1's inability to be trauma informed or with this population ultimately lead to S1 leaving the agency after this incident. As a result of the investigation, documentation received, and interviews conducted, the allegations that facility staff handle minors in a rough manner and that staff do not speak to minors with dignity and respect are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The agency was cited for violation Interim Licensing Standards, Section 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights as the licensee is to ensure that youth are able to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with dignity and respect. As a result of this incident, C1 was not accorded their personal rights per this regulation as evidenced by the staff and administration at the facility knew that S1 struggled with interactive supervision and harm reduction while working with youth in care and did not provide additional training to ensure S1 was implementing training in a trauma informed manner with youth in care. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided, along with appeal right to Ms. Edwards.

The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, including to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. This was not met as evidenced by Based on interviews conducted, C1 was not accorded their personal rights per this regulation as evidenced by the staff and administration knew that S1 struggled with interactive supervision and harm reduction while working with youth in care and did not provide additional training or appropriate interventions to ensure youth were appropriately supervised which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights violation to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Due to this incident, S1 was on leave due to their injuries and when they were due to return, they resigned their position with the agency in December 2024.  

Since this incident the agency has implemented a new, quarterly staff evaluation that includes staff inviting their supervisor for a 1:1 evaluation of the staff to discuss issues and concerns that would identify additional training needs. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted a case management inspection at the agency's administrative office on 6/26/25 at 11:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss an 24-hour incident report dated 6/2/25. The incident report details that C1 was administered a five panel drug screening as a result of returning from a home pass and this report details that it is in accordance with the "standard protocol for all clients after home visits". LPA Hill advised the agency that this could be perceived as an unnecessary search as just because a youth is returning from a home visit is not sufficient to render it probable cause for such searches. LPA Hill advised that in the absence of a court order explicitly stating that drug testing is required for such events for each youth in care, the agency cannot do this. LPA Hill stressed that this must be by court order and not as ordered by the youths' probation officers. Furthermore, this practice is not in the Program Statement for the agency and cannot be implemented without approval from Licensing. LPA Hill did provide the agency with an Advisory Note - Technical Violation related to Personal Rights and unreasonable searches. LPA Hill also discussed an incident report dated 6/14/25 where C2 was able to abscond from the facility without detection either 6/13/25 or early morning hours of 6/14/25. The incident report details that S1 did not complete the required 15 minute bed checks in that S1 failed to ensure that when conducting a bed check they were seeing skin. As a result, C2 was reported absent from the facility on 6/14/25 from an unknown time and returned 6/15/25 in the evening hours. LPA Hill obtained S1's disciplinary for not performing the appropriate bed checks. Exit interview conducted and documents provided.

it was reported that S1 did not supervise C1 and C2 while they were in or near the alcohol isle in the store. narrative: Confidential interviews were conducted with staff and clients in care. Youth admitted to going outside and while outside of staff view, smoked a nicotine device called a "puff bar". Prior to being found out of staff supervision, youth returned back inside the facility and hid the device. Youth reported that staff was not aware of them being outside and out of staff supervision until they were alerted via email by a neighbor later in the evening. This incident was not reported to Licensing per Title 22 Regulations. Staff performed a search of the facility and found a device amongst one youth's possessions. The device was confiscated and disposed of. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff did not provide adequate supervision to minors engaging in inappropriate activities is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that a "preponderance of evidence" standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of Title 22 Regulation Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The facility staff did not provide the supervision to two youth who were able to leave the facility and smoke a prohibited nicotine device on the side of the house. During the course of the investigation, it was noted that the agency did not provide the 24-hour notification to Licensing or the subsequent seven day written report to Licensing and a citation was issued for violation of Title 22 Regulation Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Exit interview was conducted and documents provided along with appeal rights.

C1 (see LIC811 dated 10/19/20) states that C2 made made physical contact with C1's face while C1 was laying in bed sleeping and that this physical contact included an inappropriate gesture. C1 claims that in feeling this inappropriate touch and gesture, C1 jumped out of bed upset angry and did attack C2 as a result. C2 alleges that C1 attacked him after engaging in a discussion in the bedroom with C1 and C3 and that the attack was not provoked. While there is a not a dispute about the fight happening between C1 and C2. The allegation is related to a lack of supervision which allowed C2 to be in C1's room for the period of time resulting in the inappropriate contact. The facility documented that when the cameras were reviewed, C2 was observed to have gone into C1's room and be in that room for 22 minutes before staff responded to the room, due to the fight. When interviewed, Program Administrator states that the night shift is to conduct bedroom checks every 15 minutes but to vary their bedroom checks between 10 to 15 minutes so as to not be predictable for the youth. In this case, the Night Watch Log obtained for this night show that bed checks were done ever 15 minutes on the nose which the facility documented elsewhere to not be true since video footage shows that C2 was able to leave his own room and be in C1's room for 22 minutes which is more than the documented 15 minute bed checks. As a result of the investigation and documentation obtained, the complaint is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility was cited for violation of Title 22, Division Six regulation 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The facility has a policy requiring bedroom checks every 15 minutes but it was documented that 22 minutes had lapsed between the time that C2 exited his room and this fight in C1's room where staff responded. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Edwards and documents provided, along with appeal rights, to the facility via email for signature and return.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection on 11/02/2020 at 1:00 PM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Administrator to discuss the findings of this complaint investigation. LPA informed Ms. Edwards that the investigation included a health and safety inspection conducted on 8/25/20 and included interviews with four youth and one staff person who were present. Additional investigation included interviews with complainant on 8/20/20, three additional staff and four youth and review of documentation obtained from the facility from 8/26/20 to 10/18/20. The complaint alleges that a lack of supervision resulted in an inappropriate interaction between youth in that one youth was able to leave his own room undetected after lights out and be in another youth's room where a fight broke out between the two youth as a result of the alleged inappropriate interaction. During confidential interviews, it was not clear what inappropriate interaction took place between the two youth prior to staff responding to the sounds of fighting coming from the room.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This standard was not met as evidence by: Facility's policy is to conduct random bed checks every 15 minutes throughout the night. On 8/13/20, night log states that bed checks were done every 15 minutes exactly but camera review showed a lapse of 22 minutes between youth entering another youth's room and a fight breaking out between two youth which poses an immediate health and safety risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility shall provide a retraining on interactive supervision which includes being present where the youth are at all times when supervising youth. In addition, training shall include a retraining of the night log documentation and night supervision. Facility shall provide proof of the training as stated as well as a written statement of understanding of the regulation and how to prevent future violations by the plan of correction date indicated.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 11/30/21 at 12:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Manager, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Hill conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. There were no clients present and this facility is currently closed due to lack of clients at this time. LPA observed three, dual occupancy client bedrooms, two bathrooms accessible to clients, and one staff room with staff bathroom during the inspection. LPA Hill inspected and/or reviewed the following: Postings of facility license, Personal Rights Poster Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible There are two refrigerators but neither are plugged in at this time due to no clients There are no nonperishable or perishable foods present due to no clients Working telephone was present Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were functioning First Aid Kit was present and had all required components Common Room (living room) was available as was a separate room for relaxing/recreation Dining area with enough seating was present and in good condition Medication was centrally stored, locked/inaccessible but there are currently none at this time LPA observed a locked staff office/sleeping area. All documentation and equipment in the staff room is locked as is the staff room. Hot Water was between 105 -120 degree F Fire Extinguishers were observed to be last inspected on 2/8/21 and 4/1/21 (there were two present) Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures appeared to be in good repair, no leaks and delivering hot water. LPA observed there to be soap and paper towels available in the bathrooms.

Laundry Facilities were available even though there are no clients Bedrooms appeared to be clean and organized with required linen and furnishings Motor Vehicle was not present due to the lack of clients Facility appeared to be free of vermin LPA observed no citations during the physical plant inspection. There are currently no staff or client files to review. Exit interview conducted and documentation provided to Ms. Edwards.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced annual inspection on 2/7/23 at 9:20 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator, to conduct the inspection. LPA Hill toured the facility inside. LPA Hill did not tour the outside of the facility due to the volume of snow surrounding the building. LPA Hill observed that the facility is currently not occupied and there are no clients in care at this time. LPA observed that the smoke detectors were functioning as required and that there is a carbon monoxide detector on the second level of the home. LPA Hill observed that the fire extinguishers were last serviced on 2/2/23 and there is one on the first floor near the kitchen and the other is upstairs at the top of the stairs. LPA Hill observed that the mental health certificate is on display at the front door and is current for year 2022 to 2023. At this time, this facility does not have any clients in care. LPA Hill observed that the facility is ready for clients should the need arise. LPA Hill observed that the bedrooms are equipped with appropriate furnishing and that beds are made and ready for clients. LPA Hill observed that the water is within the required temperature. LPA Hill observed that there is no food at the house - perishable or nonperishable due to there being no clients in care. The freezer and refrigerator are unplugged at this time due to them not being in use. LPA Hill advised the facility that if clients are placed in the facility that the administrator notify licensing so that we are aware that clients are no occupying the facility. There were no citations issued during the inspection today and exit interview was conducted with Ms. Edwards. Documentation was provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced collateral inspection to the agency's administrative office in Minden, Nevada and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Director, on 6/6/23 at 12:45 PM. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the purpose of the inspection was to discuss a program design addendum regarding overnight staffing that was sent to LPA Hill on 5/28/23. The addendum from the agency outlines that this facility will not have an awake night staff person but would have a staff person present at the facility sleeping while the three youth sleep. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that the regulations for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Programs (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) requires "During the hours of 10 pm to 7 am, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every six children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. [86065.5]" This means that the Department cannot accept this addendum and the facility shall provide the awake night staff as required. Further discussing, Ms. Edwards requested an exception for the three youth currently present in the facility to not have the awake night staff as required as the youth have completed their requirements as STRTP clients and are awaiting AB 12 transition and/or transitional housing acceptance. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that an exception would need to be in writing and submitted to the Department for review/approval. LPA Hill informed Ms. Edwards that if they would like to proceed, they can submit the required written documentation to the Department for review. Ms. Edwards stated that she would work on the necessary paperwork this week to get it to the Department for review. End of inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced annual inspection on 12/22/23 at 9:30 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator. LPA Hill conducted an announced inspection as the facility is currently not operating and does not currently have clients in care or staff. This facility currently does not have an administrator as the named administrator has been redirected to programs outside the state of California. The agency will not populate the home or operate this location until a qualified administrator can be hired and trained. LPA Hill conducted the physical plant inspection of the facility and observed that the facility is a split level home with two client rooms upstairs and one client room downstairs. There are two client bathrooms in the facility and that there was hot water in all faucets and sinks. There is currently no food in the house as the facility is not sure when they will be able to fill the home as they are still recruiting for an administrator and Head of Service for this house. LPA Hill observed that the carbon monoxide detector and smoke alarms are all working as required. LPA Hill observed a fire extinguisher that was last inspected in November 2022. LPA Hill observed that the facility meets all requirements according to the Interim Licensing Standards and there were no citations observed during the inspection. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Edwards and document provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced annual inspection on 12/10/24 at 9:00 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Program Administrator, to conduct the physical plant inspection of the facility as part of the annual inspection. LPA Hill observed that the facility has three dual occupancy bedrooms upstairs, one downstairs and two upstairs, for clients in care, but there are currently no youth in care at this time. LPA Hill observed that the facility was clean, safe and sanitary during the annual inspection. LPA Hill observed that the smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were functioning as required. Fire extinguishers were last inspected 1/23/24. LPA Hill observed one client restroom upstairs that had running hot water, paper towels, a flushing toilet, and a shower that delivered hot water. The other restroom is downstairs and also has hot water, paper towels, flushing toilet, and a shower that delivers hot water. LPA Hill observed that the client bedrooms were supplied with proper bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheets, blankets, pillows, closet space, and storage for belongings. LPA Hill observed that the facility did not have the required perishable or non perishable food supply as there were no clients in care at this time. LPA Hill observed that the facility did have the appropriate cook ware and dining supplies and can make ready this facility for clients should there be a need. LPA Hill observed that the facility was safe for youth, inside and out, if needed for client placement. No interviews were conducted for staff or clients as there are no clients in care. End of inspection. Document was provided to Ms. Edwards and exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted a case management inspection at the agency's administrative office on 6/26/25 at 11:15 AM and met with Tracy Edwards, Administrator to discuss an incident report dated 6/18/25. The incident report details that C1 received a probation visit on 6/18/25 where C1 was drug tested by the probation officer. C1 tested positive for a substance(s) that are prohibited which prompted the probation officer to then search C1's bedroom, finding another prohibited item(s). As a result of the drug test and contraband found in C1's possession, C2 and C3 were also tested and their rooms searched. When discussing this incident with Ms. Edwards, LPA Hill advised the agency to be careful as this may be perceived as an unnecessary search of C2 and C3's persons simply because they share the house with C1. LPA Hill advised that there did not seem to be any behavior(s) that prompted C2 or C3 to be tested or their rooms searched nor was it documented that approval from their placing agency was obtained prior to conducting said drug testing or rooms search(es). Ms. Edwards stated that permission was obtained from the placing agencies for C2 and C3, for the drug testing and the room searches, but did not document it on the incident report. In addition to this, it is noted on the incident report that the agency will "continue to randomly drug test all three [youth]". LPA Hill advised that without a court order explicitly stating that random drug testing is required, the agency cannot do this. LPA Hill stressed that this must be by court order and not as ordered by the youths' probation officers. LPA Hill did provide the agency with an Advisory Note - Technical Violation related to Personal Rights and unreasonable searches. Exit interview conducted and documents provided.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection with REFUGE and spoke with Sylvia Smith Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA Rollins conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, social workers and conducted client file review. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about facility staff having inappropriate interactions with a client in care. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories on if facility staff are not properly trained and if facility humiliated a client in care. Based on interviews and documentation there was not enough evidence to prove that facility staff had inaapropriate interaction with a client in care, faacility staff humiliated a client in care and facility staff are not properly trained. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that facility staff had inaapropriate interaction with a client in care, facility staff humiliated a client in care and facility staff are not properly trained, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with Adminstrator and report was e-mail to Administrator for signature

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection with REFUGE and spoke with Sylvia Smith Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA Rollins conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, social workers and conducted client file review. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about facility denying food to a client in care. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about if facility staff hit a client in care and if facility staff made inappropriate cooments to a client in care. Based on interviews and documentation there was not enough evidence to prove that facility denied client in care food, facility staff hit client in care and facility staff made inapproriate comments to a client in care. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that facility denied client food, facility staff hit client in care and facility staff made inappropriate comments to client in care, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with Adminstrator and report was e-mail to Administrator for signature

met_with: Sylvia Smith-Administrator, Geneva Morgan- Program Manager and Jason Henderson-Director
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced annual required inspection to REFUGE Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Sylvia Smith Administrator, Geneva Morgan Facility Manager and Jason Henderson Director. The STRTP is licensed to served 6 clients ages 13-17. The facility consists of three bedrooms (3 for clients) and 2 Bathrooms. The facility is a one story home with a side office. The facility is licensed for 6 residents and currently 4 clients reside in facility. No more than two clients share a bedroom. At 11:15 AM, LPA, Administrator and FM conducted a walk through of the facility and office. LPA observed the kitchen to be clean. The hot water in the bathroom, shower and kitchen measured 110 degrees F which is currently between 105 - 120 degrees. The facility has plenty of nonperishable and perishable food supply. Medication, knives and cleaning supplies is locked away. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are update and working. The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. There are no bodies of water on the property. The home is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted and in clear view.

At 12:20 PM, LPA reviewed four clients files with Administrator, FM and Director. LPA observed all four clients files to be missing Authorized Representative signatures for Needs and Services Plans, Medical Consent Form and clients' personal rights documents. LPA also observed that all four clients TB Test, Immunization Records and Medical Assessment form were not up to date. At 1:20 PM, LPA reviewed six staff files with Administrator, FM and Director. LPA observed all six staff files to be complete and found no deficiencies. LPA observed all staff files to have the correct up to date documentation and all staff were up to date with their staff training for the year. Per Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards regulations were cited and exit interview was conducted. A Copy of the report and deficiencies were left at the facility.

narrative: On Monday February 28, 2022 at 11:00 AM Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Carolyn Flynn, Helga Wong and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a Office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Community Care Licensing (CCL) met with Executive Director Jason Henderson, Consultant Jeff Rackmil, DHCS Representatives, Sandi Snelgrove and DSS Representative, David Gutierrez. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the Mental Health Status Approval (MHSA) Update, and the required items for permanent licensure for R.E.F.U.G.E. The facility has not submitted their MHPA yet to DHCS and the facilities 24 month expires on April 10, 2022. DHCS provided the facility all required documents for submission. During this meeting the following options were discussed; withdrawal of STRTP application by the program, this would prevent CCL (Community Care Licensing) from taking legal action against the program. The facility was informed that if the program is not able to obtain their Mental Health approval by the date of April 10, 2022 the department will have to take legal action. The facility was also informed that they could withdraw their STRTP application and submit a plan of closure. At this time, the facility will be working on submission and agrees to have a follow-up meeting on 3/9/22 at 11 AM. The meeting was concluded, and a copy of this report will be sent to Executive Director, Jason Henderson.

On Wednesday March 09, 2022 at 11:00 AM Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers (LPM's) Carolyn Flynn, Helga Wong and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a follow-up office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Community Care Licensing (CCL) met with Executive Director Jason Henderson, Consultant Jeff Rackmil, Clinicial Director, Jacqueline Smith, California Alliance, Chris Stoner-Mertz, DHCS Representatives, Pat Coyle, Kelsie Martinez, and DSS Representative, David Gutierrez. The purpose of this meeting was to follow-up on 2/28/22 office meeting regarding the Mental Health Status Approval (MHSA) Update. At this time, the facility submitted there application to DHCS on 3/6/22, and the application is currently under review. Per DHCS current review, the facility did not submit all required documents. Multiple items will be needed and revisions will be required. DHCS will complete their full review by next week 3/15/22, and will send out a notice. Also, will be coordinate a meeting with the provider to discuss all necessary changes. The meeting was concluded and CCL will follow-up with the provider towards the end of the month regarding the MHPA review. In addition, CCL reminded the provider withdrawal of STRTP application by the program, will prevent CCL from taking legal action against the program. The facilities 24 month expires on 4/10/22. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to Executive Director, Jason Henderson for signature.

Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Lisa Schlembach made an unannounced inspection to the above facility on 5/25/2022 at 10:00 AM. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management. LPA’s Belfield and Schlembach met with Administrator who assisted with the visit. During a visit conducted on 4/22/2022 LPA’s met with Sylvia Smith. During that visit a walk though was conducted with staff Issac as part of an annual inspection. During that inspection it was confirmed by staff interviews that incident reports were not being reported to the department. Due to technical issues with LPA Belfield’s computer the forms were not able to be printed and given to the staff. During this inspection LPA discussed with staff that all incident reports have still not been reported regarding the clients in care. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards 87061(j)(1) Reporting Requirements. During the inspection conducted on 4/22/2022 LPA’s Belfield and Schlembach were informed that staff Sylvia Smith is the administrator for Refuge I. LPA Belfield discussed with staff Smith that they would look into the requirements for them to be the administrator as well as the information that CCL had in the system. During a walk through of the facility LPA Belfield and Administrator Smith had a discussion regarding the bedframes being used for the clients. LPA will refer to the regulations for clarification and conduct a follow up with administrator Smith on whether or not the black frames being used should be changed.

During a staff file review it was observed that one staff is not qualified to be the facility manager for the facility. LPA Belfield discussed with administrator Smith regarding applying for an exception request. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards Version 4, Section 87061(j)(1) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to administrator Sylvia Smith.

On July 12, 2022, at 10:45 AM, LPA's George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng, made an unannounced inspection and met with Kurmonie Govan, direct care staff. Upon arrival, we discovered that there was no Facilty Manager nor House Manager present. At 11:17 AM, Silivia Smith (Facility Manager) arrived. Silvia stated that she had to leave for an appointment that could not be cancelled. There is a current census of four clients. Two clients are on AWOL and three clients were present. LPA Karkazis is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065(f) Personnel Requirements. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Silvia Smith, whose signature confirms this receipt.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Karkazis made an unannounced case management inspection at REFUGE on 10-6-22 10:00AM, and met with Sylvia Smith, Administrator. The purpose of this inspection was to discuss the complaint investigation control number 14-CR-20220708100610, dated 07/08/22. LPA Karkazis conducted a walk through inspection of the facility with Sylvia Smith, Administrator. LPA Karkazis observed that the facility was clean and in good repair. On 8/8/2022, Investigator Megan Mullen was interviewing Administrator Sylvia Smith (S1), please refer to LIC 811, 7-12-22, and requested a copy of the incident report and (S1) could not provide a copy of the report within the required timeframe. It took (S1) four days to provide the report. On 8/8/2022, Investigator Megan Mullen requested the client’s file and was not readily accessible. (S1) stated that the client files were located at the facility office and did not have access to the office and could not find anyone who has access. The following deficiencies were cited, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Art. 6, Section 80061(b) Client Records, and Title 22, Division 6, Article 4, Section 80044(c)(c) Inspection Authority. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Sylvia Smith, Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 10-6-22 9:41 AM Licensing Program Analysts Karkazis conducted a complaint investigation with REFUGE and met with Sylvia Smith, Administrator. The purpose of this inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The complaint was taken by Community Care Licensing’s (CCL’s) Investigative Branch (IB)and assigned to investigator Megan Mullen. During the investigation, it was discovered that the alleged staff member had an argument with the client. During the investigation, through document research and confidential interviews with staff and clients, no one made any disclosures regarding observing firearms in the facility or staff talking about firearms. Child and Family Services (CFS) conducted an investigation and were provided with conflicting information.. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff threatened a minor with a firearm while in care. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTATIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Sylvia Smith, Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 1-6-23 2:57PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced follow up inspection at the REFUGE I, and met with Dwayne White, Facility Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Regarding the allegation of staff yelling at minors: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews and documentation research. There was no evidence of staff yelling at minors in document research. Staff and clients interviewed stated that they have never heard staff yelling at clients in a derogatory manner. S1 stated that she speaks in a loud tone regularly and may raise her voice occasionally if clients cannot hear her. LPA interviewed residents of neighboring homes, stated that they have never heard staff yelling at minors. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff are yelling at minors. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. continued on LIC 9099-C

investigation_findings: 13On 3-1-23 3:35PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced inspection to REFUGE and met with Dwayne White, Facility Manager. narrative: On 8-30-23 3:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE to open a complaint dated 8-25-23 #14CR-20230825103959. LPA met with Administrator Dwayne White (DW). While reading the second page of the complaint, LPA observed that C1 (see LIC 811 confidential names list) has their eighteenth birthday tomorrow, 8-31-23. LPA has not received an age exception request letter from REFUGE or the Administrator. DW stated that he was not aware of the regulation that requires a request letter of age exception within 30 days of a client's 18th birthday, which must be sent to CDSS. DW told LPA Karkazis that he was trying to place C1 in REFUGE's Tay Adult Extended Foster Youth Program. DW stated that C1's behavior was poor in the last few weeks and would not recommend C1 for the Tay Adult Extended Foster Youth Program. DW stated that C1 could still apply for the TAY Adult Extended Foster Youth Program, but without a recommendation. DW also stated that C1 could no longer stay at REFUGE after he turns 18 years old, but was trying to find a placement for him, notifying C1's social worker of the situation. The facility is being issued a Technical Violation, 80010(a) Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 02, Limitations of Capacity and Ambulatory Status. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Dwayne White, Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 10-27-23 11:47, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE and met with Arireisea Adanandus, Facility Manager, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that staff handled a foster child in a rough manner, staff do not accord foster child with dignity and respect, staff leave tools accessible to foster children, staff leave cleaning supplies accessible to foster children, and facility is in disrepair. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, representatives, and conducted document research, in which inconsistent information was provided. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Arireisea Adanandus, Facility Manager.

narrative: On 4-24-24 9:15AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Dwayne White, Administrator, and toured the facility inside and out. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 1 staff and 0 clients. Dwayne White informed me that there have been no clients in care for the past 2.5 months at this facility. LPA requested copies of LIC 500,610, and 309. At 9:25AM, LPA Karkazis reviewed staff files, which were complete and in good order. There are no clients in care, therefore no client files were reviewed. At 10:15AM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 105 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 72 which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There are no clients in care, there was not two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication (none) was also stored and locked in the kitchen cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed 1 staff and 0 clients. At 10:30AM, LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time the facility is being cited for National Accreditation ILS 87089(a). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Dwayne White, Administrator.

On 8-28-24 4:34PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE 1. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct interviews. While conducting interviews, LPA Karkazis discovered that a facility manager was not on duty while three clients were present. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personnel Requirements 87065(f). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Kendall Winfrey, Direct Care Counselor, whose signature confirms this receipt.

deficiencies.description:
87065 Personnel Requirements
(f) The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present:
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA's observation, the licensee did not ensure a facility manager was on-site at all times children are present.  This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator agrees to have a training session.  Adminstrator will  ensure that a  Facility Manager will be present in the absence of the Administrator.  Administrator will provide a roster of staff attendance,and  topics discussed,  Administrator will send an updated LIC 500 by 9-13-24.

narrative: On 1-31-25 1:53PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced case management at REFUGE 1 and met with Dwayne White, Administrator. They occurred 9-12-24, 9-16-24, 9-19-24, and 10-6-24. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Continuing requirements, Reporting Requirements 80061(b), Type B. investigation_findings: 13On 1-31-24 1:49PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at REFUGE 1, and met with Dwayne White, Administrator, who helped with the inspection.
